column2: Dr. Benjamin Fine's alarming report in The Times of Nov. 7 on the extent to which Russia is outstripping the United States in training engineers and other technicians will not stampede us, I hope, into a dangerous race.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 12 -- G. M. Syed, leader of the Opposition of eighteen Deputies in the Sind Provincial Assembly of 111 members, was arrested today under the Pakistani Security Act.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France gave up his efforts today to induce the French Socialists to join his Cabinet and revised it without Socialist participation. This step was taken as the Government employes in many services in Paris and throughout France were staging demonstrations for revision of their status and for increased pay on the eve of the Premier's departure for Canada and Washington.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- Trygve Lie, first Secretary General of the United Nations, declared today it would be a "political mistake" to admit Communist China to the world organization at this time.
Eating establishments dedicated to the steak, chop and other American favorites claimed our attention this week.

HAMPTON, Va., Nov. 12 Queen Mother Elizabeth of Britain ended her seventeen-day visit in the United States this afternoon. She left Langley Air force Base in a Canadian Air Force plane, bound for Ottawa.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 12 -- Senator Thomas A. Burke, Democrat of Ohio, will ask the United States Senate to investigate the election count in the Senatorial race he lost to Representative George H. Bender, a spokesman said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Development of the country's atomic weapons program has been unimpaired by the bitter dispute over the Dixon-Yates private power contract, Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss asserted today.

A Democratic Governors' bloc, patterned after tile Republican group that played so influential a role in President Eisenhower's nomination two years ago, appears to be in process of formation. As yet it is nebulous.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 -- Demands that the United Auto Workers will make on the automobile industry next summer were spelled out today by union officials.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 12 -- The nation-wide strike of waterside workers that began last Tuesday will end next Tuesday. Branches of the Waterside Workers Federation will meet in all ports Monday to approve the terms of a resolution unanimously agreed upon by the Emergency Committee of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and representatives of eighteen maritime unions in Sydney today.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The British Government intends to require that future airplane types be submitted to the same test-to-destruction that revealed the fatal weakness in the Comet jet airliner, it was announced today.
The Federal Pacific Electric Company of Newark, manufacturers of electrical equipment, has opened a new plant in Scranton, Pa.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 12 -- Msgr. Fermin Lafitte, Archbishop of Cordoba, accused by President Juan D. Peron of having stirred discontent against the Government, sent a telegram to the President today stating that he always had been loyal to authorities and especially to the President himself.
The Health Department is sending at least four and perhaps as many as ten sound trucks around the city today and tomorrow in the hope of preventing a second week-end of carbon monoxide deaths.

MOSCOW, Nov. 12 -- As a result of integrating their economic plans and production the countries in the Communist camp have achieved an "unprecedented increase" in productive capacity and very large foreign trade gains, it is reported here.
Dr. Albert Schweitzer's speech delivered in Oslo touched me deeply, as I am sure it did thousands of others who were fortunate enough to read major portions of it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- A miscalculation of how quickly Western Europe could unite and a consequent neglect of Asia was declared here today to be America's worst mistake in its regional peace arrangements.

A generous response should be made to the current appeal of the Young Women's Christian Associations of Greater New York for funds to carry on their Program for 1955. The well-rounded program of Y. W. C. A. clubs, classes, health and recreational activities deserves support.
Two babies -- one of them eight and one-half feet tall and the other a foot taller -- were placed on exhibition at the Bronx Zoo yesterday. The babies, of course, are giraffes.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 12 -- The Communist threat to American liberty in the international field poses problems for our national and state governments alike, Judge John J. Parker, Federal Court of Appeals, Fourth Judicial Circuit, declared tonight.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- By the lowest majority Premier Pierre Men- des-France has yet received, the National Assembly gave implicit approval tonight to his policy in French North Africa.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- A $5,000,000 loan has been given to the Agricultural Development Bank in Peru by the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development to help finance imports of farm machinery and livestock.
OTTAWA, Nov. 12 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth arrived in the Canadian capital tonight to renew ties made fifteen years ago on her pre-war visit with the late King George VI.

Alaska, that vast territory for which statehood is perennially debated, is the subject of a history by its Governor, Ernest Gruening. Entitled "The State of Alaska," the volume tells the territory's story from its discovery to the present and discusses its resources and physical conditions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- A General Assembly committee voted unanimously today to refer twenty-one applications for United Nations admission back to the Security Council "for further consideration and positive recommendation."
A bill exempting probation officers in the Magistrates and Domestic Relations Courts from provisions of the Lyons Residence Law was signed yesterday by Mayor Wagner.
DENVER, Nov. 11 -- Time is running short for the planners of the United States Air Force Academy, which must open its doors in July to the first class of 300 cadets.

GENEVA, Nov. 12 -- Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have submitted a proposal to the Geneva trade conference that would authorize countries of West Europe to discriminate against dollar goods for an indefinite period.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Led by Prime Minister Churchill, the Conservatives moved today to take the initiative from the Labor party on the issue of in- creasing old-age pensions.
PARIS, Nov. 12 -- Maggy Rouff emphasizes the hipline on her midseason party frocks in many attractive ways.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Department store sales during the week ended last Saturday were 4 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
On the heaviest volume -- 3,720,000 shares -- since January of 1951, stocks made new twenty-five-year highs yesterday in the fifth successive day of advances.

FOUM TOUB, Algeria, Nov. 11 -- This village, which fell into rebel hands briefly after the outbreak of terrorist agitation in Algeria Nov. 1, is now one of several strong points from which French troops are penetrating the rebel-infested Aures Massif.
TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 12 -- President Eisenhower bagged the Federal limit of four ducks within a half hour this morning. Later he bagged five pheasants.
Directors of the Associated Telephone and Telegraph Company have declared a dividend of $3 a share on the common stock, payable on Dec. 10, bringing the 1954 total to $6 on the present share basis.
DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Many automobile factories are working overtime and on Saturdays to step up assembly volume of 1955 model cars.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 -- Federal Refugee Administration officials met here today with Central West Protestant and Orthodox churchmen to discuss resettlement of 214,000 refugees permitted to enter the United States under the 1953 Immigration Act.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 12 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Superior Court today took under advisement a motion by the state, which is fighting to make a suspension and fine stick against Johnny Bratton, to set aside a lower court decision favoring the boxer.

Foresight and courage have been shown by Traffic Commissioner Wiley in initiating a new study of one-way avenues that might result in a marked modification of the master plan for moving traffic through the city.
RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 12 (AP) -- A simple device that can give a hospital patient in bed the tonic effects of a round of golf is being used to reduce post-operative fatalities.

Ever since Wouter Van Twiller imported materials from Holland and built himself the first brick house in America back in 1633 it has been customary for residents of this island, and sight-seeing visitors, to think of Manhattan as the natural center of anything remarkable in the way of larger, taller and more wonderful buildings.
AN interesting place in contemporary American abstract sculpture is taken by Seymour Lipton, whose recent work is on view at the Betty Parsons Gallery.

Hector Constance, a shifty middleweight from Trinidad in the British West Indies who is fast afoot and sharp with his punches, took a split decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones of Yonkers in the ten-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Fred B. Snite Jr., the infantile paralysis victim who lived for eighteen years and seven months in an iron lung, died today at the age of 44.

CHICAGO, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Michigan won its first title since 1922 and its second in Conference history and Indiana's Jim Lambert took the individual crown today in the fortieth Big Ten cross-country championships.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Spokesmen for the British bicycle and motorcycle industry charged today that American manufacturers were trying to exclude its products from the United States market.

SAIGON, Nov. 12 -- The French light aircraft carrier Bois Belleau arrived here today with several thousand refugees, most of whom earlier in the week were rescued from a sandspit on the coast of South Tonkin.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Army's powerful Black Knights, playing their first game in fourteen years without Coach Earl (Red) Blaik on the bench, are overwhelming favorites to hand Pennsylvania its eighth straight loss of the season tomorrow before 30,000 at Franklin Field.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (AP) -- Rabbi Benjamin Schultz, coordinator of the National Rally for McCarthy, said today it turned out to be "tremendously successful."
The first break in cocoa prices since Nov. 4 occurred yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange, when quotations fell 65 to 95 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 196 contracts.

Bishop Frederick Buckley Newell of the New York Methodist Area has appealed for voluntary contributions tomorrow to restore or replace Methodist churches and Methodist-related institutions damaged or demolished in the recent war in South Korea.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 12 -- D. N. Aidit, secretary general of the Indonesian Communist party, told a plenary session of the Central Committee today that the party would continue to "fully support" Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo's Cabinet.

PARIS, Nov. 12 -- As the consequence of a pair of official diplomatic visits the United States is about to be faced squarely with two specific problems of coexistence. These involve intricate relationships in both Europe and Asia between Communist nations and the democracies.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 12 -- Forty thousand Vietnamese refugees of the Indochina war will be evacuated direct to South Vietnam instead of first being shifted from the northeastern provinces to camps in the interior of Thailand, it was disclosed today.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 12 -- India's Vice President pleaded today for greater tolerance in ideas and more genuine freedom of thought and speech in an address before the general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

Events today: Little Orchestra Society Young People's Concert, Hunter College, 11 A. M.; Natalie Hinderas pianist, Town Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Dorothy White, singer and pianist, Brooklyn Academy, 3; "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; and the Philharmonic - Symphony, Franco Autori conducting, Norman Carol, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 - Following is an unofficial translation excerpts from an address today by Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Soviet delegate, to the Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly:
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 12 -- A Yugoslav delegation will go to Moscow soon to negotiate a formal trade treaty with the Soviet Union.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 12 -- The possibility of a new turn in South Vietnam's political situation was foreshadowed today when Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, Chief of Staff of the armed forces, indicated that he might soon leave for France.
The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies began yesterday a drive to find families to board 300 boys and girls during the coming year.
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Nov. 12 -- The Sikorsky S-59 helicopter, the world's first turborotor aircraft, completed its initial testing today.

Vaclav Nelhybel, Czech-born composer who is music director of Radio Free Europe in Munich, Germany, has received first prize in a one-act opera contest sponsored by the Bernard Ravitch Music Foundation, 370 Fort Washington Avenue, the foundation has announced.

The Cities Service Company and subsidiaries reported yesterday a net income of $30,911,053 for the first nine months of this year. This is equal to $7.95 a common share, and compares with a net of $37,715,444, or $9.70 a share, in the nine months to Sept. 30, 1953.

Jack Resnick, realty investor, has purchased the seventy-two-family garden-type apartment colony which occupies a two-acre site at 43 Calton Avenue in the Wykagyl section of New Rochelle, N. Y. Calman Rossel of New York was the broker in the sale.
HONG KONG, Nov. 12 -- The Hanoi radio charged today that South Vietnam's Government had "forced or induced" a "number" of Vietnamese Roman Catholics to leave Vietminh-controlled territory.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Operation of the Christopher Street ferry across the Hudson will end Dec. 20, after sixty-eight years of continuous service. The line is a victim of modern motor travel.

The entry of Fly Wheel and Cold Command will carry the silks of C. V. Whitney in the $75,000 added Gallant Fox Handicap at Jamaica today. Actually, the entry is a triple one, with the 3-year-old Fisherman listed with his stablemates, but Trainer Sylvester Veitch will scratch the 3-year-old this morning.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 12 -- A report on the Korean negotiations at the Geneva conference last summer was made public today by fifteen of the sixteen members of the United Nations who fought in Korea.
TOKYO, Nov. 12 -- The leaders of the Progressive party, Japan's second largest conservative political group, decided today to throw their full weight behind the move to form a new right-wing party.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission said today four interstate pipeline companies had asked for wholesale natural gas rate increases totaling $3,958,000 annually.
GUATEMALA, Nov. 12 -- Negotiations for a new contract between Government and the United Fruit Company got underway yesterday, President Carlos Castillo Armas said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- Senator John C. Stennis, a member of the Senate's special censure committee, denounced Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for allegedly continuing abuse of the Senate and for pouring "slush and slime" on it.

The building containing twenty-two apartments and five stores at 1463 Vyse Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by David Kaplan to a client of Arthur Rosenfeld, lawyer. The property is assessed at $50,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $30,000 through Wishnow Horowitz, brokers.

For half a day yesterday eight leading drivers found themselves eligible to drive at Yonkers Raceway last night despite suspensions of six months each meted out to them by the State Harness Racing Commissioner, George P. Monaghan.

Milton Kabinoff, 33 years old, of 2142 East Sixty-third Street, Brooklyn, died last night in a fire in the garage-office of the New Way Transport Company, 5 Roebling Street, in the Williamsburg section. He operated the concern with his brother.

A fundamental disagreement in political and economic philosophy -- one that has divided free Europe into rival camps crossing national boundaries -- has been dramatized by the decision of Jean Monnet to retire as chairman of the High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community.

LONDON, Nov. 12 -- The British Government is to introduce legislation revising the disciplinary codes of the army and air force under which soldiers and airmen would be executed for mutiny only in its more serious forms.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 12 -- The three minority parties in the Government coalition delayed today the Cabinet's approval of the Saar agreement with France. This approval is required before all the Paris agreements may be submitted to the two houses of Parliament for ratification.

WHEELING, W. Va., Nov. 12 (AP) -- Minority shareholders renewed their fight today to at least delay transfer of the physical assets of the Follansbee Steel Corporation to Frederick W. Richmond, financier.

When Scandinavian Airlines System, Inc., begins tomorrow the first regularly scheduled transpolar passenger flights between the United States and Europe, a new instrument will be used to navigate in the vicinity of the North Pole.

Zeller's, Ltd., which operates a chain of specialty - department stores in Canada, has called a special meeting of stockholders Nov. 22 to authorize issuance of $5,000,000 of 4 1/2 per cent cumulative redeemable preferred stock. Walter P. Zeller, president, said the new issue would provide capital for expansion and to redeem existing preferred stock.
LONDON, Nov. 12 -- Prime Minister Churchill paid his annual visit tonight to his old school, Harrow, where he received the grounding in his mastery of the English language.

The history of medallic art from the Roman era to the present day is represented in the redecorated west exhibition hall that the American Numismatic Society will open formally today at a membership meeting.

DETROIT, Nov. 12 (AP) -- A Detroit attorney who served four months for criminal contempt for his court-room conduct in the 1949 New York trial of eleven top Communists was publicly reprimanded today by a panel of three Michigan Circuit Court judges.
Reference is made to a letter by Cooper D. Ponton appearing Nov. 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 12 -- The growing importance of filmed television to Hollywood actors, and their concern over the smog situation, which is hampering outdoor filming, were made clear tonight by reports presented at the annual general membership meeting of the Screen Actor's Guild.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 12 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Utah Republican, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy on these counts against him:

The coming holidays -- both Thanksgiving and Christmas -- are providing thematic material for scores of dealers taking part in the Thirty-ninth Eastern States Antiques Fair, which opens Monday at the Westchester County Center at White Plains.

THESE fifteen American folk tales, pleasantly illustrated with black-and-white sketches, have their roots in cultures of both the Old World and the New. All have been found in little-known sources, and many have been adapted or retold for children.
A benign but shrewd nonconformist clergyman, the Rev. James Butterworth, has returned to London from a trip to the United States with gifts of about 5,000 ($14,000).
WASHINGTON -- All over the country ferryboat crossings are being replaced with bridges of shining steel and enduring concrete, or are just being abandoned, leaving stubs of old roads ending nowhere.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The University of Southern California kept its slate clean in Pacific Coast Football Conference play today by defeating Washington, 41 -- 0, before 36,108 fans. Aramis Dandoy returned the opening kick-off 95 yards for a touchdown.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Just as Premier Mendes-France was about to start for North America this week, in the full tide of a prestige gained while turning his back on a European union of the federal type, the principal advocate and designer of this kind of union decided the time had come to make a fight in its defense.

Potato prices will fall sharply during the first six months of next year unless the present situation changes radically. Warehouses are receiving large consignments and the consumer will benefit when these stocks are unloaded on the market.

HAD Martin de Porres been born white his wealthy Castilian father might not have abandoned his family. Children on the streets would not have jeered, "You don't belong" nor would his Negro mother have beat him with cries of, "I did not want you."

DETROIT, Nov. 13 -- Almost unanimous support of demands for a guaranteed annual wage, higher pay and larger pensions was voted today by the 1,100 delegates to the two-day conference of the United Automobile Workers, C. I. O.

THE God-fearing citizens of seventeenth-century Boston worked hard on convicted pirate Cormac O'Shaugnessey Doyle in the expectation of an edifying testament of sin and repentance. What they got, in this adventure yarn by the author of "The Tamarack Tree," was a picaroon's unrepentant tale of rum, romance and rebellion, with providential meetings and escapes enough to shake any belief in the predestinate salvation of only the just.
LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 13 -- Ohio State's Buckeyes nailed down at least a tie for the Big Ten football championship and probably a Rose Bowl trip today by defeating Purdue, 28 -- 6.

WHAT to do when the child asks; "Daddy, why is the sky blue?" The reply is easy: "Ask your mother." Or, if one's mood is frivolous: "Because the angels painted it that way" or "It just looks blue because you're looking at it through blue eyes."

EMORY COOK, whose recordings of music from the standard repertory have been impressive in the height of their fidelity, has added a new wing to his catalogue. Road Recordings is the title he has chosen for it, and the reason for the name is that the disks of the series are to be confined to material found in the course of knocking about the world.

WITH remarkable speed, Michael Straight, editor of The New Republic, has written a vivid and penetrating book about the Army-McCarthy hearings. For fifteen chapters, Mr. Straight's book is mainly good color reporting and interpretation -- not neutral, of course, but with a forthright, unconcealed crusading partisanship.

READING "Flying Is My Life" by Hanna Reitsch is like making a flight in a jet. The beginning of the book -- which is about the author's adventures as a young girl learning to be a glider pilot -- is smooth, gentle and quiet.

Miss Frances Coleman will give a luncheon on Wednesday in her home at 4 East Sixty-seventh Street for a group of women serving with her in behalf of the card party and tea for the benefit of the American Women's Unit for War Relief, Inc.

FORT WORTH, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The University of Texas showed the power expected of it all season today, ripping out three tremendous fourth quarter touchdowns to nose out Texas Christian, 35 to 34, in a thrilling offensive duel.

WAKE FOREST, N. C., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Duke's football team staved off Wake Forest's strong challenge in the fourth period to triumph 28 -- 21, today and take another step along the path the Blue Devils hope will lead to the Orange Bowl.
DETROIT, Nov. 13 -- The carriage trade still likes its limousines painted black. But the colors on the new model automobiles now appearing in dealers' showrooms across the country run the spectrum.

One of the most unusual labor-management agreements ever negotiated was disclosed yesterday by David Dubinsky, president of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union A. F. L. It was a pact with a major New York garment manufacturer who promised to pay the union $250,000 over a four-year period to neutralize the saving in labor costs he derives from operating two of his shops on a nonunion basis in the South.

JOSE LIMON will be the first artist to receive State Department support under the new International Exchange Program, which is being administered by the American National Theatre and Academy. As its title indicates, the project is designed to help familiarize other countries with our art forms, to balance as far as feasible the apparent ease with which other countries manage to familiarize us with theirs.
George L. Smith, president and treasurer of G. R. Kinney Shoe Company, has been elected a director of the Federation Bank and Trust Company.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Nov. 13 -- John F. Simms Jr., hardworking 37-year-old New Mexico Governor-elect, is not making any mighty predictions of what he is going to do in the next two years, but he has plenty of solid ideas.
Thank you for printing that column of praise to the cat -- "Felis Regina" (Nov. 7).
What happened in Wall Street last week is probably best indicated by the fact that each day was better than the previous one in the averages.
NEWARK, Del., Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Delaware Blue Hens swept to a 41-7 football victory over the Lafayette Leopards today with Delaware's right halfback, Jim Flynn, scoring 17 points.

NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Prospect Point, the famed observation site at Niagara Falls, was reopened today after repairs made necessary by the rockslide July 28. Spectators can again stand within a foot of the American Falls.

A circular reminding physicians how to recognize the early symptoms of carbon monoxide poisoning is being sent to 500 doctors who give part of their time to the maternal and child health services of the city's Department of Health.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- In a laboratory shadowed by Colorado's Flatiron Mountains, the Government is secretly exploring a world where temperaturse are close to "absolute zero." There, tough steel turns brittle, rubber loses its elasticity and a kind of liquid helium runs straight up.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy accused Senator Arthur Watkins, Republican of Utah, of "most unusual, cowardly" conduct and told a cheering crowd of birthday greeters tonight that he would seek re-election.

Members of the Mary Washington Colonial Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution have arranged a reception, musicale and tea for the afternoon of Nov. 22 in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane. The occasion will mark the fifty-eighth anniversary of the founding of the chapter, of which Miss Marguerite Dawson Winant is regent.

WE have always been interested in our revolution, not merely because of its paramount importance to the United States, but also because it is increasingly apparent that it was one of the most momentous happenings of modern times and continues to influence the course of history.
LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13 -- Nebraska's Governor-elect, Victor E. Anderson of Lincoln, has turned down all speaking engagements while he "bones up" for the job he takes over in January.
The Chicago Black Hawks kept the New York Rangers in the hockey doldrums at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 11,260 watched, the Hawks triumphed, 5 -- 3.
BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- Boston has found 500 additional parking spaces in time for the Christmas shopping season.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 13 -- The free exploitation of petroleum in Brazil was urged today in the Chamber of Deputies by Campos Vergal, Deputy from Sao Paulo.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida of Japan began his return trip to Tokyo this afternoon bearing an agreement with the United States providing his Government with $100,000,000 worth of this country's surplus farm commodities.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 13 -- The Federal Reserve Bank's recently initiated index for department store sales in the Eighth Federal Reserve District shows an improvement for the month of October over a year ago, despite the fact that the dollar volume this year was 1 per cent less.

TONY and Little John walked away from their homes one day while their mothers were busy with the housework and taking care of the babies. The boys visited a large grocery store, a barber shop, a pet store, watched a steam shovel and had a lively visit at the fire station.

A SUPREMELY gay picture book this, and thankfully not a whimsical one. Obviously the author-illustrator is in sympathy with the child-mind, and has observed kindergarten artists expressing themselves in great splashes of primary colors.

The Ursinus College football team scored three touchdowns in the second half yesterday to defeat Brooklyn College, 19 -- 9, on the Brooklyn field. It was the Kingsmen's fifth setback of the season and their twenty-fifth consecutive game without a victory.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 13 -- Treaties granting sovereignty to West Germany and incorporating its 500,000-man army into the West's defense force are to be sent to the Senate Monday by President Eisenhower.
A battle is raging among beverage producers to create preference for their particular products on the part of drinkers in the United States.

SACRED cows, cherished shibboleths, and accepted "truisms" are never sacrosanct to the good historian. Samuel Eliot Morison, a good historian who has shown his independence of judgment in his past work, now demonstrates it again in this volume -- the ninth in his fourteen-volume history of the Navy's operations in World War II.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 13 (AP) -- "Eisenhower is still a popular President and Senator Joseph McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, did not stand well in the public mind," the University of Michigan's Survey and Research Center said today in a report on an October national political sampling.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The British open champion, Peter Thomson, scored a six-stroke victory over the Australian open titleholder, Ossie Pickworth, and Kel Nagel in the $3,360 Ampol golf tournament today.

MADRID, Nov. 13 -- The Roman Catholic magazine Ecclesia announced today that Enrique Cardinal Pla y Deniel, Primate of Spain, had "accepted the resignation" of the Rev. Jesus Iribarren, the magazine's editor in chief for the last twelve years.
A major revision of the traditional Jewish marriage contract was announced yesterday by the leaders of Conservative Judaism in this country.

A YEAR ago Random House began a new series of books for readers of 11 and up, the World Landmarks. Readers were introduced to such fascinating persons as Alexander the Great, Marco Polo, King Arthur, and Joan of Arc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- This morning's headlines illustrate a serious national problem. They are dominated once more by McCarthy, by Dixon-Yates, and by the petty dissensions of state and national politics.

OLD Lisette lived in a clearing in the forest with the company of one rooster and six hens, seven ducks, eight rabbits and one goat outside the house and two cats and a dog inside. When Lisette went to the village to shop, on her seventy-sixth birthday, all these animals prepared a party for her return, with a number of entertainments and surprises.

The interview with Walter Bedell Smith quotes him as saying that it was never the intention of the United States Government to unify Korea by force of arms. It is shocking to learn that he should entertain this widely accepted misconception.

THIS year's winter national championship tournament of the American Contract Bridge League will be played in Atlanta, Ga., beginning Nov. 27 and lasting through Dec. 5. The big contests are the open pair championship, to be played in four sessions over the Dec. 4-5 week-end, and the national team-of-four tournament with match-point scoring, to be played on four days from Nov. 29 through Dec. 2.

The Smith College Club of New York has issued invitations for its annual theatre party for the benefit of the club's scholarship fund. The Dec. 22 performance of "Fanny," starring Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak, at the Majestic Theatre, has been chosen for the benefit.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Albert J. Hayes, president of the International Association of Machinists, A. F. L., cautioned organized labor today against using "lunatic fringe" tactics in fighting subversion.

AS NOBODY will be surprised to learn, the New York City Ballet has further extended its current engagement in "The Nutcracker" at the City Center through Sunday, Dec. 19. This will make a total of seven weeks.

MAGGIE loved to flaunt tradition. At her debut, she carried red roses instead of white ones, and she had wanted to keep her engagement a secret. When she fell in love with a young mining engineer, she was happy to turn her back on the gay whirl of San Francisco in the Nineties and follow him to the hinterlands of Mexico.

The Jan. 31 performance of "The Desperate Hours" has been chosen for the annual theatre benefit of the Rehearsal Club. The play, starring Karl Malden and featuring Nancy Coleman, an alumna of the club, opens Jan. 26.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Lehigh spoiled Carnegie Tech's hopes for an undefeated and untied season today by holding the Tartans to a 13-13 deadlock in the last game of the year for Tech.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- The dynamic trio of Tommy Bell, Pete Vann and Don Holleder led Army's football team in a 35-0 rout of Pennsylvania before 34,477 spectators at Franklin Field today.

MINOU, a cat who speaks French, and Andy, a little boy who speaks English, explore Paris together, meeting and greeting a diversity of Parisian characters, including a butcher, a fisherman, a waiter and "children of all sizes, shapes and colors."

WEARY parents who find the bedtime-story hour the longest part of the day will welcome these seven brief tales of the animal world. Each story requires only five minutes for reading aloud and contains the simple but important moral that "it's best to follow mother's ad vice."

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 13 -- One of the reasons that department store sales in the twin cities have been running well above the national average for months is disclosed in a special survey just completed by the Minnesota Employment Service.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 13 -- Navy let Columbia have it with all batteries today. Rolling up a record yardage total of 629 yards and using every able-bodied player on the squad, the midshipmen crushed the Lions, 51 to 6.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Rhode Island's 87-year-old Theodore Francis Green, newly re-elected to a fourth consecutive term, likes to think about becoming the first 100-year-old Senator.

JUMPING off from a title reminiscent of Sinclair Lewis and Hamlin Garland, Lewis Atherton presents what may be called a social history of the Middle Western small town from the Eighteen Sixties to the present.

MEDIEVAL legend pictured Charlemagne as a gigantic hero whose active life extended far beyond the span of years usually allotted to man. This legendary Charlemagne undoubtedly sprang from the overwhelming awe with which his contemporaries and their descendants viewed his accomplishments.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 11 -- Jorge Prat, Chile's Finance Minister, who likes to be described as a "hard-money man," recently outlined a series of financial measures that he says will restore sanity to the republic's economy within two years.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., Nov. 13 -- Rebounding in superb fashion after yielding a first-quarter score, the Hill School's football team turned back its time-honored foe, Lawrenceville School, 13 to 7, in the forty-ninth clash between the schools on Dell Field today.

DURING the last twelve years of his life, a choleric, middle-aged, stout man toiled to write an apologia for his efforts as a British general in the War of the American Revolution. That disgruntled warrior was Sir Henry Clinton and the product of his long labor, now published in full for the first time, is an event of top-drawer importance for anyone interested in the history of the period.
Columbia University has prepared a detailed study of its proposed arts center. In its tentative form, the project is to include a professional repertory theatre, it was disclosed yesterday.
The influence of the Jewish Bible upon American history was emphasized by Rabbi Elias L. Solomon yesterday as having promoted the spirit of freedom.

EAGERLY young Squanto sailed away from his Patuxet village on the great English boat to visit the land of the White Men. The friendly Indian's long years in a strange complex world make a true story well suited for Clyde Robert Bulla's distinctive, simple, direct style.

EVANSTON, Ill., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Florian Helinski threw three passes in the last minutes of the game today to set up the tying touchdown and then calmly kicked the winning point as Indiana beat Northwestern, 14 to 13, before 28,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- With a straight party-line vote, the Joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy cleared the Dixon-Yates private power contract today.

Because Eric Guerin, the stable's regular jockey, was under suspension for causing traffic trouble in a race on Thursday, Ovie Scurlock got the opportunity to ride Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's Social Outcast in the $87,650 Gallant Fox Handicap at Jamaica yesterday.

THAT perennially popping-up question of how to put opera on the screen -- assuming that such an achievement is passionately to be desired -- was given two positive answers in these purlieus last week, and there isn't much doubt as to which answer -- which method -- this viewer would choose.

THIS story is spun around a famous "Bishop's Menie," which is an ancient treasure belonging to a family believed to be extinct, and the search for the cause of the death of Quinn Anders' half brother, Stark Anders.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- In a bid to forestall ratification of the Paris agreements for the arming of West Germany, the Soviet Union issued formal invitations today for an all-European security conference. It would be held in Moscow or Paris on Nov. 29.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is fighting a desperate battle with curious tactics for ultimate objectives that are remarkably unclear.

Given excellent shopping weather in the week ended yesterday, New York City's department stores were able to top the volume of an excellent week in 1953 by a few percentage points, merchants reported. They did this in spite of the fact that Veterans' Day promotions came on a Thursday, which is a good shopping day anyway.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Justice Department officials said today that Attorney General Herbert Brownell Jr. had set in motion the machinery for the first grant of immunity to be sought under the immunity statute adopted by Congress in August.

EXCEPT for Eddie Chapman, nobody can be absolutely sure. A couple of things are certain, though: Eddie started out as a safecracker. He had once been kicked out of the Coldstream Guards. And when the war started in 1939 he was serving a sentence in Jersey Prison, on the Channel Isles just off the coast of France.

LOU, aged 10, flies alone for a month's visit with his cousin in another state and takes his 'cello along. The landing gear of the plane gets stuck just at the wrong time and, while the pilot is working to loosen it, Lou avoids a panic among the passengers by giving them a concert.

Out in the woods and brush patches, safely remote from casual passers-by, the bittersweet dangles its clustered berries, their orange husks now open and the still brighter orange pods within now vivid with November. They are like autumn flowers in the leaf-crisp evening of the year, brighter than the haw of the wild rose, far more generous than the lacquer-drop berries of their creeper neighbors, the partridge berry.

WALTER TERRY, dance critic of The New York Herald Tribune combines skillfully the biographies of great ballerinas with the high points in the history of the ballet. Each dancer is placed in time and mention is made of the ballets in which she appeared. Then, with deceptive ease, Mr. Terry slips in a golden thread of ballet information.

This Persian Gulf port, home of the world's largest oil refinery, is awakening, as these pictures show. After three and a half years of virtual shutdown -- the result of a British boycott following ex-Premier Mohammed Mossadegh's nationalization of the oil industry -- foreign ships are once more inching up the muddy, shark-infested Shatt al Arab, Abadan's river, getting in line for oil.

THESE two ballet books are original, informative and authoritative. Though both are written for serious students of the ballet, they will repay even the casual reader. Both books assume that the student will use them only as texts to supplement lessons with a good teacher.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., Nov. 13 (AP) -- An unbeaten and untied Trinity College football team, held at a 7-7 deadock for three periods, scored three times in the final quarter today to defeat Wesleyan, 26 -- 14. It was the final game of the season for the traditional rivals.

SKILLFULLY re-creating Stephen Foster's era and background, Mrs. Douty shows how his songs grew out of the friendships and experiences of his youth. In this well-balanced and frequently moving narrative she indicates his weaknesses without detracting from the wistful charm of the man whose songs have become a deeply rooted part of American life.

"IT'S only a book for children." "To start with something easy I thought I should write a book for children." "It's only a little fairy tale that anyone could write." Most people believe things like that; I believed them myself until I came to try to write books for children.
Producers of home laundry appliances this fall are pulling rapidly out of an eight-month slump, according to W. H. Reeve.

One of the more curious surprises of the Eisenhower Administration, now approaching its half-way mark, is the extent to which the continued demilitarization of the military has taken place under a soldier-President.

FOR more than half a century Philadelphia's Commercial Museum has performed friendly services as a clearing house for world trade, extending a helpful hand across oceans, between cultures and industries.
PIERRE, S. D., Nov. 13 -- Joe J. Foss, Republican Governor-elect of South Dakota, does not expect to make any radical changes when he takes office Jan. 4.

Persons interested actively in the American Library in Paris, Inc., have arranged a concert for the night of Nov. 30 at Carnegie Hall for the benefit of the library. The artists at the forthcoming concert will be Zino Francescatti, violinist; Robert Casadesus, pianist, and Daniel Guilet of the Guilet Quartet. Mrs. William B. Olmsted Jr. is American representative of the American Library in Paris, Inc.

SENECA FALLS, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., this week announced completion of new facilities at it's television picture tube plant here. The additions will make possible the production of 25,000 more large-size, aluminized picture tubes a month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Two of Washington's more unusual visitors -- Jewish cave dwellers from Tripolitania who lately moved to Israel -- presented a handwoven rug to Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower this week as a birthday present.
A LOT of water has passed under the bridge since Esther Williams splashed her way to movie fame. And I was there when it started flowing.

MONTROSE, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- A group of parents in School District 3, which includes most of the suburban area of the town of Cortlandt, are waging an aggressive campaign to put over the approval of a twenty-eight-room school.

THE protagonist of this second novel by Gordon Merrick, who also wrote "The Strumpet Wind," is an early American settler of the Cote d'Azur who also becomes, in the dizziness of time, a solid citizen of the fast and frantic international set.

BRIDGEHAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 13 -- The note, scribbled on a deposit slip, said, "I don't know who is responsible for the flower arrangements in this bank, but they are especially appreciated by one who is more accustomed to the impersonal atmosphere of metropolitan banks."

JENNIFER CALDERON dreads the prospect of spending a year in Cuba with the family of her dead father. They are strangers, and only the fact that her grandmother's imperious summons comes at a time when Jennifer's mother must go away for a long rest makes her accept the invitation.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 13 -- The "road that couldn't be built" -- eighty-eight miles of straight highway through the roughest mountain terrain east of the Rockies -- has just been completed to provide a new gateway to the South.

THREE well-known horticultural firms in New Jersey will play host on Wednesday to members of the Horticultural Society of New York, Inc., and their guests. The pilgrimage is planned so that the visitors may enjoy the Thanksgiving and pre-Christmas display of plants growing in the greenhouses.

SYRACUSE, Nov. 13 -- Syracuse toppled Colgate from the ranks of unbeaten teams today, winning, 31 -- 12, in the fifty-fifth game of their football rivalry. A gathering of 37,000 jammed Archbold Stadium and paid in excess of $110,000 for the largest gate in the history of Syracuse football.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 -- Retail sales in this metropolitan area shot up 17 per cent last week, with the greatest rise in the suburban sections, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia reported. Part of the gain, however, was laid to the fact that a heavy snowstorm had curtailed sales in the corresponding week of 1953.

SET in the days of King Solomon, this tale centers on a boy whose desire to help his mother almost costs him his life. Captured and sold into slavery, Jared escapes from Solomon's mines and throws himself on the mercy of that great and just ruler.
BONN, Nov. 13 -- The West German Government is approaching the problem of creating the half-million-man military establishment sanctioned by the Paris agreements with a certain amount of trepidation.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Kings Point rallied for two touchdowns in the third period and a 13-12 victory over King's College of Pennsylvania today.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Once-beaten Wichita displayed dazzling speed in the backfield today to upset Cincinnati, the nation's 17th ranked team, 13 -- 0, and broke a 16-game Bearcat winning streak extending over two seasons.

NOT so long ago it was difficult to find books on more than a minority of the topics American children were yearning to hear about. Nowadays, when publishers have seized upon the "series" idea, the cornucopia is overflowing, and the puzzle is: How are we to pick and choose among titles and series of titles?

TO see Thornton Wilder's "The Matchmaker" at the Edinburgh Festival and again at its West End opening at the Haymarket Theatre has been like watching a sprinter make two attempts to run the 100-yard dash in 10 seconds.
"WHAT is human speaks. What is not human may produce various noises, but not true speech." That is the basis of Mario Pei's approach to language.

THE story of the orchestra, formerly the N. B. C. Symphony, disbanded by the National Broadcasting Company after its final concert with Toscanini last April, now reorganized bly itself as the Symphony of the Air, is a dramatic one.
THIS is a wonderful book even for kids who don't usually like mystery books.

I THINK this was a good book. This baffling mystery, asks you how $13,000 could have been stolen out of the school safe*. The money was raised by a fair. Ted Wilford, who was editor of the school paper and school correspondent for a weekly paper was in charge of selling tickets when he got involed in the case.

STATE and national tourist offices and winter vacation communities from California to the Dolomites will be among the exhibitors at the International Winter Sports Show at Madison Square Garden Saturday to Nov. 28.

THIS much-needed Thanksgiving picture book tells the story of one family during their first year in the Plymouth Colony. Among the passengers on the Mayflower were the Hopkins children: Giles. Constance, Damaris and Oceanus -- the baby brother born on shipboard.

INDUSTRIAL production has begun to reflect the pick-up in retail trade, introduction of new automobile models, and a reduced pace of inventory curtailment. The $64 question is whether the upward trend is seasonal or whether it will continue well into 1955.
UNION, N. J., Nov. 13 -- Nearly 20,000 customers of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company in this area will start "going to school" by telephone soon to learn how to use their new dial service.

BOHEMIA, L. I., Nov. 13 -- This community of 2,000 persons, which was founded in 1855 by settlers from Czechoslovakia, is making elaborate plans for its centennial celebration next year. While the village now includes many persons of non-Czech descent, the year-long observance undoubtedly will have many features of old-country flavor.

SHELBYVILLE, Del., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Too many chickens and too few buyers -- that's why the poultry industry is in "a very depressed condition," according to James P. Winchester 3d, manager of the Eastern Shore Poultry Growers Exchange.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 13 -- The Indonesian Government, apparently chafing at Red China's delay before opening talks on the controversial double citizenship issue, has submitted to Parliament draft legislation declaring that dual nationality will not be recognized in Indonesia.

PEOPLE are frequently of the opinion that "abstract" and "realistic" art are totally opposed in concept and execution whereas the real difference between them is one of degree and not of kind. True enough, in each direction there are extremes, post-card art at one end and, at the other, pure form (Mondrian) or pure expression (Pollock).

Borough President John Cashmore appealed to Brooklyn residents yesterday to join him at a hearing tomorrow to protest proposed cuts in Brooklyn service. The hearing will be held in the Board of Education auditorium, 110 Livingston Street, at 10:30 A. M.

HONG KONG, Nov. 13 -- Premier Yoshida's proposal for a $4,000,000,000 a year economic aid program has resurrected the vision of a "Marshall Plan for the Far East." In the past such a vision has paralleled various hopes for a defense alliance on the Western Europe pattern in the Pacific.
EDESSA, Greece, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The first phase of the vast electrification program conceived in United States aid plans for Greece is nearing completion.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 13 -- Communist China's pledge to India and Burma of noninterference in the affairs of neighboring states definitely bars "encouragement or help" by Peiping to subversive Communist movements in other Asian countries, India's Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, declared today.

Columbia University is offering a newly created program of East European studies, financed by a $250,000 grant from the Carnegie Corporation. The program will encompass all of Eastern Europe except Finland and Greece. The studies are planned to continue for a minimum of seven years.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 13 -- Many American teachers are afraid to teach controversial issues, Dr. Martin Essex, superintendent of schools of Lakewood, Ohio, declared here today. As a result, he said, much of the teaching is in danger of becoming sterile, dull and meaningless.

A LONDON vicarage in the slums is the setting for Noel Streatfeild's latest "Shoes" book. From the very first page we are immediately in that house, sharing the Bells' fun and tribulations. With no money for necessities, Paul dreams of being a doctor, Jane a ballet dancer.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 13 -- The level of economic activity in the Twelfth District showed no substantial over-all change from August to September Moderate improvement in output and employment in some industrial lines, however, added a firmer tone to the general business situation than has been true in recent months.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 -- General business in New England is on the upgrade. The improvement in recent weeks, while spotty and moderate, has been none the less unmistakable. Metal working plants and machine shops have been receiving larger orders and have been stepping up production.

LUMMOX was an octopod, six-ton, talking creature who was the very special pet of John Thomas Stuart XI of Westville, Planet Earth. One day, waiting for John and his friend Betty to fly home from school, Lummie began eating the neighbor's rosebushes.

NEWARK, Nov. 13 -- Republican hopes of salvaging at least one of six important offices in Essex County, which were lost to Democrats in the recent election, were pinned today on a recount of the vote.

HARTFORD, Nov. 13 -- Gov.-Elect Abraham A. Ribicoff, who defeated Gov. John Davis Lodge by 3,115 votes, announced this week that he would start State budget hearings Nov. 29, when he returned from a vacation.

"Nucleocytoplasmic Interchange in Oocytes" is not the kind of title that is likely to lure the average reader into a scientific paper. But it is an arresting title scientifically nevertheless -- one that was given by Prof. Arthur W. Pollister and his Columbia colleagues, Mark Gettner and Robert Ward, to a paper read at last week's meeting of the National Academy of Sciences.

HAVANA, Nov. 9 -- The plague of flies and bad odors around the bay of Havana, about which United States tourists have complained for many years, should disappear within the next few months. The Government thinks it has the answer in a ninety-nine year concession it has granted to a private company to make compost out of all garbage collected daily in this capital city.

IN homespun and buckskin, a score of Hollywood actors have been ranging up and down hills and rivers of the Bluegrass State for the last couple of months gorging CinemaScope color cameras on some incredibly lush scenery for Hecht-Lancaster's "The Kentuckian," in which burly Burt Lancaster is making a stormy debut as a director and is co-starring with Diana Lynn and Dianne Foster.

IN its essence, Mr. Bemelmans' narrative is a winning one. It recounts the change of heart effected in a pompous government official by some Tyrolean villagers -- in particular, a mountain family of poachers, the Amrainers.

IN an age of conformity Thad Snow is a militant individualist. He has been called everything from the "Cottonfield Confucius" to "Swampeast Missouri Devil," but whatever the sobriquet he has borne up under it with shocking aplomb.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 13 -- Governor General Ghulam Mohammed accused the "foreign press" yesterday of publishing "strangely colored versions" of "recent constitutional events in Pakistan."
DES MOINES, Iowa, Nov. 13 -- Union organization of thirty-five of the forty-seven Polk County deputy sheriffs was the center of a dispute here today.

THE third in the adventures of David "Lucky" Starr is Paul French's best juvenile science fiction book to date. Crackling with suspense, lit by humor, sparkling with complexities of plot, and alive with interest, it is a tasty deep-sea dish for every reader who is young at heart.

ROCQUENCOURT, France, Nov. 13 -- Battle-ready forces and their equipment will get a greatly increased share of the defense spending of the North Atlantic alliance in the next two years if the recommendations of the military experts are followed.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- United States diplomatic authorities brushed aside today the Soviet Union's proposal for an all-European security meeting as an insincere gesture and a propaganda appeal.

IN fields, woods and gardens, activity is at fever pitch as countless small animals prepare for winter. Though true Indian summer is yet to come and gardeners may not see these animals at work, speed is the order of the day. Insulated living

IN this sequel to his Newbery-Award book, "Rabbit Hill," Robert Lawson presents again the entertaining animal community of a Connecticut countryside. Old Uncle Analdas, the patriarch of the previous book, opens this one with a prediction: "It's goin' to be a tough winter and needn't nobody bother to deny it."
Mrs. Robert M. Ready, 26-year-old daughter-in-law of a vice president of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, jumped or fell to her death shortly after 8 o'clock last night from the seventh floor of the hotel.

Five of North America's leading naturalists and lecturers will present their wild life motion picture films in color here, with accompanying narrations, on Nov. 22 under the auspices of the National Audubon Society.

A LARGE assortment of awards ranging from council fellowships to monthly club competition winners was distributed at the Seventeenth Annual Awards Dinner of the Metropolitan Camera Club Council held last week.
Averell Harriman's margin over Senator Irving M. Ives in the voting for Governor rose to 12,137 yesterday with the completion of the official canvass in Saratoga County.
Passage of the Revenue Act of 1954 in August whipped up a debate that is still raging over its liberalization of the short-sale rule regarding "put options."
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Sigma Delta Chi, national journalistc fraternity holding its annual convention here, today elected Alden G. Waite of Los Angeles, Calif., president.

PHILATELY, according to Robert E. Fellers, director of philately in the Post Office Department, is a large and profitable business for the Government. In an interview last month Mr. Fellers said that 12,000,000 or more avid stamp collectors spend about $15,000,000 a year to buy ordinary and commemorative stamps from the Department's Philatelic Agency and from post offices.

THE Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences and the Library of Congress have joined forces in a project that appears destined to wrest valuable, historic and heretofore irreplaceable film incunabula from the ravages of time.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The second stringer scored in handsome fashion for the stable of Ada L. Rice in the rich Marguerite Stakes today at Pimlico as Proud Pomp closed with a gallant bid to post a nose victory over Barclay Stable's Reddy Ro.

I enjoyed Louis H. Bean's analysis of why voters vote the way they do -- "The Head, the Heart or the Pocketbook?" (Oct. 31). For those interested in mentally or physically indexing what they read, may I state that I have filed Mr. Bean's study under the heading of psephology.

Pablo is a fun-loving Tarascan Indian boy who lives in Mexico. More than anything else, Pablo longs for a man-style hat but somehow he is always getting into trouble. He knows he must stop his foolishness and prove he is man enough to wear one.
Margaret Mead, anthropologist and author, will be the speaker at the Barnard College conference on "Working with a Liberal Arts Degree" to be held Dec. 1.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 13 -- It was stated in official quarters here today that Gen. Nguyen Van Vi, Deputy Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese National Army, would become acting chief on the departure of Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh next week for France.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 13 -- Premier Adnan Menderes has in effect assured India that the Turkish-Pakistani Treaty has no aggressive intent and is designed solely to strengthen the defense of the Middle East.

AFTER his long winter nap William Woodchuck awoke to a great surprise. Percy the skunk, Potter the opossum and Jackson the rabbit presented him with a whole day's feast, on condition that he would eat it in bed.

Among the outstanding art events in another crowded week of exhibitions is the show of French eighteenth century paintings opening at the Wildenstein Galleries Tuesday, organized by the Minneapolis Institute of Art. The exhibition is touring for the benefit of the institute's education program; it includes masterpieces from a dozen American museums.

ALTHOUGH most of the gardener's feathered friends have already started their wintertime vacations, there are a host of others who prefer to brave it in the cold and stay around. And it is these "stay arounds" that the thoughtful gardener will not forget.

JIM STANLEY, 18-year-old student who dreams of the stars, is selected to help build the most rigidly kept secret on Earth: the first Space Station. Then America's political enemies discover the truth. Immediately, a series of disasters strikes Space Station Number One.

GENEVA, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Hobart scored in the first and third quarters today to complete its first perfect football season with a 13-6 victory over Alfred. The triumph was Hobart's eighth this season and twelfth in a row over a two-year period.

PERHAPS "Quadrille" should be regarded as a partnership of three actors. For Noel Coward, the author, is also an actor who once appeared with the Lunts and knows exactly the sort of thing they can do to perfection.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Florida bounced back from last week's defeat to down Tennessee, 14 to 0, today. A substitute quarterback, Dick Allen, passed for both touchdowns and added the extra points.

ON the surface, this story is simple. It tells how six Dutch children went on a quest for a wagon wheel so that storks would come once again to the roofs of their windswept fishing village. But the children discover much more than a wheel for the storks to nest on; they discover how to wonder and how to do, they learn to understand others and also themselves; they gain perseverance, patience and generosity.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- A possibility that the McCarthy censure resolution would be toned down before it came to a vote in the Senate was kept alive at the Capitol today.

ORHAN is a likely little citizen who lives in a Turkish country village and tends the family sheep. Orhan was such a good shepherd all summer that his father rewarded him with a fine journey. Together they went by autobus to see Ankara, their capital.

AMHERST, Mass., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Amherst won its third consecutive Little Three football crown today by downing Williams, 21-14, as Quarterback Bob Kisiel scored the winning touchdown on a 3-yard sneak on the last play of the third quarter and then bucked over for the extra point.

IN a year marked by a near-famine of good American first novels of crime and suspense, Clinton Seeley's STORM FEAR (Holt, $3.50) is a pleasant discovery -- not precisely a mystery novel (though with strong elements of mystery), but a tale of terror presented with economy, insight and a surprising amount of technical skill.
A group of young men and women who formerly were doomed to lives of idleness and hopelessness because of mental retardation are now helping to earn their own living.

The National Association of Travel Organizations voted unanimously last week to urge Congress to eliminate the 10 per cent Federal tax on transportation. Another resolution proposed steps to stimulate foreign travel to this country.

As savings-and-loan men tell it, this will be a banner week for their industry. Total assets of the nation's savings and loan associations, according to their records, will pass the $30,000,000,000 mark, thereby establishing a comfortable lead over the 138-year-old mutual savings banks.

ACTH is a hormone which comes from the pituitary gland and causes the adrenal glands to produce cortisone. Both ACTH and cortisone have been used since 1949 in the treatment of numerous diseases, among them rheumatoid arthritis and bronchial asthma.

BLOOMINGTON, Ind., Nov. 13 -- Seven thousand American almanacs, dating from 1696, the second largest collection in the United States, has been acquired by the Indiana University libraries, Dr. Robert A. Miller, library director, said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- J. Edgar Hoover, director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said tonight colleges and universities "all too often" had converted American youths into Communists.

QUEBEC, Nov. 8 -- The trend in Canadian commercial aviation seems to be more business with rising costs, J. R. Baldwin, Deputy Transport Minister said at the twentieth annual Air Industries and Transport Association convention here this week.

EACH year we pass through a calendar of events known as the sports seasons. From April to October baseball reigns supreme on the sportscasts and sports pages, at times even successfully competing for front-page headlines. Long before the world series contestants are decided, college football squads are off to their training camps.

YOUNG Sir Robert Wakefield, in the autumn of 1596, lived a chill life with his three aunts in the great gray house in Suffolk. A spaniel puppy arrived which Aunt Isabella said would be disposed of and, in no time at all, Robin, as he was called, had set off with the puppy and a pillowcase full of necessities.

THOSE readers who know the novels of D. E. Stevenson will be glad to learn a new one has come along. Of no great import, but with pithy little observations to tie it down, the book tells the story of a headmistress of a fashionable girls' school near London.

DJUNA, a young detective, is all set to have a wonderful time with his friend, Bobby Herrick, when up pops a mystery! Of course, he still has a wonderful time but it is considerably more hectic. Single-handed he solves the mystery in a few days and entangles the villain in a herring net. * * *

May I protest in Mr. Bean's generally excellent political analysis his suggestion that prejudices are inherited? He writes of "grandfather's genes;" and, "the head, applying * * * also to those who vote on the basis of their prejudice, acquired or hereditary."

BEHIND the silken curtains of three plate glass windows in a building on Gorki Street, Moscow's equivalent of Fifth Avenue, are two neat, bright rooms with small tables, chairs and lamps. At the end of one room is a bronze statue of Josef Stalin depicted as if sitting at a writing desk.

Holy Cross beat Fordham's football team, 20 -- 19, in a struggle of passes, penalties and points-after-touchdowns at the Polo Grounds yesterday. The Crusaders suffered more from the penalties, losing 100 yards for thirteen infractions, but they had the better tossers, the better catchers and a surer kicker.

I HAVE tried to imagine some class or group among the American people who can afford to do without this book, and I have not succeeded. For Justice William O. Douglas' "An Almanac of Liberty" -- the best book of our time to "proclaim liberty throughout the land unto all the inhabitants thereof" -- presents the birthright of freedom that belongs to every one of us.
OXFORD, Ohio, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The Dayton Flyers, sparked by the passing of Kenny Bockenstette, rallied today to upset perviously undefeated Miami, 20-12.

ANY adult reader who suspects (no child reader has this suspicion) that Walter Brooks may let his Freddy stories degenerate into the stereotype of "series" books has only to read each new one, and at once be reassured.

BOSTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Boston College and Boston University matched fourth period touchdowns today but Boston College won an upset 7-6 victory when the Terriers failed to convert the point after touchdown. A crowd of 40,542 saw the game.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 13 -- Notre Dame riddled North Carolina with crisply efficient blocking and tackling today before 55,410 for a 42-to-13 triumph, the sixth in seven games for the Irish this season.

IT has always appeared to me that there are hundreds and hundreds of children's books I know nothing about, and they shape up in some sort of indiscriminate lump. It is difficult to find a critic of children's books because, though each child is a critic, no critic is a child.

FIVE weeks ago, one hundred miles off the coast of Norway, a seventy-ton fin whale was spotted by the watch of a swift diesel-powered catcher. When the small ship came within fifty yards of the whale, the gunner at the bow sighted down the end of the sixty-millimeter Svend Foyn gun and shot a six-foot, two - hundred - pound harpoon into the whale forward of the dorsal fin.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Quarterback Pete Kohut engineered a fourth - period touchdown today to give favored Brown a 21-21 tie with Harvard in their fifty - third Ivy League game at Harvard Stadium.
A TRAVEL industry-wide campaign to encourage travel to and within the United States by citizens of other countries and to make it easier for them to enter this country appears to be in the making.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Two Air Force officers have parachuted safely from a record height of more than eight and one-half miles in test jumps from a B-47 jet bomber.

ONE of aviation's greatest advances will be made this week when Scandinavian Airlines System, Inc., starts scheduled passenger service between the West Coast and northern Europe via the Arctic. The company's four-engined airliners will begin tomorrow twice-weekly direct flights between Los Angeles and Copenhagen, flying the Great Circle route over Canada, Greenland and the north Atlantic, a route the airline considers the only truly new one of importance opened up during the past 1,000 years.

A one-alarm blaze that produced a lot of smoke but not much fire drew a crowd last night of Greenwich Village visitors and thirty-five firemen to a seven-story factory loft building at 53 East Eighth Street.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The nation's biggest steel producer -- intent on keeping one of its best customers happy -- is increasing its use of inland water routes to cut shipping costs on oil country goods.

HONORABLY descended from Louisa May Alcott, from Booth Tarkington, from Mark Twain, the young adult novel is still a comparative newcomer to the world of fiction, and it might as well be admitted that the newcomer has not been greeted with unqualified pleasure.

MILAN, Italy, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Charles Humez of France won the European middleweight championship tonight with a third-round technical knockout over the Italian titleholder, Tiberio Mitri. Humez weighed 159 pounds, Mitri 158 3/4.

EL MUCHACHO was not like a giant in a fairy story and he was not like a giant in the circus. For one thing he was only 8 years old, and his disposition was altogether pleasant. For another, he was bigger than the biggest circus giant who ever lived.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The National Labor Relations Board announced today it would enforce all previously issued orders in unfair labor practice cases even though the cases did not come under the board's new jurisdiction standards.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Muhlenberg came up With three last-period touchdowns today to rout Franklin and Marshall, 33 -- 6, in the final game of the season for the Mules.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 13 -- Royce Flippin today scored a personal triumph in the Bowl comparable to that of Albie Booth against Army twenty-five years ago. Flippin led Princeton to a stunning 21-14 victory over a Yale team that fumbled away opportunity after opportunity.
OTTAWA, Nov. 13 -- Crowds in a holiday mood poured into the heart of the Canadian capital today to greet Queen Mother Elizabeth.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- The organization called For America announced today that forty-three prominent men and women "from both [major] political parties" have accepted membership on its national policy committee.

In one of the closest finishes in the meet's history, Marty Williams of Morris edged Larry Twomey of Jackson by less than a foot to capture the individual title in the Public Schools Athletic League city-wide cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx.

READERS of Astrid Lindgren's earlier "Bill Bergson, Master Detective," will need no introduction to Bill's habit of combining a day dream of super-detection with active participation in the rough-and-ready affairs of his village gang.

THREE separate first books of poems are issued in this single experimental volume. A. good idea, publishing costs considered, but the accident of co-publication should not force comparisons upon these poets. Each clearly deserves a hearing.
TORONTO, Nov. 13 -- A lighthouse keeper on a lonely Lake Superier island has been imprisoned since Friday morning by a 900-Pound moose he raised from infancy.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 -- It is obviously a matter of great pride and a source of great confidence for the Soviet Union these days that it is no longer a single Communist country standing alone in a capitalist world, but is the leader of a coalition that embraces the greater part of the Eurasian continent.

The New York Giants have a glowing opportunity to take undisputed possession of first place in the National Football League's Eastern Conference today. They meet the Philadelphia Eagles, with whom they are tied for the lead, at the Polo Grounds. The kick-off time is 2:05 P. M.

The annual parish fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Resurrection, to be named Town Fair, will begin next Saturday at 11 A. M. in the parish hall of the church, 115 East Seventy-fourth Street.

MOSCOW, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note to France proposing an all-European conference. Similar notes were sent to the Governments of twenty-two other European countries, with copies to the United States and Communist China.

WITH "Sunset and Evening Star" Sean O'Casey completes his autobiography. The six-volume series began fifteen years ago with his valiant and lovely impressions of childhood, "I Knock at the Door." In that book "Johnny Casside," as the chief character was then named, innocently entered the slum world of Dublin.

A tour of two homes and an office to view private art collections, and a visit to the Sculpture Center at 167 East Sixty-ninth Street will be conducted next Tuesday for the benefit of the scholarship fund of the Greenwich House Music School.

CHARLESTON, S. C. -- Florida-bound tourists will find it worth while to pause a bit in South Carolina instead of dashing through. Charleston alone is worth a visit of several days -- or months. For those traveling inland, Camden, Aiken and other lesser known towns are worth examining.

Mr. Parrott's article on Tokyo was very interesting. Having spent a short, though memorable, vacation in Tokyo this summer, I am not qualified to criticize the city so lucidly as he does; however, there is a side of Tokyo which Mr. Parrott omits.

IN view of the quality of current Broadway drama, a condition of vertigo-induced deafness, as hastily and unscientifically diagnosed by Miss Tallulah Bankhead in your section last week, would be merciful indeed. An unhurried check by my doctor (graduate specialist's degree in eye, ear, nose and throat: pre-war Vienna) reveals my hearing shipshape.

WHEN Mother came out into the yard to find Andy, he slipped quietly round the apple tree and followed close behind her. Then began a delightful game, with Andy hiding and Mother looking for him in such strange places as her sewing box, the cupboard shelf and the waste basket.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 8 -- The number of tourists entering Mexico through Nuevo Laredo, the principal port of entry for North American tourists, dropped sharply in October.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Former Gov. Elbert N. Carvel of Delaware and Archibald S. Alexander, New Jersey State Treasurer, were added today to the list of those being considered for the chairmanship of the Democratic National Committee.
The Little Orchestra Society opened its seventh season of young people's concerts yesterday morning in the Hunter College Assembly Hall before an audience of 2,000.
CAIRO, Nov. 13 -- Egypt today recalled her Ambassador to Syria, Maj. Gen. Ali Naguib, brother of President Mohammed Naguib, for the stated purpose of consultations.

LAKELAND, Fla. -- Central Florida is the golf course and lake area. For the tourist it begins at about Winter Park and Orlando and runs southwest to this city and Lake Wales' Bok Singing Tower. Three excellent U. S. highways -- 27, 17 and 98 -- serve this vast stretch, and there are good connecting county and state roads.

Lindesay Parrott's report on Tokyo -- "A New Birth for the 'City of Disaster'" (Oct. 31) -- brought back memories of my stay in Japan shortly after the end of World War II. The noise so blatant in Tokyo is noticed not only by foreigners but also by the Japanese themselves.

EARL WARREN, 57, CHIEF JUSTICE. Former Attorney General of California he served as Governor for eleven years before his appointment to the Court by President Eisenhower in 1953. He was Republican candidate for Vice President on the ticket headed by Dewey in 1948, and was instrumental in the pro-Eisenhower movement in the 1952 G. O. P. convention.

THE ABC book said "B is for Bear -- an animal brave who lives in a cave." But when Beady, a wind-up toy bear, tries to live according to the book, he quickly discovers it takes more than a cave to satisfy him.

EVERY so often a discovery of antique photographic plates signed "Brady, N. Y." is made and the name Mathew Brady reappears in the papers. Who was this man with the power to make news even though he has been dead for fifty-nine years?

Things are definitely looking up for the long-dejected zinc industry. Shipments to domestic customers are higher than they have been since early 1952. Government stockpiling is contributing additional volume. The smelters' top-heavy accumulation of unsold metal is diminishing rapidly.
TORONTO, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Charles Dennehy Jr., a 22-year-old rider from Chicago, tonight won the international team puissance for the United States at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- James Andrew Wright, one of nine Negroes convicted in the celebrated "Scottsboro case" in Alabama a generation ago, was arrested today on a charge of second-degree assault.

BELDON CRAIG was a man of sea and woods. Through his tender love for Florence ran his insistence that she come to terms with Alaska's wilderness, Florence continually retreated to the safety of her neat house When she agreed, at last, to go hunting, she refused to dress sensibly because it was "unladylike."
Despite shady practices by some dealers and manufacturers, the aluminum combination storm Window and door business is not being warped to any great extent.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 13 -- The Citizens Committee to Save Mettler's Woods, still $30,000 short of its $75,000 goal needed to buy the area, has renewed its campaign with the help of sportsmen.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- The gates of Alcatraz closed recently -- but only for a day -- behind a slender blonde.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The Rev. Pablo Gottardi, Roman Catholic parish priest at Villa Maria in Cordoba Province, was arrested by police tonight on charges of "spreading unfounded and alarming rumors."

FRENCH Premier Pierre Mendes-France arrives in America this week as the salesman of a new France and of himself as its leader. For six days this economist-turned-statesman who, in his five months in office, has baffled, irritated and impressed the world's diplomats, and who promises something like a political and economic revolution at home, will submit himself to the scrutiny of the American public.

An increase in acreage allotments on cotton is expected to be among the first matters to be considered by the new Congress when it convenes in January. With so much dissatisfaction over the farm measure enacted by the last Congress, an attempt also may be made to enact an entirely new agricultural law.
