IN the summer of 1863, a year before Hawthorne's death at the age of 60, his publisher, Fields, arranged for the serialization of Hawthorne's unfinished romance -- later to be entitled "Doctor Grimshawe's Secret" -- in the Atlantic Monthly.

LONDON, Nov. 13 -- An improbable and inaccurate report made nearly fifteen years ago by a German diplomat who has since died catapulted the curiously changeless figure of the Duke of Windsor back into the headlines this week.

TAKE YOUR CHOICE. By Maurice Walsh. 187 pp. Philadelphia and New York: J. B. Lippincott Company. $3. IN these new tales the prolific Irish novelist Maurice Walsh continues the romantic tradition. This tradition, as all who saw the movie John Ford made out of Walsh's story "The Quiet Man" well know, exploits Ireland's beautiful scenery, charming people, irresponsible individuality, and gift of broguish speech.

PAUL BROWN, the moody genius who coaches the Cleveland Browns, is so sparing with his superlatives that amazed gasps followed the Statement he made after the Philadelphia Eagles had routed his Browns in the opening game.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 13 (Reuters) -- Clark Gregory, director of the United States Foreign Operations Mission in Jordan, said today a $200,000,000 economic development plan had been approved by the Jordan Development Board and submitted to the Jordanian Council of Ministers for signature.

BEDFORD, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Whining jet fighter planes and ceaselessly rotating radar antennas are symbols of the super-secret continental defense research project that is being undertaken at this mushrooming air force base, twenty miles from Boston.

WHETHER his medium be song or words without music, Burl Ives is a born storyteller. In both ballad and story, his is the cracker-barrel style of pure, simple narrative in colloquial language. He tells his stories as he sings them; he introduces them as he introduces his songs, Listen:

THE drawings on this page are taken from the ten children's books (published in 1954) named as outstanding, from the point of view of illustration, by a special art jury. The judges were Victor D'Amico, Director of the Department of Education, Museum of Modern Art; Catherine Crask, Librarian of the Junior Museum, Metropolitan Museum of Art; and Aline Saarinen, associate art critic of this newspaper.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Oklahoma struck twice through the air today and rolled on to a 34-13 triumph over Missouri in a Big Seven Conference football game. The victory assured the Sooners a share in their seventh straight Conference title and knocked the losing Tigers out of a chance to go to the Orange Bowl.

THIS peripatetic interviewer has always wondered about the problems of collaboration faced by a husband and wife team -- and the curiosity, finally, prompted a call upon Margaret and John Kieran. They are the authors of "John James Audubon" (Book Review, Nov. 7), one of the new Landmark Books.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 13 -- The Director General of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization called on the agency's General Conference here today to give him wider powers to dismiss members of his staff who are considered security risks.

A new chapter in the history of conservation has been written in the last few weeks with the strenuous and successful efforts to save from the logger's axe the last significant remnant of the virgin stands of bald cypress that only two or three generations ago covered thousands of square miles of the Southern States.

An interesting program was played in an interesting manner by Natalie Hinderas, who gave a Town Hall debut recital Saturday afternoon. There were many agreeable things about her work. She has imagination and personality, obviously a fine musical background, and a technique in good functioning order.

OF the eight pages of photographs in this book, one is devoted to Leonardo da Vinci's paintings and drawings and seven to sketches of his inventions. Moreover, the book jacket states that particular emphasis is placed on his scientific discoveries and inventions. No doubt this is what the author intended, but instead her book is a diffuse mixture of fact and fiction concerning Leonardo's scientific and artistic achievements.

CORE FOR THE WEEK: Finish fall planting except for trees as soon as possible. It is far more difficult to set out spring-flowering bulbs and even rose bushes once the ground has been frozen. Thereafter even on a sunny day the ground is cold and wet.

YONKERS, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Trustful Hanover won the feature pace at Yonkers Raceway tonight, beating, Adio Abe and Merle Rose, who finished second and third, respectively. The winner was timed in 2:06 and returned $4.80 for $2.

The Society of Naval Architects and Marine Engineers can be expected to open full-scale attacks on the apathy of the American public toward shipping if the organization follows the lead of its new president, Earle W. Mills.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 13 -- With all negotiations suspended indefinitely, observers today held out little hope for settlement of the department store strike before its first anniversary. The strike of twelve American Federation of Labor unions will be a year old Nov. 27.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Nov. 13 -- Revision of State laws to conform with the Supreme Court mandate ending segregation in public schools will be one of the major problems facing Oklahoma's next Legislature when it convenes in January, Governor-elect Raymond Gary believes.

The Great Soviet Encyclopedia has identified a 51-year-old Russian physicist, Igor V. Kurchatov, as having been one of the major scientific directors of the mammoth effort that led to Soviet success in mastering the secrets of the atomic nucleus.

ROBERT MONTGOMERY has quite a project on his hands in his current two-part production on N. B. C. of "The Hunchback of Notre Dame." Any similarity between Channel 4 and Victor Hugo is a little hard to find.
KNOWN the world over for his essays, novels and biographies, Stefan Zweig was one of the most widely read modern authors. He was also one of the last great humanists of our time.

SAUGUS, Mass. -- The newest tourist attraction in Massachusetts is the Saugus Iron Works Restoration, a $1,500,000 project recently completed and dedicated with the inspiration and financial support of the American Iron and Steel Institute.

A QUIET sentence opens Sir Edward Spears' front-row autobiographical chronicle of World War II: "The story begins with a luncheon at Chartwell on Aug. 1, 1939." As appropriately, this review could begin with a luncheon at Grosse Pointe, Mich. in August, 1941.

ONE of these first-hand accounts of the emergent post-war Germany is written from within, the other from without. Both are by women. One is a trapped Berliner, noting in freighted daily records the horror of violation, hunger and swift-learned expediency.

LINCOLN, Neb., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Pitt used a 40-yard run by Chuck Cost and a one-handed pass interception and 30-yard return by center Ed Bose today to trim Nebraska, 21-7, before 40,000 homecoming fans.
State and municipal governments are no longer occupying a back seat in the market for new capital.

TRENTON, Nov. 13 -- The New Jersey Legislature, ending a three-month recess, will reconvene its 1954 session here tomorrow. Awaiting its action are a number of important measures, some of them highly controversial.

COLLEGE PARK, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Ronnie Waller got his hands on the ball only eight times today and twice he went on spine tingling touchdown runs and 61 and 51 yards to carry Maryland to a 16-0 football victory over Clemson and closer to the Orange Bowl.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- Dealing with friends in opposing camps -- the Arab States and Israel -- the United States has encountered in the Near East one of its most vexing and challenging problems of foreign policy.
OUR only child, Johnny, a trifle older than 4, started to school, play school, this fall.

BOSTON. A MODEST, pleasant, youngish man with ruddy hair and an affable manner, the English director, Hugh Hunt, has a wide and varied background of experience. He directed the Abbey Theatre company in Dublin for four years during the regime of the great and contentious poet, William Butler Yeats.
NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 13 -- Traffic policemen in this area will be relieved when the New York State Thruway runs right through Orange County without stopping.
A badly splintered Queens Democratic organization proved unable yesterday to pick a successor to James A. Roe as county leader and postponed the decision for a month.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 13 -- Several hundred of the nation's top speedboat pilots, owners, regatta officials and yacht club flag officers convened today at the Hotel Roosevelt for the opening of the fifty-first annual week-end meeting and election of the American Power Boat Association.
A vegetable store proprietor, who temporarily hid $2,000 in a garbage can, was down in the dumps in more ways than one for an hour last night.

Many debutantes of this season, who are also provisional members of the New York Junior League, will be the guests of honor at the sixth annual Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League to be held on Nov. 24 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Favored Wisconsin exploded for three touchdowns in the final period today to hand Illinois its fifth straight Big Ten defeat, 27 -- 14.

FARMINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 13 -- One man was killed today and fifteen others who were trapped underground were believed dead after a rumbling explosion followed by fire ripped through the big No. 9 mine of the Jamison Coal and Coke Company near here.

Over the narrow strip of water separating the northernmost Japanese island of Hokkaido from the southernmost of the Russian-held Kurile group, there took place last Sunday another in the long string of East-West air incidents. Two Russian MIG's attacked and shot down an American B-29 conducting a routine photo-reconnaissance mission.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, said today that the Soviet Embassy here had directed the establishment of Communist spy rings in "every part of the Government" and within the United Nations.
HAMBURG, Germany, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Hamburg's Blohm Voss yards, once the backbone of Germany's shipbuilding industry, will soon be back in production after nearly a decade of idleness.
Three persons were killed and seven others, including a baby, were seriously injured last night in two separate automobile accidents in Queens and Staten Island.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 13 -- Permission of the Federal Power Commission to study two Snake River areas with the view of establishing hydroelectric dams has been asked by the Pacific Northwest Power Company, a group of four privately owned utilities.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 13 (UP) -- Former Persident Truman returned a compliment from President Eisenhower today.

DEBORAH SANFORD resents her family's decision to operate a newly inherited Nantucket inn because it interferes with her own summer plans and those of the boy who fills her thoughts. She does her part of the work but is finally forced to come to grips with the results of her own self-centered aims.
A contest in juvenile speed and artistry highlighted the opening session of the Audubon Society's fiftieth annual convention yesterday at the New York Historical Society.

Expansion of trade and overseas investment is now one of the most vital -- and difficult -- problems confronting the United States and other free nations. Removal of barriers to trade expansion could open a new age of peace and mutual economic gain.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 13 (AP) -- Former President Truman became a Kentucky Colonel tonight at the annual Veterans Day reunion of the field artillery battery that he commanded as captain in World War I.
TRENTON, Nov. 13 (AP) -- The New Jersey Department of Conservation and Economic Development has announced $929,000 in coast protection projects in shore communities.

The City College alumni association has named Dr. Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research, to receive the college's 1954 John H. Finley Medal for "significant service to the City of New York."

WE are informed by the title page that this is "The Autobiography of the North American Matador." Patricia McCormick is a 24-year-old Texan who has been fighting calves and half-grown bulls in Mexican bullrings, employing the regular techniques of the corrida de toros and getting her share of cornadas y dinero -- the wounds and money which accrue to toreros.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 13 (AP) -- C. F. Colwell had no aspirations to be a hero in the first place.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Sunday, Nov. 14 -- The progress of the counting in the New Zealand election yesterday shows that the National (Conservative) party Government received a decided setback. The party will retain office but with a majority of six compared with twenty in the last Parliament.

THE wide-screen principle will be brought within reach of the average amateur movie maker when New Eye Vistascope lens is made available tomorrow simultaneously in thirty-three cities throughout the country.

PROFESSOR of Business Administration of the Harvard Business School, J. D. Glover has set himself an ambitious task, only part of which is accomplished. And this is a pity, for in the area of his greatest competence his observations are judicious and wise and only too tantalizingly brief.

National attention was focused on the adult education program last week when 1,500 community leaders, university extension directors and educational specialists from all parts of the country gathered in Chicago to attend the annual conference of the Adult Education Association.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 13 -- Getting the jump in the opening minutes, Andover's eleven powered its way to a 31-6 triumph over Exeter before 9,000 at Brothers Field today. It was an impressive triumph, the home team dominating the play throughout.

HIGHTSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 13 (AP) -- Fire started by the collision of an automobile and a tractor trailer early today killed a man and destroyed 272 sacks of United States mail intended for South Jersey points.

The Sun Oil Company tanker Bidwell, which has done little more exciting than carry oil for thirty-one years, finished off her 500th trip in the company's service last week and took a few minutes out to take a bow.
PARIS, Nov. 13 -- Premier Mendes-France left by plane tonight for a ten-day visit to Canada and the United States that will be more social than diplomatic but a combination of both.

A BRITISH subject, and a Protestant, A. P. Ryan writes on Ireland's history with compassion, understanding and often with wit. The first half of his book traces Irish history from its earliest known pagan days and its Christianization by the somewhat shadowy St. Patrick on through its centuries of struggle and suffering under British occupation.

ATLANTA, Ga., Nov. 13 -- Department store sales in the Southeast are continuing to climb, with dollar volume last week substantially exceeding that in the corresponding period of last year. Trade for the year to date also has edged above levels of the similar 1953 period.

Four thousand years old and still full of savor, cheese has yet to catch on in this country as a common cooking ingredient. We think of it in sandwiches, with pasta, in an occasional souffle -- and then dismiss from culinary consideration this concentrated form of milk.

Brooks Atkinson's article, "The Theatre Is Not the Thing" (Oct. 31), was both interesting and astonishing for its peculiar logic. Obviously Mr. Atkinson is of the opinion that a theatre that is comfortable and attractive can be just as disconcerting to the audience, as a row full of squirming children with fists clutching bags of popcorn.

The dismissal of John Paton Davies from the Foreign Service has implications for the public welfare that not all private persons are in a position to appreciate. One who after thirteen years has now resigned from the State Department (of his own accord, on good terms with its Administration and not under a cloud) may be permitted some comment on it.

CASSIAR, B. C., Nov. 13 (Canadian Press) -- An asbestos mine is being carved out of a mountainside at the 6,000-foot level near this British Columbia settlement, about sixty miles south of the Yukon border.

IT is an overnight flight from New York to the Lesser Antilles, that chain of small islands extending down the eastern edge of the Caribbean from Puerto Rico to South America. The islands are tropical, the pace of life leisurely and, best of all, the natives far outnumber the tourists.

By choosing a Governor and an Attorney General of opposing parties the voters of New York have made possible a continuous conflict within the executive branch of the state Government for the next four years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 -- There is general agreement on Capitol Hill today that the Atomic Energy Commission has lost a large measure of its Olympian prestige. Informed Republicans and Democrats both feel that the confidence formerly placed in the agency has been weakened by internal political friction that has grown to serious proportions.

FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 13 -- Southern Methodist University knocked Arkansas out of the nation's unbeaten ranks and out of the Southwest Conference leadership today by defeating the Razorbacks, 21 to 14.

ANANSI and Br'er Rabbit both trace their ancestry to Africa, but whereas Br'er Rabbit grew up in the southern part of the United States, Anansi became the folk hero of the Caribbean. When all went well, Anansi was a man; when danger arose, he became a spider, safe in his web on the ceiling.

TO her list of distinguished books for children, Ruth Sawyer adds this modern fairy tale about a young queen and her prince consort who find happiness in a cottage by the sea. Elizabeth's queenly duties leave her no time to indulge her secret longing to cook; and Prince Michael almost never has a chance to tinker with automobiles.

Advanced styling, increased horsepower, longer bodies and three-tone color combinations are among features of the 1955 Dodge cars presented yesterday by the Dodge division of Chrysler Corporation. Prices on city delivery are expected to be announced on Wednesday when the cars will go on display in dealer showrooms here.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 13 -- Yugoslav leaders have rejected, for the time being, serious discussion of Italy's entering the Balkan alliance. Italy is known to desire membership in this Yugoslav - Greek - Turkish grouping.
ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- Governor Dewey telephoned Averell Harriman today to invite the Democratic Governor-elect to send a representative to budget hearings opening here Monday.

WHEN Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield announced early in the year that the lavender 47-cent denomination in the new regular series would be given first-day sale at the Nov. 19 opening of the National Postage Stamp Show in New York, he happily provided a theme for this year's edition, the sixth, of the philatelic exhibitions sponsored by the American Stamp Dealers' Association.

Plans have meen made for the marriage of Miss Georgiana Wetherill Lewis, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence J. Lewis Jr. of Haverford, Pa., to Robert D. Lilien, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Lilien of New York, which will take place Feb. 4 in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Redeemer, Bryn Mawr, Pa. The Rev. Dr. Thorne Sparkman will perform the ceremony.

ALBANY, Nov. 13 -- The apparent victory of Averell Harriman in the neck-and-neck race for the Governorship presages a 1955 legislative session that will be radically different from the pattern set by the Dewey Administration over the last dozen years.
A member of the Westchester County Parkway Police was suspended late yesterday on bribery charges linking him to the police "courtesy card" traffic scandal.

MERANO, Italy -- One of the few winter resorts which offer a combination of skiing and sun-bathing in mild winter temperatures is at last creeping out of its post-war doldrums and once again is welcoming winter sports enthusiasts to a new, ultra-modern hotel.
Cardinal Spellman yesterday blessed and dedicated the $1,000,000 Cardinal Spellman Building for Specialty Medical Services of St. Clare's General Hospital, 411-13 West Fifty-first Street.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa. ,Nov. 13 (AP) -- Lenny Moore, the second leading ground gainer in the nation, scored two touchdowns and gained 171 yards in the best day of his gridiron career as Penn State crushed Rutgers, 37 -- 14, today before 15,200 at Bever Field.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 13 (UP) -- Jack George's field goal in the final two seconds gave the Philadelphia Warriors an 87-86 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers tonight in their National Basketball Association home opener before 4,983 fans.

The scholar is, of course, absent-minded, and easily loses Philip. When Philip finally floats down into the professor's hand just as rain begins to fall, he (or it) has not even been missed.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 13 -- Watching the Sheppard murder trial, now starting its fourth week here, one would almost conclude that this courtroom drama has been produced for the benefit of the press, radio and television.

PARIS, Nov. 13 -- The ordinary Parisian agrees with Premier Pierre Mendes-France that something ought to be done about alcoholism in France, but he is a good deal more cynical than the Premier about what the Government can do.

READERS of Hazel Wilson's earlier books will not be surprised to learn that this one lives up to its title and is "more fun." In eight chapters, each one of which is a complete and satisfactory unit, Herbert's adventures -- whether with a singing mouse or shoes that light campfires -- invariably bubble with unpretentious fantasy and good slap-stick humor.
VIENNA, Nov. 13 -- A new obstacle is halting an effort by Austria to reach agreement on indemnification of Jewish victims of nazism before Chancellor Julius Raab's forthcoming visit to Washington.

KANSAS CITY, Nov. 13 -- A return of warm weather recently was credited with the slackening off in retail distribution after more than two months of consistent gains over last year. In the Tenth Federal reserve District, comprising seven states, department store sales in October ran 10 per cent ahead of a year ago and September's gain was 6 per cent.

ELIZABETH, N. J., Nov. 13 -- A collection of old phonographs, paintings and photostatic copies of historical documents depicting the early history of this city is on display at the Elizabeth Public Library.
SINGAPORE, Nov. 9 -- Steady progress is being made with plans to open here next fall the first Chinese university in Southeast Asia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 13 (UP) -- The police followed their noses to the master bedroom of a $20,000 brick home in a quiet residential section of the Capital today and found a cheerfully bubbling copper still that had been turning out about eighty-five gallons of corn whiskey a day.

Jefferson evened its season's record at three victories and three defeats by beating Adams, 25 -- 6, in a Public Schools Athletic League contest at Wilson Field, Queens, yesterday. Jerry Kershenbaum tallied twice for the winners, with Stan Mazur and Mike Goldberg providing the other touchdowns.

SUDDENLY the garden is almost bare of bloom for this year, and even the last few chrysanthemums look pretty dismal after the frosts. While most gardeners have been cutting down dead perennials and pulling up annuals for a month or more, the realization comes that there are several more last-minute chores before it's just too cold to work outdoors.
ROME, Nov. 13 -- A committee of women in Rome has started an international collection among women to build a new shrine in Rome dedicated to the Virgin Mary.

WITH this book Everett Carter, Assistant Professor of English at the University of California, establishes himself among our more talented young literary historians and critics. LESS famous than his fellow-warrior, Sitting Bull, the Oglala-Sioux chief Crazy Horse was one of the leaders of the Custer Massacre. Writing from the Indian viewpoint, Mrs. Meadowcroft tells of the misunderstandings between white men and red and of the shabby treatment of the Indians which led to the attack on Custer and to the final betrayal of Crazy Horse. Despite an undistinguished style. this is a dramatic narrative.

IN the delicate penciled lines and water-colors which her name evokes for her many devotees Tasha Tudor draws an alphabet around the wardrobe of Grandmother's doll, Annabelle. Two small girls examine Annabelle's bandbox, her Victorian cloak, dresses, earrings, fan, gloves, hat and other belongings alphabetically itemized down to her improbable miniature zither.

A utility holding company that once controlled $3,000,000,000 of assets scattered over thirty-eight states and several countries in Latin America is making a comeback. Last week the Electric Bond and Share Company listed its assets at $149,564,200 on Sept. 30 of this year. This was equal to $28.49 a common share and represented a gain of $19,827,200, or 15.3 per cent, over the asset value of $24.71 a share at the beginning of this year.

(The work will receive its American premiere this week in Chicago by the Chicago Orchestra and the Sauter-Finegan band.)

PEOPLE didn't break their necks on Breakneck Hill -- only their backs. Imagine a hill so steep and high that people who climbed up or down it walked at an acute angle for hours afterward. That was old Breakneck! A horse-drawn street car was tried and it worked fine -- for the trip up.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 13 -- The Soviet Union is seeking to exploit Turkey's economic distress by offering urgently needed goods under an expanded barter trade agreement. Simultaneously, Moscow has multiplied expressions of friendship and sympathy for Turkey.

CHICAGO, Nov. 13 -- Evidences of a pickup in business continues to accumulate in the Chicago area. THE gardener who wishes to devote a shady area of his property to native woodland plants will find autumn an excellent time to start a private wildflower preserve. Since most woodland plants need a cool, moist situation, fall planting gives them a chance to become established before the arrival of summer's drought, which in recent years has caused drying out of many normally moist areas.

The diamond business is sparkling, at least at the wholesale level. Dealers report steady monthly gains over their 1953 figures for more than a half year. But the increases are attributed rather to inventory replacement buying by jewelers than to improved retail diamond sales.

Joe Carney led his Brooklyn Prep team to the title yesterday in the tenth annual Jesuit high schools cross-country championships at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. Carney took the individual crown with a 14:15 performance for the two-and-one-half mile course.

THE child who thinks of hide-and-seek only as a game in which he closes his eyes and counts to a hundred will find pleasant surprises here. He will discover that hide-and-seek goes on all about him. People seeking out and hiding in doorways during a thundershower, the policeman hiding a lump of sugar in his pocket and his horse seeking it out, goldfish darting in and out of their stone castle.

CHILDREN need to be busy. Nursery school is often the best part-time answer, but the child who cannot attend should not be deprived of the wonderful feeling of busyness. To meet this need, Miss Frances Horwich, of TV's Ding Dong School, has written a read-out-loud book that promises to be a boon to many a harried mother or frustrated child.

In the first two articles in this series of three on the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (Gatt) the writer sought to trace the train of circumstances and trends of thinking in foreign trade policy that led to the emergence of that body in 1947.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Surely everyone recalls the story of the Emperor's new suit. Deceitful tailors persuaded the Emperor that he was parading about in splendid apparel when actually he wore nothing at all. One is reminded of this tale by the paeans of praise for Western European Union within which Germany is to be rearmed.

Although the first snow has yet to touch a New York pavement, Christmas is in the air. Many New York stores are anticipating the season by opening special shops devoted to decorations for tree and home.
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- More facts about the mysterious life and death of the brutish race of Ice Age men known as Neanderthalers have been pieced together recently by European paleontologists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The Printing Industry of America, a trade association, called today for doubling of the industry's training programs.
CAIRO, Nov. 14 -- Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib was quietly relieved today of the Presidency of Egypt by the ruling military junta.

The New York Philanthropic League of the United Order of True Sisters announced yesterday that ground had been bought for the $500,000 recreation and rehabilitation center it plans to erect for handicapped persons at 334-36 East Twenty-third Street.
Too many persons are "individualists" in religion and have "no feeling for its social implications," the Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken said yesterday in his sermon at the Riverside Church.

The Rev. Michael Scott of Chichester, England, in a sermon yesterday at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine), urged Christian leaders to unite to prevent the spread of the doctrine of apartheid(white supremacy).

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Fifteen $25 prizes were awarded to Westchester artists and craftsmen this afternoon at the twenty-fourth annual exhibition of the Westchester Arts and Crafts Guild in the Westchester County Center.

Two new series of cars make up the 1955 line announced yesterday by the De Soto Division of the Chrysler Corporation. One group, the Fireflite, has a 200-horsepower V-8 engine; the other, the Firedome, a 185-horsepower V-8 engine.

There have been many people, clerical and laymen alike, who have not been tempted to air publicly their views on Senator Joseph McCarthy. I for one have been reluctant to discuss any aspects of the controversy with anyone but my closest associates. But since reading in The Times the comments of Msgr. Martin, I feel it necessary to add a word -- my own, very personal word.

A six-story apartment house in the Riverdale section of the Bronx passed to new control with the sale by the Residence Realty Company, A. Cuneo, president, of the property at 3804 Greystone Avenue, northeast corner of West 238th Street, to a client of Green Selzer, attorneys. The parcel is 100 by 100 feet and was sold through Nehring Brothers, brothers.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 (AP) -Hank Greenberg, the Cleveland Indians general manager, urged today that the "American League expand to ten clubs at the earliest opportunity."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Senator Samuel J. Ervin Jr., a member of the McCarthy censure committee, charged tonight that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was "giving the committee hell" because he could not defend himself against its findings.
The program that Franco Autori, assistant conductor of the Philharmonic - Symphony, conducted with that body Saturday night in Carnegie Hall was of uncommon interest, and was admirably interpreted.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings, blanked in their last two starts, scored three goals in the final period tonight to defeat the National Hockey League-leading Montreal Canadiens, 4 -- 1, at Olympia.

Discovery that corticotropin, one of the life-essential hormones, actually consists of eight distinct chemical compounds, is announced in the current issue of The Journal of the American Chemical Society. The chemical architecture of the most abundant of the eight has been determined.

There are several remarkable features about the Central Committee decision, signed by Nikita S. Khrushchev, chiding the excessive zeal of Soviet Communists fighting religion. The very fact that such a denunciation of actions offensive to religious believers had to be issued suggests that the number of these believers is quite substantial and that they are a force the Kremlin must reckon with.
It may be the influence of an easier, softer silhouette or a vogue for elegant sweater wraps at all hours of the day, but cashmere is a favorite of fashion this season.
FARMINGTON, W. Va., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Miners finished the job late tonight of sealing up a blazing, explosion-wrecked coal mine -- the tomb of fifteen men.

Back home in New Delhi after his visit to Peiping, Prime Minister Nehru has now given an extensive press interview on his trip and his impressions of Communist China. On the whole he appears to be more skeptical of the Communist regime than some of the earlier dispatches seemed to indicate. At least he has his fingers crossed.

Heroes in fiction are not always the heroes of our sober moments. We cheer the bravura exploits of the Scarlet Pimpernel as he opposes the French Revolution. We applaud G. A. Henty's too-fearless young men as they implement British imperialist policy.

The Steamship Freight Brokers Association has warned the members of forty-four steamship conferences that Government regulations forbid brokerage payments to forwarders who have a "beneficial interest" in the cargo they handle.
William Willis, who made a voyage from Peru to Samoa on a raft, has spent much of his life on extensive voyages.

The Most Rev. Thomas J. McDonnell, Coadjutor Bishop of the Roman Catholic diocese of Wheeling W. Va., Yesterday accused the United States Indian Bureau of neglect and lack of good faith toward its charges on reservations.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- A decision is expected before the end of the month in the Government's historic anti-trust suit against the du Pont family of Delaware and three of the country's largest corporations.
NEWARK, Nov. 14 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey voiced the fear tonight that although Senator Joseph R. McCarthy might have lost influence, his ideas would continue "to poison minds."

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" will return to the Metropolitan during the third week of the season, which opens on Monday, Nov. 22. The twin bill will be presented on Saturday evening, Nov. 27. No new singers are scheduled to make their appearance during the week, although several popular Metropolitan artists will be heard in familiar roles for the first time this season.
Members of the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, instructed their union officials last night to reopen contract negotiations with the Publishers Association of New York City.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- Former Foreign Minister Georges Bidault declared tonight that the Soviet Union's proposal appeared to be more acceptable than its suggestions made at the Big Four foreign ministers' conference in Berlin.
Normal radio and television broadcasting in the metropolitan area will be halted from 1:30 A. M. to 4:30 A. M., Wednesday, during a nation-wide Conelrad test.

PARIS, Nov. 14 -- The Popular Republican party's National Committee adopted today a motion condemning the Paris accords on German rearmament and urging reversion to the system of European union of a supranational or federal type.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 14 -Averell Harriman, Democratic Governor-elect, announced this afternoon he would appoint Paul H. Appleby, dean of the Maxwell Graduate School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University, as his Budget Director.

Dr. Eelco van Kleffens, president Of the United Nations General Assembly, said yesterday that regional pacts among nations, and even "old-fashioned diplomacy," could serve the aims of the United Nations if they helped to keep the peace.

LEXINGTON, Mo., Nov. 14 (AP) -- Former President Truman said today that it was impossible to have world peace "unless we are able and willing to stand up for our rights and the rights of the free world."
Free, or less-than-cost, ward and clinic care for the medicaly indigent last year left the nonprofit, voluntary hospitals in New York City with a gross loss of $19,000,000.

THERE'S a historic greenlichened cave on Hoboken shore just below Castle Stevens that didn't quite come in for its share of public notice last Wednesday when the castle's one hundredth anniversary was formally celebrated.
An intensified campaign against crime will be conducted by the police in the 103d (Jamaica) Precinct, Queens, along the lines of the experimental Operation 25 in East Harlem.
MICKEY ROONEY is a lot like a man trying to sop up Niagara Falls with a box of facial tissues. Nature makes it hard for him to do his work.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Cleveland Browns broke open a tight defensive battle with two touchdowns in thirty-seven seconds of the third period today and went on to swamp the Chicago Bears, 39 to 10, before 48,772 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -Western diplomats here expressed the conviction today that almost all the countries on this side of the Iron Curtain would reject the Soviet Union's invitation to a twenty-five-power conference on Nov. 29.
EAST HAMPTON, L. I., Nov. 14 -- A big, boxy fifteen-room Coast Guard Station is going to put to sea near here in a few weeks.

ALBANY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The University of Rochester has put in a bid for the papers that Governor Dewey has collected in his years as a special rackets prosecutor, District Attorney of New York County and Governor.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 14 -- Two sessions of the National Council, the formal annual meeting and election followed by the annual dinner made the closing day of the American Power Boat Association's convention a crowded one today.

The Government's prediction of a 13,206,000-bale cotton crop pushed futures prices downward last week in one of the sharpest breaks of the year. There was a belated rally in the market, but it was insufficient to regain the ground that had been lost, and active futures contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange closed the week with net losses ranging from $1.75 to $3.05 a bale.

The foreign exchange market passed through a listless trading week. While there was a good volume of business it produced nothing in the way of sizable price changes, except in the case of British sterling.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The World Jewish Congress today denounced Dr. Theodor Heuss, West German President, for his message last week to Constantin von Neurath, former Nazi Foreign Minister, on the latter's release from prison as a major war criminal.

Leontyne Price, who was Bess in the latest revival here of "Porgy and Bess," and who sang twice last summer at Lewisohn Stadium, gave her first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Because of the reputation she already has acquired, the event drew an audience of almost 1,500.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- The number of persons who have escaped from behind the Iron Curtain and are admitted to the United States is expected to rise early next year. The total had been sharply reduced by Refugee Relief Act security precautions.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 -- The Arctic short cut to Europe, its hazards overcome by science, will become a regular airline route.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Woodley Lewis ran back the opening kick-off 88 yards for a touchdown and the Los Angeles Rams scored three more on long plays to defeat the Chicago Cardinals, 28 to 17, today in a rough, penalty-ridden National Football League game.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Sales of the Peabody Coal Company in the quarter and six months ended on Oct. 31 declined from the levels of a year earlier, but there were profits for both 1954 periods, in contrast with losses in 1953, Otto Gressens, president, reported today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- William Jay Robinson, a Chicago attorney, today was elected president of the Jewish National Fund Council of Chicago at the group's annual conference in the Morrison Hotel. He succeeds Milton J. Silberman, vice president of the Exchange National Bank of Chicago.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Treasury gave notice today that it would call for redemption next March 15 the 2 7/8 per cent Treasury bonds issued on March 15, 1935, and due on March 15, 1960.

Between $75,000,000 and $100,000,000 of the 1950 issue of $220,000,000 New Jersey Turnpike Au thority 3 1/4 per cent bonds due in 1985 will be marketed as a secondary distribution on or about Nov. 23, according to Smith, Barney Co., manager of the marketing syndicate.

In their joint special plea for Chiang Kai-shek in The Times of Nov. 2 Bishop Welch and Editor Poling say: "Peace * * * cannot be built on the shifting sands of emotion, of wishful thinking or of transient forms of political control, but only on the firm foundations of truth, freedom, justice and goodwill."

The city faces an increase in its outstanding debt that "may make it difficult to sell our securities in the public market at favorable interest rates," Controller Lawrence E. Gerosa warned yesterday.

LONDON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Robert K. Christenberry, president of the World Boxing Committee, said today he will ask the group to select either Britain's Don Cockell or Cuba's Nino Valdes as Rocky Marciano's next opponent for the world heavyweight championship.
The first Negro to become pastor of a Reformed Protestant Dutch Church in this country was installed yesterday as minister of the Mott Haven Reformed Church, 348 East 146th Street, the Bronx.

The long contemplated production of a musical version of "Seventh Heaven," based on the Austin Strong play, appears now to have moved a major step toward realization. Gant Gaither, who has been nurturing plans for a presentation of the Victor YoungStella Unger-Victor Wolfson version, has reached an agreement with William A. Bacher, Hollywood producer, whereby the latter will join him in the sponsorship.
First reports on the Government's Special School Milk Program indicate that youngsters here are drinking considerably more milk than at the same time last year.

HONG KONG, Monday, Nov. 15 (Reuters) -- A spokesman for a British shipping company said here today that Chinese Nationalist warships intercepted two of the company's ships in the Formosa Strait during the week-end but released them "after routine checks."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -Appointment of a Democrat to a top post in the State Department, "not as an agent of Democrats in Congress but as an agent of the Democratic party within the Administration," was proposed today by Senator Alexander Wiley.

The Brookhattan-Galicia team defeated the Philadelphia Uhriks, 5 -- 3, in an American Soccer League game at Zerega Oval in the Bronx yesterday. The defeat was the first of the season for the Uhriks, who toppled to second place.

Considering the variety of goods and service a man with a coin can get from a machine, it is no wonder that robot toll collectors have turned up on a New Jersey highway. The recent intellectual progress of the machine has been many times outdistanced by its commercial advances.
QUEBEC, Nov. 14 -- French Premier Pierre Mendes-France arrived by plane today for a courtesy call to French Canada as the start of his visit to Canada and the United States.

An audience of 1,500, including almost fifty on the stage, assembled at Town Hall Saturday night to attend the third recital to be given there by Martha Schlamme, folk singer, who has won a following through her personal appearances and her phonograph recordings.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- Cornelius Shields kept his Dainty consistently near the front of the fleet through nine races today to win the third championship regatta of the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite season with 254 of a maximum 270 points.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Transamerica Corporation is preparing to create a new California banking system with resources of more than $800,000,000 and offices in fifty-five cities.
Mrs. Bertha Nolan, the right halfback on West Jersey's No. 1 field hockey squad, was named to the New Atlantic Section first team yesterday for the fourth consecutive year.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 14 -The Communist party in Argentina has issued a call for the formation of a National Democratic Front to resist possible capture of the Government by rightist forces. Such a front, the party said, could form the basis for a new Government "for the people and by the people."
LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Sir Anthony Eden returned this afternoon from his country home in Wiltshire and conferred with Foreign Office experts on the Soviet note.
The Cross Bronx Expressway, one of the first post-war projects here, has outdistanced all competition as the last to be finished.

CHARLESTON, W. Va., Nov. 14 (UP) -- West Virginia's newly completed turnpike turned into a motorist's nightmare today as thousands of Sunday drivers clogged the eighty-eight mile length from here to Princeton.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 -- Wheat has been the leader on the bull side of the market the past week, registering a succession of new crop highs for all deliveries except the December. The near delivery however was relatively strong.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 14 -- "What American Jewry needs and Conservative Judaism seeks to supply is not merely an interest in Jewish survival, but a dedication in thought, word and act to the building of a worthwhile Jewish future in America."

The Citizens Budget Commission announced yesterday that it had endorsed a proposed law establishing the new Department of Commerce and Public Events. The bill is now pending in the Committee on City Affairs of the City Council.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- In the last few days the stock markets have experienced their sharpest setback in several weeks. Industrial shares, as leaders in the bull movement, have suffered most, but nearly all groups show some reaction, and a note of general caution has become apparent.
An evaluation and measurement service center to help schools and colleges devise and interpret tests has been opened by Teachers College, Columbia University.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 14 -- Seasonal factors will not affect seriously the upward movement in steel-mill activity during the balance of this year, according to reliable trade sources. The steel rate advanced again last week and indications are that the peak has not been reached for this quarter.
RALEIGH, N. C., Nov. 14 (AP) -The State of North Carolina today asked the United States Supreme Court to put its forthcoming decree on how to end segregation in public schools into effect slowly.
Shipowners expressed optimism again last week as rates rose to new peaks for recent months and more cargo was offered than could be handled.
Seven unbeaten-untied college football teams, including Arkansas and Cincinnati, fell by the wayside on Saturday, leaving only twenty-five schools in the select group.

As part of a greatly expanded New York office at 655 Madison Avenue, Grant Advertising, Inc., with headquarters in Chicago, is taking over a large part of the talent of Cecil Presbrey, Inc. The latter agency will go out of business on the first of next year.

THE fellow who writes the script for the Yale-Princeton series has no imagination. He keeps using the same plot over and over again. He varies it ever so slightly but fools no one by such a transparency. That last-minute pulse-quickener he uses to yank the customers from their seats is too easily recognizable.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 14 -- Argentine stocks, long looked at askance in Switzerland, are again booming here.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 14 (AP) -A two-engined Navy patrol plane with a crew of five aboard crashed into the Atlantic Ocean about forty-six miles southeast of Cherry Point, N. C., tonight.
FRANKLIN, Tex., Nov. 14 (UP) -- Walter W. Williams, the nation's oldest veteran of the Civil War, celebrated his 112th birthday today with the declaration that "I will live after everyone else goes."
BOSTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, scoring in every period, continued their hot National Hockey League pace tonight by defeating the Boston Bruins, 3 -- 1, to hold second place.

The entire twenty-fourth floor in the office building erected recently by Simon Brothers, builders and owners, at 477 Madison Avenue, northeast corner of Fifty-first Street, has been leased by the Rheem Manufacturing Company, world's largest manufacturer of water heaters and steel shipping containers.

For fifty years more than 22,000 boys have received timely guidance through the individual friendship and interest of the volunteer Big Brothers of Greater New York. Back of the personal relationship between these men and boys lies the work of the Big Brother Movement's professional staff and year-round schedule of camp, club, health and vocational services.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers rolled into an early lead and then fought off the Baltimore Bullets near the end of the game to triumph, 95 -- 93, in a National Basketball Association game today.
A new work and a new pianist were heard at yesterday afternoon's Carnegie Hall program of the Philharmonic conducted by Dimitri Mitropoulos.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -There's a dandy "whodunit?" mystery on Capitol Hill today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The New York Rangers, spearheaded by Danny Lewicki and Nick Mickoski, scored four times in a six-minute burst tonight and went on to beat the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 0, in a National Hockey League game.

A convocation, underscoring the religious meaning of 300 years of Jewish settlement in America, was held last night in Carnegie Hall, Messages from public leaders hailed the event as "an inspiration to the free peoples of the world and a powerful challenge to the forces of communism who would deny religious belief."

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Inquiries about the antiquarian activities of Charles Dawson, who "discovered" the Piltdown skull -- proved a year ago to have been a fake -- indicate that a number of items from his private collection of antiquities are bogus, too.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Office of Defense Mobilization today granted Federal Tax benefits to assist six railroads in the purchase of $35,000,000 worth of new freight cars, locomotives, and other rail transport facilities.

The drive against police corruption has brought implied threats of demotions for district and division commanders whose subordinates take graft. Detectives as well as uniformed policemen have been included in the warnings.

THE long reign of Charles II, 1660-1685, commonly known as the Restoration, although the term sometimes includes the short reign of James II, 1685-1688, exerts a curious fascination on many modern minds. It is uncertain whether people of today are attracted more by the scandalous conduct in Charles' corrupt court or by the cynicism of an age that prized wit above most human attributes.
The sentimental salami problem again is plaguing officials of the Departments of Agriculture and the Treasury.

ANDOVER, Mass., Nov. 14 -- The Diamond Anniversary football game at Brothers Field yesterday between Andover and Exeter may not have been the teams' seventy-fifth meeting after all. Undoubtedly, that matter will be settled shortly, but right now amateur historians at both schools are busy.

The Giants cleared a high hurdle yesterday when they downed the Philadelphia Eagles, 27--14, before 46,565 fans at the Polo Grounds. Their sixth victory of the National Football League season gave the New Yorkers exclusive possession of first place in the Eastern Conference, dropping the Eagles from a tie for the lead to third place.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 14 -- The eighth general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, meeting here, has to face an issue that may seriously, change the organization's character.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Twenty-one persons ware killed in Tunisia and ten in Algeria yesterday in the heaviest fighting since the rebellion was renewed two weeks ago, French sources reported today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Business activity rolled along in the third quarter of the year at about the same pace that has prevailed since January, the Department of Commerce said today.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman intends to make the State Labor Department a key unit in his campaign to attract new industries to this state and to deter old industries from leaving.

AMITYVILLE, L. I., Nov. 14 -- After swimming and wading for a mile this morning through the cold, choppy waters that had capsized his small boat in Great South Bay, Alfred Muscara, 29 years old, of Bellmore, L. I., collapsed and died on the beach here.
ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 14 -The Board of Regents of the American College of Surgeons adopted today a policy report demanding a complete overhaul of workmen's compensation laws.
" How much do you think a man adrift at sea can take?"

ALBANY, Nov. 14 (AP) -- The Legislature's two top Republican leaders served notice on the Democratic Governor-elect today that they would offer their own program to carry out G. O. P. campaign pledges.

Attorney General-elect Jacob K. Javits said yesterday that he anticipated no trouble in working with the Harriman Administration. However, if he finds any, he said, he will go over Gov. Averell Harriman's head and appeal to the public for support.
The Home Liner Atlantic will be renamed the Queen Frederika on Dec. 22 in Piraeus, Nicos Vernicos, president of the company, announced yesterday.

The program given by the Concert Society of New York yesterday afternoon in Town Hall was signalized by Virgil Thomson's first appearance as conductor and composer in this city since he relinquished his duties as music critic of The New York Herald Tribune last summer.

DETROIT, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions, led by Halfback Doak Walker, took a giant stride in quest for a third straight National Football League championship today with a 48-7 rout of the San Francisco Forty-Niners before a record crowd of 58,431 fans at Briggs Stadium.

President Eisenhower is scheduled to submit to the Senate today the Paris agreements for military unity aimed at replacing the now defunct European Defense Community. He will ask for the speedy ratification of these agreements, a request in consonance with the efforts by United States diplomats to secure quick ratification by the other contracting nations.

GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 14 -- Dr. Samuel Milbank of New York City handled his 2-year-old Springer spaniel, Rivington Countryman, winner of the English Springer open all-age stake today at the annual meeting of the Connecticut Spaniel Field Trial Association at Yale Farms.

MUST it finally be said that Ibsen's "A Doll's House," creaking for some time, now is on the verge of collapse? On the basis of the production it received over the week-end at the Finch College Playhouse by The Club Theatre, the answer would appear to be yes.
Plans to bring the city's Multiple Dwelling Law up to date, compel landlords to conform to decent housing standards and halt the growth of slums were announced yesterday by Mayor Wagner.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 14 -- The production of beef cattle per acre in this country could be increased five times with the aid of known techniques, the Joint Committee on Grassland Farming was told here today.
One motorist, at least, has found a way to beat the city's traffic congestion. And in the process he has helped brighten life in New York.

The editorial in The New York Times of Nov. 9 on "Jobless Who Won't Work" indicates that on the basis of Government statistics "lazy" individuals draw little or no unemployment compensation. To support this conclusion the editorial states:

Net income of the Anaconda Copper Mining Company and its subsidiaries declined to $19,171,803 in the first nine months this year from $24,156,882 earned in the corresponding period a year ago, according to the report released for publication today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower observed her fifty-eighth birthday anniversary today. Her pastor wished her "many more days of good health and helpful service."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 14 -- This country's enthusiasm for codification of the legal principles first developed in the war crimes trials at Nuremberg and Tokyo has cooled.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 -- Chief Justice Earl Warren has come up with an astonishing idea. He thinks the members of the Supreme Court of the United States ought to be able to hear each other and be heard by the lawyers and others in the courtroom.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 14--An 1,800-ton Chinese Nationalist destroyer escort was sunk by four Communist torpedo boats this morning. The attack took place north of the Nationalist-held Tachen Islands off southeast China's Chekiang coast.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 14 -- The stock market showed heavy fluctuations last week due to profit-taking after recent advances. The share price index, after touching a high of 225.61, finished at 220.40, against 222.06 a week ago.

Net income and sales of Columbian Carbon Company in the nine months ended Sept. 30 were slightly below those of the comparable period of 1953, the company reported over the week-end. Net earnings were $3,256,068, or $2.02 a share,' against $3,376,537, or $2.09 a share. Sales were $38,721,240 and $39,420,807, respectively. 'i

A conscientious effort on the part of Stern's to foster a "family feeling" about the store among customers and employes has paid dividends in mounting sales in the last year, according to Thomas W. MacLeod, president.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 14 -Filling the spacious greensward in the National Stadium here this morning, 60,000 school children cried "Long live Uncle Nehru!" in a birthday greeting to Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru.

The naming of Walter W. Weismann, chairman of the Aetna Industrial Corporation, as "Man of the Year" was announced yesterday by Sydney W. Roos, president of the New York Federation of Reform Synagogues.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, said today the Dixon-Yates contract would be a "running sore * * * for years to come" and would cost President Eisenhower bipartisan support for his programs in the new Congress.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,129,933,751. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

The 51,000 persons in the Yale Bowl Saturday had as enjoyable an afternoon of sport as football offers. From the opening kick-off to the last scrimmage the exciting action on the field kept the stands in an uproar as hopes soared and sank and the suspense remained constant.

MONTREAL, Nov. 14 -- Extradition hearings for two United States stock salesmen who were operating from a Canadian base will continue tomorrow before Chief Justice W. B. Scott of the Montreal Superior Court.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 14 -- Republic Pictures will step up its production activity by starting five pictures between the end of the month and Jan. 3, according to an announcement by Herbert J. Yates, president.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -A subcommittee of the American Federation of Labor today recommended that the new Congress, dominated by the Democrats, adopt a five-point program to discourage industry from quitting high-pay areas for those with lower scales.

LONDON, Nov. 14 -- Prime Minister Churchill, master politician as well as master statesman, intervened today in a West Derby (Liverpool) by-election in an effort to retain a parliamentary seat for his party.

The first of six programs of the newly formed Knickerbocker Chamber Players took place last night in the Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art. A miscellaneous program was presented; it included chamber music as well as works for string and chamber orchestra.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (AP) -The Washington Redskins rebounded from a 62-3 lacing a week ago to overcome favored Pittsburgh today, 17 -- 14. The defeat virtually knocked the Steelers out of contention for the National Football League championship.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 14 (UP) -The American Civil Liberties Union declared today that the Eighty-third Congress had "made deep inroads into civil liberties" with some of its anti-Communist legislation.

Everything went beautifully at the Saturday night performance of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly" at the Metropolitan Opera. "Madama Butterfly," of course, is a work that pretty much stands or falls on the singer who takes the title role, and it is a pleasure to report that Licia Albanese, who sang Cio-Cio-San, was in admirable form.

GUATEMALA, Nov. 8 -- The Guatemalan Medical Association has cleared members accused of having participated in the alleged police tortures and murders during the last days of the Jacobo Arbenz Guzman regime in June.
CHICAGO, Nov. 14 (AP) -- Blazes apparently set by an arsonist today damaged historical objects in two exhibition rooms at the Chicago Historical Society Museum.

Juan Vincente Gomez, who for twenty-seven years ruled Venezuela as his personal domain, is the subject of a biography by John Lavin entitled "A Halo for Gomez." The author also depicts Venezuela's transformation from a colonial country of bellicose warlords to the present progressive and prosperous nation.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 14 (UP) -- The Guatemalan press attache, Arnoldo Orantes, was shot and killed on Mexico City's main boulevard today. The Guatemalan Embassy charged he was slain in retaliation for Guatemelan efforts to punish officials of the overthrown pro-Communist Guatemelan Government of Jacobo Arbenz Guzman.

A ten-day nation-wide drive was announced here yesterday for 10,000,000 signatures on petitions urging the Senate to reject censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as inspired by Communist propaganda.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 14 -Political observers here hope the departure of Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, Army Chief of Staff, will lead to changes and improvements in the faltering government of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem. The general is due to leave for France Thursday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Delegates from fifty-six county units of the New York State Farm Bureau Federation voted today to separate the Farms Bureau from the State Extension Service. The federation is holding its annual meeting here.

James C. Petrillo, president of the American Federation of Musicians, A. F. L., ordered the music turned back on last night for unionized actors, hoofers and chorus girls in night clubs, vaudeville houses and one-night stands in the United States and Canada.
Recent political and economic problems in Pakistan and the continued weakness of most of the Arab countries have hampered materially the development of a "situation of strength" in the Middle East.

For thirty-nine years Averell Harriman has been a member of the Palisades Interstate Park Commission. Yesterday, his sixty-third birthday, he attended what will be his last meeting as a commissioner before he assumes his duties as Governor on Jan. 1.

CHICAGO, Nov, 15 (AP) --Producers unloaded the largest number of hogs in nearly two years on the livestock market today. As a result, prices declined, although the drop was hot as sharp as might have been expected in view of the large numbers placed on sale.

LAWRENCE, Mass., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Fred E. Beal, who served four years of a seventeen-year prison sentence for conspiracy to murder in the fatal shooting of the Gastonia, N. C., police chief during a 1929 textile strike, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home. His age was 57.

French and American dignitaries, including Premier Pierre Mendes-France and United States Under-Secretary of State Herbert Hoover Jr., paid tribute last night to the historic cooperation between their two nations. They predicted the two would stand side by side in meeting any new threat of totalitarian aggression.
An underwriting syndicate headed by Scott, Homer Mason is offering new issues of debentures and common stock of Shenandoah Gas Company of Lynchburg, Va.

The undersigned propose an unhysterical and sober approach to the full implications of the proposed vote of censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. To us it seems rather that there has been forged a powerful weapon to suppress unpopular people and unpopular ideas. The consequences can only be disastrous.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- United States Representative Frances P. Bolton, Republican of Ohio, today presented to the United Nations fifty-two recordings of classical musical programs for radio on behalf of a number of individuals and organizations in the Cleveland area.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Dr. Peters said today he was as mystified as ever about who was responsible for questioning his loyalty. But, he added, he was happy the Supreme Court had agreed to review his dismissal from a Government post.

Predetermined engineering and industrial standards are basic requirements for an orderly transition from today's mechanization to tomorrow's automation. Roger E. Gay, retiring president of the American Standards Association, issued this warning yesterday.

The city's fish smokers started cooking again last night after a two-week strike. A two-year contract providing a wage increase of $6 a week for 250 unionized workers opened the way for a swift return to New York tables of smoked salmon, sturgeon, whitefish and other marine delicacies cut off by the work stoppage.

The Health Department will open on Thursday a pilot project in the mass control of diabetes. It will be in the Brownsville Health Center at 259 Bristol Street, Brooklyn, because that health district has the highest death rate from diabetes in the city.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Kenneth C. Gifford, chairman of the board of Schick, Inc., maker of electric razors, announced here late today that "to meet the need for expanded manufacturing facilities," it would move from this city to Lancaster, Pa., next April.
F. W. Olin Hall, the new ten-story student residence of Cornell University Medical College, was dedicated yesterday at 445 East Sixty-ninth Street.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 15 -- The inauguration of the Scandinavian end of the passenger air route along the Arctic Circle between Europe and the United States became a fact when the Scandinavian Airlines' Helge Viking took off from Copenhagen Airport tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Republican leader in the Senate, today issued a vigorous dissent to his own Administration's foreign policy.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Settlement of differences between the management of the Air-Way Electric Appliance Corporation and stockholders, headed by Edward Lamb of Toledo and Harry S. Samuels of New York, was announced jointly today by Mr. Lamb and Joseph H. Nuffer, president.

Buick has stepped up engines to 235 horsepower and improved automatic transmission performance in the 1955 line announced yesterday by Buick division, General Motors Corporation. There is a gain of fifty-four horsepower in some of the cars over comparative 1954 models.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday 5 to 22 points net higher than on Friday, with the far months stronger.

Sam Wiesenthal, independent producer, has bought the rights to "Rage," a story about a man's search to find himself. It was written directly for the screen by John Rich. The producer plans to make it next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today received an award from the New Jersey Department of the Army and Navy Union "for his unrelenting efforts in exposing and combatting subversives in the United States."

The Princeton University Debate Panel announced yesterday that it had wired John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, Gov. Robert B. Crosby of Nebraska, and the presidents of the four state-supported teachers' college in Nebraska, strongly opposing the suppression of the Communist China topic in intercollegiate debate.

The biennial elections of the Atlantic and Gulf District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., began yesterday morning at union halls all over the nation. Forty-nine elective posts in the district are up for contest by a record number of seventy-eight candidates.

TRENTON, Nov. 15 -- The State Senate voted tonight to increase by $500 the annual minimum salary of New Jersey school teachers and to establish the first state-wide schedule of minimum salary increments for teachers.

The Scandinavian Airlines plans to maintain a regular passenger service of four flights a week between Europe and California by way of the Arctic -- two in each direction. They will not be the first long-distance flights over polar seas; for in 1937 the Russians soared over the Pole to America.
PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- A $39,006 treasure trove was discovered today in the tiny apartment of a frugal, mild-mannered tinsmith who had been found dead there yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 109.7 (1947-49 equals 100) in the week ended on last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Higher average prices for processed foods were offset by lower average prices for farm products; all commodities other than farm products and processed foods remained unchanged.

MONTREAL, Nov. 15 -- Employes of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada today identified Walter H. Link, one of two persons fighting extradition to the United States, as the "Mr. Walters" who had made arrangements for telephone service at the office of T. M. Parker, Inc., a Montreal firm dealing securities.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Supreme Court was urged today to permit a gradual solution of the problems arising from its historic decision last May that racial segregation in the public schools was unconstitutional.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold won committee approval today for his plant to reorganize the Secretariat of the United Nations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Following are the texts of President Eisenhower's message to Senate submitting the Paris agreements on West German sovereignty and armament and Secretary of State Dulles' letter to the President on the agreements:

CLEVELAND, Nov. 15 -- The defense in the trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard tried to show today that the police had "jumped to the conclusion" that the 31-year-old osteopath had murdered his wife and that the authorities had ceased all other investigation soon after the crime.

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- A special deputy attorney general charged today that some of the 1,400 absentee ballots cast on Nov. 2 in Albany County had been tampered with to eliminate votes for Republican candidates.

The Westchester Square Hospital has sold its seven-story building on St. Raymond's Avenue in the Bronx to the Tishman Realty and Construction company and has leased back the property for twenty-one years.

The Malayan Communist party is the subject of a book by Harry Miller, a staff member of The Straits Times of Singapore. Praeger will issue it Thursday with the title "The Communist Menace in Malaya." The author "ties the leadership of the party to Ho Chi Minh, the man behind the Viet Minh war in Indo-China."
MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 15 -- About 27,000 striking dock workers at sixty ports voted today to return to work tomorrow, following a two-week stoppage.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Brig. Gen. Charles A. Lindbergh went on active duty with the Air Force today for the first time since his commission was restored by President Eisenhower last February.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, who has promised to vote to give Democrats control of the Senate next year, said today he intended to seek re-election in 1956 as an independent.
Mayor Wagner warned the Transit Authority yesterday that its proposed cuts in bus and trolley service would lead the public to boycott municipal transit facilities.
OTTAWA, Nov. 15 -- The governor of the Bank of Canada, Graham Towers, will retire at the end of the year, it was announced today.
Ten years from today the aircraft industry will have an engine that will produce four times the power of the liner Queen Mary, it was predicted last night.

It is time, this morning, to take up the entire matter of the cook. This problem has been worrisome for months, seldom out of mind, yet with one thing and another it escaped review. Now, definitely, it must be considered without further delay.
Lou Little, now in his twenty-fifth year as head football coach at Columbia University, was paid high tribute by New York writers at a luncheon in Toots Shot's yesterday.
American Jews were urged yesterday to restore the synagogue to its place of primacy in Jewish life.

Word was received here yesterday that Foremost Dairies, Inc., with headquarters in Jacksonville, Fla., was reaching into the Wisconsin-Minnesota "milk pail of the United States." N. W. Bandler, president of Blue Moon Foods, Inc., of Thorpe, Wis., said that negotiations for a merger with Foremost on an exchange-of-stock basis had reached the stage where "stockholders should know about it."

SINGAPORE, Tuesday, Nov. 16 -- The cause of an airliner crash here March 13 in which thirty-three persons died "was not the ridge at the sea-wall end of the airport, but the fact that [the] pilot of the plane touched down at a place where the aircraft had no right to be."

THE French nineteenth-century romantic painter Monticelli is an artist to whom less than justice has been done. This neglect has been somewhat made up for recently; first of all in an important retrospective of his work held at the Orangerie in Paris, in 1953, and at the present moment at Paul Rosenberg's, where a handsomely representative selection of twenty-four of his paintings in American collections is being shown.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 15 -- Ray Bolger, looking beyond his current weekly television show, has purchased motion - picture and TV rights to "All the Ships at Sea." The dancer plans to film the story for theatrical presentation next summer.
DETROIT, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The printing industry of America was told today the ratio of apprentices in the industry should be 1 to 5 but is only 1 to 10.

The football season ends for all except a few college teams in the East and Middle West this week. By Saturday night most of the conference champions will be determined, as well as the teams to take part in some of the bowl games.

Events today: Jean Wentworth, pianist, Town Hall, 3 P. M.; "Andrea Chenier," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy conducting, Alexander Brailowsky, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Ralph Hollander, violinist-composer, Town Hall, 8:30; Gerald Tarack, violinist, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; New York Singing Teachers' Association, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30; Manhattan Orchestra, Franco Autori, conducting, Manhattan School of Music, 238 East 105th Street, 8:30; Ernest White, organist, Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Following is the text of the statement to the Senate today by Senator William F. Knowland of California, the Majority Leader, suggesting a review of the Eisenhower Administration's foreign and defense policies in the cold war:

After losing a forty-yard advantage in the last mile because of doubt as to which turn to take on the strange course, George Terry of Boston University put on a scorching stretch drive to win the intercollegiate A.A.A.A. cross-country championship at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday.
Ohio State returned to the top of the weekly Associated Press football ranking poll yesterday, but by a narrow margin.
ALBANY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- A stockholder in the New York City Omnibus Corporation today withdrew his effort to block its proposed merger with the Fifth Avenue Coach Corporation.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 15 -- Official sources here expressed the view today that the Chinese Communist attack on the Nationalist destroyer escort Taiping was designed to seek information about the intentions of the United States Seventh Fleet.

THERE is nothing like the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra playing pit band for "There Is Nothing Like a Dame." It happened last night, plus a lot of other unusual and amusing things, when Richard Rodgers brought his music and baton to Carnegie Hall.

The Albert Einstein College of Medicine, now under construction in the Bronx, received yesterday a $3,500,000 loan from the Bankers Trust Company. The money will assure completion of the college and its official opening next fall.

The expansion of the social security system has closed a long chapter in the nation's "fight against misery and destitution," Roswell B. Perkins, Assistant Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- The Supreme Court today ordered further hearings on the appeal of the Yonkers, N. Y., Committee for Peace, which was refused the use of school property to hold a public forum.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15--President Eisenhower asked the Senate today to approve arrangements to put West Germany into the Atlantic alliance and bring 500,000 German troops into the Western defense.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Supreme Court agreed today to review a decision of the Federal Court of Appeals here upholding the Government's personnel security program.

New York's first direct sea link in many years with Asuncion, the mid-continent capital of Paraguay, will be forged on Dec. 12 when a tiny Dutch freighter begins a new service for the Lamport Holt Line.
MASTERPIECES of eighteenth-century painting by French masters, on loan from a dozen American museum collections, will be shown, beginning today, at the Wildenstein Galleries.

Talk about the Giants shifting their baseball franchise from New York to California is just that -- talk. The thought of moving the club has not even entered his mind, Horace Stoneham, the president of the Giants, said yesterday.

The annual fiesta named for Casita Maria, a settlement house at 61 East 107th Street, will be held on Dec. 1 in the Crystal ballroom of the Park Lane. The fiesta, which is for the benefit of the settlement house, is given by the Elizabeth Seton League, Inc., which operates Casita Maria.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Pennsylvania Supreme Court said today that a court of equity had jurisdiction to halt mass picketing employed in an effort to organize a union.
Eight-foot-high photo murals carrying an urgent message were installed yesterday in the Fifth Avenue building of the New York Public Library.
Christmas cards are heartwarming. Friend salutes friend with personal as well as seasonal greetings.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Utah Re publican, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy on these counts against him:
BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 15 -- Many young Chinese here would like to help the Formosan Government's fight to recover the mainland, according to several leaders of Bangkok's huge Chinese community.

Stockholders of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company at a special meeting here yesterday approved and adopted a re-capitalization plan, whereby about 47 per cent of the outstanding common stock could be exchanged for a new preferred stock issue, according to David T. Staples, president.

Members of the board of managers and residents of St. Luke's Home for Aged Women will hold their annual reception and sale on Wednesday and Thursday at the headquarters of the home at Broadway and 114th Street.
