Luncheon, for which reservations must be made in advance, will be served on Wednesday, and tea will be served on Thursday.
Sales in the nation's chain and mail order stores in October inched slightly ahead of those of the previous year, according to a tabulation made yesterday by The New York Times.

Jack Johnson, the professional court tennis champion, defeated Alastair B. Martin, the amateur titleholder, 6 -- 5, 5 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, yesterday in the opening phase of a thirteen-set match for the North American Open championship.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Government predicted today that the building boom would set another record next year.
Realizing hit the stock market yesterday and it retreated stubbornly, fighting every inch of the way. For the last hour or so it was gaining ground.

A suspended Westchester parkway policeman will refuse to waive immunity before the Brooklyn grand jury investigating a racket in "courtesy cards" for traffic offenders, his lawyer said yesterday. The lawyer conceded this would expose the policeman to dismissal under the State Constitution.
A Westchester center of public information and service will be opened by The New York Times tomorrow morning at the Cross County Shopping Center, Yonkers.

General liquidation and profit-taking tumbled cocoa prices the l-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. There was little buying interest and volume was only 196 lots. There were 156 offerings at the limit down at the close.

An inkling of what the new ANTA Theatre, 245 West Fifty-second Street, will be like when it opens its doors on Dec. 6 with a preview performance of "Portrait of a Lady," was given yesterday by Robert W. Dowling, chairman of the American National Theatre and Academy.
A masculine version of that female sanctum, the beauty shop, will open today. Called the Gourielli Men's Shop, it is behind a discreet town house facade at 16 East Fifty-fifth Street.
Deputy Housing Commissioner Bernice P. Rogers last night advised Puerto Ricans living in substandard, expensive rooming-houses to buy homes in other boroughs.

It is a sad fact of this country's musical life that many young artists, after promising starts, fail to develop. Happily, Larry Walz, Kansas pianist, who gave his fourth New York recital last night at Town Hall, is not one in this class. He is continuing to grow.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Practical uses come to mind for many of the archaic kitchen tools in the early American exhibits at the thirty-ninth annual Eastern States Antiques Fair. The fair, which opened today at the Westchester County Center here, continues through Saturday.
Telephone service to the Roosevelt Hotel was disrupted yesterday by the initial response to a pro-McCarthy petition campaign.

WINNIPEG, Man., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Scandinavian Airlines' Royal Viking landed here at 9:15 A. M. (New York time) today after completing the first leg of its initial trip oper the Arctic route between Los Angeles and Copenhagen, Denmark.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 15 -- The Grand National Assembly broke up in fisticuffs late tonight. The fighting came after an Opposition Deputy had suggested that Premier Adnan Menderes was "arm in arm" with Greek officers who fought Turkish forces after World War I.

Directors of the United Carbon Company authorized yesterday a three-for-two split in its stock. This would be accomplished by the distribution on Nov. 26 of one additional share for each two outstanding. The distribution will be mailable to stockholders on or about Dec. 27.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- At the suggestion of Giacomo Cardinal Lercaro, Archbishop of Bologna, the barbers of that diocese are about to proclaim a humble sixteenth century mulatto Dominican friar protector of their profession.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- A United States delegate accused Andrei Y. Vishinsky today of conducting experiments in the United Nations along the lines that made Dr. Ivan P. Pavlov and his drooling dogs famous.

Gene Fullmer, unbeaten middle-weight from West Jordan, Utah, scored his twenty-sixth triumph last night by gaining a unanimous decision over Peter Mueller, Cologne, Germany, in the main bout of ten rounds at The Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the fourth day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Nov. 15 -- Steve Doctor, Lordi Range, and Pat Stanley, Island Hills, shaved six strokes from course figures with 31, 34 -- 65, to win the Long Island Professional Golf Association's Pro-Pro tournament at the Sands Point Club today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 15 -- Many lives could be saved among the 95,000 who now die annually as the result of accidents, it was declared here tonight at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs have continued to drop.

It was pointed out during the recent election that voting machines were in use throughout New York State. This is of course a great advance, there being very little doubt that the use of machines in voting is much more efficient than the use of paper ballots. However, I feel that there is another needed improvement that should be made in the mechanics of the voting process.
MONTREAL, Nov. 15 -- Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier, said tonight that the work to be done in France "is not the work of a day but of a generation."

Two sites in Maspeth, Queens, have been acquired for improvement by the Wanda Realty Corporation, builder. One will be used for the development of seventeen two-family dwellings and the other will be used for a gasoline service station.

Governor-elect Harriman has set a high standard of character, ability and technical competence in selecting as his State Budget Director Dean Paul H. Appleby of Syracuse University's Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs. It is a choice fully in consonance with the high standards maintained by Governor Dewey's present Budget Director, Dr. T. Norman Hurd, and his predecessor, John E. Burton.

Harold Riegelman came up yesterday with a proposal to finance his plan to develop the Hudson River as the permanent future source of New York's drinking water -- abolition of the Board of Water Supply.

A certain familiar pattern is discernible in the occasional official statements that come from the Controller of the City of New York. At the time of his annual report he invariably (in recent years) finds the city's credit "sound." When capital budget-making time comes around he traditionally warns against going overboard on spending.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 15 -- Premier Moshe Sharett today described United States efforts to strengthen Middle Eastern stability through military and economic aid to Egypt as a "unique form of logic."
Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy announced yesterday that five new day centers to care for children of working mothers would be established in city housing projects.

Antonino Rocca, 225, of Buenos Aires, pinned Don Leo Jonathan, 280, Salt Lake City, in 18:21 of the feature wrestling exhibition at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 12,378, who paid $55,889, saw the South American win with a drop-kick and body press.

During the Christmas season last year individuals and units throughout the Korean Communications Zone participated in welfare activities to help those Koreans in need. This demonstration of goodwill and generosity brought comfort and cheer to thousands of impoverished Koreans in the Communications Zone, which covers two-thirds of South Korea, extending from Seoul south to the Port of Pusan on the southern tip of the peninsula.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 15 -- Frustrating a Communist bid for control, the Central Government today assumed direct administration of Andhra State [shown in black on map] in South India.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 15 -- Seriously hampered by injuries, the Yale University football team canceled its regular workout today in favor of a three-hour meeting behind closed doors.

A 70-year-old woman was found dead in her Bronx apartment yesterday morning with the gas oven turned on but not burning. Health Department inspectors are investigating whether the sixteenth gas poisoning death here in nine days might be due to something wrong with the gas pressure or equipment.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- Secretary of State Dulles paid a quick visit to New York today for a luncheon meeting with the heads of twenty Latin-American delegations to the United Nations. Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., chief United States delegate, was host at the private luncheon, held at the Hotel Ambassador.

LEXINGTON, Va., Nov. 15 (AP) -- Virginia Military Institute's cross-country team made a shambles of the Southern Conference cross-country meet today, scoring a low of 27 points against 71 for Washington and Lee, the runner-up team.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- President Eisenhower endorsed today a new, national, nonpartisan nonprofit organization for slum clearance and neighborhood improvement.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams reiterated last night that his department was "desperately in need of men and money to pay them," but declared that it was necessary to strengthen the department internally first.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 --The President's Committee on Government Contracts reported today some progress in eliminating discrimination in employment, but made no claims to spectacular successes. "Our task has just begun," it said.
Tampa, Fla., announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Dec. 14 on an issue of $10,000,000 sewer revenue bonds.

AMARILLO, Tex., Nov. 15 -- The Texas Seventh Court of Civil Appeals held today that it would be legal for the Santa Fe Railway System and the International Association of Machinists to enter a union shop agreement.

The clash between the military junta that in effect rules Egypt and the popular but powerless President of the republic, General Naguib, is one of those events that have an air of inevitability once they occur. Friction between President Naguib and Premier Nasser, head of the Revolution Command Council, goes back almost to the first days of the overthrow of King Farouk in July, 1952.
GENEVA, Nov. 15 -- One important issue dividing the Western powers already has been pushed firmly into the background at the Geneva trade conference.

Directors of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., declared a year-end dividend yesterday of $2.50 a share on the concern's common stock. The disbursement is payable on Dec. 14 to holders of record on Nov. 22.

The New York Knickerbockers meet the Baltimore Bullets in the feature of a National Basketball Association double - header at Madison Square Garden tonight. Paired in the opener are the Syracuse Nationals and Philadelphia Warriors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that it had received replies from two of the seventeen health and accident insurance companies it charged last month with false and misleading advertising.

Philip Morris (Australia), Ltd., will soon offer for subscription 600,000 ordinary shares at 20 shillings ($2.25) a share, it was announced yesterday by Alfred E. Lyon, chairman of Philip Morris Co., Ltd., Inc., the parent company here.
CHICAGO, Nov. 15 -- After a sagging tendency most of the session yesterday, wheat spurted well above the previous close.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 16 (AP) -- John Bromwich, for-mem member of the Australian Davis Cup team, turned in one of the big surprises of the New South Wales tennis championships today when he eliminated teen-age Lewis Hoad, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 7 -- 5, in the quarter-finals.

Mrs. Lewis Turner of 969 Park Avenue will be the hostess at a brunch at her home on Friday for members of the committee arranging the annual theatre benefit for the Play Schools Association. The Nov. 30 and Dec. 1 performances of Graham Greene's tragedy "The Living Room," starring Barbara Bel Geddes, which opens tomorrow at Henry Miller's theatre, have been selected for the benefit.
The First, Lady made an impromptu visit to New York yesterday and had a busy day of decisions in the city's shops.

Charles Laughton is planning a nation-wide tour of Shakespeare's violent drama, "Richard III," with Robert Newton, one of Britain's top-flight film players, portraying the title role of the deformed, crafty monarch.
Union and employer negotiators on New York's strike-groggy waterfront agreed yesterday to ask Federal mediators to help settle their dispute over terms of a new two-year contract.

ROME, Nov. 15 -- The extreme left-wing parties suffered a severe defeat in elections for regional councils in the semiautonomous Province bf Val d'Aosta. Their share of the total vote dropped since last year's national elections from 42.3 to 30.9 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (UP) -- Senator Samuel J. Ervin Jr., Democrat of North Carolina, said today Senator Joseph R. McCarthy reminded him of Uncle Ephraim and the Lord.

Herman E. Goodman, president of Hego Fabrics and the Herman E. Goodman Corporation, will leave the active management of these companies to rejoin Robbins Mills, Inc., in an executive capacity, it was announced yesterday.

Communist torpedo boats have won their most important action to date over the naval forces of Nationalist China. Off the Tachen Islands they have been able to sink a destroyer escort, one of the larger ships under the command of Chiang Kai-shek. This is a part of the sporadic warfare for control of the island groups off the Chinese mainland that are still held by the Nationalists.
COLOMBO, Nov. 15 -- The Ceylonese Government will ask the World Bank for a new loan to cover a substantial part of the $20,000,000 capital needed for a Development Corporation to be established soon.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The President knows the complexity of the "security" standards for Government servants that, in its latest manifestation, caused the dismissal of John Paton Davies and the cartooning of Secretary of State Dulles as a cruel administrator and a cowardly man.

Recent progress of the free nations toward political and economic stability, puts it up to the United States now to "push forward" development of freer international trade, it was declared yesterday by Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

YONKERS, Nov. 15 -- A closing night crowd of 29,237 poured $2,151,176 through the machines for a harness racing record mutuel handle under the lights as Yonkers Raceway drew the curtain on the 1954 Metropolitan season tonight.
The annual Village Fair of the First Presbyterian Church will be held this Friday, from 3 to 10 P. M., in the church house, 7 West Eleventh Street.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- In a quiet trading session many of the leading industrials were dull today, shedding a few pence to about three shillings (42 cents). However, some of them closed above the day's lowest levels.

Governor Dewey announced yesterday that he would become senior partner in the law firm of Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer Wood, one of the largest in the city and nation, when he leaves public office at the end of next month.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Increased costs and a requested increase in rate of return from 5 3/4 to 6 1/2 per cent are given by the Panhandle Eastern Pipeline Company as reasons to raise its Wholesale gas rates to produce an increase of about $12,000,000 a year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Senator Francis Case said today he would not vote to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy on charges of having abused Brig. Gen. Ralph W. Zwicker.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 15 -- The Iron Curtain countries brought the "peace offensive" technique into the eighth general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today.

Southern Methodist's upset of Arkansas produced the only major change in The United Press college football poll yesterday, as the "big three" of U. C. L. A., Ohio State and Oklahoma remained at the top.

CAIRO, Nov. 15 -- Foreign diplomatic and business circles today regarded the removal of Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib from the Presidency as a stabilizing move. Egyptians took the President's ouster calmly.

It was 6 o'clock, the time the days died with a sudden turn from light to deep gray and then darkness. A slight pain touched my solar plexus, but I had spent three uneventful weeks at sea and I passed it off to indigestion.

Ward French, one of the major figures in the concert business and a pioneer in the organized concert-audience movement in this country, was "relieved" yesterday of his office as president of Community Concerts, Inc. He had held the position for more than twenty years.

LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Old-age pensioners, increasing rapidly in this country as they are in the United States, are being wooed by Conservative and Laborite politicians as the possible key to the next general election.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The Supreme Court ruled today that the constitutional rights of an Indian hero killed in the Korean War were not violated when a Sioux City, Iowa, cemetery refused to permit his body to be buried there.
The General Dynamics Corporation and its subsidiary increased the nine-month net income by 37 per cent to a record $12,844,834 from $9,337,061 earned in the same period last year.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 15 -- In recognition of his long leadership in American literature, Robert Frost, now in his eightieth year, received a Doctor of Laws Degree tonight from the University of Cincinnati.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 15 -- Representatives of the Philadelphia Civic Grand Opera Company and the Philadelphia La Scala Opera Company agreed late today to merge under the name of the Philadelphia Grand Opera Company.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- A 1955 Westchester County gross budget of $45,959,417, which would provide $5,383,000 in cash for capital improvements and yet produce a lower tax rate, was proposed to the Board of Supervisors today by County Executive James D. Hopkins.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 15 -Lionel Barrymore died tonight at Valley Hospital in Van Nuys. He was 76 years old. His physician, John Paul Ewing, attributed his death to a heart ailment.

In what is in effect the first official reply to the latest Soviet effort to wreck Western unity President Eisenhower has sent the Paris agreements to the Senate with a request for immediate study and prompt approval when it meets again in January.

The seven-story commercial building at 127-29 Prince Street has been sold by Milton Fox and others to Ethel Shumsky who plans to hold the property for investment. The building is on a plot 40 by 94 feet and has an el about 46 by 23 feet.
A Wall Street customer's man was under arrest yesterday on charges that he had fleeced clients of $200,000 with high-sounding sales talks about nonexistent stock mergers and utility companies.

JUST, before the Army-Columbia game at Baker Field a few weks ago, the gray-uniformed cadet cheering section broke out a huge banner which read: "Happy Anniversary, Lou." Then the cadets sang it to the tune of "Happy Birthday." Unfortunately, no one apprised the West Point football team of the significance which lay in the Silver Anniversary of Lou Little as Columbia football coach. So the unthinking Black Knights clobbered the Lions, 67 to 12.

Ventriloquism, an act that never has become strongly entrenched as evening television entertainment, will be featured on two new Saturday morning programs for children. Both shows start this week over the N. B. C.-TV network.

Steel operations are slated this week at 78.9 per cent of theoretical capacity. This should produce an estimated 1,882,000 tons of ingots and steel for castings, which would exceed the record for this year established last week.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation is turning its attention to the north. Conrad Hilton, president, completed negotiations yesterday for the Hilton Hotel organization to manage the Canadian National Railways' new $20,000,000 hotel, the Queen Elizabeth, now rising in Montreal.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 15 -- The financial obligations inherent in a strong national defense can better be supported through constructive land-use conservation policies, the Soil Conservation Society of America was told today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was told today where he could find who promoted Maj. Irving Peress, the Army dentist whom he has accused of being a Communist.
A representative of a resident buying office criticized textile mills yesterday for too-heavy cutbacks in production.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- The Premier of the Sudan, Ismail El Azhari said today his Government was "sorry" for the deposition of General Naguib as Egypt's President.
The trial of four adolescents charged with murder began yesterday in Brooklyn and was adjourned quickly until Nov. 22 when a defense lawyer said he had not had enough time to prepare the case.

A wide variety of what-will-they-think-of-next items designed to assist advertisers and agencies in their work went on display yesterday at the Biltmore Hotel. The occasion was the third Advertising Essentials Show put on by the Advertising Trades Institute.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- Following are excerpts from a hearing of this morning of the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today declined to rule on the validity of a Federal Power Commission license for construction of a power dam on the East Fork of the Chippewa River in Sawyer County, Wis. The dam is planned by the Winter Electric Light and Power Company of Wisconsin.

MELBOURNE, Nov. 15 (UP) --The four Austraian tennis stars who successfully defended the Davis Cup against the United States in 1953 were chosen again today to represent the Aussies in this year's challenge cup.

SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- With the deer season opening in Vermont yesterday, and this borderline county opening today, there were almost as many hunters as deer, and apparently there were a few of the latter with antlers, for we heard at least fifty Shots during the course of the day.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Parke Carroll today was named vice president and business manager of the new Kansas City Athletics of the American League.

Two city firemen were accused yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. of taking $250 in connection with refrigeration and air-conditioning inspection. Mr. Cavanagh charged the firemen with kicking back part of the sum.
A new medical research institution is being setup for applying sensitive measuring techniques of the physical sciences to biological studies, particularly to the study of human diseases.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) -- Following are texts of letters from Senator Francis Caze, Republican of South Dakota, and Secretary of the Army Robert T. Stevens:

ALBANY, Nov. 15 -- The outgoing Dewey Administration must share "some of the basic responsibility" for the state's 1955-56 budget, Governor-elect Averell Harriman's prospective Budget Director said today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 -- The United States Military Academy at West Point and the Naval Academy at Annapolis have forbidden participation by cadets or midshipmen in college debates on whether the United States should recognize Communist China.

I have friends who have been held on Ellis Island pending the decisions as to their status in the United States. Their stay on Ellis Island was distressing enough, but now that Ellis Island has been closed for reasons of economy, we are told, their condition is most unfortunate. The men are sent to a house of detention in White Plains and the women to a prison, also in Westchester, N. Y.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 15 -- The United States delegation, with the authorization of President Eisenhower, announced today that the Atomic Energy Commission had allocated 220 pounds of fissionable material for use by other countries under the United States' atoms-for-peace program.
LONDON, Nov. 15 -- Sir Anthony Eden told his countrymen tonight that changes in Soviet tactics did not mean changes in Soviet objectives.

PARIS, Nov. 15 -- The leader of the Tunisian nationalist movement, Habib Bourguiba, accused the French today of obstructing talks and forcing the Tunisians to fight for their independence. He is negotiating indirectly with the French Government for internal autonomy for Tunisia.
TORONTO, Nov. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Spain won the international jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair tonight. West Germany was second.

An examination of the books of the Civil Rights Congress was begun yesterday by a joint legislative committee seeking to determine whether that and other organizations were diverting to propaganda purposes funds collected in the name of philanthropy.

There were 32,818 fans at Jamaica yesterday. They were there to say au revoir -- fond or otherwise -- to the thoroughbred horse, who won't be seen in local competition again until April Fool's Day, 1955.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Cardinal Spellman of New York said today the statements made by Msgr. Edward Martin of New York concerning Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin were "none of my business."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Enrico Fermi of the University of Chicago today became the first winner of a special award -- $25,000 -- from the Atomic Energy Commission for "especially meritorious contributions" in atomic energy.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 16 -- A 1,000-page photographic facsimile edition of the 1623 First Folio of Shakespeare's plays will be issued tomorrow by the Yale University Press. It is known as the Poor Man's Folio.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 16 -- Princeton's football team went through a stiff defensive workout against the junior varsity this afternoon in preparation for the clash with Dartmouth in Palmer Stadium Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Eisenhower called today for a better understanding between the peoples of the United States and the Soviet Union. Only thus can man's dream of a lasting peace be realized, he declared in sounding a new note of conciliation.
TRENTON, Nov. 16 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, seized the offensive today in the political hot war initiated yesterday by the Republican majority in the State Senate.
The election of Lester D. Egbert as a trustee of Columbia University was announced yesterday. Mr. Egbert is president of Brown, Crosby Co., Inc., New York insurance concern.
As Thanksgiving approaches we at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House are once again hoping to make this holiday one of real meaning for the many elderly men and women who belong to our Friendship Club.

BEGINNING today the Whitney Museum will show 100 works of art from the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Neuberger. This is the second time the museum has shown the major part of a contemporary collection, having begun the series with the showing two years ago of work in the collection of Mr. and Mrs. Milton Lowenthal.

Earnings of the Royal McBee Corporation, manufacturer of typewriters and other office equipment, were off for the fiscal quarter ended Oct. 31, but "we look forward confidently to a substantial improvement" during the next three quarters, Allan A. Ryan, chairman, reported yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Britain's top soccer team, the "Wolves," retrieved Britain's prestige and salved sorely wounded national pride by trouncing the Moscow Spartaks by 4 -- 0 tonight.
Directors of the B. F. Goodrich Company yesterday authorized a two-for-one split of the common stock and an 80-cent dividend for distribution on Dec. 31 to holders of record of Dec. 7.

TORONTO, Nov. 16 -- The Ontario Securities Commission today lifted the requirement that brokers comply with United States Securities and Exchange Commission regulations when selling Canadian stocks south of the border.

Thirty local housing authorities having subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration borrowed $103,288,000 in the public market yesterday on short-term notes due from May 6, 1955, to April 6, 1956.

The first annual award of the Ambrose Monell medal for "distinguished achievement in mineral technology" was made last night to Dr. Lloyd M. Pidgeon, head of the Department of Metallurgical Engineering at the University of Toronto.

I feel that John Foster Dulles performed an excellent service to his country in dismissing John Paton Davies Jr. from the State Department. Mr. Davies' attitude toward the Nationalist Government of China left much to be desired. His perspective in relation to a number of situations caused the American people to believe that all was not as it should be.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- An American flag was attached today to the first column of the top floor of Chicago's newest skyscraper, the forty-one-story, $40,000,000 Prudential Building, more than 600 feet above ground.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Eisenhower learns something about politics every day, and frankly he doesn't like what he learns.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A program to add to United States history the variety and richness hidden in the personal papers of great men was presented today to President Eisenhower.
A psychiatric specialist in children's neuroses recommended yesterday that the disturbed child be taken from his own family and placed with another in the community.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- President Eisenhower applauded today the broadening of education in the United States. He gave large credit for it to the land-grant colleges.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, slated to become chairman of the House Un-American Activities Committee in the new Congress, today gave up his fight to abolish the group.
A miracle that residents of New York City long have awaited, but never before have beheld, is now on view: something in this town that was being destroyed has been rescued and restored.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Vice President Julio Lozano Diaz became acting President today in the absence of President Juan Manuel Galvez, who left for Panama, probably to undergo medical treatment.

A mahogany plaque nearly as big around as an automobile wheel was presented yesterday to the Advertising Council to mark its first annual Advertising Council Day observance today. The gift, which reproduces the council's seal appearing in newspaper advertising and all other campaign material, came from a committee representing the campaigns that benefit annually from the various council programs in the public interest.
A drive to raise funds among investment and brokerage houses for a new building for the Graduate School of Business Administration, New York University, was begun yesterday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 -- Los Angeles' periodic sieges of smog are due primarily to its millions of automobiles and backyard incinerators, it was reported authoritatively today.

The New York United Service Organizations Defense Fund yesterday took 140 members of the armed forces on a tour of various sections of the city. Much of the venture, labeled U. S. O.-Pal Day, was arranged by the B. Altman, Arnold Constable, Gimbels, Macy's and Stern's department stores.
Mayor Wagner's program for setting up a city multiple dwelling code to control "trickster" landlords and halt the growth of slums went to the City Council yesterday.

Gerald Tarack and Jerome Maggid are violinists in the Radio City Music Hall Orchestra. Last spring they used their spare time to organize a series of three concerts at Carnegie Recital Hall and last night they opened a new series there. This one will consist of five concerts.

I needed fish for myself and Meekie, my black cat, and after throwing my line over the side without a bite, decided to try my luck aft. My bait, a flying fish, had landed on the deck the night before. Fastening my worn tuna line to the crosslog that served as a rail on the stern, I threw the baited double hook over and let out 200 feet of line.
CAMP LEJEUNE, N. C., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Thousands of Marines came plunging ashore today from a giant force of Navy ships and wrested a beachhead from a "foreign" invader who had occupied the area.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Rutgers squad went through the week's first full-dress practice today, with pass defense getting the spotlight. Coach Harvey Harman indicated, after getting a scouting report on Columbia, that he'll take to the air most of the time Saturday.
Stockholders and employes of the Eastman Kodak Company can face the Christmas shopping season with more enhusiasm following dividend action of the company's directors yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the fifth day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

TORONTO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Spain tonight won the international two-and-two competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair Horse Show. West Germany was second, the United States third and Mexico fourth.
OTTAWA, Nov. 16 -- No useful purpose would be served by a Soviet-proposed meeting of representatives of more than a score of countries on European security, Premier Pierre Mendes-France said today.
A residence hall for 500 students and faculty members of the New York University School of Law will be built on Washington Square West. Construction will start the first of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Steel and durable consumer goods, particularly autos, set the pace in a slight pick-up in industrial production during the past six weeks, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

TRENTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The New Jersey Highway Authority sold $20,000,000 worth of Garden State Parkway bonds today to a financial syndicate headed by four New York concerns at a net interest cost of 3.2364 per cent.
JERSEY CITY, Nov. 16 -- A section of this city's $41,000,000 Medical Center was rented today to Seton Hall University for use as a school of medicine and dentistry.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 16 -- An addition to the proposed Inter-American Cultural and Trade Center in the form of a world fair was outlined here today. The fair is expected to attract 15,000,000 visitors the first year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Powerful Republicans would look very coldly upon any plan to bring the Democratic leaders into regular domestic legislative discussions with President Eisenhower in the next Congress.

During the past ten years there has been a growing realization in our State Department, as among the leading art organizations of the country, of the importance of the cultural life of the nation in our relations with foreign countries. This awareness is evidenced by the many bills recently introduced in Congress to centralize, reorganize and further subsidize our federal art activities.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- Gov. Theodore R. McKeldin of Maryland warned today that the rapid spread to suburban living in this country was lessening the intelligent interest of American citizens in good government.
The National Probation and Parole Association announced yesterday the beginning of a five-year program to fight juvenile delinquency.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 16 (AP) -- An all-Australian final was assured today in the New South Wales tennis championship when Ham Richardson of Baton Rouge, La., was eliminated. But the stunning surprise came when John Bromwich upset the Davis Cup star, Lewis Hoad.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Roxy is "Desiree," the Twentieth Century-Fox film version of the Anna Selinko novel, with Jean Simmons in the title role co-starring with Marlon Brando as Napoleon.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 16 -- While the Governor and the Bishop of the Province of Corrientes were issuing a statement to the effect that no church-state problem exists, three priests were being brought from Cordoba to this capital under arrest today for "anti-Government activities."

Net income of the United Corporation, once one of the largest utility holding companies in the country but now being converted into an investment company, will be $4,100,000 for 1954. This was reported yesterday following a meeting of directors. United derives all its income from dividends on investments.
The New York City Housing Authority is seeking authorization for the construction of more than 20,000 additional low-income and middle-income dwelling units.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Nov. 16 -- The inaugural airline flight on the Arctic route from the West Coast of the United States to Europe was completed today five minutes ahead of the estimated time of arrival.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Israel and the Arab states were chided today by the new head of the United Nations agency now caring for 900,000 Arab refugees made homeless by the 1948 Palestine war.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 16 -- A chemical that concentrates selectively in cancer tissues, offering promise as a new weapon against malignant growths, was described today at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

MOSCOW, Nov. 16 -- Using much plainer words, the Soviet Union today reiterated its warning that, if the Western powers persisted in the arming of West Germany, Russia and her allies would be obliged to consider new measures for their own defense.
A nation-wide investment banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., will offer to the public today $50,000,000 of 3 1/8 per cent debentures of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Nov. 16 (UP) -- The Florida Supreme Court today criticized the United States Supreme Court's anti-segregation decision as "a great mistake."

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Gen. Bonner Fellers, who won the Distinguished Service Medal during World War II, was appointed today executive director of For America, an educational and nonpolitical organization devoted to spreading the principles of Americanism.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 16 -- Dr. Eugen Gerstenmaier, a leading member of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic party, was elected today President of the West German Bundestag, lower house of Parliament, to succeed the late Dr. Hermann Ehlers. Dr. Gerstenmaier was chairman of the Bundestag's Foreign Affairs Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Producers, directors and actors who rose to fame with Lionel Barrymore will attend a funeral service for him on Thursday at the Calvary Cemetery Mausoleum Chapel. Mr. Barrymore's body will be buried in a crypt beside that of his wife, Irene Fenwick, the actress, and his brother, John.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today forestalled a major airline strike threatened for next Friday by creating an emergency board to investigate the dispute. The members of the board were not named immediately.

MONTROSE, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- For the sixth time in two years, the voters in School District 3, which includes most of the suburban area of the town of Cortlandt, went to the polls today over the issue of a new elementary school. This time they approved the plan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 16 -- Columbia Pictures will enter the arena of play-financing on an international scale, underwriting theatrical ventures that have a motion-picture potential.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 16 (AP) -- A tape recorder will be the soloist Thursday and Friday at two performances of the Los Angeles Philharmonic Orchestra.

The nation's paper industry is headed for the second best year in its history, it was announced yesterday by E. W. Tinker, executive secretary of the American Paper and Pulp Association. Production is running just a shade under the record volume of last year.

STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 16 -- Leaders of five communities paid tribute today to the record of human salvage established in the last ten years by the Rehibilitation Center for the Physically Handicapped, Inc.
One of the top officials of the city's hospital system was demoted and temporarily suspended yesterday for having work done on his private property by a patient in a city home.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 (UP) Senator Herman Welker told the Senate today that some of its members had been led from the chamber because they were drunk.

A new biography of Denis Diderot, eighteenth century French philosopher, will be published next Wednesday by the Michigan State College Press. The title will be "The Embattled Philosopher." The last biography of Diderot in English appeared more than seventy-five years ago.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Britain gracefully backed down today on an action firmly described as "final" a year ago, and allowed an African people to call back their deposed King, if they accept a new constitutional status for him.

THE magic of theatre touched television on Monday evening. Through the facilities of the N. B. C. network there was presented a fine production of "State of the Union," the Pulitzer Prize comedy by Howard Lindsay and Russel Crouse, with Margaret Sullavan giving a radiant performance as the wife of a would-be President of the United States.

The defense of free Asia against further Communist penetration now depends chiefly on intensifying its economic improvement and on opening new export markets to Japan, the forty-first National Foreign Trade Convention was told yesterday.
BRIDGEPORT, Pa., Nov. 16 (AP) -- James Lees Sons Co., one of the nation's major carpet manufacturers, announced today it is discontinuing the manufacture of woolen carpet yarns.
RENO, Nev., Nov. 16 (AP) -- Maj. James Call waived extradition to New York today to face charges of slaying a Lake Placid policeman.
Plans for raising the balance of a $252,881 operating budget for the current fiscal year were discussed yesterday at the first directors' meeting of the Manhattanville Community Centers, Inc.

Horace Stoneham's vacation trip to Puerto Rico was a fruitful one. While there the Giant president signed two of his key players, Willie Mays and Ruben Gomez, Secretary Eddie Brannick revealed yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- The General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee broke an old impasse this afternoon and brought the Special United Nations Fund for Economic Development one step closer to reality.

An international organization within the framework of the United Nations was suggested yesterday to deal with the problems of overpopulation. This is "the next logical step" in solving the food and economic worries of many countries, Dr. William Vogt, national director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Official results revealed today that V. Vorisov of Russia, and not his countryman, A. Bogdanov, shot a world-record-equaling perfect score of 400 in the master marksman competition, prone position with .22 caliber rifle at fifty meters, in the world shooting championships yesterday.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 16 -- Gov. Herman E. Talmadge of Georgia declared today that it was "crucial" to the South's expanding economy that Congress approve tax relief legislation for industries and farmers engaged in forestry conservation practices.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- What does the Soviet Union mean by "peaceful fur coexistence," which is the underlying theme of all its present diplomatic efforts? What are the terms and conditions for "coexistence?" How long would it last?
Turkey's merchant marine will grow by almost 70,000 tons and eleven vessels within the next twenty months under the term of a ship purchase and construction agreement signed here yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Lowell (Red) Dawson today resigned as football coach at the University of Pittsburgh to accept a job in private business. His three-year contract had been scheduled to expire Feb. 1.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Nov. 16 -- The traditional New Eng- land town meeting was preserved for New Canaan today when residents defeated by 1,066 to 858 votes a motion introducing the representative type of government.

The board of directors of the Association on American Indian Affairs charged yesterday that the present Congress had passed and President Eisenhower had approved bills dictating the "extermination" of Indians as such.
The Board of Education was charged yesterday with erecting a Bronx elementary school for which there were no pupils.

Dr. Harry D. Gideonse, president of Brooklyn College, affirmed yesterday that whether or not the United States should recognize Communist China would be debated by the college team in intercollegiate tournaments.

A consolidated net income of $3,906,000 was realized by the United States Lines Company and its subsidiaries in the first nine months this year, John M. Franklin, president of the shipping company, reported yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- A Budapest radio broadcast said tonight that Noel Field and his wife, Herta, who disappeared behind the Iron Curtain in 1949, had been released.
Mediators moved in yesterday on the sluggish negotiations between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.

Hardly had Mr. Lodge announced in the U. N. that the United States will allocate 220 pounds of fissionable material to the international agency which the President would create to carry out his "atoms-for-peace" proposal than Britain followed with an allocation of forty-four pounds -- a powerful endorsement.

Oldsmobile has gone in for styling changes, a wide scope of colors and increased engine power in the 1955 line announced yesterday by Oldsmobile division, General Motors Corporation. The new models will be displayed in dealer showrooms throughout the New York metropolitan area on Friday.
The nation's colleges and universities were cautioned yesterday against producing "partly educated" men and women who are proficient in a skill but know little of the finer things of life.

In all the discussions on juvenile delinquency we are led to believe that this is a new development in our city. The children of today are very little different from those of forty or fifty years ago. I taught in our New York school system from 1908 to 1912 and to this very day I still dream of being attacked by the class I was teaching.
BUFFALO, Nov. 16 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery made his peace with Buffalo today.
Jean Wentworth, pianist, the third artist to be presented this season as a winner of the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation Award, made her recital debut at Town Hall yesterday afternoon.

Many dinner parties will be given before the theatre party to be held at tonight's performance of "Peter Pan" at the Winter Garden. The benefit will aid the Third Street Music School Settlement. Mrs. Bruce Bromley, a director of the settlement, is committee chairman for the event.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- A proud forty-three-pound turkey christened Kentucky Colonel had his moment in the limelight today en route to the chopping block and President Eisenhower's Thanksgiving Day dinner table at Augusta, Ga.
A national campaign to get 10,000,000 signatures on pro-McCarthy petitions by Nov. 25 continued to roll yesterday at its headquarters in the Roosevelt Hotel.

The problem of "coexistence" -- that equivocal concept thrown into the international debate by the Soviets as a substitute for real peace -- has come to the fore again as a result of two new developments. One of them is the stepped-up Soviet campaign against the Paris agreements, featured by Soviet threats of counter-measures unless these agreements are buried in an immediate all-European "security" conference.

PARIS, Nov. 16 -- The revolution in Egypt is not yet over and the principal reason for this is the accumulated misery of fifty centuries. Poverty, disease and lassitude are fastened around the Egyptian people like the sticky mud of the Nile. It will require prolonged effort to prod the nation from its ancient lethargy into the twentieth century.

OFF the playing field Ralph Kiner is a man who possesses charm, intelligence and personality. He's an admirable fellow. On the playing field Ralph Kiner is a man who hits an occasional long ball. Period.

THE other evening I sat at dinner beside one of the most distinguished of living American historians, a life-long student of Jefferson, Hamilton, Washington, Adams and their great contemporaries. What, I inquired, had those men in common which made them great? "Energy," the historian replied, "energy far beyond that of ordinary men."

Bankers' dollar acceptances outstanding in the United States increased seasonally during October by $78,506,000 to a total on Oct. 31 of $687,252,000, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday. This sum, which is $170,530,000, or 33 per cent greater than a year ago, is the largest since the $750,127,000 total on Feb. 28, 1934.
The New York Rangers will meet the Boston Bruins in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight.
The 1955 March of Dimes Poster Girl is 5-year-old Mary Kosloski of Collierville, Tenn. This was announced yesterday by Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis.

Five nominations for a referee to keep labor peace on the municipal subway system have been sent to the Transit Authority and the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., by James P. Mitchell, United States Secretary of Labor.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams asked the public yesterday to withhold judgment on the traffic "courtesy card" scandal and to try to understand the police department's "real problems."

CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner, one of baseball's great home run sluggers, moved to the Cleveland Indians from the Chicago Cubs today in a surprise waiver deal that reunited Kiner with his old friend and team-mate, General Manager Hank Greenberg.

ALBANY, Nov. 16 -- Despite a decrease in the amount of money wagered at both harness and flat tracks, the state collected a record-breaking $59,110,065 from its racing taxes for the season that closed yesterday.

The city will start a survey within two weeks to find out how many long-term patients in the municipal hospital system could be transferred to "homesteads." In these new institutions they would receive rehabilitation in more pleasant surroundings -- and at less cost -- than in a general hospital.

A five-story office building and three apartment houses at 1919-29 Broadway and 103-07 West Sixty-fourth Street, the northwest corner, have been sold by Adelaide G. and Adelaide L. Martins to an investing client of Reuben Lesser, attorney, through the Charles F. Noyes Company. The property fronts 105 feet on Broadway and is assessed at $296,000, of which $262,000 is land value.
SEOUL, Korea, Wednesday, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The United States and the Republic of Korea today announced agreement on the $700,000,000 American aid program to Korea.
Four teen-agers, members of a youth gang, were charged with felonious assault yesterday afternoon in the beating of a 19-year-old Queens student last Tuesday.
The machinery was started yesterday for the first ouster of a policeman as a direct result of the Brooklyn investigation into a racket in "courtesy cards" for traffic offenders.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 16 -- Peruvian air and naval forces have seized five ships of a whaling fleet operated by Aristotle Onassis, Greek-born shipowner. The Government announced today the vessels had hunted whales inside the 200-mile offshore zone claimed by Peru.

HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- The first two races of the Western Hemisphere snipe championship were sailed today off the Miramar Yacht Club. Entries from the United States, the Bahamas, Bermuda, Brazil, Canada and Cuba are competing in the six-race series.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 16 -- While Yale nursed its injuries of the Princeton and Army games, Harvard went through a stiff scrimmage behind closed gates today for Saturday's football finale with the Elis.

The New York Knickerbockers missed an opportunity to take first place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association last night when they bowed to the Baltimore Bullets, 110 to 107, in the feature of a double-header at Madison Square Garden.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- By unanimous decision of its governing body which began meeting in Rome today, the question of forced labor will be discussed in next year's general conference of the International Labor Office.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 16 (UP) -- William David Griffith, 57 years old, of Columbus, for many years a sports publicist, died shortly before midnight yesterday after his car was struck by a Pennsylvania Railroad freight train at a suburban grade crossing.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The London News Chronicle printed today a poem, "Winniehaha," inspired by a remark by Capt. Lionel Leslie, a cousin of the Prime Minister, that Sir Winston Churchill inherited a trace of Indian blood through his grandmother, Clara Jerome.

Automobile finance companies and commercial banks, working together, can bring automobile ownership to many Americans unable to afford a car now, Robert L. Oare declared yesterday. He is the new president of the American Finance Conference.

The long-waisted and flared-back silhouettes figured prominently in Jay Thorpe's presentation yesterday of Martini holiday designs for the after-six hours. The showing was held at the Waldorf-Astoria.
For a short while yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, a 38-year-old woman thought she had been mistaken for an international celebrity.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- Britain pledged forty-four pounds of fissionable material today to the atoms-for-peace program sponsored by the United States and other Western atomic powers.
Whether the W. T. Grant Company will take control of Zeller's, Ltd., Canadian variety chain, will be decided on Monday at a meeting of Zeller stockholders in Montreal.
HALIFAX, N. S., Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Crew members of the 7,111-ton Panamanian freighter Stork manned the pumps tonight as the storm-crippled ship edged near the west coast of Newfoundland.

Lionel Barrymore was not so much an actor as a beloved American institution. In his autobiography, "We Barrymores," he spoke of "my frustrations as a painter, my preoccupation with music and my obsession with the idea that I wanted to escape from the theatre."

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Prime Minister Churchill disclosed in Parliament today that he had consulted the Duke of Windsor last May before permitting publication of the captured German war records that referred to the Duke. Regarding those references Sir Winston said "they are, of course, quite untrue."

Eleven radio stations in the metropolitan area participated early today in a nation-wide test of CONELRAD, a system for communicating civil defense information without providing guidance for enemy aircraft. The exercise was conducted from 1:30 to 4:30 A. M.
The Giants, who have surprised even themsellves by achieving the lead in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League, have "a rough road ahead."

Indications of an upward turn in sales of television receivers for the rest of the year emanated from several sources yesterday. Allen B. DuMont Laboratories, Inc., reported October sales of receivers 10 per cent above the 1953 level.
The Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, which is not yet three months old as a corporate entity, is already planning a century ahead.

Tonight more than a thousand of his friends are getting together at a dinner to pay tribute to a kindly, high-principled citizen of New York. There was never a better excuse for a meal or a meeting. For Stanley M. Isaacs, now minority leader of the City Council, has long been a warmhearted supporter of every deserving cause.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today that the honorable discharge of Maj. Irving Peress was "a routine thing in the Army" on which he had not been consulted.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Chairman of the Special Censure Committee, demanded in the Senate today additional censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for his conduct during the current debate.

The Christmas gift season is getting an early start these days at, of all places, Fort Jay on Governors Island. Amateur jewelers, leather workers, ceramics makers and others are devising attractive items, many of which will turn up in the Christmas stockings of their friends.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission received a recommendation today from one of its examiners to end racial segregation on all trains and in all stations of railroads operating in interstate commerce.

George L. Bagby, president of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., will give a tea today in his apartment at the Waldorf-Astoria for members of the subscription committee for the annual Bagby Concert.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Wednesday, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins said today the United States planned to take over the training of South Vietnam's national army from the French.

LONDON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The World Boxing Championship Committee today banned the controversial "return bout" clause in title fights and said the group would not recognize a bout if the "return" was included in a contract.
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (UP) -- Dr. Fermi said tonight the award would not have been possible without the help of "many younger men."
Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein charged the Democratic organization of Albany County yesterday with "the wholesale buying of votes" in the election.

A rich period in the city's formative years, from the time of Washington's inauguration to the opening of the Erie Canal, is reflected in an exhibition opening today at the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 16 -- Taking advantage of mild weather today, the Dartmouth football team held a long practice session to prepare for Saturday's meeting with Princeton. Coach Tuss McLaughry started with individual offensive drills for his backs and ends, and quickly shifted to the main work of the afternoon, defense against the Tiger singlewing.

Nathan Straus, owner of radio station WMCA, will present a series of weekly editorials over his own station beginning Friday from 9:30 to 9:45 P. M. He will voice the editorials in the name of the station "to stimulate community thinking on public issues."
CHICAGO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock market here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
SHUSHAN, N. Y., Nov. 16 -- According to Oakey Butcher, who has roamed these wooded ridges and valleys for more than thirty years, the situation today was unique.

The United States has fallen to ninth place among the world's shipbuilding nations and is now responsible for but 2 per cent of the merchant tonnage under construction or on order, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday.

Events today: Wheeler Beckett Orchestra of New York, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15, and the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Joseph Fuchs, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.
Bomb experts of the Police Department searched the orchestra floor of Radio City Music Hall last night in a vain hunt for a bomb. Someone had telephoned the theatre that a bomb was about to go off.

A handsome dessert that is surprisingly easy to prepare is a spiced apple meringue cake. It makes use of plentiful apples and such short cuts as a pound cake purchased at the store and, by way of frosting, beaten egg white that is browned in a hot oven.

There seems to be a lack of clear thinking in the decision by our military authorities that West Point cadets and Annapolis midshipmen may not participate -- apparently on either side -- in collegiate debates regarding the question of United States recognition of Communist China.
The principal feature of last night's Town Hall recital by the violinist and composer Ralph Hollander was the first performance of his "Psalm Cycle," for solo violin and dramatic actress.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Rica Rosie, a New York invader owned by W. Arnold Hanger, drove to a two-length victory over Carry the News in the Harford Purse at Pimlico today.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The House of Commons rejected tonight a Labor party motion censuring the Government for its policy on old-age pensions. The vote was 305 to 284.
The National Maritime Union, C. I. O., agreed yesterday to open its hiring hall to nonmembers.

LONDON, Nov. 16 -- The United States in modern times faces "a supreme test of character and wisdom," the Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Geoffrey Fisher, told a British-American audience at the Pilgrims dinner tonight.
Cocoa prices continued to fall yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. All positions tumbled the daily limit of 1 cent a pound on 245 contracts.
Three transfers of major league franchises to other cities, the most recent moving the Athletics to Kansas City, have stirred the civic spirit in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- "Peaceful coexistence" does not mean in Washington what it seems to mean in Moscow. In fact, the term does not mean the same thing to all men or even to all Government officials here.
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 16 -- The United States called on the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization today to adopt a "streamlined" program to increase efficiency.
Although motors and oils lagged far behind the pace, stocks recovered yesterday from a ragged opening and pushed forward to new highs for the upward movement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 16 -- Wheat futures moved into new high ground for the season for the December, March, May and July deliveries here today. Buying was persistent and absorbed the limited offerings easily. December and March oats futures also registered new tops for the year.

MORTIMER J. DAVIS, who was elected the other day as president of the Society of Former Special Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Inc., is old-school F. B. I. He was a Department of Justice agent from 1917 to 1925, but got out when the bureau, as such, was only a year old.

Increases and decreases in selling prices here of 1955 Plymouth and Dodge cars made by the Chrysler Corporation were reported yesterday by dealers. The Plymouth scale is up $25 to $121 and down $45 to $46, while Dodge is $20 to $43 higher and $31 to $106 lower.

BOSTON, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The new president of the Boston Wool Trade Association, the country's principal organization of wool dealers, called today for cooperation with wool grower organizations and the National Association of Wool Manufacturers to maintain and improve the competitive position of wool.

Frozen condensed soups, latest in the quick-to-cook field, have one outstanding advantage. Delicate flavors, especially those of shellfish, survive quick freezing much more successfully than they do conventional canning methods.

ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The Dutch branch of the world-wide Unilever concern is considering applying for the listings of its common stock on the New York Stock Exchange, Dr. Paul Rijkens, president of Dutch Unilever, told a meeting of stockholders here yesterday.

Better known as a novelist, Graham Greene will make his local debut as a dramatist with "The Living Room," starring Barbara Bel Geddes. The event will take place at 8 o'clock this evening at Henry Miller's. The tragedy has a year's run to its credit in London and is prospering in Paris.

AUCKLAND, New Zealand, Nov. 16 -- Despite official denial that the coming United States Antarctic expedition will seek hydrogen bomb test sites, United States intentions in the Antarctic still are receiving keen attention in New Zealand.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these counts:

TOLEDO, Ohio, Nov. 16 (AP) -- Edgar Kaiser, president of the Kaiser Motors Corporation and Willys Motors plans to consolidate all motor vehicle operations of the two companies in Toledo within the next six months and increase output of civilian jeeps and trucks.
BERLIN, Nov. 16 -- Walter Ulbricht, Secretary General of the Socialist Unity (Communist) party has conceded that the program in East Germany to raise living standards is far behind schedule.
The New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program collected 371 pints of blood on Monday, including 123 at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Stephen of Hungary School, 408 East Eighty-second Street.
Bernard M. Baruch called last night for "fresh thinking" at every level to deal with the problems caused by the cold war.

TRENTON, Nov. 16 -- The Federal Government, it was announced here today, will start an intensive two-year study of air pollution in New Jersey soon. The project will be undertaken by the United States Public Health Service in cooperation with the State Bureau of Adult and Industrial Health.

PANAMA, Nov. 16 -- Sources close to the Government reported today that dispatches from the Panamanian-flag whaling fleet operated by Aristotle Onassis said two of the catcher vessels had been machine-gunned 300 miles off Peru's coast and ordered to a Peruvian port.

ROME, Nov. 16 -- The Communists have made political capital for months out of the "bourgeois immorality" they saw in the Wilma Montesi case. Today the police revealed another scandal and preferred charges of immorality against a prominent Communist lawyer who had loudly denounced immorality in others.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 16 (AP) -- The world lightweight champion, Paddy De Marco, will make the first defense of his title tomorrow night and against the man he won it from last March -- Jimmy Carter of South Ozone Park, Queens.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- The White House social season opened tonight with half the diplomatic corps as guests of President and Mrs. Eisenhower. The other half will be entertained tomorrow night.

Governor-elect Averell Harriman commissioned George B. DeLuca, the Lieutenant Governor-elect, yesterday to develop a "step-by-step" program for combating juvenile delinquency for submission to the new Legislature.
Tagged with an investment yield of 3.83 per cent, common stock of the eighty-five-year-old Campbell Soup Company is today joining the ranks of the "blue chips" of America's financial marketplace.

The music of Sergei Rachmaninoff is its own justification for an entire program like the one played last night at Carnegie Hall by Eugene Ormandy and the Philadelphia Orchestra with Alexander Brailowsky as piano soloist.

Stockholders of the Brown Company were urged yesterday by Laurence F. Whittemore, president, to refrain from giving Leopold A. Renaud any proxies to allow Mr. Renaud to represent them at a stockholders' meeting in Portland, Me., on Friday. Mr. Renaud is president of the Montreal brokerage firm bearing his name.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 16 -- With stunning surprise, the state exhibited in court here today the clear print of a "surgical instrument" on the blood-stained pillow of Marilyn Sheppard.
The discovery of a bodily mechanism that appears to play a vital role in determining whether an individual is innately resistant or susceptible to attack by tuberculosis was reported here yesterday.

The complaint of a Colombian businessman that he had been swindled out of $15,925 in an export deal involving thirteen Army-style jeeps resulted yesterday in a grand larceny indictment against a New York concern and two Long Island men.

The chances are fifty-fifty that today's college girl who applies for a job after graduation will offer, in addition to a degree, some working experience, according to a report from the Vassar College Vocational Bureau.

Discounting refreshments, dressing up is the most exciting facet of a children's party. Holiday dresses offered this season will put both mother and daughter in a bright, festive spirit. Colors are gay enough to please youngsters, and mothers are placated with the fuss of starched nylon, handmade lace, lush velvet, tucked broadcloth, delicate eyelet work and wide, prissy bow sashes.
LONDON, Nov. 16 -- Industrial shares strengthened on the stock exchange today though best prices were not always held. Selling slackened and a slight increase of demand found prices sensitive.
BOSTON, Nov. 16 -- Officials of state and municipal fair employment agencies were told today that there was "unquestionably" discrimination against Jews seeking jobs in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 16 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today that a new reserve forces program embodying a continuation of the two-year draft for active duty was almost completed.
The cotton futures market here moved somewhat irregularly yesterday. The close was 2 points off to 6 points up in rather narrow trading.
ONE cannot, perhaps, apply with exact meaning the Broadway phrase "smash hit" to the revival of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association.

HAVANA, Nov. 17 -- After a one-hour delay during which sails hung limp in the absence of a breeze, the nine skippers competing in the Western Hemisphere snipe championship got off this morning on the third race of the series.

One of the primary problems to be faced by a new state administration in Albany, and a question even now involved in the preliminary budget-making process, is that of state aid to localities and particularly for education. Governor-elect Harriman frequently expressed his deep interest in school financial needs during his campaign and, indeed, devoted a last-day tour to assuring upstate voters that he would not cut state aid to rural school districts.

The tendency of some "nonacademic" agencies to invade the functions of the governing boards of state colleges and universities was decried yesterday at a meeting of educational trustees and regents from all over the country.
SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The Puerto Rican Supreme Court reversed today a District Court conviction of Miss Ruth Reynolds of Terraville, S. D., in the 1950 Nationalist revolt here.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 17 -- Coroner Samuel R. Gerber cast further doubt today on the story of Dr. Samuel Sheppard that a burglar killed the doctor's wife, Marilyn.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

The comeback of Ray Robinson, former world welterweight and middleweight champion, is not yet organized, according to the fighter's business manager, Joe Glaser, who denied yesterday that Sugar Ray had signed to box Joe Rindone in Detroit on Dec. 8.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 -- The Matson liner Lurline left for Hawaii today after an eighteen-hour delay attributed to an inter-union dispute.

PARIS, Nov. 17 -- The French Minister for Tunisian and Moroccan Affairs was understood to have talked by telephone today with Premier Pierre Mendes-France in efforts to break a French-Tunisian deadlock over peace in the protectorate.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Plans for financing a power plant under the disputed Dixon-Yates contract with the Federal Government were submitted to the Securities and Exchange Commission today for approval.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 17 -- Despite the continuing eruptions along the Southeast China coast, well - informed United States sources here still do not expect an immediate large-scale Chinese Communist invasion drive against either Formosa, the Pescadores or any of the other major Nationalist-held offshore islands.
The 1955 Cadillac line featuring a 270-horsepower engine, styling advances and mechanical improvements was announced yesterday by the Cadillac division of the General Motors Corporation.

THE attendants at Football's Hall of Fame had better dust off a niche for Warner Woodson, the University of Arizona coach. Here's a guy who rates. He is as deserving of football immortality as Pop Warmer, the inventor of the single-wing attack; Knute Rockne, the inventor of the Four Horsemen; Amos Alonzo Stagg, the inventor of the spiral pass from center, and all the other gridiron titans.

Events today: Searie Wright, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, Clifford Curzon, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Manhattan College Benefit Concert, Town Hall, 8:30; Amor Musicae, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
Pari-mutuel betting at thoroughbred horse race tracks exceeded two billion dollars this year for the second time in history.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 17 (AP) -- The nation's newspaper editors divided sharply today on how much leeway should be given in interpreting news events and in using information from sources who refuse to be named.

An apartment house for thirty families on lot 46 by 86 feet at 143-45 Waverly Place and 10 Gay Street, at the northwest corner, has been purchased by a syndicate headed by Harry Klein, operator, from the Haft estate. The Title Guarantee and Trust Company insured title to the property, which is assessed at $66,000.

GENEVA, Nov. 17 -- West Germany has submitted proposals for the amendment of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade that put it in the line-up of "tough" countries alongside Britain, the United States and Canada.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 17 -- Alan Ladd's second picture for Warner Brothers, to be made by the star's own producing unit, will be "The Darkest Hour." In the suspense melodrama. based on the novel by William P. McGivern, Mr. Ladd will portray a New York policeman who is the victim of a frame-up.

New York City delivered prices on 1955 De Soto and Chrysler cars were announced yesterday by dealers here. In the De Soto line the Firedome series will sell for about $100 less, and the Fireflite series about $100 more than 1954 models.

The Grand Central Terminal Concourse is one of the few splendid architectural spaces in New York. Its great area, theatrically lit by shafts of sunlight, gives a sense of dignity and excitement to the commuter and the cross-town pedestrian as well as to the architect and the art critic.
GRAHAM GREENE can certainly make religion sound difficult. In "The Living Room," which was acted at Henry Miller's last evening, he tussles with the drama and the devil and concludes in a draw.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Government announced today that it would not appeal the refusal of Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl to disqualify himself from presiding at the trial of Owen Lattimore on charges of perjury.
A group of conservationists showed a disposition yesterday to withdraw their opposition to the Upper Colorado River development program, providing the Echo Park Dam is dropped from the project.
The Baltimore Bullets yesterday received an extension until Monday in order to obtain an undisclosed amount of money to continue the team's franchise in the National Basketball Association.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The Soviet Union today accepted a Western invitation to serve on the committee that is to help make arrangements for an international conference on the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Nov. 17 -- President Carlos Ibanez del Campo maintained his Cabinet today, with only two changes. He acted in a suddenly threatened crisis over the efforts in Congress to restrict his Administration.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 17 (AP) -- An 83-year-old man who admitted he committed one of the nation's most famous crimes -- the murder of the founder of Rice Institute -- was found dead of a bullet wound in his Baytown home last night.

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The United States Legation announced today that it had sent a message of reassurance to Noel and Herta Field, freed after five years in a Hungarian prison. The legation was waiting to find out whether they "want to see us."
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The City of Detroit today was approved as the American bidder for the 1960 Olympic Games by a selection committee of the United States Olympic Committee.
Twenty-five young women from this country, Europe and Latin America will be presented at the first International Debutante Ball to be held next Tuesday night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Senator Everett M. Dirksen, Republican of Illinois, announced today that he would introduce tomorrow a proposal to soften the censure resolution pending against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson, Democrat of New Mexico, said today that another armed service planned to build an atomic cannon similar to the Army's. He said he would try to halt the project when the Democratic-controlled Congress took over in January.
OTTAWA, Nov. 17 -- To the wife of French Premier Pierre Mendes-France New York is almost a second home.

Volume improved yesterday on many of the New York commodity markets. Zinc sales were the greatest since June 17, rubber since Sept. 9 and hides since Sept. 30. The domestic sugar contract had its most active session since Oct. 19.

" Abie's Irish Rose" is expected to bloom tonight at the refurbished Holiday Theatre at 8 o'clock. If past events are a measure of future happenings, then the Anne Nichols record-breaking comedy should be flowering hereabouts for a while to come.

Two six-story apartment houses accommodating 115 families at 87-40 and 87-42 Elmhurst Avenue in Elmhurst, Queens, have been sold by Harry Horwitz, real estate operator, to an investment syndicate represented by Regosin Edwards, attorneys. Stanley Russell Associates, Inc., were the brokers and E. Louis Gothelf was attorney for the seller.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. l7 -- With one year still to go on her five-year development plan, India has exceeded her target for food-grain production. The increase was 11,400,000 tons compared with a planned rise of 8,902,000 tons. India has increased cotton production by 960,000 bales, and has brought under irrigation 8,100,000 acres of land.

THE annual exhibition of painting and sculpture organized by the Allied Artists of America opens today in the galleries of the National Academy of Design, 1083 Fifth Avenue. Prizes were announced at the preview reception last evening.
Richard H. Balch, Democratic state chairman, asked Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein yesterday to investigate Republican fund-raising in Syracuse and the surrounding area of Onondaga County.
Much has been made, and rightly so, of the littered state of our highways. To date neither threats nor pleas have had much effect. It seems to me that a new approach to the problem should be made.
A three-man mediation panel continued yesterday its exploratory talks in the contract dispute that threatens a new shutdown of the harbor some time after midnight Nov. 27.

A parody of a Gilbert and Sullivan song that they found objectionable led three City Councilmen to walk out last night from a dinner honoring Stanley M. Isaacs, the Republican - Liberal minority leader of the Council.

CAIRO, Nov. 17 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser, strong man of Egypt's ruling military junta, assumed tonight the functions but not the title of President Mohammed Naguib. Major General Naguib was ousted last Sunday and placed under house arrest.

In their letter on the McCarthy censure resolution printed in The New York Times for Nov. 16 Messrs.
