Flynn, Burnham, Lyons, etc., seek to justify Senator McCarthy's conduct in openly encouraging federal employes to bring him official Government documents dealing with subversion and corruption, regardless of the applicable federal laws and Government regulations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Democratic leaders of the House of Representatives sketched a legislative program today that portended sharp clashes with the Eisenhower Administration on domestic issues but held promise of cooperation in foreign affairs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Senator Herman Welker, Republican of Idaho, demanded today that Secretary of State Dulles give his "real reason" for discharging John Paton Davies Jr., career diplomat.
Coach Jim Lee Howell sent the football Giants through their longest drill yesterday -- from 10:30 A. M. to 3 P. M. -- and concentrated chiefly on pass defense.

Although more than 1,400 national standards are in use, most engineering colleges are not aware of their full significance to the economy, Thomas D. Jolly, vice president of the Aluminum Company of America, said yesterday.

The South American Gold and Platinum Company, which mines precious metals in Colombia by means of dredges, announced yesterday the acquisition of more than one-third of the capital stock of Pato Consolidated Gold Dredging, Ltd., which also operates in Colombia.
VIENNA, Nov. 17 -- The Austrian Government is discussing with the West German Government a recent German court decision that Austrians living in Germany still are German citizens.

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Small advances in wheat at the opening brought another set of new price highs for the year. But the upturn was followed by heavy selling, which sent the market down as much as 1 1/2 cents from the early levels.

MOUNT TREMPER, N. Y., NOV. 17 -- The hunting pressure has been light during the first few days of the season in this popular deer hunting area, but the week-end will provide a solution to this problem, and undoubtedly result in a large harvest of deer.
A dramatic attempt to focus attention on the perils of the highway will be made on Dec. 15. The day has been designated by the President's Action Committee for Traffic Safety as Safe Driving Day.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined by 1,242,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Supplies totaled 147,896,000 barrels at the week-end, compared with 149,138,000 a week earlier and 142,836,000 a year ago.
The return of Claude Benham remained a big question mark as Columbia's football team drilled in a light drizzle under the lights at Baker Field yesterday afternoon.

Unusual articles, many of them suitable for Christmas gifts, will be offered for sale at the annual fair of the First Presbyterian Church to be held tomorrow afternoon and evening at the Church House, 7 West Eleventh Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The United Nations Palestine truce chief proposed today a series of measures to curb border incidents along the Israeli-Egyptian frontier.

LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 17 -- The eyes of Britain are fixed on the outcome tomorrow of the West Derby Parliamentary by-election here. The result may show for the first time in months a possible swing either to or away from the Churchill Government as it rounds out its third year in office.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Mme. Pierre Mendes-France tonight received her official welcome to Washington from the wife of the Vice President.
If we do not succeed in "catching up with our inventions," Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, warned last night, the world faces complete disaster.

A $50,000,000 share in the ownership of the Campbell Soup Company, representing the first breakaway of company equity from the estate of Dr. John T. Dorrance, was placed yesterday with investors in all of the nation's forty-eight states as well as abroad.

That old faithful of the blue chips, American Telephone and Telegraph Company, performed again yesterday. The directors declared the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25, payable on Jan. 15 to holders of record of Dec. 15.
A fire that produced more smoke than flames forced firemen yesterday to break through the walls on all twenty-two floors of the Biltmore Hotel to remove smouldering insulation in an incinerator flue.

The Maritime Administration signed yesterday the first contract under the new trade-in and build program. At the same time it disclosed that the Sun Shipbuilding and Dry Dock Company had submitted the lowest bid to build three tankers for the Navy.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) President Eisenhower today presented the Harmon international trophies to Maj. Charles E. Yeager for breaking the world's aviation speed record and to Jacqueline Cochran as the first woman to break through the sound barrier.

Giovanni Bagarotti, who in the 1951-52 season gave three concerts at Carnegie Hall devoted to the violin concertos of Mozart, last night opened a similar series of three concerts at Town Hall. He was assisted by eight wind players and five other string players.

Eleven prominent New Yorkers met on Nov. 20, 1804, in the office of Mayor DeWitt Clinton "to form themselves into a society the principal design of which should be to collect and preserve whatever may relate to the natural, civil or ecclesiastical history of the United States in general and of this state in particular."
LONG VALLEY, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Almost all 2,200 residents of Washington Township are digging into their pockets to help a 13-year-old boy who lost an arm in a schoolyard accident.

Directors of Marine Midland Corporation yesterday approved a proposal to increase its common stock by 2,000,000 shares, to issue 500,000 shares of cumulative preferred $50 par and to retire its outstanding preferred shares.

Saturady will be a ten-year milestone in the battle against tuberculosis. At the interim scientific session of the American Trudeau Society here yesterday, three researchers who used streptomycin for the first time in a case of human pulmonary tuberculosis ten years ago, reported to the society.

The Navy-Marine amphibious exercise in North Carolina this week emphasized once again, as such exercises have done nearly every year since World War II, the importance of the amphibious technique in modern warfare.

The issues involved in the T. V. A. and the Dixon-Yates controversy are exceedingly fundamental if private enterprise is to continue in this country. I cannot help but feel that President Eisenhower's statement as reported in The Times of Nov. 11 both at the press conference and in his letter to the chairman of the Atomic Energy Committee, is a splendid outline of the fundamental issues that are involved in these matters.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Duke of Edinburgh light-heartedly entered a heated newspaper dispute today with a dig at the tabloid Daily Mirror, which had said the royal family was underemployed.

In 1949 the Bahamas attracted 32,000 visitors. This year the figure will be a record 100,000. Victor Chenea, general sales manager for the Nassau, Bahamas Development Board, cited the rise yesterday by way of pointing up the effect of an advertising, publicity and sales promotion program running to $1,000,000 or so a year.

Attendance at motion-picture theatres throughout the country rose sharply during the second quarter of this year, as did theatre earnings. This was revealed in a special report compiled for the Council of Motion Picture Organizations, Inc., by Sindlinger Co., an independent research organization.

THIBODAUX, La., Nov. 17 (AP) -- District Attorney Leander Perez of Plaquemines and St. Bernard Parishes says suits will be filed against any oil company that starts operation under Federal lease within the historic Gulfward boundary of Louisiana.

When the cut-back in armament spending began to take effect in the third quarter of 1953 that development was quick to express itself in the Federal Reserve Board index of industrial output. The latter declined from 136 in August to 133 in September, and by March, 1954, it had fallen to 123, a loss of thirteen points, or between 9 1/2 and 10 per cent.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17 -- The Penrose Medal, the highest honor conferred by the Geological Society of America "in recognition of outstanding original contributions and achievements," has been awarded to Dr. Arthur F. Buddington, former chairman of Princeton University's Department of Geology.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- The first major breach of the no-raiding pact between the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations appeared on its way toward adjustment today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The United States notified the Soviet Union today, that United States aircraft would be given "necessary defensive protection," presumably fighter escorts, unless Moscow took steps to bar further attacks by Soviet planes.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Although Congress has voted the Foreign Operations Administration out of existence at the end of next June, the agency is now preparing, at the request of the National Security Council, a world-wide program forecast for 1955-56.

The new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Capitol is an evening premiere of "The Last Time I Saw Paris," starring Elizabeth Taylor, Van Johnson, Walter Pidgeon and Donna Reed. The supporting cast is headed by Eva Gabor, Kurt Kasznar and George Dolenz.

The seventy - five - family apartment house at 1515 Grand Concourse, southwest corner of Rockwood Place, in the Bronx, has been purchased by M. Robert Steel, investor. The property was sold by a client of Gerard Bloomfield, lawyer, through Mrs. Anne Inselstein, broker.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- A series of interim measures designed to relieve London's increasingly severe traffic congestion was announced today by John A. Boyd-Carpenter, Minister of Transport.
TRENTON, Nov. 17 -- Democratic state leaders decided at a closed meeting in New York tonight to proceed Tuesday with the recount of ballots cast in the New Jersey Senatorial election.

A link between Bronx and Brooklyn investigations into a courtesy-card racket for traffic offenders was disclosed yesterday. Two Bronx civilian defendants were reported to have distributed cards bearing the names of two policemen who are material witnesses in the Brooklyn inquiry.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- Judge Walter J. LaBuy announced in Federal Court today that he would rule on the du Pont antitrust case Dec. 3.

Governor-elect Averell Harriman indicated yesterday that he planned frequent use of television and radio after he takes office, to keep the public informed about the operations of the state government.
The petition campaign in behalf of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, continued unslackened yesterday, its third day.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 17 -- Prime Minister Daniel F. Malan flew to Pretoria today in an effort to prevent a split in the Nationalist party over the choice of his successor.
New patterns of world trade, in which products of higher living standards and advanced technology will have a dominant role, were forecast by a banking executive last night.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The United States today scored 2,373 points -- a world record -- to win the English match crown at the thirty-sixth world shooting championships, according to official results released tonight.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Jimmy Carter won the world lightweight crown for the third time tonight when he floored the defending champion, Paddy De Marco, twice and then scored a technical knockout in 14 seconds of the fifteenth and final round.

The annual mass for deceased members of the Fire Department's Holy Name Society of Manhattan, the Bronx and Richmond was celebrated yesterday morning by a former fireman, the Rev. Martin de Porres Clarke. He is honorary chaplain of the department.

The Executive Council of the Eastern College Athletic Conference yesterday ruled that Army's star halfback, Tommy Bell, would be permitted to play against Navy on Nov. 27. At the same time, the council ruled out the future use of "turned-back" plebes on first year teams at the service academies.

The Yankees last night completed "one of the biggest deals in recent years" with the Baltimore Orioles, according to information obtained by The Associated Press. Announcement of it is to be made at a press conference this morning.

The income levels of a majority of the tenants in state and Federal low-rent housing projects here are below the median family income for the city's population, according to the New York City Housing Authority.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 17 -- An increase in American steel production in 1955 of 5,000,000 to 10,000,000 tons from the estimated 1954 output of 86,000,000 tons was forecast here today by Benjamin F. Fairless.

Alfred Rainer's holiday and early spring fur collection, shown yesterday at 17 East Fifty-fifth Street, placed special emphasis on broadtail persian and river otter. The latter is a flat, golden beige fur the designer introduced in this country fifteen years ago.

The home cookery of New York is as unpredictable and interesting as the city itself. One housewife may give her meals an Italian accent, another a German inflection, while a third may borrow freely from many national cuisines.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the Attorney General's Committee to Study the Anti-Trust Laws have exchanged polite but positive refusals to exchange arguments and information.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 17 -- Coach Lloyd Jordan cut down "the time and tempo" of Harvard's football practice today because of the "unseasonable weather." The temperature was in the 50's as the Crimson prepared for Yale's visit to the Stadium Saturday.
DES MOINES, Nov. 17 -- Thirty-five Polk County deputy sheriffs who joined the A. F. L. Teamsters Union in a reported attempt to protect their jobs will be out of the union by tomorrow evening.
Any visiting celebrity is a salesman of sorts. The most important product that Premier Mendes-France has to sell during the American visit that started last evening is himself.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that a proposed 50,000-ton increase in this year's sugar quota "will not be made effective at this time."

Kansas City, Mo., sold $5,875,000 of various-purpose bonds due from 1955 to 1974 in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 1.728 per cent. The bonds, which bear interest at 3, 1 1/2 and 1 3/4 per cent, were awarded to the Harris Trust and Savings Bank, Chicago, and associates.

The March 10 performance of the musical, "Silk Stockings," has been taken over for the benefit of the Madison Square Boys Club. The musical opens Dec. 30 at the Imperial Theatre with Don Ameche and Hildegarde Neff in starring roles.
Faculty and staff members of the four municipal colleges made pleas for more teachers and higher salaries yesterday at a preliminary budget hearing of the Board of Higher Education.

The national committee of the American Museum of Immigration in its first organizational meeting yesterday at the Town Hall Club voted to incorporate and to set up an executive committee to run its fund-raising campaign early next year.

ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 17--By condining the fellagha rebellion in rural Tunisia, the Tunisian Neo-Destour party has aroused grave apprehensions here about the future security of Algeria and of French North Africa as a whole.

Irving Berlin, the songwriter, was one of twenty-four winners of the Christopher Award for achievement in radio, television motion pictures and song writing in the last six months. The winners were announced yesterday by the Rev. James Keller, director of the Christophers.

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 17 (AP) -- A Richmond pharmaceutical plant closed tonight as 100 employes walked off the job for an all-expense paid four-day Florida vacation. The walk-out was led by E. Claiborne Robins -- the boss.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the sixth day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these counts:

CHICAGO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Butcher grades and sows generally sold around 25 cents lower in the hog market today although a few light weight butchers commanded steady prices. The top price remained unchanged at $19.75, although it was paid for only 85 head of choice 200-pound butchers. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
The Tennessee Gas Transmission Company filed a registration statement covering $125,000,000 of first mortgage bonds, due in 1975, with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington yesterday.

The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation, construction engineering concern, disclosed yesterday that it had obtained two loans amounting to $14,000,000 from a group of nine banks. One loan was for $8,000,000, the other for $6,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the renewing principal changes for the week ended Nov. 10:
YONKERS, Nov. 17 -- The new information and service center of The New York Times was opened here today in the Cross County Shopping Center.
The New York, Chicago and St. Louis (Nickel Plate) Railroad yesterday joined the growing ranks of those companies planning to replace preferred stock with bonds.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 17 (AP) -- Harvey Harman, Rutgers football coach, worked today on a diversified attack to throw against Columbia Saturday.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 17 (UP) -- A private testified today that a lieutenant whose ideas of discipline allegedly bordered on terrorism once had him buried with only his mouth exposed and ordered a cross stuck in his teeth.
CHICAGO, Nov. 17 -- John A. Barr, vice president and secretary of Montgomery Ward Co., said today that the big mail order company would close a few of its smaller stores at the end of the year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France arrived late today for a brief official visit to Washington. He immediately expressed confidence that Western unity would "assure the safety and development of our common civilization."

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 17 -- Die Transvaler of Johannesburg, Nationalist newspaper controlled by Johannes G. Strydom, candidate for Prime Minister, took exception today to a Columbia University exhibition here.

The eighth seagoing Naval Reserve merchant marine company to be formed aboard liners sailing from the Port of New York was activated yesterday aboard the Panama Line passenger vessel Cristobal, at her berth at West Twenty-fourth Street.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Mlle. Lorette set a track record for a mile and an eighth at Pimlico today in winning the $15,000 added Gallorette Stakes -- a race named for Mlle. Lorette's dam.
ALBANY, Nov. 17 -- Governor-elect Averell Harriman and members of his immediate family contributed $49,550 to his successful campaign and put up another $40,000 in loans.

BLOOMINGDALE, N. J., Nov. 17 -- The Paul Dumonts, formerly of Palisades Park, moved into their new home yesterday. Besides the usual moving van, it took a plywood raft lashed to a pair of rowboats to accomplish the feat.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee today gave thought to employing the new immunity law in an effort to draw information about Reds from a reluctant witness.
The State Employment Service is sending 200,000 cards through the neighborhood postman to help recruit housewives to work in stores here during the Christmas rush.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 17 -- Yugoslavia informally told the Soviet Union today that if it thought of reimposing the old satellite status on Yugoslavia it was due for disappointment.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- The Paris accords arming West Germany won the solid if unenthusiastic support of the House of Commons today. In its fight the Government was bolstered by a German agreement to restrict the production and import of nuclear fuel for civilian uses.

CALGARY, Alta, Nov. 17 -- Tim Buck, Canadian Communist leader, has asked the Canadian Prime Minister to demand the recall of R. Kenneth Oakley, United States consul here. Mr. Oakley was quoted as having said he had reported to the United States Government on Communist activities in Alberta.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- The West Jordan Boxing Association today suspended Bill Boatsman, a Longview, Wash., heavyweight, for his tactics in last night's fight with Rex Layne of Salt Lake City.
MANILA, Nov. 16 -- A studied approach to problems of family life and moral standards in changing southeast Asia took form here tonight with the closing of a fortnight's seminar and conference.

Quite aside from the need of adequate military strength there is another aspect of the problem of defense against communism and the question of "coexistence." This is the economic aspect, which arises not only because the Communists exploit poverty and ignorance for their own ends, but even more because of the economic strength being developed by the Communist bloc.

ALBANY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Dr. Currier McEwen, dean of the New York University College of Medicine at Bellevue Hospital, to the advisory council for the joint hospital survey and planning commission.

Furs and jewelry seized in the homes of thieves and fences but never claimed by the robbery victims were auctioned off yesterday by the police. A hundred men and women, many of them dealers, were so active in their bidding that the auction took in $12,815.

HARTFORD, Nov. 17 -- An experimental method of "packaging" garbage, designed to cut municipal labor costs and eliminate much unsightly litter, was demonstrated here today under the auspices of City Manager Carleton F. Sharpe.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold proposed today that the United Nations take over next April 1 the highly successful guided tour service at its headquarters.

Most pleasing in a Pauline Trigere collection are the perfectly "drawn" contours of her costumes, whether dresses, suits or coats. She has mastered the art of eliminating the unecessary and letting fabric, detail and silhouette speak for themselves.
Unionized employes of the John Wanamaker department store have suffered a first-round defeat in their efforts to keep the store open after Jan. 31.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Following is the text of a note delivered today by the United States Embassy to the Soviet Foreign Ministry in Moscow on the shooting down Nov. 7 of a United States reconnaissance plane by Soviet fighters over northern Japan:

Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother of Great Britain, spent the last night of her twenty-three-day visit in the United States and Canada on the Cunard liner Queen Mary. She flew to New York late yesterday from Ottawa, where she had spent the previous four days.
Australia, the last foreign government except Canada to sell bonds in the American market, will undertake a further borrowing in the public market here within the next three weeks.

The closing of Ellis Island, long-time symbol of the difficulties -- and often undue hardships -- in gaining admission to this country is dramatic and welcome evidence of the determination of the present Administration to treat aliens with more consideration.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 17 -- The Dartmouth football team sharpened its aerials today. Although part of the drill was devoted to defense against the single wing, the Big Green concentrated on offense.

Milt Schmidt of the Boston Bruins was banged around a lot last night in his team's game against the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden. The 36-year-old star who serves as captain of the Hub sextet decided, in the waning minutes of the clash, that he had taken enough.

The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday. Prices were 2 to 8 points (10 to 40 cents a bale) lower on the active months, with old December showing the most weakness.

Five children, all of the same family, were among seventy-one refugees who arrived at New York International Airport, Idle-wild. Queens, yesterday from Munich, West Germany, aboard a plane chartered by the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration.

LONDON, Nov. 17 -- Britain's health, as reflected in many of the basic statistics, showed signs of becoming stabilized in 1953, Sir John Charles, chief medical officer of the Ministry of Health, said in a report issued today.
LONDON, Nov. 17 -- With the improvement in industrials continuing, the new fortnightly bookkeeping account had a cheerful start today.
KANSAS CITY, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Lou Boudreau today was signed to a two-year contract as manager of the Kansas City Athletics. The stint will be his third as an American League skipper.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon has received hundreds of letters from members of temperance organizations protesting his appointment of Robert L. King, former official of a St. Louis distilling firm, as administrative assistant.

EN ROUTE TO TEXAS, Nov. 17 -Those who make the news of government work in shifts. Hence many of them are always out of Washington, refreshing their spirits with the sights and sounds of homekeeping America and adjusting their minds to what the people are concerned with -- which is frequently no topic that absorbs the capital.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- Successful transplantation of the thyroid and parathyroid glands from a dead infant to a 30-year-old woman was reported here today at the annual clinical congress of the American College of Surgeons.

LYTTON STRACHEY said thirty years ago that it would be hard to find a novelist so important, so remarkable, and so little known to English readers as Henri Beyle, who called himself Stendhal. Well, thanks perhaps to Strachey, among others, things have changed considerably in three decades. The fame of Stendhal is secure everywhere.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 17 -- Gen. J. Lawton Collins, United States special Ambassador on a mission here, today proclaimed United States support, and asked United Vietnamese backing for the Government of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem.
The National Retail Hardware Association has begun a program to convince manufacturers of the harmful effects of price cutting on fair-traded products.

Issues of $10,600,000 of new securities of Producing Properties, Inc., a company formed to acquire and operate oil and gas properties, will be placed on the market today by Hemphill, Noyes Co., Shields Co. and Rauscher, Pierce Co.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 17 -- Such jubilation reigns at Princeton over last Saturday's spectacular upset of Yale that it is difficult to steer the conversation to other subjects.

Steels and rails lifted the stock market yesterday in a day of new highs for the upward movement and record volume since mid-January of 1951. The turnover was 3,830,000 shares, compared with 3,260,000 on Tuesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 17 -- The president of the Mizrachi Organization of America tonight accused Dr. Arnold J. Toynbee, British historian, of "defamation" of Israel and the Jewish people in his evaluation of the Israeli war of independence.
Two employes of the Transit Authority have been suspended as security risks as a result of their refusal to answer questions about suspected Communist affiliations.

Alvin D. Doyle of The New York Daily Mirror was elected president of the Inner Circle, an organization of political, writers, at the organization's annual meeting in the Sheraton Astor Hotel last night.
A feminine, custom quality marked the afternoon and evening dresses in the collection by Countess Alexandra that was presented yesterday by De Pinna at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

Dried fruits, so necessary for adequate nutrition during the winter months in days gone by, are welcomed by the modern cook for the seasonal change they bring to meals now and through the holiday season.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 17 -- Four agreements were initialed today by Ambassador Ellis O. Briggs and Premier Y. T. Pyun resolving differences that have split United States and South Korean policies for three months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee will decide tomorrow whether to call Alger Hiss for questioning when the former State Department official is released from prison a week from Saturday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said today that his Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee had reason to "suspect" that the sale of the Follansbee Steel Corporation may violate the antitrust laws.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 17 (UP) -- Australia's prize doubles team of Ken Rosewall and Lew Hoad came from behind to defeat Tony Trabert and Ham Richardson of the United States, 3--6, 6--2, 2--6, 6--2, 6--3, today. Trabert and Richardson were the last Americans in the running for a major title in the New South Wales tennis tournament.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 17 -- The Soviet delegation is preparing to press for a concerted campaign by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization against war-mongering propaganda. The Russians contend it is being spread by "certain countries" through the press, radio and movies.

Ruth Gilbert, the comedienne who played Max on the Milton Berle show, was notified formally yesterday that her services had been terminated. But Irving Gray, Mr. Berle's manager, said the question of her return to the show had not been settled and would be determined by arbitrators.

Maj. Gen. William M. Creasy, Chief Chemical Officer of the Army, said last night that a committee of "outstanding industrial leaders" was being formed to study the organization and operational structure of the Army Chemical Corps.

TORONTO, Nov. 17 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs, making the most of shaky net-minding by a rookie goalie, Claude Evans, whipped the Montreal Canadiens, 5 -- 2, tonight to move within a point of the league leaders.

LAKE RONKONKOMA, L. I., Nov. 17 -- Superintendent Walter M. Ormsby, head of Suffolk County's Second Supervisory School District, announced today the issuance of an order consolidating three school districts in this area -- those of Lake Ronkonkoma, Holbrook and Holtsville.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- The second state dinner at the White House tonight duplicated last night's season's opener even to the table decorations.

Although attractive books for children are being printed in growing numbers each year, the majority of youngsters never get a chance to see the best ones, Miss Helen R. Sattley, director of school library service for the Board of Education, said last night.

A military march, sent to "His Worship, the Mayor of New York City," by a composer in South Africa with pleasant memories of a visit here, will have its first public performance over Station WNYC tomorrow night by the Sanitation Department band.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Nov. 17 (AP) --American football came back to Northern Ireland today after a ten-year lapse and drew 8,000 spectators to a game between two United States Air Force teams from England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 17 -- President Eisenhower and the leaders of the incoming Democratic-controlled Congress made gingerly progress today toward determining the future conduct of a bipartisan foreign policy.

A plan for merging the American Woolen Company, Textron Incorporated, and Robbins Mills, Inc., has been unanimously approved "in principle" by the boards of American and Textron, it was made known yesterday.

MOSCOW, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Representative Victor Wickersham, Democrat of Oklahoma, just back from a one-week tour of interior Russia, said today "Russia just can't compare with the United States standard of living."
So far in this account of the voyage, I have told of some of the most spectacular and hazardous incidents. To a reader, I felt, these incidents seemed most likely to be of interest.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 17 -- President Victor Paz Estenssoro last night reaffirmed his faith in democratic principles and refused the extension of his term as Chief Executive for another five years without benefit of elections.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 17 -- The Mount Vernon Exchange Club joined the roster today of Exchange Clubs opposing the national organization's charter provision that restricts membership to white persons.

American Export Lines, Inc., suffered a loss for the first nine months this year and yesterday omitted the dividend on the common stock for the second successive quarter. The last payment was 37 1/2 cents in June.
DETROIT, Nov. 17 -- The American Motors Corporation announced today that it had secured exclusive rights to a smaller version of the jeep.
TORONTO, Nov. 17 (AP) -- Mexico won the Capt. Michael G. Tubridy Memorial Trophy in the international team competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair Horse Show tonight.

The United States Lawn Tennis Association announced yesterday that Billy Talbert of New York, captain of the American Davis Cup team, would leave by plane for Australia on Nov. 26, although his recent illness will not permit him to play overseas.
I suspect that mine will be a lone voice of dissent. I must nevertheless express it.
The great challenge to public welfare now is the problem of the aged, the New York State Welfare Conference was told yesterday.

BOSTON, Nov. 17 -- The Harvard Endowment Fund of Harvard University increased the market value of its total investments by $57,000,000 during the fiscal year ended last June 30.
The Georgia State Bridge Building Authority sold $10,635,000 of bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.2493 per cent.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 18 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer virtually prohibited tonight a Bundestag discussion of proposals for a big power conference with Moscow pending ratification.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- In quiet trading, prices in most sections of the stock market closed today with narrow irregular changes that indicated no definite trend.
HAVANA, Nov. 18 (UP) -- An investment group headed by Lowell M. Birrell of New York has bought Oriental Park, the home of Cuban horse racing, for almost $3,000,000, it was learned today.
Prices of 1955 Buick and Oldsmobile cars delivered in New York City were announced by dealers last week.

The Fields disappeared behind the Iron Curtain beginning in 1949. Until the release of Hermann Field from a Polish prison last month, and this week's release of Mr. and Mrs. Noel Field, many guesses were made about the reasons for their disappearance.

A strong French influence, evident in shapely molded torso silhouettes and chic higher necklines, lent verve to the Saks-Thirty-fourth showing of Lee Claire cocktail and evening designs yesterday at this store. Saucy and youthful, the silhouettes proved extremely flattering with their swirl of fullness in the skirts beneath the slim molded bodices.

Negotiations for the merger of Botany Mills, Inc., and Princeton Worsted Mills have been suspended, it was announced yesterday by A. M. Sonnabend, chairman of Botany, and Erwin Schwarz, president of Princeton.

Not that it needed it, but the Army-Navy football classic at Philadelphia Nov. 27 got yet another lift as a-gate attraction yesterday as the midshipmen returned to the top of the list of the nation's leading defensive units among the major colleges.
ALBANY, Nov. 18 -- Jacob K. Javits, the only Republican elected to state office this fall, paid his first post-election visit to the Capitol today.

Arthur M. Schlesinger Jr., Professor of History at Harvard University, said here last night that "Nixonism, a kind of kid-gloves McCarthyism, would replace the more ruthless tactics of Senator McCarthy" in Republican strategy in the next two years.

If Western culture with all its art and artifacts, sciences and traditions were to sink into the ground except for one New York building, which would you choose to be saved? Something extreme like the Empire State Building, something typical like a Bronx apartment house?

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Hog receipts again were heavy today and most offerings sold at lower prices. The decline generally ran to around 25 cents although some prices were steady with yesterday particularly on choice butchers weighing under 220 pounds. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Gil Turner, fresh from boxing lessons from the former heavyweight champion, Joe Louis, slugged his way to an eighth-round technical knockout of Charley Scott in a scheduled ten-rounder tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl asked the Government today to disavow as "without substance" the affidavit of prejudice filed against him in the Owen Lattimore perjury case.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- The French announced today that "an agreement in principle" had been reached with representatives of the Tunisian Government on how to deal with terrorist bands in the French protectorate. There was no elaboration of the accord.
TORONTO, Nov. 16 (Canadian Press) -- Maj. Manuel Ordovas Gonzales of Spain tonight won the International Fault-and-Out Stake of the Royal Winter Fair Horse Show.

Laurance S. Rockefeller has acquired options to purchase about half of the scenic Island of St. John in the Virgin Islands. The third son of John D. Rockefeller Jr. affirmed yesterday reports that he would like eventually to have two-thirds of the island's 12,700 acres accepted as a national park.

TRENTON, Nov. 18 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner said here this morning that a criminal investigation section would be set up in the State Department of Law and Public Safety to improve law enforcement in New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 708,757 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 13,660 cars or 2 per cent more than for the preceding week, 18,301 cars or 2.5 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 119,993 cars or 14.5 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

CALGARY, Alta., Nov. 18 -- The newspaper report of a speech by R. Kenneth Oakley, United States Consul in Calgary, which led to a demand by Canada's top Communist that the consul be recalled was a paraphrased version of the actual speech.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Wheat futures moved irregularly today and failed to hold rallies, but the close was strong. Corn and oats were steady most of the day. In soybeans, there was increasing pressure on deferred deliveries.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Calvin Griffith said today the Washington Senators had worked out with the Baltimore Orioles a program designed to protect both clubs from ruinous television competition.

The proposed Narrows Bridge between Brooklyn and Staten Island probably will be built within the next eight years, Frederick H. Zurmuhlen, Commissioner of Public Works, told a group of engineers here last night. He said the span should be constructed as a necessary addition to the city's facilities.
Today's new film is "The Unholy Four," a British-made mystery melodrama starring Paulette Goddard, at the Palace. William Sylvester, Patrick Holt and Paul Carpenter head the supporting cast.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany and Democratic National Committeeman for New York, revealed yesterday that he planned to devote most of his time in the next two years to rebuilding the Democratic party organization in up-state counties.

PARIS, Nov. 18 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France's visit to Washington dominated the front pages of the Paris press today. French correspondents in the United States told both of his welcome and of what they presented as divided views of him in the United States.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Democrats are bemoaning the decline of the Atomic Energy Commission into politics, but they are obviously determined to keep it there.

Charles Stuart-Linton in The New York Times of Nov. 5 writes that no question of self-determination is involved in the Cyprus question now before the U. N., because the Greek Government has called for "enosis," entailing transfer of sovereignty.

Foreign observers are often struck by the relative "classlessness" of American society -- something we natives take very much for granted. After all, it is part of our traditional democratic way of life. But there has been some distinction between the wage-earner and the salaried white-collar worker.

Walter J. Meyer, a retired city patrolman, was arraigned and freed in $5,000 bail yesterday as a material witness in the investigation of a "courtesy-card" racket for traffic offenders. In Kings County Court, Assistant District Attorney Julius Helfand described him as an "amenable" witness.

MOUNT TREMPER, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The hunters in this area who insist all of the local deer are antlerless may now take heart. There is one large, heavily-antlered buck on the slopes of Mount Tremper who, at this writing, is undoubtedly rather gun shy.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov. 18 -- Contrary to usual custom here, the film version of "Carmen Jones," with an all-Negro cast, was passed and praised yesterday by the Memphis and Shelby County Board of Censors.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Treasury Department has suspended as a security risk a compositor at the Bureau of Engraving and Printing because for one thing, he and his wife attended cocktail parties at the Soviet Embassy in the late Nineteen Forties.

Net income of the Ohio Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Pennsylvania Power Company, was $19,933,574 in the year ended on Oct. 31, 1954, Walter H. Sammis, president, reported yesterday. This was equal to $2.96 a share on the 5,806,136 common shares outstanding at the end of the period, and compared with a net of $18,717,085, or $3.05 each on 5,278,306 shares a year before.

Events today: Haarlem Philharmonic Society, Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, 11 A. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, Clifford Curzon, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; Ray Lev, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30, and "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- A General Assembly committee recommended today a scale of assessments for the 1955 budget of the United Nations under which Canada, New Zealand and Sweden would continue for a third year to pay a higher per capita contribution than the United States.

Governor-elect Averell Harriman disclosed yesterday that he expected to be ready with concrete proposals, either legislative or administrative, to redeem Democratic campaign promises when he takes office the first of the year.
GLENDALE, Calif., Nov. 18 (UP) -- Manager Casey Stengel said today the Yankees made the trade with Baltimore because the Bombers needed "some new men" on the club, which was "getting a little aged."

The legislation forwarded to the City Council by Mayor Wagner to halt the growth of slum conditions, lift the standards in present tenement housing and bring conscienceless landlords to book is probably the most important step taken by the new city administration.

Many tickets have been purchased for the performance of "Quadrille" on the night of Nov. 30 at the Coronet Theatre for the benefit of the New York City Hospital Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association. Mrs. Dexter Blagden and Mrs. Edmond T. Drewsen are co- chairman of the benefit committee.

TUXTLA GUTIERREZ, Mexico, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Pan-American auto race officials said today they have completed pre-race examinations of more than ninety cars, and that a starting field of 116 is expected for the five-day, 1,908-mile race which starts early tomorrow.

The regional Red Cross blood program received 831 pints of blood on Wednesday. At Camp Kilmer, near New Brunswick, N. J., 309 pints were collected. Local 1199, Retail Drug Employes Union, C. I. O., 210 West Fiftieth Street, gave 262 pints, while 186 pints were collected at the New York Telephone Company, 140 West Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these counts:
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Lionel Barrymore was buried today in the Roman Catholic faith of his birth while 2,000 fans crowded around the Calvary Cemetery Mausoleum Chapel.

The Transit Authority at a meeting at 370 Jay Street, Brooklyn, reported yesterday that Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, its chairman, had written to Mayor Wagner disagreeing with the Mayor's criticisms of actual and proposed cuts in transit service.

" Song of the Sky," a new work by Guy Murchie Jr., which Houghton Mifflin will publish Dec. 1, is the December selection of the Book-of-the-Month Club. Mr. Murchie has been an instructor in navigation in the Air Transport Command and a navigating officer on planes flying regular transoceanic service.
American private enterprise was urged yesterday to undertake a great expansion of foreign trade and investment.

It would be unfair to suggest that the injury to Senator McCarthy's elbow in Milwaukee on Saturday was anything but an unhappy and unpremeditated accident. Even the Senator's bitterest critics would not like to see him hampered by a bad elbow or by other physical ailment.

Consolidated net income of Northrop Aircraft, Inc., rose 483 per cent above the 1953 level in the quarter ended on Oct. 31 on a sales increase of 84 per cent. Directors declared another 80-cent dividend on the present capital stock, which stockholders voted yesterday to split on a two-for-one basis.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Senate decided tonight to adjourn the censure proceeding against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy until Nov. 29 because the Wisconsin Republican is hospitalized with an injured elbow.

The commission charged with the task of negotiating the sale of the Government's huge synthetic rubber plants reported yesterday it was optimistic that it would be able to recommend a denationalization program to Congress by the Jan. 27 deadline.
BERLIN, Nov. 18 -- The seizure of 1,750 tons of scrap metal being exported from West Berlin has touched off a debate as to whether or not the Russians plan a new squeeze on this city.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- An indictment charging Julius C. Holmes, a career officer of the State Department, and E. Stanley Klein, New York financier, with conspiracy to defraud the Government in surplus ship deals was dismissed in Federal court here today.
MEXICO CITY, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Two Americans were killed tonight near Tehuantepec as they drove to Tuxtla Gutierrez for the start of the Pan American race.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- The Chairman of the House of Representatives Un-American Activities Committee said today Alger Hiss probably would not be recalled before the committee unless he indicated he had information "vital to the security of the nation."

If the Rev. Bert G. Marino's program for fighting communism is to be confined to feeding the hungry, clothing the naked, cleaning up the slums, etc. -- as he would seem to indicate in his letter published Nov. 15 -- then he fails completely to appreciate the extent and depth of the Communist conspiracy.

A pension plan was agreed on yesterday by the four national television networks and the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists, A. F. L. It was believed to be the first to be established for actors by a performers' union.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Smithsonian Institution was richer today by a "priceless' pink pearl from the stickpin of a recent distinguished visitor, Mohammed Ali, Prime Minister of Pakistan.
An experiment by Federal agencies seeking to expedite the landing of transatlantic passengers here ended yesterday with some confusion and considerable disagreement.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- The Dixon-Yates Contract was not submitted to competitive bidding because of two important factors well known to all practical utility operating men, Mr. Dixon said today. He spoke at a luncheon sponsored by the Investment Analysts Society in Chicago.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Mrs. Hubert G. Olson of Bloomington, Minn., was named today the country's "most successful homemaker of 1954." The selection was in a contest conducted by newspapers in forty-one states.

HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 18 -- In ending their football practice for the year, the Dartmouth Indians ran through the offensive plays they will use at Princeton Saturday. The major part of today was used to tighten defenses against the single-wing attack favored by the Tigers.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- Two years of research carried out in the Department of Chemistry, London University, has substantiated the identity of a cancer producing chemical in the tar of cigarette smoke.

SEVEN years have passed since Zygmunt Menkes' last one-man show in New York, but there is no lessening of flourish and energy in his expressive new paintings of figures and still-life at Associated American Artists, 711 Fifth Avenue.

An inspector of water consumption has been discharged from his $4,200 civil service job with the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity for refusing to reply to questions about possible Communist affiliations.

The nation's textile industry is "completely undersold" in the financial and commercial world as well as to the public, according to J. Spencer Love, chairman of the board of Burlington Mills Corporation.
Evening dresses in shiny fabrics that sparkled with rhinestones and glittering beads lent a holiday air to the fashion show presented by Russeks yesterday at the Plaza Hotel.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -- A trong appeal to American Jewish communities to give first priority to Israel's needs in 1955 was made here today by Dr. Joseph J. Schwartz, executive vice chairman of the United Jewish Appeal. He emphasized Israel's precarious security position in the Middle East because of Arab-Israel tensions and noted that 30,000 to 40,000 immigrants were expected in Israel next year from North Africa.
Senators Styles Bridges, Republican of New Hampshire, and Estes Kefauver, Democrat of Tennessee, called last night for a reappraisal of the State Department's policy in the Middle East.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 18 -- Richard Breen, screen writer, has been elected the first president of the Writers Guild of America, West.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 18 -- Jordan Olivar looked up from the newspaper he was reading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent below sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

It is always good to have Bruno Walter back. Returning as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall last night, he led a refreshing and illuminating concert. He had Clifford Curzon as soloist, and since the British pianist's musicianship is cut from the same fine cloth as Mr. Walter's, it was a richly satisfying evening.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The United Nations announced today the resignation of Dr. Frank Calderone as director of medical services.
" Faust" had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera last evening, with Pierre Monteux conducting and with Jan Peerce singing the title role for the first time there.
SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 18 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers moved into the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division lead by beating the Philadelphia Warriors, 96 -- 94, tonight.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 18 -- The whole community, and not the Federal Government and a few agencies alone, must take responsibility in rehabilitation of disabled workers, Dr. Donald A. Covalt asserted today. He is associate director of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation at New York University-Bellevue Medical Center, New York.
Walter E. Maloney announced yesterday his resignation, effective in February, as president of the American Merchant Marine Institute.
CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- Armour Co. said today that net earnings after taxes in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30 were expected to be $1,250,000. This would compare with $10,339,164 a year ago.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 18 -- Dr. Paul R. Hawley, director of the American College of Surgeons, disclosed here today that 189 out of 215 fellows of the college from Iowa had "agreed to open their financial records to prove that they do not engage in unethical fee-splitting."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Commuters who use six railroads operating in New Jersey to New York and Philadelphia will pay an average of 10 per cent more in fares beginning Sunday.

There is ground for satisfaction in the accord that has now been reached with the Republic of Korea over the dollar-hwan relationship. This agreement ends a dispute of several months' standing that has all but paralyzed the attempts to get on with Korean aid and reconstruction.
The Holland Society of New York awarded its Distinguished Achievement Medal last night to Robert Moses.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 18 -- The art of music was described here today by Abram Chasins, pianist-composer, as one of the primary symbols of civilizations.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Sister Louise Fey, a Sister of Charity and the mother of eight sons and daughters who entered religious orders, died last night at St. Michael's villa. She was 85.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the seventh day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:
The Board of Education, taking an important step toward improving high school facilities in the city, yesterday approved plans for three building projects.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Treasury offered investors a choice of short and medium term securities today in exchange for $17,347,000,000 of bonds and notes maturing on Dec. 15.
The competitive battle in the automotive industry has induced the Murray Corporation of America to withdraw from the automotive body business.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Supreme Court heard arguments today on whether the constitutional rights of Michael J. Regan, a former New York policeman, had been infringed by proceedings that led to his conviction in 1953 of criminal contempt of court.
Legislation to require the election of savings bank trustees by depositors rather than by the traditional "self-perpetuating" system was urged yesterday by a Long Island commercial banker.
Several weeks ago you published a letter from one of your readers which criticized the length of time required for an ambulance to reach the scene of an accident in the city.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- The Western nations and the Soviet Union agreed today on all except one provision of a resolution endorsing President Eisenhower's program for the peaceful uses of atomic energy.

Vince Martinez of Paterson, N. J., fifth-ranking challenger for the welterweight boxing title, spurned a $20,000 offer to throw a fight at Madison Square Garden on Oct. 29, he said yesterday. Mr. Martinez won the fight, scoring a technical knockout over Carmen Fiore.
SYDNEY, Australia, Nov 18 (UP) -- Mervyn Rose and Rex Hartwig gained the final today in the New South Wales tennis championship and will meet Saturday for the title.

A long and bitter controversy was ended yesterday when the Board of Estimate voted to take title to the 17.68 acres of land needed for the $25,000,000 Washington Square Southeast slum clearance development.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 18 -- Princeton's football team went through a long non-contact session today as the Tigers polished assignments for their season's finale against Dartmouth here Saturday.

CAIRO, Nov. 18 -- Egypt's military rulers declared today that Maj. Gen. Mohammed Naguib, whom they ousted Sunday from the Presidency, had "long contemplated" a conspiracy with the Moslem Brotherhood to overthrow the regime with a terrorist movement.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 18 (AP) -- Major strides were made in the last year to help get out newspapers faster and better, according to a report filed here today. Some of the major technological advances and experimental work that is expected to lead to new processes were reviewed at a meeting of The Associated Press Managing Editors Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Mme. Pierre Mendes-France had tea in the Red Room of the White House today with the President and Mrs. Eisenhower. It was tea for four, and the fourth was Mme. Henri Bonnet, wife of the French Ambassador.

A new series, the Montclair, has been added to the longer and wider cars comprising the 1955 Mercury line, which was announced yesterday by the Lincoln-Mercury division, Ford Motor Company. The newcomer joins the Monterey and custom series, with the latter two restyled and re-engineered.

After sailing my raft the Seven Little Sisters for sixteen weeks across 6,400 empty miles of the Pacific, I reached the Samoan Islands, the heart of Polynesia -- my destination. But it didn't turn out to be easy to land.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Nov 18 (UP) -- A grandson of a former North Carolina Governor and described as "leader of the Communist party" in three Southern states, was arrested tonight on charges of underground Red activities.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was barely steady yesterday and active months declined 4 to 14 points net.

IN early evening and at midnight when Grazietta Durante makes her cat-feeding rounds in Forty-second Street one block west of Times Square you would not think if you saw her that she had known a rich past.

YOU are hereby invited to make early application for tickets for the opening game of the 1955 world series which will be played at the Yankee Stadium on Sept. 28. The Bronx Bombers clinched next year's pennant yesterday by whisking away from the Baltimore Orioles two youthful strong-armed pitchers and a flashy shortstop in exchange for no one they'll miss.

The entire foreign-aid program -- and with it all facets of American shipping -- is being imperiled by a new policy of "rate shopping," James B. Stuart, president of the American Tramp Ship-owners Association, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery will be the Thanksgiving holiday guest of the President and Mrs. Eisenhower at Augusta, Ga.
The Yankees yesterday confirmed their deal with the Baltimore Orioles, one of the biggest in major league baseball history.

Jan Sibelius, 89-year-old Finnish composer, will soon begin to receive royalties due him for performances of his music in the United States, it was announced yesterday by Herman Finkelstein, general attorney for the American Society of Composers, Authors and Publishers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- The Administration's new reserve forces plan, which will be submitted to the Congress in January, has been approved in broad outline by the National Security Council.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- It was understood here that Chase proposes to set up a corporation with initial capital stock of $5,000,000 to be subscribed by itself, the General Motors Corporation and other large manufacturers dependent on foreign markets for much of their business.

The first in the series of supper dances, known as the New York Assemblies, under the direction of Miss Clementine Miller, will be held tonight in the ballroom of the Pierre. The second dance in the series will be held Jan. 7 at the Plaza.
LIVERPOOL, England, Nov. 18 -- Prime Minister Churchill's Conservative party won a significant victory today over the Labor party in the West Derby parliamentary election.
A substantial reversal in the recent unseasonal decline in business loans in the New York area has just set in, the Federal Reserve Bank reported here yesterday.

The National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. announced plans yesterday to make an "extensive" study of "the implications" of a recent statement by Pope Pius XII that the authority of the Roman Catholic Church is not limited to purely religious matters.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver said today he would try to block Senate confirmation of two new Atomic Energy Commissioners "as long as the A. E. C. is in the power business."

In its new note of protest against the latest Soviet attack on American planes over Japan the United States has notified Moscow that henceforth American aircraft will be provided with the "necessary defensive protection," which may be taken to mean fighter escorts, and that, if the Soviets persist in their attacks they will have to accept responsibility for any resulting battles in the air.
The National Cash Register Company plans to split its common stock three-for-one, subject to stockholders' approval at a special meeting in Baltimore on Feb. 10.

Vitality and simplicity characterize a new group of printed fabrics designed by four young Irish painters. The fabrics are hand-printed Irish linen done in Dublin by John McGuire. They are available through decorators at Isabel Scott, 17 East Fifty-third Street.

CHICAGO, Nov. 18 -- A spokesman for the broadcasting industry charged the Watkins Committee today with censorship of news by arbitrarily closing its doors to radio and television reporters while it was hearing censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

VIENNA, Nov. 18 -- Noel Field and his wife Herta, whose release after five years' imprisonment for alleged espionage was announced by the Hungarian Government two days ago, are now in a hospital in Budapest. The United States Minister to Hungary, Christian M. Ravndal, was permitted to see them this morning.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 18 (UP) -- August Westergaard of Iowa won the world championship of shooting with a small bore rifle from the prone position at 50 meters, equaling the world record of 400 points, according to unofficial results tonight.

HAVANA, Nov. 18 -- Harris Whittemore of Lake Quassapaug was setting the pace in the Western Hempishere snipe championship six-race series at the end of the fifth race today. The last event will be held tomorrow.
Once upon a time, a teen-age French boy set down his versions of several stories that even then, in 1695, were "Once Upon a Time" tales.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $45,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
MOSCOW, Nov. 18 -- Cold weather has apparently set in here, putting an end to a long, mild autumn that was a weather bonus for Soviet agriculture.

Commodity futures were generally higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, coffee potatoes, rubber, hides, burlap, cottonseed oil, soybean oil, zinc and lead were stronger. Sugar, wool and copper closed mixed and only silk ended lower.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (AP) -- A shift of more than thirty Navy ships, ranging from carriers and cruisers to amphibious vessels, is under way, to augment naval strength in the Pacific.

Louis Effrat of The New York Times was elected chairman of the New York Chapter of the Baseball Writers Association of America at the organization's annual meeting at Toots Shor's Restaurant yesterday. He succeeded Roscoe McGowen, also of The Times.

Confusion and consternation spread yesterday in the sugar business as the full impact of the first cancellation of a Government tonnage allotment in the twenty-year history of the Sugar Act struck home.
Two small but outstanding collections, one of mosaic work by Rose Krebs and the other of ceramic pieces by Virginia Davidson, are on display at the Willow, 182 West Fourth Street.

The aggregate short interest position on the New York Stock Exchange fell between Oct. 15 and Nov. 15, the Exchange reported yesterday. On the latter date it stood at 3,125,462 shares, only about one-tenth of 1 per cent of all shares listed, and compared with 3,192,027 shares on Oct. 15.

No matter how public-spirited we may be, most of us think first about our own families. That is why we can find re-assurance in our wonderful modern hospitals, the amazingly fast cures of new drugs, the swift and certain skills of our doctors and nurses and the intricate life-saving equipment.

Housewives will pay less for their Thanksgiving turkeys than they have in several years. That was the good news yesterday from the City Department of Markets, which predicted that next week prices for the traditional gobbler might reach level close to those of 1942.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- Further consideration of the draft code of offenses against the peace and security of mankind was postponed today by the United Nations for two years.
Push-button retailing has moved closer to reality with the introduction of a device which speedily and automatically computes needed information at the point of sale.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 18 -- Defense counsel for Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, on trial on charges that he murdered his wife, accused Coroner Samuel R. Gerber today of testifying falsely for the state.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 18 (UP) -- An Army lieutenant accused of brutality testified today that he had got "rough" with his company because some members answered "uh-huh" instead of "sir" and the group marched "like an accordion going in and out."
The Advertising Council, nonprofit public service group, will put on two national campaigns in various media to assist in the fight on juvenile delinquency and slum conditions.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Intencion today won the featured Maryland Racing Writers' Purse at Pimlico before 11,245 fans.
With assurances that her trip had been a personal as well as political success, Queen Elizabeth, the Queen Mother of Great Britain, left New York yesterday for England on the Cunard liner Queen Mary.

Quite a tribute is being paid to "Porgy and Bess" by Milan's famed La Scala. The management of the Italian citadel of opera has selected the renowned operetta by George and Ira Gershwin and DuBose Heyward, derived from "Porgy," the drama by Mr. and Mrs. Heyward, for performances there the week of Feb. 21.
In anticipation of the Christmas shopping season, gift boutiques were opened yesterday at Ohrbach's and Bloomingdale's.

There will be a scarcity of play guns in the Christmas stockings of one group of preschool children in Brooklyn this year and, for that matter, fewer toy firearms the year round, if their mothers have their way. This decision was reached at a mothers' discussion program yesterday at the Brooklyn Public Library's New Utrecht Branch, 8204 Eighteenth Avenue.
The Chase National Bank announced yesterday plans for "a multi-million-dollar corporation" to meet American industry's need for medium-term credit in financing export trade.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 18 (AP) -- Paul Richards said today he knew that the first baseball deal he made would bring Baltimore down on his head because he traded the Orioles' star pitcher and idol of the kids, Bob Turley. But the gambling instinct in Paul prevailed.
The city's first diabetes control center should also be called a prevention center, according to Dr. Henry E. Marks, president of the New York Diabetes Association.
Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, urged yesterday that Air Force personnel receive a 25 per cent pay increase at the time of their first reenlistment.
The Kansas City Southern Railway Company sold $50,000,000 of first mortgage thirty year 3 1/4 per cent series C bonds in the public market yesterday.

The Panamanian freighter Lake Charles and the Japanese freighter Merinsan Maru collided in a mist in the East River just south of the Williamsburg Bridge shortly before 8 o'clock last night. The Lake Charles made her way to the Manhattan shore, where she went down by the bow in twenty-five feet of water along-side the sea wall at the East River Park.
Two selling waves beat upon the New York Stock Exchange yesterday and carried away some of the recent profits.
The Board of Estimate yesterday authorized the long-projected face-lifting of the Manhattan Plaza of the Brooklyn Bridge.
Martin Van Buren, Edgar Allan Poe, Alfred E. Smith and other patients among the "sick poor" of the past might have a hard time recognizing the Northern Dispensary today.

THE Federal Communications Commission acknowledged yesterday that its staff had begun the paper work preparatory to raising formally the question of whether the agency should authorize pay-as-you-go television, the system of home video whereby a viewer would pay for the program he sees.
Claude Benham, Columbia's sophomore star quarterback, is expected to be ready to play against Rutgers as the Lions close their football season at Baker Field tomorrow.

The people of Red China would welcome a Nationalist invasion of the mainland, in the opinion of four veteran Roman Catholic missionaries who returned here yesterday after five years, under house arrest in China.

MONTREAL, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Jean Marc Beliveau scored a tie-breaking goal with 14 seconds to play tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 5-4 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 18 -- United States sources said today that the 220 pounds of fissionable material to be provided by the United States under the atoms - for - peace program would be uranium 235. This is to be used in small experimental atomic reactors.

LONDON, Nov. 18 (Reuters) -- Leaders of the Church of England adopted today a resolution criticizing the right of Prime Ministers of Britain to advise the sovereign on who should be appointed Bishops and Deans.
LONDON, Nov. 18 -- The House of Commons tonight approved by 264 votes to 4 the Paris accords arming West Germany.

AFTER thirty-two years the machinery of "Abie's Irish Rose" is still rickety. In the revival, which was put on at the Holiday last evening, Anne Nichols' plot is as mechanical as it used to be, and most of the jokes are elementary.

EN ROUTE TO TEXAS, Nov. 18 -- The colors of autumn are still bright on the rugged mountain that goes by the geographical name of West Virginia. And the oaks and maples on the Russell Cave Pike near Lexington, Ky., glow with what seems to be a golden fire when they catch the sunset's last rays.

The annual ball arranged by members of the Canadian Women's Club of New York City, Inc., will be held tonight in the Gold Ballroom and the Salon Bleu of the Savoy-Plaza. Proceeds will further the philanthropic work of the organization and the Lighthouse Nursery Schools.

CINCINNATI, Nov. 18 -- Maurice A. Hutcheson of Indianapolis was assured of re-election when he was nominated without opposition here today for the presidency of the United Brotherhood of Carpenters, A. F. L., in convention here.

Stanley M. Isaacs, Republican-Liberal minority leader of the City Council, said yesterday he was sorry that anyone might have been offended by a verse distributed at the dinner in his honor on Wednesday evening in the Roosevelt Hotel. He said that to him and most of the others present, it had been a "wonderful party."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France appealed to the United States today for greater financial help in holding South Vietnam against communism.
Floyd Patterson, the 19-year-old light-heavyweight who has made great strides since turning professional, faces the most important bout of his career tonight at Madison Square Garden.

The future home-making plans of 4,000 men and women college seniors, all engaged to be married, indicate that bread-winning responsibilties are to be shouldered by both wives and husbands in nearly every household. This fact was indicated in a report released yesterday on a survey conducted by consumer research specialists among senior students on twenty campuses in sixteen states.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 19 -- Damages estimated at $1,000,000 were sought in a trademark infringement suit filed in Federal Court today by Louis H. Loew against the Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation and KMTR Radio Corporation over the use of the title CinemaScope.

The opening of the American Stamp Dealers Association's Sixth Annual National Postage Stamp Show was highlighted yesterday by the first-day sale of a new 4-cent stamp bearing a portrait of Abraham Lincoln. The exhibit drew crowds of stamp collectors to the Seventy-first Infantry Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Thirty-fourth Street.

MANAGUA, Nov. 19 -- President Anastasio Somoza said today that his Government had recommended the elimination of exchange taxes. The aim will be to obtain for Nicaragua the best possible trading position with free commercial and exchange transactions based on a healthy and stable currency and balanced payments, he said.
Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, commanding general of the First Army for the last two years, closed the book on his active career as a soldier yesterday.

The Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company filed in Federal Court yesterday a voluntary petition of reorganization under the National Bankruptcy Act. The petition was filed by the company's president, William Reid.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- The stock markets were generally brighter today although the improvements on yesterday's prices were small. The more confident atmosphere was attributed to yesterday's Conservative victory in a key by-election.

SOMERSET MAUGHAM, a master of Savile-Row-tailored fiction, likes to say that a story should have a beginning, a middle and an end. Well so, to be sure, should laundry lists and angleworms. The important things about a story concern depth, not length; the things we remember are subject, pace, style. In these Mr. Maugham excels, as he shows once again in John Beecroft's excellent new anthology, the Literary Guild December selection, "Mr. Maugham Himself."*

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- L. Judson Morhouse, State Republican Committee Chairman, told State Young Republicans here tonight that the Republican Legislature next year "will give fair consideration" to any fiscal proposals advanced by the Democratic administration of New York City but "will fight any attempt to raid the State Treasury."

Three four - story apartment houses at 148-152 Parkside Avenue and 5 St. Paul's Place in Brooklyn have been sold by the Park End Realty Corporation to an investing syndicate represented by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York.

At the request of the National Security Council the Foreign Operations Administration is now preparing a comprehensive aid program with special emphasis on Asia. Some of the program is already being accelerated. In the case of free Vietnam, for example, a "crash" program of greatly increased assistance has already been launched.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Premier Pierre Mendes-France placed France today "on the front line" of the struggle against communism and other forms of totalitarianism.
MIAMI, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Miami's swift football team, led by Quarterback Carl Garrigus, cut down Alabama tonight before 61,421 in the Orange Bowl, 23 to 7.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Gen. B. W. Chidlaw, commander of the Continental Air Defense Command, asked radio and television news directors today for assistance in "building a public appreciation" of the country's danger from air attack.
Trade buying pushed cocoa prices up the cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Synthetic star sapphires and rubies, bred here of wartime research, today gave the Court of Customs and Patent Appeals a rare case involving alleged unfair trade practices in the import of goods.

Breakfast for the business community is being served from the mantelpiece this morning. Last night at the Sheraton Astor Hotel 1,502 moguls of finance, industry and government "assumed the position." In its thirteenth "Financial Follies," the New York Financial Writers Association did the rest.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The United States has undertaken to build and finance a radar warning system across the Canadian Arctic. The network is to be linked with seven experimental radar stations already established in northern Alaska.
The focus of attention at last night's performance of Puccini's "Madama Butterfly," at the Metropolitan, was Lisa Della Casa, who was making her first appearance in the title role.
BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission plans new bomb tests in Nevada next spring.
CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Montgomery Ward Co. reported today that net income dropped in both the third quarter and nine months ended Oct. 31 from the levels of 1953.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 19 -- Hermann Field reached the free world today after five years in a Communist prison in Poland.
Theodore Reeves' new play, "Wedding Breakfast," will be served to Broadway theatregoers at the Forty-eight Street Theatre tonight at 8:20.

BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., Nov. 19 -- William M. Harris, an amateur art collector, said tonight that a painting he had bought at an auction for less than $1,000 had been authoritatively appraised as a self-portrait of Elisabeth Vigee Le Brun, noted eighteenth century French artist, worth as much as $75,000.

TRENTON, Nov. 19 -- Attorney General Grover C. Richman announced today that the Cape May County grand jury had indicted forty-two persons, including a borough commissioner, for alleged voting frauds in the seashore resort of Avalon.
JERUSALEM, Nov. 19 -- The Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission decided today that the Egyptian complaint in connection with the Israeli ship Bat Galim was "unfounded."
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 19 -- The nation's leading weather forecasters paid tribute today to the late Grady Norton at the closing session of the American Meteorological Society's convention at the Beach.
Life expectancy of the average American today who survives infancy is about 71 years, contrasted to the average span of 49 years in 1900. A person who reaches 50 can expect to see 75, at least.
Frozen, stuffed Thanksgiving turkeys in the transparent plastic film known as Cryovac can go directly into the oven in this wrapping.
SANTA FE, N. M. -- A New Mexico District Court ruled Wednesday that a Negro woman teacher must be reinstated by a local school board thtat had dismissed her.
A "tough" approach to communism is the best way to prevent another world war, Gen. Mark W. Clark, former Far Eastern Commander declared yesterday.

Research in construction techniques to produce houses with less waste and with fewer man-hours of labor is the greatest need of the building industry at the present time, Herman H. York, Queens architect, declared yesterday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 19 -- The possibility of rain tomorrow and a long list of Eli injuries have combined to make the seventy-first football game between Harvard and Yale a virtual toss-up. A sellout crowd of 40,000 is expected to see the contest. The kick-off time is 1:30 P. M.

A bookkeeper's suspicion of a possible hold-up led to the shooting of an alleged narcotics seller and the arrest of a man said to be his customer on the sixteenth floor of a midtown office building yesterday afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Following is the text of a speech by Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, at a National Press Club luncheon today:

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Efforts of Herbert Brownell Jr., Attorney General, to put the National Lawyers Guild on the subversive list of the Department of Justice were assailed today at the guild's national convention here.
