Walter F. O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, returned yesterday from a tour of the Caribbean winter leagues and forthwith set the record straight on a number of interesting items.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States called today on all who love justice and hate iniquity to join with them in protest against the "misuse of power" in Communist nations.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The United States and French Governments are disturbed about the declining military and political situation in Indochina.
Yesterday was the first weekday since July 20 without a new polio case to record at the Health Department.

Six men prominent in boxing circles here were suspended by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday pending the official hearing of charges of blacklisting and monopoly directed against the New York Boxing Managers Guild and its parent International Guild.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Associated Press observers of Russia and the Far East said today that United States prestige abroad had slipped in the last two years and that something should be done to revive it.

The Treasury's terms for refunding $17,347,000,000 of maturing debt were well received by the bond market yesterday. United States Government obligations gained slight fractions of a point, with firmness especially notable among issues of bonds resembling in term that of the new eight-year-eight-month 2 1/2 per cent issue which the Treasury proposes as part of the conversion of maturing debt.

Private industry yesterday offered to build twenty-three new 25,000-deadweight-ton tankers for long-term charter to the Navy's Military Sea Transportation Service in response to an invitation to bid on fifteen vessels.
TOKYO, Nov. 19 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida, fresh from a two-month tour of the United States and Western Europe, told the Japanese people today he had become more keenly aware of the Communist menace.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Following is the reply by M. Mendes-France at the National Press Club luncheon today to questions put by those present:

Despite Soviet wrecking maneuvers, the process of ratifying the Paris agreements is off to a good start. The honor of being the first nation to complete this process belongs to Denmark, but the British House of Commons was close behind when it approved all the agreements calling for a historic British commitment to the defense of the European Continent.
MOSCOW, Nov. 19 -- Regardless of whether any Western countries participate, the Soviet Union apparently intends to hold its proposed European mutual security conference in Moscow Nov. 29.
BOUND BROOK, N. J., Nov. 19 -- An election recount today gave the police a pay rise they thought they had lost by twenty votes on Nov. 2. The recheck showed it passing by fifty-two votes.

BOMBAY, Nov. 19 -- K. C. Reddy, Minister for Production, formerly opened a $35,000,000 Standard Vacuum Oil Company refinery today at Trombay, an island eight miles from Bombay. The establishment, which went into actual operation in July, six months ahead of schedule, represents the largest single foreign investment in India since the country became independent in 1947.

In the renewal of a 56-year-old rivalry, the oldest in the city between public school elevens, Boys High overpowered Erasmus, 27 -- 0, yesterday. The contest at Boys Field, Brooklyn, was the forty-ninth in a series that Erasmus leads with twenty-three triumphs. Boys has twenty-two victories and four games were tied.
NAPLES, Nov. 19 -- Charles (Lucky) Luciano, former New York vice king, will have to stay home every night for the next two years.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Sir Anthony Eden denied tonight any knowledge that he would be elevated to the Prime Minister-ship. But he made it clear he did not consider his long service as Foreign Secretary had made him unfit for the office.
The owner and manager of a Brooklyn automobile repair company accused of overcharging a motorist was sentenced yesterday in the Court of Special Sessions.
BUFFALO, N. Y., Nov. 19 (AP) -- State Supreme Court Justice Regis O'Brien today denied a petition by a stockholder of Remington Rand, Inc., seeking access to the stock record.

YONKERS, Nov. 19 -- A veteran newspaper reporter received a death threat early today after chunks of concrete were thrown through five windows of his home by three or four men who fled in an automobile.

In the city's campaign to stop book stores and novelty shops from selling erotic books, pictures and postcards, Supreme Court Justice Edward A. Gavagan granted a temporary injunction yesterday against Kingsley Books, Inc., and ordered that an early date be set for trial.

JACOB LATEINER, one of the most significant pianists of the rising generation, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. The program was not one of unusual contents, although it had been arranged in an individual way.

New York's distinctive character was said yesterday to derive from a spirit animated by a sensitive civic conscience that no other city can quite match. Dr. Allen Nevins, Professor of History at Columbia University, developed the point in an address at the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West.
If New Yorkers needed additional proof of the erroneous reasoning on which their traffic laws are based, this latest scandal on the "fixing" of tickets should have provided it.

In the Social Committee of the United Nations General Assembly the question of the illegal traffic in narcotics by Communist China has again been raised. This is not a new question. The use of the opium trade by Red China to obtain foreign exchange has been closely documented for the United Nations by our own Commissioner of Narcotics, Harry F. Anslinger.

The Tax Court of the United States, in a precedent-making decision, has ruled that recipients of grants from philanthropic organizations for fellowships in research and study are exempt from paying income tax on them.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 19 -- Contradictions in various statements a few days apart by Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard as to how his wife was beaten to death were shown by testimony of a detective at the 31-year-old osteopath's trial for murder here today.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (UP) -- The six best 3-year-olds, fit and ready to run, headed by Fisherman and Helioscope, were entered today for tomorrow's eighteenth running of the $50,000 Pimlico Special.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Frank Wiener, the chairman of the State Athletic Commission, reprimanded the two judges and the referee who last night awarded to Carmen Bartolomeo an eight-round decision over Jake Josato at the Met.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 19 -The West German Cabinet forwarded the Paris and Saar agreements to the Bundesrat, the upper house of Parliament, for ratification today.
The emotional problems parents have with other adults in their family are discussed in a book published today, "In-Laws: Pro Con," by Dr. Evelyn Millis Duvall.
PARIS, Nov. 19 -- France has widened the Tunisian Government's powers before it has gained the internal autonomy it is seeking.
ALBANY, Nov. 19 (AP) -- At least 4,339 ballots from service men and their dependents remain to be counted in determining the official outcome of the Nov. 2 election.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery of Great Britain arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, by plane from Toronto yesterday at 12:30 P. M.

ALTHOUGH no one would know it, the official opening of the "tip-up" season occurred this week, so if you can locate a body of water with ice of sufficient strength to hold your weight you may fish through it.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- An international race for atomic knowledge has now begun. The United States and Britain are seeking to confine competition to purely peaceful purposes. For this reason Washington offered 100 kilograms of fissionable material for the construction by other countries of experimental reactors and London pledged an additional twenty kilograms.

Less than a month after he completed a ninety-day contempt-of-court sentence, William L. Patterson, executive secretary of the Civil Rights Congress, was sentenced yesterday to another ninety-day jail term for failure to produce books and records of his organization.

A new book of poetry by Lewis Carroll, as odd as it may sound, will be issued Nov. 29 by Macmillan and will be titled "Useful and Instructive Poetry." The poems were written and illustrated by Charles Dodgson, author of the "Alice in Wonderland" stores, at the age of 13 for his young brother and sister.
The Ladies of Charity of New York Catholic Charities will attend a conference at 11:30 A. M. today at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel after their annual communion breakfast.

The city's quest for a sound career and salary plan for its employes got under way yesterday with an all-day hearing before the Board of Estimate. The session was devoted to a tentative reclassification set-up for the architectural and engineering services.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Officials of the world shooting championships today took away a title apparently won by an American and gave it to a Russian on a recount.
TOKYO, Nov. 19 (Reuters) -Japan today decided to cut cotton goods exports by nearly half.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Gen. Nguyen van Hinh, Vietnamese Army Chief of Staff, left by plane for France tonight for consultations with former Emperor Bao Dai that are expected to end the political crisis here.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 -- Wheat futures prices moved irregularly here today. After receding from early high spots, the market moved up to new seasonal highs for all deliveries before again receding. At $2.30 a bushel and over for the December delivery there was considerable profit-taking.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Two cotton state Senators announced today they would introduce legislation to add 1,400,000 acres to the 1955 cotton planting allotment when Congress convenes in January.

CHICAGO, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Engineers are working on a plan to remodel the Lake Michigan shoreline here and give to the city a harbor for ocean-going vessels that would rank with the greatest in the world.

One of today's most vexing social problems is the relentless growth of slums in the nation's urban communities. They represent severe economic loss and human misery. They breed juvenile delinquency, crime and lax government. One million new dwelling units go up each year, but all equal number are permitted to degenerate into slums.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Second Lieut. Charles C. Anderson, 24-year-old Korean combat veteran, was convicted by court-martial today of mistreating Army recruits at near-by Camp Gordon and dismissed from the service.

Gen. Walter Bedell Smith, surveying world affairs from the vantage point of "six whole weeks of private life," said last night that bold advances in the cause of peace had been made in the last several years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A report that cerebral palsy research topped the half-million-dollar mark for the first time this year was made tonight by Leonard H. Goldenson, president of United Cerebral Palsy, at its fifth annual convention.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Any action toward Senate approval of President Eisenhower's nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York to the Supreme Court was blocked today until next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Republican leaders sought today to dispel suspicions that they might sanction efforts to kill the pending censure action against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, or thrust it into the Democratic-controlled Eighty-fourth Congress.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 19 -Dartmouth and Princeton will end their 1954 football seasons tomorrow when the Indians and the Tigers meet at Palmer Stadium game before 30,000 spectators.

FEW contemporary abstract painters have had such influence on today's younger artists (particularly those in and about New York) as Hans Hofmann. The present exhibition of his recent canvases at the Kootz Gallery, 600 Madison Avenue, is therefore an event of interest not only for those who heed the precepts and the practice of this genial veteran but also for those who attempt to understand his art.
NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Nebraska will meet Oklahoma tomorrow in a Big Seven Conference football game that is expected to give the Sooners their seventh straight loop title.

Now that Premier Mendes-France is tackling the drinking habits of his fellow-citizens he may find that Indochina, North Africa, German rearmament and the Saar were child's play. The French Cabinet has adopted a series of measures that would cut down on the manufacture and consumption of hard liquors.

MOSCOW, Oct. 24 -- "The word 'career' is not used in our life," Anna Andreevna Grinyenko, director of the Red October candy factory, said reprovingly to the news correspondents from capitalist countries who sat around the conference table in her office.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 19 (UP) -- A driving finish carried W. J. Beattie's favored Terry S. to a three-length triumph today in the feature for 3-year-olds at Narragansett Park.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 19 (AP) -Clair Bee, former Long Island University basketball coach, has resigned as coach of the Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association.
Joseph Prendergast, executive director of the National Recreation Association, yesterday was elected chairman of the advisory committee of Keep America Beautiful, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Lawyers for Prof. Owen Lattimore today told the Department of Justice that it should withdraw charges of bias against Judge Luther W. Youngdahl or test their validity in the Federal Court of Appeals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Navy said today that it had canceled airplane contracts valued at $372,000,000 because of delays in the development of two jet engines and one airframe type.
Continuation of the present system of apportioning state grants for school operation for another year will probably be recommended by the special State Commission on Educational Finance.

Stocks slipped in the first hour of yesterday's market, as if in a continuation of the Thursday decline, but found their feet before noon. The closing levels showed that the losses of the day before had been recovered with a little to spare, although no new 1954 highs had been recorded by the averages.

Robert R. Young, a maverick in the railroad industry for the last eight years, is back in the Association of American Railroads' corral. That organization is the official spokesman for the nation's 129 Class I railroads -- those with operating revenues of more than $1,000,000 annually.

SYDNEY, Australia, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Australia's Davis Cup hopes soared today when Ken Rosewall and Lew Hoad made a brilliant return to form and retained the doubles title at the New South Wales tennis championships with a 7-5, 8-6, 6-1 victory over their countrymen, Mervyn Rose and Rex Hartwig.

Two five - story apartment houses and a six-story loft building at 47-49 Eighth Avenue and 338 West Fourth Street have been sold by the Ottinger estate to a syndicate headed by Harry Klen. Walter Samuels, Inc., were the brokers and title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Wilfrid Pelletier conducting, Carnegie Hall, 11 A. M.; Roland Hayes, tenor, Town Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 2; Eldin Burton, pianist, Mason Hamlin Salon, 3 East Forty-third Street, 3; and the National Association for American Composers and Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30.
The Gaylord Container Corporation and its subsidiaries re-] ported yesterday net profit of $5,189,492 for the first nine months this year, against $5,653,615 earned in the 1953 period.
VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- Chancellor Julius Raab will fly to Washington tomorrow without having achieved a settlement of the claims of Jewish victims of nazism against his country.

TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 19 -- The Board of Regents of the University and State Colleges, for the first in its history, will hold a meeting tomorrow with newspaper reporters present. Expansion of Arizona State College at Tempe may be urged.

BERLIN, Nov. 19 -- Otto Grotewohl, East German Premier, echoed today Moscow's warning that the Western European Union would be met by counter-moves in the East. At the same time he elevated his minister in charge of the quasi-military forces to Deputy Premier.

CAMDEN, N. J., Nov. 19 -- The case of the two union employes whose discharge on Nov. 5 from the New York Shipbuilding Corporation precipitated a work stoppage that extended to midnight last Tuesday will be submitted to arbitration.

The annual Thanksgiving Eve dinner dance for the benefit of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind will be held Wednesday night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. The occasion will mark the organization's fortieth year of service.

It is heartening to see The New York Times give front-page significance to a discussion of the decision by West Point and Annapolis to forbid debate on this year's intercollegiate topic, the recognition of China. This reaction gives distressing evidence of the limits applied to liberal education at the two academies.

HAVANA, Nov. 19 -- Harris Whittemore of Lake Quassapaug, Conn., won the Western Hemisphere snipe championship today when he brought his yacht across the finish line third in the last event of the six race series. He had a total of 9,134 points. His brother, Robert, served as crew.

ROME, Nov. 19 -- Giampiero Piccioni and Ugo Montagna were provisionally released today after having passed fifty-nine days in prison pending an investigation of their connection with the Wilma Montesi case.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today that he did not believe war was inevitable or that a conflict with Russia would "necessarily convert our world into a radioactive cinder."

TRENTON, Nov. 19 -- New Jersey ordered twelve major oil companies today to defend discrimination in gasoline prices to service station dealers or face suspension or revocation of their licenses to distribute motor fuels in the state.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged for the second consecutive week at 109.7, based on the 1947-49 average of 100 in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
At the request of a Federal mediator, organized longshore-men and shipping companies in the Port of New York took another look yesterday at what they want from each other.
Authorities on cancer will attempt to answer questions from viewers tomorrow during a telecast entitled "Answers to Cancer," to be seen over WRCA-TV, WOR-TV and WABD from 2 to 2:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these counts:
A total of 708 pints of blood was donated to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program on Thursday.

A plan to put more patrolmen on duty at night, when more crimes are committed, is under consideration at Police Headquarters. The plan would be accomplished by abolishing the precinct day squads and rearranging the round-the-clock schedules of tours.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 19 -The West German Bundestag reduced the income tax today for the second time in two years. The cuts average 20 per cent and will result in a saving of approximately $800,000,000 to taxpayers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Two Puerto Rican soldiers who were "busted" for cheering the wrong team at a basketball game have been given back their stripes, the Army said today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 19 -- Motion-picture rights to "The Bridge Over the River Kwai," a newly published novel by Pierre Boulle, French author, have been purchased by Sam Spiegel. The independent producer, who last made "Waterfront" for Columbia release, has opened negotiations with John Ford to direct the new picture.
Norman Thomas, elder statesman of American socialism, is 70 years old today.
Three Long Island State Parkway policemen have been suspended as a result of the investigation into a "courtesy card" racket for traffic offenders.

James C. Hagerty, press secretary to President Eisenhower, declared yesterday that the recent elections across the country were "screwy." But, he added, they "dramatized the importance of each individual vote" and the fact that elections were "decided by independent voters."

WHEELING, W. Va., Nov. 19 (AP) -- The president and vice president of the Follansbee Steel Corporation will each receive up to $15,000 annually as consultants if the corporation is merged with the two Midwestern companies, a member of the Follansbee board testified tonight.

In your editorial on John Marshall Harlan's appointment you mentioned that some Supreme Court justices come to that distinguished bench with no previous judicial experience. Examples of such justices which you cited included Taney, Hughes and Brandeis.

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- A three-year program designed to restore prestige to the teaching profession was proposed here today at the third annual meeting of the New York State Citizens Committee for the Public Schools.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -- A Presidential Executive Order is being prepared to reduce the leeway enjoyed by United States concerns in competing with foreigners for Federal orders.

OAXACA, Mexico, Nov. 19 (AP) -- An American driver was killed and his American team-mate was injured today in the Pan-American road race as competitors from many parts of the world sent their machines over the mountainous backbone of southern Mexico on the opening leg.

TORONTO, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press) -- West Germany won its first international jumping competition at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show tonight. The Germans defeated Mexico in a jump-off for the team stake.

Three new works by contemporary composers were introporary by Ray Lev, the pianist, at her Carnegie Hall recital last evening. Two novelties, announced as first performances, were a "Sketch," by Alfred Grant Goodman, Irving Mopper's Sonatina No. 2.

Today's new film is "Fire Over Africa," a Columbia adventure in Technicolor with Maureen O'Hara Macdonald Carey, Binnie Barnes and Guy Middleton, at the Globe. M. J. Frankovich produced and Richard Sale directed. Robert Westerby wrote the screen play, Hugh McDermott, James Lilburn, Harry Lane and Leonard Sachs are among the supporting players.
The editorial in The Times of Nov. 18 entitled "State Aid Flexibility" was an intriguing one for many reasons.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 19 -- American Jewish communities were urged here today to intensify their support of local fundraising campaigns next year to meet growing Jewish needs in this country and overseas.

Columbia and Rutgers will add the twenty-seventh chapter to the second oldest football rivalry in America when the two injury-plagued teams close their seasons at Baker Field this afternoon. The kick-off time is 1:30 P. M.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 3.9 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 8 per cent and orders 0.6 per cent.

LONDON, Nov. 19 -- Aroused by portents of the new Bevanite rebellion and by Conservative electoral successes, the leaders of the Labor party called on British socialism tonight to unite for next year's general election.

UNION CITY, N. J., Nov. 19 -- Lieut. Herman Bolte, answering the police headquarters telephone at 1:30 this morning, was told by a timid voice: "You may think this is a joke, Lieutenant, but I have broken into a building at Forty-sixth Street and Bergenline Avenue and can't get out."

Socialism is not these days a winning cause, what with communism crowding it on one side and an increasingly vigorous and productive capitalism crowding it on the other. Consequently one might not expect a man who, next to Gene Debs, has represented socialism in this country, a man who ran six times for President on the Socialist ticket, to be nationally known and admired.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Community efforts to end race segregation in public schools generally have succeeded and a generation hence the nation's schools may have completed the job, a Ford Foundation study reported today.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 1 point higher to 10 points lower, with a moderate volume of business.

The fifty-second meeting in a 70-year-old rivalry between St. Paul's and Poly Prep and the forty-ninth contest between Stuyvesant and Clinton top today's local schedule of public and private school football games.
MANILA, Nov. 19 -- The Foreign Office of the Philippines announced today that new negotiations with Japan on World War II reparations would start "from scratch," possibly within a fortnight.
The Government filed a civil anti-trust suit here yesterday against the Radio Corporation of America, charging monopolization of radio-television patent rights since 1932.
Your correspondent Susan Faulkner, in her letter of Nov. 13, "To Avoid War," endorses the idea of world government to supplant the "ideal of nationalism" as safeguard against war and violence.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today received a copy of a United States Junior Chamber of Commerce creed described as being "diametrically opposed to communism."

A thrilling idea was included in the Refugee Relief Act of 1953. This was that the United States should open its gates to refugees outside the regular quota who had fled from foreign tyrannies of the Communist variety. These were individuals who had suffered for liberty's sake and could be expected to cherish liberty when they found it here.
Floyd Patterson, 19 - year - old Brooklyn light - heavyweight, scored a unanimous decision over a surprisingly inept Jimmy Slade in the eight-round main bout at Madison Square Garden last night.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 19 -- Two great new power plants have ended, for the present at least, power rationing that has hobbled Brazil's expanding industry.

WATERTOWN, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The chiefs of the St. Regis Indian Tribe of Hogansburg, N. Y., filed a $34,000,000 lawsuit today against New York State to establish the tribe's title to Barnhart Island, the site of the St. Lawrence River power development.

For the first time in twenty-five years an Italian business concern has obtained a private loan from foreign sources without Government assistance or guarantee, according to word received here by the trade news letter, Economic News from Italy.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- India again sought today the right to take part in the founding of an international agency to promote the peaceful uses of atomic energy.
The left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union and the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen, A. F. L., were reported near agreement on a merger last night.

ALBANY, Nov. 19 -- The long-standing tradition under which some would-be lawyers have qualified for admission to the bar by "reading" in a law office rather than by going to law school appeared to be on the way out.

PARIS, Nov. 19 -- In a lawsuit for damages filed today, a Greek shipowner charged he had been defrauded by Aristotle Onassis, shipping operator, of promised compensation for negotiating contracts with the Government of Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (AP) -The Bureau of the Census reported today that cotton consumption in October averaged 35,777 bales each working day. This compared with an average 35,177 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 33,278 for September.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 19 -- This municipality will continue to elect its nine-member City Council by the proportional representation system, as a result of a recount completed last night.
Fordham's football team will try for its second victory in eight games when it meets Syracuse at the Polo Grounds today at 1:30.
GENEVA, Nov. 19 -- The European Organization for Nuclear Research expects to have its synchro-cyclotron ready in about three years, Prof. Felix Bloch, the organization's director, said here today.

VIENNA, Nov. 19 -- Austrian politicians recently have expressed sharp dissatisfaction with what they term the inflexibility of United States policy toward the Soviet Union in relation to Austria's case for a state treaty.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 19 (AP) -- Alger Hiss already has had the "customary talk" with the warden in preparation for his Nov. 27 release from the Federal penitentiary here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 (UP) -- Capt. Eddie Rickenbacker accused two competitors today of having used "underhanded" methods to block his Eastern Air Lines from obtaining a nonstop route to Mexico City.

The Transit Authority has authorized the construction at a cost of $3,831,000 of a conveyer-belt system to carry passengers in a steady stream between Grand Central Terminal and Times Square. There is every reason to believe that the Board of Estimate will approve, inasmuch as the cost is already provided for in the city's capital budget for 1954.

Headed by Bob Cousy, who is leading the league in scoring with an average of 23.7 points a game, the Boston Celtics will clash with the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball League contest in Madison Square Garden tonight.

DETROIT, Nov. 19 (AP) -- Motor vehicle production will move up again this week with United States output of 152,886 units, Ward's Reports said today. The agency counted 130,176 cars and 22,710 trucks for the week. Last week 116,285 cars and 21,496 trucks were assembled.

Havard and Yale furnish one of football's magic pairings today as they have for more than three-quarters of a century. Their seventy-first meeting at Cambridge gets top billing on the final full-scale program of the college season, along with the Ohio State-Michigan, U. C. L. A.-Southern California and Notre Dame-Iowa games.
Common stock financing promises to take the spotlight in the public capital market next week.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 19 -- Opposition leaders in Parliament today presented a motion of nonconfidence in the reorganized Indonesian Cabinet.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Gen. Maxwell D. Taylor, World War II commander of the 101st Airborne Division, took over today command of all United States ground forces in Japan, Korea and Okinawa at special ceremonies at Camp Zama.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 19 -- The United States asked today for "tangible" evidence that the Arab states will go along with public works projects to make Palestine Arab refugees self-supporting.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 19 -Nitroglycerin, which heretofore has been transported gingerly in small quantities by rubber-tired handcarts, can now be sent safely through pipes.
OTTAWA, Nov. 19 (Canadian Press ) -- The interests of Canadian Eskimos will be protected during construction of the Dew line, Government officials said today.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 19 -- The medical schools of the nation, facing increasing financial deficits, must ask and receive aid from the Federal Government in order to survive, according to Dr. Alfred Blalock. Dr. Blalock gave his inaugural address here tonight as president of the American College of Surgeons.

THIS unique adventure tells how a young couple changed the course of their life from empty frustration to loving fulfillment. Frustration number one: Carl and Helen Doss faced a childless future. Frustration number two: 28-year-old Carl, a house painter, wanted to be a minister but this would involve seven years of education.
JOAN BENNY BAKER, the daughter of Jack Benny, responded to a knock at the door of the suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where her father was staying during a brief visit to Manhattan last week.
A program designed to supply electric power to New York through atomic energy is now under way.

BELGRADE, Nov. 20 -- Yugoslavia now has been longer outside the Cominform bloc than she ever was in it. Yet her continued espousal of Communist theory and adherence to a Communist society appears sufficient to require repeated assurances to the West that she will not succumb to Soviet overtures and revert to the Cominform sphere in the East.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, Independent of Oregon, today accused Senator Francis Case, Republican of South Dakota, who switched his position on part of the McCarthy censure report, of "alibiing * * * without an iota of justification.

"THE DARK LADY" of this novel by a Shakespearian scholar is a bastard child, daughter of an Italian actress from whom she gets her coloring, and Edward deVere, Earl of Oxford, from whom she gets her brains.

BUYING the whole trip in one package has proved so popular with travelers to Florida in the summer that both the Atlantic Coast Line and Seaboard will continue the plan during this winter season, although at higher rates.
An outgrowth of the Industrial Revolution, industrial life insurance has reached the staggering proportions of a $38,000,000,000 business in this country in terms of protection.

EASTON, Pa., Nov. 20 -- Pre-game form, which had Lehigh the 13-point favorite, was washed away on Fisher Field today by Lafayette and an almost constant rain as the Leopards overwhelmed their rivals, 46 -- 0, before 15,000 water-soaked spectators.

CROTON-ON-HUDSON -- History, not as an echo of ages but as a tangible reality, looms large along a stretch of the old Albany Post Road between this Westchester village and the Tarrytowns, fifteen miles down the river from here.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov, 20 -- Sixty experts from twelve countries will discuss land reform at the Center on Land Problems in Asia and the Far East opening here Monday under the auspices of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization.
PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 20 -- A new set of administrative procedures went into effect this week at Reed College, the product of a several-week study by its president, Dr. F. L. Griffin.

The Philharmonic - Symphony Society of New York opened its thirty-second season of young people's concerts yesterday morning at Carnegie Hall. The event was the first concert of its senior series -- that is, designed for children over 9.

Frederick C. Schang, president of Columbia Artists Management, Inc., and chairman of the board of Community Concerts, Inc., has sent a letter to the 900 civic groups organized under the banner of Community Concerts concerning last Monday's ouster of Ward French and Robert Ferguson, the two top officers of Community Concerts, Inc.
LONDON, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Interest in British soccer centered on the first qualification round for the Football Association Cup today.

WHILE it is always interesting for house plant enthusiasts to try something unusual, by the same token it is pleasant to have a few tried and true performers on hand. Among these are the angel wing begonia (Begonia coccinea) and crown of thorns (Euphorbia splendens).

LLOYD HARBOR, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Norman Thomas, who ran for President six times on the Socialist party ticket, marked his seventieth birthday here today at a small family luncheon at the home of his son, Evan.

Another solar "battery" (actually a single cell) has turned up -- the third this year. This one is the invention of Edward Keonjian, a General Electric engineer. Like its predecessors of the year Keonjian's cell uses transistors instead of electron tubes. Selenium converts sunlight into electric energy, an old principle.

The Parks Department will give twenty-five competitive boxing shows this winter at its recreation centers. The department conducts boxing classes for boys who may enter the bouts. Any boys who desire to enter these classes may do so at the centers nearest their homes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Senators who recommended that Mr. McCarthy be censured for his treatment of General Zwicker said today they would stand fast despite the defection of Senator Case.

CAIRO, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Egypt rejected today the finding of the Israeli-Egyptian Mixed Armistice Commission yesterday that the Israeli freighter Bat Galim, seized by Egypt in September, had not violated the terms of the armistice.
DETROIT, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Gordie Howe celebrated his return to the Detroit line-up tonight with a goal to help the Red Wings rout the Chicago Black Hawks, 5 -- 0.

A year ago we saw an active industry pouring out advances we saw tape ready technically but still in the wings commercially, and we saw the electro-static speaker still some distance away from the living room.
ALGIERS, Algeria, Nov. 20 -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, said here yesterday that he had taken a critical look at Morocco and found it not yet ready for independence.

MONTREAL -- The St. Lawrence has made a remarkable comeback as a major steamship route to Europe, and the shipping lines plan to broaden its appeal by specializing in the least expensive passages across the Atlantic.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 20 -- Further drastic cuts in electricity for Belgrade's industry as well as home consumption were announced in the press today to take effect immediately. Factory and store working hours were revised.

CHICAGO. ON the first day of November, the newly organized Lyric Theatre of Chicago opened its first season of opera with the Brooklyn-born soprano Maria Callas making her United States debut in the name role of Bellini's "Norma."
KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 20 -- The fifth annual North Shore Hospital Thanksgiving Ball will take place in O'Hara Hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy here next Saturday.

M., at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street. "Different Approaches to Design" is the topic of the lecturer, Bernice Dobkin Hall, an artist and teacher of art.

The civilian guard plan for school crossings, which got under way in the Bronx Sept. 13, has been enthusiastically approved by the Board of Education, the Police and Traffic Departments, parent-teacher groups and even by truck drivers who had been skeptical about women directing traffics.

ALMOST all efforts to control the publication of crime fiction, whether by direct censorship or by "voluntary" self-policing (as in the recent comic books code), deal with matter rather than meaning, the subject treated rather than the intended effect upon the reader.

DES MOINES, Nov. 20 -- The Des Moines University of Lawsonomy, a controversial institution here since the site for it was purchased by Alfred W. Lawson, has been sold to F. A. DePuydt, a Des Moines business man, for $250,000.

TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Associated Press Managing Editors Association was told at its final meeting today that the best way of protecting freedom of information was through an aroused public opinion.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 20 -- New Jersey farmers will not be any better off economically next year than now because a continued high level of production is expected in 1955.

The baffling economic problems which Latin-American nations will present at this conference preclude any simple solutions. Yet our nation, the United States, will inevitably be the center of attention and the source of hope.

The "patient," flat on a turntable, was the 22-year-old Artur Schnabel recording of Beethoven's Fifth Piano Concerto with the London Philharmonic. The "operation" was to transfer the six sides to tape from which it would later reemerge on one long-playing Victor record.

The Boston Celtics took over first place in the Eastern division of the National Basketball Association by trouncing the New York Knickerbockers, 117 -- 98, before 7,240 fans in Madison Square Garden last night.

The scheduled arrival in New York this 'morning of Austrian' Chancellor Julius Raab adds another important name to the list of distinguished visitors this country has received in recent weeks. As leader of a coalition Government which represents 85 per cent of the Austrian electorate, Chancellor Raab comes here as the representative of a vigorous democracy which has made substantial economic and political strides since the Second World War.

PARAMUS, N. J., Nov. 20 -- A local tavern owner, arraigned today, was the eleventh man arrested in the investigation of a high-stakes dice game in the home of a Paramus policeman who received $5 from each person participating.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov 18 -- The leaders of the Praja-Socialist (People's Socialist) party, the only strong rival to the ruling Congress party besides the Communists, are reported in backstage efforts to prevent a disastrous split in their organization before its convention in Nagpur Nov. 26 and 27.

PORTLAND, Ore., Nov. 20 -- Oregon Democrats, flushed with the success of their campaign to elect a Democratic United States Senator, moved this week to bring the state's independent Senator, Wayne Morse, into the Democratic fold.
ROME, Nov. 20 -- Pope Pius XII has suffered a recurrence during the last two days of the hiccuping that has troubled him from time to time.

THOSE who enjoyed knowing Desmond Stewart's fictitious Arab country Media in his earlier novel "Leopard in the Grass," will look forward to a renewed acquaintance in his second book. Media features very prominently in this story of snobbery and surviving imperial attitudes in a part of the oil-rich Middle East that Europeans despise but apparently cannot do without.

WHEN "Kind Sir" closed last spring, Joshua Logan like other producers before him, tackled a recurrent and vexing problem: What to do with a show's props after they have been sat on, gazed upon or wielded for the last time.
TAMPA, Fla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Two more persons were arrested today on charges of transporting stolen bonds in interstate commerce.

Two young men were arrested yesterday and charged with beating a cafeteria manager to death in the Bronx when he tried to settle an argument. One of the prisoners, the police said, was out on bail at the time on a burglary charge.

Stuyvesant High School, celebrating its fiftieth anniversary, completed its football season undefeated and untied by downing Clinton, 12 -- 6, yesterday at Randalls Island. It was the first all-victorious campaign for the Peg-legs since 1923.

NORMAN, Okla., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Through the air and on the ground, by intercepted pass and by recovered fumble, Oklahoma ground down a determined but undermanned Nebraska football team, 55 -- 7, today to wrap up its seventh straight Big Seven conference title and its eighteenth consecutive victory.

A PLAN to make the Garden State Parkway into an important link in a major north-south route is under consideration. MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Nassau County, which originally was to have been the testing ground for permanent personal registration, will take no action under the present law before the first of the year.

HAVING announced early last week that it would turn to George Bernard Shaw's "The Doctor's Dilemma" for its third play of the season, the Phoenix Theatre is ready this morning to let you know that it isn't going to neglect Henrik Johan Ibsen either.

HAVANA, Nov. 16 -- One of the important results of the unopposed election of Gen. Fulgencio Batiste to the Presidency on Nov. 1 will be the rise of a new political movement, according to present indications. The form of organization has not yet emerged, but it is likely an attempt will be made to break with the traditional Cuban political modes and that new leaders will be sought. This may eliminate the present Opposition parties.

IN MAN'S QUEST FOR GOD (Scribner's $3) Abraham J. Heschel, Associate Professor of Ethics and Mysticism at the Jewish Theological Seminary, has written a small book with a large message. Subtitled "Studies in Prayer and Symbolism," the book discusses in six brief chapters not only the nature and purpose of prayer but religion and worship in general and the whole relationship of God and man.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 10 -- A new symbol towers today above the Biblical landscape. In the Carmel hills, where the Canaanites sacrificed to Baal, on the plain from which the Philistines marched against Israel's mountain stronghold, in Abraham's country west of Beersheba and on the cliff above the scene of Sodom's destruction, the oil rig raises its steeple to the sky.
