FOR decades the basic principles of stereophotography have been demonstrated by lining up two box cameras on a level support and releasing the shutters of both cameras simultaneously. To assure uniform print density and contrast the two rolls of film are then developed together.

A LARGE book, this -- large in its subject, scope and point of view, as well as its size. Here you will find an informed, absorbing presentation of the genius and ingenuity of a galaxy of men whose efforts over the last one hundred and seventy-five years have given the United States her eminence in science and her industrial might.

NEARLY every phase of the record business is still on the upgrade. Whether you consider economic or technical developments, the making of recordings or the interest in high-fidelity equipment, artistic standards or laboratory experimentation, the prevailing attitude toward the future is optimistic.

THERE are signs of a returning religious literacy in the books currently being published for the ordinary reader. A case in point is John Dillenberger's and Claude Welch's "Protestant Christianity." This volume is one of several in the field of religion sponsored by the National Council of Religion in Higher Education.

NOT a few Americans will be able to identify themselves with Hadrian; their situation is so much like his. Chosen by a young world power to carry vast political and military burdens, he still demanded individual satisfactions -- art, philosophy, love.
I WONDER if W. Norman Pittinger in his fine review of Jacques Maritain's "Approaches to God," is quite correct in calling it "the Roman Catholic approach to the reality of God."

THIS collection of popular and classical love songs reveals something I had never before realized: we Americans are without a single great popular national love song. Neither Stephen Foster nor Jim Bland, our two pre-eminent writers of minstrel songs, wrote love songs that compare in quality with their songs of place, "My Old Kentucky Home" and "Carry Me Back to Old Virginny."
Established five years ago, the Memorial University of Newfoundland is now embarking upon an extensive educational program to bring schooling to the adults of the entire area of Labrador.
A NEW excitement in Shubert Alley these halcyon mid-century days is a pensive young lady in a cloche hat, a blond marcel, pots of blue eyeshadow and an unblinking expression of azure incredulity.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- A prediction that better "electronic tools" would aid news media in speeding information to the public in the future was voiced today before the convention of the National Association of Radio-Television News Directors.

LONG-PLAYING records may have given the industry the well-known shot in the arm and spurred classical music sales to new heights, but it should come as a surprise to nobody to learn that the bread-and-butter items of the big companies year in and year out are still the Kostelanetzes, the Glenn Millers, the various jazz musicians and the fifteenth "Nutcracker" Suite.
Most adult parties in households that include children seem to fall roughly into five categories.
STAMFORD, Conn., Nov. 20 -- Sixty-five industrial plants, members of the Stamford-Greenwich Manufacturers Council, received questionnaires today designed to find out what ails the area.

MEXICO CITY, Nov. 20 -- Phil Hill of Santa Monica, Calif., regained the lead in the Pan-American road race by thirty-nine seconds today with a blistering ninety-six-mile-an-hour dash over a treacherous mountain road.

SPOKESMAN for the record companies were invited by The New York Times to comment on the state of their company, the industry in general, and to contribute any ideas or get rid of any grievances. Herewith follow brief excerpts from the responses that were received:
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Nov. 20 -- An air defense system 90 per cent effective in blunting a thermonuclear attack on the United States might not be good enough to guarantee national survival.
The manufacturer knew he had a good product. But he needed some money for advertising to tell the public what it was, what it could do, how much it cost and where it could be bought.
LAKE PLACID, N. Y., Nov. 20 (UP) -- A young major who deserted from the Air Force has confessed he killed a policeman when he was surprised during a burglary here, the state police said today.

In East-West relations the idea of "coexistence" was under close scrutiny last week. The idea was blurred by the mists of propaganda. The Communists have all but copyrighted the word; the Eisenhower Administration prefers "modus vivendi." Whatever the language used, the central question involved is this:

The National Committee for Rural Schools yesterday presented a citation to J. Waties Waring, whose ruling as a Federal district judge in South Carolina in 1947 led the way to the Supreme Court's decision last May ending segregation in public schools.

What is to be done with an annual surplus of 200,000,000 pounds in the form of chicken feathers in the face of a shortage of goose feathers? Two Mellon Institute chemists, Edward R. Frederick and Michael C. Jaskowski, have been working on this for the Albany Felt Company and the Navy's Bureau of Ships, respectively.
Stocks advanced for the third successive week to the highest levels in a quarter of a century. The rise was interrupted after midweek when profit taking whittled away some of the gains.

CAIRO, Egypt, Nov. 20 -- Lieut. Col. Gamal Abdel Nasser, Egypt's Premier, added the presidential powers this week to those he already possessed as state executive and leader of the governing Revolution Command Council.

THINGS do end but things do begin too. Take yesterday. Yesterday was the thirty-sixth annual official wind-up to Children's Book Week, a period of time devoted to promoting the idea of "Let's read a book." The picture of a kid reading a book negates the other picture we have of a kid honing the kitchen knife or lining up the sights of a .30-.30, and this negation pleases us.

MORGANTOWN, W. Va., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Quarterback Freddy Wyant directed his West Virginia University Mountaineers in four long power marches today as they trounced North Carolina State, 28 -- 3, before a crowd of 20,000.

AT first glance the home of the modern architect Charles Goodman, provides something of a shock. For all that can be seen from the road is the slightly altered facade of a fifty- year-old house. But once down the driveway and past the concealing black- and-white fence, a new wing is revealed that is all glass and rough stone, in decidedly contemporary style.

NUTLEY, N. J., Nov. 20 -- East Orange defeated Nutley, 13 -- 6, before 8,000 fans today. The victory was the eleventh straight and the fourteenth for East Orange in the series, which concluded with this game. Nutley had won six and four games were tied.
ALBANY, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Governor Dewey's collection of about 1,000,000 papers spanning nineteen years of his service in Government will be turned over to the University of Rochester Library.

THE Senate debate on the McCarthy censure resolution has again focused the nation's attention on the current Congressional investigative practices which lie at the root of this controversy. With few exceptions the charges leveled against the Wisconsin Senator grow out of investigations in which he has been, in one capacity or another, a principal participant.

CALCUTTA, India, Nov. 20 -- Dr. C. S. Liu, the editor of a local Chinese newspaper with strong Nationalist sympathies, has been ordered deported by the Calcutta police. He is preparing to leave India.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 20 (UP) -- A. Bogdanov of Russia, with 396 points, led his country to a sweep of the three top places in the .22-caliber rifle shooting, kneeling position, official placements revealed today at the world shooting championships.
AN organization known as Inter Nationes, in Bonn, Germany, has issued a list of some of the operas being presented this season in twelve German opera houses. It makes interesting reading.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- President Eisenhower, sitting at a desk in the underground White House bomb shelter, today flashed orders to top Administration officials who had fled the capital for secret emergency headquarters in an atomic war preparedness exercise.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -- Farmers with land holdings on areas of Federal reclamation projects in the West apparently have Come through the 1954 season in better shape as to water supplies than droughts in some areas had indicated. The outlook for next season is good, except in a few spots.

NEWARK, Nov. 20 -- Federal Judge Alfred E. Modarelli declared a mistrial this afternoon in the income-tax evasion case of Albert Anastasia after a jury had deliberated seventeen hours and failed to reach a verdict.

AFTER reviewing the careers of such choice twentieth-century specimens of the genus demagogue as James M. Curley, Theodore G. Bilbo, William Hale Thompson and Huey P. Long, among others, Reinhard Luthin arrives, in this careful, learned study, at the conclusion that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin is America's foremost living exemplar of the art of misleading multitudes of Voters.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- In the recent campaign, President Eisenhower and other Republican speakers dwelt at great and agonized length on the paralysis that would surely strike the Government should the voters heedlessly install a Democratic majority in the two houses of Congress -- as, by a narrow squeak, they did.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The trend toward a big labor merger looks like a rush.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- Following is the text of the United States-French communique issued today at the conclusion of the visit to Washington of Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier:

A COLLECTION of twelve stories by the author of "Monkey Shines" and "Touchdown Trouble," this book takes its title from a weak and flat tale of a boy who makes good in professional baseball more by virtue of enthusiasm than skill.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Westchester officials are reluctant to adopt permanent personal registration for the county under the new permissive state law until corrections are made in the statute.
KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 20 -- Hofstra College's football team defeated the United States Merchant Marine Academy, 37 to 0, before 5,000 fans at Tomb Memorial Field today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- The Soviet Union made public today a revised amendment to the Western powers' resolution on the peaceful uses of atomic energy. The amendment would make the proposed international atomic energy agency responsible to the Security Council and its veto.

In an atmosphere of Alpine yodeling, ice skating, skiing and other activities that help make up a winter wonderland, the first International Winter Sports Show began its nine-day stand at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

The latest offer of about $5,285,000 by the Austrian Government in payment for losses suffered by Jews in Austria under the Nazis was rejected as "wholly unacceptable" yesterday by Dr. Nahum Goldmann.
Ten policemen from New York City, Nassau County and Yonkers have been called to testify tomorrow before a Brooklyn grand jury investigating a "courtesy card" racket for traffic offenders.

The weather was warm and muggy last week with rain toward the close. Last year the same week was even warmer and more humid. Comparing the two weeks, merchants estimated that business volume was slightly ahead this year.

IF anyone were pessimistic enough to think that every conceivable gadget applicable to high-fidelity musical reproduction already had been invented, the recent Audio Fair and subsequent developments must have disabused him of this idea.

FEW ears are completely closed nowadays to the siren song of "High Fidelity." Yet, so far, for every listener who has been inspired -- and able -- to create a Brave New World of sound in his own home, there must be hundreds or thousands of others who are held back by combined and reinforcing considerations of prudence and cost.
Manufacturers of better-dress lines who showed spring styles last week made it clear to retailers that they intended to tailor production to orders, according to resident buying offices.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 20 -- Louis Bromfield gave up the dairy business this week at his Malabar farm in Richland County, Ohio. The author said present milk production and prices made it unprofitable to operate a dairy farm.

IN the last paragraph of this third and final volume of his comprehensive history of the duel between Cross and Crescent, Steven Runciman comes to this disillusioning conclusion: "In the long sequence of interaction and fusion between Orient and Occident out of which our civilization has grown, the Crusades were a tragic and destructive episode * * *.

For several years the "Field mystery" -- the disappearance behind the Iron Curtain in 1949 and 1950 of four members of an American family -- has been one of the baffling puzzles of this time of international intrigue and "cold war" espionage.

LANCASTER, Pa., Nov., 20 (AP) -- Frank Gagliardi, the quarterback, passed for two touchdowns to lead Gettysburg to a 33-0 triumph over Franklin and Marshall today. The record in the 57-game series now stands twenty-eight victories, twenty-four defeats and five ties in favor of Gettysburg.

A number of comments in the press since the election have indicated widespread opinion that the results amounted in part to a repudiation of Vice President Nixon and his methods of campaigning, especially in those Western states that elected Democrats to the Senate.

JAMES FARRELL remarks that his daily writing stint on his principal fiction project of the moment is five pages, or somewhere between a thousand and fifteen hundred words. On some days he may also work on a secondary undertaking, like an essay.

PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- The physics section of the Office of Naval Research has made a "substantial" grant to the Paterson General Hospital to develop and construct automatic refractometric instruments for analyzing biological substances and body fluids.
HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 20 -- A $2,000,000 "city" is being loaded on board the Mohammed Ali El Kebir here for shipment to Arabia.

Setting the pace in the race for the National Football League's Eastern division title, to the consternation of most of the experts, the New York Giants will oppose the Los Angeles Rams at the Polo Grounds today. The kickoff time is 2:05 P. M.

JAZZ recordings finally moved into the Microgroove Age during the past year. There had been sporadic efforts to apply the benefits of long-playing records and high-fidelity recording to jazz before this, but the general tendency was to hold to established concepts of the audibility and length of a jazz performance.

ONE of the old "systems" of betting was called martingales. The approach was simple, plausible and wholly fallacious. The general idea was that you wait until something has happened an unlikely number of times and then bet a pile that it won't happen again.

ORLANDO, FLA. -- This resort city will inaugurate the winter season with a big pre-Christmas celebration on Tuesday evening: a 6:30 parade with forty lighted floats, followed by a coronation ball at 8 to include a beauty contest at 9:30 with thirty-five entries from Central Florida.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 20 -- A new Office of Church and Public School Relations, set up here by the Methodist Church's Board of Education, is seeking to determine the "right relation between religion and public education."
OTTAWA, Nov. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The Supreme Court of Canada will be asked to decide whether Federal or provincial labor boards have jurisdiction in industrial relations of longshore workers.

BY increasing the range of its comfortable doubled-decked Boeings, Pan American World Airways has developed a specialized fleet of newly designated Super Stratocruisers with which it is able to schedule non-stop eastbound flights between the United States and Europe on a year-round basis.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 -- Silvio De Vita and Joseph Grillo, who have made an unsuccessful series of appeals from death sentences imposed thirty-two months ago, have won a review of their convictions from the Third Circuit Court of Appeals here.
The veteran tenor, Roland Hayes, gave a recital yesterday afternoon before a large and cordial audience at Town Hall.

MANY of the most cherished spring wild flowers are adding the special beauty of their fruits to the fall landscape. Some must be sought in the forest and others stand out along the lakesides and fields for all to see.

IT doesn't take too much juggling of letters to change set-up into upset. And never is there a football Saturday, it seems, that doesn't have its share of stunning upsets. Some ill-regarded underdog, presumed to be a set-up for a highly favored powerhouse, unexpectedly up-ends the favorite and another upset leaves people gasping.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 20 -- A new undergraduate calendar will be inaugurated next September by Yale University. It will eliminate the "lame duck" period period between the end of Christmas recess and the beginning of mid-year examinations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States decried today the advance of materialism in this country and declared that unless the "invasion" was pushed back outside enemies, as well, could not be withstood.

E. M. FORSTER once wrote that it was "impossible, through reading alone, to interpret the past." It is unlikely that he was thinking of the spoken word on records as an aid to the study of history, but the thought is not an altogether idle one.

A SIMPLE, no-down-payment installment travel plan has been inaugurated by Colonial Airlines as it joins the fly now, pay later trend being followed by more and more airlines. The prospective passenger fills out a form in a Colonial office or at an authorized agency and usually within forty-eight hours tickets can be issued.

GENERAL MOTORS CORPORATION will celebrate the building of its fifty millionth vehicle in the United States Tuesday. The corporation was organized on Sept. 16, 1908, and during the first ten years, four months and two weeks, the companies under its jurisdiction made 1,000,000 units.
Borough President John, Cashmore announced yesterday that his staff had completed plans for the widening of Nostrand Avenue to ease the flow of traffic to and from Sheephead Bay.
CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Germany was described tonight at the annual convention of the National Lawyers Guild as the key to war and peace.

"Oak and triple bronze were about the breast of the man who first committed his frail raft to the angry sea, and did not fear the furious southwest wind battling with the north wind, nor the rage of the south wind."

Grinding out 332 yards along the ground while restricting Lou Little's hapless Lions to a net loss of six yards in that department, Harvey Harman's Rutgers football team humbled Columbia, 45 to 12, in the final game of the season for both teams at Baker Field yesterday.

When George F. Kennan proposed, seven years ago, that the United States adopt toward the Soviet Union "a policy of firm containment" he predicted that this would "promote tendencies which must eventually find their outlet in either the break-up or the gradual mellowing of Soviet power."

Carbon monoxide poisoning might have caused, more than 400 deaths hers instead of ninety-one so far this year, if it had not been for the preventive work of the Health Department, according to Dr. Harry S. Mustard of the Board of Health.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- Douglas W. Orr, a leading authority on the relationship of architectural plans to the curricula of colleges and universities, has been appointed a consulting architect at Princeton University.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 (AP) -- San Francisco's Forty-Niners, paced by the running of Joe Perry and John Henry Johnson and the passing of Quarterback Y. A. Tittle, routed the Pittsburgh Steelers, 31 -- 3, tonight in a National Football League game.
Forty years ago last week the twelve central banks of the Federal Reserve System began operations, thereby ending the re-current "money panics" that had plagued the nation since the Civil War.

Fifty years ago this month, a group of men met in the club rooms of the Central Presbyterian Church, now at Park Avenue and Sixty-fourth Street, and agreed to take a personal interest in the affairs of a group of wayward boys.

Several thousand persons were guests for three hours yesterday aboard the aircraft carrier Bennington. Many were friends and relatives of shipyard workers who have almost completed repairs on the vessel.

LELAND HAYWARD had no need of a guide to show him around the Warner Brothers Studio when he moved in to produce the film version of "Mister Roberts" (See photo above). He had worked there before in the scenario department and as a production executive when the studio was the home of First National Pictures.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 20 -- The next move in a West Coast waterfront situation with troublesome potentialities was awaited by shipowners this week-end. Cast in leading roles were the Sailors Union of the Pacific, A. F. L., of which Harry Lundberg is secretary-treasurer, and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated, headed by Harry Bridges.

Budget Director Abraham D. Beame recommended to the Board of Estimate yesterday that the proposal of Park Commissioner Robert Moses to build six new recreation centers at a cost of $7,546,045 be scrapped.

GENEVA, Nov. 20 -- Although it is not the sort of thing that can be measured with a ruler, world trade is now undoubtedly greater than ever before. The best estimates available show that in 1953 it reached a "volume" (a statistical measure designed to eliminate the influence of changing prices) nearly 25 per cent above that of 1950 and that in 1950 it had already passed the previous all time high of 1929.

AS in his previous book, "Larry Leads Off," Mr. Bishop uses a contemporary situation to dramatize the value of team play. Jim Corson, discharged from the Marines for being under age at enlistment, returns to high school, planning to use football as a sesame to college and security.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 20 -- After the Nationalist-held Tachen Island were bombed for the first time by the Chinese Communist TU-2's on Nov. 1, several American destroyers attached to Task Force 72 got the order to head north.
Many national descents are evident in the art exhibitions this week, as the names of the artists indicate.
GENEVA, Nov. 19 -- Western Europe, it appears, is having most of the advantages of an economic boom with none of the drawbacks -- a sort of boom without tears.
The room air-conditioning industry, commercially speaking, passed from infancy to juvenile delinquency last summer.

THE Pineville Panthers have little chance to win the Weybourne Basketball Trophy. With inexperienced players like Frenchy Beaumont, who almost allowed his first love, hockey, to interfere, the rookie team loses its opening game.
CAIRO, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Egypt has ratified the Suez agreement providing for the withdrawal of 80,000 British troops from the strategic canal zone, Foreign Minister Mahmoud Fawzi announced today.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Northwestern's slashing halfbacks overcame the handicap of seven fumbles today to trip favored Illinois, 20 -- 7, before 39,186 fans for the first Wildcat Big Ten victory since 1952.

The 334th anniversary of the landing of the Pilgrims at Plymouth will be celebrated at a dinner dance to be given, tomorrow in the Terrace Room of the Plaza by the Society of Mayflower Descendants in the State of New York.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., Nov. 20 (UP) -- A forgotten William and Mary quarterback came back today through rain and mud to engineer a 13-to-9 upset of Wake Forest in the fourth period before a drenched crowd of 2,000.

WHETHER or not readers are familiar with the game, they will find that lacrosse provides Mr. Tracy's well-written story with interesting background material. A snobbish and rebellious Buzz Hart wastes little time in becoming Mr. Unwanted on the campus.

WHEN halfback Jerry Rand returns from overseas Army service, he finds that his father, a famous college football coach, has disappeared in mysterious and odious circumstances. Gamblers and fixed games, Jerry discovers, are definitely -- and brutally -- involved.

MORE and more Americans are coming to realize that traveling in late fall, when the days are crisp and clear, is much to be preferred to being packed like sardines in trains, restaurants and buses during the usual vacation months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- This week has seen a rallying to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy by organizations now assured of ten clear days in which to gather their signatures to petitions and otherwise to press the case against his censure by the Senate.
MOSCOW, Nov. 20 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of questions submitted by Pravda, Communist party newspaper, and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov's answers made public today:
Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, arrived here by train at 6:45 o'clock last night accompanied by his wife and a party of twelve for a four-day stay in this city.

THIS afternoon will see the opening of the eighth annual Dance Laboratory series by Walter Terry at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A. at 2:40. In these sessions, Mr. Terry interviews various important dancers on aspects of their art, with witty informality, and leads them ultimately into technical demonstrations and the presentations of several finished dances.

AS further evidence of the maturity of the musical theatre, take the case of "Fanny." It has character. In Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak it also has two actors with style and personality. There is a profusion of routine showmanship in "Fanny," and some of it is distracting.

HOME owners who are doing their shade-tree shopping and planting this month are acting with horticultural wisdom, for late fall is the best time for this activity. But these same shoppers frequently suffer unnecessary upset when they go into the question of price.
BOSTON, Nov. 20 -- Construction of the 123-mile Massachusetts Turnpike will begin next month.
IOWA CITY, Nov. 20 -- Ralph Guglielmi led Notre Dame to a 34-18 victory over Iowa before a sell-out crowd of 52,700 today. The rivals played a controversial tie last year.

DALLAS, Nov. 20 (AP) -- Del Shofner, a sophomore, and Billy Hooper, a senior, set the pace as Baylor subdued Southern Methodist, 33 -- 21, today. The defeat knocked the Mustangs out of the Southwest Conference football race and put Arkansas into the Cotton Bowl.

The thirty-fourth annual bazaar, known as Ye Olde English Faire, arranged by the Daughters of the British Empire in the State of New York, will be held tomorrow, Tuesday and Wednesday in the main ballroom of the Biltmore.

SLOPES or banks present a greater soil conservation challenge to the property owner than almost any other land formation. And, certainly, the steeper the bank the more difficult the soil erosion problem becomes.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, in his counterattack against possible censure, has brought up again the activity of his subcommittee in the Fort Monmouth security investigations. He stated as "uncontrovertible fact that thirty - three security risks at Fort Monmouth were suspended after the committee got the job."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Senator Henry M. Jackson, Democrat of Washington, said today he agreed with Senator Knowland on the need for a review of United States foreign policy.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 20 -- A hospital survey, which industry helped finance, recommends improvements costing up to $7,500,000 for this area.

Barbara Ward's article on the Cold Coast -- "One Answer to the Challenge of Africa" (Oct. 31) -- intrigues me. She seems to find plenty of room for justification of the Gold Coast Government's short, simple and straightforward device of accumulating capital. But the device adopted in the Gold Coast is suspiciously similar to what she claims to be used in Communist countries, namely, accumulation by "starving the marginal people."
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 20 -- South America in general is pessimistic about the Inter-American Conference of Ministers of Finance and Economy, which opens Monday at Petropolis, near here.

WITH the publication of "Travelled Roads," M. A. Schalit celebrates his eightieth birthday, demonstrating that the creative faculty is ageless. Four generations of Jews form the background of this memoir. It tells of the author's childhood in pogrom-ridden Russia of the Eighteen Seventies, boyhood among the first pioneers of Turkish Palestine, adventures as a medical student in the Geneva University and trials as a young doctor in an Arab town.

I DON'T visit the record shops as often as I'd like, but I assume most people buy records periodically -- at least as often as once a week or perhaps oftener. In order to do this, they apparently know what they want, examine records until they find a satisfactory copy, acquire it, then forget about it, going on to another record to add to their library.

AFTER making history -- or at east re-creating it -- every Sunday night for the last seventy-five weeks, C. B. S.-TV has decided that the events ought to be pictorially recorded for further showings. As a result "You Are There," in which moderately young C. B. S. newsmen report on old times and great events, will become a filmed feature beginning Jan. 2.

Field researchers for the Ford Foundation recently completed a study of "Schools in Transition," which was published on Friday in book form. The field work extended clear across the country from New Jersey to Arizona. It took in twenty-four communities including Camden, N. J., Cairo, Ill., Roswell, N. M., and Tucson, Ariz.

A moderately high blood pressure may be a blessing in cases of atherosclerosis, a common disease of the arteries that accounts for the large incidence of coronary thrombosis and strokes. Such was the message conveyed at the annual meeting of the American Therapeutic Society by Dr. Joseph B. Wolffe of the Valley Forge Heart Hospital, Fairview Village, Pa., and the Wolffe Clinic, Philadelphia.

Each year about 800 college and university debating teams compete with one another in regional tournaments and the winners are invited to the United States Military Academy at West Point to participate in a national championship debate tournament.
Two hundred persons participated yesterday in the second annual institute of the Community Services Committee of the New York City C. I. O. Council.
The year -- old City Center Gallery will hold an exhibition and sale of paintings on Nov. 30 to raise funds.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Quarterback Leonard Dawson plunged for one touchdown and passed for another today to spark Purdue to a 13-7 victory over its intra-state rival, Indiana, in their season's finale before 44,000 fans.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 20 -- From a 7-7 standoff at halftime, Princeton stormed to a top-heavy, 49-7 victory over Dartmouth before 23,000 rain-soaked spectators at Palmer Stadium today. Charlie Caldwell's Tigers wound up the season with a spectacular five-touchdown fourth quarter, achieving the most points by one team in any of the thirty-four games in the rivalry that began in 1897.

SOME indoor gardeners are lucky enough to have a room or enclosed porch that they can devote at least partially to house plants. If the room is so situated (separated from the main stream of daily traffic and living) to permit maintenance of a temperature range no higher than 45 to 55 degrees, then it is a real blessing because the culture of an unusual and interestingly different class of plants will be made possible.
Two subjects as diverse as a debate topic and a petition in favor of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy emphasized again last week the thin line between military propriety and military indiscretion.

FROM the moment they were announced, "Moby Dick," directed by John Huston and starring Gregory Peck, and "The Dambusters," a screen dramatization of the historic feat of the Royal Air Force in bombing the Mohne Dam in Germany, promised to be two of the major British films of 1955.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Three championships were awarded and the first qualifier for the 1955 National Horse Show was selected today during the first half of Secor Farms Riding Club's annual two-day horse show held for benefit of the S. P. C. A.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Supreme Court was asked today to review the case of Walter Lee Irvin, Negro convicted of rape and awaiting execution in Florida's electric chair.

ALTHOUGH the deer season is drawing to a close in most of the northern coastal states, the hunter interested in spending another month or two in the field will merely put away the rifle in favor of the shotgun, and he will find plenty to keep him busy.

THE slim, seasonal "Christmas card" of a book has become one of the harbingers of the year's favorite holiday. Helen Topping Miller's slender volume, a vignette of violence drawn from Civil War papers and diaries, will no doubt enjoy a brisk postal flurrying in the weeks immediately ahead.
A PSYCHIATRIST recently remarked at a large meeting of food writers in New York that the traditional feast days in this country gave "a splendid chance for the reintegration of family life."

IN a plot as well-worn as a tackling dummy, Jay McKay is an "outsider" his first day at college. Preferring to tinker with inventions rather than make touchdowns he is cold-shouldered by the student body. After being pressured into joining the team Jay finds he is long on talent but short on incentive -- except when playing against the team bully.

IN the early Twenties Gen. George Pereira discovered a great mountain on the China-Tibet frontier. The natives called it Amne Machin. Shortly afterward he wrote to me from India: "I saw Amne Machin distant more than a hundred miles, but the beauty and majesty of this sublime peak beggars description.

GEORGES BLOND, whose name reminds one of a wrestling mastodon currently popular on TV, is a mature Frenchman who moved out of World War II naval service into a new career as a successful novelist. So far as is revealed, he has never seen a land battle or cooled his heels at a high field headquarters during war.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 20 -- The 9-to-10 favorite was the winner of the $50,000 Pimlico Special for 3-year-olds on this rainy, foggy afternoon at the old Pimlico Race Course. William G. Helis Jr.'s Helioscope did the job. He did it with ease.

MONTREAL, Nov. 20 -- Charlie Hodge became the third substitute Montreal goalie to post a victory in his first National Hockey League start as the Canadiens downed the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, tonight before 14,451 fans.

ON the night Mrs. Simpson arrived at Cannes, shortly before the abdication, Lord Brownlow, the aide accompanying her, dropped exhausted onto a divan and put a question to the Duchess-to-be, who was in the next room.
Marshall Ryon, a starter for the first time this season, tallied three touchdowns as Poly Prep routed St. Paul's School, 32 -- 13, on the victor's gridiron in Brooklyn yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- A gift of 100,000 flowering cherry-tree seeds from the United Nations Association of Japan has arrived in New York for distribution in the United States, according to an announcement by the association's office.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 20 -- The United States delegation is entering the inter-American conference of finance ministers with one major concession: a decided expansion of the Export-Import Bank's facilities.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 -- The nation's top - ranking U. C. L. A. Bruins exploded for four touchdowns in the final period today to defeat the University of Southern California, 34 to 0, and capture their second straight Pacific Coast Conference championship.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 (AP) -- A Congress of Industrial Organizations official said today he had heard that Senator Robert W. Upton, Republican of New Hampshire, was under White House consideration for nomination to the National Labor Relations Board.
EACH new day hordes of men and women step timidly through the invisible sound barrier that separates outmoded listening enjoyment from the enchanting realm unhappily misnamed "high fidelity."
Night baseball is still on the increase in the major leagues and in Brooklyn it will reach a new high next summer. Thirty games under lights have been booked by the Dodgers for 1955.
The reborn German airline, Lufthansa, a well known name in pre-war aviation, probably will start domestic passenger service early next year.

HERBERT WEST writes in his review of William Plomer's "Museum Pieces" that it is a pity that it is only the third of Mr. Plomer's novels to be published here. Prior to "Museum Pieces," Mr. Plomer had not written a novel in nearly twenty years and in all has published only five.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Bob Hardy tossed a 22-yard pass through the downpour in the closing minutes today to give Kentucky a 14-to-13 victory over Tennessee in a game that included a flurry of fist fights.

For the man with $50,000 in cash or common stocks there are Wall Street opportunities for yields ranging as high as 21 per cent. There are risks, of course, but they are the kind of risks that an insurance company takes.
Virtually all of the commercial production of titanium so far has been by the Kroll process, but its inventor has yet to receive a penny in royalties.
UVALDE, Tex., Nov. 20 (AP) -- John N. Garner will be 86 years old Monday. He plans to celebrate the way he always does -- hunting.

CRAMMED with enough dramatic games to satisfy the most voracious young basketball fan, this book follows the climb to the top of a small Indiana team. Or almost to the top -- for this, like several recent sports novels, has stopped short of the ultimate in happy endings.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Investment in industrial projects in the Chicago area during October boosted the ten-month total to $203,990,000, a 76 per cent increase over the $115,695,000 reported in the same 1953 period, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry said.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I. IF the music-lover will not come to high fidelity, high fidelity may come to him -- right in his own home. This refinement in the marketing of hi-fi has been perfected by a young engineer named George Schimmel.
"THERE is no limit to the number of pictures this company may make in the course of a year," Merian C. Cooper said in commenting on the aims of the newborn C. V. Whitney Pictures, Inc.

The New York State Education Department has outlined a plan to modernize the elementary school curriculum. In a 152-page report, prepared by the Bureau of Elementary Curriculum Development, the department urges the state's elementary schools to introduce modern teaching practices.

Cobalt 60 is a highly radioactive isotope or variant of ordinary cobalt -- a product of such reactors as those at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Chalk River, Canada. Of late years it has been used in place of radium and X-rays in the treatment of cancer, the reason being that it emits gamma rays, which are much like X-rays but far more penetrating.
Opposition to the recently announced change in the traditional Jewish marriage contract by the leaders of Conservative Judaism in the United States was expressed yesterday by a Conservative rabbi.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 20 -- Bunker Hill, Los Angeles' most prominent landmark and scene of some of the community's most gilded memories, was designated this week as the site of one of the largest slum clearance projects in the West.

CAIRO, Nov. 20 -- Egypt's military rulers have offered the post of President to Ahmad Lutfi el-Sayed, 84-year-old scholar and former Foreign Minister, according to an announcement made late tonight by Maj. Salah Salem, Minister of National Guidance.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 20 -- An impression prevails in the West German Bundestag that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer had better start mending his fences. His coalition and even a substantial part of his party, the Christian Democratic Union, were in rebellion much of last week.

HERBERT WEST writes in his review of William Plomer's "Museum Pieces" that it is a pity that it is only the third of Mr. Plomer's novels to be published here. Prior to "Museum Pieces," Mr. Plomer had not written a novel in nearly twenty years and in all has published only five.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Bob Hardy tossed a 22-yard pass through the downpour in the closing minutes today to give Kentucky a 14-to-13 victory over Tennessee in a game that included a flurry of fist fights.

CHICAGO, Nov. 20 -- Investment in industrial projects in the Chicago area during October boosted the ten-month total to $203,990,000, a 76 per cent increase over the $115,695,000 reported in the same 1953 period, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry said.
