The New York State Education Department has outlined a plan to modernize the elementary school curriculum. In a 152-page report, prepared by the Bureau of Elementary Curriculum Development, the department urges the state's elementary schools to introduce modern teaching practices.

Cobalt 60 is a highly radioactive isotope or variant of ordinary cobalt -- a product of such reactors as those at Oak Ridge, Tenn., and Chalk River, Canada. Of late years it has been used in place of radium and X-rays in the treatment of cancer, the reason being that it emits gamma rays, which are much like X-rays but far more penetrating.
Opposition to the recently announced change in the traditional Jewish marriage contract by the leaders of Conservative Judaism in the United States was expressed yesterday by a Conservative rabbi.
The Senate debate on censure of Joseph R. McCarthy has a built-in deadline for this Congress. Under agreement with the House, the Senate must adjourn by Dec. 24.

THE solid achievements of the Dutch artists of the Seventeenth Century having been spread before us in the magnificent exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum, New York may now at the same time make the most of an opportunity to appraise a vastly contrasting era of painting -- the French Eighteenth Century -- in a remarkable show at the Wildenstein Galleries.

BENNETT CERF, whom larcenous columnists detest because he occasionally appropriates what they have stolen, is deeply tanned from exposure to the sunny rays of humor. As a sideline from random publishing, he collects and passes on nuggets of anecdotal wit and giggly gossip, and the puns he assembles are among the most magnificent flagellations of the English language.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 20 (UP) -- Boston University came up with three long scoring plays, including a 96-yard touchdown-pass play today, probably the longest intercollegiate aerial gain of the year, to defeat Temple University, 19 - 7, and become the most successful football team in Terrier history with a 7-2 record.
Isaac B. Grainger of New York, president of the United States Golf Association, has been nominated for re-election.

IN his review of James Warburg's "The United States in a Changing World," Samuel Flagg Bemis reflects our common failure to appreciate negative criticism. His dogmatic conclusion that "simply the U. S. S. R." has prevented world disarmament and economic cooperation emphasizes the need for the contribution Mr. Warburg's book makes.
Although the week's offerings in the auction galleries are relatively light because of Thanksgiving Day, a variety of items in popular categories will be available in several of the galleries.

ON Friday, Oct. 29, the morning after the opening of "The Rainmakers," the play reviewers told us we had "a hit." And many of them congratulated me on having forsaken the "symbolism" of my earlier play, "See the Jaguar."
SINCE January, when television was officially inaugurated in this country, rooftop antennas in increasing numbers have become a rather incongruous addition to this city's domed and pillared skyline.

TWO fairy-tales -- tough, brilliant romances in which reason wavers and intuitions of Good and Evil storm and take the senses, sometimes in an assault by headlong, staring dream-images, sometimes after a quiet, shocking infiltration -- have been pulled off the dusty top shelves of Victorian fiction, given a prudent editing by Mrs. Fremantle and a first-rate preface by Mr. Auden, and handsomely reprinted.
An explorer whose world is as deep as the ocean and the unknown forms of life far beneath its surface is heading again for deep waters and new records.
HARTFORD, Nov. 20 -- Patronage and leadership problems are beginning to trouble the Republican party in this state.

A TREK in the primitive back country of Liberia is the subject of this engaging book by a young American sculptor, whose interest in African art sent her to the source for deeper understanding. Miss Warner is already known for her previous book, "New Song in a Strange Land."

STENDHAL dedicated one of his books: "To the happy few." He did not mean "to a social elite," but "to a few privileged souls, capable of making stendhalism or beylism a way of life." Henri Beyle, who later took the name of Stendhal, spent his whole life (1783-1842) attempting to devise for himself and for the happy few a method that would insure happiness.

The Children's Village of Dobbs Ferry, N. Y., will be the beneficiary of the Dec. 2 performance of "Quadrille." The play, starring Alfred Lunt, Lynn Fontanne, Brian Aherne and Edna Best, opened Nov. 2 at the Coronet Theatre.

SHOWMEN had good cause to cheer last week with the issuance of a special report by the Council of Motion Picture Organizations based on research by Sindlinger Co., independent analysts, which revealed that both theatre earnings and attendances rose sharply this year.

Plans are being completed for the nineteenth annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball to be held on Dec. 20 in the Waldorf-Astoria. This year's event, which will benefit the New York Infirmary, will be sponsored by Jacqueline Cochran Cosmetics. One hundred young women will be presented that evening.

BROOKLYN, long noted for its independence, with a baseball team and an art museum of its own, will soon also have a dance center of its own comparable to the best anywhere. This is less a new project than the consummation of an old one, for the Academy of Music has given hospitality to all the greatest dancers.

MOSCOW, Nov. 20 -- The Soviet Union, which already is training more engineers and scientists than any country in the world, is taking steps to see that the skills of its technical specialists are applied to production and not wasted on administrative tasks.

In a statement delivered on Nov. 5 to the General Assembly of the United Nations, Henry Cabot Lodge Jr. made it plain that the President was determined to create an international agency to develop his "atoms-for-peace" program, outlined on Dec. 8, 1953, before the United Nations.

The resolution on the peaceful uses of atomic energy which in spite of unexpected delays seems certain to pass in the U. N. General Assembly's Political and Security Committee this week scarcely touches the peril that menaces the human race today. It does nothing directly to abolish or reduce the atomic weapon. Yet any agreement among the nations, and particularly between the Communist and non-Communist nations, that affects the uses of atomic energy contains hope.
An increase in shipment of foreign-aid grain cargoes through New York has resulted in the first solid run of business this year for the harbor's floating grain elevators.
OMAHA, Nov. 20 -- A frank talk by a panel of speakers set the National Congress of American Indians buzzing today.
TORONTO, NOV. 20 (AP) -- Spain won the International Team Challenge Trophy -- one of the world's top riding prizes -- at the Royal Agricultural Winter Fair horse show tonight.

WHEN Sylvester L. (Pat) Weaver, president of the National Broadcasting Company, emerges the public stage, attention is not to be directed to his propenity for indulging in his own form intellectual yoga -- writing mos that only Weaver can understand.

Creation by the Colombian council of Ministers of the "Autonomous Regional Corporation of the Cauca" is an event which may well prove to be of great historical importance -- both to Colombia and also to the United States in its relations with Latin America, now so badly in need of improvement.
The French liner Liberte sailed for home yesterday with Olivier F. Naffrechoux, veteran maitre d'hotel, smiling a welcome to first-class diners for the last time.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 20 -- Penn State's Lenny Moore, No. 2 rushing back in the nation, who frustrated Pittsburgh's goalward drives with pass interceptions today, and Quarterback Bobby Hoffman directed the Nittany Lions to a 13 -- 0 victory over the Pitt Panthers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 20 -- M. Mendes-France has been in Washington for the last few days, charming the birds out of the trees and arguing that the milk-drinkers will inherit the earth.
WANT to escape from the mounting pressures of the day? Losing faith in yourself? Having trouble falling asleep? Afraid to face your homework ? Your best girl run out you? Nerves on edge?

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 10 -- The Prophet's Birthday tragedy here Nov. 7, which took the lives of twenty-one persons and put more than 200 injured in hospitals, may have averted an outbreak of religious strife in nominally-Christian Lebanon.

A new customs undercover unit, organized only last July, scored its first major success last week when two of its members blocked an attempt to smuggle thirty-five ounces of pure heroin into the country.

FRITZ KAHN has undertaken the daring and ambitious task of surveying the universe in terms of matter, energy and time and interpreting the conclusions reached by scientists of the past and of our own day in language that a well-educated but technically uninformed reader should have no difficulty in understanding.

MADISON, Wis., Nov. 20 (AP) -- Wisconsin's Badgers, their offense hobbled by Alan (the Horse) Ameche's aching ankle, set a pair of Big Ten pass interception records today and cashed in on enough breaks to rout Minnesota, 27 -- 0, for a second-place tie in the Conference football race.
GLENVILLE, W. Va., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Glenville Democrat went to press last week with a front page bearing only its masthead and an embarrassed explanation to readers.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 20 -- Great Lakes vessel operators felt the full impact of the spring and summer business recession, it was disclosed today.

IN his review of Gilbert Highet's "A Clerk at Oxenford" DeLancey Ferguson writes that Mr. Highet made mention of the Alpinist, Frank Smythe, and then adds, "Gilbert Highet missed a trick by not quoting Mark Twain's remark that Smythe's lectures made people as eager to see Mont Blanc as if it owed them money."

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 20 -- A noted educator said here tonight that the crest of the dangerous post-war offensive against "the right of the teacher to teach unhampered by obscurantists seems to be passing."

LONDON, Nov. 20 -- The Western reply to the Soviet bid for a conference on European security will challenge the Moscow Government to demonstrate its readiness for a settlement of Continental disputes.

PARIS, Nov. 20 -- After eight hours of negotiation French and Tunisian Government representatives agreed on details of a plan to end the activity of the fellaghas, the armed bands operating in rural areas of the French protectorate.
German resurgence and Turkish emergence in the travel industry have set an impressive record, Ralph T. Reed, president of American Express, declared here last week.

TWO sharply different Vietnams are taking shape north and south of the Seventeenth Parallel, which is fixed as a dividing line between the Vietminh and Saigon Government areas by the Indochina armistice agreements.

THE clash between a coach's ethics and the unjust pressure of students and alumni for "big-time" athletics is the theme of this bruising football novel. With a well-disciplined team and a few wins over rivals, Sanborn's coach, Dave Burnell, finds a powerful old grad is "recruiting" star players for the team.

PULLMAN, Wash., Nov. 20 (UP) -- Washington State, led by Fullback Duke Washington and Halfback Jim Hagerty, broke loose in the second half today to whip Washington, 26 -- 7. It was Washington State's most decisive victory in the forty-seven-year history of the Pacific Coast Conference series.

THE French are often admired abroad because "they know how to live." They are conscious of this reputation and, in an era when their prestige has sunk low in so many other fields, they cling to the conviction that they can still give lessons to the world in the graces of life.
THE effect of the revival of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier" last Tuesday night at the Metropolitan was really astonishing. Essentially the opera is second-rate music, but first-class musical theatre.

Members o( a junior committee will act as hostesses at the fourth annu//1 luncheon of the Friends of the Philharmonic to be' held! on Tuesday in the Grand Ballroom 'of the Waldorf-Astoria. The occasion will be a mid-campaign event in the organization's annu,al drive for funds for the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Or. 'chestra.
Is it Utopian to plead for a return to reason and moderation in the public discussion of public policy?
OH, what a character is Hawes! She rates both brickbats and applause. paragraph incites my scorn With its opinionated corn. The next precept turns out to be Disarming with sincerity.
Mayor Wagner commended the Ladies of Charity of the Roman-Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday for their "loving care" of the city's needy for whom municipal agencies are unable to provide.
COLUMBIA, Mo., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The Missouri Tigers used all of their substitutes today in a 41-18 victory that ended the first winless football season in the history of the Kansas Jayhawks.

One of the most ticklish problems that Governor - elect Averell Harriman will face when he takes office on the first of the year will be the adjustment of financial relations between the State Government and the City of New York.

HARTFORD, Nov. 20 -- The Connecticut League of Women Voters announced this week that it would seek to have the General Assembly adopt a bill placing the care of neglected children in the state in the State Welfare Department.

THERE is a right side and a wrong side of the tracks even in the art world. On one side are works of art, man's communication on the highest level; sensitive, talented and dedicated men called artists; and a respectable entourage of collectors, dealers, critics et al, peripherally related to them.

WORCESTER, Mass., Nov. 20 (AP) -- The heavily favored Holy Cross Crusaders spotted surprisingly strong Connecticut three touchdowns today and then bounced back for a 46 -- 26 victory as fullback Bob Rosmarino scored four touchdowns.

Although they had an advantage of two goals in the third period, the New York Rangers were unable to win their National Hockey League game against the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night. The best the Broadway Blues could do was to skate off with a 2-to-2 tie, to the disappointment of the 10,672 onlookers.
NEWARK, Nov. 21 -- A greyhound, Ch. Truly Fair of Mardormere, became best in show tonight in the thirty-sixth event of the Newark Kennel Club.
Former President Herbert Hoover departed by air yesterday aboard President Eisenhower's plane, the Columbine, for a six-day goodwill visit to West Germany.
A $75,000 drop in public contributions may result in the closing of some Police Athletic League youth centers, Deputy Police Commissioner James B. Nolan, president of the league, warned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -Personal income in the United States amounted to $286,000,000,000 last year, compared with the $86,000,000,000 total reported for "prosperous" 1929, the Government reported today. It conceded, however, that the tax "bite" had grown even more and that citizens had paid $36,000,000,000 of their income for taxes in 1953, compared with only $3,000,000,000 a quarter century ago.
The Advertising Council is turning to a cartoon quiz in its public service campaigns for the Red Cross, Community Chests, safety and forest fire prevention, among others.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 21 -- A history of labor-management relations in the last twenty-five years is being prepared at Harvard University.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 21 (AP) -- West Germany made plain today it wanted no part of the Soviet Union's projected all-European security conference, either Nov. 29 or later, at the price of delay in ratification of the Paris accords for German rearmament.

Exercise Minuteman, a simulated twenty-four-hour attack during which an "enemy" dropped six "atomic bombs" on the northeastern United States and was "resisted" by military forces, was ended at noon yesterday.

WELLINGTON, N. Z., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Representative W. Sterling Cole, Republican of New York, said today the United States was not planning any atomic explosions in Antarctica. New Zealand leaders recently expressed concern over rumors that such test blasts had been planned.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- Marl Frank, 13-year-old Hartsdale, N. Y., rider, became the first qualifier for the 1955 national horse show Good Hands championship today by winning the saddle seat equitation test at the Secor Farms Riding Club.

The Philharmonic Chamber Ensemble opened its fourth season on Saturday night, when it gave the first of three concerts it is presenting at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association. To see that the series got off to a good start, twenty-eight members of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony, including the conductor, Dimitri Mitropoulos, took part.

ALGIERS, Nov. 21 -- French forces operating against rebel bands in the mountains of eastern Algeria were preparing today to throw their full strength into a determined effort to force a decision before the first snows.

Your editorial of Nov. 9 and the letter of Nov. 15 by Thomas Jefferson Miley on behalf of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York set forth differing views concerning one aspect of our state's unemployment insurance law -- i. e., the methods used to enforce the law's clear requirement that unemployment insurance recipients be available for work.

The men's clothing industry operated at 70 per cent of capacity during the first ten months of this year, compared with 80 per cent in the 1953 period and 69 per cent in 1952, according to Harry A. Cobrin, executive secretary of the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A.
A loss of 720,000 white inhabitants in the city's population by 1970, as compared with the 1950 census, was forecast by the Department of City Planning yesterday.

Dr. Selman Waksman, winner of the 1952 Nobel Prize for the discovery of streptomycin, and Elmer Davis will receive awards from the Tamiment Institute for their literary work. Dr. Waksman will receive the annual book ward for "My Life With the Microbes" (Simon Schuster).
Smart women have always kept close watch against an increasing waistline, but now they also must be alert for a drop or rise of the belt line as determined by current fashion.
ATLANTA, Nov. 21 -- Thousands of people on farms and in small towns throughout much of the three-state area of Alabama, Georgia and South Carolina are living with acute water shortages.

Hardy Burt, an independent radio and television producer, asked the American Civil Liberties Union yesterday to investigate attempts to "destroy" Facts Forum, an organization that sponsors various discussion programs.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The National Lawyers Guild, at its thirteenth national convention, adopted resolutions today calling for the extension of Social Security benefits to self-employed lawyers, physicians and dentists and urging additional old age survivors benefits, unemployment compensation, Federal housing and Federal aid to health.
BERLIN, Nov. 21 -- The release from jail of Noel, Herta and Hermann Field may lead to the freeing of a number of prominent East European Communists who have been victims of post-war purges.

The hemispheric economic conference which begins in Rio de Janeiro today should be the most important meeting of its kind ever held. Whether or not it will prove that important is doubtful, because there are no signs that the United States is prepared to offer any strikingly new policies, and without a great North American contribution it is hardly possible for the economy of the hemisphere to be powerfully affected.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 -- Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, New York, warned today that the schism between "scientific know-how and ethical know-why" must be eliminated if Western civilization was to survive.

My immediate reaction to the list of members of "Ten Million Americans Mobilizing for Justice" was to wonder if any historical parallel could possibly exist between Senator McCarthy's zealous military defenders and the select army corps that have inevitably been a component in the deposition of democratic processes.
THEODORE REEVES has written a small and winning play. "Wedding Breakfast," he calls it. It opened with a beautiful performance at the Forty-eighth Street on Saturday evening.

Maurice Wilk, young in years but a veteran of the concert stage, gave a violin recital last night in Town Hall. Several ambitious works were on the program, including Bartok's Sonata No. 1, Beethoven's Sonata in D, Op. 12, No. 1, and Bach's unaccompanied Sonata in A minor.

Kermit Bloomgarden's next production will be "Anne Frank: The Diary of a Young Girl." Mr. Bloomgarden, who brought "Wedding Breakfast" into the Forty-eighth Street Saturday night, said Albert and Frances Hackett, adaptors of the popular autobiography, are now in London talking to Garson Kanin in the hope that he will attend to the direction.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- The Ministry of Finance is preparing a bond issue to be offered toward the end of the year, to give the Treasury the full resources needed to meet payments due in December and January.
COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., Nov. 11 -- The Command post for the Battle of North America is a windowless, three-story building in this Rocky Mountain resort town.
THE city's second oldest church edifice, the Sea and Land Presbyterian Church at Market and Henry Streets, looks as clean and new from the outside today as it did when it was finished 135 years ago.

PANMUNJOM, Korea, Monday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- North Korea, which has been unofficially wooing South Korea via the radio, made it official today. The Communists formally proposed "friendly relations between North and South Korea" to the joint Korean Military Armistice Commission.

TO Leopold Stokowski and the chorus and orchestra of Boston University, augmented here by the choir boys of St. Thomas Church, must go the heartfelt thanks of this community for the first New York performance, last night in Carnegie Hall, of one of the most fascinating and delightful choral works that this century has produced, on either side of the water.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) The Senate-House Committee on Defense Production reported today that the industrial mobilization started after fighting began in Korea now was "a long way toward achievement."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 21 -- President Tito reaffirmed today that Yugoslavia was not returning to the Soviet bloc. He underscored this by announcing that Yugoslavia would not accept the Soviet invitation to a conference on European security.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 21 -- There was ample evidence last week that the usual year-end seasonal influences would have little effect on the steel rate this year. It appeared that steel output was headed for new highs in the early part of next month. This is an outlook somewhat better than had been expected a few months ago.

Giving to the needy was recommended by Msgr. William T. Greene yesterday as a fitting expression of gratitude to God on Thanksgiving Day. Msgr. Greene is chairman of the music commission of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York.
Mayor Wagner said yesterday that juvenile delinquency was "a serious problem" in this city, but added that its increase here was less than in any other section of the country.

The Gordon R. Clapp report to Mayor Wagner on the future of the three city-owned power generating plants that supply the subway system reminds us once more that when you have a bear by the tail it is hard to let go. The time to sell these plants and get out of the power business was back in the early O'Dwyer days, before the costly modernization program began.
Election of two vice presidents and a budget director of the Texas Company, effective Jan. 1, was announced over the week-end by J. S. Leach, board chairman.

The Toy Novelty Workers of America, Local 223, has purchased the eight-story office building on plot 64 by 100 feet at 132 West Forty-third Street, east of Times Square. The purchase was made as an investment from the union's welfare fund.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams will make another television and radio report to the people next Sunday afternoon. He will speak from 2:30 to 3 o'clock over Channels 4 and 11 and radio stations WRCA and WNYC.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- The Zenith Radio Corporation has announced what it called "the most powerful hearing aid in its history." The device will cost no more than other models in Zenith's "T" series of tubeless, transistor instruments, William N. Brown, manager of Zenith's hearing aid division, said.

MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 21 -A new wing of B. Altman Co.'s Manhasset store, to be opened to the public tomorrow, expands the suburban branch into a complete department store with nearly two and a half times its original floor space.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Registered lobbyists report they are spending more this year than last.

Activity in the foreign exchange market during the past week was extremely light with transactions reported as being mostly routine. British pound sterling fluctuated erratically and the Canadian dollar displayed a strong undertone.
BONN, Nov. 21 -- The West German Federal Supreme Court will open hearings Tuesday on the Government's demand for banning the Communist party. The case is expected to last three months.

In the quick span of seventy-five years greater strides have been taken in the science of medicine than in all previous millenniums of man. The last quarter of the nineteenth century brought the "age of bacteriology," asep sis, "painless surgery," good nursing and the real start of modern medical care.
The prospective merger of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations would be a good thing for the country, in the opinion of James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor.
KHARTUM, Sudan, Nov. 21 -- A Sudanese political leader reported today a strong trend in the Sudan for independence rather than union with Egypt.
The charter market continued so firm last week that business was even given for a year ahead to a ship still being built.

Horace Ashenfelter of the New York Athletic Club won the Senior Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union cross-country race in 29 minutes 59.3 seconds at Van Cortlandt Park yesterday, This was the fastest time ever registered in the event over the 6-mile 110-yard course.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Premier Mendes-France has evidently had an outstanding personal success in correcting unfavorable impressions of his policies in Washington. However, comment on his talks with President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles was reserved tonight because of what was considered the vagueness of the Washington communique.

A father and the two sons he tried to save were killed yesterday in a fire in their apartment at 2473 Seventh Avenue, between 143d and 144th Streets. The dead were John McNeil, 35 years old, and his boys, Tobey, 11, and Kenneth, 5.
Friends of many years paid tribute last night to Norman Thomas in honor of his half century of last night to Norman Thomas in honor of his half century of labor for American socialism.
Pierre Mendes-France said last night that the Western nations would extend their present unity in the field of defense to unity in political and economic affairs.
A driving rain late Saturday and early yesterday dissipated the fog that had plagued the city for three days. Partly cloudy and cooler weather was forecast for today.

The Adriatica Line, one of the major passenger carriers from Italy to the eastern Mediterranean, has expanded its business fourfold since 1952, Oddo Nasso, its general passenger traffic manager, declared here yesterday.

On a gain of 19 per cent in operating revenues, the Arkansas Power and Light Company realized a 29 per cent increase in net income for the twelve months ended with October, over the preceding twelve-month period.

ATLANTIC CITY, Nov. 21 -The Mizrachi Organization of America expressed profound concern today over "irresponsible statements" that foes of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy oppose the Wisconsin Republican because of his Roman Catholic beliefs.

SALT LAKE CITY, Nov. 21 -- Reversing traffic trends that are harassing department store officials throughout the nation, suburban motorists by the thousands this month have been driving into the heart of downtown Salt Lake City to park and shop.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 21 -- For the first time since World War II an Italian loan is to be floated in Switzerland. It was sanctioned unanimously last week in Milan at a special meeting of stockholders of Montecatini, the leading concern of the Italian mining and chemical industry.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, Democrat of Oklahoma, said today the "only evidence" available indicated the Republicans hired about half of the 6,926 Federal employes dismissed by the Eisenhower Administration as security risks.
HARRIMAN, N. Y., Nov. 21 -Governor-elect Averell Harriman said today that broader Federal aid to the states would improve the competitive position of the states in trying to face their problems.

LONDON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Sir Oliver Franks said tonight Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had damaged the reputation of the United States throughout the world and it was a tragedy that so many Americans were unaware of this.

CAIRO, Nov. 21 -- The Pharaoh Cheops' solar ship, which has lain for nearly 5,000 years in a limestone chamber in the desert floor beside his Great Pyramid at Giza, will be uncovered at 10 A. M. Tuesday.

Mayor Wagner declared yesterday that he would root out corruption among city employes wherever it existed. He also warned givers of bribes to "beware." The Mayor gave his warning through his monthly televised "Mayor's Conference" over WRCA-TV.

Cotton prices in the domestic market held to a rather narrow trading range last week and closed with small changes. Active futures contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange finished at prices ranging from 35 cents a bale lower to 30 cents higher than at the close of the previous week.
MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 21 (UP) -- A caretaker's tip led to the arrest of four persons accused of operating a $250,000 counterfeit money ring, a Secret Service agent said today.

Although the Zimbler String Sinfonietta had aroused a certain amount of local curiosity through some fine recordings, it had not appeared in New York until its Town Hall debut late yesterday afternoon.
A meeting to discuss "fair and reasonable" rates for American ships carrying Government cargoes will be held today. The problem aroused American ship-owners last week.

The four-story and penthouse building containing thirty-six apartments at 435-39 Webster Avenue, corner of Kress Avenue, in New Rochelle, N. Y., has been purchased by Andrew Chow, an investor. The property was sold by Webster Gardens, Inc., through the Harry Levy Realty Company, broker.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Representatives of West Germany's Krupp industries are negotiating with Argentina for participation in Sociedad Mixta Siderurgica Argentina, Argentine steelmaking combine, owned partly by the Peron Government.
DES MOINES, Nov. 21 -- Gov. William S. Beardsley of Iowa was fatally injured tonight when his car crashed into the rear of a pick-up truck two miles north of Des Moines on State Highway 60.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The Post Office Department is pressing forward with its experiments in sending first-class 3-cent mail by air despite intensified opposition from the railroads.

BLAIRSTOWN, N. J., Nov. 21 (AP) -- Robert Dickerson, 18-year-old son of John J. Dickerson, former state Republican chairman, was accidentally wounded Saturday night by a schoolmate examining young Dickerson's pistol.

Bishop Horace W. B. Donegan of the New York Protestant Episcopal Diocese dedicated the Manning Chantry, or chapel, yesterday. The service was held in the Patriotic Societies Bay at the New York Cathedral (St. John the Divine).

E. T. Moore, president of the Jersey Central Railroad, said yesterday the increase in interstate commutation fares on northern New Jersey railroads "will not even come close to paying for our out-of-pocket cost of furnishing the service."

When Roger W. Babson started in the securities business he found dignified old-line Boston investment houses selling bonds to Back Bay clients at 100 and interest. When the youngster, who was being paid a commission of 1 per cent, pointed out that the true market for these bonds was 80 and interest, he was fired.

" Aida," a substantial portion of which was presented on the Metropolitan's televised opening-night program, had its first full-length presentation of the season last evening. The performance was a benefit for the Yeshiva University Women's Organization.

ALBANY, Nov. 21 -- Enrollment in the state's public schools at the end of September was 2,246,967, an increase of 42,362 in a year, the Bureau of Statistical Services of the State Education Department said today.
A complete revision of the city's parking regulations will be submitted tomorrow to Mayor Wagner. The new code, which is slated for approval, includes the following major changes:

BOSTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- John Henderson, a rookie goalie, scored his second straight shutout as the Boston Bruins beat the Montreal Canadiens, 2 -- 0, tonight at the Boston Garden in a National Hockey League game.
ELMIRA, N. Y., Nov. 21 (AP) -The Chemung County Medical Association today announced that it would not support the national fund-raising drive of the Muscular Dystrophy Association.

SAIGON, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The International Armistice Commission's press officer said today the commission was satisfied no substantial amounts of any military equipment had been delivered to the Vietminh in violation of the Geneva accords.

ON the first page of his enthralling book of Northern adventure, "Dangerous River,"* R. M. Patterson refers to the Nahanni region of the Northwest Territories of Canada as "a friendly country and a happy, well-stocked hunting ground." Such words of enthusiastic approval in no way prepare Mr. Patterson's readers for the narrative that follows, for what the author endured in that frozen wilderness twenty-six years ago was enough to kill ten ordinary men.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- Senator Francis Case said today "many Senators" had privately urged further study on the censure count against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy involving alleged abuse of an Army general.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -The National Petroleum Council has appointed a committee to study tank truck transportation on the nation's highways, it was announced today.

The Bank of Montreal achieved the highest capital figures in Canadian banking history and record totals for deposits, loans and resources for the year ended Oct. 31, according to its 137th annual statement released for publication today.

LARGE-SCREEN color television of startling quality became a home reality Saturday evening under the most delightful circumstances. It served to introduce Jeannie Carson, an English girl, who this morning is the town's newest darling.
A Long Island elementary school principal said last night it was time for teachers to urge the abolition of junior drivers' licenses in New York State.
TUCSON, Ariz., Nov. 21 -Palmer Hoyt, editor and publisher of The Denver Post, said today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy "is a grave threat to all our basic liberties."
The anti-litter campaign in effect here should be broadened to cover "the degeneration of taste and talent in this country," Donald Harrington said yesterday.

Senator Knowland argues that co-existence, if we are lulled into it, will lead to atomic stalemate; that atomic stalemate will leave the free world defenseless against Communist "nibbling aggression"; and that after the Communists have picked off the other free nations one by one the United States, standing alone in a hostile world, will have only "the choice to surrender, or die."

Bootin' Ben Agajanian, the Giants' 35-year-old place-kicking specialist, made three field goals against the Los Angeles Rams yesterday at the Polo Grounds. Within three and a half minutes in the second quarter, Agajanian succeeded from the 33, 18 and 37.

When Don MacWillie of Kent School caught a Loomis punt on his 25-yard line recently, and with the aid of fine blocking, went all the way for a touchdown, he did more than pave the way for a 7 -- all tie in that traditional game.
Ohio State and U. C. L. A. each produced well-deserved victories over the weekend to finish their season's work with a perfect record of nine triumphs.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 21 -- President Chiang Kai-shek warned the Chinese Nationalists on Formosa today to be prepared for Communist air raids. In a Civil Air Defense Day statement emphasizing the need for alertness, he declared:
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (AP) -The chemical industry reported over the week-end another $1,514,000,000 worth of privately financed plants under construction or "definitely planned."
The fourth week of opera at the Metropolitan will feature a performance of Massenet's "Manon" on Friday evening, Dec. 3.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 21 -- Columbia Pictures will film the Broadway comedy success "The Solid Gold Cadillac," with Judy Holliday taking over the starring role first performed on the stage by Josephine Hull. Harry Cohn, president of the company, who is on a play-shopping tour in New York, set the arrangements for the Howard Teichmann-George S. Kaufman hit.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 21 -- The reaction here to the new United States-South Korean agreements is almost universally good. High officials on both sides have expressed themselves as pleased with the outcome.

Equipped with the most modern devices to train the physically handicapped in occupations to make them self-sustaining, the four-story renovated building of the Federation of the Handicapped, Inc., was dedicated yesterday afternoon. More than 200 persons were present at the exercises at 211 West Fourteenth Street.
The Reliance Manufacturing Company is offering to purchase 75,000 shares of common stock of Rice-Stix, Inc., at $42 a share, it was announced over the week-end.
The plan to merge Textron, Incorporated, the American Woolen Company and Robbins Mills, Inc., moved one step closer to fruition over the week-end.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 21 (AP) -- Cleveland's Browns, rising to their greatest defense in four years, beat the Philadelphia Eagles, 6 -- 0, today and moved into first place for the first time this season.

CAIRO, Nov. 21 -- Egypt has made her peace with the Sudan over the ousting a week ago of President Mohammed Naguib, according to statements tonight by a special Sudanese delegation and Maj. Salah Salem, Minister of National Guidance and Sudanese Affairs.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Republic of Korea authorities ordered the Communist members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission today to get out of Korea in one week. The Provost Marshal, Lieut. Gen. Won Yong Duk, said that if the Czechs and Poles did not leave "most positive measures" would be taken.
CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- All wheat futures registered new highs for the crop year last week. Oats also moved up to new highs.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -Military chiefs of the fourteen North Atlantic Treaty nations will meet here tomorrow to shape their strategic plans for 1955-56.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 21 -- Restrictions on imports from Japan will be eased tomorrow as a result of discussions between the Commonwealth Government and the Japanese Embassy. Japan is one of Australia's best customers for wool but her shortage of sterling has lately restricted purchases.

Allan Sproul, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, delivered the opening address last week before the Forty-first National Foreign Trade Convention here. In his speech, which was a plea for a more truly international foreign economic policy, Mr. Sproul saw "questions raised," he said, "on two main scores -- our relative reluctance to invest abroad, and our halting approach to a more liberal foreign trade program."
MADRID, Nov. 21 -- Spaniards voted today for officially approved candidates in the first stage of nation-wide municipal elections being held on three successive Sundays.

WASHINGTON Nov. 21 -- Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria arrived tonight to seek the help of President Eisenhower and Secretary of State John Foster Dulles in obtaining a state treaty that would end the nine-year-old occupation of Austria.
AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Nov. 21 -- Dutch imports from the United States have shown a marked increase since the liberalization of trade announced last June.
Good words for the city's Police Department came yesterday from Supreme Court Justice James B. M. McNally of the First Judicial District.

The United States Treasury will undertake this week the second largest piece of refinancing in its history. It will involve the refunding of December maturities of $17.3 billion in bonds and notes. The only operation of the kind exceeding this one in size was also carried out under the present Administration.

The Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes Jr. preached his farewell sermon yesterday as rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church, Park Avenue and Fifty-first Street. He will become Bishop Coadjutor of the Episcopal Diocese of Massachusetts on Dec. 4.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 20 -- Tea would become a more popular beverage in the United States if restaurants improved their brewing methods, United Nations experts have decided.

CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Nov. 21 (UP) -- Karl Wallace, president of the Speech Association of America, said today that recognition of Red China as a topic for college debate would be restudied, but hinted strongly that it would not be dropped.

YOKOHAMA, Japan, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The crew of a United States-chartered freighter quit work and shut down the boilers in Yokohama Harbor Friday, demanding shore leave and delayed pay, it was learned today.

The Rev. Dr. Robert D. Hershey criticized yesterday the practice of equating peace with the concept of "a contented life in a worldly suburbia." His sermon was delivered at the Evangelical Lutheran Church of the Holy Trinity, Central Park West at Sixty-fifth Street.
The Rev. Leopold W. Bernhard preached his first sermon yesterday as pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church, at Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street. He had taken up his duties there last Monday.
Two research projects at Wagner College on Staten Island are aimed at providing a cure for the island's air pollution.
ROME, Nov. 21 -- The oldest church in Rome dedicated to the Virgin Mary and one of the oldest in Christendom was reconsecrated today after eleven centuries of neglect and virtual oblivion.

GREEN BAY, Wis., Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, two-touch-down favorites, had their hands full today before eking out a 21-17 victory over the Green Bay Packers. Bobby Layne's pair of scoring passes and his one-yard sneak through the middle enabled the defending champions to win.
LONDON, Nov. 21 -- A special meeting of the British Actors Equity Association voted today to seek to limit recruitment into the acting profession by agreement with producers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- In this city of anxieties, fears and insecurities, security checks run to artists, window washers, building cleaners and birdproofers.

TOKYO, Monday, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Two unidentified gunboats machine-gunned and sank two Japanese fishing boats today in the neighborhood of Chinese Nationalist-Communist skirmishes in the East China Sea, the Japanese Coast Guard reported.
Five new films, only two of which are Hollywood entries, are scheduled to open in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 21 -- The National Congress of American Indians re-elected as president today Joseph R. Garry, 44 years old, of Plummer, Idaho, a member of the Couer d'Alene Tribe.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 21 -- The United States and six other sponsoring nations will stand firm against the Soviet Union's renewed attempt to bring under the Security Council the Western proposal for an international agency to handle President Eisenhower's plan to use atomic power for peaceful purposes.
NEW HAVEN, Nov. 21 -- Yale University will increase undergraduate tuition by $200 a year to $1,000 and graduate school fees by an amount still to be determined.

There is nearly always an element of home music-making in the concerts of the Early Music Foundation. It was only fitting therefore, that last night's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall, which celebrated the foundation's tenth anniversary, should have that element, too.
Nathan Milstein, who made his American debut twenty-five years ago come January, gave his only New York solo violin recital of the season Saturday evening in the Hunter College auditorium.

Fire insurance rates on New York City waterfront piers will be reduced by 15 per cent effective today for an annual saving in premiums of more than $200,000. Other rate drops are expected to result from a seven-month study by the city of the port insurance situation.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Members of the Methodist Church were called upon today to fight any attempt at peacetime conscription. The appeal was in a message adopted by the Council of Bishops of the church at its semi-annual executive sessions here.
Cadets of the United States Military and Naval Academies have been forbidden to discuss in public debate the question of United States recognition of Communist China.

Two uniformed guards were robbed of $11,000 in movie theatre receipts at 12:30 o'clock this morning by three armed thugs outside the Times Square branch of the National City Bank Broadway and Forty-first Street.
PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, Chief of Staff of the South Vietnam Army, said today that he would submit his case in the quarrel with Premier Ngoc Dinh Diem to Bao Dai, the Chief of State.
Harvard and Yale men for many long years have been giving each other a physical going over on the football field such as they give no other.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Clark Griffith, owner of the Washington Senators, a chipper 85, observed his birthday anniversary today with a big party and greetings from President Eisenhower, former president Truman and his personal hero -- the Lone Ranger.

He noted that men (and women) of his generation were still using such phrases as "scarce as hens' teeth," "knee-high to a grasshopper" and "a stitch in time."
MONTREAL, Nov. 21 (Canadian Press) -- The New York Central Railroad says it is losing $126,444 annually in its Malone, N. Y. Montreal commuter service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 21 -- The visit of French Premier Pierre Mendes-France is regarded in the highest official quarters here as a success.

PARIS, Nov. 21 -- Moscow is making frantic final efforts to prevent the attachment of a rearmed Germany to the Western bloc. Alternating currents of sweet and sour wind are blowing into Europe from the Kremlin. But it is clear the Soviets recognize at last that the project is going through.

EDMONTON, Alberta, Nov. 20 -- Recent events have brought home to the citizens of Edmonton, Winnipeg and Vancouver -Western Canada's three largest cities -- that a period of great development in trans-Arctic air transport is upon them.

One of the most cherished tenets of Communist ideology is the notion that centralized economic planning is superior to what Moscow calls "capitalist anarchy," i.e., our own system of free enterprise with coordination through supply and demand interaction in the market.

LONDON, Nov. 21 -- After reaching the climax last Monday of one of the sharpest setbacks experienced in the present boom, the stock markets here have staged a noteworthy recovery in the last few days.

A committee set up by the Congress of Industrial Organizations to stamp out welfare rackets reported yesterday that union-administered funds accounted for fewer than 3 per cent of the 4,600,000 C. I. O. members covered by union-negotiated welfare programs.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,129,527,751. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Fordham University had a surplus last year of $69,357 out of an operating budget of $5,157,585, the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, its president, announced yesterday. The annual report and a financial statement for the fiscal year ended June 30 were made public before 500 faculty members at a general convocation in Keating Hall, on the Bronx campus.

YALE and Harvard met in The Game at Cambridge last Saturday and that promptly rang a bell down memory lane. It was twenty-five years ago this month that a meteorological phenomenon hit the area from Boston to New York. Antarctica moved in for a short stay. Oh, brother, was it cold!

DURANGO, Mexico, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Umberto Maglioli of Italy took the lead in the accidentriddled Pan-American road race today with a reckless ll5-milean-hour dash across Central Mexico on the third day of the contest
RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 21 -Delegates of twenty-one American republics were assembling and conferring today at near-by Petropolis in preparation for the economic conference beginning tomorrow.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 21 (AP) -- The Chicago Bears called on Zeke Bratkowski today for his first full stint as a National Football League quarterback and the former Georgia star came through by passing them to a 28-13 victory over the Baltimore Colts before 23,093 fans.
STONY BROOK, L. I., Nov. 21 -- The purchase of land for construction of a nonprofit osteopathic hospital at Farmingdale was announced here tonight by the Long Island Osteopathic Society.
MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 21 -Chaminade High defeated Stepinac High of White Plains, 19 -- 6, today in the bowl to finish second to Iona in the Catholic High School Athletic association with a 4-1 record.

There is obvious and general satisfaction in this country over the visit of French Premier Mendes-France and its immediate impact on the relationship between his country and ours. He has done a splendid service to both in restoring a better climate of understanding. We welcome the change just as we welcome the Premier during his visit to New York.

Continuation of a $258,000,000 rehabilitation of transit power plants and possible use of St. Lawrence River energy to run the subways have been recommended to the city. These proposals were made public yesterday in a report by Gordon R. Clapp, deputy City Administrator and former Chairman of the Tennessee Valley Authority.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (UP) -- Ollie Matson scored four touchdowns today, two of them on 62 and 79-yard runs from scrimmage, to pace the Chicago Cardinals to their second victory of the season, a 38-to-16 decision over the Washington Redskins before 15,619 fans.

An operating deficit of $482,963 at St. Vincent's Hospital for the first nine months of this year was announced yesterday by Sister Loretto Bernard, administrator. Cardinal Spellman presided at the annual meeting of the Roman Catholic institution's officers at the hospital, Seventh Avenue and Greenwich Street.
Ship operators and longshoremen made "some progress" yesterday toward finding a way out of their collective bargaining deadlock. Another meeting was scheduled for today.

LUXEMBOURG, Nov. 22 -- The draft text of a treaty providing for closer cooperation between Britain and the European Coal and Steel Community was approved unanimously today by the Council of Ministers representing the six-nation community.
The Metropolitan Opera and the American Guild of Musical Artists completed a new two-year contract on Nov. 6, it became known yesterday.

IT hardly seems necessary to "go where the wild goose goes" this fall, for word has come in during the past week that there have been more honkers seen between Cape Cod and Long Island than have been encountered in these sections in many years.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The United States gave qualified support today to the proposal of Pierre Mendes-France, for a Big Four conference next May.
GENEVA, Nov. 22 -- West Germany is on the verge of becoming a country of immigration instead of an important source of European settlers for underdeveloped countries overseas.

FOR the first time since they were organized in 1946 the Cleveland Browns will come to New York without having Marion Motley booming out of the fullback spot. The large Mr. Motley was the perfect foil for Otto Graham. If the enemy rushed Graham with too much eagerness, he'd call for the giant bear-trap play and send the fleet 238-pound Motley rocketing through.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower rejected today proposals that would have restricted the imports of spring-type clothespins and tung oil.

Lorus and Margery Milne, a husband and wife team of Durham, N. H., have received a Eugene F. Saxton Memorial Trust fellowship for the completion of a natural history book dealing with night creatures. The Milnes are scientists, writers, lecturers and photographers and have studied nature in many parts of North America, Mexico and Central America.

The last vestiges of last month's general truck strike in the metropolitan area were settled yesterday with an agreement covering 2,000 members of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., in Mercer, Middlesex and Monmouth Counties, N. J.

Nearly everyone who is anyone in major league baseball was in town yesterday. Not the least prominent was Hank Greenberg, industrious general manager of the Cleveland Indians. At various times Greenberg was in conference with other front-office bosses, but, apparently, most of his talking was done with Frank Lane of the Chicago White Sox and George Weiss of the Yankees.

A man of great ability, great energy and great industry died yesterday, but we do not mourn his loss. Andrei Yanuarievich Vishinsky sent too many men unjustly to death, and helped enslave too many millions, for us to regret his end, a relatively merciful and quick conclusion compared with the fate of many of his victims.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Capt. Edward V. Rickenbacker, chairman of the board of Eastern Air Lines, said today his company was willing to spend millions to develop an effective service between the Northeast and Fort Worth-Dallas, Tex.
Dr. Isador Lubin was chosen yesterday by Governor-elect Averell Harriman to be Industrial Commissioner in the new State Administration.
A "no-raiding -- general cooperation" pact was signed yesterday between two maritime affiliates of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations.
G. Keith Funston, president of the New York Stock Exchange and member of its board of governors, was one of four men elected yesterday to membership in the Presbyterian Hospital Corporation.

Deputy Attorney General Rogers, who is especially qualified to speak on the operations and problems of the federal courts, asserts that Congress has placed these institutions "on a starvation diet." Congress has given the United States courts only $27,000,000 -- one twenty-fifth of 1 per cent of all sums appropriated to run the Federal Government -- for the fiscal year of 1955.

BOSTON, Nov. 22 -- Bishop William C. Martin, president of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A., warned today that unless this country was "brought more fully under God, its own future will be in peril and the peace of the world will be jeopardized."
The Bendix Aviation Corporation authorized yesterday payment on Dec. 27 of an extra dividend of $1 a share and a quarterly dividend of 75 cents a share on the common stock.

The municipal elections being held in Spain on these three successive Sundays are not to be taken seriously as elections. They are in no sense an expression of popular sentiment or choice, any more than an election behind the Iron Curtain would be. In this respect both left and right extremes of totalitarianism are alike.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census said today that United States exports, imports and military aid shipments all declined in September.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Following is the text of a speech by Pierre Mendes-France, French Premier, to the United Nations General Assembly today:

Much of the buying power held by consumers can be converted into sales by means of advertising, Elwood Whitney, executive vice president of Foote, Cone Belding, asserted yesterday in a letter to 300 advertising and industrial leaders.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner today named Joseph Weintraub, Newark attorney, to succeed Maj. Gen. Edward C. Rose as New Jersey member of the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor. The appointment was promptly confirmed by the State Senate.
The Eisenhower Administration's support of voluntary health insurance was underscored by Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell in a talk here last night.
CARACAS, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Russia continued its domination of the world shooting competition today, setting three international records in winning two team championships and one individual title.

The Japanese freighter Meirinsan Maru was on the wrong side of the East River when she collided with the Panamanian cargo ship Lake Charles last Thursday, the pilot of the latter ship testified yesterday.
Though Joseph P. Ryan, former pier union leader, accepted money from employers, he did not thereby violate the Taft-Hartley Act; it was contended yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower has created a formal Cabinet secretariat to organize the work, keep the records and follow through on decisions.

Robert Moses, chairman of the State Power Authority, yesterday attacked as a "fantastic scheme" a proposal by Deputy City Administrator Gordon R. Clapp that St. Lawrence River power be obtained for city transit.

The Ivy group, which prides itself on having returned to "old-fashioned" football, minus the frills and fanfare of extra-big time competition, yesterday revealed its All-Star team for the 1954 season.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The stock market turned irregular today in the face of diminished buying. About the only industrial groups to go against the dull trend were engineering, electrical equipment and building materials.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- President Eisenhower signed today an Executive Order designed to provide greater job security for about 455,000 employes whose status in the Federal Government now is listed as "indefinite."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Pierre Mendes-France, who used to speak to empty galleries at the United Nations only a few years ago, drew today one of the largest and warmest crowds ever to turn up here.
If you want to talk about the duties of an Ambassador to Russia, or the work of a Secretary of Commerce, or the task of being director of the Mutual Security Agency, Averell Harriman is your man.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 22 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru sketched in rough outline today what might be called a "coexistence" plan for India and Red China. He said it was arrived at in his recent "historic" talks with Communist leaders in Peiping.

TRENTON, Nov. 22 -- The Republican-dominated State Legislature tonight adopted four bills over the veto of Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat. The Senate and Assembly each then passed two additional bills, which also bore Mr. Meyner's outright veto, making eight bills in all.
ALBANY, Calif., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Tordito won today's feature at Golden Gate Fields, but what had the fans talking was Jockey Ray York's daring rescue of Johnny Longden from a fallen horse.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Treasury reported today that its short term borrowing costs have fallen to the lowest point in more than four months.

ROME, Nov. 22 -- The United States Embassy's tough policy toward Communists began to pay off today. The results of a shop steward election in the concern of Bombrini, Parodi Delfino were announced and revealed a stinging defeat for the Communist-dominated General Italian Confederation of Labor.

More than 38,000 persons will be killed this year in motor vehicle accidents, a toll greater than that levied by polio, cancer and tuberculosis combined. Death on the highways is more preventable than death from disease, but because it has become an accepted part of this age of speed too little has been done to cut the appalling record.

The Rev. Dr. John Sutherland Bonnell, pastor of the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church, called last night for a "new Christian concept -- the apostleship of the laity." He addressed a Presbyterian men's rally held under the auspices of the Presbytery of New York at the Fifth Avenue Church, at Fifty-fifth Street.

Goodall-Sanford, Inc., will liquidate the major portion of its real estate and equipment holdings in Sanford, Me., it was made known yesterday. The company has agreed to sell to Grossman Family Trust of Quincy, Mass., the four remaining plants in Sanford and will lease back one of them to continue production of cloth for the Goodall Palm Beach Company subsidiary.
Army's staff of football coaches expects that the clash Saturday between the cadet and Navy elevens "will be the best in many years."

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation in White Plains, N. Y., have recovered $13,000 worth of bonds stolen at Southington, Conn., on Sept. 29, it was announced today. The bonds were part of the $250,000 loot taken from the home of Dr. R. E. Thalberg.

Scovill Manufacturing Company has authorized payment of a dividend of 50 cents a share on the common stock on Jan. 1. With this dividend, Scovill will have paid dividends on its common for 100 consecutive years.

Proposed changes in the traffic code to legalize overnight parking were criticized yesterday by business and civic groups in protests to Mayor Wagner. At the same time, representatives of the New York County Medical Society voiced opposition to new restrictions on parking by physicians.
A $250,000 breach of contract suit filed yesterday in Federal court here charged that radio and television broadcasts of major league baseball games were financially ruining minor league competition.
BALTIMORE, Nov. 22 (UP) -- A jet bomber dropping from the sky in "perfect silence" crashed in a suburban neighborhood today, killing its two civilian test pilots and setting fire to a nearby house.

No glowing white candle atop a fancy cake was needed on Friday to commemorate the first birthday of Family Night at the Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association, 331 East Seventieth Street. The occasion was more than satisfactorily observed with cider and doughnuts, plus a lively square-dance session and a quantity of merriment, at a pre-Thanksgiving holiday program shared by 100 parents and children.

Events tonight: Michael Tree, violinist, Carnegie Hall. 8:30 P. M.; Rossini's "Otello" in concert form, American Opera Society, Town Hall, 8:45; Classic String Quartet, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Murray Phillips, guitarist-ballad singer, New York Public Library, 174 East 110th Street, 8; Anne Frances Byrne, organist, American Academy of Arts and Letters, 632 West 156th Street, 8:30; Jan Peerce, tenor, Brooklyn Academy of Music, 8:30.
Successful growing of human lung tissue in laboratory animals was announced here yesterday.

Commodity futures drifted irregularly in light trading yesterday on the New York exchanges. Potatoes, coffee, rubber and wool were higher; sugar, hides and silk moved lower, and cocoa, cottonseed oil, burlap, lead, copper and zinc ended mixed.

Advertising clients need help from the agencies in marketing their products as much as or more than they do in composing and placing their selling messages, the annual Eastern conference of the American Association of Advertising Agencies was told yesterday at the Roosevelt Hotel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The United Nations' first tourist death at headquarters occurred today.
The General Electric Educational and Charitable Fund announced yesterday a new plan to provide more funds for American colleges and universities.

A feature of this year's Yuletide Assembly Ball to be held on Dec. 27 at the Ambassador, will be a tableau in which women prominent in society will participate. The beneficiary of the ball will be Boys Harbor, Inc.
Torn ligaments in Frank, Gifford's right knee will sideline the fleet tailback of the Giants for at least ten days, Coach Jim Lee Howell disclosed yesterday.
The General Electric Company has abandoned its practice of suggesting store prices for its major (large household) appliances, Roy W. Johnson, executive vice president, disclosed yesterday.
Cotton futures were barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Final prices were 14 points lower to 1 point higher than on last Friday.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Marian MacDowell was receiving messages today from all parts of the nation for her assistance to four decades of artistic achievement in the United States.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The National Football League today set up play-off dates for its two conferences should the divisional races end in a tie or ties.

Fordham will resume its football rivalries with Penn State and Missouri in 1955 according to the nine-game schedule announced yesterday by Jack Coffey, graduate manager of athletics. West Virginia and Rutgers will be dropped from the Rams' schedule.
A turkey dinner will be served at the annual Christmas fair, sponsored by the Women's Association of Grace Church, on Dec. 1 at the church, 802 Broadway.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Maj. Gen. James M. Gavin said today that the Army was on the verge of a "breakthrough" in developing new and more efficient nuclear battlefield weapons.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Andrei Y. Vishinsky, Moscow's chief spokesman at the United Nations, died at 9:30 this morning of a heart attack. The First Deputy Soviet Foreign Minister, one of the most colorful personalities at the world organization, would have been 71 years old on Dec. 10.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A Presidential emergency board, appointed under the Railway Labor Act, today recommended pay increases for Pullman conductors amounting to 18 cents an hour retroactive to Dec. 16, 1953.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Military Committee today put aside until next month the question of Germany's contribution to the defense of Western Europe. The committee thus made short work of its annual strategic planning review.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- The Labor party's leaders recommended tonight the disciplining of seven members of Parliament who broke the party front in last week's House of Commons debate on West German armament.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- V. K. Krishna Menon of India announced today that he would not press for a vote on his amendments to a Western resolution endorsing President Eisenhower's atoms - for - peace program and calling an international scientific conference next summer.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The number of businesses throughout the nation rose by 6,500 to a total of 4,185,300 during 1953, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The recent upward trend in the steel industry's production rate is expected to level off this week, at least temporarily.
A new collection of rare antique jewelry, plus some precious contemporary pieces, all of which were collected by Charles Walker, are on view at his Petit Musee, 16 West Fifty-eighth Street.

After nearly a half century in the freight business, Philip E. McIntyre will retire at the end of the month as general freight traffic manager of the United States Lines. He has served this company and its subsidiaries for twenty-three years.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- An official of the Foreign Operations Administration indicated today that some previously rejected bids from United States ship-owners for carrying coal to Korea might be accepted tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Supreme Court refused today to rule on an Alabama law prohibiting the marriage of Negroes and white persons.
The Waterfront Commission reported yesterday that it had unearthed a "classic kickback racket" in Port Newark.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The United States has suggested to the nations of Western Europe that they take part with the United States in a "broad development program" for the free countries of Asia.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 22 -- Pakistan announced today a plan to merge four provinces and ten princely states of West Pakistan into a single unit.

Lu Rossini, Columbia's basketball coach, has eleven players who will see considerable action this season, and if one or two of them improve enough to "cover the second big man and the second small man in Ivy League play," the Lions "will be tough to beat."
DETROIT, Nov. 28 -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of the General Motors Corporation, forecast today an increase in motor vehicle sales and employment and in general business in 1955.
LONDON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Mrs. Gillian Crowcroft reported today she was learning all about life underground from a pack of moles with radioactive bracelets on their tails.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A game bird, new to the United States, the black francolin, will soon be brought from Pakistan to the Southwest of this country.

The formulation of a guide outlining the "Responsibilities and Rights of the Teaching Profession in a Democracy" was announced yesterday at the 110th annual meeting of the New York State Teachers Association.
The blowing of automobile horns between the hours of 10 P. M. and 6 A. M. may be outlawed here.
The Board of Higher Education voted last night to seek $5,000 pay raises for the presidents of the city's four municipal colleges.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Pravda assailed Premier Mendes-France today as an enemy of European security.

Exploratory drilling indicates that a recent mineral discovery in Southwestern Labrador "may be the world's greatest single deposit of iron ore," Premier Joseph R. Smallwood of Newfoundland announced here yesterday.
" I've never had to use a hospital," a man told a United Hospital Fund volunteer. "A rare call on the doctor has kept me well. So how do your hospitals concern me?"
CINCINNATI, Nov. 22 -- Senator Burke deposited $11,020 today for a recount of all 1,102 precincts in Hamilton County. The recount will get under way next week, probably Monday, it was announced.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Cattlemen predominated in a group of sixteen men invited to a stag dinner with President Eisenhower at the White House tonight.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Power Commission today announced reopening of its investigation into the rates of Phillips Petroleum Company, Bartlesville, Okla., for natural gas sold in interstate commerce. The commission started the investigation in 1948 but dropped it three years later on the ground it did not have jurisdiction over the company.

Blood donations collected by the Red Cross on Friday totaled 687 pints. Included were 263 taken at City College, making a total of 452 for two days, and 144 donated at the Western Union Telegraph Company, 60 Hudson Street. On Saturday 151 pints were given at the Pro Patria Council, Knights of Columbus, 5400 Post Road, the Bronx.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Mister C. L., under a strong stretch ride by Norman Cox, registered his first major victory today in the $7,500 added Bowie Breeders Stakes before an opening-day crowd of 9,565.

Neither the muggy, foggy weather early in last week nor the rain at its close kept shoppers from New York City's department stores. Sales for the week ended on Saturday were 10 per cent heavier than in the like week a year ago, according to the "flash" report issued yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- United States businesses and individuals have invested $10,000,000,000 since World War II in foreign business enterprises that they control, the Department of Commerce reported today.
If parents are alert and sensitive to youngsters' reactions, they can learn a lot about their children by reading aloud to them, it was said here yesterday.
A Canadian business leader called yesterday for a liberal and realistic foreign trade policy by the United States.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria conferred with President Eisenhower today on moves the United States might make to persuade the Soviet Union to sign the Austrian state treaty.

EAST LANSING, Mich., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Allen Frame, a Kansan, let a group of Eastern favorites set the pace, then exploded with a kick in the last half mile to win the sixteenth annual N. C. A. A. cross-country run today.

The annual Christmas bazaar of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Holy Trinity will be held on Dec. 2 and 3 in St. Christopher's House at 316 East Eighty-eighth Street. Mrs. Livingston Cromwell heads the committee for the event, and Mrs. Robert N. West is treasurer.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 22 -- Leland Hayward apparently is preparing for a long stay in Hollywood. The producer announced today that he had acquired motion-picture rights to "Point of No Return," in which Henry Fonda was starred on Broadway.

OTTAWA, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The Federal Government's arbitrator in Canada's railway-union contract dispute today awarded 145,000 non-operating employes fringe benefits estimated at $7,000,000 a year. Simultaneously, he recommended a Federal subsidy for the roads.

Emphasizing the world's need for leadership, Viscount Montgomery said yesterday that promising youth should be selected at an early age for the special training that will put their abilities to full use.
R. H. Macy Co., Inc., has joined with a hundred other companies in a partnership with the United States Goverment aimed at showing the nations of the world the products of this country's economy.

In refutation of Soviet charges that the Paris agreements increase the danger of war, the Western Powers have taken two more steps which should puncture a lot of Soviet propaganda balloons. They are completing the text of a new note rejecting the "childish and unrealistic" Soviet proposal for an immediate all-European "security" conference as being merely a device to bury these agreements and to divide the West rather than to solve East-West problems.
The Los Angeles, Calif., Department of Water and Power announced yesterday that it would receive bids on Jan. 26, on an issue of $18,000,000 of electric plant revenue bonds.

Market financing by the Oklahoma Turnpike Authority will take place next month in the form of offerings of three toll revenue bond issues totaling $214,000,000, the Authority said yesterday. The offering will be made around Dec. 8, it was said. A syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation will manage the marketing.
On the third floor of the five-story mansion housing the Soviet delegation to the United Nations at 680 Park Avenue, Andrei Y. Vishinsky lay dead.

MORRISTOWN, N. J., Tuesday, Nov. 23 -- A Morris County jury of eight men and four women early this morning found Mrs. Ida Pontery guilty of manslaughter in the fatal shooting last Aug. 7 of her fourth husband, Dr. Herbert Pontery.

Boardwalk Billy Smith, 173 1/2, of Atlantic City, scored a technical knockout victory over Archie McBride, 184, Trenton, N. J., in the ninth round of the scheduled ten-round bout at the St. Nicholas arena last night.

The American Foundation for the Blind announced yesterday a search for deaf-blind children under the age of 20. The project was outlined at the Overseas Press Club, 35 East Thirty-ninth Street, by Annette B. Dinsmore, consultant to the foundation and chairman of the National Study Committee on Education of Deaf-Blind Children.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- The United Nations General Assembly adopted today a resolution confirming the new status of Greenland as a part of the Danish realm.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Indictments charging contempt of Congress were returned by a Federal grand jury today against eight witnesses who refused to answer questions of the House Un-American Activities Committee. The committee wanted to know about their alleged Communist activities and associations.

Edward R. Murrow has canceled plans to appear in a National Broadcasting Company color show because of a "contractual conflict." The commentator conducts several radio and television programs for C. B. S. and is on the board of directors of the Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc.
PARIS, Nov. 22 -- The Tunisian Government formally appealed today to terrorist bands operating in rural areas of the French protectorate to lay down their arms.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Princeton University will grant blanket increases of $1,000 next year to professors and associate professors on regular tenure, Dr. Harold W. Dodds, president of the university, announced today.
Some parent appreciate what school teacher do for their children -- and free lunches given to two delegates at the annual meeting of the New York State Teachers Association yesterday proved it.
Army and Navy, fast as whippets and more evenly matched than they have been in a long time, bring down the curtain on the college football season Saturday in one of the naturals of the year.

The 1955 Rambler line of cars was announced yesterday by American Motors Corporation. The cars will go on display here Friday in Nash and Hudson dealer showrooms. New York City delivered prices are expected to be announced at that time.
The National Broadcasting Company announced last night it had "turned down" a request by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for television time. The company declined to amplify its brief statement.

ON July 20, 1944, a bomb exploded at Hitler's headquarters near Rastenburg in East Prussia and failed to kill Hitler. The man who left it in a briefcase leaning against the leg of the map table at which Hitler stood was an officer who had been severely injured in Tunisia. His left eye was missing. There were only three fingers on his left hand.
A proposal to transfer mineral rights of the Texas Pacific Land Trust to a new company to be known as TXL Oil Corporation was approved by certificate holders of the trust here yesterday.
An unexpectedly traditional look characterizes two new collections of metal furniture introduced by Arbuck, Inc., 473 Fourth Avenue, and available there through decorators.
Delivered prices of 1955 Lincoln and Studebaker cars were announced yesterday by dealers in this city.
One of four Brooklyn adolescents accused of first-degree murder was granted a separate trial yesterday when the case was resumed in Kings County Court after a week's adjournment.

A landmark in American economic history will be passed today when the 50,000,000th car produced by the General Motors Corporation rolls off the assembly line. This is clearly an occasion for congratulations, in which we are happy to join, but it is also more than that.
CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, Nov. 22 (UP) -- Umberto Maglioli of Italy, virtually clinched the championship today as the fifth competitor was killed in the Pan-American road race.

VIENNA, Nov. 22 -- The French Premier's suggestion that the Soviet Union might consider signing an Austrian treaty provided two years were allowed for the evacuation of occupation troops came as a surprise to the Aus trian Government, according to its officials here.

Seventy years ago this month patents were issued for the first fountain pen, thereby enabling young scholars to lose pens as well as pencils in the long walk between school and home.
