Pens have improved greatly since L. E. Waterman perfected one with an ink-feeding device, but no manufacturer has solved the problem of how to keep children from losing them.

LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Jacob Malik, Soviet Ambassador, called on Britain today to wipe out trade restrictions and develop instead her commerce with the Soviet Union. The two countries have never been competitors in trade, he said.
AIKEN, S. C., Nov. 22 -- Two top defense officials today got approval for "the objectives" of President Eisenhower's new military manpower plan from Senator-elect J. Strom Thurmond.
Two minor accidents in the tunnel leading to Grand Central Terminal delayed 30,000 to 40,000 railroad passengers from three minutes to two hours and ten minutes yesterday morning.

CHICAGO, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Most butcher hogs sold off 25 cents today although a few sales on weights under 200 pounds were steady. Sows were steady in a fairly active trade. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 22 (AP) -- The University of Southern California was chosen today to represent the Pacific Coast Conference in the 1955 Rose Bowl game at near-by Pasadena next New Year's Day.

TOKYO, Nov. 22 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida asked his trusted political aides today whether he should drop the reins of government after more than six years or wage an all-out battle against his political foes.

Robert Casadesus scored both as a composer and pianist at last night's concert of the Little Orchestra Society in Town Hall. His new capriccio for piano and string orchestra proved a delightful work and his playing in his own piece and in Mozart's A major Concerto had the softness, the sheen and the airiness of gossamer.

I appreciate sincerely the space and attention given in the Nov. 16 issue to the presentation of the 1850-75 type of school by the pupils of the New Lincoln School. But I regret the term "ultra-progressive" used to describe school.

" Day of Triumph," the recently completed feature film based on incidents in the life of Christ and produced by the Rev. James K. Friedrich-Century Films, will be released by George J. Schaefer in key cities during the Christmas holidays, the distributor announced yesterday.
A strong drive to eliminate the payment of commissions on billions of dollars of insurance written for labor management welfare funds developed yesterday at a union hearing on welfare rackets.

Billy McNeece of Islip, L. I., won a majority decision victory over Ted Olla, Milwaukee, in the feature bout of ten rounds at Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night. McNeece weighed 165 1/2 pounds and Olla 164.

In The Times editorial of Nov. 13 it was pointed out that no existing agency, whether American or international, seems to be doing all that can be done to produce the flow of capital investment and the necessary trained personnel into countries where these are needed.
In one of the first annual reports covering 1954 operations by a major company, the Bank of the Manhattan Company yesterday announced record postwar net operating earnings.

The suspension of a hero fire captain for seeking a $50 Christmas gratuity was made known yesterday two days after he had rescued a child from its burning bed. The announcement followed by only a day Mayor Wagner's warning over television that he would root out graft wherever it exists.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- The Supreme Court Unanimously ruled today that Federal and State Legislatures had broad powers to authorize redevelopment of slum areas.

The "Night of Stars," an annual extravaganza arranged for the last twenty-one years by the United Jewish Appeal, netted $102,000 at Madison Square Garden last night. The proceeds from the benefit will be used for the organization's rehabilitation program in Europe, Israel and the United States.

EN ROUTE TO TEXAS, Nov. 22 -- This leisurely search into the reasons why Americans do the things they do, including electing chosen candidates for public office, has now extended along the midland trail of their pioneer and subsequent ancestors from the Tidewater to the high bluff that rises from the Mississippi at Memphis, Tenn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Pierre Mendes-France suggested today that a Big Four conference be held in May, after the ratification of the London and Paris agreements on West German armament and sovereignty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- A two-thirds cut in unemployment tax payments to the Federal Government by the states and a resulting sharp reduction in Federal control over state jobless compensation systems have been recommended by a task force of the Commission on Intergovernmental Relations.

Turkey is priced so reasonably this year that for the first time the City Department of Markets featured the bird not only on its high-cost Thanksgiving dinner menu but also on the medium and low-cost meals.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- The Roman Catholic Bishops of the United States called on all Catholics today to comply faithfully with their pledge to shun motion pictures found objectionable by the Legion of Decency.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 22 -- The Anglican Bishop of Johannesburg, the Right Rev. Ambrose Reeves, has ordered the closing of all the denomination's mission schools for Negroes in the Southern Transvaal to avoid relegating the pupils to a place of permanent inferiority under the new Negro education law.
Intensifying its safety drive, the city made plans yesterday for a thorough recheck of tenement buildings inspected previously this year.
Andrei Yanuarievich Vishinsky was the Soviet Union's most skillful and vitriolic exponent of Communist doctrine at the international table.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 22 -- Scenes and conversations illustrating the marital and emotional difficulties of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard were described today by three witnesses at the osteopathic surgeon's trial for the murder of his wife, Marilyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 22 -- Arkady A. Sobolev, who was the ranking Soviet member of the Secretariat during early years of the United Nations, became acting head of the Soviet delegation to the General Assembly on the death of Andrei Y. Vishinsky.

MADRID, Nov. 22 -- The final results of the municipal elections in Madrid, published today, gave candidates of the Falangist (Government) party 77.8 per cent of the votes cast. The controlled press called this an "overwhelming victory" for the regime of Generalissimo Francisco Franco.

LAWTON, Okla., Nov. 22 (AP) -- Fist fights broke out here today among 400 old-age pensioners and relief clients over distribution of drought emergency food rations. City and county officers struggled for almost forty minutes before quelling the disturbance.

UPPER MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 22 -- Mrs. W. Rhys Jones, chairman for the Christmas Ball, has announced that the annual event will take place at the Woman's Club of Upper Montclair on Dec. 28. Nineteen young women will be introduced to society at the dance, which will be preceded by a dinner party at the Montclair Golf Club.

" Sandhog," described as "a ballad in three acts," by Earl Robinson and Waldo Salt, will open at the Phoenix Theatre, 189 Second Avenue, tonight at 8 o'clock. It is based on Theodore Dreiser's short story, "St. Columba and the River."

Edward T. Dougherty, president of the Standardbred Owners Association, and eight harness racing drivers withdrew in Supreme Court yesterday their petition to have George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing commissioner, lift his suspension of the nine men.
Workmen yesterday began dismantling the giant illuminated waterfall sign atop the Bond Clothes building on Broadway between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.

Cuba's economic stability is being threatened by an effort on the part of American beet and cane sugar growers to enlarge their mainland sales quota, Laurence A. Crosby, chairman of the United States Cuban Sugar Council, said yesterday at a conference at the Harvard Club.
MOSCOW, Nov. 22 (Reuters) -- The body of Mr. Vishinsky will be brought here from New York for a state funeral, the Soviet Government said tonight.

" Sandhog," described as "a ballad in three acts," by Earl Robinson and Waldo Salt, will open at the Phoenix Theatre, 189 Second Avenue, tonight at 8 o'clock. It is based on Theodore Dreiser's short story, "St. Columba and the River."

Edward T. Dougherty, president of the Standardbred Owners Association, and eight harness racing drivers withdrew in Supreme Court yesterday their petition to have George P. Monaghan, State Harness Racing commissioner, lift his suspension of the nine men.
Workmen yesterday began dismantling the giant illuminated waterfall sign atop the Bond Clothes building on Broadway between Forty-fourth and Forty-fifth Streets.

A five-year loan of $200,000,000 has been granted to Brazil by a syndicate of nineteen American banks, a Brazilian delegation announced here yesterday. The rate of interest will be 2 3/4 per cent a year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Because of Senatorial delay in confirming Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York to be an associate justice, the Supreme Court postponed indefinitely today arguments on ending segregation in the public schools.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 22 -- President Joao Cafe Filho of Brazil urged delegates of the twenty-one American nations today to see to it that posterity did not judge their efforts at economic cooperation as "too little and too late."

The difficult program that the pianist Grete Sultan played at Carnegie Recital Hall last evening consisted of Debussy's "Pour le piano," Schoenberg's "Five Piano Pieces," Op. 23, and the Beethoven "Diabelli" Variations.

I would like to be able to support the milk-drinking program of Premier Mendes-France when I am in his country -- not at the expense of wine, but to counteract the disastrous effects which that beautiful, not to be resisted liquid has upon me.
Two points of some importance have been overlooked in comments on the dismissal of John Paton Davies Jr. from the State Department.

CHICAGO, Nov. 21 -- Grain trends were pretty well mixed in todays' operations, with wheat and oats weak and corn strong. Rye showed strength early, and soybeans also moved up in the late trade, closing higher.

Stock prices yesterday continued the uptrend that developed last Friday following Thursday's sharp reaction. But while the list reached new bull-market highs, as measured by the averages, there was considerable selectivity.
An employment agency lost its license yesterday after clients had complained of being directed to nonexistent firms or nonexistent addresses to fill nonexistent job vacancies.

Baseball's annual basement bargain scramble, known as the major league draft, took place in the Biltmore Hotel yesterday and, as was generally expected, produced no results likely to cause any upsets in the 1955 pennant races.

Under the auspices of the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization, a new operation has been started in Thailand. Representatives from twelve Asian countries, sixty in number, have opened a "center" in Bangkok to discuss land problems in Asia.
SEOUL, Tuesday, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The United Nations Command warned South Korea yesterday it would protect Communist Czechoslovak and Polish, members of the Neutral Nations Supervisory Commission.

PARIS, Nov. 22 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France's speech to the United Nations General Assembly today was considered here to fill in somewhat the emptiness of the Washington communique of Saturday. It also was viewed as giving the communique a positive instead of a negative twist by fixing a date for possible talks with Moscow.

Operations of the National Container Corporation and subsidiaries for the nine months ended on Sept. 30 resulted in a net profit of $2,403,094. This was equal to 67 cents a share on 2,909,033 common shares. The profit this year was 16.4 per cent below the $2,873,248, or 86 cents each on 2,808,862 shares cleared in the corresponding period of 1953, the report issued yesterday showed.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 -- Senator Thomas A. Burke, Democrat of Ohio, and his supporters filed today for a recount of the Nov. 2 balloting in twenty-three Ohio counties on charges of irregularities and errors.

Clarence Senior, chief of the migration division of the Puerto Rican Department of Labor, said yesterday that the estimate of more than a million Puerto Rican residents here by 1970, made on Sunday by the City Planning Department, was valid only if high employment levels continued.
Austrian and United States parents have a problem in common -- comic books. Six months ago the slow stream of these "literary" imports from West Germany increased to a flood.

TURIN, Italy, Nov. 22 (AP) -- Attorneys for two former American service men today launched appeals against their conviction, in absentia, for the wartime behind-the-lines slaying of Maj. William Holohan of New York City.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 22 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower will inaugurate a new Presidential plane, the Columbine III, when they fly to Augusta Wednesday afternoon for their Thanksgiving week-end.

TORONTO, Nov. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Bank of Commerce had net profit in the year ended Oct. 31 of $6,404,350, compared with $5,789,242 in the preceding year. This was after provision of $6,807,000 for Federal taxes, compared with $5,558,000, and after provision of depreciation on bank premises of $1,685,029, compared with $1,166,968.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Dillon, Read Co., Inc., is offering today a new issue of 39,200 shares of $25 par value 4.56 per cent cumulative dividend convertible preferred stock of Black Hills Power and Light Company, which serves western South Dakota and eastern Wyoming.

Jimmy Slade, who was badly beaten last Friday night by Floyd Patterson in a televised fight at Madison Square Garden, won a unanimous decision yesterday at an inquiry into his performance by the New York State Athletic Commission.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 22 -- Sir Hamilton A. R. Gibb, authority on the Middle East, will join the faculty of Harvard University July 1, 1955. He will be University Professor and James Richard Jewett Professor of Arabic.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Nov. 22 (UP) -- Joseph S. Petersen Jr., Government code clerk accused of unauthorized use of secret information, asked the Federal District Court here today to dismiss two of three counts of the indictment against him.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- West German armament must be well under way before the Western powers can confer successfully with the Soviet Union, according to British diplomatic sources.

Thousands of New Yorkers will halt their holiday diversions tomorrow morning to offer prayers of thanksgiving in church and synagogue. In many instances, they will bear gifts of material goods for the less fortunate here and overseas.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A Senate Judiciary Committee inquiry into charges of prejudice filed by Leo A. Rover, United States Attorney, against Federal Judge Luther W. Youngdahl in the Owen Lattimore case was postponed today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Exceptional gains in several key industries helped the general economy last month, the Department of Commerce reported today.
The city moved yesterday to qualify for a potential $8,000,000 in state aid for mental health as the City Council passed a proposed local law establishing a nine-member Community Mental Health Board.
The New York Rangers team yesterday acquired Bill Gadsby, a defenseman, and Charles (Pete) Conacher Jr., a forward, in a major National Hockey League trade with the Chicago Black Hawks.

A fresh start has been made in trying to reach agreement on the troublesome subject of Japanese reparations to the Philippines. The former tentative agreement, which the Philippine legislators refused to ratify, has now been scrapped and a new negotiator has been appointed in Manila with the rank of Ambassador to begin further talks.
The Kings County District Attorney's office announced yesterday that it was conducting an inquiry into alleged gangster influence on prize fighting in Brooklyn.
The Child Study Association of America, which usually sells its publications directly from its headquarters or through other parent education groups will be represented on newsstands starting today.
WOODFORD, England, Nov. 23 -- Sir Winston Churchill revealed tonight that, even before the end of World War II, he had considered rearming the beaten Germans to help stem the Russian tide in Europe.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower made these main points at his news conference today:

Corliss Lamont, lecturer and philosopher, contended in a motion in Federal Court yesterday that the Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations headed by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had "no apparent legal existence'' when it questioned him.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- M. Mendes-France returns to Paris after a phenomenal success in the United States. Yet one can almost hear the politicians' grindstones sharpening knives with which to cut his throat. The most acrobatic Premier in French history will have to be agile to avoid disaster.

EVEN a dog's life in television, it seems, is not easy. Two of Hollywood's more notable canine names, Lassie and Rin Tin Tin, are represented this season on the video medium. They may be excused if they're already barking to themselves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -Joseph M. Dodge, Budget Director for the first seventeen months of the Eisenhower Administration, has been recalled by the President to review the Government's foreign economic policy.

The supper that follows tomorrow's Thanksgiving dinner probably will be light. The family will not have much appetite and the home cook will be too tired to prepare anything elaborate. An excellent solution is a soup that may be devised from a combination of two canned varieties with, perhaps, additional seasoning to add piquancy.

Directors Of the New York Central Railroad Company cleared the track yesterday for a possible merger with one of the system's most individualistic leased-line companies, the Boston and Albany Railroad.
The American Friends of Spain Foundation has arranged a benefit dinner dance, to be called A Spanish Evening, on Dec. 17 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Ohio State University, ruler of the Big Ten, headed The Associated Press weekly football poll yesterday for the second straight week. If the Buckeyes can remain No. 1 in the final poll next week, they'll become the mythical national champions for the second time since the AP rankings were inaugurated in 1936.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A former Chief of Staff of the United Nations command in Korea declared today that the Communists were beaten there in 1950 but that victory was snatched from the anti-Communist forces, apparently with the American State Department calling the signals.
In your edition of Nov. 16 you published a letter from Pearl S. Buck depicting the plight of immigrants resulting from the closing of the Ellis Island detention station.
Thank you for publishing Arthur Davis' letter in the Nov. 16 New York Times, for it gives me an opportunity to try to explain what he and thousands of other library friends must have questioned.

Looking at the matter quickly, one might not see anything very wrong or right in carrying unenforced or unenforceable laws on the books. The average citizen, one might argue, soon learns by trial and error or hearsay what he can get by with and acts accordingly.

Pink and white chrysanthemums, ferns and the flags of various countries formed a colorful decor for the first International Debutante Ball held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Underwritten by Parfums Evyan, the fete was a benefit for the Wooden Church Crusade, a nonsectarian movement to combat communism through the construction of a chain of simple wooden churches in West Germany.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 23 -- The history and growth of General Motors and its contribution to the nation in peace and war is the story of American industry at its best, Admiral Ben F. Moreell, chairman of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, asserted today.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- There will be no more blocking and tackling for Army's football players until they come to grips with their Navy counterparts before 101,000 spectators at Municipal Stadium in Philadelphia on Saturday in the most eagerly awaited gridiron contest in years.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 23, (UP) -- The Chicago Black Hawks rallied with a three-goal third period tonight to gain a 4 -- 4 tie with the National Hockey League-leading Montreal Canadiens.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh, Chief of Staff of the South Vietnam Army, indicated here today that he would propose the removal of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem when he consults with Chief of State Bao Dai. Premier Ngoc Dinh Diem has been backed by the United States Ambassador, Gen. J. Lawton Collins.

Four world record performances in track and field by United States athletes will be submitted for approval to the sixty-seventh annual convention of the Amateur Athletic Union at Miami Beach, Fla., that starts tomorrow. If approved by the A. A. U., the marks will be forwarded to the International Amateur Athletic Federation for world-record listing.
MOSCOW, Nov. 23 -- The French Premier's proposal for a four-Power meeting in May met with no sympathy in Soviet circles today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Debate opened today in the General Assembly's Political Committee on the status of West New Guinea, called West Irian by the Indonesians.
PATERSON, N. J., Nov. 23 (AP) -- A boxer dog here has been willed $1,000 but he may not live to enjoy its benefits.

SHEBOYGAN, Wis., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Circuit Judge F. H. Schlichting said today he had sold his interest in a food store chain because a union ban against two local stores was causing his associates "a substantial loss."
FLINT, Mich., Nov. 23 -- The General Motors Corporation produced its fifty millionth motor vehicle here today.
The city established its first tow-away zones yesterday to keep traffic moving on all lanes of major crosstown streets during the evening rush period.

Wool prices soared yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange in the sharpest rise in several years. Trading was influenced by strength at the Australian auctions. Tops closed here 4.2 to 7.1 cents a pound higher and grease wool was up 4.3 to 5.7 cents.
TRENTON, Nov. 23 -- The Democratic National Committee, in a surprise move, has withdrawn its offer to help defray the cost of a recount in the New Jersey Senatorial election.

I read your editorial on the Grand Central Concourse and found it so pertinent that I write to commend your thoughts and urge that a real crusade be started to insure the perpetuation of this landmark.
Troubles multiplied yesterday for Aristotle Socrates Onassis and his far-flung "empire" of shipping.

" EVERY generation needs its popular history written in a way it can understand," says Sir Arthur Bryant in his introduction to "The Story of England: Makers of the Realm."* After paying tribute to the great works of J. R. Green and G. M. Trevelyan, Sir Arthur explains how his approach differs from theirs.

FIRE ISLAND, L. I., Nov. 23 -- The bluebirds that have not moved to a warmer climate circled our blind on the east end of this almost deserted finger of sand, holly and beach grass, but throughout most of the day the ducks rested quietly on the placid bosom of Great South Bay.
LONDON, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -- A campaign began today to leave the British Treasury without a farthing.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Foreign Operations Administration accepted four bids today from United States shipowners for carrying coal to Korea at rates that were rejected last week as "unreasonable."
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 23 (AP) -- T. Frank White's Miss Weesie, a candidate for the Barbara Frietchie Handicap here Saturday, won the Tred Avon Purse, today's feature.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -President Eisenhower said today he was making a broad restudy of the security risk program with the objective of eliminating any indicated faults in its impact on individuals.

The International Nickel Company of Canada will increase the price of the refined metal by 4 1/2 cents a pound today to 64 1/2 cents -- the highest commercial price since before the turn of the century.
CAIRO, Nov. 23 -- The prow of Pharaoh Cheops' solar ship emerged today from the darkness of its 4,700-year-old subterranean hiding place into the flickering brilliance of photographers' flashbulbs.
A preliminary code of ethical practices, designed to end labor-management welfare rackets, emerged yesterday from two days of public hearings sponsored by the Congress of Industrial Organizations.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The "strongest possible protest" was sent to the Chinese Communists by the United States State Department tonight against the sentencing of thirteen Americans to prison terms was on "trumped up" charges of espionage.

The Ted Forbes family camped out on the long trip from Davis, Calif., to New York City. They plan to "camp out," so to speak, on their year-long stay here, while Mr. Forbes, head football coach of the University of California at Davis, studies for a doctorate in physical education at Columbia University.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman hinted yesterday that a place in the new State Administration would be offered to Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.

Admiral Jerauld Wright, Supreme Allied Commander of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's Atlantic forces, declared last night that the destruction of NATO was the Soviet Union's primary objective.
TOKYO, Nov. 23 -- The Peiping radio announced today that a military tribunal had sentenced thirteen Americans accused of espionage inside Red China to imprisonment ranging from four years to life.
Four members of Congress from this area cruised the Arthur Kill yesterday to see why a six-mile stretch, which carries one-quarter of the harbor's entire cargo, needs funds for improvement.
PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 23 -- Chile proposed at the inter-American economic conference today the creation of a Latin-American stabilzation bank to help solve the area's critical problems.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Commander in Chief said today that West Point and Annapolis debaters should be allowed to argue any question that troubled the world, including United States recognition of Communist China.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 23 -- The United States pledged today increased financial support to Latin-American economies in the form of accelerated loans. The pledge was made with the understanding that this was to be an encouragement to free enterprise rather than a displacement of it.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Securities and Exchange Commission, today authorized the Mississippi Power and Light Company to sell 44,476 shares of $100 preferred stock. The issue will be sold to retire a corresponding number of outstanding preferred shares of $6 par value.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Britain suggested today the renewal of efforts to adjust the Israeli-Jordanian armistice demarcation line where it now separates settlements of Arab refugees from their old farmlands on the Israeli side.

Twenty-two leading educators from seventeen countries who had studied at Teachers College, Columbia University were recipients yesterday of a medal recently established by the college for distinguished service to education.

Howard G. Cann, New York University's affable skipper, lost four outstanding basketball players through graduation last June, but he is not permitting that fact to worry him as he prepares his current squad for the 1954-55 campaign.
The body of Andrei Y. Vishinsky left here by plane for Moscow at 7:09 last night.

Stiff penalties were imposed by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday on two of the key figures in its investigation of television fight "donations" and blacklisting charges involving officials of the New York Boxing Managers Guild and the London Sporting Club, which operates the St. Nicholas Arena.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 23 (AP) -- Narragansett Park today received permission to extend its fall horse racing season to Dec. 4, three days beyond the originally licensed closing date.

Two developments during the last few days have an important bearing on the mounting problem of financing education. Last week the Federal Tax Court decided that grants from philanthropic agencies to individuals for research and study are exempt from the payment of income tax by the recipient; and, on Monday, the General Electric Fund announced it would match, up to $1,000 each, contributions by employes to colleges from which they graduated.
Lovers of Italian opera are indebted to the American Opera Society, which last evening presented Rossini's "Otello" in Town Hall under the direction of Allen U. Gamson.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- It is the intention of President Eisenhower to confine to foreign and high military policy all close bipartisan liaison with the Democratic majority in the new Congress.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The Government tonight easily repulsed a Labor attack against the commercial television industry, which is being set up in skeleton form to broadcast next autumn. The vote was 300 to 268 against a censure motion in the House of Commons.

One of the most successful visits any foreign statesman has made in recent years came to an end last night when Premier Mendes-France left for Paris. This success is not to be measured by the formal agreements reached in official conferences in Washington, important as these are.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Bethesda Naval Medical Center disclosed today that "a small amount of fluid" had been withdrawn by hypodermic needle from Senator McCarthy's injured elbow. The hospital said the procedure "is not considered technically to be an operation."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The President's remarks are in indirect discourse as required by conference rules:

The Muscular Dystrophy Associations of America, 39 Broadway, defended yesterday its policies for allocation of funds collected by public fund drive. Sunday, the Chemung County Medical Association announced in Elmira that it would not support the national fund-raising drive of the association.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Public sentiment is steadily rising in Britain for a bold national road-building program to speed the increasing industrial output from the nation's factories to the ports.

PALMER, Mass., Nov. 23 -- A local housewife, who thought "some man ought to start something" about uncovering sentiment in favor of censuring Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, decided today that she was not doing too badly on her own.

The Encore Concert presented last night at Carnegie Recital Hall was distinguished for two reasons. It introduced an excellent new ensemble in the Classic String Quartet and the all-British program the foursome played contained some lovely music.

PARIS, Nov. 23 -- Tunisian and French representatives resumed their negotiations today on internal autonomy for the North African protectorate but the problem of the fellagha terrorist bands was still a distracting influence.
The superintendent of a Brooklyn demolition company was arraigned yesterday in the Brooklyn investigation of gratuities allegedly paid by the concern to city workers.
Longshoremen seeking a new contract in the Port of New York drew closer to agreement with the New York Shipping Association last night, according to Federal Mediator John Andrew Burke.
The menace of the "I. B. M." made President Eisenhower's visit last Saturday to the White House bomb shelter symbolic of the shape of things to come.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration said today it would begin paying early next year regular dividends totaling $226,000,000 to about 5,380,000 veterans holding Government insurance policies stemming from World Wars I and II.

Despite a record enrollment of Southern Negro students in interracial colleges, a survey has shown that less than 3 per cent of the graduates of segregated high schools for Negroes would be likely candidates for non-segregated colleges.

This is a good time to begin working up an appetite for that dinner. To be sure, the turkey itself is some hours away, but that should not prevent the working up of appetite. In fact, it is hard to think about the turkey at all without working up an appetite.

" The Street" buzzed yesterday as the Dow-Jones industrial average finally went above the 1929 record high of 381.17, hitting 382.74 at the close. Standard Poor's index went over the top last spring but the New York Times combined average is still 61.46 points below it.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Santiago Luis Cardinal Copello, Roman Catholic Archbishop of Buenos Aires, made public today a pastoral letter exhorting Catholics to "comply with your civic duties always, without detriment to religious principles."

Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery received yesterday an honorary degree from Columbia University. The citation hailed his valor, his brilliance at war and his role as "builder and protector" of peace.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 23 (UP) -- A Federal judge today dismissed a $200,000 damage suit filed by a former heavyweight boxer, Al Ettore, over the television showing of his bout with Joe Louis eighteen years ago.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- Following is the text of the resolution on peaceful uses of atomic energy, as approved today by the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee:
MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Willie Pastrano, an 18-year-old New Orleans middleweight, punched out a unanimous ten-round decision over Bobby Dykes of Miami tonight.
The Welfare and Health Council was called on yesterday to assume leadership in the development of a master plan for community health and welfare.

The president of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Society and a high city official agreed yesterday that New York should have a music festival comparable with those of Edinburgh and Salzburg. But each thought the other should take the initiative in getting the project under way.

Two Yonkers policemen resigned yesterday after reconsidering a costly legal fight against dismissal for refusing to waive immunity before the Kings County rackets grand jury. They still face possible recall before the jurors.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower said today he understood the Supreme Court did not intend to be arbitrary in establishing procedures to end segregation in the public schools.

NEW HAVEN, Nov. 23 -- The Howland Prize of Yale University will be presented to Ralph Vaughan Williams, British composer, Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, President of the university announced today. The award will be made Dec. 1 when Mr. Vaughan Williams will lecture at the School of Music.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Jacob A. Malik, the Ambassador of the Soviet Union in London, left London Airport tonight for New York, where he will temporarily lead the Soviet delegation to the United Nations.
Department store sales in the Second Federal Reserve District dropped 5 per cent in October from the 1953 level, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.
Family reunions planned for tomorrow around a festive board will set off heavy holiday travel today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower established an emergency board today to inquire into a dispute between the Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen, independent, and most of the country's railroads. The dispute has been in negotiation for two years or more.

The responsibility for last Thursday's East River ship collision was again placed on the Japanese freighter Meirinsan Maru yesterday, this time by the master of the Panamanian-flag cargo ship Lake Charles, who testified that his vessel had the right of way.

LINDEN, N. J., Nov. 23 -- Plans for construction in the Esso Research Center here of a radiation laboratory in which to conduct atomic energy experiments were announced today by Eger V. Murphree, president of the Standard Oil Development Company.

At the end of a three-day trial without jury, Federal Judge Edmund L. Palmieri reserved decision yesterday on a charge that Joseph P. Ryan, former president of the International Longshoremen's Association, had violated the Taft-Hartley Act by accepting $2,500 from employers of I. L. A. labor.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was active yesterday with the volume estimated at more than 350,000 bales. Closing prices were 3 to 15 points higher than on Monday.
Continuing unemployment was blamed yesterday by Welfare Commissioner Henry L. McCarthy for an increase in city public assistance rolls for the eleventh consecutive month.
A professor of law has been elected as a Tammany leader.

The third volume of "The Secret Diary of Harold L. Ickes" with the subtitle "The Lowering Clouds" will be issued Dec. 3 by Simon Schuster. It begins with an entry by the late Secretary of the Interior on Sept. 16, 1939, immediately, after the outbreak of war in Europe, and ends with his account of the Cabinet meeting the night after Pearl Harbor.
The Liberal party decided last night at a meeting of its state policy committee to embark on a recruiting drive to strengthen its balance-of-power role in New York politics.

TRUJILLO, Dominican Republic, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Milwaukee Braves were named today to help start competition in the new $3,500,000 Trujillo Stadium with a series of four big league exhibition games in 1956.

The consumer -- the man or woman with cash or credit, busy buying -- is too often overlooked as the most powerful factor of all in business, the Sales Executive Club was told yesterday by Donald M. Hobart, vice president and director of research of the Curtis Publishing Company.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 23 (Reuters) -- The touring English cricket team drew its four-day match with Queensland today when the visitors' 288 second innings left the home team only thirty minutes for its second knock.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 23 -- Repeal of the Taft-Hartley Act was opposed by an overwhelming vote of the Commonwealth Club of California today after a year's study by its industrial relations section.
TOKYO, Nov. 23 -- Officials of Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Liberal party urgently sought a formula today that would permit them to retain political power in Japan even if their leader resigned.

" Realistic" salaries for teachers, with a minimum ranging from $4,000 a year for beginners to $9,000 for those with more than ten years of experience, were urged yesterday by the house of delegates of the New York State Teachers Association.

U. C. L. A.'s undefeated and untied Bruins are a good bet to win the national college football championship. The Pacific Coast Conference champions were voted the nation's No. 1 team yesterday by The United Press board of coaches for the fifth week in a row.
This is in reply to your editorial "Grand Central," published Nov. 18.
Judging by Bergdorf Goodman's Christmas Bazaar, which opened yesterday on the store's fourth floor, Santa Claus is going , to have connoisseur's taste and lucky the recipient whose home he visits.

" One Eye Closed" opens at 8 o'clock tonight at the Bijou. Nursed by Haila Stoddard over the rustic circuit under the title of "Reunion '54," the Justin Sturm farce, previously described as a comedy, is Miss Stoddard's first solo attempt in New York.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Training young Indian women as sanitarians and nurses' aides was described yesterday as an important part of the Public Health Service plan to cut down high Indian infant mortality rates. A sanitarian's services are directed to improving home cleanliness, particularly in the preparation of children's food.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 23 -- Illinois Governor William G. Stratton announced today that revenue bonds for $390,000,000 would be sold about the first of the year to finance the construction of 191 miles of toll roads in the Chicago and northern Illinois area.
TRENTON, Nov. 23 -- Frank Thompson Jr. has been stripped of his powers and functions as Democratic minority leader of the State Assembly.

A FULL year's preparation goes into the Macy Thanksgiving Day parade that will cover two miles tomorrow and last only one hour and two minutes. Plans for the next one start the following day -- the talking stage, that is.
It has been no accident that the growth of the voluntary hospital system, both in quan tity and in quality, has coincided with the phenomenal medical progress of the last 75 years.

THERE wasn't even one slightly raised eyebrow yesterday when Walter O'Malley, the president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, announced that Walter Alston would return as manager of the Brooks for another season. That's just the way it figured to be from the start and only one thing could have prevented this move.
THANKS to the Phoenix Theatre, another original musical has come to Second Avenue. It is "Sandhog," which opened there last evening.
Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, called upon the chemical industry here yesterday to help conserve natural resources by developing new products and processes.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company's operating revenues fell to $70,795,438 last month, off $18,607,655 from the October, 1953, level. The company managed, however, to carry $2,716,897 down to net income, comparer with $2,851,648.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Following are the texts of statements issued today by the State and Defense Departments on the sentencing of thirteen America in Communist China:

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov, 23 -The tournament director, Howard Myers Jr., today made the draw for the fourth annual Hofstra College Christmas invitation basketball tournament scheduled for Calkins gymnasium Dec. 27-30.

ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Truckers are not using the State Thruway "to any appreciable extent," it was reported today, but a Thruway Authority spokesman said commercial travel was in line with the authority's rough estimates.

Former students and graduates gathered yesterday between 5 and 7 P. M. in the ballroom of the Theatre Guild Building, 23 West Fifty-third Street, to honor their alma mater, the American Academy of Dramatic Arts.
This may come as good news to some adults, bad news to some children and a surprise to many, but corporal punishment is still permitted in some schools in this state.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Methodist Church plans for a radio and television ministry were discussed at a luncheon of the national meeting of district superintendents here today. Nearly 600 superintendents are in attendance.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 23 -- The West German Communist party injected a sensation today into the opening of the case brought against it by the Government. The Federal Republic has applied in the Supreme Constitutional Court to have the party banned as unconstitutional.
The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday plans for borrowing $42,195,000 on short-term loan notes for the financing of four low-rent projects.

The beat-beat-beat of drums and the howl of a timberwolf shattered the otherwise sober atmosphere of the Supreme Court yesterday as a blind man offered a musical backdrop to his $100,000 damage suit charging misuse of his art.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 23 -- Dr. John Peterson Elder, Associate Professor of Greek and Latin, will become Dean of the Harvard University Graduate School of Arts and Sciences, July 1, 1955. He will succeed Dr. Francis M. Rogers, who is resigning to devote full time to research and teaching as Professor of Romance Languages and Literatures.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Corporations in the United States raised $7,000,000,000 through sales of stocks, bonds and notes during the first nine months of this year, compared with $6,400,000,000 in the same months of 1953, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

Max Boydston, who has been playing a terrific game at end for Oklahoma all season, turned in a peak performance last Saturday against Nebraska and earned the designation yesterday as The Associated Press lineman of the week.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- President Eisenhower's foreign trade program won valued support today from an influential organization of business and educational leaders. Even bolder steps toward easing trade barriers were advocated by the group.
The forty-fifth annual Blue Ridge Ball for the benefit of the Blue Ridge School, Bristol, Va., will be held Jan. 28 in the main ballroom of the Pierre.

CHICAGO, Nov. 23 -- Wheat prices had better support for a time today and there was a rally of 1 cent or more from early lows. But the upturns were hard to hold as buyers showed little inclination to follow them.
MONTREAL, Nov. 23 -- Charles Trenet, French singer, is spending the night in a jail here after last-minute attempts to have him released on bail of $25,000 failed.

GENEVA, Nov. 23 -- The United States delegation to the Geneva trade conference is opposing, for the present at least, the inclusion of an anti-cartel rule in the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- A Congressional committee charged today that nearly $3,000,000 in Government-backed funds was poured into a nonproductive Alaskan tin mine because of "gross inefficiency" and "influence."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- The Department of Justice announced today that eighty-nine persons had been indicted during September and October in connection with reputed irregularities in the Federal housing program.
CLEVELAND, Nov. 23 -- The mark of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard's left thumb was found on the headboard of the bed on which the osteopath's wife, Marilyn, was slain, a Cleveland detective testified today.

It is indeed frightening to survey the current situation wherein the leaders of two atomic colossi wrangle about "coexistence" and a "modus vivendi" while the rest of the world trembles at the possibility of atomic bomb destruction. Are there no means by which human reason can resolve the terrifying situation?
Directors of Niles-Bement-Pond Company voted a year-end extra dividend of $1 a share yesterday and increased the quarterly rate to 50 cents. Previously, 35 cents was paid quarterly.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -President Eisenhower stood firm today on a foreign policy seeking coexistence with the Soviet Union without forgetting for a moment the Communist aim of eventual world revolution and domination.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Legislature's two top Republicans declared today that Averell Harriman was "trying to kid the people" in proposing more Federal aid to the states.
Stocks, enjoying their broadest market on record, rolled ahead yesterday to their best level since 1929. Two hundred issues made new 1954 highs and only five made new lows.
Pierre Mendes-France underscored present moves for a bipartisan foreign policy in the next Congress when he spent one hour yesterday discussing France's role in world affairs with Adlai E. Stevenson.
The world champion New York Giants will play twenty night games at the Polo Grounds next year, one more than in 1954, with the majority of the floodlight affairs scheduled in July and August.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 23 -- The records of the engineering firm of Mayor Harry J. Thourot of Union City should be made available in a Superior Court investigation into Jersey City's financial transactions, it was decided today by Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Julius Raab, Chancellor of Austria, urged the Western powers today to put "the Austrian question" at the top of their list of quesions to be handled.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 23 -- William W. Remington, former Federal aide, was in serious condition tonight from head injuries received when he was attacked in the Federal Penitentiary here. He is serving a three-year term for perjury.
The world champion New York Giants will play twenty night games at the Polo Grounds next year, one more than in 1954, with the majority of the floodlight affairs scheduled in July and August.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 23 -- The records of the engineering firm of Mayor Harry J. Thourot of Union City should be made available in a Superior Court investigation into Jersey City's financial transactions, it was decided today by Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Julius Raab, Chancellor of Austria, urged the Western powers today to put "the Austrian question" at the top of their list of quesions to be handled.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 23 -- William W. Remington, former Federal aide, was in serious condition tonight from head injuries received when he was attacked in the Federal Penitentiary here. He is serving a three-year term for perjury.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 23 -- "Radical change" in the marketing of motion pictures, affecting distribution, publicity and advertising methods, was forecast tonight by Steve Broidy, president of Allied Artists Pictures Corp.

For more than 300 years in this country cranberries have been symbolic of harvest plenty and today they are as traditional as roast turkey for the Thanksgiving feast. At the peak of supply now and at reasonable cost (25 cents a pound in chain stores), the colorful autumn berries are available for the usual Thanksgiving sauce or jelly and also for desserts and relishes to use during the coming winter months.

Hiram Walker-Gooderham Worts, Ltd., achieved the second highest sales in its history during the fiscal year ended on Aug. 31, according to the annual report of Howard R. Walton, president, issued yesterday.

AT irregular intervals for the rest of this week a play compiled from Menander, "The Girl From Samos," will be acted at Labor Templem, 242 East Fourteenth Street. Despite a rude performance under inadequate direction, it is an interesting event for people curious about Greek civilization and drama.
MONTREAL, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The top places in the National Hockey League scoring race were held by four Montreal Canadiens today.

Michael Tree, a young violinist of uncommon talent and sensitivity, made his debut, giving on that occasion his first public recital last night in Carnegie Hall. He is a product of the Curtis Institute of Music and a pupil of Efrem Zimbalist whose influence is clear in his disciple's style.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 23 -President Chiang Kai-shek said today the Chinese Communists would not try to invade the Nationalist-held islands off the Southeast China coast if the United States announced its participation in the joint defense of these islands.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 (UP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration today published winter safety rules for 50,000 owners of small aircraft, with a special warning that they beware of carbon monoxide.

Holders of about 80 per cent of the outstanding preferred and common stock of Griscom-Russell Company of Massillon, Ohio, have tentatively accepted a stock exchange offer of General Precision Equipment Corporation. If the offer is accepted, control of Griscom-Russell will be acquired by General Precision.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Gen. Alfred M. Gruenther, Supreme Allied Commander in Europe, said today there were already seven East German divisions in the Soviet-controlled armed forces.

LONDON, Nov. 23 -- The stock markets here made a mixed showing today, with many of the leading industrial equities improving after an uncertain start, while small irregular changes characterized the rest of the list.

Andy Romeo, Fordham University left halfback, was confined to the college infirmary with a virus infection yesterday and may miss the Fordham-Villanova clash in the Polo Grounds on Saturday. Romeo also suffered a back injury in last week's game against Syracuse.

While Stalin lived, all victories and accomplishments of the Soviet state had to be attributed solely to his genius, foresight and perspicacity. Now that he is dead the new rulers who previously moved in the shadows are making clear how much they disliked their former obscurity by rewriting the record of history so as to enhance their own glory and stature.
LONDON, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The Peiping radio announced today the sentencing of the following Americans:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 23 -- A resolution endorsing President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace program was approved unanimously today by the Political and Security Committee of the United Nations General Assembly. Unanimous adoption by the Assembly is expected within a few days.
JUAREZ, Mexico, Nov. 23 (AP) -- Three Pan-American Road Race records were smashed today as the world's longest test of car stamina and driving skill ended.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 23 (UP) -- Torsten Ullman of Sweden was declared the winner of the world championship in the center-fire pistol or revolver event at the thirty-sixth world shooting championships today when tournament officials reversed last night's ruling that gave Hulet Benner of the United States a tie.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 23 -- Tecumseh in fresh war paint and midshipmen singing and cheering in ranks were portents at the Naval Academy today of the imminence of the showdown with Army.

" Walter Alston will be our manager in 1955," Walter O'Malley, president of the Brooklyn Dodgers, said yesterday, "and on terms that I'm sure are satisfactory to Alston. They're satisfactory to us. The contract is for one year."
College basketball games played by members of the Western Conference -- known as the Big Ten -- will be televised by the C. B. S. network, beginning Dec. 11.
CHICAGO, Nov. 23 (AP) -- The report of the Department of Agriculture on today's livestock markets here follow:
A major controversy over the future of the Manhattan Bridge has developed between the Transit Authority and the Department of Public Works.
ALBANY, Nov. 23 -- Mrs. Averell Harriman today proved herself as much of a diplomat as her husband.

Designs depicting the natural textures of stone, tree bark and brick appear in an interesting new collection of wallpapers available through decorators at the Timbertone Decorative Company, 50 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- Members of the Securities and Exchange Commission and their staff today were giving close study to the formal notice by which the Ontario Securities Commission has abrogated its agreement of cooperation with the United States agency.
The United Press yesterday announced its 1954 All-America football team, chosen by the ballots of 308 sports writers and broadcasters in all sections of the country.
LONDON, Nov. 23 -- Seven Labor party members were cast into political limbo by their colleagues in Parliament tonight after a sharp debate that further revealed the deep differences in the party.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 23 -- A total of 32,692 tons of copper was made available to industry to relieve the shortage resulting from the recent strike, the Office of Defense Mobilization announced today. The figure represents 16,358 tons from inventory accumulated for Government use and 16,334 tons that were diverted from delivery to the Government.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Australia said today she viewed with "utmost gravity" the possibility of United Nations endorsement of any change in sovereignty over West New Guinea.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The Government and the sugar beet industry formally agreed today upon a tentative 1955 sugar beet marketing limitation equal to 75 per cent of the 1954 quota.

White blossoms, white balloons, smilax and boxwood provided the traditional green and white decor for the annual Debutante Ball of the New York Junior League held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The fete served as a benefit for the League's Welfare Trust Fund.

Thomas Louis Hardin, blind street musician who calls himself "Moondog," is entitled to an injunction to restrain Allan Freed, disk jockey, from using his "Moondog Symphony" if he "thinks it worth his while to insist," Supreme Court Justice Carroll G. Walter ruled yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Britain announced today the licensing of imports of United States tinplate to supply increasing demands which cannot be met out of domestic production.

The nation's gasoline stocks declined by 672,000 barrels last week, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Stocks were reported at 147,224,000 barrels at the week-end, compared with 147,896,000 a week earlier and 143,054,000 a year earlier.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Joey Maxim, his right eye closed by a left hook in the first round, staved off his rival until his vision cleared and then punched out a narrow ten-round decision over Paul Andrews of Buffalo tonight before 2,827 fans at the Chicago Stadium.
The great debate about United States security policies, which has waxed and waned in Washington ever since World War II, is opening a new chapter.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Harold E. Talbott, Secretary of the Air Force, warned today that guided missiles and interceptor planes could not be relied on to guard the United States against attack from the air.

Richard A. Strickland, co-chairman of the Washington Square Neighbors, an association of residents of the area, said yesterday that the controversy over the Washington Square Southeast slum clearance project was not over.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The largest field in the history of tomorrow's $7,500 Thanksgiving Day Handicap forced Fair Grounds officials to split the race into two divisions today.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 24 -- The agreements and conflicts between the United States and Latin-American countries on financial and economic policies were clearer as the Inter-American Economic Conference ended its plenary sessions today and began committee work.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria suggested tonight that the West push ahead with ratification of the Paris agreements granting sovereignty to West Germany, then urge the Russians to come to terms on Austrian independence.

PARIS, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A police disciplinary committee recommended today that Inspector Jean Dides be suspended from duty for six months as punishment for alleged misconduct in connection with the case of French defense leaks.

NEEDLES, Calif., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Seven cars of the eastbound Santa Fe Chief en route from Los Angeles to Chicago were derailed tonight, sixty-two miles west of Needles. First reports indicated no one was killed.

A fund of $25,000 to $50,000 is being raised by underworld elements bent on ousting the leaders of the "cleanest" union of truck drivers in the metropolitan area, the New York City Anti-Crime Committee asserted yesterday.

The Symphony of the Air, formerly the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, held a supper and label-writing party last night in the Carnegie Hall lounge to fill back orders for its first LP recording, a copy of which is given to each contributor of $10 or more to the orchestra's treasury.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Jacob A. Malik arrived today from London to take over as chairman of the Soviet delegation to the General Assembly. Mr. Malik, who is Soviet Ambassador to London, succeeds Andrei Y. Vishinsky, who died Monday.

The belief that Brazil may change its exchange rate, the improvement in the New York dock situation and the lack of interest by roasters in green beans tumbled coffee prices the 2-cents-a-pound daily limit in all months except the spot position yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. December was off 170 points (hundredths of a cent a pound). Volume was 88,250 bags.
It is to be hoped that the staff of the United States Department of Agriculture sits down today to tables groaning with all the good things that their efforts over the years have made even better.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 -- Penn and Cornell will play their sixty-first annual football game tomorrow on Franklin Field.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The executive committee of the British Labor party reproved three members of Aneurin Bevan's rebellious left wing faction today.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 23 -- The Government does not contemplate any further nationalization, according to President Victor Paz Estenssoro.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 24 -- Friends' School, a private co-educational school with high school departments, will admit Negroes, starting next September with the nursery school and kindergarten, Dr. G. Canby Robinson, chairman of the education committee, announced today.

The small cause of all those big noises in spring -- the peeper -- was presented yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History, along with a fat and civilized woodchuck, a sedentary flying squirrel and other wildlife.
Selection of a blue-ribbon jury to try three adolescents for first-degree murder was completed yesterday on the fourth day of the trial in Kings County Court before Judge Hyman Barshay.
Representative Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr. declined yesterday a bid from Governor-elect Averell Harriman to join the Harriman Administration.
VANCOUVER, B. C., Nov. 20 -- Canada's highest dam, a 325-foot structure in the Capilano River less than half an hour's drive from the center of Vancouver, was officially opened today.
On the highest turnover since Dec. 18, 1950, stocks crashed through to new highs yesterday, backed away from them and closed with modest gains.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower today smashed a bottle of water from a Colorado trout stream on the nose of the President's new airplane, christening it the Columbine III. The President, Mrs. Eisenhower and Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery then took off for a Thanksgiving week-end in Augusta, Ga.
Directors of M. Lowenstein Sons, Inc., a large textile concern, voted yesterday to split the common stock on a two-for-one basis and distribute one new share for each share held.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Eisenhower gave assurance today that the Government was doing everything "humanly possible with peaceful means" to liberate thirteen Americans sent to prison by the Chinese Communists as "spies."
One thousand and sixty-eight vessels totaling 8,488,000 net tons passed through the Suez Canal in September, an increase of 860,000 tons over the corresponding 1953 figure.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The new multi-million-dollar automatic switching center here for transcontinental telephone calls, largest installation of its kind in the world, was unveiled today by the American Telephone Telegraph Company.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 24 -- Counsel defending Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard against the charge that he murdered his wife, Marilyn, on July 4 today set about minimizing the significance of a thumb print left by the 31-year-old osteopath.

The nation awaited expectantly last night the festivities of Thanksgiving Day, as Americans here and abroad prepared to say thanks today for the things they have. They will pray also for continued peace, while maintaining their vigilance.
Cotton futures rose 7 to 23 points (35 cents to $1.15 a bale) yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- West Germany became today the forty-seventh government to ratify or accede to the United Nations' genocide convention. The six-year-old pact would outlaw the kind of mass destruction of religious, racial or national groups that was practiced under Hitler against European Jews and other minorities.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- Queen Mother Elizabeth came home today and Londoners turned out to welcome her with joy and pride over the success of her visit to the United States and Canada.
Events tonight: "The Barber of Seville," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15 o'clock; Philharmonic-Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

A section of the National Collegiate Athletic Association resolution putting City College's basketball team on probation for one year will be reviewed by the N. C. A. A. committee on infractions, Nat Holman, C. C. N. Y. basketball coach revealed yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- New records for crude steel production were reached in Western Europe during the third quarter of 1954, the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe reported here today. Exceptions were France, Belgium and Luxembourg, but even in those countries the output approximated the record annual levels attained in the corresponding three months of 1952.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Treasury Department acted today to block the Soviet section of Germany from dumping potash here at prices calculated to disrupt the American market.
The Lockheed Aircraft Corporation is about to offer the commercial airlines a turbo-prop Super Constellation it hopes will be the first jet plane in trans-Atlantic service.

There is more than merely a fascinating historical footnote in Sir Winston Churchill's latest public supplement to his published memoirs. In the late stages of the war in Europe, before the Western and Soviet armies had made contact, Sir Winston feared that the Soviet forces might not stop when they met the Western Allies.
LEVITTOWN, L. I., Nov. 24 -- The fatal beating of Remington "is not a tragedy of mine alone but a tragedy for the entire country," his wife, Mrs. Jane Remington, said today.
ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Major Democratic organizations spent more than $1,000,000 to elect Averell Harriman Governor.

The $36,000 armed robbery of the Clinton Trust Company last April and a West Side tavern slaying in 1953 were reported solved yesterday with the round-up of four men. All four have prison records and two were already in prison when the new charges were brought against them.

Former union officials, described as one-time Communist party members, "split up" a local's funds in 1948 to keep Michael Quill from getting control of the money, a witness testified here yesterday in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A drop in average consumer prices throughout the country for the third straight month was reported today by the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics. Food continued to pull the averages down, and this means Thanksgiving dinner is costing less this year than last.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The world's tallest mechanical messengers, a dumbwaiter and a chain conveyor belt, work here. They move thousands of pounds of documents and mail daily up and down the 483 feet separating the Secretariat building's top floor, the thirty-eighth, and its third basement.
New York is finally to have a skyscraper designed by one of the great leaders of modern architecture, Mies van der Rohe.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 24 (AP) -- M. Sgt. Huelet Benner, a pistol instructor at the United States Military Academy, today won the world free pistol title.
With the over-all height of his squad better than that of the 1953-54 outfit, Coach Ken Norton believes Manhattan College's basketball squad "potentially will be a stronger scoring team."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 24 -- "The Rainmaker," which joined the Broadway hit parade four weeks ago, has been purchased for filming by Hal Wallis, independent producer associated with Paramount.

Stocks today are "catching up with the past rather than discounting prospective developments." Such is the burden of a market letter put out yesterday by A. J. Cortese of A. M. Kidder Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange. Stock prices, Mr. Cortese says, have not yet fully taken into account the huge increase in the money supply during the war years.
Two Transit Authority employes were dismissed and another was suspended yesterday as the agency acted to remove security risks.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France returned today from the United States amid a final barrage of superlatives from some who had witnessed his unexpected success in Washington.

Governmental agencies instinctively reach out for power and stubbornly resist any effort to curtail it. The courts, too, have at times fallen victim to this tendency. Perhaps in no area of human endeavor is the need for tempered self-discipline required more than in the judicial process.
HONG KONG, Nov. 24 -- Communist China said today 106 "special agents" of those allegedly sent into China since 1951 had been killed and the others, 124, had been captured.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 24 (UP) -- Two 1954 track performances, one excelling world and American records and the other equaling those standards, were approved today as National Collegiate marks by the track and field rules committee of the N. C. A. A.

Sales of Grayson-Robinson Stores, Inc., for the quarter ended Oct. 31 improved to $21,262,755 from the $21,043,240 volume in the similar months last year, Hyman P. Kuchai, president of a chain of seventy-two specialty stores, reported to stockholders at the annual meeting here yesterday.

RENO, Nev., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Rita Hayworth and Aly Khan won today legal approval of a divorce settlement that sets up an elaborate guarantee for the return of their 5-year-old daughter. Yasmin, when she visits the Moslem prince.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- A pick-up in factory jobs is going on now and is expected to continue in the immediate future, the Labor Department reported today.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- A fresh breath of spring blew into clammy, fog-bound London last week with the previews of Horrockses' 1955 warm-weather fashion collections.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 24 -- The police announced tonight that the Rev. Rodolfo Carboni had been sentenced to thirty days in jail in connection with a sermon critical of the regime of President Juan D. Peron.
LONDON, Nov. 24 -- The stock market was rather subdued again today and the main domestic issues finished with small, irregular changes.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Ezra Taft Benson, Secretary of Agriculture, today reprimanded department employes who participate in the policies, membership drives and other activities of farm organizations.

BACK in 1943, when manpower shortages hit professional football a crushing blow, Coach Steve Owen of the Giants received a phone call during pre-season training. It came from Bert Bell, now the commissioner but then the coach of one of those wartime hybrids, a combined Philadelphia-Pittsburgh team.

Two members of the crew of the Panamanian-flag freighter Lake Charles yesterday presented opposite versions in describing last Thursday's East River Collision with a Japanese cargo ship, the Meirinsan Maru.
MUNICH, Germany, Nov. 24 (UP) -- An American who unwittingly boarded the special plane bearing Pierre Mendes-France back to France said today, "it was a wonderful mistake."

The first indictment under the new Federal bail-jumping statute was returned yesterday by a Federal grand jury against an alleged narcotics seller whose $20,000 bail was forfeited after he failed to appear for trial. At the same time, a co-defendant pleaded guilty to possession of narcotics.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Charles E. Bohlen, United States Ambassador to the Soviet Union, began his consultations on current Soviet policy today in the back seat of a State Department limousine.

The Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday that it had signed a twenty-year contract with Ed Sullivan. In doing so, it matched a similar offer made a few days ago by the National Broadcasting Company.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Arthur S. Flemming, head of the Office of Defense Mobilization, today revised the policy he laid down last August for maintaining the "mobilization base."

President Eisenhower staged a historic event yesterday when he entertained three Premiers at luncheon in the White House -- Hans Hedtoft of Denmark, Oscar Torp of Norway and Tage Erlander of Sweden. It was a symbolic event as well.
In the fight over new recreation centers for the city, Park Commissioner Robert Moses, who wants them, appeared yesterday to have lost several battles but to have won the war.
May an old sailor be pardoned for drawing some salty conclusions in a moral way from the voyage of the Seven Little Sisters?
Directors of the International Paper Company have elected J. E. McCaffrey as a Vice president, Richard C. Doane, president, announced yesterday.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -- Theodor Blank, Defense Commissioner, was attacked and beaten tonight at an election campaign meeting in Augsburg, Bavaria, by youths opposed to service in the new German armed forces.
DUBLIN, Ireland, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Two winners of England's Grand National steeplechase, rated the world's most difficult jumping race, were sold today by Joe Griffin for a total of $17,346.
A 73-year-old Bronx doctor and a 62-year-old Manhattan East Side cobbler were severely beaten last night in two separate assaults by unidentified persons.

William Walter Remington, former top Government economist who held a succession of security-sensitive posts, turned secret Government information over to the courier of a Soviet spy ring during wartime.

At the President's press conference on Tuesday the correspondent of The Christian Century took the floor to read a statement several hundred words in length. It dealt with a set of resolutions adopted recently by the World Council of Churches at Evanston.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 -- Much of the trade in grains and soybeans today was for evening of holdings, with nervous swings in narrow limits the rule in all pits.

At the meeting of the U. N. General Assembly on Nov. 22 Premier Mendes-France made it plain and unequivocal that the West would not consider any meeting with Russia before the Paris agreements on Western Germany's rearmament had been ratified.

The Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, announced yesterday that it had set Dec. 12 as the deadline for a new contract with the publishers of eight daily newspapers in the metropolitan area.

Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey said here yesterday that his state's court calendars were up-to-date, whereas it requires thirty-one to forty-nine months for litigants to receive a trial in New York and Connecticut.
PONTYPRIDD, Wales, Nov. 24 -- The coal field of South Wales, which has been mined since the thirteenth century, is undergoing a remarkable transformation.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 24 -- The Government of Nepal will establish an army brigade headquarters in the Dang district in the western part of the Himalayan Kingdom to cope with continued lawlessness there, a report from Katmandu said today.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- President Eisenhower and a Republican Congressional wing led by Senator William F. Knowland of California are moving toward a struggle over foreign policy in the "cold war."
With financial and automotive advertising as leaders, newspapers are looking hopefully ahead to an increase in linage this year over 1953 by the time the year is done.

Three films will provide new holiday fare at first-run theatres today. "An Inspector Calls," a British-made drama with Alastair Sim in the title role, is at the Plaza. A. D. Peters produced and Guy Hamilton directed the Watergate Production.

Jerome Weidman, author of the best-seller "I Can Get It For You Wholesale" and a sheaf of other volumes, has signed contracts to write a play for Richard Charlton's producing company, American Productions.
Nine charitable institutions eventually will inherit more than $1,000,000 left by the late Jacob E. Schorsch, retired paper manufacturer.
FAYETTEVILLE, Ark., Nov. 24 (AP) -- The University of Arkansas today raised the salary of the coach of its Cotton Bowl-bound Razorback football team.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Nov. 24 -- It is better to give than to receive a dozen Nassau County policemen will assure anyone today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today appointed four members, including two from Puerto Rico and one from the Virgin Islands, to posts in the United States section of the Caribbean Commission.

Increasing competition from foreign shipbuilders, dependence on foreign raw materials and the desire to land new shipbuilding contracts to maintain this vital industry have induced Japan to resort to straight barter and hidden government subsidy practices.

The Transcontinental Gas Pipe Line Corporation, which extends some 1,800 miles from the lower Rio Grande border of Texas to New York, intends to raise $85,000,000 of new capital during 1955. Tom P. Walker, president of the natural gas line, made this statement yesterday in a talk before the New York Society of Security Analysts here.

In your columns of Nov. 2 you reported that the Agent General of the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency had presented a report to the General Assembly of the United Nations on the efforts of that agency to restore the war-battered economy of my country.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- Army will go into its final game against Navy at Philadelphia on Saturday in better shape than it has been at any other time this season.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 24 -- William W. Remington, former Government economist imprisoned for having perjured himself concerning Communist associations, died in the Federal penitentiary here today of injuries received in a beating on Monday.

GENEVA, Switzerland, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Franklin C. Gowen, United States consul general here, said today he expected a reply within "two or three days" from his Chinese opposite, Weng Peng-chiu, on his demand for a meeting on the thirteen American airmen sentenced as spies.
AS the producer of "One Eye Closed," which opened at the Bijou last evening, Haila Stoddard has one occupational asset. She is an actress and can replace the ladies in her Cast.
PETROPOLIS, Nov. 24 -- There are increasing indications that a solution of the problem of multiple taxation of foreign investments, will be at least initially achieved here.

"INCIDENTS OF TRAVEL AND ADVENTURE IN THE FAR WEST,"* by Solomon Nunes Carvalho, has almost completed its first century as a Classic of American exploration and discovery in the Rocky Mountain country. It was a happy idea of the Jewish Publication Society of America to bring it out in a new edition for the Jacob H. Schiff Library series, on the occasion of the tercentenary of Jewish settlement in North America.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The United States made a strong plea today to the Arab states to absorb several hundred thousand Palestinian Arab refugees as permanent citizens.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- A newly formed "citizens committee" said today it was asking all members of the Senate to answer fifty-seven questions about their finances "before a vote is taken on the McCarthy censure resolution."

Scholastic football will put on its final big show of the campaign today as more than a dozen traditional rivalries are renewed, including a pair that originated prior to 1900. Several games postponed from earlier in the season have swelled the schedule in the metropolitan area to forty.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Lou Boudreau, newly named manager of the Kansas City Athletics, met Bobby Shantz today and said he was satisfied with the improvement in the southpaw pitcher's ailing arm.

The General Assembly of the United Nations, acting as a committee, has adopted without a dissenting vote a resolution endorsing President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace plan and urging all nations to cooperate in making it a reality. This resolution does not deal with atomic weapons, which remain the West's most potent defense against Communist aggression.

The Macy parade on Thanksgiving Day started back in the era of President Coolidge, and has now become such an institution -- rain or shine -- that it is an essential appetizer before turkey dinner. In its advertisement yesterday, welcoming one and all to the line of march, father's importance in the event is recognized.

A number of Far West turf figures will be among those attending the annual meeting of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations at the Hotel Plaza next Wednesday and Thursday, Spencer J. Drayton, the executive secretary, said yesterday.
