QUEBEC, Nov. 24 -- The value of mineral production in the Province of Quebec will approximate $300,000,000. This year, W. M. Cottingham, Provincial Minister of Mines, said here today. Fifty years ago the figure as $2,500,000.

BOSTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Boston's one-two scoring punch of Bob Cousy and Easy Ed Macauley led the Celtics to a 108-103 triumph over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game tonight at Boston Garden.

ALBANY, Nov. 24 -- Elementary schools must serve as "extensions of the home" to provide one of the school-child's principal needs -- "a warm friendly atmosphere for growing." The importance of a close relationship between home and school is thus officially recognized in a new publication of the New York State Education Department, now being distributed.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The forthcoming convention of the National Association of Attorneys General has been switched from Phoenix, Ariz., to White Sulphur Springs, W. Va., to avoid any "restrictions," it was announced today.

TRENTON, N. J., Nov. 24 -- State Democratic leaders appeared more hopeful today than at any time since the recent election that Representative Charles R. Howell would ultimately emerge victorious in the New Jersey Senate race.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The General Federation of Women's Clubs today urged its 15,304 member clubs to continue efforts to abolish crime comic books even though the industry had made self-regulation moves.

HOUSTON, Tex., Nov. 24 -- A most unlikely thought to enter the mind of a traveler approaching this astonishing urban product of the free enterprise system is a thought of ancient Troy. But as the mass of Houston arose from the surrounding plain, and the celebrated skyline of the oil-gas-glass-and-chemicals metropolis dominated the scene, the writer of these lines found himself wondering whether the spectacle did not complete a rare analogy.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 24 -- The Minister of Negro Affairs, Dr. Hendrik F. Verwoerd today accused leaders of English churches in South Africa and abroad of unchristian attacks on the Malan Government's Negro education policy.

The United States Plywood Company soon will own its warehouse outlets in full for the first time and thus will add some $15,000,000 a year to its sales volume, S. W. Antoville, president, said yesterday. The company is the largest distributor of plywood in the country, with sales of $124,000,000 in the fiscal year ended April 30.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The application of Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation for authority to carry out the first of a series of railroad mergers ran into a snag today.

Gross revenues of the Hilton Hotels Corporation increased to $78,203,014 for the first nine months of this year from $68,753,520 for the corresponding period of 1953, Conrad N. Hilton, president, reported yesterday.

ATLANTA, Nov. 24 (UP) -- Gov. Herman Talmadge of Georgia tonight called the Justice Department's proposal to enforce integration of schools on a lower court level a sign that the Administration was taking "local folks" into consideration.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 24 -- The opening of discussions on West New Guinea in the United Nations brought new tension here today in relations between Indonesia and the Netherlands.
Noel Coward, actor and playwright, scoffed yesterday at reports that he had been offered $35,000 a week to appear in Las Vegas, Nev.

A rally in Madison Square Garden Monday night and simultaneous meetings in Chicago and Los Angeles will be the climax of the pro-McCarthy petition campaign of "Ten Million Americans Mobilizing for Justice."
MEXICO CITY., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Umberto Maglioli, who won the Pan-American road race by driving 1,908 miles at 109 miles an hour without a scratch, mashed a hand in a taxi door today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 24 -- The Carnegie Endowment for International Peace paid tribute to its founder today on the occasion of the 119th anniversary of Andrew Carnegie's birth.
TOKYO, Nov. 24 -- Japanese conservatives opposed to Premier Shigeru Yoshida formally launched a new political party here today.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 24 -- Navy's high-spirited football squad, with the connivance of the equally high-spirited brigade of midshipmen, gave Coach Eddie Erdelatz and his staff a surprise, in - advance - of-schedule ducking tonight as the apprentice admirals began to whoop it up in earnest in preparation for Saturday's big game with Army.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Three Scandinavian Premiers told President Eisenhower today they thought it was impractical to try to prevent Moscow from buying certain types of ships in the West.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Carl M. Graham's Country Bumkin, the 11-5 favorite, broke the mile-and-a-sixteenth track record today in the Call Over Purse. He won by four and a half lengths from Galdar before 8,034 fans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Nov. 17, the Federal Reserve Board reported today:

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Nov. 24 -- Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming opened his appeal today from a court - martial conviction on charges he had collaborated with North Korean Communists while a prisoner of war in Korea.

A Thanksgiving Day which this nation hoped to enjoy for the first time in two decades in a world at least formally at peace has been darkened by shock and anger at the news that thirteen Americans have been imprisoned in Communist China for terms ranging from four years to life.

DETROIT, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Bobby Layne, quarterback of the Detroit Lions, could join Sammy Baugh land Sid Luckman in pro football's exclusive "century club" tomorrow when the Lions meet the Green Bay Packers in Briggs Stadium.

The State of Maryland yesterday borrowed $16,025,000 in the public market on two issues of bonds to finance general construction projects. The obligations were sold at public sealed bidding to a syndicate headed by Harris Trust and Savings Bank.
PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 24 (AP) -- A Colgate team aiming for the Red Raiders' best football record since 1934 invades the Brown University Stadium tomorrow to meet the favored Bruins.

The Great Northern Railway Company's gross operating revenues slipped to $210,048,245 in the first ten months of 1954 from $226,206,555 in the like period of 1953. Net income was $20,441,669, or $3.38 a share, compared with $23,925,188, or $3.93 a share, last year.
The danger of a week-end pier strike in the Port of New York virtually evaporated last night.

CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A classified advertisement in a Chicago newspaper headed "A Grateful American," was Alex Washchenko's way of expressing thanksgiving for the blessings he has found in the United States.
Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams praised the Police Department yesterday at promotion exercises in which twelve men were elevated in rank.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- The Eisenhower Administration told the Supreme Court today that it should give states and local communities a reasonable time to end racial segregation in the public schools.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The president of the Hudson and Manhattan Railroad Company today assured officials of New York, Jersey City and Newark that no increase in fares or curtailment in service would result from its bankruptcy proceedings.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

A collection of the philosophical writings of scholars of all major nations has been assembled by Dagobert D. Runes under the title "Treasury of Philosophy." The selections span the period from the sixth century B. C. to the present.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 -- Jefferson Caffery, United States Ambassador to Egypt, has requested retirement after forty-three years in the diplomatic service.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 24 (AP) -- Maryland's football team which has inched slowly back into the top ten of the country, despite two losses and a tie, gets a chance to present its qualifications here against Missouri tomorrow before a nation-wide television audience.

Eddie (Whitey) Ford, the 26-year-old southpaw who is expected to join the newcomers, Bob Turley and Don Larsen, and Bob Grim to give the Yankees a Big Four mound corps comparable with their best in recent years, let the Bombers know yesterday he was ready to cooperate 100 per cent in their efforts to regain the American League pennant.

A throwback to the days of rugged hockey was unfolded last night at Madison Square Garden where the New York Rangers defeated the Boston Bruins, 3 to 1. A crowd of 10,355 thrilled to the contest in which the teams went at one another with a bitterness that, among other things, touched off two fist fights and provoked two misconduct penalties.
The current issue of a new British publication Nuclear Science publicly exposes a piece of atomic information that is still regarded as "secret" by most atomic authorities in the United States.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 24 -- The Columbine III landed here, the President's private golfing retreat after a flight of 2 hours and 5 minutes from Washington. The plane touched down at 5:04 P. M. During the flight it had encountered 50-mile-an-hour headwinds and mild turbulence and had dodged electrical storms.

"Archy and Mehitabel," a new opera by George Kleinsinger, with libretto by Joe Darion, will have its first performance by Thomas Scherman and the Little Orchestra Society at the fourth concert of their Town Hall series on Monday evening, Dec. 6.

The McGraw-Hill Publishing Company has elected Paul Montgomery as executive vice president, effective April 1, and a member of the finance committee, Donald C. McGraw, president, announced after the board meeting yesterday.

THE late reports indicate that the Catskill deer hunting has improved since last week-end, and as this area provides farm-fringe sport the chances are that the improvement is the result of heavier hunting that keeps the deer on the move.

LONDON, NOV. 24 -- The Soviet and United States Embassies here were mentioned in court today when John Clarence, a 27-year-old British clerk, was committed for trial on charges of obtaining and recording information about British anti-aircraft defenses "calculated to be useful to an enemy."

Thanksgiving Day is one of the happy occasions of our calendar. Only an unconverted Scrooge would be solemn or churlish about it. It is a day for laughter, for not taking one's self too seriously, for renewing old friendships, for cultivating a fresh appreciation of all the old familiar things.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- A delegation of New Jersey poultry farmers said after a conference with Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today that they expected Federal aid in expanding exports of eggs to strengthen poultry markets.

Capt. Norman Kaye Roberts, U. S. N., retired, former legal officer of the Third Naval District, was killed at 10:55 A. M. yesterday when he fell in front of a southbound IND subway train at the Seventh Avenue and Fifty-third Street station. He was 52 years old.

The Eastern Conference title in the National Football League may be decided when the Cleveland Browns, now in first place by half a game, tangle with the second-place Giants at the Polo rounds Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Senator Herbert H. Lehman, Democrat of New York, asked the Army today to justify its "unexplained and sudden" decision to close the New York regional office of the Signal Corps Supply Agency and transfer its functions to the agency's Philadelphia headquarters.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Nov. 24 (UP) -- Attorney General Latham Castle ruled today that a bingo-type game played on television was an illegal lottery under Illinois law.

Switzerland's watchmakers, still hopping mad over the United States decision to increase the duty on Swiss watches by 50 per cent, inadvertently got some small revenge recently. For a Geneva gremlin must have made his way into President Eisenhower's alarm wrist watch, causing it to go off in the middle of a sober sentence at a White House press conference.

MOSCOW, Nov. 24 -- The volume of electric power construction in the Soviet Union has so increased, according to an official announcement today, that a special Government Ministry has been created to handle it.

The American-Marietta Company, manufacturer of paints, building materials and resins, announced yesterday that it had acquired control of the Standard Lime and Stone Company of Baltimore in a cash transaction of more than $10,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, made a new bid today to increase Government shipping to the Orient through Puget Sound.

MONTREAL, Nov. 24 -- The Quebec Labor Relations Board upheld yesterday the right of a newspaper reporter to refuse to divulge the source of his information. The ruling is in direct contrast with a recent decision by the Supreme Court of Canada.

A policeman was shot and wounded last night while pursuing three men on foot near a busy shopping district on Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn. All three fugitives escaped, and an ensuing search with hand floodlights and sub-machine guns was witnessed by a large crowd of pre-Thanksgiving shoppers.
CHICAGO, Nov. 24 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
Christmas, the great feast of The Child, means toy time in most households. Toys this year, as in the past, reflect in miniature the world in which a child lives.

DIGNE, France, Nov. 24 -- More than 200 French and foreign journalists, press photographers and radio men have crowded into this little Alpine tourist town this week. They are attending the trial of Gaston Dominici, 77-year-old farmer accused of the slaying of Sir Jack Drummond, Lady Ann Drummond and their young daughter, Elizabeth, on Aug. 4, 1952.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 24 -- A resolution calling for maximum support of the technical assistance activities of the United Nations was unanimously adopted today by the General Assembly's Economic and Financial Committee.

JERSEY CITY, Nov. 24 -- Dr. Joseph Donnelly of this city was appointed today as medical director of the Margaret Hague Maternity Hospital, a unit of the local medical center, at an annual salary of $12,500. He succeeds Dr. Samuel A. Cosgrove, who retired on pension Oct. 27 after heading the institution since its inception twenty-four years ago.

An "encyclopedia of freedom," intended to give children a better understanding of democracy and what it means to be an American, has been prepared by the Citizenship Education Project of Columbia University's Teachers College.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 24 -Former President Herbert Hoover expressed faith here today in a healthy German nationalism.
LONDON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- The Soviet Union said tonight that a four-power European security conference after West German rearmament had been ratified by the West "would have no point."
A hitch has developed in progress toward labor unity, but high union officials expressed confidence last night that it would be overcome without upsetting hopes for a merger next year.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (UP) -- A key Federal Power Commission official formally recommended today that the Idaho Power Company, not the Federal Government, be permitted to develop the vast water resources of the Hell's Canyon stretch of the Snake River.

Legal moves were started yesterday to free a suspended New York City motorcycle patrolman held as a material witness in a traffic "courtesy card" racket and to get back cards and papers seized in his home.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 24 (AP) -- The White House said today that Joseph M. Dodge, former budget director, was making a general study for President Eisenhower of the organization, coordination and development of foreign economic policy.
BERWICK, Pa., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Browning Ross, United States Olympic long-distance star representing the Penn Athletic Club of Philadelphia, won the Berwick Marathon today for the fifth year in a row.

Fresh picnic shoulders, now an economical offering, might be presented as a refreshing interlude before the turkey left from Thanksgiving is served again. It would be particularly delicious if prepared in the German manner, for which the meat is boned and rolled (it is best to have the butcher do this) and then baked with white wine, bay leaves, lemon rind and seasonings.
A patrolman shot and captured a motorist who had run him down while driving on the wrong side of a Brooklyn avenue last night. The motorist was wounded in the foot.
In keeping with a tradition older than the United States itself, Americans around the world gave thanks yesterday for the bounty of their blessings.
This season's resort shoes offer as much color and variety as do the travel folders that lure the south-bound vacationer.
Church and synagogue joined yesterday in services of prayer for continued peace and of reverent gratitude for past blessings.

When the Supreme Court unanimously decided last May that racial segregation in the public schools was unconstitutional it invited the Attorney General of the United States, as well as the Attorneys General of states in which segregation was required or permitted by law, to submit briefs as to what form the subsequent decrees should take.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 (AP) -- French and German officials will hold new discussions in Paris this week-end on the controversial agreeemnt to Europeanize the Saar territory, the West German Government announced today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 25 -- A special committee of the Egyptian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission upheld today the commission's resolution of last Friday, rejecting Egypt's complaints in the Bat Galim case. But the committee decided to delete a clause stating that the complaint was "unfounded."

The dispatch from your Helsinki correspondent in The Times of Nov. 18 on the Finnish Government's plan to build an oil refinery may create the impression that this project is merely a result of Finnish trade with the East. This is misleading. The idea of building an oil refinery was discussed in Finland in the Nineteen Thirties.
WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 25 -- A week-old theft of $92,000 in jewelry emerged tonight from a shroud of police secrecy that Mayor Walter A. Quinn had called "ridiculous."
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 25 (AP) -- A team of young marksmen brought Italy the world clay pigeon title today in the international championships with a world record score of 773.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Art Andrews of Iowa City won two national indoor tennis championship matches today as the annual tourney began. He defeated St. Louisan Steve Brown, 6 -- 0, 6 -- 2, and Ted Duncan of Nashville, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, said today that the Air Force Secretary, Harold E. Talbott, apparently had admitted the present budget level for the Air Force was "inadequate."

Robert Schasseur Inc, international representative for Westinghouse, Bethlehem Steel and other concerns, through Cushman Wakefield Inc, agent, in 460 Park Ave; Hoffman Advertising Inc, general and executive offices, in 370 Lexington Ave; A. E. Phelps Co Inc, importer-exporter of textiles, in 417 5th Ave Winfield S. Bondy, consulting engineer, in 105 W 40th St -- Albert B. Ashforth Inc, broker.

OTTAWA, Nov. 25 -- A plan to spare residents of the Province of Quebec double taxation at no cost to the Federal Government was reported today to have been formulated by officials of the Federal Finance Department.
If the nonprofit, voluntary hospitals in New York City were forced to abandon their free and part-cost ward and clinic service because of the lack of popular support the result could be catastrophic.

A biography of D. H. Lawrence, "The Intelligent Heart," by Harry T. Moore, which had been scheduled for publication next month, will be issued by Farrar, Straus Young on Jan. 3. The author visited many of the places where Lawrence lived, interviewed people who knew him and found documents "full of new information."
The letter from Pearl Buck which appeared on your editorial page Nov. 16 brought a flood of calls to our institution, since it seemed to be alluding to Westfield State Farm.

Jewish congregations in this city and over the country will observe Tercentenary Sabbath this evening and tomorrow morning in grateful commemoration of the 300th anniversary of Jewish settlement in this country.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25 -- A "persistent and unholy alliance" between the leader of the Labor Opposition, Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, and the Communist party was alleged today by William M. Bourke, the Labor member of Parliament for suburban Fawkner in Melbourne. He said:

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 25 (AP) -- President Juan D. Peron attempted to sound a calming note tonight in his feud with the Roman Catholic Church. But even as he did so at a rally here, another priest was punished on charges of having stirred up a student demonstration.

David A. Wallace has been elected a director of the Federal Machine and Welder Company, manufacturer of resistance welders and presses. Until his retirement a year ago, Mr. Wallace was president of the Chrysler division of the Chrysler Corporation.
Competition in fire-fighting techniques will be held tomorrow to determine a city-wide champion company of the Civil Defense Auxiliary Fire Corps.

A large group of "middle men" in the selling profession have not been getting the recognition they deserve, the National Sales Executives, Inc., believes. The group, beginning next spring, will present Field Sales Management Awards to men on the regional and local levels who supervise salesmen.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- President Eisenhower pledged today that the United States would work "resolutely and tirelessly" for the proper treatment and eventual freedom of Americans imprisoned in China.
RECENT putterings by geologists in ancient strata around the lower Palisades reminded a local scholar that one of New York's oldest residents, Rutiodon manhattanensis, came from around those parts.
Three vice presidents have been elected by two companies affiliated with the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), it was announced yesterday.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Nov. 25 -- The American-owned Mediterranean Refining Company and the Lebanese Government were deadlocked today on the price of gasoline to be produced at the refinery nearing completion at Sidon, Lebanon.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- France has filed what is believed to be the first international claim of its kind in the atomic energy field.

In the rush of autumn activities, fevered this season by the inclusion of political tonics, adequate attention may not have been given to one of our more important fall events. At the Pumpkin Show, in Pickaway County, Ohio, more than 200,000 persons came to do honor to Cucurbita pepo of the world-wide gourd family -- and to inspect the pies made from it.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The eleventh Ryder Cup matches will be played at the Thunderbird Country Club, Palm Springs, Calif., Nov. 5-6, 1955, the Professional Golfers Association announced today.
MONTREAL, Nov. 25 -- There may not be snow in New York for Christmas, but there should be no shortage of Christmas trees.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert, America's Davis Cup doubles team, easily gained the second round in doubles in the Victorian tennis championships today with a 6-0, 7-5, 6-3 triumph over Australia's Brian Robin and Tony Ryan.

Your appreciated editorial and the excellent story by Abe Raskin on Norman Thomas' seventieth birthday provoke the question: We make good use of ex-Presidents, such as Mr. Hoover; why not utilize ex-Presidential candidates?

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- French military operations against the fellagha (terrorist) bands in Tunisia will be halted for from three to six days next week to allow the terrorists time to heed appeals to lay down their arms.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Hat Box, one of two horses entered by R. R. Damon in the featured Thanksgiving Day Purse, won the six-furlong race for 3-year-olds at Narragansett Park today.

In order to give business men in this country an opportunity to look into business possibilities and prospects in Latin America and to explore new fields of American enterprise, Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) is conducting a series of trade tours.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 25 (AP) -- An All-Ireland team of eleven women defeated the New Atlantic No. 1 regional American team, 6 -- 0, today in the opening of the United States Field Hockey Association tournament.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 25 -- Despite the recognized importance of preparing students to be intelligent, well-informed citizens, the majority of the country's high schools do not require their pupils to take one course in world history or world geography.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The stock market generally was slightly firmer today. However, demand was selective among the industrials and most showed small irregular changes.
VIENNA, Nov. 25 (AP) -- An Italian Army officer released from a Russian prison said today he had seen a tall major of the United States Air Force in a Siberian prison camp last year.

We suppose there is considerable reason for gratification in the attainment of an agreement, still to be ratified, between the International Longshoremen's Association and the shipping and stevedoring companies. Reached on Thanksgiving morning after an all-night session, and near the expiration of a forty-five-day truce, it appears to promise more stability on the docks than has existed for some time.
CHICAGO, Nov. 25 -- Educators have reverted to an ancient mathematical aid -- the abacus -- to teach fundamentals of arithmetic to school children.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- A three-year renewal of the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act, will go to Congress in January.

AMMANFORD, Wales, Nov. 25 -- On a stretch of level land southeast of here and on a hilltop overlooking the farms of the Gwaendreth Valley to the southwest, the National Coal Board is sinking shafts for two new collieries designed to tap 235,000,000 tons of valuable anthracite.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 25 -- Informed Yugoslavs say the possibility that the Eastern European satellites can divest themselves of direct Soviet control has grown.

PARIS, Nov. 25 -- Speaking of the visit of Premier Pierre Mendes-France to the United States, the American Ambassador to Paris, C. Douglas Dillon, said today that French-American relations have never been better than they are now.

LONDON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Two British scientists reported today that young race horses grew 14 per cent faster than normal when treated with a daily dose of aureomycin. That means Queen Elizabeth II may have some giant 2-year-olds running under her colors soon.
FORT WORTH, Tex., Nov. 25 (UP) -- An oil transaction involving almost $21,000,000 and including property owned partially by Bing Crosby and Bob Hope will be completed Monday in Dallas.

TURIN, Italy, Nov. 25 (AP) -- An Italian Appeals Court today upheld a life sentence for former Lieut. Aldo Icardi of Pittsburgh, Pa., and increased the seventeen-year term for former Sgt. Carl Lo Dolce of Rochester, N. Y., in the wartime slaying of Maj. William Holohan.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Wichita, completing its greatest football season, beat Tulsa, 33 -- 19, today to sew up its first Missouri Valley Conference championship.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Goalie Terry Sawchuk turned in his third straight shutout and his sixth of the season tonight to lead the Detroit Red Wings into undisputed possession of second place in the National Hockey League with a 2-0 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs.
Alternate-side parking will go into effect Monday in a triangular section of Greenwich Village.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Nov. 25 -- Staff officials of the discussions here on land problems in Asia said today that the inquisitive and critical attitude shown by several participants indicated there would be a fruitful exchange of experiences and ideas.

PSYCHOLOGISTS would enjoy making character studies of Red Blaik and Eddie Erdelatz, the rival coaches at the Army-Navy game at Philadelphia on the morrow. Blaik is a dedicated man, intense and single-minded, an introvert to the core. Erdelatz is more like a mischievous boy. His eyes twinkle and a ready laughter bubbles within him.

MOSCOW, Nov. 15 -- Prince Peter Alexeyevich Kropotkin, who was an aristocratic Russian revolutionary, would no doubt be astonished to find that there is now a school in the back rooms and basement of the Moscow mansion where he was born in 1842.

Joseph O'Callaghan has sold the six-story apartment house on lot 24 by 100 feet at 580 Eighty-third Street in Brooklyn to O. Esposito for investment. The Bulkley Horton Company, broker in the transaction, also reported the sale of the two-family house at 930 Seventy-first Street by Arthur H. Mackin to Bernard J. Baker for occupancy.
Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Die Meistersinger," Metropolitan Opera, 7:30; "Carmen," Amato Opera Theatre, 159 Bleecker Street, 8:30.
Donald A. Windsor has been appointed general manager of grocery merchandising, and John A. Longenberger, general manager of meat merchandising, for the Grand Union Company, East Paterson, N. J.
Columbia's award-winning drama, "From Here to Eternity," has been named the "top money picture of the 1953-54 season" in the annual poll conducted by the Independent Film Journal.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Friday, Nov. 26 -- The Chinese Communists began a raid before dawn today against a tiny Nationalist-held island off the Fukien coast on Formosa Strait.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- In its most encouraging report in more than a year, the Federal Reserve Board said today that it saw prospects for "some expansion" in business.

National Airlines announced yesterday that, with record air travel expected between New York and Florida this winter, its near schedule would be put into effect on Dec. 15 and make available 20 per cent more seats on the airline's north south routes than a year ago.
Member lines of the North Atlantic Continental Freight Conference won another round yesterday in the long post-war fight to re-establish a dual-rate contract system in North Atlantic trade.

MANILA, Friday, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Philippine Foreign Office opened an investigation today of the reported "unfriendly and disparaging attitude" of the Indian Minister and an unidentified British diplomat here. The Government Press Office said last night President Ramon Magsaysay had ordered an inquiry, after having received "fresh evidence of the unfriendly attitude" of Indian Minister Mirza Ali Rashid Baig.

The City of New York obtained $1,305,552 from the auction sale of 389 improved and unimproved parcels comprising 523 tax lots in Brooklyn. The three-day sale was held in six separate sessions at the Brooklyn Academy of Music and was attended by about 3,000 persons.
Referring to your article of Nov. 5 on the front page of your newspaper, "Art World Mourns Matisse":

NEWARK, Nov. 25 -- Santa Claus, singing "White Christmas" in a rich tenor from the marquee of L. Bamberger Co., at Washington and Market Streets, provided the finale for the department store's twentieth annual Thanksgiving Day parade.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 18 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver of Tennessee, who fought Adlai E. Stevenson for the 1952 Democratic Presidential nomination, said today that Mr. Stevenson appeared to have "the best chance" of winning the nomination in 1956.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (AP) -- What woman would wear a hat identical with 20,000,000 other mass-produced hats?
The National Child Labor Committee took issue yesterday with the argument that laws controlling the employment of children breed idleness and contribute to juvenile delinquency.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Fred T. Wilkinson, acting warden, said today the majority of prisoners at the Federal penitentiary here were "very sorry" about the slaying of William W. Remington.
MOSCOW, Nov. 3 -- A wholesale indictment of bad taste in Soviet clothes and home furnishings has recently been made in this country.
Down Central Park West and Broadway yesterday wended Macy's Thanksgiving Day parade under a canopy of helium-inflated monsters, interspersed with gaudy floats and accompanied by blaring music.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 25 -- President Eisenhower played golf in perfect weather today before he sat down to carve a forty-three-pound turkey in the traditional observance of Thanksgiving Day.

Physicians here warned yesterday there was a strong possibility that "medical chaos" would result beginning next Wednesday. That is the effective date of a new traffic code that will drastically curtail parking privileges for doctors.

The new two-year wage agreement on the New York-New Jersey waterfront gives the International Longshoremen's Association an opportunity to demonstrate whether it is prepared to re-enter the ranks of bona fide trade unions.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- The election campaigns for state parliaments in Hesse and Bavaria have widened the rift between Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and Dr. Thomas Dehler, leaders of the two biggest parties in the Bonn coalition Government.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The remains of two Europeans who died 50,000 to 150,000 years ago were labeled "Praesapiens" or the "forerunners of modern races of man" at a meeting of the Royal Anthropological Institute here tonight.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- The cozy English open fire, spewing black smoke from the chimney pot, may be doomed in the next decade. The Government published today a report estimating that pollution of the atmosphere costs Britain $700,000,000 a year.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- New Rochelle High defeated Iona prep, the previously unbeaten Catholic Football League champion, 20 -- 14, on muddy McKenna Field this morning before 10,000 fans.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, said today he was not paying any attention to the battle of petitions for and against censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

CHICAGO, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The league-leading Montreal Canadiens rallied for two goals in the last period tonight to defeat the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2, before 8,864 fans for their fifth triumph in six games between the clubs this season.
Families are moving not only from the city to the suburbs, but also from larger suburban cities to more open environs on the suburban fringes.

Baron Silvercruys, Belgium's Ambassador to the United States, confirmed yesterday that his country planned to borrow $30,000,000 in the public market here on an issue of bonds payable in United States dollars.

Mortgage auctions of the New York Mortgagee Exchange will be resumed on Dec. 15 at the Roosevelt Hotel. Discontinued during the summer, the exchange will again be operated once a month. The Fred Berger Company will be the auctioneer.
The National Manpower Council reported yesterday that poor vocational guidance was keeping many young people from taking advantage of opportunities to become skilled workers and technicians.
The Suez Canal Company will embark early next year on a $45,000,000 improvement program that calls for widening and deepening the waterway along its entire 100 miles.

Percy Bassett, the Philadelphia featherweight who was the interim champion of the 126-pound division, will encounter Teddy (Redtop) Davis of Hartford at Madison Square Garden tonight. Because the gladiators are foremost in line for a chance at the world crown held by Sandy Saddler of Harlem, the bout is listed for twelve rounds.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse attacked today a Federal Power Commission lawyer's recommendation for private development of Hell's Canyon water power. He said the proposal was part of the Eisenhower Administration's plan for "a giveaway of the people's power resources to private combines."

RICHMOND, Va., Nov. 25 -- A major exhibition of the art of China, representing a survey of Chinese culture from 1525 B. C. to the end of the eighteenth century, will open at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts tomorrow and continue through Jan. 2.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Saratoga turned in a tremendously game effort today to capture the $17,875 Bowie Endurance Gold Cup Stakes by a length and a half from Crown's Glory.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 -- Charles E. Merrill, New York City investment banker, has endowed a chair of medicine at Harvard University to study heart diseases.
Recently completed studies, supported in part by the National Society for the Prevention of Blindness, indicate that one out of four school children need some kind of eye care.
Retirement of William Edwin Hall as president of the Boys Clubs of America after thirty-eight years in office was announced yesterday.

LOUISVILLE, Nov. 25 (AP) -- The University of Tennessee won its third straight team title and Indiana's Francis Zellers successfully defended the individual crown today in the thirty-sixth Thanksgiving Day cross-country run at Shawnee Park.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Miami of Ohio rallied today to defeat the University of Cincinnati, 21 -- 9, in the oldest football series west of the Allegheny Mountains.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 -- The American Federation of Labor opened a country-wide drive today against so-called right-to- work laws, which, it says, will be sought in more state Legislatures next year.

DALLAS, Tex., Nov. 25 -- The incredible news on election night, Nov. 2, that Dallas would send a Republican to Congress instead of Wallace Savage, the Democratic candidate, filled the Republican national leaders with hopes of an established Southern political revolt against the one-party system.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Steve Thomas scored four touchdowns and passed for two more as East Orange defeated Barringer, 45 to 25, at Martens Stadium before 9,000 fans today.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- With all sails set and all guns blazing, Sir Winston Churchill sailed jauntily today into the middle of a rousing political fight. Its basis is the Prime Minister's recollection in a speech last Tuesday of a message to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery late in World War II ordering him to stack captured German arms for possible reissue to the Wehrmacht for use against the advancing Russians.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Nov. 25 -- Brown University's football squad ended Colgate's domination over the Bruins of recent years by staggering to an 18-to-14 victory over the Red Raiders before 15,000 persons at Brown Field this morning. It was Brown's first triumph over its rival since 1949.
Communities that try to keep up with the "Jonesvilles" in airport construction pose a problem for Civil Aeronautics Administration airport engineers.

Three elderly persons were found dead in a Queens apartment yesterday, the victims of a defective gas water heater. The number of deaths in the city attributable to side-arm heaters thus rose to sixteen in less than three weeks and to ninety-six for the year.
NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (AP) -- Loyola University of the South dropped today all segregation barriers -- among both players and spectators -- at its basketball games.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 25 -- The appointment of Milton E. Pickman as executive in charge of production for the newly formed Distributors Corporation of America was announced today by Fred Schwartz, president of the concern.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Nov. 25 -- With a comprehensive drill that lasted nearly two hours, Navy's football squad today completed preparations for its fifty-fifth meeting with Army at Philadelphia's Municipal Stadium on Saturday.

The Hilton Hotels Corporation has completed arrangements to repay an investment banking group headed by Carl M. Loeb, Rhoades Co. more than $7,400,000 it advanced the company on Oct. 27 to help finance its purchase of Hotel Statler Company, Inc.

Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Martenet of 25 East Seventy-seventh Street gave a dinner dance last night in the ballroom of the Colony Club for their debutante daughter, Miss Emily Hopkins Martenet. The debutante, who received with her mother, wore a ballerina-length bouffant gown of pale gold-colored silk and carried a spray of yellow orchids.

AUSTIN, Tex., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Quarterback Charley Brewer threw two touchdown passes today as Texas downed Texas A. and M., 22 -- 13, and preserved a thirty-year jinx over the Aggies in their traditional game.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Nov. 25 -- A Democratic and a Republican member of Congress today criticized the United States delegation at the inter-American conference of finance ministers as being too conservative in their approach to Latin-American economic aid.
BOSTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The Boston Bruins and the New York Rangers fought to a 2-2 deadlock tonight in a National Hockey League contest at the Boston Garden before a crowd of 11,028.
Brooklyn Tech's powerful football squad won the Division I championship of the Brooklyn Public Schools Athletic League by defeating Boys High, 42 -- 28, on the loser's field yesterday afternoon.

BERN, Switzerland, Nov. 25 -- The Swiss Government has virtually decided on a fundamental change in commercial policy. Because it reflects an important modification in the Swiss view of future economic developments in the non-Communist world, the matter is of more than local importance.
The city and a group of savings banks are accusing each other of dragging their heels in the redevelopment of the $100,000,000 Brooklyn Civic Center.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 25 -- The Cornell team that got off to a disastrous start, losing its first four games, finished the season today tied with Yale for the Ivy League football championship.
A two-year contract for peace on this port's strike-and-crime-ridden waterfront was negotiated at 5 o'clock yesterday morning.

ROANOKE, Va., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A slow-starting Virginia Tech football team found itself in the second period today and went on to crush Virginia Military Institute, 46 -- 9, to finish its first undefeated season in thirty-six years and place itself in line for a possible bowl bid.

The representatives of Indonesia have done no service to the cause of good government and free government by presenting their claim to Western New Guinea as a case of "colonialism" versus "anti-colonialism." The issue of "colonialism" is not involved and never has been.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- Two of the four Government coalition parties asked today for a general amnesty for all German war criminals before the Paris agreements are ratified.
The role of the youth court in the New York criminal court system will be discussed in a broadcast on Monday from 2:20 to 3 P M. over Radio Station WQXR.

Much of the atmosphere of a Tokyo department store is recaptured in miniature in an exhibit that opens today at the Japan Trade Center, 393 Fifth Avenue. Although the public may not purchase, it is invited in for a look.
The nation's retailers are optimistic about Christmas business, according to a survey released yesterday by the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

Black Mike is back in baseball. Gordon Stanley (Mickey) Cochrane, a former star catcher with the Philadelphia Athletics and Detroit Tigers, and a one-time manager of the Tigers, has been appointed a scout for the New York Yankees.

Fordham Prep finished its eight-game campaign unbeaten and untied yesterday by downing Xavier, 18 -- 12, before 8,600 fans at Jack Coffey Field in the Bronx. It was the first unblemished season for the Little Rams, who have been playing football since 1908.

One of the nations largest common stock investment concerns, Affiliated Fund, Inc., reported yesterday that its assets had reached a record level. On Oct. 31 they amounted to $280,914,822, or $5.49 a common share, compared with $248,744,204, or $4.81 a share, a year earlier.
ONCE again "See It Now" has performed a notable service in the cause of free speech and civil liberties.

The towel was thrown in after last night's performance -- the third -- of "One Eye Closed." Written by Justin Sturm, the farce had its premiere on Wednesday night at the Bijou and gave a matinee yesterday.
TUEBINGEN, Germany, Nov. 25 -- Former President Hoover said here today the Communists were seeking "to destroy the freedoms of Western civilization," but they would fail.
HUNTSVILLE, Tex., Nov. 25 (AP) -- For a slight little man who has been in the Huntsville Penitentiary for twenty-two months this was a special day of Thanksgiving for tomorrow he will be free.

A 2-year-old male spitz that apparently had fallen into the North River on Sunday and found refuge under Pier 99, at West Fifty-ninth Street, was rescued from a cross beam about 100 feet from shore yesterday morning.

NEEDLES, Calif., Nov. 25 (AP) -- A broken rail was blamed today for the derailment of nine cars of the eastbound Santa Fe Chief as the train traveled at a mile-a-minute speed across the Mojave Desert last night.

COLLEGE PARK, Md., Nov. 25 (UP) -- Maryland's fast backs stunned Missouri today with three touchdowns in the first twelve and a half minutes of play and went on to wreck the Tigers, 74 -- 13, before 20,000 fans and a nationwide television audience.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The historic Fair Grounds opened its eighty-second season today with record opening-day betting and attendance figures as W. H. Bishop's Heredity and Joe W. Brown's Bobby Brocato won the split $7,500 Thanksgiving Handicap.

Bruno Walter opened his concert with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall with Schoenberg's youthful, unblushingly "romantic" "Verklaerte Nacht," a product of its composer's twenty-fifth year.

Blindness was the only ticket of admission to a Thanksgiving Day dinner in Queens yesterday. One hundred and fifty sightless persons along with some seeing-eye dogs, were the guest of the Gospel Association for the Blind at the Flushing Day School, 142-10 Sanford Avenue, Flushing.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Fifteen workers were hospitalized with minor injuries today after police fired four shots in the air to break up a jurisdictional clash by 150 McLouth Steel Corporation employes in suburban Trenton.
Charles Berry, a Harlem taxicab driver, won the New York-to-Coney Island handicap walking race yesterday.

The entire manufacturing business, including machinery, stock and good will, of the Courtcraft Manufacturing Company on Raritan Road in Clark Township, N. J., has been sold to George Smith of the Jane Smith Shops on Central Avenue in Westfield.

STONY POINT, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Frederick Rowley, 47-year-old carpenter of Central Nyack, was shot by a deer hunter 100 yards off Bulsontown Road, here, today. He died on the way to a doctor's office. It was the first fatal hunting accident of the present season in the metropolitan area.

LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Critics here for the most part extended a warm welcome to Beatrice Lillie on her return to the London stage in "An Evening With Beatrice Lillie," which opened at the Globe Theatre last night for a limited engagement.

An investing client of Spooner Spooner, attorneys, has bought the five-story apartment house for forty families on plot 100 by 100 feet at 1140-42 Woodycrest Avenue, the Bronx, in a deal negotiated by Joseph Spooner Sons, brokers.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Fifteen workers were hospitalized with minor injuries today after police fired four shots in the air to break up a jurisdictional clash by 150 McLouth Steel Corporation employes in suburban Trenton.
Charles Berry, a Harlem taxicab driver, won the New York-to-Coney Island handicap walking race yesterday.

The entire manufacturing business, including machinery, stock and good will, of the Courtcraft Manufacturing Company on Raritan Road in Clark Township, N. J., has been sold to George Smith of the Jane Smith Shops on Central Avenue in Westfield.

I was glad to read, in connection with the proposal to legalize overnight parking, your emphasis upon the absurdity of not including the $5 a month parking charge which has long been within the power of the city. It seems to me wholly unsound to permit free overnight parking on the city streets.
BERLIN, Nov. 25 -- Berlin's Jewish communal organization and several other groups protested today against an alleged revival of anti-Semitism and ultranationalism at a rally of the German party.

MALTA, Idaho, Nov. 25 (AP) -- What happens when there's no driver in the oncoming car to counter a zig with a zag? There is a head-on crash, Calvin T. Christensen, 30 years old, of Nyssa, Ore., said today.
MONTCLAIR, N. J., Nov. 25 -- Montclair High ended its sixth undefeated season under Coach Clary Anderson with a 34-to-0 triumph over Bloomfield at Woodman Stadium before 11,500 fans today.
DANVILLE, Va., Nov. 25 -- The Sadler's Wells Opera Company has signed Camilla Williams, Negro lyric-soprano, to make four appearances next March at Bournemouth as Cio-Cio-San in "Madama Butterfly."
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 24 -- The chief of Bolivia's political police said today that 538 political prisoners were now in jail, compared with about 800 several months ago.

DETROIT, Nov. 25 (UP) -- Bobby Layne passed for two touchdowns, the 100th and 101st scoring tosses of his National Football League career, and Jack Christiansen added the other two tallies today to give the Detroit Lions a 28-24 victory over the Green Bay Packers.

Alexander B. Louden of Amityville, L. I., has purchased the 216-acre Hilltop Farm in Ghent, N.Y. Charles H. Collins of Colorado Springs was the seller. The Taghkanic Real Estate Agency of Hillsdale was the broker in the sale of the property which was listed through Previews, Inc.

Continuing the substantial gains recorded in every month this year, the 527 mutual savings banks of the nation showed an increase of $101,000,000 in deposits during October, to $25,939,000,000 on Oct. 31, J. Hamilton Cheston, president of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, announced yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- India and the Ukraine lined up today behind Indonesia in her dispute with the Netherlands on the question of West New Guinea.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Chances are that football fans never heard of Paul Winkel or Tom Bullock, second classmen at the military academy. The headlines and the spotlights have belonged to the Pete Vanns, the Tommy Bells and the Don Holleders, but if Army beats Navy at Philadelphia Saturday Cadets Winkel and Bullock may be taking bows.

James Wright, 37-year-old ex-convict, was held without bail yesterday on homicide and armed robbery charges in Felony Court. Teddy Kazmierzak, 35, an alleged accomplice of Wright in the hold-up last April 26 of the Clinton Trust Company, also was held without bail.

POUGHKEEPSIE, N. Y., Nov. 25 (AP) -- Rodolfo Mendez, 20-year-old Brooklyn printer, and Edward Alger, 21, Syracuse University junior from Schenectady, won the annual Young Men's Christian Association road races today.
The Johns-Manville Corporation announced yesterday the formal opening of a new central asbestos mill at Mashaba, southern Rhodesia, with an initial capacity of 20,000 tons of fiber a year.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis T. P. Plimpton of 1165 Fifth Avenue and Sweet Hollow, West Hills, Huntington, L. I., and Mr. and Mrs. Duncan H. Read of New York and Middleburg, Va., entertained jointly with a dinner dance last night in the St. Regis Roof for their respective debutante daughters, Miss Sarah Plimpton and Miss Caroline Duncan Read.
Determined to beat the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds on Sunday, the football Giants continued their preparations yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 25 (UP) -- The Democratic National Committee reported today that twelve Governors had accepted invitations to attend its national fund-raising "victory" dinner in New Orleans on Dec. 4.

At the fifth annual Gotham Ball last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza, forty-two young women, most of them from the metropolitan area and Massachusetts, made their debut. Proceeds from the event will go to the New York Foundling Hospital.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 25 -- Two Arab spokesmen asked the United Nations today to make an on-the-spot inquiry into their charges that Israel was abusing her Arab minority of 180,000.

DESPITE pre-season reports on the relative abundance of ruffed grouse in New England, New York, adjoining states, and the maritime provinces, the information that has been received from most areas indicates that the results were well under whose of last season.

NEWBURGH, N. Y., Nov. 25--1 Mr. Cooper was a delegate ap-i pointed by Governor Dewey t01 represent New York at the! eighty-fourth prison association meeting. The 53-year-old chap-! lain became ill after arriving, underwent surgery on Oct. 30, and again eight days later.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today the production of motor vehicles for November will be 501,700 cars and 89,600 trucks. The year's peak level is indicated for December, the agency said.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Aristotle S. Onassis, the Argentine shipping man, arrived in Britain today protesting volubly against "this Peruvian pipe dream," which has cost him, at least temporarily, the service of his fleet of whalers.

ALBANY, Nov. 26 -- The State Education Commissioner today reinstated one of the five members of the Lindenhurst, L. I., Board of Education whom he had removed two weeks ago for "wilfully disobeying" his orders.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Democratic National Committee will elect a new national chairman next Thursday in a meeting in New Orleans. The race is wide open, but three men were reported tonight to be leading candidates for the position.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Nov. 26 -- The Chinese Nationalists repulsed a small-scale Communist raid this morning in the Strait of Formosa at Wuchiu Island, about 125 miles west of Taipei. A Defense Ministry announcement said the Reds "tried to invade" Wuchiu, but it was not clear whether they landed troops on the tiny island.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 26 (AP) -- If Southern California can find any comfort in meeting Notre Dame here tomorrow, it may be in knowing things won't be much rougher in the Rose Bowl against Ohio State.
With hardly a pause, the stock market pushed forward hour by hour yesterday and registered new high marks for the upward movement.

BERKELEY, Calif., Nov. 26 (AP) -- A laboratory experiment that quickly produced large numbers of congenital heart and blood vessel defects in rats was reported today by four University of California medical researchers.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- An Air Force pilot was killed today when he accidentally was hurled through the plastic canopy of his jet trainer plane while waiting to take off from nearby Andrews Air Force base. He was identified as Lieut. Col. Glenn E. Davis, 39 years old, of Arlington, Va.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

Jacob Malik, newly appointed chief of the Soviet delegation to the United Nations, has been invited to tour the United States and talk to Americans "in all walks of life" to learn their attitude on peace and war.

With operating revenues down more than $67,000,000 to $520,307,364, consolidated net income of the Southern Pacific Company dropped to $39,580,037, or $4.37 a share, in the first ten months this year. In the same months last year, when the railroad system's gross reached $587,782,619, it carried $53,870,654, or $5.95 a share, through to net income.

LONDON, Nov. 26 -- The stock markets again were quietly irregular today on reduced turn-over. A new batch of favorable profit statements helped industrial shares initially, but they were unable to hold gains.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Wheat had a firm tone today, but the deferred months showed more strength than the December, which met fair. Free-selling traders were uncertain as to what December deliveries would be.
Members of the Junior Auxiliary of St. Joseph's Day Nursery will give their annual tea dance tomorrow afternoon at the Stork Club for the benefit of the nursery.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Ship repairers in the London docks, who have been on strike for ten weeks, voted today to resume work next Monday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Israel said today she was giving "fresh consideration" to six-year-old demands by the Arab states for compensation for Arab refugees who fled during the 1948 Palestine conflict.

ATLANTA, , Nov. 26 -- The Georgia Customs District, embracing Savannah, Brunswick and Atlanta, leads all other Southeastern districts in the rate of gain in the dollar value of goods shipped to foreign countries in the first half of this year.

The sightseers -- now numbering a million a year -- who are escorted through U. N. headquarters by the guided tour staff have a natural concern, as has the U. N. itself, with the quality and performance of the guides, described on this page in a letter from a competent and unprejudiced observer.

Members of Building Service Employes, Local 32-E, A. F. L., voted last night to strike against 5,000 Bronx apartment houses unless a pension plan awarded by an arbitrator two months ago is put into effect.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 26 -- Ambassador James Scott Kemper has withdrawn an invitation to Representative James G. Fulton to an embassy dinner because of the reaction to Mr. Fulton's criticism of United States policy at the inter-American economic conference.

THE retrospective exhibition of paintings by Guy Pene du Bois at the Staten Island Museum in St. George is a tribute to an artist who has held fast to the luminously realistic style he originally developed under the teaching of Chase, Henri and DuMond.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- The 21,000 postal employes in this city will be going to school after Christmas in what is described as the first educational program of its kind in the country.

According to Ralph G. Albrecht, in his letter published Nov. 7, the Allied decartelization program represented an "extraordinary interference in German affairs, pursuant to an occupation law that leading Continental and American lawyers are agreed is illegal under international law * * *."
SINGAPORE, Nov. 26 (AP) -- A post-war tin production record is virtually certain to be set this year by the mines in the Federation of Malaya.
Standing in the middle of Lord Taylor's Young New Yorker Shop yesterday afternoon, pretty Anne Fogarty was surrounded by an admiring group of young girls and women.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Nov. 26 -An invitation from Bermuda for a team series was read to the members of the International Class at the awards dinner held at the Larchmont Yacht Club tonight.

A bedridden woman and an arthritic man were rescued by the police and firemen yesterday in a two-alarm blaze in Brooklyn. The fire is believed to have been caused by a cigarette spark igniting the naphtha in a hat-cleaning fluid.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 26 -- The methods with which one of Cleveland's chemist-detectives helped uncover the possible path of Mrs. Marilyn Sheppard's killer were described today before a jury in Common Pleas Court.
Members of an opposition slate in a truck union election branded yesterday as an "unmitigated and malicious falsehood" a charge that their campaign was backed by funds raised by underworld elements.
Prices of futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 9 to 19 points yesterday, led by old December.
Bobby Layne, Detroit Lions' quarterback, was the fourth, not the third, player in National Football League history to throw 100 or more touchdown passes.

The third General Assembly of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. will be held tomorrow through Friday in Boston. There will be seven plenary sessions and a number of public meetings.

General liquidation and profit taking tumbled cocoa prices yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Closing prices were down from 87 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) to the 100- point limit. The spot month which has no limit, was off 110 points.
PARIS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Four paintings by Paul Cezanne and Vincent Van Gogh, never shown publicly before, went on display today as part of a gift to the Louvre.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 2 per cent above sales in the corresponding period last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

The H. Wolff Book Manufacturing Company, in an expansion move, has leased the ten-story building at 265 Tenth Avenue from the 265 Tenth Avenue Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of the General Realty and Utilities Corporation. The building, which occupies the entire block on the west side of the avenue between Twenty-fifth and Twenty-sixth Streets, contains 220,000 square feet of space.

To the editorial in The Times of Nov. 21 on the proposed transference of the Guided Tour Service at the United Nations from the American Association for the United Nations to the Secretariat some supplementary facts should be added.

YONKERS, Nov. 26 -- Mixing showmanship with the hubbub of 5,000 shoppers, and adding a generous dash of superlatives, the Cross County Shopping Center opened its first season as "the Christmas City" this afternoon.
MANHASSET, L. I., Nov. 26 -- A tiny shingled building that was a slum dwelling for many years has been salvaged for preservation by Nassau County as the oldest schoolhouse on Long Island.

A Tuckahoe, N. Y., insurance man charged yesterday that two of his children in one Westchester County parochial school were being subjected to "brain washing" in behalf of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. He said that a third, in another parochial school, was being subjected to "almost daily praise" of the Wisconsin Republican.

Directors of the National Acme Company lifted 1954 dividend payments to $4 a share fro fn $3.50 paid last year, with the declaration yesterday of a year-end extra of $1 on the common stock, payable on Dec. 22.
Appetites for turkey can be piqued almost to the degree they reached on the holiday if the leftover bird is transformed into an interesting dish.

The Baltimore Bullets received permission yesterday to suspend operations in the National Basketball Association for the remainder of the campaign. The Bullets can resume play next season if their financial difficulties are overcome.

Dr. Nelson Glueck, president of Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion, asserted last night that through the use of dense settlement and exploitation of natural resources Israel's southern Negev desert could be restored to its ancient prosperity.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 26 (UP) -Cesare Merlo of Italy won the three-day clay pigeon event in the world shooting championships today with a score of 296.

Mild, clear weather plus a long Thanksgiving Day week-end brought unusually large throngs into midtown Manhattan yesterday to shop, see a show or take the children to view the toys in the big department stores.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- The Parliament has taken steps to bar use against the Indian. Government of the principal weapon that brought it into existence.

ROME, Nov. 26 -- The Paris agreements for the Western European Union were advanced toward ratification by the Italian Parliament today when they were approved by the Defense Committee of the Chamber of Deputies.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Britain's atomic bomb-conscious military leaders are beginning to experiment seriously with aerial supply lines for combat troops.

The four-story factory building at 38-14 Thirtieth Street in Long Island City, Queens, has been purchased by Germaine Monteil, Inc., manufacturer of perfumes, lipstick and other cosmetics. The seller was the Metallizing Engineering Company which has opened a new plant in Westbury.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- Communist China is described by a leading Indian editor who was recently there as a microphone-regimented "sea of bleak blue."
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 26 -- The A. F. L. General Teamsters Union tonight ended its strike against five downtown department stores on the eve of the walkout's first anniversary.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Sewell Avery and other directors of Montgomery Ward Co., facing a vigorous challenge for control, voted today to give stockholders a bigger quarterly dividend and a larger year-end extra.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- M. Mendes-France has three political heroes: Raymond Poincare, conservative statesman and financial expert; Leon Blum, Marxian idealist and esthete; and Gen. Charles de Gaulle, uncompromising nationalist and believer in the mystique of French grandeur.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The United States consumed 1,231,317 tons of new rubber in the twelve months from July 1, 1953, to June 30, 1954, the Department of Commerce reported today. This was a decrease of 134,000 tons from the previous twelve months.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Nov. 26 -- Prime Minister Mohammed Ali said today Pakistan was ready to reopen negotiations with India to settle disputes that frequently threatened peace between them.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -The Navy has started a new crackdown on laxity aboard ships and among American crews in Hong Kong and other Asian ports. It has been reported that American equipment has leaked into Red China.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 7.6 per cent above the like week lash year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 5 per cent and orders 7.8 per cent. Following are the weekly statistics in thousands of board feet:
VIENNA, Nov. 26 -- Representative Victor E. Wickersham, Democrat of Oklahoma, arrived yesterday after having spent twenty-five days behind the Iron Curtain, including two weeks in the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- A lightweight bathtub, made of glass fibers and plastic, was patented this week as a substitute for the traditional ponderous cast-iron vessel.
LONDON, Nov. 26 -- Sir Winston Churchill warned the Western world today against incautious or unprepared advances in international affairs.

CLIO, Ala., Nov. 26 (UP) -- A Federally insured bank opened here today with the best wishes of Clio's one-time "informal banker," who vanished for twelve days last March with the savings of hundreds of townspeople missing from his vault.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States, in an "unusually strong" note, demanded today the release "forthwith" of thirteen Americans jailed by the Chinese Communists.

The New York Yankees will complete their "million dollar" deal with Baltimore by obtaining First Baseman Dick Kryhoski, Catcher Ray Murray, Pitcher Mike Blyzka, and another player within the next few days, the United Press reported last night.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Following is the text of the joint United States-Austrian communique issued today at the end of Chancellor Julius Raab's visit:

Community chests this year are collecting 4 per cent more money than last year, according to 10 per cent of the chests reporting yesterday. But they are running slightly less than 1 per cent behind this year's goals, a spokesman said.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- The Democratic party, one of three pro-German parties in the Saar, will boycott the plebiscite foreseen in the Paris agreement on that region.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 26 -- A growing pall of smog caused Los Angeles County officials today to request citizens to suspend trash burning for at least twenty-four hours.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Atomic Energy Commission sources predicted today that it might be years before the commission's Patent Compensation Board acted on a French claim for a reasonable award for the use of a uranium fission process.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Sheriff John E. Hoy notified immigration officials today that he would accept no more detainees for temporary lodging in the Westchester County jail at East View.

CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Two pioneers in heart surgery presented evidence today that a blood - shunting operation could prevent or delay cardiac failure in certain patients suffering from plugging or narrowing of their heart arteries.
The "721 Club," Bonwit Teller's Shop for men who shy away from crowded counters and the hectic hustle of Christmas shopping, celebrates its twenty-first anniversary this year.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- The Soviet Ambassador to France was reported today to have told Gen. Charles de Gaulle that the Soviet Union would repudiate its alliance and trade accords with France if the National Assembly ratified the agreements on West German armament and sovereignty.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 26 (UP) -- A gunman robbed a branch bank of about $14,500 today and fled into the crowd at near-by Fair Grounds Race Track where the police carried out a manhunt among 5,000 racing fans.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 26 -- Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the Social Democratic party, said in Munich today that any attempt to arm West Germany without the cooperation or against the resistance of his party and the trade unions would be catastrophic for democracy in the Federal Republic.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Lieut. Col. Edward Richardson, public information officer at the Military Academy, said today that the Superintendent, Lieut. Gen. Blackshear M. Bryan, contemplated no change in the Academy's policy regarding topics to be debated by the corps of cadets.

TRENTON, Nov. 26 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican, regained today some of the votes he had lost to Charles R. Howell, Democrat, in the first two days of the recount for United States Senator from New Jersey.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -Following is the text of a United States note to Communist China on the imprisonment of thirteen Americans:

AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 26 -- President Eisenhower announced today his intention to appoint George V. Allen, now Ambassador to India, as Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern, South Asian and African Affairs.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Florida will open its 176-day racing season tomorrow, and the $10,000 Inaugural Handicap at Tropical Park will be run in two divisions.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- A group of Latin-American nations began today to seek a compromise in the deadlock between the Netherlands and Indonesia on the question of West New Guinea. The territory, now ruled by the Dutch, has been a matter of contention since Indonesia won her independence from the Netherlands late in 1949.

The one-story automobile sales and service building at 1630 Bedford Avenue, northwest corner of Crown Street, in Brooklyn has been purchased by Tri Line Motors, Inc., sales agent for Ford cars and trucks.

QUEBEC, Nov. 26 -- Following a discussion of federal provincial tax problems with representatives of the Federal Government, Onesime Gagnon, Finance Minister of Quebec, declared that no basic change would be made in the provincial income tax law.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -- Troop reinforcements have been sent into the wild tribal country of northeastern India following receipt of reports that tribesmen on a mission of revenge had killed fifty-seven persons and burned the village of Yimpang.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- Former President Hoover ended his good-will visit to Germany today by congratulating Chancellor Konrad Adenauer on his leadership of West Germany along a road of spectacular recovery.

School has settled down to a frantic routine involving completion of impossible homework assignments and incredibly involved research projects. It has settled down enough to encourage teachers to believe that they can, by means of tests, determine roughly what their charges have learned since school resumed in the fall.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Fifty-six nations endorsed today the achievements of the United Nations Technical Assistance Program, pledging a total provisionally set at $12,264,000. For the first time since inception of the aid program, however, the United States was unable to announce its continued participation.

Christmas trade unexpectedly jammed traffic in the city's retail districts yesterday. Many customers came in from the suburbs in private automobiles and there was a bustle of trucks to replace stocks bought in the week's early rush.

Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell last night turned down a request by the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., that he "disassociate" himself from selection of an impartial adviser to iron out labor disputes on the city's transit system.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- During the week ended Nov. 24, member bank reserves decreased $445,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
Teddy (Redtop) Davis of Hartford, Conn., fought the 107th bout of his professional career and made it his best one in Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The United States and Austria renewed today their pledge to press toward an Austrian state treaty and the withdrawal of four-power occupation forces at "an early and fixed date."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Dr. Leonard A. Scheele, Surgeon General of the Public Health Service, announced today a sweeping expansion of its commissioned reserves for civil defense duty.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The resumption Monday of the Senate's censure debate seemed assured today after the disclosure that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy had left the Naval Hospital for several hours yesterday.

HAVANA, Nov, 10 -- Renegotiation of the reciprocity treaty between Cuba and the United States, now going on in Washington, has focused the attention of importers of American products here on the high taxes elected simultaneously with duties in the custom house.
LONDON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The International Sugar Council today estimated world sugar free market requirements next year at 4,400,000 metric tons and fixed the Cuban export quota at 1,789,877 tons.
A nation-wide movement for petitions urging the Senate to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy has been started by a group of Harvard students.

No Republican President in the foreseeable future is likely to advocate complete free trade. Nor, for that matter, is any Democratic President. The time has come, as a matter of fact, when the old slogans and shibboleths don't mean much. What is needed in today's international world is an increased flow of goods for the mutual benefit of all nations willing, in good faith, to participate.
Maureen Stapleton and Anthony Ross have been signed to co-star in the first half of Tennessee Williams' two-play program "27 Wagons Full of Cotton" and "Lord Byron's Love Letter."

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 26 -- Jackie Gleason, one of television's top-rated comedians, will be starred in a motion picture to be financed by Jack Benny and George Burns, if plans now under discussion materialize.
Corporate debt financing will come back into the spotlight of the new capital market next week after a brief respite.

DETROIT, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Emil Mazey, secretary-treasurer of the United Auto Workers, C. I. O., told Chrysler Corporation today the union would strike the company's automotive body division at 7 A. M. Tuesday unless it yielded to union demands.

For a time last summer it seemed as though large areas in the West and Southwest were in for a bad dry spell. The Rio Grande almost stopped flowing. In western Oklahoma "practically all streams were dry." Secretary of the Interior Douglas McKay gave warning that new "dust bowl" conditions might be building up.
Marvin Greenwood, vice-president and general manager of Celotex Corporation, has been elected president of the Insulation Board Institute of Chicago.

Representatives of the Publishers Association of New York City and the Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, met briefly yesterday at the offices of the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service, 341 Ninth Avenue.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 26 -- The new Indonesian business men sponsored and protected by the Indonesian Government since the country won independence from the Dutch have lately come in for sharp criticism from many quarters. The new merchants are being widely blamed for everything from high prices and irregular supplies of goods in the market place to corruption and unwillingness to work.

Events today: Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conducting, Hunter College, 11 A. M.; "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony Young People's Concert, Wilfrid Pelletier conducting, Town Hall, 3; Raymond Lowenthal, pianist, Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, 3.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, proposed today that the free World set up "regional finance corporations" to promote economic stability in underdeveloped nations where communism might prove attractive.

Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's one-man subcommittee on investigations was not lawfully constituted when he questioned Corliss Lamont, and therefore a contempt of Congress indictment against the philosopher-lecturer must be dismissed, it was argued yesterday in Federal Court.

Recently this newspaper carried a story about the arrival in this city of the forty-foot ketch Nola Sargent, five weeks out of Montreal. She carried a crew of four Canadians and a cargo of modern paintings, forming a traveling art exhibit.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 26 -- The fear of criticism has caused some teachers to "turn back the clock" and seek safety in a curriculum that ignores contemporary issues, a national meeting of educators heard today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended last Saturday totaled 697,346 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 11,411 cars or 1.6 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 28,386 cars or 3.9 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 113,727 cars or 14 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.
A man who confessed taking part in a murder twenty-three years ago was dismissed from custody yesterday for lack of evidence.

FORT SHERIDAN, Ill., Nov. 26 -- The conviction of.Lieut. Col. Harry Fleming, 46 years old, of Racine, Wis., on charges of collaborating with North Korean Communists while a prisoner of war was affirmed today by Lieut. Gen Hobart R. Gay, commanding general of the Fifth Army.
Four thugs who robbed a Bronx meat-packing company of a $12,807 payroll yesterday morning eluded two police cars that pursued their get-away car into Manhattan.

More than 40 per cent of the shoppers at Cross County Center come from Yonkers, according to a survey released yesterday by the center's management committee. The study showed that 22.4 per cent come from the Bronx, 21.6 per cent from the remainder of Westchester, and the rest from other areas, particularly from Connecticut, Manhattan and Queens.
Once they advertised a bath with every room; now it's a television set.

John Parisen has purchased the apartment buildings at 45-47 Clark Street and 120 Ward Street in Paterson, N. J., from the Alport Realty Company and the Renclerk Realty Company. J. I. Kislak, Inc., was the broker in the transaction and the J. I. Kislak Mortgage Corporation arranged financing for the buyer.

EBBW VALE, Wales, Nov. 26 -- The transformation of the south Wales coalfield under the National Coal Board's modernization plan is being matched in another of the region's old industries, the manufacture of tin plate.
