BOSTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- Holy Cross will take to the air tomorrow in a bid to upset favored Boston College in the fifty-first contest of the surprise-studded series at Fenway Park. A sell-out crowd of 40,207 is expected for the finale of the New England football season.

President Jose F. Figueres of Costa Rica warned yesterday that his country faced in the next few days the "great danger" of being invaded by rebel forces under the leadership of former President Rafael Angel Calderon Guardia.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 20 -With fifty players entered from six states, the District of Columbia and Manila, the Interstate masters' tournament at the Log Cabin Chess Club was off to a good start today.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- More than 1,000 men, women and children living in the mountainous Aures region of Eastern Algeria descended into the plains today to meet a deadline imposed by the French authorities for their evacuation. Most of the men and women evacuated were elderly.
The Chicago Pneumatic Tool Company and its domestic subsidiaries showed a moderate gain in earnings this year over the corresponding nine months of 1953.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -There is no legislatively defined method for the admission of such private patients as Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to the Bethesda (Md.) Naval Hospital. The Wisconsin Republican has been under treatment there for a sore elbow.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 26 (AP) -- Rustic Billy, a 20-1 shot owned by Mrs. J. V. Stewart of Elkton, Md., won the $5,000 Stymie Purse today in a field of hopefuls for the $25,000-added John B. Campbell Memorial Handicap on closing day, Dec. 4.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- Whether members of the United Nations Secretariat may accept part-time outside employment was debated here today.

Jerome Fine, 32-year-old factory owner who was arrested for disorderly conduct after a dispute in the West 100th Street police station, was adjudged guilty yesterday by Magistrate Walter J. Bayer, sitting in Probation Court.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 26 (Reuters) -- England's Marylebone cricket team had a bad time on the opening day of the first test match against Australia today as the Aussies scored 208 for two and the British star, Denis Compton, suffered a hand fracture.

Most sincerely do I congratulate you on the editorial in The Times of Nov. 23 in which you present with ex-actness a scorching appraisal of the life of Andrei Y. Vishinsky, checkered with ruthless, murderous deeds.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 26 -- India has prepared two drafts of a resolution under which the United Nations General Assembly would recommend the resumption of negotiations for a Korean peace settlement.

Anthony Kooiker, pianist, played a debut recital in Town Hall last evening. A native of Hull, Iowa, he studied at Northwestern University and the Eastman School, continuing his studies with Carl Friedberg in this city and Georges Enesco in Paris.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 26 -- A heckler expelled from a political rally in San Mateo last month sued Vice President Richard M. Nixon for $150,000 damages today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Government dropped today criminal charges against three Cicero policemen resulting from a 1951 race riot in the suburb.

Sylvania Electric Products, Inc., will buy for somewhat more than $1,000,000 in cash the television picture tube manufacturing facilities of the National Union Electric Corporation at Hatboro, Pa., if the stockholders of the latter company sanction the sale.

A Brooklyn grand jury investigating rackets is looking into the possibility of grand larceny in fund raising for police war veterans' organizations. Some of these groups are reported to have received only 25 per cent of the proceeds of benefit affairs.

Dana X. Bible, director of athletics at the University of Texas, was named yesterday as the 1954 recipient of the award the Touchdown Club of New York presents annually to "the individual who has rendered unusual service to football."

MELBOURNE, Nov. 26 (AP) -The United States champion, Vic Seixas, already labeled the enigma of America's Davis Cup team, will have the Australians guessing again tomorrow in the third round of the Victorian tennis championship.
MOSCOW, Nov. 26 -- In subfreezing temperatures, the ashes of Andrei Y. Vishinsky were buried today in a niche at the base of the great Kremlin wall in Moscow, necropolis of Soviet fame and greatness.

There was a new honor yesterday for Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt's great race horse, Native Dancer. In the voting by thirty-three members of The Morning Telegraph-Daily Racing Form staffs, the Dancer was picked as the horse of the year.

The pilot of the Japanese eighter Meiransan Maru testified yesterday that the signals sounded should have permitted his ship to pass safely the Panamanian-flag Lake Charles in the to East River a week ago, instead of colliding with her.

Election campaigns often produce oratorical outbursts which are not taken too seriously and are forgotten as soon as the election is over. But the fireworks accompanying the current election campaigns in Germany in the states of Hesse and Bavaria and in West Berlin begin to suggest developments which, if continued, could easily raise new doubts about that country's future course.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 26 (AP) -Russia won the international shooting championship today as the two-week competition came to a close with Finland taking the world title in the pistol event.

PARIS, Nov. 26 -- A concerted effort to spread unionism in the major plantation areas of the world was agreed upon today by the Executive Board of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions.

SYDNEY, N. S., Nov. 26 (AP) -- The Dominion Steel and Coal Corporation announced today that it had completed an iron and steel deal with West Germany, Britain and Mexico that included its biggest single order for the Sydney steel plant.

Thousands of homeward-bound New Yorkers using the Lexington Avenue I. R. T. and the Manhattan-Queens I. R. T. and B. M. T. subway lines were delayed by a snarl caused by a train breakdown in Queens during the rush hour late yesterday afternoon.
The first Junior Assembly for this season, one of the oldest and best-established dances for debutantes in this city, was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

BERLIN, Nov. 26 -- The leading German organization for combating anti-Semitism charged today that nationalism and anti-Semitism were again on the march. It said it was "regrettable" that this should be taking place "in the course of the remilitarization" of Germany.

Your editorial on Mr. Vishinsky bothered me considerably. Not that the content wasn't correct -- in fact, all you stated concerning his chosen way of life is true and I am in complete accord with it. Yet to say "we do not mourn this loss" seems to me quite unnecessary.
Just as with a fire department or police force, a hospital must always be fully staffed for an emergency at all times. Hospitals are not business enterprises and they cannot behave as such.
CHICAGO, Nov. 26 -- Dr. Harold C. Urey, the Nobel Prize winner and Professor of Chemistry at the University of Chicago, today offered a new approach to measuring the earth's earliest temperatures.

Each of the 3,000 licensed plumbers here is being reminded by the Health Commissioner of his duties in regard to side-arm gas water heaters, which can be deadly when defective or improperly installed.
Business loans in the New York area registered a nominal rise for the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank here reported yesterday.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Art Andrews of Iowa City, Al Holtman of St. Louis, Dave Harum of Coral Gables, Fla., and Crawford Henry of Atlanta, the first four seeded players in the order named, today gained the national junior indoor tennis semi-finals.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The Communist raid on Wuchiu is regarded in the Pentagon as a new attempt to smoke out the intentions of the United States Seventh Fleet.

The Commerce and Industry Association of New York asked the City Council yesterday to postpone a public hearing, scheduled for Dec. 9, on the proposed City Multiple Dwelling Code, to give the public more time to study it.

MIAMI BEACH, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Mexican sports fans are looking forward With enthusiasm to the Pan-American Games to be held in Mexico City next March 12-26, officials of the National Amateur Athletic Union reported today at the sixty-seventh annual A. A. U. convention.

THE reports on waterfowl from the north and from the south indicate that shooting has improved during the last few days. In every instance the improvement seems to have been due to increased number of flights of waterfowl rather than good hunting weather.
Although the rate of improvement in the wood furniture industry slowed during October, the general outlook for the business was described yesterday as still favorable.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 26 -Fifty leading Indian scientists met behind closed doors today to evolve a program of atomic energy for peaceful purposes.
Capt. William V. Bradley -- with an agreement for two years of pier peace in his pocket -- promised yesterday to make good on pledges to clean up his International Longshoremen's Association.

The western hemisphere's oldest airline --Avianca, Colombian National Airways -- will celebrate its thirty-fifth anniversary on Dec. 5. Originally known as Sociedad Colombo - Aleman de Transportes Aereos, the airline was formed on Dec. 5, 1919, and began operations early in 1920 with one aircraft.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 26 -Army and Navy will meet here tomorrow as two of the top college football teams of the country and with interest the keenest it has been in years in this great sports spectacle. The game will be the fifty-fifth of the series.

LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 26 -- The Federal Bureau of Investigation said today that an accused slayer of William W. Remington, former Government economist, had asserted that robbery was the motive for the crime.
A traditional male attitude that women "must be protected from complicated business matters" is nearly out-moded, according to findings in a recent study by the Institute of Life Insurance.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (UP) -- The Interior Department said today it was studying a recommendation that surplus food be used to improve the health of the Alaskan native population.

With Andy Romeo, Fordham's left halfback, recovered from a brief bout with a virus, the Rams are at peak strength for their encounter with Villanova today. The game is scheduled to start at 1:30 P. M. in the Polo Grounds.

TOKYO, Saturday, Nov. 27 (AP) Pascual Perez, captured the world flyweight championship by out-pointing Yoshio Shirai of Japan, the defender, last night and became the first man from Argentina to wear a world boxing crown.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 (AP) -- Representative Joel T. Broyhill, Republican of Virginia, today called for a Congressional investigation of the Lewisburg, Pa., prison where William W. Remington was slain.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Senator William F. Knowland proposed today a United States naval blockade of the Chinese mainland unless Peiping released thirteen Americans imprisoned on charges of spying.
A group of obscure minerals known as the rare earths is a center of debate in the steel industry.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Miss Ann Volp of Bergey, Pa., was named captain of the all-America field hockey team tonight. Miss Volp plays left inner.

THE world resounds with talk of freedom. In almost any language freedom ranks with bread and peace as a primary object of men's desire. But it has a different meaning in different parts of the world. In much of Africa and Asia it means to the individual scarcely more than national independence from the hated imperial powers.

THE glory that was Vienna is evoked by Bruno Walter's recording, with the Philharmonic-Symphony, of the four Brahms Symphonies and other orchestral music (Haydn Variations, Tragic and Academic Festival Overtures, four Hungarian Dances -- Columbia, four disks).

The spiritual contributions of Jews to American life were described as "priceless gifts" in a sermon yesterday morning by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Army won the toss and elected to defend the south goal. It was about the only defensive gesture either team was to make today in the deliriously daffy Army-Navy game. Everything else was geared to the attack as the midshipmen and cadets hammered away at one another with joyous abandon in a rousing spine-tingler that kept pulses pounding until the final frantic seconds.

THERE is a standing joke around the airports about the weather getting so bad that even the birds won't fly. Last week-end the weather over New York's three big terminals was that bad or worse, but while the birds were nesting comfortably, airplanes full of passengers were still trying to fly safely into any airport hereabouts that would handle them.

RETURNING from a business trip to Europe, where he made a survey of philatelic trends by talking with leading collectors and dealers, Edwin Mueller, one of the world's noted authorities on early stamp classics, said he had to conclude that "subject matter" collecting was "on its decline in its cradle, Europe."

NASHVILLE, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Fullback Don Hunt ran and Quarterback Jim Looney passed Vanderbilt to a decisive 26-0 victory over Tennessee today in a football game marked by a free-for-all in the final forty-five seconds.

Fighting Home Folks of Fighting Men, an organization of 350 kin of servicemen held captive by the Chinese Communists, protested the Administration's handling of the prisoner situation in a telegram yesterday to President Eisenhower.

BRANFORD, Conn., Nov. 27 -Officials of this town pledged today to continue a fight to persuade G. Albert Hill, State Highway Commissioner, to construct a toll station on the Greenwich-Killingly Expressway east of its present proposed site to permit free travel to near-by New Haven.

WRITERS who like to pigeon-hole modern art into neat and comprehensive categories rely with confidence on two fundamental generalizations. French art is decorative, clever and formal; German art is wild, woolly and expressionistic.

Squadron A defeated the Rough Riders, 10 -- 16, and the Meadow Brook Blues topped the Ramblers, 11 -- 4, as the New York Indoor Polo League began its twenty-eighth season at the Squadron A Armory last night.

AMARILLO, Tex., Nov. 27 -- The Forest Service of the United States Government has some lakes for sale in the Texas Panhandle, where getting water is one of the problems of life. CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Illinois moved a step closer this week to construction of its first toll road system designed to uncork traffic bottlenecks and speed traffic through the state.
BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- United States policy in the Middle East was criticized by a Zionist official today at the closing session of the Junior Hadassah's national convention.

AT this time of year festive decorations for the home come to the fore. And everywhere families are eagerly planning to decorate their homes and make gay trimmings for the holiday season.

OMAHA, Neb., Nov. 27 -- The Missouri River, which once provided the commercial lifeline for the opening of the Far West, has been taking steps to regain its place as one of the nation's great inland shipping routes.

IN honor of Sir Winston Churchill's becoming an octogenerian on Tuesday, the N. B. C. and C. B. S. networks are planning special salutes to the British Prime Minister.

At the Brookhaven National Laboratory, Upton, L. GREENWICH, Conn., Nov. 27 -- Greenwich's own Robinson Crusoe is making preparations to hibernate in wind-swept Long Island Sound.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois will re-examine on Monday a list of twenty educators, seeking one qualified for the presidency of the school.

ERIC BENTLEY has developed into one of the most exciting dramatic critics writing today. ONE of the events in the American Contract Bridge League's annual national tournament, which is just getting under way in Atlanta, Ga., is the national individual championship. Few cooks today will have the industry to rise before dawn to assemble this dish, which came over from England as a Christmas tradition in the days of the early colonists. But if they give ear to custom at all they will make plum pudding early -- in time for the flavors to mingle and mellow.

In his latest volume of memoirs-"Triumph and Tragedy"--Sir Winston Churchill records that on March 19, 1945 he dispatched the following crisp note to Mr. Ralph Assheton, the Conservative party chairman:

THIS book is the story of the Nahanni country in the Northwest Territories of Canada and of an attempt to find the lost gold of that little-known land. The attempt failed, so this must also be the story of a failure -- but it was a failure that succeeded in so many other ways that, if life could be entirely filled with such defeats, I for one would never ask for any victory."

An instance of erroneous thinking seems to me to be the attribution to policies of the Federal Government of responsibility for the decline in the number of young Americans specializing in science. There are other powerful influences to be considered.

Roy Meredith's article "Camera Adventures With Brady" (Nov. 14) was both informative and touching, since it proves that, like many "firsts" in any field of endeavor, Mathew Brady, too, died in poverty and obscurity, after having left a most lucrative business to become a war photographer.
LONDON, Nov. 27 -- One of the harshest gales in living memory has been lashing the British Isles for about twenty-four hours and still was raging tonight.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Auburn blasted once-mighty Alabama, 28 -- 0, today on star performances by Bobby Freeman and Joe Childress.

Mayor Wagner and Brooklyn Borough President John Cashmore have accepted honorary co-chairmanships of the Brooklyn College Hillel Building Fund Drive that was announced yesterday by Abe Stark, City Council President and chairman of the campaign.

QUEBEC, Nov. 17 -- With the Provincial Government still as anti-Communist as ever, there is no chance that Quebec's famous "padlock law" will be removed from the statutes at the legislative session just opened.
The American Christian Palestine Committee has asked President Eisenhower and Secretary of State Dulles for a reappraisal of the United States' policy in the Middle East.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- President Eisenhower's conversion of the Cabinet into a collective and formal policy making group, disclosed this week, is an event of historic importance.

PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 27 -- Arthur P. Morgan, a former regional director of Mathieson Chemical Corporation, has been appointed secretary for special gifts in the office of the Princeton University Fund.

GAINESVILLE, Fla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The deception of Quarterbacks Mario Bonofiglio and Carl Garrigus overcame Miami's tendency to fumble today and gave the favored Hurricanes a 14-0 football victory over Florida.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 22 -- The struggle between Roman Catholic authorities and the Government-supported priests' associations has flared up again. The associations have been condemned by the Vatican as being part of a Communist campaign against the church.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 27 -- Istanbul's 500-year-old covered bazaar, one of the largest and most famous of today, was scoured by fire early this morning. About 2,000 tiny shops and miles of stone-roofed alleys were demolished.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Nov. 27 -- A simple funeral service for William W. Remington, slain Federal prisoner, was held at 10 A. M. today in the small, stucco church here that he attended as a boy.
Paul G. Hoffman's article "To Insure the End of Our Hysteria" (Nov. 14) is vital to our understanding of a most serious problem.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -World airline representatives meeting here this week have voted to recommend to the International Civil Aviation Organization, a specialized agency of the United Nations, a series a measures to reduce "red tape" confronting air passengers and crews landing in various countries, a spokesman said today.

TWO books on the work of two important modern architects have just appeared almost simultaneously. The architects are Frank Lloyd Wright, as of this writing still of Spring Green, Wisconsin, and the Arizona Desert, and Walter Gropius, formerly of the Bauhaus school in pre-Hitler Germany and more recently Chairman of the Graduate School of Design at Harvard.

THAT most convenient source of gastronomical quotations, "The Physiology of Taste," says that fish is less nourishing than meat, tastier than vegetables and suitable to every temperament. This statement will find no quarrel with James Beard, who has undertaken to write about the entire subject of fish as found in our coastal and inland waters and has given it the usual delightful, methodical and complete Beardian treatment.

The New York Diabetes Association has elected Dr. Henry E. Marks as president. Dr. Marks is an attending physician at New York City Hospital and former president of its medical board. An associate in medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, he has served as chairman of the Clinical Society of the New York Diabetes Association, the professional organization of the association.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Stability characterized manufacturing employment in the Philadelphia area in October, according to the Pennsylvania State Employment Service. Hirings and layoffs in manufacturing industries last month canceled each other and left the area's labor force, exclusive of Government workers, at 551,900, the same as in September.

LINCOLN KIRSTEIN, general director of the New York City Ballet, has devised a lively method of relieving the routine and raising the morale of his company during the extended run of "The Nutcracker." Playing the same bill every night is hard enough for any theatrical troupe, but for one accustomed to the enlivening demands of repertory it presents more than ordinary difficulties.

I'M sure most of you remember, and with great pleasure, Owen Cameron's "Catch a Tiger," one of 1952's best suspense novels. Convincingly localized in the back country of northern California (so different from the unreal Southern California prevalent in murder novels), this was a brief and powerful intimate study of The Detective as a human being, his personal involvement with the crime and the motivations behind his manhunt.
PITTSBURGH, Nov. 27 -- Prospects for a quick over-all settlement of the department store strike rose today on its first anniversary.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Mrs. D. L. MacLachlan's Heart Flash, a 15-to-1 shot, took the lead soon after the start and stayed in front the rest of the way to win the first division of the $11,712,50 Inaugural Handicap before 15,037 fans at Tropical Park today.
PALO ALTO, Calif., Nov. 27 -- Stanford University, with 9,000 rolling acres of campus and a perennial need for ready cash, has plunged into the land development business.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 27 -- Senator Homer E. Capehart announced today that on his return to the United States he would press for revision of United States foreign policy in economic matters to give positive preference to Latin America.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 27 -Registrations here for the forty-third annual convention of the Investment Bankers Association have reached 1,200, a new high record.

WELCOME this new "Treasury" as an example of the way Yiddish literature should be presented in English. Ordinarily the general American reader may miss some of the finer points of Yiddish writing because he lacks the necessary background knowledge.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- No more than a year ago atomic scientists were clamoring for the United States to build an early warning radar screen across the Far North and on the North American continent's seaward approaches, to give the country six hours' warning in the event of an attack.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: Hybrid tea rose bushes and tree roses require winter protection. Hill up a cone of soil six inches high around stems of hybrid teas. Dig up tree roses and lay in a trench lined with salt hay and covered with a couple inches of soil.

THIS world is two-fifths land and three-fifths water. The population load on the land has increased by half in this century and continues to increase at the rate of 70,000 mouths a day. Sunshine drives the weather mill by which the land is diminished in nutrient fertility, mineral stores and energy.
Mayor Wagner moved yesterday to bring the Police Department up to its full authorized strength of 20,878 before this year ends.
The third New England Institute of Transportation will be held in Boston on Dec. 10.

TORONTO, Nov. 27 -- Breaking out of a four-game slump, the Toronto Maple Leafs rallied with two second-period goals to beat the New York Rangers, 3 -- 1, tonight and tie the Detroit Red Wings for second place in the National Hockey League.

SAYVILLE, L. I., Nov. 27 -The Sayville Board of Education disclosed today its opposition to plans for centralization of school districts in this area. Also it notified three districts that it would not be able to accommodate all their junior-senior high school pupils after the 1955-56 school year.

A FURORE developed in the press of India recently when it became known that the biography of Mohandas Gandhi, in the new edition of the Large Soviet Encyclopedia, called him the descendant of a family of "usurers" and accused him of having helped wage war by the British against the Zulus.

LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- A campaign against the method of selecting movies for the royal film shows bore fruit today. It was announced that "new ways" of selecting a movie will be studied before next year's show for Queen Elizabeth II.

To Dr. Helene W. Toolan of the Sloan-Kettering Institute for Cancer Research goes the credit for having succeeded in growing human "epidermoid" cancer in mice. Epidermoid cancer is the kind that attacks the lungs. Human embryonic lung tissue has been grown in a similar fashion in animals.

LONDON, Sunday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The worst storms in thirty years pick up a death toll believed to be more than thirty, in a long list of shipping disasters today and spread floods and havoc over much of Britain. Hundreds of seamen fought for their lives in crippled ships.

DALLAS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- While the man who created Southern Methodist's famed "aerial circus" watched as an honored guest, the Mustangs stuck to the ground for an easy 21-6 victory over Texas Christian University today.

WHEN in need of expert instruction on driver safety education, call in the family doctor. This accident-prevention prescription is suggested by Dr. Ross A. MacFarland of the Harvard School of Public Health.

NEWARK, Nov. 27 -- Two labor union trustees of New Jersey's Blue Cross Plan protested today against the action of the plan's management in trying to block payment of unemployment compensation benefits to 300 former part-time employes.

The desirability of letting commercial banks issue preferred stock is yet to be determined by the Federal Reserve Board. But according to a highly placed banking official, several of the board's members are inclined to reject such financing except in an emergency.
The need for new research on the problems of Jewish social relations in the United States and of Jewish settlement in other countries was underscored last night by a group of social scientists.

WILL Alaska become the forty-ninth state? That is the ambition of a majority voting in a recent poll there; and one of the very active leaders in this movement has been Ernest Gruening, who held the governorship, 1939-53, the longest term of any incumbent.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Bill Wohrman, a 195-pound senior from Bloomingdale, N. J., known primarily as a blocker, switched suddenly to a running role today and pounded for two touchdowns to lead South Carolina to a 20-to-19 victory over Wake Forest before 10,000 chilled fans.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Statistics of department store sales in Boston do not give an accurate picture. While the trend is toward slight improvement over a year ago, some stores are making wide sales gains. In general it appears that the stores concentrating on higher priced merchandise are doing considerably better than the average.

TENNESSEE history reveals that Melchior Thoni, a Swiss wood carver, settled in Nashville and in 1869 carved the first animals to be used on a flying jenny, as the merry-go-round was called. Mrs. Snow leaps from this obscure fact into a delightful tale of a young backwoods boy who became Thoni's helper.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 27 -- Mayor Walter A. Quinn has called a special meeting of the Town Commission for 4 P. M. tomorrow to hear a report on police handling of the news of two large jewel thefts.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -Senator William F. Knowland of California called today for a showdown vote by Dec. 11 as the Senate prepared to resume debate Monday on the proposed censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

The new schoolhouse of the Collegiate School at 254 West Seventy-eighth Street, will be dedicated Tuesday. Exercises will be held at 5:30 P. M. in the near-by West End Collegiate Church, 245 West Seventy-seventh Street.

PROOF that the moviemakers are not only on the alert for story material but also are ready and willing to part with impressive sums for pre-tested properties came to light last week. At press time it was learned that "The Rainmaker," the romantic comedy by N. Richard Nash now at the Cort Theatre, for which several major studios as well as some independent producers had been spiritedly bidding finally was acquired by Hal Wallis.

ANTA Theatre, 245 West Fifty-second Street, newly renovated and incorporating the most modern developments in design for production and comfort, will be dedicated on Dec. 20. The ceremony will take place in advance of a preview benefit performance of "Portrait of a Lady," starring Jennifer Jones.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- Preparations are being made in Moscow today for the conference on European security called by the Soviet Union.
BOSTON, Nov, 27 -- Two Massachusetts candidates already are campaigning for Governor in 1956.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 27 -- Delegates of all the American republics meeting here this week have been making the most comprehensive effort yet attempted to analyze and remove the basic causes of misunderstanding and disagreement among the countries they represent.

Governor-elect George M. Leader of Pennsylvania will address the fifty-sixth annual dinner of the Pennsylvania Society at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Dec. 11. An attendance of 1,500 persons is expected.

Norman Palefski, Abe Sodden and Irwin Blumenreich scored 21 points each as Yeshiva University's basketball team overwhelmed New York Cathedral College, 97 -- 40, at the Central Needles Trades High School gymnasium last night.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- Boston College brought its most successful gridiron season since 1942 to a close at Fenway Park today when it overpowered Holy Cross, 31 -- 13, in the fifty-first meeting between the schools. It was one of the most impressive showings against the Crusaders since the series began in 1896.

NOT many people realize that President Ulysses S. Grant had a remarkably liberal attitude toward the American Indian. While public sentiment was strong against the Red Man in the last phase of the opening of the West and extremists were urging the Government to complete the extermination of the race, Grant growled at his Second Inaugural, "Our superiority of strength and advantages of civilization should make us lenient toward the Indian.

Governor-elect Averell Harriman's office announced yesterday the schedule for a three-day visit to upstate cities by a special survey team named to assist the new Democratic state administration in formulating plans to improve employment.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The Cabinet, at an early meeting, will re-examine the whole question of East-West trade in the hope of curbing capital goods sales by Western Europe to Russia and her satellites.

A major East Coast propeller manufacturer recently received an SOS from a New England ferryboat operator to correct vibration in one of his boats so severe as to cause fallen arches among the crewmen.

A new kind of financial corporation, one which may hold the formula for quickening the flow of development money to the world's backward lands, is about to be established. The enterprise will be known as the Industrial Credit and Investment Corporation of India.
ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- Two state experts on agriculture will be on their way to Israel in a month to help carry out a three-year, $1,850,000 technical cooperation program there.
ATLANTA, Nov. 27 -- The Georgia Institute of Technology's Engneering Experiment Station has begun a long-term research program on naval stores.
LEWISBURG, Pa., Nov. 27 -- Alger Hiss was released this morning from the Lewisburg Federal Penitentiary, where he had served forty-four months for perjury involving espionage.

VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- Chancellor Julius Raab's visit to Washington may not have improved the prospects for his country's liberation, since that depends on the will of the Soviet Union. But it has clarified the status of the negotiations on an Austrian state treaty.

Having been in the first-night audience at "The Living Room," and then having read the reviews, I find myself shocked beyond words. If the critic is supposedly to endorse drama that is spellbinding, rich in human emotion and powerfully gripping, then why is he (and by "he," I mean the misleading band of reviewers) so obvious about the reason for writing so harshly and falsely about this stunning play? * * *

"CONSIDER your voice, first, last and always your voice," wrote Mrs. Fiske, that admirer of technical skill and precision of performance. Alas, what would the great lady say were she to be taken the rounds of Broadway and obliged to hear what pass for trained voices on our stage today?

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Korean war veterans studying under the G. I. bill reached a record 451,000 on Nov. 1, about twice that of a year ago -- and still is climbing, the Veterans Administration announced today.
Cranberry sauce, once identified chiefly with the traditional Thanksgiving Day feast, has achieved year-round popularity.

CAT stories for children are often oversweetened and sentimentalized to the point where the independent, adventurous feline loses his character and reality. Not so with "Fish Head." A down-to-earth, rat-chasing, thoroughly believable wharf cat, Fish Head does what he likes and likes what he does.

CARACAS, Venezuela, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Russia already had the championship trophy in its possession today when the official team point totals were released in the two-week international shooting competition.
ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- Although there are 55,000 more professional and practical nurses in the state than there were a dozen years ago, one-third of the nurses' positions in hospitals are still vacant.

THEATRE party agents are considering running a fellow named Tom Hammond for President. Mr. Hammond, general manager of "The Rainmaker," at the Cort, has just struck the first objective blow against the canard that all theatre party audiences are cold turkeys.
Investors are becoming more tax-conscious as the period for establishing tax liabilities on security transactions grows shorter.
Despite the growing demand for specialists in Russian and other Slavic languages, the number of students enrolled in such studies in American colleges and universities has dropped sharply since 1950.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams has warned city policemen against soliciting the public to buy tickets or program advertising for the social affairs of any police organization.
Mayor Wagner will present the city's Scroll for Distinguished Public Service to Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria at noon Tuesday at City Hall.

I NOTICED a letter by William H. Allen, in which he says that the author of "Blackboard Jungle," Evan Hunter, had taught in a vocational high school only seventeen days. This is supposed to be an argument against the authenticity of the author's judgment.

At last a constructive and optimistic note concerning the Middle East, amidst the gloomy discord which as a rule characterizes all discussion of this troubled region. I refer to Gertrude Samuels' thoughtful and thought-provoking article "Israel: Five Years of Change" (Nov. 7)'.
The automobile manufacturers and their advertising agencies are no longer looking for the man who wants a car to get from here to there and back again.

RHODE ISLAND, whose exposed shoreline was the area hardest hit by last summer's devastating hurricanes, is determined to prove the almost-too-pat saying that it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good.
LONDON, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- The Soviet Embassy here complained today of the way British newspapers have handled a current spy case in which the embassy has been implicated.

M. M. Miller and Raymond Pollock, two Douglas Aircraft engineers, told the Acoustical Society of America at the University of Texas last week that the commercial plane of the future will have a double fuselage, at least eight inches thick. The two hold that otherwise passengers in jets to come will not be able to endure the noise that will be generated.

ENTHUSIASM for his subject is the chief ingredient of James Reynolds' large travel book about Italy. From the moment islands off Sicily come into view as he sails across the Tyrrhenian Sea until he makes his departure through a Piedmontese valley he is in a state of continuously infectious euphoria.
TOPEKA, Kan., Nov. 27 -- Kansas' Governor-elect sees as his principal challenge the starting of a program leading toward the mitigation of the effects of devastating droughts and floods.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Mrs. Preston McGoodwin of Washington and New York will give a tea dance on Dec. 29 at the Columbia Country Club to introduce her granddaughter, Miss Constance McGoodwin. The guests at the forthcoming party will include many older friends of the family as well as debutantes and their escorts.

Wage increases and other gains have been granted to 3,500 employes under an agreement negotiated between the Bloomingdale Department Store and District 65 of the Retail, Wholesale and Department Store Union, C. I. O.

THE ouster of Ward French as president of Community Concerts, Inc., has caused considerable speculation in musical circles. Since Community Concerts long has been looked upon as his particular domain, people have wondered why he should have been "relieved" of his leadership of the musical associations that he helped organize in 900 towns.

THOSE audiences still making their way to see "Lili" may now read the book from which this motion picture was adapted. In Mr. Gallico's machine-tooled story, the heroine (Petite Mouche) is a jobless orphan, about to throw herself into the Seine when Carrot Top, a puppet in a carnival show, calls out and stops her.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Frederic Joliot-Curie, former high commissioner for atomic energy, today declared that he knew nothing about a suit in the United States against the Atomic Energy Commission by its French counterpart.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 27 -- The inventory of America's Davis Cup stock today -- exactly one month before the challenge round -- shows it at least 50 per cent better than at the same period last year.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- James V. Bennett, director of the Federal Bureau of Prisons, said today that more than one motive might have been involved in the attack on Remington.

ANY attempt to analyze what makes an artist tick is beset by many pitfalls. Estheticians from the beginning have expended more effort in the attempt than any other except, perhaps, in trying to arrive at a definition of beauty, which is equally elusive.

IN the schools and colleges of India and Pakistan a Western visitor sees an inspiring and, at the same time, a most dismaying challenge. Here is an immense subcontinent with a population of more than 425,000,000 people, some dozens of languages and dialects, a score of religions and sects, poor communications, strong political divisions -- and with every need for cohesive action.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (UP) -Two key Senate Democrats expressed guarded general approval today of Administration proposals for a development and aid program for Asia. The proposals, thus far only tentative, envision the United States' sharing the cost with Western European nations.
More than four-fifths of the post-war economic expansion in the New York metropolitan area went to the seventeen counties of the city's environs and less than one-fifth occurred within the city.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Negro leaders from six states and the District of Columbia proposed today that school boards be encouraged "to take a firm and positive position" against segregation.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- Several hundred Mayors and other city officials will exchange ideas on problems during the thirty-first American Municipal Congress here next week.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- With the Tunisian Government tagging somewhat reluctantly along, the French will make a determined effort next week to end an incipient military threat to their position in the North African protectorate.

Gen. Carlos P. Romulo, chairman of the Philippine delegation to the United Nations, will speak at the seventy-fourth annual dinner of the City College Alumni Association Thurdsay evening. The dinner will be given in the grand ballroom of the Commodore Hotel.
VIENNA, Nov. 27 -- The Austrian Government declined today to participate in the proposed "all-European security conference" in Moscow. The Soviet-sponsored session opens Monday.
MAKING any gardener's dreams come true this Christmas is no idle dream. For never has a more tempting assortment of gardening gifts been available in garden supply and department stores.

PIERRE, S. D., Nov. 27 -- A huge new tunneling machine, which may introduce simpler and less expensive engineering techniques on large construction projects, has been put into operation at the Oahe Dam site near here.

SALVATION ARMY WEEK starts today. This year, for the first time, a White House proclamation will herald the occasion because the Army is about to celebrate its seventy-fifth anniversary in this country. Only the parent organization in England is older.
Investors had much to be thankful for last week. Not only was the stock market strong and at a new high level since 1929, but the flow of bigger year-end dividends gained momentum.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 27 -- President Syngman Rhee suffered his second recent major setback this afternoon when South Korea's National Assembly defeated his strongly sponsored constitutional amendments by a vote of 181 to 179.

Newspaper men from twenty-one states and Canada will convene at Columbia University tomorrow for the opening session of a five-day American Press Institute seminar on newspaper circulation, promotion, organization and operation.
AUGUSTA,, Ga., Nov. 27 -- President Eisenhower was a professed neutral leaning "slightly toward the Army" as he watched the annual Army-Navy football game on television this afternoon.
Vyacheslav Molotov's repeated propositions and warnings in connection with the Paris agreements are intended to prepare the West for a significant new move on the part of the Soviet Union.

If there are no good new plays available to the off-Broadway theatre, as Sylvia Leigh asserted in your section recently, then perhaps the stage unions made a mistake in bending over backward to help this "contributory" branch operate as it does.

Coming down the last stretch of the pre-Boat Show period, nearly every section of the boating industry and nearly every unit in the fraternity of pleasure boating is making plans for the big mecca in New York in January.
An experiment involving early mail deliveries in three Manhattan areas has "proved an outstanding success" and will be continued indefinitely, acting Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer has announced.

IT happens that within a week of the first anniversary of the Berlioz Society there will be given on Dec. 14 a performance of Berlioz' "Damnation of Faust," under the direction of Robert Lawrence. The performance in Carnegie Hall will present that work for the first time in this city in its original scoring.

Alger Hiss returned home yesterday to the modest Greenwich Village apartment he had not seen in almost four years. The group of reporters and photographers awaiting him was increased by a gathering of 100 persons, who looked on with curiosity and silence.

The Citizen's Committee on Children will benefit from the Jan. 12 performance of Henry James' "Portrait of a Lady." The story, dramatized by William Archibald, stars Jennifer Jones, Cathleen Nesbitt and Douglas Watson.

SUCCESS with orchids indoors depends largely on the choice of varieties. Some of them will grow in the house with relatively little trouble; others won't thrive under any but the most exacting conditions.

MAN'S problem of getting about and his dissatisfaction with the status quo have always led him to discover or invent easier and more efficient means of travel. The burden of carrying all his provisions himself led him to find the horse who would labor for him.
ATHENS, Ga., Nov. 27 (AP) -- A 19-yard pass from Wade Mitchell to Henry Hair gave Georgia Tech a 7-3 football victory over Georgia's fierce Bulldogs today.

SPANISH music has been high on recent lists of best-selling records. A number of manufacturers, it seems, have been reading those lists, for in recent months they all have been scrambling to bring out Spanish music, too. Recent Spanish releases form a pile so high that a reviewer can do hardly more than check them off.
BONN, Germany, Nov. 27 -- About 9,400,000 Germans are eligible to vote tomorrow for new State Parliaments (Landtage) in Bavaria and Hesse.

IN "The Living Room," Graham Greene has combined what Richard Watts in The Post describes as a "horror play" with a religious point of view. If it were not for the presence of a benign priest, "The Living Room" might be called "The Fall of the House of Browne."

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Nov. 27 -- The emphasis will be on an expanding economy when Milward L. Simpson, lawyer and business man, takes over as Wyoming's nineteenth Governor Jan. 3. That was the theme of his campaign

NOW in the glowing Indian summer of his fame, it is hard to see in the stout, benign figure on the Government Front Bench the man who moved the world and changed the course of history. The hurrying years, taking first one and then the other old friend or enemy, have left Sir Winston Churchill detached, Olympian above the clamorous times.

The United States today has the largest school enrollment of any nation in the world. A far greater proportion of its youth are attending public elementary and high schools than at any previous time in our history. It used to be that almost everybody went to grade school and now almost everyone goes to high school, too.

The African Research and Studies Program of the Boston University Graduate School is now entering its second year. With the aid of a $200,000 grant by the Ford Foundation, the expansion of basic teaching and research and the accumulation of library source materials will be greatly facilitated during the next five years.
MOSCOW, Sunday, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Pravda make a blistering attack today on Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill of Britain. It accused him of "treachery against his allies."
DAYTON, Ohio, Nov. 27 -- Rural churches in Western Ohio are getting a new lease on life. They're making a remarkable comeback with a new and different program for growing congregations.
Robert Moses, Chairman of the New York State Power Authority, is expected to discuss the impact of the St. Lawrence Power Project on northern New York at a luncheon in Ogdensburg Dec. 15.

AMMAN, Jordan, Nov. 4 -- Black-rock Nabatean towns in East Jordan, waterless and deserted in summer since early Christian times, are coming back to life as water once more pours into their huge Roman-built canals and rock cisterns.
CHAPEL HILL, N. C., Nov. 27 -- Duke exploded for five second-half touchdowns in a display of split-T power today to crush North Carolina, 47 -- 12, before 35,000 fans.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Don Hancock's Driftwood and Mr. and Mrs. Oliver D. Appleton's Mr. O'Malley took commanding leads for two of the Foxchaser championships in the first half of the Boulder Brook Club's thirtieth fall horse show during three sessions today and this evening.
The Near East College Association will be the beneficiary of a performance of "On Your Toes" at the Forty-sixth Street Theatre tomorrow.

EVERY Sunday evening, one of the biggest regular television audiences in the world watches the grumpy, sometimes rude and always shrewd antics of a former policeman-candidate and schoolmaster who has become the biggest star in British television.

The infliction of long prison terms upon thirteen American airmen captured during the hostilities in North Korea is, of course, an insolent and unforgivable affront to the American Government and people. It is only natural that the United States Government should make immediate and emphatic protests through the only available contact with the Chinese Reds at Geneva.
BERLIN, Nov. 27 (AP) -- A leader of the extreme rightist German party has denied charges by West Berlin officials that members of the faction have been guilty of anti-Semitic, Nazi-like activities.

AN improved model of the Simmon Omega D-2 4x5 manual-focusing enlarger was announced last week by Simmon Brothers, Inc., 30-28 Starr Avenue, Long Island City 1, the manufacturers. With condenser head the price is $173.50; with the Omegalite diffusion light source, $164.40.
ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Top-seeded players in both singles divisions were eliminated today in upset-filled semi-final rounds of the national junior and boys' indoor tennis tournament.
The election appears to have had no effect on industrial volume during November, according to a membership survey by the National Association of Purchasing Agents.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 27 -- Charles H. Mahoney, who has had a quarter-century's experience in insurance, is hard at work as a United States delegate these days helping to insure the world.

LONDON. ON these pages is a selection of the ten moments which I would judge to be the most exciting in the long career of Winston Churchill, who celebrates his eightieth birthday this Tuesday. It should he explained at once that this is not the Prime Minister's own list.

NEW ORLEANS, Nov. 27 (UP) -- Win Turner, a sophomore quarterback who played fullback most of the season, threw two touchdown passes to End Joe Tuminello today to lead Louisiana State in a rally that defeated Tulane, 14 to 13.

I HAVE long admired Joseph Gaer for his ability to retell folk stories and religious narratives on either the adult or juvenile level. He has an unfailing knack of entering sympathetically into the tradition in which he is working.
Twenty-three college football teams, headed by Oklahoma and Tennessee State, completed the 1954 season with perfect records, according to The United Press.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Non-farm employment in Illinois declined 6,300 persons in the month ended Oct. 15 to a total of 2,969,400, the State Unemployment Compensation Bureau reported. The Oct. 15 figure was 145,800 below the same date last year.

The current meeting of the National Council for the Social Studies has again pointed to some significant gaps in our secondary education program. The Indianapolis conference was told that perhaps as many as 65 per cent of our high-school students have not had a course in world geography or world history.

Robert Notkoff, 13-year-old violinist, was the soloist yesterday morning at the young people's concert of the Little Orchestra Society at Hunter College Assembly Hall. He played the second and third movements of the Mendelssohn Concerto, which he had played a week earlier when he was soloist at the young people's concert of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony.

Twelve young women were introduced formally to society at dinner parties given in advance of the annual Grosvenor Debutante Ball. The fete, which serves also to raise funds for the Grosvenor Neighborhood House, was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza. Autumn flowers, smilax and palms were used in the decorations.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 27 -The raising of the legal age for marriages among Hindus to 21 for boys and 16 for girls is proposed in the report of the joint select committee on the projcted Hindu marriage and divorce bill.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 27 -- Public officials took steps this week to set up a smog warning system that would avert casualties if this city's intermittent spells of air-pollution reached the danger point.

INDICATIONS are that 20 per cent more plastics will have been used in buildings this year than in 1953. This increase may be multiplied many times in years to come if some of the farseeing experiments currently in the research stage reach fruition.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- It too often has been said that the game is only part of the show when the football teams of Army and Navy get together. Their fifty-fifth annual meeting today had all the usual colorful trappings, plus unusually fine weather.

"To Insure the End of Our Hysteria" excellently stated the climate of fear which has gripped the nation in so alarming a manner. It develops as the reason the terrible disappointment of the country in the aggressive actions of Russia after the war, culminating, as an immediate cause, in the loss of our secrets of nuclear processes to the Communists.

AS one theatregoer who thoroughly enjoyed the London production of Graham Greene's "The Living Room" and who is looking forward to a second visit in New York, I was rather dismayed by the inadequate review of the play in your newspaper.
A new kind of contract for carrying so-called "storage mail" will be put into effect Jan. 1 by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad and the Post Office Department.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 27 -- The United States champion, Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, and Weaver W. Adams of West Orange, the national open champion in 1948, continued their victory strings today in the Eastern States open tournament at the Log Cabin Chess Club.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 27 -- Having turned its back on communism Bolivia's national revolutionary movement is looking to the United States for further help toward a diversified economy.

RICHMOND, Nov. 27 -- Unfavorable weather conditions are blamed by fifth district retailers for a slight tapering off in sales but with Thanksgiving behind them they look forward to an upsurge which leaders believe will set a new high before the Christmas season is over.
TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 28 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida's Liberal party voted today to replace him as party president in a 'maneuver' aimed at easing the stormy opposition to his six-year reign.
A system of low - cost export credit insurance, extending to consumer goods as well as industrial equipment, will be developed in this country within the next two years, it was predicted last week.
"Billy," a 14-year-old homeless street wanderer, was sought by the police yesterday in connection with the death of his 16-year-old friend in the Bronx Friday.

Because of the holiday weekend few buyers were in town, but resident buying offices said they were busy trying keep store stocks level on holiday merchandise. Retailers were especially looking for sportswear, budget dresses, hosiery, women's accessories and jewelry.

OXFORD, Miss., Nov. 27 -- Mississippi, in a period of three minutes, turned two breaks into touchdowns today and hit its greatest football jackpot -- a 14-to-0 victory over Mississippi State, a Sugar Bowl date with Navy and the Southeastern Conference title.

DALLAS, Nov. 27 -- The Christmas shopping season appeared to be under way over most of the Southwest this week and merchants were expecting Christmas volume as good as last year, or better. The usual boom in extra seasonal employment was under way too, with department stores taking on part-time salesmen for the buying season.

DIMITRI SHOSTAKOVICH'S new Tenth Symphony is heard in two recorded performances released almost simultaneously by Columbia and Concert Hall Society. The Columbia performance is by Dimitri Mitropoulos and the New York Philharmonic-Symphony; Concert Hall's version is an imported performance by Eugene Mravinsky and the Leningrad Philharmonic Orchestra.
Robert B. Magnus Jr. has been chosen chairman of the floor committee for the annual Yuletide Ball on Dec. 23 in the ballroom of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.

LEISURELY Saturday breakfasts are becoming a thing of the past for a growing group of Long Islanders. Instead of lingering over cocoa and coffee cups, grownups and youngsters by the dozen hurry off to 9 A. M. Saturday classes at Levittown Memorial High School.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Nov. 27 -- After trailing three times during the game, Notre Dame rallied to beat the Rose Bowl-bound Southern California team, 23 -- 17, on a soggy field today.
The undiminished importance of the United Nation as a platform and an instrument of national policy was emphasized once again last Week by Pierre Mendes-France's speech to the General Assembly.

V. K. Krishna Menon, India's chief delegate to the United Nations, and Gaganvihari L. Mehta, Indian Ambassador to the United States, will join other Indian representatives and American educators in a two-day forum here on India.

I wish I could agree with Mr. Hoffman's opinion that hysteria is receding, but in the light of the news I don't see how I can. I was dismayed to read that officials decided that cadets at West Point and Annapolis could not debate the national collegiate topic in intercollegiate debates -- recognition of Red China.

ALTHOUGH the economic indices fail to show any sharp deviation from their recent flat course, several factors in the business picture appear to complement each other. Despite the lower level of industrial production this year compared with a year ago, buying at the retail level is holding up well.

CRITICISM has been defined by Stephen Spender as "the substitute muse of the universities" and my impression is that this definition has some point in America. Many Americans agree with me. They explain that in each decade since 1931 American writers have been obliged to take up teaching in order to earn their living.
ALBANY, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The State Thruway Authority moved today to avert traffic delays such as were caused by snow on the superhighway last Sunday.

President Eisenhower has rejected Tariff Commission recommendations for import restrictions on two different items, tung oil and spring clothespins. The three Republicans on the commission, led by Chairman Edgar B. Brossard, ruled that imports of the products were threatening the domestic industry with serious injury.
The first part of the Prospect Expressway, from Gowanus Parkway to Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, will be opened at 4 P. M. tomorrow.
HOUSTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- One of the two Triple-A leagues, perhaps both, will undergo a face-lifting during the annual minor league baseball convention here next week.
MANSFIELD, Ohio, Nov. 27 -The United States Air Force will dedicate one of the largest Air Force warehouses in the world next month at the Wilkins Air Force Depot in near-by Shelby, Ohio.

PARIS, Nov. 27 -- Police Inspector Jean Dides, one of the central figures in the investigation into leaks of secret information from the French National Council of Defense, was dismissed today from the police service by the orders of the Ministry of Interior.

ST. LOUIS, Nov. 27 -- A longtime effort to bar segregation in St. Louis threatres, hotels and restaurants, defeated in the current session of the Board of Aldermen, is expected to be revived in the next session of the board.

IN early autumn skies over Hungary, great white flights of storks can be seen moving southward. It is the start of their annual migration to the "warm wild wilderness" of Africa. In spring these storks make their long, perilous return to Europe, to build nests on farmhouse roofs and chimneys, to raise families, and finally to join again the great flight south.

OBSERVERS of the cinema here are remarking anxiously or sadly these days that French motion picture production has fallen sick of "the American malady," by which they mean imitation ad nauseam of past successes.
WASHINGTON, Nov 27 -- President Eisenhower has given top priority in the coming session of Congress to his program for liberalizing foreign trade

ALBANY, Nov. 27 -- The state Department of Commerce believes that the completion of the St. Lawrence Seaway and power projects will create "vast new opportunities for business and industrial growth" in the state.

MINNEAPOLIS, Nov. 27 -- Despite the downward price drift, farm income in Minnesota has kept pace with that in 1953 as the harvesting season drew to a close, the Federal Reserve Bank in Minneapolis reported. The State Federal Crop Reporting Service estimates an increase of 5.5 million bushels in the state's corn crop to 274 million bushels.
A Brooklyn championship company of the Civil Defense Auxiliary Fire Corps won the city-wide finals yesterday in a competition of skill and speed in meeting emergency fire conditions.
QUEBEC, Nov. 27 (Canadian Press) -- The Sunrip, one of the largest ocean-going ships to be built in Canada, sailed from Quebec today on her maiden voyage to Port Esquivel, Jamaica.
President Jose Figueres of Costa Rica said yesterday that an armed plot against his country had failed. He intimated that it was financed from Nicaragua and Venezuela.

A "barometer" to help communities forecast trends of school enrollments has been provided in the form of a report issued by the Metropolitan School Study Council of Teachers College, Columbia University.

THE translation and publication of the Latin American Classics Series, sponsored by UNESCO, means that this organization intends to make amends for the private publishing companies' neglect in this field.
HARTFORD, Nov. 27 -- Gov. John Lodge, Republican, and Gov.-elect Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat, will confer at the State Capitol at 10 A. M. Monday on the transition in the state administration.

The feverish tempo here in New York is often misinterpreted by visitors as callousness and indifference to human needs. Visitors are startled by the subway rush and the fact that many New Yorkers do not know the name of their neighbors next door.

After a slight lull over the Thanksgiving holiday, New York art galleries resume a full schedule of activities with more than thirty new exhibitions this week. A number of them are opening Christmas shows with the holiday bargain-seeker in mind.
WACO, Tex., Nov. 27 -- Dicky Moegle and a strong Rice defense crushed Baylor, 20 -- 14, today and handed the Southwest Conference football championship to Arkansas undisputed.
MOSCOW, Nov. 27 -- Both this year and last the Soviet iron and steel industry has failed to reach goals set by the Government's planners for increasing labor productivity.

HIGHLY unconventional, the Clabo family lived on a highway, locally called "the Pike," in the hills of East Tennessee, catered in a small way to the tourist trade. Lute, the father, was a hell - fire preacher turned atheist.
UNION, N. J., Nov. 27 -- Relocating Newark State Teachers College on the former Green Lane Farm estate here of the late United States Senator Hamilton F. Kean is estimated to cost $3,700,000.

CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- The Juvenile Protective Association of Chicago this week evaluated its experimental program for combating juvenile delinquency. It involves quick agency reference by the police for trivial or first offenders and younger children.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- The lobbying industry has been increasing its outlays in recent months, hoping thereby to get more of a legislative run for its money.

THE prudent reader will take these two books as antidotes for one another. Although they deal with almost identical major problems, it is probable that Mrs. Darnton would turn in dismay from the Hubler child-raising system, and Mr. Hubler would surely have to punish his kids for throwing rocks at the Darnton boys.

A BIG novel of brutal realism and stark drama, "Prisoner in Paradise" is certain to be compared, favorably and unfavorably, with "Arrowsmith" and "Not As a Stranger." It is not a story of legitimate medicine, however, but an expose of the healing cults of Southern California, where the quacks grow faster and bigger than anywhere else.

Fighting off a New York threat in the last quarter the Syracuse Nationals took a firmer hold on second place in the Eastern Division of the National Basketball Association race by turning back the Knickerbockers, 80 to 74, at Madison Square Garden last night.

Behind the walls of the Federal Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., by coincidence last week, the stories of two men reached dramatic climaxes. One was murdered under strange and brutal circumstances. The other was released to pick up the threads of a shattered life.

A 26-year-old ex-convict, who detectives said had been arrested thrice for robbing business establishments while posing as a window washer, was arrested again yesterday and charged with being up to his old trade.

THE McKean family were putting all their hopes in the oil well which Mr. Curtis was going to drill on their farm. The widowed Mrs. McKean needed it to pay off her mortgage, young Thad was wild to learn about prospecting, and 13-year-old Penny (her real name was Pennsylvania) feverishly hoped that Mr. Curtis' daughter Crane would be a permanent friend.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Nov. 27 (AP) -- The Holyoke committee to censure Senator McCarthy announced today its members would refuse to buy or sell Wisconsin products until the voters of that state had removed the Senator.

BRICABRACOMANIACS -- they love to grub through junk shops of a Saturday, or any other day for that matter, searching for the odd, the curious, the fugitive, the toys of yesterday, objects once useful and even commonplace but now rare.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Nov. 27 -Radcliffe College will commemorate its seventy-fifth anniversary next week by breaking a tradition and awarding special citations to eight distinguished alumnae.
BUFFALO, Nov. 27 (AP) -- The November Erie County grand jury recommended yesterday the "establishment of an appropriate curfew" for youths as a means of preventing juvenile delinquency.

The only thing Coach Ed Danowski's Rams hit yesterday at the Polo Grounds was a new low, as Fordham's poorest football season since 1946 ended with 41-0 setback by Villanova. For, when the hornless and hapless Rams failed to score, it was the first time in forty-seven straight games over a five-year span that they had not tallied.

IT is a challenge to try orchids as house plants: and tle beginning amateur needs only to understand the basic needs of the plants to enjoy a reasonable amount of success, The necessary information may be considered under five topics: light, moisture, temperature, air and nutrients; a sixth might be the proper varieties.

Handsome and intricately crafted French period furniture in an important collection of cabinetwork, works of art and fine oriental rugs will be auctioned on Thursday, Friday and Saturday at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Seventy manufacturers of automatic measurement and control systems and associated equipment will exhibit their devices for control of plant operations at the First International Automation Exposition opening here tomorrow.
PIQUA, Ohio, Nov. 27 -- A neglected farm two miles north of this city may soon become a state park.
PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 27 -- The United States was outvoted by all the Latin American states today on a Cuban resolution to consider creating an inter-American fund.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Sotto Voce, generally regarded as a sprinter, came from off the pace in the mile-and-a-sixteenth Barbara Frietchie Handicap today to gain a length victory over Mlle. Lorette.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Nov. 27 -- More than 1,600 persons from Long Island and New York attended the fifth annual Thanksgiving Ball tonight in O'Hara Hall of the United States Merchant Marine Academy, many of them coming from dinner parties in nearby country houses.
WESTMINSTER, Md., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Mr. Chambers, formerly a senior editor of Time magazine, is now living in retirement on a farm near here, recovering from a heart ailment.

IT is good news that Chicago had an opera company of its own month. Even if the season was short, it was evidently exciting. If it stimulatess our second largest city to go on and build a permanent company, it will be a wonderful advance for the cause of the lyric theatre in America.

THE growing infiltration of oriental art in American painting, particularly in the abstract field, has been repeatedly commented on in the last decade. This week, by sheer coincidence in the crowded art calendar, no less than eight exhibitions are current of work by oriental artists.

LES McCOIN, almost 13 and absorbed in tennis lessons at the French Lick Country Club, never questioned his grandmother's grade list for nice people in Nashville. "Gamma," a Quintard who married a DeWitt, worked on the generally accepted Middle Tennessee principle that old families with money are very nice people; old families with no money but with ante-bellum standards are fine old Nashville family; kin from out of town are lovely people and well connected.
ROME, Nov. 27 -- The health of Pope Pius XII took a turn for the worse today after a restless night. He was troubled at intervals during the night by fits of hiccuping and vomiting.

With the aid of a $20,000 grant from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education, Stanford University is to investigate important problems of undergraduate education looking toward further improvement of the university's program.
Retailers are getting a pleasant present from Santa this year, an extra shopping day in the heavy selling period between Thanksgiving and Christmas Day.
Many persons of prominence have subscribed to the annual Bagby Concert to be given tomorrow afternoon at 2:30 o'clock in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 -- Fundamental changes in the Administration's foreign-aid policy are now taking shape.

WITH two performances today, the Ballets Espagnol's Teresa and Luisillo will close a four-week engagement at the Mark Hellinger Theatre. On Monday they will open a four-month tour with a performance in Philadelphia.

The weather early this week was better than in the same week a year ago, enabling stores to take a good sales lead for the first three days. Temperatures higher than in 1953 on Friday and yesterday resulted in some reduction of this gain.
Herbert Hoover arrived at Idlewild Airport yesterday after a six-day trip to West Germany.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -Senator A. S. Mike Monroney predicted today that the top objective of Democrats in the Eighty-fourth Congress would be to repeal President Eisenhower's flexible farm support program and restore rigid, high-level farm price props.

INDIANAPOLIS, Nov. 27 -- Schools are neglecting one of the nation's greatest human resources by failing to provide adequate educational programs for gifted children, the National Council for the Social Studies was told today.
JACKSON, Mich., Nov. 27 -- A pilot program to attempt to reach and treat the alcoholic before he has become a family or state liability is under way here as a joint city and state project.

WHEN Fred Cherrill was a boy in Dorchester his favorite reading matter was the weekly exploits of Sexton Blake, those hack-written vulgarizations of Sherlock Holmes which were the closest equivalent, in Edwardian England, to America's dime novels.

The effects of automatic manufacturing processes, a guaranteed annual wage, and the Taft-Hartley Law will be discussed at the fifty-ninth annual Congress of American Industry at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel Dec. 1-3.
A new type of competition is beginning to put the "squeeze" on the frozen concentrate and canned orange juice business.

AS someone aptly expressed it, "gardening knows no season" for the true enthusiast. When cold weather calls a halt to outdoor accomplishments, he can merely transfer his interest and effort indoors. For the gardener's activity, and the pleasure he derives from his hobby, are not necessarily confined to planning, planting and maintaining flowers, vegetables, lawn and shrubs.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 27 (AP) -- Georgetown maintained its narrow lead in the eleven-team Mark Pimme Angsten Memorial trophy race today with a two-day total of 148 points. Its nearest rival, Syracuse, had 146.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Nov. 27 -- Christmas shopping was on in earnest this week and sales for the abbreviated week set a new peak for the year as a result of the big turnout yesterday and today. Dollar volume was modestly ahead of a year ago and markedly improved over the previous week.
ALBANY, Calif., Nov. 27 (UP) -- Golden Abbey, with Jackie Westrope riding, collared the odds-on favorite, Imbros, in the stretch today to win the $16,300 Golden Gate Mile at Golden Gate Fields.

A BAND LEADER who is one of America's best-known entertainers was explaining himself before the House Committee on Un-American Activities. "I have never been politically minded," he said. "I mean, I have joined organizations which had to do with words like democracy and peace.

The Erasmus Hall football team, a non-winner in seven previous starts, wound up its season yesterday with a 33-6 rout of Manual Training at Tilden Field, Brooklyn. Erasmus now has won five straight in the 53-year-old series and holds a 22-17 margin in victories with eight games tied.

DR. PEALE'S "The Power of Positive Thinking" has been on the best-seller list for more than 100 weeks and sold close to 1,000,000 copies. Now the author has published a revised version for young readers, with new material and a teen-age angle.

STILLWATER, Okla. Nov. 27 -- The Oklahoma Aggies, not given a chance to stay in the same stadium with the powerhouse Oklahoma eleven, threw up an amazing defense against the Sooners before going down to the nation's No. 3 team by 14 -- 0 today.

MILWAUKEE, Nov. 27 -- Although there is very little visible interest here in the McCarthy censure hearings, it would be wrong to assume that the subject of McCarthy has been forgotten in the controversial Senator's home state.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Nov. 27 -- The expansion of grassland agriculture in the South has brought greater stability to the region's farm economy because of the increased need for mechanical equipment, fertilizers, new plant seeds and chemicals for insect and weed control.

CONSTRUCTION of a luxury residential and tourist club development ten miles from Nassau was announced last week. The first big development on the south shore of New Providence Island in Bahamas, the project is an ambitious one with plans for clubs, other buildings and home sites.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Nov. 13 -- The British in the administration of this island colony, those in business, and those here for pleasure, altogether amount to less than 1 per cent of the population, which numbers about 500,000.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Offers of Federal Government financial aid for the United States Olympic team have been rejected, the Amateur Athletic Union was told today at its annual convention.
BATTISTINI RECITAL: Arias from Otello, L'Africana, Il Trovatore, Hamlet, etc., sung by Mattia Battistini, baritone (Eterna). Collectors re-issue of acoustic disks.

NOW that Thanksgiving is past, a lot of hunters can stop thinking about roast turkey and give some attention to the game they have or will have, and how it should be treated immediately after it is shot as well as just before it is eaten.

PAWTUCKET, R. I., Nov. 27 (AP) -- Royca, a French-bred filly owned by J. M. Schiff, won the richest race of her brief career today as she came from far back to win the $15,000-added Jeanne d'Arc Stakes at Narragansett Park.
The forty-third annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens next Sunday.

ONE of the really whizz-bang selling novelists in America is Frank Yerby. When we learned he was coming out with a new one, "Benton's Row," we decided to talk to his publisher, Dial Press, and find out what we could.

WHAT is the function and purpose of the TV-Radio Workshop of the Ford Foundation? The question arises again with the continuance of the aimless policy of the foundation's program "Omnibus," now in its third season on the C. B. S. network (5 P. M., Sundays).
CLEMSON, S. C., Nov. 27 (UP) -- A blocked punt late in the first quarter paved the way for a Clemson touchdown today and the Tigers rolled to a 59-to-0 victory over The Citadel before 1,500 fans.

TOKYO, Nov. 27 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida agreed today with the recommendation of his leading advisers that he should resign from the presidency of the Liberal party, Japan's largest conservative political group.

A large subscription has been reported for the theatre party on Dec. 14 for the benefit of Berkshire Industrial Farm. The party is being sponsored by Chapter One, an auxiliary group affiliated with the farm. Noel Coward's new play, "Quadrille," at the Coronet Theatre has been taken over for the evening.

ANY historical novelist pressed for a narrative line and a set of characters may relax and get to work, now that the Marslands have told the story of Venezuela in English. For their book is full of action, studded with melodrama and peopled with authentic heroes, beauties and villains.

THERE has been nobody quite like Mustapha Kemal Ataturk in this or any century -- a demonic mixture of Attila, Patrick Henry, Machiavelli, John L. Sullivan, Henry VIII, Martin Luther, Justinian, Noah Webster, George Washington, John Dewey and Ivan the Terrible.
CHICAGO, Nov. 27 -- Chicago policemen have presented their case for a forty-hour work week before a special session of the City Council Finance Committee.

THE months of Lenin's last illness and the first months following his death, on Jan. 21, 1924, were crucial for Soviet policies in many fields, and especially for the struggle to seize control of the rapidly hardening apparatus of party dictatorship.

Both the technical aspects and the professional justification for face-lifting, a subject rarely brought up at scientific meetings, were the subject of a panel discussion at the opening session of the American Society of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at the Hollywood Beach Hotel, Fla. Drs. Gustave Aufricht, Albert D. Davis and James B. Johnson told 200 plastic surgeons that patients for a face-lift operation must be chosen with care.

BOSTON, Nov. 27 -- A series of committee meetings today set the stage for the week-long third General Assembly of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. The first general session will be held tomorrow evening in Symphony Hall.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 27 -- With steel mills accelerating production, ore consumption climbed from 4,619,843 tons in September to 5,398,398 tons in October for a gain of 778,555 tons, according to the Lake Superior Iron Ore Association.
