The Middle Collegiate Church will hold a Christmas Bazaar Dec. 2 from 7 to 10 P. M., and on Dec. 3 from 2 to 10 P. M. at the Church House, 50 East Seventh Street. Mrs. George F. Schmidt is executive chairman of the bazaar.

Just how much good our "unusually strong" note about the imprisonment of Americans by Red China will do in Peiping is problematical. It may do some good elsewhere. It may do some good, for example, in Great Britain, since the British are willingly transmitting the protest and have associated themselves with its tone.
Navy defeated Army, 27 -- 20, in a thriller at Philadelphia yesterday and accepted an invitation to play Mississippi in the New Orleans Sugar Bowl on Jan. 1. Scores of major games:

GREENSBORO, N. C. -- Autumn shares with early summer the distinction of being the best time of the year to visit Guilford Courthouse National Military Park, only a few miles north of here on U. S. 220.

With dramatic suddenness the focus of the free world's concern in the "cold war" shifted last week from Moscow to Peiping. Accompanying this shift was a new effort on the part of Western diplomats and intelligence officials to evaluate the capabilities of Communist China and its ability to achieve both its present objectives and its longer-run goals for the future.

UNUSUAL and attractive arrangements for coffee tables, mantels or similar likely spots can be had with small trays of assorted foliage plants. Most of these plants are easily cared for and boast unlimited possibilities in forms and shades of green.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 27 (AP) -- On the big table in the conference room of the National Labor Relations Board is a small crystal ball. Members of the five-man board assure visitors that it is just a paper weight. They deny that they consult it in reaching decisions.

TOKYO, Sunday, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The Chinese Communists today rejected the United States demand for the release of thirteen Americans jailed on trumped up spy charges. The Communists' Peiping radio denounced the American demand as "hysterical outbursts and denials."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Nov. 27 -- Mexico suggested today that the United Nations General Assembly issue a "cordial exhortation" to Indonesia and the Netherlands to work for a solution of their dispute over West New Guinea. The Pacific territory is ruled by the Netherlands but claimed by Indonesia.

One of the fine miniature poodles of Mrs. Marguerite Tyson of Washington, this one an American-bred, became best in show last night in the 666-dog event of the Queensboro Kennel Club at the 104th Field Artillery Armory in Jamaica.

Professor Lawrence Podell's solemn analysis of why old grads enjoy themselves at football and other college games -- "Old Grads: Regression, Projection or What?" (Nov. 14) -- irritated me sufficiently to improvise the following bit of doggerel which represents my summary of Dr. Podell's views, and which may be harmonized to that Old Grad's tune, "I'm a Ramblin' Wreck From Georgia Tech."
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 27 -- The two top offensive teams of college football played each other today in a riotous scoring duel that ended with Navy the victor over favored Army by 27 -- 20.

A Police Department field headquarters will be established tomorrow night at the southwest corner of Fiftieth Street and Eighth Avenue for the rally of the pro-McCarthy group called Ten Million Americans Mobilizing for Justice.

DR. WALTHER HEERING'S "The Rollei Book" (Seebruck am Chiemsee, Germany: Heering-Verlag: Philadelphia: Rayelle Publications, $6.50), for years the standard manual on the Rollei twin-lens reflex cameras, has just been published in a revised sixth edition.

Nine persons were taken to St. Vincent's Hospital last night for examination of injuries suffered when a bus and a private automobile collided at the corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifteenth Street. Two of the injured suffered cuts and their condition was tentatively listed as serious.
New York's citizens have traditionally been men and women who wished to provide for themselves in their own way to meet their own needs.

With a crowd of more than 40,000 anticipated if the weather is fair, the New York Giants will meet the Cleveland Browns at the Polo Grounds today in the top attraction of a five-game National Football League program. The kick-off time is 2:05 P. M.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 27 (Reuters) -- Two left-handed batsmen today shattered English bowling to give Australia the impressive first innings' total of 503 for six on the second day of the first cricket test against England.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, said today the decision against West Point and Annapolis cadets debating the Red China issue was "indicative of the low estate" to which freedom of expression had fallen.
Twenty-two counties comprising the New York metropolitan area will gain 4,145,000 in population in the next twenty years, but only 14 per cent of the increase will be in New York City.
The comments of Thomas Jefferson Miley in The Times of Nov. 15 may lead some of your readers to wrong conclusions about New York State's unemployment insurance program.
Many residents of New York pay their hospital bills in full, through insurance or directly.

LEBANON, Conn., Nov. 29 -- The steeple of the Congregational Meeting House on the green here was dedicated today as a memorial to William Williams, one of the Connecticut signers of the Declaration of Independence.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Communist China rejected today a United States note protesting the imprisonment of thirteen Americans as spies. The speedy turndown left Wash ington officials studying possible next moves.
LONDON, Nov. 28 -- The Government's u734,000,000 debt conversion operation, which has been rather anxiously awaited for some time past, has come at last.

ATLANTA, Nov. 28 -- The twenty-eighth annual winter national bridge championships opened at the Atlanta Biltmore Hotel here this afternoon with 260 contract bridge players competing in the two-session national open individual championship.

LONDON, Nov. 28 -- After standing by throughout the night in a gale that at times exceeded sixty miles an hour, an Irish lifeboat rescued this morning the captain and six members of the crew of a tanker that broke in two in the Irish Sea yesterday.

This morning in Moscow the stage is set for the beginning of a puppet show thinly disguised as an international conference. Two weeks ago, it will be recalled, the Soviet Union called for an all-European conference on mutual security, a conference whose objective was bluntly stated to be the prevention of the ratification of the Paris agreements for Western military unity and the rearmament of Germany.

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" were staged for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House Saturday evening. If musical merit were in direct relation to decibels of sound produced, the performance would have ranked among the marvels of the age.
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., called on Governor-elect Averell Harriman yesterday to make an immediate start toward getting legislation to abolish the Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A new installment of Harold L. Ickes' secret diary says President Franklin D. Roosevelt once intended to ask the Vatican "indirectly to put Bishop Bernard J. Sheil at the head of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Chicago."
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 28 -- The Screen Directors Guild of America and the Association of Motion Picture Producers announced for release tomorrow terms of a new three-year contract.

LIMA, Peru, Nov. 28 (AP) -- A Peruvian court has ordered Pan American-Grace Airways (Panagra) to pay an exiled former Mayor of Guayaquil, Ecuador, 250,000 sols ($12,500) for failure to honor his ticket for a flight from Lima to Guayaquil Sept. 12, 1953.
CINCINNATI, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Irked by restrictions imposed by the Hamilton County Board of Election, the handwriting expert hired by Senator Thomas A. Burke resigned today.

DIGNE, France, Nov. 28 -- Gaston Dominici, the 77-year-old domineering and suspicious patriarch of an isolated Alpine community near here, was condemned to death today. He was judged solely responsible for the murder of a British couple and their daughter who camped for the night near the Dominici farm two and a half years ago.

BABYLON, L. I., Nov. 28 -- The first three miles of the Sunken Meadow State Parkway, a new link between the Northern State Parkway and Sunken Meadow State Park, has been completed and is ready for traffic.

American Airlines' fleet of DC-7's completed one year of operations last night. The four-engine airliners began coast-to-coast non-stop flights on Nov. 29, 1953. They are now being operated on four daily non-stop, round-trip schedules between New York and Washington and the West Coast, as well as on other routes.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Gordon McKenzie, 27-year-old civil engineer, today upset Browning Ross to win the senior National Amateur Athletic Union 10,000-meter cross country championship in Fairmount Park.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 28 (UP) -- The president of the American College of Chest Physicians said today specialists did not know what caused lung cancer and had refrained from blaming cigarettes "or any other specific agent."

THE Metropolitan Opera will stage eight different performances this week and George Cehanovsky, baritone, will appear in four. He finds this not unusual. He has often exceeded that record in the twenty-eight years he has been with the Met, singing character roles.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- A new phase of the wage dispute in France has commenced. After the Government's action in revising the lower wage scales on October 11, negotiations have begun between employers and workers for agreements on the medium and higher wage levels.
Ship chartering continued in good volume last week with the rates still moving forward but at a slower pace than in the last few months.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Ambassadors of the United States, Britain and France in Moscow will deliver tomorrow similar notes to the Kremlin rejecting the Soviet invitations to a Big Four foreign ministers' conference and a conference on European security.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Patrick Eugene McDermott, 55 years old, who shot and killed a vice-crusading Canton editor in 1926, walked away from an honor dormitory at Ohio Penitentiary here this afternoon in the company of a woman who had been visiting him.

YESTERDAY'S production of "Macbeth," starring Maurice Evans and Judith Anderson, was two hours of television theatre at once extremely interesting yet, to this corner at least, strangely disappointing. By video's standards it was assuredly an event not to have been missed, but it also seemed a "Macbeth" regrettably often out of joint.

A scholarship fund in memory of Anne O'Hare McCormick, a member of the editorial board and a columnist of The New York Times until her death last spring, was announced yesterday by the New York Newspaper Women's Club, of which she had been a vice president.

Ward French and Robert Ferguson, who were ousted on Nov. 15 from the top-ranking jobs of Community Concerts, Inc., have formed a new concert bureau of their own, the International Concert Service. Its headquarters are at the Madison Hotel, and it will compete with their old concern in the organized audience field.

The American Jewish Congress charged yesterday that Austria's behavior in its negotiations for the settlement of claims of Jewish victims of Nazi persecution had "raised grave doubts" as to the Austrian Government's "moral capacity to qualify it for equality in the family of free nations."

Last year I was naive enough to give an order to a mail-order house for several things for Christmas gifts. This year they sent me five identical catalogues. In addition to that they must have placed my name on a list. Catalogues began to arrive in late September and they are still coming, two, three or four identical ones from each house.
An example of the contributions by American enterprises to economic progress in underdeveloped nations is the subject of a report being issued today by the National Planning Association.
When fairy tales and lullabies fail to triumph over television, cuddle toys and appealing night-wear may help lead reluctant sleepyheads to bed.

Two more R's -- for responsibility and religion -- should be added to education's traditional reading, 'riting and 'rithmetic, high school students on The New York Times Youth Forum suggested yesterday.
Howard S. Cullman said yesterday that elimination of certain charges by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad would help the port meet competition that had grown out of rate discriminations.
FAIR LAWN, N. J., Nov. 28 -Three business houses received summonses for staying open today as Fair Lawn put into effect its new Sunday-closing ordinance. All other businesses obeyed the regulation.

There is reason strongly to commend President Eisenhower's action in the appointment of a special Cabinet committee to spearhead a new attack in the war on the narcotics traffic. There has been no reason to be complacent about this social menace. It is doubtful that, in spite of our best efforts, we are even holding our own.
I want to commend The Times for the excellent editorial entitled "Aliens' Entry" and Pearl Buck for her letter referred to therein.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Two brothers jointly named today as the nation's corn kings at the International Livestock Exposition later lost the title when grain show officials disqualified them.

The first regular train passed over the new Harlem River drawbridge of the New York Central Railroad at 10:30 o'clock yesterday morning. The train was nothing special, just a locomotive and four passenger cars running from Croton-on-Hudson into Grand Central Terminal. The crossing was made at a careful ten miles an hour.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- The skepticism of Germany's middle class and skilled workers on the long-term value of any German or other European government's money came to the fore in the conflict last week over the corporation tax.
The tactics of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy were assailed from a Brooklyn pulpit yesterday as constituting "a real subversion."

Some day men may be able to control the weather. Now they are sometimes, not always, able to predict it. The storm that has been sweeping the British Isles released an energy beyond anything that humanity could produce or restrain -- unless it is the energy contained within an H-bomb.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Nov. 28 -- On the subject of the sudden weakening of the official rate for sterling in London to $2.79 last week, the lowest point in two years, spokesmen of the Swiss banks had this to say:

A study of scientific education and the caliber of scientists in the Soviet Union will be undertaken by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology under one of several grants announced yesterday by the Carnegie Corporation of New York.

MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- A pledge that if the West did not attack the Soviet Union, the Soviet Union would not attack the West was given over a glass of wine tonight by Maxim Z. Saburov, a Soviet Deputy Premier.
MOSCOW, Nov. 28 -- Premier Georgi M. Malenkov and Foreign Minister Vyacheslav M. Molotov confirmed tonight that the conference on European security sponsored by the Soviet Union would begin tomorrow.

Does the Santa Claus myth harm youngsters? The answer is "No," according to some childcare specialists. Their views appear in the latest issue of "The Two-to-Five World," a monthly newsletter for parents of pre-school children.

We can't say that we enjoy saying good-by to our good friends. We are sorry to have to note the departure of Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress, who has been for two years commanding general of the First Army. In that capacity he has been our neighbor and our fellow-citizen.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 -- While most of the larger steel buyers show no signs of increasing their inventories, many smaller ones are said to be concerned over legthening steel delivery dates. This is no surprise to observers here who have for months been predicting that many users' inventories had been cut too low.
Operation 25, which put 250 more policemen into East Harlem, reduced major crime there "almost 50 per cent" in ten weeks, Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday.

EVERY autumn as Christmas approaches the seasonal gift books pile high in brightly colored drifts in the "Books-of-The-Times" office. Many of these are devoted to subjects of special interest -- cookery, antiques, interior decoration, horses, sports, art -- and are handsome examples of bookmaking, ideal gifts when the subject matches the recipient's taste.
NOME, Alaska, Nov. 28 (Reuters) -- A new highway that would permit American motorists to drive almost within sight of Siberia is in prospect.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Trucking interests declared today that the railroads of this country were distorting facts and corrupting public officials in an effort to kill the trucking industry.
Colombia, a South American nation now stirring with new economic growth, has recently taken the first official step toward adapting United States techniques for regional development.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The choice of a new Democratic National Chairman appeared today to be narrowing rapidly to a field of three -- Paul Butler of Indiana, James Finnegan of Pennsylvania and Michael V. DiSallo of Ohio.
After a poor start, cotton futures prices strengthened in the latter days of the week and close firm, the New York Cotton Exchange reported yesterday.

Russel Wright, the industrial designer, went back to elementary school to do research for his newest designs. The result of Mr. Wright's eighteen months of study in classrooms in many cities is a new collection of school room furniture.

The Rev. Dr. Robert J. McCracken criticized yesterday persons who "sedulously cultivate" the pursuit of health into a disease, influence into a fetish, success into an end in itself or happiness into a frustrated striving.

A strong appeal to the United States Government to stop sending arms to Arab states was made yesterday by top Zionist leaders. This country also was urged to exercise its influence in establishing a permanent peace between Israel and the Arab states to thwart Communist aggression.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 28 -- A recent American trend in Roman Catholic architecture -- the swing from Gothic and Romanesque design to Georgian colonial simplicity -- was displayed here today at the dedication of Our Lady of Loretto Church.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 28 (AP) -- The police dispersed a crowd that gathered today before the palace of Cardinal Santiago Luis Copello to chant their loyalty to the Roman Catholic Church in its controversy with President Juan D. Peron.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Adrian Burk, who appears the world's greatest quarterback when exposed to Washington uniforms, pitched five touchdown passes today to lead the Philadelphia Eagles to a 41-33 victory over the Redskins in a National Football League game.
Mayor Wagner will present the city's Scroll for Distinguished Public Service to Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria at noon Wednesday at City Hall.

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- The satellite security conference commencing in Moscow tomorrow may lead to the creation of a Soviet Treaty Organization from the hodgepodge of bilateral military pacts now linking the Communist states of eastern and central Europe. This might presumably be for the purpose of serving as counterpoise and antipode to NATO.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The Government now plans to station permanently and as soon as possible specially trained skeleton forces in some thirty-five secret headquarters outside the capital to take over executive operations in an emergency.
Mrs. Bernice P. Rogers, Deputy Commissioner of Housing, listed yesterday fifteen conditions in multiple dwellings that she considered hazardous.

Christmas must be coming earlier than usual this year. For a month now the postman has staggered under great loads of gift catalogues, and each time the bell rings twice the house-hold is thrown into further unrest.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Nov. 28 -- Because of recent wage increases, the stock market boom and forthcoming tax reductions, Christmas spending in the Netherlands is likely to be heavy.
Tony Trabert and Maureen Connolly head the combined world rankings compiled by tennis writers of England, France, the United States, Australia, Italy and South Africa.

Addressing the Inter-American Economic Conference in Brazil last week, Secretary of the Treasury George M. Humphrey indicated that the Administration was considering new tax concessions to stimulate overseas private investment.

SEOUL, Korea, Monday, Nov. 29 -- The supporters of President Syngman Rhee in the National Assembly pushed through a ruling today that a constitutional amendment permitting the 79-year-old President to run for more than two terms had been adopted contrary to an earlier announcement.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 28 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru today made a scathing attack on the Indian Communist party. He said that, although the party had been trying to work under the democratic Constitution for the last four years it had not "repudiated its plan of organizing insurrection in the country."

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Dolph Schayes, limping because of an injured heel, sank a driving lay-up with twenty-seven seconds left to play as the Syracuse Nationals came from behind to beat the New York Knickerbockers for the second straight night in a National Basketball Association game, 79 -- 77, tonight.
Two films are scheduled to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:

The man who may justly be termed the Columbus of the atomic era passed from our midst yesterday when Enrico Fermi suffered his untimely death. His brilliant work in helping to unravel the secrets of the atomic nucleus has assured his name of immortality in the history of humanity, as well as in the history of science.
LONDON, Nov. 25 -- Sir Winston Churchill and the people of Britain will celebrate the Prime Minister's eightieth birthday this week just when he finds himself in the midst of a violent political row.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- Memorial High was held scoreless until the final period by Archbishop Stepinac of White Plains at Memorial Field today. Then, with one sudden burst, the West New York (N. J.) eleven scored a touchdown and was off to its twentieth straight triumph, 9 -- 0.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks said yesterday that he was more confident of business expansion in the first six months of 1955 than he had been about any other half-year period since assuming office in January, 1953.

Soldiers and sailors and hundreds of thousands of persons who made out their own travel orders streamed into and out of the city in close-packed array yesterday. The Thanksgiving Day week-end ended with its traditional traffic congestion.

Negotiations for sale of the Diamond Match Company's Plattsburg, N. Y., paper mill are part of a company program looking toward more effective integration of wood fiber processing from controlled sources of timber, Robert G. Fairburn, president, said over the week-end.
MILTON, Mass., Nov. 28 -- A conversation with Louis Andrews, wrestling coach at Milton Academy, can switch to unexpected channels.
The Civil Aeronautics Board is expected to act this week on a procedural question that threatens to put out of business the eleventh largest air carrier in the country.
Sponsors of the campaign for 10,000,000 signatures opposing the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarty of Wisconsin announced last night the program for their rally at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Commissioner Adams' impressive report yesterday on the results of Operation 25 in East Harlem, an experiment in "saturation policing," should convince any doubters that it pays off to have more policemen on the streets. It is one more piece of evidence that New York City needs a considerably larger police force, of a strength of 25,000 men at least, and probably more.
The text of Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams' broadcast yesterday over WRCA radio and television stations and over WNYC follows:

A steady stream of offerings of British sterling every day of last week knocked that unit off to $2.78 15/15, lowest since October, 1952. Week's highest was $2.79 5/16, and Friday's final of $2.78 31/32 recorded a loss of 11/32 cent from the preceding week. Forwards were similarly affected.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Public Safety Commissioner Edward W. Roos today blamed superior officers in the Police Department for "errors of judgment" in failing to make public the news of a recent jewel theft.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- A new censure count against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was made public today a few hours after the Wisconsin Republican had left the Naval Hospital at near-by Bethesda, Md.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- One of the most wide-open practices in Congress is the use of the Congressional franking privilege by members.
ANNAPOLIS, Nov. 28 (AP) -Navy's football heroes returned today from their 27-20 victory over Army and got a roaring welcome from classmates and townspeople.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 28 -- In opening here today the largest convention in its history, the Investment Bankers Association of America indicated that it would sidestep the biggest question before the securities industry.

Two highly professional Dixieland jazz bands, the Tigertown Five of Princeton University and the Spring Street Stompers of Williams College, made what was freely announced as history at Carnegie Hall in the early hours of yesterday morning.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 28 -- Vigorous agitation has appeared here for a militia defense force on the Swiss pattern instead of the usual type of army desired by the North Atlantic Treaty Organization command.

The Composers Forum presented its second concert of the season Saturday night at the Mc-Millin Theatre of Columbia University. The composers whose works were performed and who were present to answer questions were Alfonso Montecino of Chile, who has been working in this country since 1947, and Gunther Schuller, a horn player in the orchestra of the Metropolitan Opera.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears held the Los Angeles Rams without a touchdown for the last fifty-seven minutes today to gain a 24-to-13 victory and climb to second place in the Western Conference race in the National Football League.

PITTSBURGH, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Nick Bolkovac, a tackle dropped by Pittsburgh early in the season and then recalled, kicked a 26-yard field goal mid-way in the last period today to give the Steelers a 20-17 victory over the Chicago Cardinals.
NORFOLK, Va., Nov. 28 -- The Coast Guard was preparing tonight to begin an air search for Mrs. Ann Davison, first woman to cross the Atlantic alone in a small boat.

HOUSTON, Nov. 28 -- Efforts on the part of the Yankees to find a home for their Kansas City American Association franchise had top billing today as baseball moved into its annual minor league convention.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Thurgood Marshall, who led the successful legal fight against public school segregation, said today that "any efforts to perpetuate segregation will have to be answered in the courts."

Showing much improvement over their recent performances, the New York Rangers battered the Canadiens of Montreal into submission in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Muzz Patrick's skaters carried the action to the Habitants all through the contest, and in so doing they scored enough to win by the count of 4 to 1.

Rachel Crothers, whose twenty-eight plays -- produced between 1903 and 1937 -- earned her the title of Broadway's most prolific woman writer, is about to break a seventeen-year silence with a new comedy of manners. Called "We Happy Few," it will be presented later this season by Albert Lewis and I. B. Joselow.

Fifty youngsters dedicated a tree yesterday in East Sixty-second Street in honor of the fiftieth anniversary of Dr. Jonah B. Wise in the ministry. Dr. Wise, son of the late Isaac M. Wise, the founder of American Reform Judaism, is the spiritual director of the Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at Fifty-fifth Street.

BALTIMORE, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Gary Kerkorian and Royce Womble teamed up on a 78-yard pass play in the dying moments today for the touchdown which enabled the Baltimore Colts to gain a 17-13 National Football League victory over the San Francisco Forty-Niners.

Two buildings at 187 and 189-91 Broadway, southwest corner of Dey Street, have been sold by the Oceanic Investing Company to Aaron Levine for investment. The buyer said he planned eventually to add four stories to the two-story structure on the corner.
TULSA, Okla., Nov. 28 (AP) -Mrs. Nannie Doss, a 49-year-old grandmother, tonight admitted poisoning four of her five husbands, County Attorney J. Howard Edmondson said.

WEST POINT was flooded with propaganda leaflets last week, Enemy agents from Annapolis, infiltrating behind the lines, craftily delivered paper slips which were not unlike the safe passage guarantees offered surrendering soldiers in a real war.

This week, with reclassification hearings on legal, parole and probation services, the Board of Estimate will go into Round Two of a bout with the civil service problem that will continue into next summer. The first hearing last week involved engineering and architectural employes.

Elizabeth Schwarzkopf, German soprano who earlier this season drew a capacity audience to the Hunter College Auditorium, attracted another capacity audience late yesterday afternoon to Town Hall. She appeared there under the auspices of the Concert Society of New York, which also sponsored her local debut last season.
Gross operating income and net income of the Arkansas Fuel Oil Corporation increased in the quarter and nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported over the week-end.
Fifteen hundred Brooklyn dock workers from Local 1814 of the International Longshoremen's Association attended yesterday a solemn high mass for longshoremen who have died.

ROME, Nov. 28 -- After appearing for a few minutes at the window of his study in the Vatican Palace in reply to the cheers of a crowd in St. Peter's Square, Pope Plus XII took to his bed this morning for what is feared may be a long illness.

The dinner party hostess who must do her own cooking usually does not have much time to spend on the incidental but often important hors d'oeuvres. Ready-to-serve snacks to accompany cocktails are a popular answer to this problem.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Nov. 27 -- Horace Greeley would have been a wrong-way Corrigan in Bolivia, where the Government's slogan is "Go East."

HAWTHORNE, Nev., Nov. 28 (AP) -- Democratic Senator-elect Alan Bible said today that he would take his seat in the Senate within a few days to "get every bit of seniority that I possibly can." A few days ago the 45-year-old Reno attorney said he would wait until the special session considering censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had ended.

Two attacking forces with a consuming urge to flatten anything in their way took turns flaying each other while 100,000 persons -- Cabinet members, admirals and generals among them -- carried on like crazy. That was the fifty-fifth Army Navy football game, a double stampede that twenty-four hours later still was disturbing the quiet of Philadelphia's sabbath.

An American edition of "Raft of Despair," by Ensio Tiira, a story of human endurance, is planned for Jan. 10 publication by Dutton. On Feb. 23, 1953, the author, a Finn, was bound for Indochina as a member of the French Foreign Legion.
FUJIYAMA, Japan, Monday, Nov. 29 (AP) -- A two-pronged avalanche swept thirty-nine university students down the majestic slopes of Fujiyama [cross on map] Sunday.

A home-made time bomb exploded at 6:15 o'clock last night in a telephone booth at the Port Authority Bus Terminal, Eighth Avenue and Fortieth Street. The terminal was thronged with hundreds of week-end commuters, but no one was injured.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Nov. 28 -- Four Jordanians were killed and two wounded this morning in a clash with a unit of the Israeli police frontier force in the Judean Hills southeast of Jerusalem. There were no Israeli casualties in the engagement, which lasted twenty minutes.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 28 (UP) U. C. L. A.'s undefeated and untied team broke three Pacific Coast Conference and nine school records during the 1954 football season, records showed today.
BONN, Germany, Monday, Nov. 29 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer and the Social Democratic opposition fought to a draw yesterday in the first election test of the Paris and Saar agreements.
CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Dr. Enrico Fermi, an architect of the atomic age and Nobel Prize winner, died at his home here this morning of cancer. His age was 53.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 (UP) -- Leo Labine scored three goals and assisted on three others to lead the Boston Bruins to a 6-2 triumph over the Detroit Red Wings at the Boston Garden tonight before 9,055 fans.

Mr. and Mrs. Carroll J. Dickson sold their Brooklyn Heights residence at 30 Garden Place, Brooklyn, to Dr. and Mrs. John N. Edson in a deal negotiated by the Cruikshank Company, broker. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
VIENNA, Nov. 28 -- Elections took place, today in Czechoslovakia and Hungary. In Czechoslovakia they were Parliamentary whereas in Hungary they were local.
Charles E. Wilson says he has lost $1,000,000 on the General Motors stock he sold before his confirmation as Secretary of Defense.

SCARSDALE, N. Y., Nov. 28 -Mint Leaf, a 6-year-old bay mare that Gordon Wright bought as a yearling at Saratoga and developed, in the past year, as a fine show prospect, took double fox-chaser honors as the thirtieth Boulder Brook Club fall horse show ended tonight.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Nov. 28 (UP) -- The Colorado party emerged victorious in today's general elections. Complete official returns from the capital area showed that the Colorado factions headed by former President Luis Batlle Berres will get six of the nine seats in the National Council.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 -- The chatter of riveting hammers and the whirl of hoisting gear shattered the customary Sunday quiet at the South Annex of the Boston Naval Shipyard today. Preparations were under way for the coming Antarctic expedition of the Navy icebreaker Atka.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 28 -- Arthur B. Bisguier of New York, the chess champion of the United States, tonight won the Eastern States tournament when he drew his seventh and last game with James T. Sherwin, New York, in a Ruy Lopez, lasting sixteen moves.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -Strong new support for a general 5 per cent increase for almost 2,000,000 Government employes has developed despite President Eisenhower's desire for another kind of adjustment in Federal salaries.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Nov 28 (AP) -- Kenneth L. (Tug) Wilson, president of the United States Olympic Committee, said today American athletes were "drifting away from amateurism" and he added that "perhaps some of the blame can be placed on the colleges."

PARIS, Nov. 28 -- Opening a three-week period of parliamentary tests for Premier Pierre Mendes-France, the National Assembly will revive tomorrow the long-lingering debate on the bill for constitutional reform.

CHICAGO, Nov. 28 -- Wheat futures sold off sharply early last week but made a partial recovery, with the new crop deliveries showing relative strength on the continued dry conditions over the Southwest.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 28 -- Dr. Dan Gordon's and Dr. Norman Linde's Ch. Serius of Cross Acres from Livingston, N. J., took the best of breed award in the first specialty show and obedience trial of the Boxer Club of Long Island at the 165th Infantry armory today.

A section of the hangar deck of the aircraft carrier Bennington was converted into a chapel yesterday for services marking National Chaplains Day and the first nation-wide observance of the founding of the Navy Chaplain Corps 179 years ago.

It was probably inevitable that an economic recession should spawn a bevy of books on Big Business. From 1940 to mid-1953 there was business for all and the pressures of the giants on their smaller competitors were relaxed.

BOSTON, Nov. 28 -- American Protestantism was brought face-to-face here today with one of its most vexing problems: How to weld traditional denominational loyalties into a cooperative framework without destroying the entities.

Mozart's "The Marriage of Figaro" will receive its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan on Thursday, Dec. 9. Cesare Siepi will be the Figaro and Nadine Conner the Sussanna, George London and Lisa Della Casa will be the Count and Countess and Mildred Miller the Cherubino.

With the regular football season coming to a close, the national networks are making plans to broadcast four post-season bowl game on Jan. 1. Each game will be presented simultanously by radio and television over the following respective networks:
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Nov. 28 (AP) -- A taxicab and an automobile collided at a downtown intersection today, throwing a woman passenger out of the cab and fatally injuring her.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $77,128,673,751. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

Otto Graham and Lou Groza, the peerless combination that has brought the Cleveland Browns eight straight professional divisional championships in two leagues, moved the team to within a step of its ninth title at the Polo Grounds yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 (UP) Former President Truman said today the United States "can't very well live in peace" with Russia's present totalitarian masters.

Isaac Stern, violinist, and Leonard Rose, 'cellist, were the soloists yesterday afternoon with the New York Philharmonic-Symphony at Carnegie Hall. Collaborating with Bruno Walter as conductor, they played Brahms' Concerto for Violin and 'Cello.

CHATTANOOGA, Nov. 28 -- The South's increased purchasing power has been the most important factor in attracting new industrial facilities to the region in the last ten years, the Southern Association of Science and Industry reported today.

Louis A. Stone in his letter of Nov. 17 performed a service in pointing out the important fact that juvenile delinquency is not a new development in our city. However, his suggestion that youngsters over 15 who do not care for schooling should be allowed to leave school is unrealistic and regressive.
TORONTO, Nov. 28 (AP) -- Center Eagle Keys of the Edmonton Eskimos played in parts of the last three quarters of Saturday's Grey Cup final with broken leg, it was diclosed tonight.

The board of directors of the Public Relations Society of America, meeting yesterday before the three-day annual sessions beginning today in the Roosevelt Hotel, chose officers and directors for the coming year.
HAIFA, Israel, Nov. 10 -- Ein Hod's water reservoir probably will be the first in the world to be built with art objects.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- Bernard M. Baruch is urging President Eisenhower to strengthen the National Security Council by creating a nonpartisan roster of distinguished Americans to be available for special studies.

The third annual luncheon of the Community League for Retarded Children will be held Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The league is a voluntary, nonprofit, nonsectarian organization of parents and friends of the nearly 5,000 children at the State Training School for Retarded Children, Wassaic, N.Y.
Federal Communications Commissioner Robert E. Lee asserted yesterday that freedom in radio and television communications could be maintained only by the efforts of "a responsible industry."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 28 -- The first of 6,000,000 Christmas food packages, gifts from the people of the United States to the neediest families of forty-four countries, will be shipped from Philadelphia tomorrow.

The six-story apartment house for seventy families on plot 152 by 100 feet at 1186 East 180th Street, southwest corner of Morris Park Avenue, the Bronx, was purchased by Phillip P. Zipes, operator, through Joseph King, broker.
Retailers are getting a new weapon in their war against rising costs.
MILLIS, Mass., Nov. 28 -- The body of Roger Preston, president of S. S. Pierce Company of Boston, was found floating this afternoon in the Charles River near his summer camp. He was 54 years old.

Postmaster Robert H. Schaffer has recently been blessed by those New Yorkers lucky enough to live in the three gilt-edged postal areas in which he has vouchsafed them their mail in time to read it at breakfast. Mr. Schaffer now reports that this "experiment" -- which in the good old days used to be routine -- has been "an outstanding success" and that it is to be expanded to "other stations" after the Christmas rush.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Influenced by tomorrow's ending of current bookkeeping account most markets were quiet today, with a tendency toward dullness. A few selected industrials, mostly engineering and steel issues, went against the trend and several more finished above the day's lowest levels.

The piercing of the Suez isthmus with a navigable canal had been a dream of Ferdinand de Lesseps for twenty-two years when on Nov. 30, 1854, he received the first Act of Concession from his friend of younger days, Mohammed Said, then Viceroy of Egypt.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Pentagon has endorsed the idea of extending Federal Social Security coverage to more than 3,000,000 service men.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, rejected tonight a naval and air blockade of Communist China as a means of resolving disputes between the United States and the Communists.

Three adolescents charged with first-degree murder were denounced and defended yesterday in Kings County Court, where they are being tried before County Judge Hyman Barshay and an all-male, blue-ribbon jury.

What is literally the oldest school in New York -- city or state -- and preceded, they say, by only one in Boston, for it dates from 1638, is dedicating today a new building and celebrating three hundred and sixteen years of service to the community, interrupted only during the British occupation of the city, from 1776 to 1783.

The country's taste in advertising calendars is gradually veering from the pretty girl type, and demand is continuing without letup. This was reported yesterday by Robert Hall, vice president and sales manager of U. O. Colson Company of Paris, Ill., a major manufacturer of advertising specialties.

The St. John's University basketball team of Brooklyn may be a trifle short on experience, but the charges of Coach Al (Dusty) De Stefano are much improved over 1953-54. While many experts have ticketed the Redmen as being power-packed, Dusty isn't buying that -- at least, not at present.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Twice a week, usually about 3 P. M., the atmosphere of the House of Commons quivers with excitement when a bald, round, elderly man walks slowly down to the Government front bench and drops into his seat.

Doubts raised recently regarding German ratification of the Paris pacts and the stability of the West German Government have been dispelled as a result of bitterly fought elections in two German states. In these elections the opposition failed to make good its challenge, Chancellor Adenauer remains in control of the situation.

" Fragebogen" (The Questionnaire) has been written by a German who was held in an American prison camp after the fall of Germany. When the occupation authorities gave him the questionnaire that was given to all persons suspected of complicity with the Nazis, he wrote his answers in the form of a book.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A slight improvement in the factory employment situation was indicated today by labor turnover reports to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor.

HOUSTON, Nov. 29 -- The minor league log jam over relocation of the Kansas City Blues was broken today when the New York Yankees sold the Kansas City American Association franchise to the owners of the Denver club of the Western League.

CORPUS CHRISTI, Tex., Nov. 29 -- This beautiful, thriving city marks the end of one trail which the empire-builders in buckskin blazed from Tidewater Virginia to form the axis of a continent. To today's traveler along the trail, which this correspondent has followed, the remarkable discovery is that the ancient sections and their folkways have almost merged into a homogeneous continental pattern.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 109.5 (1947-1949 equals 100) over the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. Lower average prices for farm products and processed foods accounted for the decrease, as the index for all commodities other than farm and foods remained unchanged for the fifth week.
The American Jewish Congress urged yesterday that the Senate approve the resolution to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- A new corps of business and organized labor executives available for emergency duty in defense production will be set up here Wednesday by the Office of Defense Mobilization.

LONDON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- A British Overseas Airways strato-cruiser inbound from New York with thirty-three passengers lost its pressure needed for high altitude flying when a window blew out 200 miles off the Irish coast today.
TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- Clifford P. Case, Republican, today scored a net gain of fifty-one votes in the official recount of his race for the Senate against Democrat Charles R. Howell.

ROME, Nov. 29 -- The Italian Communist party received a body blow today when posters appeared in all Italian cities accusing several Communist leaders by name of crimes from murder to passing bad checks.

TRENTON, Nov. 29 -- Three hundred criminally insane prisoners, among them the multiple-slayer Howard B. Unruh, staged a wild dining room riot this afternoon at the New Jersey State Institution for the Insane.
Our volutary hospitals have proved their worth many times over in the dynamic advances in the treatment and prevention of many diseases that are no longer critcial illness in this country.
An agreement has been reached on terms of an option covering the sale of air (or above-ground) rights over the site of Pennsylvania Station.

FULTON, Mo., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Julius Raab, Chancellor of Austria, urged the Western powers today to help make it plain to the Soviet Union, that the signing of an Austrian State treaty "would represent the true key to further general pacification."

Events tonight: Verdi's "Aida," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Robert Casadesus, pianist, Zino Francescatti, violinist, assisted by the Guilet Quartet, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Alma Trio, Beethoven program, Town Hall, 8:30; Clarence Watters, organist, St. Thomas' Chapel, 230 East Sixtieth Street, 8:30; Young artists harp recital, Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30; Puccini's "La Boheme," Opera 55, Provincetown Playhouse, 8:15; Nell Tangeman, mezzosoprano, Turtle Bay Music School, 244 East Fifty-second Street, 8:30.
PRINCETON, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Royce Norwood Flippin Jr., a unanimous choice for all-Ivy honors during the 1954 season was elected captain of Princeton's 1955 eleven today.
Members of the New York Shipping Association ratified yesterday the agreement negotiated last week with the International Longshoremen's Association for two years of pier peace.
A spokesman for domestic lead and zinc producers said yesterday the industry was not convinced that the Government's accelerated stockpile buying of the two metals was achieving its purpose.
VIENNA, Nov. 29 -- The fifth general assembly of the World Veterans Federation began its deliberations here this morning.

With his accustomed facility for confusing the issue Mr. McCarthy told the Senate yesterday that the charges against him "boil down simply to the accusation that I have used discourteous and offensive words." It is quite true that he has used discourteous and offensive words that no self-respecting member of the Senate, acting in his official capacity, has any right to use.

OYSTER BAY, L. I., Nov. 29 -- Leonard W. Hall, Republican national chairman, is expected to resume soon the Republican leadership of Oyster Bay Township. He held that post for nineteen years before his election as Nassau County Surrogate in 1952.

It was disturbing on several counts to read in The Times of Nov. 26 that Senator Smathers and Representative Fulton had seen fit to "score" the United States delegation to the Inter-American Conference of Finance Ministers on the basis that it did not propose economic aid to Latin America that was sufficiently far-reaching.
On a wind-swept parade ground on Governors Island, Lieut. Gen. Withers A. Burress closed a thirty-eight-year career in the military service yesterday.
The Air Force is operating with an obsolete logistics system that does not allow the United States to exploit to the fullest its new nuclear weapons, it was reported here yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 29 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, examined about eleven hours after his wife had been murdered, had painful bruises and a black eye, but no apparent spinal injury, a physician testified today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- An insurance broker said today that over five years his commissions amounting to $45,773 almost matched total benefits paid under two group hospitalization policies covering A. F. L. workers in Atlantic City.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Some well-informed sources said tonight they saw in Secretary Dulles' Chicago address added indication that the United States might take to the United Nations its protest against the imprisonment of Americans in Communist China.
Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' broadcast address in Chicago last night, as recorded by The New York Times.
The traffic courtesy card investigation turned to the activities of the New Jersey police yesterday.
The city's plans to create tow-away zones beginning tomorrow to expedite motor traffic along Thirty-fourth, Forty-second and Fifty-seventh Streets have been postponed.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman and Mayor Wagner deflated yesterday Michael J. Quill's hopes for speedy abolition of the Transit Authority.

The initial official reaction to Michael J. Quill's call for abolition of the New York City Transit Authority is, we should say, on the cool side. Mayor Wagner does not think the city is in a position, at this time, to confer on the matter. As for what he thought of getting rid of the authority, he did not wish to state an opinion.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- The University of Illinois' board of trustees today reached a unanimous agreement to invite Dr. David D. Henry, executive vice chancellor of New York University, to become president of the Illinois school.

BONN, Germany, Nov. 29 -- With ratification of the Paris and Saar agreements virtually assured by yesterday's victory in Bavaria, Chancellor Konrad Adenauer took steps today to gain control of the state of Hesse.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UP) -- The National Intercollegiate Committee on Debate and Discussion announced tonight its refusal to withdraw the question of recognizing Communist China as a topic for college debate.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the eighth day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson, Democrat of Colorado, tried to put a New York Times editorial into the Congressional Record today, but Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, blocked the move.
Edward P. Morgan will resign as news director of the Columbia Broadcasting System at the end of this week to join the news staff of the American Broadcasting Company.

James C. Petrillo is making plans to become a film actor. He will do so in a documentary movie, which will be designed chiefly for the rank and file of his union but will also be available to any other groups interested in the cause of live music.

WHEELING, W. Va., Nov. 29 (AP) -- A United States District judge said today he will block sale of the Follansbee Steel Corporation to a New York financier and said he found evidence of a "breach of a directorial obligation" on the company's part.

BROOKVILLE, L. I., Nov. 29 -- Maj. Gen. William J. (Wild Bill) Donovan, former Ambassador to Thailand, said here today that the Thai were strong enough militarily and spiritually to defeat any Communist attempt to take over their country.

Group leaders of long experience can recognize quickly the temper and tempo of each new group they work with and can readily spot individuals most likely to disrupt group effort or help it along. Two publications, just issued, are designed to make the learning period easier.

ONCE in a great while someone comes out with a gadget that is so simple many wonder why they didn't think of it long before, and we can think of no finer example than Alex Rogan's "Visual Fly-Tying" book, which undoubtedly will have a lot of professional fly-tyers gnashing their teeth.

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 29 -Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery declared tonight that the Western powers would have to overhaul their military concepts and organization radically if they were to survive a future war.
PARIS, Nov. 29 -- General Nguyen Van Hinh, Chief of Staff of the Vietnamese Army, was dismissed from his post here today by Bao Dai, Vietnam's Chief of State.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- The Western powers were told today that if they condoned Israel's refusal to repatriate 900,000 Arab refugees, the Arab states would look toward the Soviet world.

TACHEN ISLANDS, Nov. 28 -- At 11:14 A. M. on Friday the destroyer escort Taikang, patrolling in the East China Sea about ten miles southeast of these Nationalist-held islands, made sonar contact with what seemed to be a moving underwater object.

Heavy liquidation of December cocoa futures tumbled prices on the New York Cocoa Exchange yesterday. All positions were off the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit and the spot month, which has no limit, fell 195 points (hundredths of a cent pound). There were seventy-one offerings at the close with no buyers. Volume was 331 lots.
Stock prices advanced yesterday for the sixth straight day, but the market was far spottier than it had been in recent days.
A wonderful source for unusual gifts that express the true spirit of Christmas is the many special sales being conducted by philanthropic organizations.
A sudden, turn by the freighter Lake Charles was given yesterday as the cause of the vessel's recent collision in the East River with the Japanese-flag Meirinsan Maru.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Senate agreed tonight to limit debate and to begin voting at 3 P. M. Wednesday on the proposals to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 29 -- Prime Minister Nehru has told a Yugoslav correspondent that coexistence between Communist and democratic countries would be "easier to achieve in Asia than in Europe."
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Foreign Operations Administration accepted today three more bids from United States ship owners for carrying coal to Korea.

Your editorial on Nov. 22 "The City Power Plants" advocates dipping into the $500,000,000 of exempt funds originally intended for a Second Avenue subway as the only present means by which modernization of the power plants can be financed.

STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Nov. 29 (AP) -- A group of agricultural economists today told the directors of dairy cooperatives that supply the New York milkshed that fluid milk production faced an adverse market in 1955.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Republicans of a House committee substantially approved today staff findings that foundation grants and operations in the educational field were taking on a "fabian Socialist" tint, if not a deeper leftist hue.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 29 -- The sale of four and a half acres of Nassau County land as the site of a proposed Academy of Medicine was approved here today by the County Board of Supervisors. The plot, near Mitchel Air Force Base, would go to the Nassau County Medical Society.

The first section of the Prospect Expressway, which will carry automobile traffic from Flatbush and Central Brooklyn to the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel and East River crossings via Gowanus Parkway, was opened to the public at 4:30 P. M. yesterday.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Nov. 29 -- Eliot Hearst of New York and Hans Berliner of Washington, former New York State champions, were the last to finish their seventh-round schedule in the Eastern States tournament of the Log Cabin Chess Club, in which Arthur B. Bisguier of New York had captured the first prize with a score of 6 1/2 - 1/2 .

An outdoor block party, with celebrities galore and rousing tunes by the 581st Air Force Band, yesterday opened a three-day Red Cross blood donation on Madison Avenue, between Fifty-first and Fifty-second Streets.

ATLANTA, Nov. 29 -- The defending champions, B. Jay Becker and George Rapee of New York, with John R. Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, today took an early lead in the open team championship. It is the major event of the twenty-eighth annual contract bridge winter national championships.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Nov. 30 -- Japan's Parliament opens a special session today that most political observers believe will see the end of the more than six years' rule by Shigeru Yoshida, 76-year-old conservative Premier.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Following is the text of the United States note rejecting the Soviet proposal for a European peace conference, as released by the State Department:
OTTAWA, Nov. 29 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Government will pay off next month $633,000,000 in called and maturing debt issues.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The United States Circuit Court of Appeals took under advisement today, after arguments by attorneys, a case involving the $100,000,000 General Aniline and Film Corporation seized by the Government during World War II as enemy property.

Despite the Thanksgiving Day holiday, the nation's steel production continued to climb last week and at 1,915,000 tons was the largest since the week of last Dec. 7. Production was. expected to edge still further to 1,919,000 tons this week.

MIAMI, Fla., Nov. 29 (AP) -The Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, Mrs. Oveta Culp Hobby, today asked the American Medical Association to support President Eisenhower's health reinsurance proposal. She called it a means of providing "insurance against compulsory health insurance."
The roster of players selected to take part in the annual East West charity Shrine football game at San Francisco was announced yesterday at the Football Writers Association luncheon at Toots Shor's.

Two stock offerings with a value of $3,757,596 will be made to the public today. Both issues are being sold for individual accounts and no proceeds will accrue to the company as a result of this offering.

For most of the past six and a half years the Soviet press, as well as all organs of world communism, have habitually referred to Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia by such terms as "traitor," "fascist dog," "capitalist spy" and similar epithets. Sunday night in Moscow, however, the highest Soviet leaders raised their glasses to toast "Comrade Tito."
The line-up for the post-season football games during December and January (won, lost and tied records in parentheses) :

OTTAWA, Nov. 29 (Canadian Press) -- Canada's exports declined by $29,800,000 in October, making a total decline of $274,000,000 for the first ten months of the year. The month's trade produced a deficit of $14,000,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 29 -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. told the thirty-first annual Congress of the American Municipal Association today that "bossism" had disappeared from government in all but a few cities.

The December "Survey" of the Guaranty Trust Company of New York, out today, says that the American economy in the next decade "is likely to experience unusual growth and development." It quotes with approval the prediction of a 20 per cent increase in the population by 1965, made by the staff of the Joint Committee on the Economic Report.

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Nov. 29 -- The inter-American economic conference took a turn for the better today. Without any spectacular developments, an atmosphere of mutual understanding and optimism seemed to have been created for the first time since the talks opened last Monday.

In The New York Times of Nov. 14 James Reston discussed the role the Government can take in making news by presenting its positive accomplishments. When it does not use this power the Government leaves a news vacuum to be filled by the sensational or by the McCarthy-type politician. Mr. Reston's analysis tells one part of the story of headline creation.

The Philadelphia Warriors, headed by the league's-leading scorer, Paul Arizin, engage the New York Knickerbockers tonight in the second game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden.
The Inter-American Press Association called on the Bolivian Government today to prevent the expropriation of opposition newspapers in Bolivia.

To be immortal and still alive, to be 80 years old and bursting with vitality, to have the admiration of everyone who cherishes freedom and who knows a whole man when he sees him -- is not this a grand thing? Sir Winston Churchill should be envied today as he enters his ninth decade.
An attack of food poisoning in London has caused a three-day delay in the arrival here of Sir John Kotelawala, Prime Minister of Ceylon, for an official visit to the United States.

A VISITOR to New York art galleries this week may, if he chooses, wander vicariously to many parts of the world and explore less definite realms of fantasy as well. Peter Blume has visited the islands of the Pacific and the Antipodes as well as Japan and is showing terse ink drawings of these regions at the Durlacher Gallery, 11 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The television repair business in New York is honeycombed with frauds that should be eliminated by local legislation, Edward S. Silver, Kings County District Attorney, declared yesterday at City Hall.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these counts:

Pierre Mendes-France, Premier of France, likes milk, but he hastened to explain yesterday that this doesn't mean that he is mad at the great wines of France, an important item in his country's export trade.
CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:
THE Musicians Guild gave the first of its four chamber music concerts last night in Town Hall.
It was certainly pleasant to read that the New York Public Library has changed its rules to permit dogs, accompanied by their masters and mistresses, to enter its branches.

MOSCOW, Nov. 29 -- The Moscow conference of European Communist Governments opened today. Vyacheslav M. Molotov, Soviet Foreign Minister, told the delegates their countries "must rally their forces and considerably strengthen them" in the event that West Germany is armed.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 29 -- President Tito left Belgrade by train tonight on the first leg of a state visit to India and Burma. There he will discuss with Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and Premier U Nu the principle of peaceful coexistence of governments with different governing systems.

SCRANTON, Pa., Nov. 29 (UP) -- The Government announced today that employes of the United States Penitentiary at Lewisburg, Pa., and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation would testify before a Federal Grand Jury here on Wednesday in the fatal beating of the former Government economist, William W. Remington.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, the United States champion, staved off a strong rally by the Australian titleholder, Mervyn Rose, and defeated the Aussie lefthander 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 4, today to gain the semi-final round of the Victorian tennis championships.
HARTFORD, Nov. 29 -- Gov.-elect Abraham A. Ribicoff conferred this morning with out going Gov. John Davis Lodge on the transition from a Republican to a Democratic administration.

Rockefeller Center's Christmas tree, a sixty-five-foot Norway spruce, was hoisted into place yesterday in an operation made difficult by the strong winds. The tree, from the estate of Elmer Rowe in Belvidere, N. J., entered New York by way of the George Washington Bridge.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- December liquidation in grain futures and scattered selling of soybeans made for lower prices during the forepart of today's session. Corn was the exception, being strong throughout the day.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Okla., Nov. 29 (UP) -- Three Oklahoma City men, one a former Atomic Energy Commission employe, were charged today with illegal possession of gold allegedly taken from the A. E. C. laboratory at Los Alamos, N. M.

Many luncheons were given yesterday in advance of the concert of the Bagby Music Lovers Foundation, Inc., presented yearly for the benefit of needy opera and concert artists. The concert was held in the main ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States, Britain and France proposed today a Big Four foreign ministers' conference, possibly to be followed by a wider conference on European security.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The United States told the Soviet Union today that United States naval forces would continue to keep the closest watch on the waters around Formosa "to prevent an attack on that island."
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved irregularly yesterday. The close was 11 points higher to 10 points lower than on last Friday.
The threat of losing part of the Christmas toy business has brought department stores in this city out in the open in their fight against discount houses.

The Atchison Topeka and Santa Fe Railway reported yesterday a net income of $3,868,218 for October. This compares with $4,869,387 for October, last year. Gross revenues declined to $43,838,326 from $48,794,646 in October, last year.

Irving Rapper will direct "The Boy and the Bull," a King Brothers production, for R. K. O. The film will begin photography in Madrid in February. . . . Richard Quine, director of the Universal musical, "So This Is Paris," has been named to handle the studio's projected "So This Is Rio."

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Treasury spokesmen expressed themselves as "more than pleased" with preliminary reports on the $17,300,000,000 refunding operation opened today. Final reports of the offering of new securities for old ones maturing on Dec. 15 will not be available until after the subscription books close on Wednesday.

Tenant-stockholders have purchased sixty-six apartments representing 75 per cent of the stock, in the twenty-story cooperative building under construction at 20 Sutton Place South, according to Douglas L. Elliman Co., selling and managing agents for the property.
King Commander was named yesterday by the racing secretaries at thirty-nine Thoroughbred Racing Associations' tracks as the champion steeplechaser of 1954.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Nov. 29 -- With Congress due to debate ratification of the United Fruit Company's new contract tomorrow, company headquarters here was cautious today regarding the Legislature's possible attitude.
Collector of Customs Robert W. Dill and Chief Appraiser Aleer J. Couri will sail on the superliner United States Dec. 1 for a two-week survey of baggage and cargo handling in European ports.
It is extremely doubtful that Chuck Conerly will be available to the New York Football Giants for the remainder of the National Football League season.
HANOVER, N. H., Nov. 29 -- Alfred J. McGuire of Rockaway Beach, L. I., was appointed freshman basketball coach at Dartmouth College today.
ROME, Nov. 29 -- Pope Pius XII seemed considerably better today after a comparatively restful night, during which he got several hours' sleep.

Martucci Sons, builders, through their Roslyn Pines, Inc., have purchased the former Slade estate of forty-seven acres with several buildings on the south side of Berry Hill Road, about 400 feet east of Route 106, in Oyster Bay, L. I. Joseph K. Alliger and Hyman Ratner of the Sterling Investing Corporation were the sellers.
The Gillette Company expects to earn more than $25,000,000 this year, Joseph P. Spang Jr., president, told the luncheon meeting of the New York Society of Security Analysts here yesterday.
BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- The "spiritual health" of the United States has never been better -- but there still is room for improvement.
The Western Union Telegraph Company reported yesterday net income of $1,082,597 for October, the highest for the month in twenty-five years.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- Mike Holovak, head coach of the Boston College Eagles who won eight of their nine games this fall; Boston University's quarterback, Tom Gastall, and Brown's coach, Al Kelley, were honored today at a luncheon of football writers, broadcasters and coaches.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 29 -- The Screen Actors Guild has urged "stricter application" by the United States Immigration and Naturalization Service of regulations governing the admission of alien actors to perform work in motion pictures made in this country.

BOSTON, Nov. 29 -- Three hundred Presbyterian clergymen have been requested by a top church official to urge their Senators to uphold the censure recommendations directed against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin.

Operations of the Federated Department Stores, Inc., and subsidiaries for the thirty-nine weeks ended on Oct. 30 resulted in a net income of $10,465,314, according to Fred Lazarus Jr., president. This represents an increase of 28.9 per cent above the $8,116,599 cleared in the corressponding period a year earlier.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 (UP) -- A substitute "corn king" was named today and two more farmers were disqualified for gluing kernels to their ears of corn in one of the biggest controversies of the International Hay and Grain Show.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 -- Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, today urged supporters of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy to petition the Wisconsin Republican to cooperate "a little more" with anti-Communist colleagues in the Senate.
Many dinner and supper parties will be given in conjunction with a performance of "Quadrille'' tomorrow night at the Coronet Theatre for the benefit of the Kips Bay Boys Club.

BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 29 -- Pro-Government newspapers forgot President Juan D. Peron's advice to remain calm on religious issues and published heated editorials today against participants in yesterday's Roman Catholic rally here.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Nov. 29 -- President Eisenhower, speaking for the American people, has saluted Sir Winston as a "world statesman" and an "unconquerable warrior in the cause of freedom."

SCHENECTADY, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- Governor-elect Averell Harriman is giving "extremely serious consideration" to the establishment of a state fund to supplement funds raised by New York communities to expand established industries and to attract new ones.
The Government's new program for speedy trials and severe sentences for narcotics violators was accentuated yesterday in Federal Court when five received stiff prison terms.
Unwavering support of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was pledged last night by 13,000 persons attending a rally in Madison Square Garden opposing the censure of the controversial Wisconsin Republican.
The public relations methods of the Soviet Union were compared yesterday to those of an unprincipled company seeking to destroy its competitor.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Tomorrow Sir Winston Churchill will celebrate his eightieth birthday. Britons from Cabinet Ministers on down have combined to make it an occasion unique in the history of this country. Never before, it would seem, has a commoner evoked so massive and spontaneous a tribute.

BOWIE, Md., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Mrs. Samuel M. Pistorio's Brazen Brat, 12 to 5, returned to winning form at the Bowie track today, leading all the way in the $5,000 Sation Purse to gain her first victory since June.

U. C. L. A., with the first per season in the school's history, yesterday was acclaimed as the national collegiate football champion of 1954 in the final United Press ratings. U.C.L.A. held the top spot by the margin of 7 points over Ohio State, the unbeaten and untied champions of the Big Ten Conference.

The Red Ridge Realty Corporation has sold the former American Chain and Cable Company property at 2145 McCarter Highway in Newark, N. J., to the Clayton Holding Company, a group of investors represented by the Louis Schlesinger Company, broker in the transaction.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Nov. 29 (AP) -- Two State Senators and six Republican county chairmen agreed today to ask Governor Dewey to call a special session of the Legislature next month to freeze state aid for education at current levels until July 1, 1956.

When a friendly "All aboard" was heard recently in the New York Central's railroad yards at Harmon, N. Y., it was a signal for a group of parents and young persons to climb aboard and inspect a huge Diesel locomotive.

The old Yorkville Magistrates Court building on Fifty-seventh Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, will be offered at auction today by the City of New York. The sale will be held at 11 A. M. in Room 1030 of the Bureau of Real Estate in the Municipal Building.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today refused to sanction special cut rates proposed by two Atlantic Coast water carriers on iron and steel shipments moving down the Seaboard.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- Dr. Alexander G. Gilliam of the National Cancer Institute told military surgeons today that the link between cigarette smoking and lung cancer had been established.

Installation of protective devices to keep young children from falling out of windows was ordered yesterday by the State Division of Housing for all state-aided housing higher than two stories built by municipal housing authorities.

BRISBANE, Australia, Nov. 29 (Reuters) -- Australia broke England's batting in fifteen minutes during today's play in the first cricket test match. As a result, the visiting Britons face and uphill struggle to ward off defeat.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 (UP) -- A group of Pacific Northwest power companies applied for a preliminary permit today for two proposed power dams on the Snake River for which Government agencies also had construction plans.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 29 -- The Treasury reported today that its short-term borrowing costs increased this week for the first time in a month. It announced its latest offering of $1,500,000,000 in ninety-one day bills was sold at a price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.029 per cent.

At the moment the practical problem that confronts the United States is how to bring the right sort of pressure on Red China to obtain the release of the thirteen Americans who are now in prison there for "spying."

The new one-story industrial building at 303-05 Maujer Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the Bellarose Paper Box Corporation from the Bar Industrial Corporation and will be used for the manufacture and distribution of paper boxes.
The General Electric Company and Farnsworth Electronics Company have begun what they call the first mass promotion of industrial closed-circuit television equipment.

Beef continues to be one of the most economical offerings at meat counters, a fact that suggests its frequent use. Boneless beef stew meat, a particularly worthwhile purchase, is a versatile cut that may be prepared in a variety of ways.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams' experiment in fighting crime by increasing manpower will be extended tomorrow to two more precincts, one in Brooklyn and one in Queens, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 22 -- Mrs. America has met Mrs. Britain and found to her astonishment that both have the same ideas on how to run a home.
Retail shoe sales from now through Easter will exceed the volume of the comparable period a year earlier by about 5 per cent, sponsors of the Popular Price Shoe Show of America said yesterday.

The New York Central Railroad is studying the feasibility of discontinuing its ferry services across the Hudson River and the possible elimination of commuter traffic on its West Shore and Putnam divisions.

ON Jan. 30, 1943, a few miles north of Stalingrad the few survivors of a German division cut off from the Sixth Army, which was itself surrounded, surrendered. They had endured the worst that war can inflict, the slaughter of most of their comrades, the cold of the Russian winter, near-starvation.
Public utilities and landlords were called upon yesterday by the city Administration to cooperate in the inspection of gas appliances.
GENEVA, Nov. 29 -- The position of France in the world trade conference here is causing increasing concern to all her North Atlantic allies.

PORT - AU - PRINCE, Haiti, Nov. 16 -- To the tired tourist, sun-drenched Haiti seems like "a heavenly paradise . . . wherein all pleasant fruits do grow." This includes, of course, bananas, grapefruit, oranges (both sweet and so sour, one American said, the juice could be used for laundry bleach), avocados (with both purple and green skins), coconuts, almonds, breadfruit, papayas and mangoes.
If winter comes, can the pounding of garbage cans at night be far behind ?

The East Village Liquor Corporation, in a purchase for occupancy, has acquired the five-story building at 1347 Second Avenue and 244 East Seventy-first Street from the Arealty Corporation. Walter Scott Co. were the brokers.

CHICAGO, Nov. 29 -- State's Attorney John Gutknecht announced today his investigators had obtained evidence of the existence of a national, and possibly international, ring that specializes in the imitation of the trade mark and watches of the Bulova Watch Company.
Gil Turner, Philadelphia middleweight, scored a ninth round technical knockout over Ray Drake of Far Rockaway in the scheduled ten-round bout at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- American Federation of Labor sailors signed aboard the American President liner President Wilson today after a twenty-four-hour delay resulting from the union's ban on overtime in port and on work on holidays.
ALBANY, Nov. 29 (AP) -- The State Board of Canvassers will meet here at 1 P. M. Dec. 16 to certify winners of the state-wide elections Nov. 2.

SARANAC LAKE, N. Y., Nov. 29 -- Trudeau Sanatorium, a treatment center for tuberculosis since 1884, will close tomorrow when Larry Doyle, its last patient, is discharged. Mr. Doyle, former second baseman for the New York Giants, has been a patient here for the last twelve years.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Nov. 29 -- A pet burro arrived here by railway express from Arizona today, but it had a difficult time finding its new home. On the way it had eaten its destination tag.
