Tied to one of the shaggy creature's long ears, when it arrived on the 8:54 train from New York this morning, was the cryptic note: "This burro belongs to New Brunswick, N. J.

The Universal Atlas Cement Company, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, announced plans yesterday to build a new plant with an annual capacity of more than 3,000,000 barrels of cement adjacent to the company's Buffington plant at Gary, Ind.

Tyrannosaurus rex got pushed around a little yesterday at the American Museum of Natural History. The fossilized skeleton of the mightiest carnivorous land animal in history, together with those of three other fantastic monsters of his era, became pawns in a strategic move to a new location.

CAIRO, Nov. 29 -- The second of forty-one massive limestone blocks covering Pharaoh Cheops' solar ship chamber was removed today, revealing more of what appeared to be the mast lying beside an unshipped bowpost.

THE Army-Navy game was not only an en-grossing spectacle but it may have proved slightly educational to millions of television viewers, especially those who have trouble in differentiating between a halfback and a touchback. Football was a simple game back in the days of the flying wedge, but it has grown steadily more complex and mysterious.

After covering a million miles in fifty years, the Department of Justice ferryboat Ellis Island made her last run yesterday to the deserted former immigration station in New York Harbor. In contrast to May 5, 1904, when she entered the shuttle service from Manhattan under fair skies and light variable winds, yesterday a strong westerly wind kicked up white caps in Upper Bay.

Bustling around town, taking in the Broadway shows and other points of interest that New York has to offer, Noel Coward is a difficult person to pin down for information about his theatrical ventures. But, according to a well-informed associate of the ubiquitous British, actor-playwright, Mr. Coward is virtually certain to be seen here early next season in two plays of his own authorship on alternating weeks.
SAN FRANCISCO, Nov. 29 -- A Japan trade center opened its doors today in the heart of San Francisco's financial district.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 29 -- The shift to a Democratic Congress will not touch off any substantial tax-reduction or other radical change in the nation's life, Senator Prescott Bush, Republican of Connecticut, predicted here today.

Andrew Goodman, president and general merchandise manager of Bergdorf Goodman, made a strong plea yesterday for the promotion of American fashions. He spoke at the Fashion Group meeting at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Nov. 30 (UP) -- Willie Hartack of Johnstown, Pa., who gained a riding double yesterday, accounted for three more winners at Tropical Park today, including both ends of the split Tarrare Purse before a crowd of 6,777.
BUENOS AIRES, Nov. 30 -- Argentina won't have a chess champion this year because thirteen of the nation's top players brought too much excitement into the title matches.
The stock market registered in November the widest gain for any month since June, 1929, as The New York Times' fifty-stock average rose to its best level in a quarter of a century.

The performance of "Aida" at the Metropolitan Opera last evening coincided with the 100th anniversary of the Suez Canal charter, and a more appropriate work could hardly have been chosen than the opera commissioned for the opening of the canal.
Cotton futures declined 13 to 21 points yesterday in moderate trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.
EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Nov. 30 (AP) -- An Ohio construction engineer testified today he paid $7,500 in four installments to Evan Dale, head of the A. F. L. laborers' union in Southern Illinois.
Leaders of Ten Million Americans Mobilizing for Justice, formed to petition against the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, hope to make the organization a permanent political fixture.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- Despite vigorous opposition, the selection of New York as permanent headquarters for the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. was approved here today after a sharp floor debate. The controversy came to a head at a business session of the biennial General Assembly.

Elizabeth C. Bosley of Unionville, Pa., was found to have violated the amateur rules of the American Horse Shows Association at a hearing yesterday at the office of the president, Adrian Van Sinderen.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Nov. 30 -- Johannes Gerhardus Strydom succeeded Dr. Daniel F. Malan today as Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa. The new leader, 61 years old, is an extreme nationalist and an advocate of an eventual republic.
WEST HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Nov. 30 -- One hundred sixty physically handicapped men and women attended the second annual family dinner of Abilities, Inc., at the West Hempstead High School tonight.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Government has begun a study of what can be done to stop "black markets" in babies.

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. declared yesterday that there was only "one boss in the Fire Department.'" He announced that he would take over all administration of the 11,000 personnel from Chief Peter Loftus.
THE script for lecturers and technicians who will put on tonight's preview of Hayden Planetarium's "Christmas 'Round the World," the holiday season show, is a rather breath-taking document.

NANCHISHAN ISLAND, Nov. 29 -- If the Chinese Nationalists lose the Tachen Islands they will probably have to withdraw about eighty miles down the islands on the coast of Chekiang Province and depend upon this rocky island as their most important outpost in a truncated offshore military archipelago.
New financing in November showed a marked decline from the levels of recent months, but exceeded that of a year ago.
AVALON, N. J., Nov. 30 -- The 17-year-old son of Henry A. Peer, chief accountant of Essex County, shot and killed himself here today over a broken romance, the police reported.
BOWIE, Md., Nov. 30 (AP) -- W. J. Appel's Metaxa won the $4,000 Southern Maryland Medical Society Purse, feature today at the Bowie track.

Events tonight: "Madama Butterfly," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; David Bar-Illan, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Bach Aria Group, Town Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet, Lexington Avenue Y. M. and Y. W. H. A., 8:40; Quartetto Italiano, McMillin Theatre, Columbia University, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Government has purchased and stored 61.3 per cent of the $6,985,000,000 worth of strategic materials required for the country's stockpile of critical materials, the Office of Defense Mobilization advised Congress today.
An electronic calculator designed to solve in a month mathematical problems that took a year on earlier devices was demonstrated yesterday at Columbia University.

Mayor Wagner expressed the hope yesterday that the city soon would be able to pay members of the Police Department salaries comparable to those in private industries. The Mayor spoke at the graduation exercises of 407 probationary patrolmen and five probationary policewomen in the Baruch School of Business and Public Administration of City College, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue. He said:

LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Virginia Hopkins Watson, former swimming champion, who thought having a baby would interfere with her chance to enter the movies, died today of complications from an abortion, the police reported.

MOSCOW, Nov. 30 -- Marshal Nikolai A. Bulganin, Soviet Defense Minister, disclosed tonight that the eight Communist countries of Eastern Europe were considering the formation of either a joint military staff or a unified command if West Germany is armed.

I am pleased to observe that in your editorial of Nov. 26 on West Irian it was admitted that the problem is essentially a colonial one. That the island, a part of Indonesian territory, is still a colony of the Dutch is obvious. But it is rather hard to agree that an Asian, peaceful and democratic, can rule in colonial fashion another Asian.
GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- Forty per cent of all migration from Europe is now under international auspices, Hugh Gibson, director of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration, said today.

CLEVELAND, Nov. 30 -- A medical technician completed her testimony at the murder trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard today after acknowledging that chemical and miscroscopic examinations could not give positive answers to certain questions.

The "Eddie Cantor Comedy Theatre," a half-hour weekly film series, has been purchased for television sponsorship in twenty-five cities including New York by P. Ballantine Sons. Beginning in April the program will be presented here by WABC-TV on Wednesdays at 9:30 P. M.
Commuters will have a voice in any modernization of Pennsylvania Station and above-ground development there, a vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad promised yesterday.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of the Speech from the Throne with which Queen Elizabeth opened a new session of Parliament today:
The Swiss Benevolent Society will be the beneficiary of a bazaar to be held on Friday, Saturday and Sunday in the Della Robbia Room of the Vanderbilt Hotel.

The savings banks of New York State had a deposit gain of $35,255,000 during October, it was announced yesterday by the, Savings Banks Association of New York. While a little below the $37,974,000 increase in October of last year, the gain is well above the average of $26,000,000 for the last five years.
One of the nation's two commercial producers of primary titanium metal, E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., reduced the price of ductile titanium sponge yesterday by 22 to 46 cents a pound.

UNITED NATIONS, Nov. 30 -- Indonesia won a major victory in the United Nations today over the Netherlands, and indirectly over all the colonial powers. The General Assembly's Political Committee voted that the two countries should continue to try to solve their dispute over West New Guinea.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The stock markets were unsettled today by talks of a possible rise in interest rates. Selling, though not heavy, tended to lower most prices.
Chuck Conerly, the football Giants' first string quarterback, still hopes he will be able to play against the Pittsburgh Steelers next Sunday, despite the torn ligaments in his right knee.

The annual campaign to raise funds for the fight against tuberculosis has begun, and within the next few days one out of every four individuals in this country will receive what has become known as the symbol of that fight -- the Christmas Seal.
Three new issues of securities valued at $27,220,000 were sold at competitive bidding here yesterday. The borrowings were evidenced by bonds, preferred stock and equipment trust certificates.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Australians jeered at Lew Hoad and cheered Rex Hartwig today and the Americans refused to despair of their Davis Cup chances despite quarter-final reverses in the Victorian tennis championships.

HOUSTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Jack Cassini, 35-year-old infielder who has been in the Brooklyn Dodger organization the past four years, was named tonight as manager of the Memphis Chicks of the Southern Association.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A significant reshuffling of the United States diplomatic service, hinged on the recall of Loy W. Henderson, United States Ambassador to Iran, for assignment to a high administrative post in the State Department, was under way here today.

Here it is, almost a decade since the young men of World War II got out of the service, and more than a decade since they went in. Enough time has passed so that few veterans of that war think of themselves as being different from contemporaries who weren't in the service.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- The Washington Senators were reported today to be cooking up a seven-man trade that would send Eddie Yost to the Chicago White Sox and bring Minnie Minoso to Washington.

The Jewish Museum at Fifth Avenue and Ninety-second Street will open to the public tomorrow at exhibit illustrating the 300 years of Jewish history in the United States and the contributions of Jews to life here.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the ninth day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

Instead of a grab-and-run, the event at the City Center Gallery staged yesterday in its quarters at 131 West Fifty-fifth Street for funds to continue its non-profit operation turned out to be a leisurely experience for picture buyers.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- College and university enrollments totaled 2,472,000 this fall, the Office of Education estimated today.

Renewal of its founders' aims for "high educational purpose on the one hand and religious freedom and tolerance on the other hand" marked the dedication yesterday of a seven-classroom addition to the Collegiate School, 245 West Seventy-seventh Street.

Alan Ameche, the 210-pound fullback who set a collegiate rushing record -- 3,212 yards in 673 attempts -- during four years at the University of Wisconsin, yesterday was named the winner of the Heisman Memorial Trophy as college football's outstanding player in 1954.
Nat Holman finds it difficult to conceal the fact that he is most happy to be back at the old stand as head coach of City College's varsity basketball team.
Three players wire had to sit out part of' the season because of injuries and other circumstances proved good enough to earn places on the All-East football team.
The Detroit Red Wings, with Gordie Howe and Ted Lindsay sparking the attack, will oppose the New Work Rangers in a National Hockey League contest at Madison Square Garden tonight.

Your article in the Nov. 23 issue on rent-free parking space for automobiles brings up this simple question: If the city charges a building owner taxes for his property on city land why should not the same reasoning apply for automobile parking on city streets?

We understand that the Board of Education is about to decide what action it will take in the case of teachers who, while giving testimony under provisions of the Feinberg Law and Section 12a of the Civil Service Law, disclose their own past Communist affiliations but refuse to identify other persons as Communists.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Czechoslovakia today attacked Senator William F. Knowland as a member of one of the groups in the United States that are opposed to peaceful negotiations. It was charged that these groups were seeking to bring about "emnity between peoples and preparation for war."

Floyd B. Odlum, president of the $67,000,000 Atlas Corporation, an investment trust that invests primarily in "special situations," suggested yesterday that Howard Hughes come to a decision about ownership of the R. K. O. Pictures Corporation.

Citing increases in revenues of "no less than 50 per cent" in all British theatres playing CinemaScope films, Darryl F. Zanuck, production chief of Twentieth Century-Fox, declared yesterday that the general attitude of foreign exhibitors and producers toward his company's wide-screen process was one of "eagerness" and "enthusiasm." Mr. Zanuck recently returned from a one-week business tour of Britain.

A three-story building 60 by 100 feet at 239 Great Neck Road in Great Neck, L. I., has been purchased by Biener Pontiac, Inc., from the O. McIntyre Company. The structure, on plot 80 by 150 feet, is suitable for offices or light manufacturing. It has been acquired by the new owner for investment.

PETROPOLIS, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The inter-American conference gave tentative approval early today to a plan that ultimately may save United States investors in Latin America millions in income taxes.

Having acquired a new violinist in Maurice Wilk, the Alma Trio has taken on a new lease of life. It deserves to be long and prosperous -- that is, if the ensemble continues to play as beautifully as it played last night when it opened the cycle of three Beethoven concerts that it is giving at Town Hall.

Kenneth R. Miller, senior vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, predicted yesterday that 1955 would be a more prosperous year than 1954, although probably not so prosperous as 1953, the peak year in American business.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Adlai E. Stevenson has been retained by the Radio Corporation of America as counsel in a $16,000,000 anti-trust suit Zenith Radio Corporation is pressing against R.C.A.
JUDGING from the increasing number of art exhibitions featuring pictorial records of travels near and far, it looks as if the artist's brush were taking over from the traveler's diary.
Catapulted into stardom after her initial Broadway stage appearance in the revue, "New Faces of 1952," Eartha Kitt returns in "Mrs. Patterson" at 8 o'clock tonight at the National.

Operations of the Dana Corporation and subsidiaries for the year ended on Aug. 31 resulted in a net income of $9,638,402, equal to $3.74 a common share, according to the report issued yesterday by J. E. Martin, president.
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Gen. Lucius D. Clay said today President Eisenhower's $50,000,000,000 "pay-as-you-go" road-building program was "desirable but not practical."

Christmas shopping may be combined with an education in contemporary art and craft work. At the Greenwich House Pottery, 16 Jones Street, one may buy Christmas tree ornaments which will be used long after the holidays.

HARTFORD, Nov. 30 -- A Connecticut conference on education opened here today to consider problems to be presented at a country-wide school symposium called by President Eisenhower. The gathering here is one of the first official state meetings to be held before the White House meeting next November.
Richmond, Va., announced plans yesterday to sell on Dec. 15 $3,860,000 of public improvement bonds dated Jan. 1 and maturing from 1956 to 1975.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Secretary of Defense Charles E. Wilson said today that Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery was "a very brave man" to offer the United States advice on strategy and military organization.
Saks Fifth Avenue and Elizabeth Arden opened gift shops this week stocked with ultra-feminine merchandise but feminine customers are prohibited.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Senatorial sound over censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was eclipsed momentarily today by Senatorial fury.

UNITED NATIONS. N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The United States delegation to the United Nations said today it had received no instruction about placing before the General Assembly or the Security Council the imprisonment by Communist China of thirty-nine Americans.

The Finch College scholarship fund will benefit from the Feb. 21 performance of "Silk, Stockings," starring Hildegarde Neff and Don Ameche. The musical is scheduled to open Jan. 6 at the Imperial Theatre.

Despite justified popular indignation over the imprisonment of American soldiers and civilians in Communist China, both President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles have ruled out, at least for the present, any naval or air blockade of the China coast as amounting to "acts of war."
Willard F. Rockwell Jr., president of Rockwell Manufacturing Company, has been named a director of Lad Manufacturing Company, Inc., Nashville, Tenn., manufacturer of garden tools.

The city government is doing its best, through several approaches, to reduce the hazards from faulty gas appliances or the misuse of gas cooking stoves and water heaters for general heating of living quarters. But in the long run -- and we know it can't be done overnight -- the ideal solution is central heating and central supply of hot water.
Austrian Chancellor Julius Raab arrived at La Guardia airport from St. Louis late last night to begin a four-day visit in the city. He departs Saturday for a state visit to Canada.
Two important trends, the covered-up look and the lowered waistline, dominate beachwear for the resort season.
With painstaking detail two assistant district attorneys assembled evidence yesterday in an effort to prove that three adolescents burned, beat and drowned a man in Brooklyn on Aug. 16.

Doc Holliday, a notorious gambler "whose name was a byword for frontier prowess" in the Eighteen Seventies and Eighteen-Eighties, is the subject of a new book by John Myers Myers. The gambler was the son of a gentle Georgia family.

An autographed copy of Adlai E. Stevenson's current best seller, "Call to Greatness," is among the items that will be awarded to the winners of the door prizes at the sixth annual Christmas fair of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Ascension to be held on Saturday at the Parish House, 12 West Eleventh Street.

DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Sugar Ray Robinson, former world welterweight and middleweight boxing champion, was suspended indefinitely today by the Michigan Board of Athletic Control for refusing to go through with a Dec. 8 fight here.
MONTREAL, Nov. 30 (Canadian Press) -- A decrease of $20,571,000 in net operating revenues for the first ten months of this year was reported today by Canadian National Railways.

The police narcotics squad has arrested thirty-five persons in a round-up of sellers and users of narcotics, and further arrests are expected. The crackdown began at 7:30 P. M. Monday and continued until 8:30 o'clock last night. In Brooklyn, twenty-one suspects, including a mother of five, were seized.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Ohio plans elaborate ceremonies tomorrow at the opening of the first twenty-two mile section of the 241-mile Northern Ohio Turnpike. The section runs from the Pennsylvania border to a point west of Youngstown.

THE differing capabilities of the radio and television media were emphasized most illuminatingly this week in programs devoted to the eightieth birthday of Sir Winston Churchill. For a change it was television that came off second best.

COBH, Ireland, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Winds of hurricane force sank a British cargo liner off the coast of Ireland today with a heavy loss of life. The storm also ripped into the British Isles, spreading destruction and driving lowland dwellers from their homes.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The portrait of Sir Winston Churchill presented to him today already has been publicly admired, reviled, criticized and defended by parliamentarians, the only persons who have seen it.

ALBANY, Nov. 30 -- The New York State Thruway will become a 100 per cent four-lane route next month when the last two-lane bottleneck between Buffalo and Newburgh is eliminated, the Thruway Authority announced today.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Administration will ask Congress to extend the draft law for four years and to establish a modified form of Universal Military Training, Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, said today.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Wheat moved up sharply today following an early dip, the deliveries apparently being less than expected on December contracts. May and July made new highs on the crop.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Nov. 30 -- Indonesia is unwilling to share the administration of West New Guinea with any other nation or with an international authority. This was made clear here today by Dr. Diapari, chairman of the Government's Irian (New Guinea) Bureau.

SOMETHING new in historical writing is being offered to the reading public today and its publishers don't know whether it is a magazine or a book. In a handsome advertising brochure distributed some months ago they called it "the only popular magazine devoted to American history." On the jacket of the first issue, or first volume, they call it "the first in a magnificent new series of books about our country."

THERE'S more than meets the eye in those vague rumors regarding the expansion of the major leagues to the Pacific Coast. It isn't idle conversation any more. It has reached the serious discussion stage. The other day the National League held a meeting for the purpose of recodifying rules. But the club presidents were somewhere else in secret session, weighing the pros and cons of grabbing Los Angeles and San Francisco in a ten-team league.

Bonds called in November for redemption before maturity totaled $147,334,000, the largest amount for that month since 1946, when $180,555,000 was redeemed. The total compared with $183,220,000 in the preceding month and $9,948,000 in November, 1953.

Despite higher incomes and better education, thousands of nonwhite families in New York still are unable to get housing outside the city's "rigid ghetto sections," an official of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday.

Today at long last the Senate of the United States comes face to face with the decision it has put off for so many months, a decision unpleasant to make but inevitable and essential if the honor, prestige and dignity of the Senate itself are to be maintained in the eyes of the American people.
Dr. Norman Salit, president of the Synagogue Council of America, questioned last night whether Germany had put a stop to the anti-Semitic policy that prevailed in the era of Adolf Hitler.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Senate leaders expect final action on the McCarthy censure resolution and adjournment of the Senate on Thursday night.
LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The people, the Parliament and the Throne, the trinity on which Britain rests, acclaimed Sir Winston Churchill on his eightieth birthday today.
LE KEF, Tunisia, Nov. 30 -- The Tunisian representatives sent out from Tunis to make peace with the Fellagha rebels reached the troubled areas today.

John Francis Roche, admitted slayer of five persons and convicted for the rape-murder of a 14-year-old school girl last June 2, was sentenced yesterday to die in the electric chair at Sing Sing in the week of Jan. 10.

Directors of the New York Trust Company have authorized payment of an extra dividend of 50 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of $1.50 a share, it was announced yesterday. The board also approved a proposal to increase the authorized capital stock and announced plans to split the common stock two-for-one.

Optimism pervaded the Popular Price Shoe Show of America at the New Yorker and McAlpin Hotels yesterday. Exhibitors and buyers said most people in the industry now predicted a good season while last year a haze of gloom hung over the market.

The newest restaurant to enjoy a vogue in New York is an agreeable place at 3 East Forty-eighth Street called Michael's Pub. Michael Pearman, formerly of the Barberry Room, has opened what is essentially a steak house with a British accent.

The Belair Stud's Nashua and the Wheatley Stable's High Voltage yesterday were named the champion 2-year-olds of 1954 by the racing secretaries of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations. Nashua took the honors among the colts and High Voltage was rated best among the fillies.

PETROPOLIS, Nov. 30 -- The inter-American economic conference gave concrete evidence today of progress. It opened its final phase with a plenary session that adopted nine resolutions on stimulating transportation and tourist travel.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Needing 281 to avoid an innings defeat, England lost two more wickets this morning before a heavy downpour stopped play 35 minutes before lunch on the fifth day of the first test against Australia.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Powerful Democrats came to the aid of the Eisenhower Administration today as the White House itself rejected as "war action" any naval blockade of Communist China.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- Queen Elizabeth II outlined at the opening of Parliament today a legislative program proposing increased retirement pensions and other social service benefits. This program seemed calculated by the Conservative Government to leave the Labor party with few issues on which to garner votes in a general election.
New state-wide youth courts and a greatly expanded probation system for criminals under the age of 21 were proposed yesterday by a subcommittee of the state's Temporary Commission on the Courts.
LONDON, Nov. 30 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of Sir Winston Churchill's address at the ceremony held to celebrate his eightieth birthday:
Unruly winds badgered trans-Atlantic shipping bound for New York yesterday, but at the same time they pushed overland and overseas aircraft to new, economically won records.
BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- A Northeast Airlines passenger plane, with six men and a woman aboard, vanished today on a flight from Boston to Berlin, N. H.
DOWNSVILLE, N. Y., Nov. 28 -- A fast-spreading man-made lake near this Catskill Mountains community marks man's newest fight against the effects of drought on New York City.

The Knott Hotels Corporation has leased the Winfield Scott Hotel in Elizabeth, N. J., for twenty-one years with purchase option. The Jersey hotel, which becomes the twenty-eighth in the Knott chain, is valued at $600,000.

GENEVA, Nov. 30 -- Five days after the first request of the United States Consulate General in Geneva, Chinese Communist representatives met here last night with United States representatives to hear a protest against the imprisonment of United States airmen as spies by Red China.

BOCA RATON, Fla., Nov. 30 (UP) -- American coffee drinkers will turn to other beverages unless the coffee industry takes steps to overcome an "unhealthy condition," speakers told the National Coffee Association here today.

JERUSALEM, Nov. 30 -- An attempt to establish a direct telephone line between Israeli and Jordanian commanders in the Jerusalem area failed today. When officials gathered this morning for signing of the agreement the Jordanian representative proposed a change.

ATLANTA, Nov. 30 -- The contract bridge team of John R. Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia and B. Jay Becker and George Rapee of New York City this afternoon continued to lead a forty-one-team field in the 1954 open team-of-four championship. It is the blue ribbon event of the twenty-eighth annual winter national championships.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman spent yesterday in conferences running the full gamut of the problems of his incoming administration.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- A professional administrator of union welfare funds testified today he made about $40,000 a year handling thirteen funds, including four for which he had paid two union officials commissions of $45,000.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Nov. 30 -- Indications have been received here that the Communist Chinese Government may soon officially recognize President Tito's regime.

WITH the winter game feeding programs getting closer every day, a number of hunting clubs are planning "open house" outings and events designed to raise funds to carry out such programs. Organized fox and rabbit hunts and assorted shoots are well represented on the schedule.

CAMP MATSUSHIMA, Japan, Wednesday, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Thirteen Japanese World War II pilots, including one who took part in the attack on Pearl Harbor, were graduated yesterday into Japan's new Air Force.
TOKYO, Nov. 30 -- Shigeru Yoshida, in perhaps his last speech as Premier, told the Japanese today that he considered communism the "greatest problem faced by the free nations."

SAIGON, Vietnam, Nov. 30 -The dismissal yesterday of Gen. Nguyen Van Hinh as Chief of staff of the Vietnamese Army produced no surprise here among Vietnamese officials. However they felt that the action by Bao Dai, the Chief of State, had not ended the political crisis.
OMAHA, Nebr., Nov. 30 (UP) -- Floyd Curry's goal at 18:14 of the last period gave the Montreal Canadiens a 3-3 tie with the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hockey League encounter tonight.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The French National Assembly adopted today the constitutional reform bill that has been under discussion for four years.

HUDSON, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- The task force appointed by Governor-elect Averell Harriman to make recommendations for combating unemployment in this state gave the cold shoulder today to suggestions that New York adopt the tactics used by southern states to attract new industries.

The two-story, ninety-one-year-old Yorkville Court building at 153 East Fifty-seventh Street is to be replaced by an eighteen-story office structure. The property was sold by the city at auction yesterday for $522,000. This was $22,000 more than the asking price at a previous auction last June, when the city failed to get any bids.

THE spirit of the evening was French. The principal musicians, Robert Casadesus and Zino Francescatti, were French. The program was of the French school. The beneficiary of the concert was the American Library in Paris.
The bail on which Patrolman Donald Goodrich is being held as a material witness in the Brooklyn courtesy card investigation was cut yesterday from $50,000 to $15,000.

Determined selling hit the stock market in the final thirty minutes yesterday. Traders packed 720,000 shares of volume into the last half-hour, with the tape running as much as three minutes behind the floor.

The New York Knickerbockers snapped a four-game losing streak the hard way last night at Madison Square Garden, beating the Philadelphia Warriors in overtime, 95 -- 91. Fort Wayne's Pistons increased their lead in the Western Division of the National Basketball Association by outscoring the champion Minneapolis Lakers, 92 -- 90, in the opener of the twin bill before 9,823 fans.

A bill requiring that vents be connected to apartment gas water heater appliances to carry fumes outdoors was unanimously approved yesterday by the City Council. The Council moved hastily in an effort to prevent further deaths from faulty use of gas water heaters.
Cadets and other personnel at the United States Military Academy will participate there for three days, beginning today, in a mass blood donation to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

SEOUL, Korea, Nov. 30 -Minority members of the South Korean National Assembly laid the groundwork today for a new Opposition party. They were angered by President Syngman Rhee's success in pushing through a constitutional amendment that allows him to run for re-election as often as he wants.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Nov. 30 (AP) -- Auburn and Baylor will meet in the Gator Bowl football game here Dec. 31.
DETROIT, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Chrysler Corporation narrowly avoided a' strike today to rush on without hindrance in the 1955 car market battle.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- A broad reorganization of the Immigration and Naturalization Service virtually has been completed.

BOSTON, Nov. 30 -- The Massachusetts Committee of Citizens for the Censure of McCarthy urged citizens of the commonwealth today to telegraph their Senators, Leverett Saltonstall, Republican, and John F. Kennedy Democrat, "expressing your stand in favor of uncompromising censure."

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- William G. Stratton of Illinois announced here today the selection of a site in the western part of Chicago upon which a $5,000,000 psychiatric and research training hospital will be built.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Nov. 30 -- Member states voted 40 to 0 today to extend United Nations assistance for five years more to Arab refugees who fled from their homes during the Palestine conflict six years ago.
To make expensive - looking clothes at inexpensive prices is the aim of Henry Rosenfeld, whose cruise collection was shown yesterday afternoon on the seventh floor of Russeks.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Nov. 30 -- If insurance companies get authority to sell variable annuities based on common stock, investment companies fear they may be crowded out of competition and may have to become insurance companies themselves.
A study of the usefulness of sending aloft an unmanned earth satellite vehicle was proposed yesterday by a committee headed by the chief of the Navy's Viking rocket project.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Nov. 30 -- Dr. Herbert V. Evatt, leader of the Australian Labor party, completed today his submissions to the Federal executive of the Labor party in support of his charge that "outside interests" controlled the party in Victoria.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- An economic offensive against communism in Asia is the central feature of a Foreign Operations Administration program for which it is now presenting estimates to the Bureau of the Budget.

Trade selling tumbled coffee prices 110 to 195 points (hundredths of a cent a pound) on 56,000 bags yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. The distant positions were weakest. There was general liquidation and hedge selling.
Let me compliment you on your editorial of Nov. 24 "Aliens' Detention." I also read the letter of the District Director of Immigration for New York, Edward J. Shaughnessy.

The New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad has acquired all the outstanding funded debt of the Boston and Providence Railroad Corporation, now in reorganization. This amounts to $2,170,000 face amount of 5 per cent debentures, due July 1, 1938.

The United States Treasury has undertaken the second largest piece of refinancing in its history, an operation involving maturing or called issues aggregating $17.3 billions. While the final results will not be available until the latter part of the week, preliminary figures issued by the Treasury would seem to constitute more than adequate evidence as to the success of this huge transaction.
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- One of the principal leaders of the fellagha bands in Tunisia has accepted an offer to surrender his arms in return for safe conduct, the French Residency in Tunis reported tonight.

A 14-year-old boy admitted to the police yesterday that he accidentally had shot and killed a 16-year-old Bronx youth last Friday night. The victim was Nicholas Scochemaro of 1515 Charlotte Street, whose body was found in a rear doorway at 1503 Charlotte Street.

ANKARA, Turkey, Nov. 30 -- Proposals by several major foreign companies to amend Turkey's new old law are now under study by the Government. Many observers fear that submission of the suggested changes to Parliament will revive the political struggle over the oil question that took place earlier this year.

LONDON, Nov. 30 -- The brief reference to defense contained in Queen Elizabeth's Speech from the Throne today is interpreted by expert sources here as an attempt to guard from premature publicity a proposed major shift in British defense policy.

VIENNA, Nov. 30 -- President Eisenhower, Sir Winston Churchill and Marshal Tito were among twenty-five heads of state who sent messages today to the general assembly of the World Veterans Federation in support of its "crusade for peace and freedom."

Frederick F. Greenman, as liquidating trustee of the Bail Fund of the Civil Rights Congress of New York, is seeking a judgment for $10,742 against the Communist party as the result of two bail bond forfeitures.

Today's new film is "Track of the Cat," a Warner drama in CinemaScope and WarnerColor, with Robert Mitchum, Teresa Wright, Diana Lynn, Tab Hunter and Beulah Bondi, at the Paramount. The Wayne-Fellows Production was directed by William A. Wellman.

It's now official: there are more savings dollars in savings and loan institutions than there are in savings banks. On Sept. 30 the savings banks held $25,838,000,000 and their newer sisters in the field held $25,895,000,000. The December issue of the National Savings and Loan Journal says the figures were "recently confirmed by the Home Loan Bank Board" in Washington.
HARTFORD, Nov. 30 -- Gov.-elect Abraham A. Ribicoff, who takes office on Jan. 5, began today a series of hearings on budget requests by state agencies and departments.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (UP) -- The State of Tennessee and three municipal power bodies told the Securities Exchange Commission today there were "substantial doubts" about the legality of the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract.
CHICAGO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:
PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The merger of Ford S. A. F., French affiliate of the Ford Motor Company in the United States, and Simca, one of the major French automobile producers, was concluded here today.

MINEOLA, L. I., Nov. 30 -Chivalry lives, still. A stenographer lost her new $12.50 bonnet in a sudden gust today and cried out in distress when she saw it disappear under a train. Then she watched like a storybook princess while an engineer and conductor gingerly and gallantly reversed their seven-car train and gave her back her feathered chapeau.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Soviet Union has published statistics on part of its trade with the outside world. A report issued in Russia last month and made available to the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe discloses in general terms the volume of Soviet transactions with Western Europe for last year and the first half of this year.
Willie Mays, the Giants' spectacular center fielder, called on Secretary Eddie Brannick at the Giants' offices early yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- A Civil Aeronautics Board hearing examiner recommended today granting of a permit to a Venezuelan airline, Aerovias Venezolanas, S. A., to fly from Maracaibo to New Orleans and Miami.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Nov. 30 -- Samuel Goldwyn Jr., son of the veteran producer, is going into independent motion-picture production on his own.
SYLACAUGA, Ala., Nov. 30 (AP) -- A meteorite crashed through the roof of a house today and slightly injured Mrs. Hewlett Hodges.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Louis E. Wolfson, top-ranking challenger -- to date -- for control of Montgomery Ward Co., told a Chicago audience today that a three-for-one stock split would be among his first proposals if he gained a seat on the Ward board.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- The free world is paying off a debt when it honors Sir Winston Churchill on his eightieth birthday because to a very considerable degree the free world owes its survival to that indomitable old man. The inspiration of his leadership held England fast against the greedy dictatorships of Eurasia in 1940 and 1941. In those finest hours the cause of democracy was saved.
TOKYO, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Japan now is the largest shipper of rayon yarn to Red China, the newspaper Asahi reported today.
Details of the worst nuclear reactor accident that has been disclosed were reported here yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

NEW DELHI, India, Nov. 30 -- Communism in India has been set back in the last eighteen months by economic headway made here by the democratic regime under Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's "strong leadership," George V. Allen, retiring United States Ambassador to India, declared today.

CHICAGO, Nov. 30 -- Herbert B. Megran, President of the Board of Trustees of the University of Illinois, will fly to New York Friday to urge Dr. David Dodds Henry, Executive Vice Chancellor of New York University, to accept the Illinois University presidency.
The Minute Maid Corporation, pioneer maker of frozen fruit juice concentrates, has purchased the Snow Crop division of Clinton Foods, Inc., Clinton, Iowa, producer of many types of frozen foods.
Reorganization of the Federal Housing Administration "under respected, competent auspices" was demanded yesterday by Robert Moses, City Construction Coordinator.

The traditional splendor of the opening of Britain's Parliament yesterday was never more appropriate, it being the Prime Minister's eightieth birthday and with a lovely young Queen to ride in the golden state coach and sit on a golden throne to read the speech.

Winners of the 1954 Nationwide Crochet Contest were announced yesterday at the Henry Hudson Hotel. Cash prizes totaling $2,600 have been awarded to crocheters whose entries were submitted through state, county and local fairs.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- Military physicians were told today to watch out for the "nestler," a service-man type who found ways of clinging to his hospital bed beyond the needs of his emotional or physical maladjustment.
LOS ANGELES, Nov. 30 -- Marshal Montgomery said today that the United States "for the first time in many years has a home defense problem -- air attack over the Arctic."

A new regulation designed to give the State Athletic Commission closer control over managers who obtain bouts for boxers managed by others was an outgrowth of the commission's hearings on the sport in this state at its offices yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these counts:
PHILADELPHIA, Nov. 30 (UP) -- Presidents of more than thirty Pennsylvania colleges made personal calls today on business and industry leaders to solicit funds to help support private schools.
A strike by 300 workers at the Fulton Fish Market, called suddenly yesterday morning, was brought to an end at midnight by a settlement agreement.
HOUSTON, Nov. 30 -- The Dodgers began repairing their Fences today.

Two promotions in the freight department of the United States Lines were announced yesterday by V. J. Freeze, vice president in charge of traffic. The changes resulted from the recent retirement of P. E. McIntyre as general freight traffic manager.

The film industry's advertising and promotion branches were accused last night of "doing more to destroy public confidence" in testimonial advertising by star personalities than any other similar group. The charge was made by Jules Alberti, president of Endorsements, Inc., agency specializing in testimonial advertising, in a talk before a class in business news reporting at New York University.
Roy M. Cohn said last night that The New York Times' coverage of the pro-McCarthy rally in Madison Square Garden Monday night was "a thoroughly dishonest job."
The Waterfront Commission said yesterday it had detected a revival of the outlawed public-loading racket on the piers and announced new, stringent regulations to check it.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 30 (AP) -- Senator Flanders' Voice of America broadcast on Thanksgiving Day was entitled "An Open Letter to the Russian People."

Representatives of American Airlines and the Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., are scheduled to meet today with David L. Cole, the referee endeavoring to settle the dispute over the carrier's non-stop transcontinental flights.

HOUGHTON, Mich., Nov. 30 -- A picturesque forest of 1,700 acres in the Upper Peninsula, a model sawmill and a town of a dozen houses and two school buildings were given to the Michigan College of Mining and Technology today by the Ford Motor Company Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Experts of the State and Defense departments are studying the possibilities of seeking release of Americans imprisoned in China by blockading Communist China. They boggle at the military and political problems such action would raise.
The League of Composers and the International Society for Contemporary Music, United States Section, have been merged into a single organization, it was announced yesterday.
Julius Raab, Chancellor of Austria, was a guest of New York and was honored by Mayor Wagner yesterday.

The Guaranty Trust Company of New York has authorized payment of a quarterly dividend of 80 cents and an extra dividend of 50 cents a share on the capital stock. Both dividends will be distributed on Jan. 17 to holders of record on Dec. 15.

The growing threat to public security from criminal depredations in New York City is readily apparent. This increase in crime is no isolated or short-term fluctuation but a clearly defined trend of increasing criminal activity. It is clear that some means must be found to restore and renew an atmosphere of law and order.

As part of their campaign to wreck the Paris accords for a strengthened NATO that includes a rearmed Germany, the Soviets have now launched a plan for an Eastern "NATO." The purpose of this plan is to create, under their control, a unified command, or a joint military staff, for the armies of the whole Soviet bloc, tied in close alliance with the armies of Communist China.

Yesterday's formal opening of the new Washington facilities of the Voice of America was properly the occasion for good wishes to this instrument of American foreign policy. It is the important business of this public agency to explain to the diverse peoples of the world that the United States seeks friendship, fair play and goodwill.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate voted tonight for a quick investigation to find out whether there had been unauthorized checking on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's mail. The action was taken after Senator McCarthy had charged that someone had "forged" the signature of Senator Guy M. Gillette, Democrat of Iowa, to letters asking the Post Office Department to check his mail and that of his staff in 1952.
David Bar-Illan, pianist, played a debut recital at Carnegie Hall last evening. A native of Israel, Mr. Bar-Illan won a scholarship to the Juilliard School in 1917,
JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 1 -- Mr. Strijdom began today to choose members of his Cabinet. He may make his first major policy statement Saturday.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Quadrille" on the night of Dec. 8 at the Coronet Theatre for the benefit of the Park Association of New York City. Mrs. Harold Irving Pratt heads the benefit committee.

DETROIT, Dec. 1 -- A police and postal investigation of the anonymous communication that led Dr. David D. Henry to withdraw as a candidate for the presidency of the University of Illinois was in prospect today.
For the season when tradition holds sway, Altman's Country Shop has been stocked with a myriad of early American antiques appropriately "used" in three newly decorated rooms of the period.
The nation's guided missile program has cost roughly one billion dollars so far and is "just hitting its stride" in production of usable weapons.

That frozen vegetables are time-savers is a fact well appreciated by those who use them. They eliminate the necessity for washing, trimming and cutting the vegetables. For this reason many cooks consider well spent the extra pennies that frozen vegetables often cost in comparison with fresh or canned versions.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Jesse Owens, a star of the 1936 Olympics, today suggested it was time to quit spreading gloom about this nation's chances against Russia in the 1956 Olympics.

BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 1 (Reuters) -- Australia won the first of the five-match test series for the mythical cricket ashes today, beating England, the holder, by an innings and 154 runs, with over a day to spare.
The National Association of Manufacturers mobilized its energies yesterday for a major effort to win a Federal income tax ceiling of 35 per cent.
MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- A formal warning of the consequences of arming West Germany is expected here to be issued to the Western powers tomorrow by the eight Communist governments of East Europe.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- In these days of speed-up basketball, height appears to be the chief concern of collegiate coaches. It happens to be one of the problems confronting Coach Jim McDermott at Iona College.

If we may judge from the evidence of the figures for the first ten months of the year, 1954 may establish a post-war low in strike-caused idleness for the nation. Through the month of October the number of strikes recorded by the Bureau of Labor Statistics was 3,050, and the number of man-days lost 19,800,000.

The International Longshoremen's Association can have a "helping hand" from the Waterfront Commission in a housecleaning campaign, if it so desires, Lieut. Gen. George P. Hays, New York member of the bi-state agency, asserted yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 1 -- Establishment of a nonprofit cooperative trade association, made up of twenty-eight companies representing 3,500 employes and an annual business volume of $50,000,000, was announced today at a meeting of the group at the Statler Hotel here.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A crowd of 90,000 Britons, among them Sir Anthony Eden, stood uneasily at attention in Wembley Stadium this afternoon while the Royal Life Guards band played "Deutschland Ueber Alles."

American industry was urged yesterday to undertake a far-reaching "Atomic Marshall Plan" to raise the health, wealth and happiness of mankind throughout the free world by enabling it to share in the virtually unlimited potentialities of the power within the atom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The Housing and Home Finance Agency today approved a loan of $1,650,000 to New York University to help finance construction of a new dormitory at the university's medical school.
Plans for an assault by scientific airmen on one of the last big barriers between earthbound man and the freedom of outer space were laid here yesterday.

CARSON CITY, Nev., Dec. 1 -- Gov. Charles Russell today signed articles of certification of the election of Alan Bible, Democrat, to the United States Senate. A dispute had threatened to delay seating of Mr. Bible as successor to the late Senator Pat McCarran.
Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and associates are offering today $15,000,000 of 3 1/4 per cent first mortgage bonds of the Laclede Gas Company.

The South American Gold and Platinum Company announced yesterday it had invested "more than $1,000,000" in the Ecuadorian Corporation as part of a program to diversify activities and find more profitable use for surplus capital funds.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- An effective national security policy for the United States demands an expanding economy, flexible defense force and ties with friendly nations, Maj. Gen. James M. Gavin said today.

Any misgivings that the New York Central Railroad might have had about revealing its plans for ending its Hudson ferry service and commuter traffic on its West Shore and Putnam divisions appeared to be fully justified yesterday.

The first of 6,000,000 food packages going as gifts from the American people to needy families in forty-four foreign countries are now on the way overseas. About half of these Christmas gifts will go to Europe, a quarter to the Far East, with the balance destined for the Near East, Africa and Latin America.

Three of the eight harness drivers suspended for six months on Nov. 10 testified yesterday as hearings opened before George P. Monaghan, state commissioner for the sport. The suspensions followed a delay over a financial dispute at Yankers Raceway in October.
After nine seasons of varied fortunes in the post Ed Danowski has resigned as head coach of football at Fordham University. No successor has been named.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 1 -- Some light was thrown here yesterday on charges made last month by President Sukarno that elements seeking to overthrow the present Left-Nationalist Indonesian Cabinet "were selling their country to foreigners."
HOUSTON, Dec. 1 -- Leo Durocher, once again baseball's glamour boy through his world series sweep, moved into the spotlight here today.
ALBANY, Dec. 1 -- Republican lawmakers are planning to confer with Jacob K. Javits, the Attorney General-elect, on a party program on New York City finances.
Traffic signs' warning "Tow Away Zone -- No Standing -- No Parking," blossomed along Thirty-fourth, Forty-second and Fifty-seventh Streets yesterday.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 1 (AP) -- R. W. Hallowell's Territory was declared the winner in the $5,000 Straight Face Purse today after Rock Cottage, who finished first, had been disqualified and placed last.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Vic Seixas, the United States champion from Philadelphia, defeated Australia s Lew Hoad today, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, 7 -- 5, to reach the final of the Victorian tennis championships.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 1 -- A new film adaptation of the D. W. Griffith epic, "The Birth of a Nation," originally released in 1915, will be financed by a syndicate of business men, it was announced today by Phil L. Ryan, spokesman for the group and a veteran production executive.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange eased 6 to 12 points yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Foreign Office issued a statement tonight emphasizing that while Britain had not been "consulted" on the treaty between the United States and Nationalist China, she had been "generally informed" and had been assured the treaty was "purely defensive."

Three waves -- two of selling and one of buying -- hit the New York Stock Exchange yesterday. The first was a surge of liquidation, at the opening. The second was a strong support movement that followed soon after and carried prices back to about their Tuesday's close. Then, after three hours of quiet trading, a third wave struck and sent prices lower.

ATLANTA, Dec. 1 -- The contract bridge team of John R. Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia and B. Jay Becker and George Rapee of New York today held its lead in the Open Team-of-Four championship, one of the major events of the annual winter national championships.
YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Dec. 1 -- The first twenty-two miles [black line on maps] of the 241-mile turnpike under construction across northern Ohio [broken line] was opened to traffic today.
PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The expectation here that the United States will reduce its financial support of the Vietnam Army is considered a probable source of embarrassment for Premier Pierre Mendes-France.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture report oft today's livestock market follows:

The thorough, perceptive and carefully reasoned report calling for establishment of a Youth Court with jurisdiction over offenders aged 16 to 21 should command the prompt attention of all who, professionally or otherwise, have an interest in juvenile delinquency and crime and in the structure of our courts in New York State.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 1 -- National army troops and police forces fought in Saigon all last night. This was construed in some quarters as possibly the first incident in a civil war in South Vietnam.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- Protestantism in the United States was urged today to "repudiate completely" all forms of racial segregation.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 1 -- Amherst's 6-foot 4-inch center, Doug Hawkins, scored 21 points tonight to lead the Lord Jeffs to 61-56 upset victory over Yale in the season's opener for both teams.
The Fruehauf Trailer Company received this week $20,000,000 in orders for 2,500 new freight-hauling units, the most ever ordered in any similar period in the industry's forty-year-old history.
Two newspaper men contended last night in a panel discussion that withholding from newspapers information on the public record constituted an abridgment of press freedom.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Presdent Eisenhower has approved a national minerals policy to strengthen security and encourage an orderly and vigorous development of domestic resources.
East Harlem's pistol - toting shopkeepers are keeping their weapons loaded against the day when the experiment in police saturation of the Twenty-fifth Precinct ends.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 -- Judge Edward Blythin reserved decision this afternoon on defense motions for acquittal of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard.
Toledo, Ohio, sold $4,100,000 of water revenue bonds at a net interest cost of 1.93607 per cent at competitive bidding yesterday.

Sheriff Hoy of Westchester County has done well in refusing to accept in the Eastview Jail any more aliens detained by the immigration service pending final disposition of their cases. He "did not like the idea" of putting people in jail without a conviction.

The broker who tried to measure sugar movements as the Department of Agriculture changed its import quotas has been sounding like the man who watched through a knothole as his friend fought a tough battle -- "He's up . . he's down . . he's up . ." Yesterday he took his eye from the knothole with a sigh of relief.

Governor-elect Averell Harriman has wasted no time in coming to grips with some of the fundamental problems he will face after Jan. 1. We are particularly pleased to note that, a full month before taking office, he has conferred with the chairman of the fifteen-member Temporary State Commission on Educational Finances, Chancellor Henry Townley Heald of New York University.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) James N. Juliana, staff director of the Senate Investigations subcommittee, said today the group would resume public hearings Tuesday in its inquiry looking for Communists in defense plants.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Bundles of petitions opposing the censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy reached Capitol Hill today under armed guards, who promptly ran into a Senate investigation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Government is tightening its licensing requirements for the export of scrap iron and steel.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 1 -- The Soviet Union proposed today that the United Nations General Assembly call another conference on the unification of Korea.

The selling efforts of New York department stores were crowned with success in November. Eleven stores registered an over-all gain of 13 per cent over their sales in the same month a year ago, according to a survey by The New York Times.
PAWTUCKET, R. I., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Alfonse Coy rode four winners and Jake Lingle's Larry Ellis came from behind to take the $7,500 Old Stone Mill Handicap at Narragansett Park today.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Landseair, a $5.30-for-$2 shot, carried the colors of Sylvester Rich of Bradford, Pa., to victory in the featured $3,000 Nautilus Purse at Tropical Park today.
It was reported on Nov. 21 that the Council of Bishops of the Methodist Church had announced themselves opposed to universal military training.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission decided today in an unusual action to hold hearings on the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract before the full commission.

The Texas Gas Transmission Corporation plans to expand its natural gas pipeline capacity by 111,000,000 cubic feet a day next year. The Federal Power Commission is being asked to approve the $17,500,000 project.

At least 9,500 pints of blood will be needed by the regional Red Cross blood program this month to provide for those requiring blood over the holidays, Dr. William M. Markel, the program's administrator, said yesterday.
BONN, Dec. 1 -- West Germany intends to draw on government or semi-government insurance organizations to provide long-term credit for exports.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Sir Winston Churchill, who on his eightieth birthday basked in the acclaim of Parliament yesterday, apologized to the House of Commons today and expressed "my regret to the House for what I said last week."
Fresh fruit cups have the distinction of being adaptable to any course in the meal.

HELSINKI, Finland, Dec. 1 -- Finland is to get a new loan from the Soviet Union, the second in a year. A ten-year loan of 40,000,000 rubles (about $10,000,000) was granted at the beginning of this year.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, Dec. 1 -- The angler with the urge to fish in waters still undeveloped, using the full gamut of methods, ranging from the artificial lure through the assorted baits, and including the spear, will find real opportunity in the Bahamas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Office of Defense Mobilization got under way today its plan for recruiting a "reserve" staff of executives to be available for service in wartime.
The boards of the Indian Head Mills, Inc., and the Naumkeag Steam Cotton Company have approved a merger proposal, according to James E. Robison, president of Indian Head.
A spirit of fun pervaded the room in which Macy's exhibited its selections of North and South resort wear yesterday morning.

An intricately fashioned glass vase from the Netherlands, one of a group of important contemporary pieces to be made by the sandblasting technique, was presented yesterday to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam, now completing its first American tour.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy asserted tonight, as the Senate neared a vote to censure him for his conduct, "I don't think the American people are at all fooled."

Net profit of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation for the nine months ended on Oct. 30 amounted to $2,200,000, it was announced yesterday. This compares with $2,100,000 for the corresponding period of 1953.

In 1946 Marshall MacDuffie, a former official of the State Department, headed a U. N. R. R. A. mission in the Ukraine and got to know N. S. Khrushchev. After Khrushchev succeeded Malenkov as First Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, Mr. MacDuffie cabled Khrushchev for permission to visit Russia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Paul M. Butler, South Bend, Ind., attorney, was reported tonight to be leading the field in the race for Democratic National Chairman.
This is one of a series on the American cook at home.

ROME, Dec. 1 -- Where once the citizens of imperial Rome roared with delight at the skill and daring of their favorite charioteers, Romans of today will applaud the exploits of the soccer players who have supplanted chariot drivers in the public estimation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Secretary of State Dulles announced today that the United States and the Republic of China on Formosa had concluded negotiations for a mutual defense treaty.
OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 1 -- This atomic city, built by the Government during World War II, has been gradually learning how to do things for itself.

TORONTO, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs went on a third-period scoring spree tonight, counting four times, to beat the Boston Bruins, 6 -- 0. Goalie Harry Lumley turned in his third shutout of the National Hockey League season.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Dec. 1 -- Hudson County Judge Paul J. Duffy today dismissed a year-old indictment against Jersey City Commissioner Donald Spence and three business men because of a technical defect. However, he ruled that Mr. Spence, who is director of the Municipal Department of Revenue and Finance and his administrative secretary, Mrs. Isabel Churlin, must stand trial on another indictment charging conspiracy to defraud the city.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland of California, today burned his last substantial bridge with the Eisenhower Administration when he announced on the Senate floor that he would vote against censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.
One the country's leading ship financing experts, Walter H. Saunders, has resigned as second vice president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company to enter the shipping field.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The State Department is considering the issuance of a statement affirming the United States' determination to do everything within its power to thwart aggression in the Middle East.

Raymond C. Harwood, executive vice president of Harper Brothers. and Dr. Robert R. Palmer and Dr. Whitney J. Oates of the Princeton University faculty, have been elected trustees of the Princeton University Press.
A Long Island State Park Commission patrolman resigned last night after a call before the Brooklyn grand jury investigating traffic courtesy cards.

Memories of old Amsterdam and the old Nieuw Amsterdam came alive here briefly yesterday when St. Nicholas, patron saint of the Dutch, rode a white horse down Fifth Avenue while his servant, Black Pieter, carried a switch alongside in search of small-fry rascals.

It is a pleasure to note that the post office is taking a realistic view of its influential position in the field of communications. Motion pictures of its services and television programs about its operations have been developed, and in October the new Postal Manual showed how much can be done to improve relations between the taxpayer and the Federal Government merely by translating regulations from bureaucratic gibberish into clear and simple English.

HARTFORD, Dec. 1 -- The solution of Connecticut's school problems appears to depend more on state aid than on Federal assistance, according to decisions reached here today. This preference even envisages a higher state tax.

NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- The imprisonment of the thirteen Americans by Communist China was described tonight by Dr. George K. C. Yeh, Minister of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China in Formosa, as "an attempt to create a situation for some neutral country to step in and mediate."
Frank Costello finally had a winning day in Federal Court yesterday.
Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, said yesterday that the hope of world peace rested in negotiations by our statesmen backed by military strength.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- A second Mr. Wolfson, not related to Florida industrialist Louis E. Wolfson, appeared today as a figure in the forthcoming contest for control of Montgomery Ward Co. He is Isaac Wolfson, chairman and managing director of Great Universal Stores, Ltd., mammoth British merchandising enterprise with retail, mail order and manufacturing divisions.
On a cold, gray morning, edged with a hint of snow, Maj. Gen. Thomas W. Herren Stepped ashore yesterday from the ferryboat to Governors Island and took command of the First Army.
The president of the Thoroughbred Racing Associations predicted yesterday that racetrack attendance figures for 1954 would reach a new high.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Special Senate Committee headed by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, unanimously recommended censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, on these three counts:

Aleer J. Couri, United States Appraiser of Merchandise, who was to have sailed on the liner United States for a two-week study of European cargo clearance procedures, canceled the trip at the last moment yesterday to await the result of a cargo clearance experiment of his own.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 1 -- India's unrelenting campaign to separate three small west coast territories from their four-centuries-old Portuguese rule and annex them to the Indian Union appeared to be boiling toward a new crisis today.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 1 -- The Investment Bankers Association convention here was told today that the success of the Treasury's $17,000,000,000 debt refunding has brought nearer the phase of heavy Government debt refundings directed largely at the banking system.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Charlie Norkus of Bayonne, N. J., scored a unanimous ten-round decision over Roland LaStarza of New York tonight. They met in the feature of the annual Chirstmas Fund Shoy in the Cleveland Arena.

BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- For the second day nightfall brought a halt to the ground search for seven persons missing aboard a Northeast Airlines plane that plunged into the mountain wilderness in New Hampshire yesterday.
HOUSTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Omaha moved a step closer to triple A baseball today as the minors completed their draft with a low take of forty-four players for $135,450.
COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 1 -- Negotiations are well advanced between the Ceylonese Government and the Shell Oil Company for the building of a $40,000,000 petroleum refinery in the outskirts of Colombo.

Scottish dancing and music will be features of the entertainment at the annual bazaar for the benefit of the Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn to be held tomorrow night at the Nurses Residence, 45 Woodruff Avenue, Brooklyn.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- A sharp recovery in British Government issues helped to steady the stock markets here today, although most prices again finished lower.
An aircraft mechanic was fined $5 by a Queens magistrate yesterday for violating a state statute against non-essential work on the Sabbath.

HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 1 (AP) -- Gov.-elect Averell Harriman's economic task force today examined the possibility of reviving Hudson River commerce here as a step toward alleviating "serious" unemployment.
CHICAGO, Dec. 1 -- Speculative cross currents were numerous in the grain and soybean futures trade today, making for conflicting price trends and unexpected moves.

VIENNA, Dec. 1 -- Curtis Campaigne of Montclair, N. J., executive director of the World Veterans Fund, was elected secretary general of the World Veterans Federation at its general meeting here today.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- An enthusiastic welcome was given tonight to "Accounting for Love," which opened at the Saville Theatre.
Your last two editorials on the plight of detained aliens are deserving of high praise and commendation.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 1 -- Twenty-two fellagha rebels surrendered their arms near Mateur in Northern Tunisia today. They were given safe conduct in return.

CHICAGO, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association's television committee decided today to recommend continued national control of football TV, but emphasized this would not rule out televised games on a regional basis.
BOSTON, Dec. 1 -- New York defeated Chicago hero today by a top-heavy score of 276 to 106.
By economic aid rather than its own arms the United States can stop the march of communism in Asia, Sir John Kotelawala, Prime Minister of Ceylon, said yesterday.
TRENTON, Dec. 1 -- New Jersey renewed today its efforts to end the disastrous price wars that have long plagued the state's retail gasoline trade.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- The United States Information Agency said today that Senator Ralph E. Flanders, Republican of Vermont, was not in conflict with Administration policy in an overseas broadcast that Senator William E. Jenner, Republican of Indiana, denounced as "twisted thinking."
SINCE Eartha Kitt is an oddly gifted actress, she is a good match for an off-beat play. That might serve as a quick description of "Mrs. Patterson," which opened at the National last evening.

The Bach Aria Group opened its eighth New York season last night at Town Hall and an audience of more than 1,400 Bach devotees assembled to hear the first of the four concerts the group will give there. The program consisted of two complete cantatas and excerpts from eight others.

SPRINGFIELD, Mass., Dec. 1 -- Bill Thieben, 6-foot-6-inch forward, set a Hofstra record by scoring 46 points as he led the Flying Dutchmen to an 85-55 basketball triumph over Springfield College tonight.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- The French Government decided today to advance to Jan. 1 the lifting of import quotas it had been committed to remove on April 1. The action was prompted by an improvement in the balance of trade. The commitment had been made to the Organization for European Economic Cooperation.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- The Government announced today increases in retirement and war pensions and in other benefits.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Chief of Staff, today presented top aviation awards to two Strategic Air Command wings and an officer who parachuted from a jet bomber at 45,200 feet.

At the age of 97, Dr. Maurice J. Lewi admits to some slowing down. He smokes only six or eight cigars a day, not the fourteen he once enjoyed. A steady hand holding a brown Havana waved fragrant clouds about his office as he gave his birthday interview yesterday.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 1 -- The Herbert Hoover Foundation, an organization pledged to preserve the birthplace of the former President and to "advance the educational, scientific and public welfare principles for which he stands," was incorporated here today.

Brutality that led to death was called "a supreme adventure" and sadism "a gag" by one of three adolescents on trial for first-degree murder, according to testimony given yesterday in Kings County Court.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers staved off a late Syracuse rally to beat the Nationals, 88 -- 86, tonight in the first game of a National Basketball Association twin bill at Convention Hall. The loss ended Syracuse's winning streak at seven straight.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 1 -- Charity racketeers are being driven out of New York and are heading for New Jersey, it was asserted here today.

Irra Petina, musical comedy artist and former Metropolitan Opera singer who made a host of friends here with her performance in "Song of Norway," is the star of "Hit the Trail," the new musical opening tonight at the Mark Hellinger Theatre at 8 o'clock.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- The Wes German Government interrupted the prosecution of its case to outlaw the Communist party today and asked for a week's recess.

THAT was Duff Cooper's finest hour. Alone among the members of Neville Chamberlain's Cabinet at the time of Munich in 1938, he refused to agree that capitulation to the totalitarians would bring peace in our time.

The American Jewish Congress charged yesterday that Austria's failure to settle claims of Jewish victims of nazism was a result of "secret clauses" in an agreement between the People's party and the League of Independents, described as a neo-Nazi party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (UP) -- A New York policewoman who joined the Communist party to check on its activities testified today that Communist party clubs in Brooklyn had given money to the Civil Rights Congress "in various ways."
Two city agencies, one new and one reconstituted, took form yesterday at City Hall. The new agency was the Mental Health Board. The revived one was the Mayor's Advisory Committee for the Aged.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities as announced today by the Federal Reserve Board shows the following principal changes for the Week ended Nov. 24:

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Dec. 1 -- The United States has found complete unanimity with the Latin American countries on aims to be pursued in the economic field, Henry F. Holland, Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs, said today.

It is distressing to find so eminent an authority as Hanson Baldwin unwilling to distinguish between positions adopted by debaters in academic institutions (even if those institutions happen to be the United States Military and Naval Academies) and statements made to influence policy by retired officers of the armed forces.

Events today: Martin Schwartz, pianist, Townsend Harris Hall, 12:30 P. M.; "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Nathan Milstein; violinist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Bell Symphony Society, Town Hall, 8:30; Budapest String Quartet, Metropolitan Museum of Art, 8:30.

PARIS, Dec. 1 -- An official statement issued here today said that the preamble to the bill for ratification of the Saar accord submitted to the West German Parliament distorted the meaning of the agreement.

Everything went just right for the Detroit Red Wings in their National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Stanley Cup champions took after the New York Rangers from the start and didn't let up all night as they trounced the Broadway Blues, 6 to 1.
BERLIN, Dec. 1 -- The Communists sought today to use streetcars as political bait.
NEWARK, Dec. 1 -- The sixteenth annual show of the Garden State Cat Club opened here today and brought together 338 aristocrats and commoners of the feline world and 125 fanciers and owners.
A secondary offering of 200,000 shares of common stock of the Federal Paper Board Company, Inc., will be placed on the market today at $36 a share by Goldman, Sachs Co. and associates.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the tenth day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.
Louis A. Wehle of Rochester was reported yesterday as a probable choice for Conservation Commissioner in the new Democratic-Liberal State Administration which takes office Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- The Senate voted tentatively tonight to censure Senator Joseph R. McCarthy. The vote was 67 to 20.
