Blends of cotton and viscose rayon made into cloth for work clothing have proved stronger than 100 per cent cotton, according to John Boyd, textile technologist for Courtaulds, Ltd., British producer of the viscose fiber.
DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 1 -- Fifteen thousand persons turned out this morning for the dedication of the new forty-story Republic Bank Building.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 1 -- The general conference of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted tonight to broaden the dismissal powers of its director general, Dr. Luther Evans.

The Metropolitan Opera has added two American singers to its roster, Rudolf Bing, general manager, announced yesterday. They are Albert Da Costa, tenor, 1954 winner of the Metropolitan Opera Auditions of the Air, and Robert McFerrin, 1953 winner.

MOSCOW, Dec. 1 -- A major campaign has been started here to cut waste, delays and inefficiency in the Soviet building industry, simplify construction and stop elaborate over-ornamentation of buildings.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Two "independent" directors of the Missouri Pacific Railroad today appealed to the Interstate Commerce Commission to block the Alleghany Corporation from gaining control of the road.

The most important task of public relations is to convince American workingmen that economic freedom and political liberty "are inseparable parts of the same ball of wax -- that we must keep them both or we shall lose them both," Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday.

SCRANTON, Pa., Dec. 1 -- A Federal grand jury investigating the death Nov. 22 of William W. Remington in the Federal penitentiary at Lewisburg indicted three inmates today on a general charge of murder.
LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain acknowledged today that the development of nuclear weapons and of long-range high-speed aircraft had outmoded her anti-aircraft defense system.

There is one form of segregation which is perfectly legal and which might well be considered by the states which now face the consequences of the recent Supreme Court decision. This is segregation of the sexes. Not even the present court can call it unconstitutional.
The following recently published booklets that may be of interest to family members are available for 50 cents each from Science Research Associates, 57 West Grand Avenue, Chicago 10, Ill.:

William Mulholland, in a purchase for occupancy, has acquired the one-family house at 164 Sixty-seventh Street in Brooklyn from Olga Hagen. The Sale was made through the Bulkley Horton Company as broker.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 1 -- When Johannes Gerhardus Strijdom, the new South African Prime Minister, was a barefoot boy on his father's farm, he used to chase ostriches and leap on their backs for a free ride.

Two hundred early applicants were on hand at 8:45 A. M. yesterday for the opening of the 1955 automobile license plate season at the local office of the State Bureau of Motor Vehicles, 80 Centre Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- Senator Bourke B. Hickenlooper, Republican of Iowa, told the Senate tonight that Democratic Senators on the joint Congressional Committee on Atomic Energy had dropped their opposition to the confirmation of Dr. Willard Frank Libby to be a member of the Atomic Energy Commission.

Commodity futures prices closed generally lower yesterday on the New York exchanges. With the exception of rubber, hides and cottonseed oil, volume was light on most items. Cottonseed oil, cocoa, wool, hides, rubber, silk, soybean oil, sugar and potatoes declined; zinc and lead were mixed, and coffee, burlap and copper ended higher.
Sales of items for home improvement that were considered luxuries only a few years ago apart from materials sold in the do-it-yourself trade, have shown marked increases in volume.

The Liquid Carbonic Corporation and subsidiaries cleared $2,840,248, or $2.77 a common share, in the year ended on Sept. 30, it was announced yesterday. This was 47 per cent more than the $1,934,557, or $1.81 a share, cleared in the preceding fiscal year.

Vivid ski jackets, in red, orange and yellow were contrasted with dark, sleek ski pants in a fashion show presented by Bloomingdale's last night at the Diplomat Hotel. Streamlined and modern, these ski clothes were in bold, dramatic designs.
CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Dec. 1 -- Colgate W. Darden, president of the University of Virginia, said today that a Graduate School of Business Administration would open to students next Sept. 15.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 (AP) -- The Eisenhower Administration today again urged the states to act through their legislatures to increase both the amount and duration of unemployment compensation benefits.

An increase last week of 1,977,00 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 149,191,000 barrels, compared with 147,224,000 a week earlier and 147,684,000 a year ago.
The New York Football Giants spent two hours yesterday rehearsing new offensive patterns designed for use in their home finale against the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Polo Grounds Sunday.

The Woolrae Realty Corporation; a holding company for the F. W. Woolworth family interests, has sold the blockfront on the west side of Lexington Avenue, from Ninety-fifth to Ninety-sixth Streets, to buyers who plan to hold the block for investment.

A contractual dispute between Milton Berle and Ruth Gilbert is scheduled to go before an arbitration panel tomorrow, but the comedian's attorney said yesterday that it was "possible an agreement may be reached" befor then.
Marion L. Edwards, former Miami, Fla., labor leader, was acquitted here late last night of a perjury charge by a Federal Court jury after six hours' deliberations.

CommoditI futures prices were irregular on New York exchanges yesterday in generally dull trading. Coffee, sugar, potatoes, zinc, tin, wool and burlap were mixed; cocoa and hides ended lower, and rubber, cottonseed oil and soybean oil closed higher.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- A former Princeton University football star was unanimously elected today to the highest office the Protestant churches of the United States have to offer.

Today's new film is "The Atomic Kid," a Republic drama starring Mickey Rooney, at the Palace. Robert Strauss, Elaine Davis and Bill Goodwin head the supporting cast. Leslie H. Martinson directed from a screen play by Benedict Freedman and John Fenton Murray and a story by Blake Edwards.

CARACAS, Venzuela, Dec. 2 -- The Government began today, the second anniversary of Col. Marcos Perez Jimenez' tenure as President, a series of dedications of public works that have cost more than $500,000,000.

Johnny Bach, Fordham's basketball coach, certainly had reason to be court-minded yesterday. He spent the morning in traffic court answering an overtime parking summons and devoted the afternoon planning and practicing for tomorrow's opener with Niagara.
Prices of cotton futures closed barely steady yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange, 3 to 6 points lower than on Wednesday.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Two of Honduras' three political parties agreed today to boycott the newly-elected congress scheduled to convene Sunday to elect a new president of the republic.

Thomas K. O'Brien of the Pelham Country Club was elected president of the Westchester County Golf Association yesterday. At a meeting of the organization at the Roosevelt Hotel, O'Brien was chosen to succeed William Kuntz of Bonnie Briar, who held the office for the last two years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Democrats gained a majority in the Senate today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- A Soviet-bloc campaign against alleged war propagandists boomeranged today.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- The United States Atomic Energy Commission was accused today of having based its recent action against Dr. Robert Oppenheimer, the atomic physicist, on a lie. The charge was made by Haakon Chevalier, who, Dr. Oppenheimer had at one time said, was a Russian agent who had approached him with an offer to transmit information to Moscow.
A used-car dealer was found dead in his car yesterday morning with a bullet wound in the back of his head.

TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 2 -- Reports reaching Tunis tonight indicated that in many troubled areas the fellaga (nationalist rebels) were responding well to the peace offer made jointly by the French and Tunisian Governments Nov. 22.

Hunter College's basketball team won its second straight victory of the campaign by defeating the Towson (Md.) State Teachers, 93 -- 68, on the Bronx school's court last night. Ira Schwartz, with 14 points, and Larry Joseph, with 13, paced the victors.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 2 -Louis de Rochemont, head of the independent, producing company known as Louis de Rochemont Associates, has completed negotiations for the purchase of "Call Me Yankee Doodle!", a historical novel by Lillian E. Ludwig, and "The Green Mamba," an African adventure story written by Richard D. Estes.
New styling and increased horsepower are among features of the 1955 Jaguar line, which goes on display today at the Hoffman Motor Car Company, 487 Park Avenue.

VIENNA, Dec. 2 -- The World Veterans Federation at its final meeting here today declared in favor of self-determination, European unity, help for undeveloped areas and "international action to re-establish conditions for refugees worthy of human being."

MELBOURNE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Harry Hopman's stern methods as team manager drew stinging rebukes in the press today as Australia's Davis Cup confidence was rocked by the crushing defeat of the country's No. 1 tennis player, Lew Hoad.

GUY MURCHIE JR.'S "Song of the Sky"* is a strange and impressive book, sometimes fascinating, sometimes dull and sometimes baffling to those not technically minded. With lyrical raptures Mr. Murchie has sung his own private hymn to the wonders of our modern age of flight and to the mysteries of the ocean of the air. He has explained the new discoveries of physicists and meteorologists.

As a colleague of the late Dr. Enrico Fermi at Columbia and as a fellow member of the General Advisory Committee to the Atomic Energy Commission I would like to add a few remarks to the excellent obituary which appeared in your newspaper.
For the first time in the city's history its Controller was authorized yesterday by the Board of Estimate to invest funds of the New York City Employes Retirement System in a world bank.

Don Heinrich, a former University of Washington star, was added to the New York Football Giants' roster yesterday. This new quarterback will make his pro debut against the Pittsburgh Steelers at the Polo Grounds next Sunday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Manufacturers' sales and orders were slightly higher in October than in September, the Department of Commerce reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following are the roll-calls in the Senate today to condemn the actions of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:

The new Prime Minister of the Union of South Africa, Johannes Gerhardus Strijdom, apparently goes all the way with his predecessor, Dr. Malan, in his belief that the whites and the Negroes in South Africa should be separated and that the whites should control the Negroes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Immigration officials disclosed today that not a single incoming alien passenger had been held under detention in New York since Nov. 11.
Modern football's greatest runner and scorer, by statistics, was named to The Associated Press' Little All-America football team for the second time yesterday.

FOR thirty-five years a heroic Minerva has held her left arm in salute from a high hill in Brooklyn to her sister Goddess of Liberty in the Bay. Few ever see her and fewer know that she was assigned that gesture in 1919 when she was erected at the Altar of Liberty on the Plateau in the southwest corner of Green-Wood Cemetery.

Two elderly brothers, who owned an apartment house at 176 West Eighty-seventh Street where a defective gas refrigerator caused a tenant's death, were found guilty yesterday of violating the city's Sanitary Code.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -Spending for economic development in Vietnam will rise steadily while the French forces there and the Vietnamese army are reduced by about one-third during 1955. Plans to this end are being worked out in Washington, Paris and Saigon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Following are excerpts from the transcript of the eleventh and final day of Senate debate on the censure charges against Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin:
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- Sentiment and business on the Stock Exchange here were strengthened today by a further rally in Government issues, and recent price losses were partly recovered.
The New York City Housing Authority borrowed $42,195,000 yesterday at an average net interest cost of less than one-fifth of 1 per cent.
The racing secretaries at the Thoroughbred Racing Associations' thirty-nine tracks have picked Native Dancer as the horse of the year.

LOUVAIN, Belgium, Dec. 2 (Reuters) -- A train carrying German soccer fans home from an English-German match in London jumped the rails here today, killing nineteen persons and injuring thirty-nine. More than half the injured were reported in serious condition.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 2 (AP) -- The United States, India and Czechoslovakia -- nations that rarely agree on peace problems -won unanimous approval today of a resolution they sponsored jointly on living together peacefully.

A seventy-fifth anniversary for a college may not seem big to New Yorkers, who have been celebrating the bicentennial of Columbia, but Radcliffe in Cambridge, Mass., is a woman's college. One forgets how recently a woman's place was in the home, and that not many centuries have passed since it was solemnly debated whether the female of the human species had a soul or not.

Father Knickerbocker is slated to incur next year the largest bill for public improvements in his long lifetime -- $738,867,351. This was the figure unanimously approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate for the 1955 capital budget.

Nearly a century ago, young Walt Whitman published his "Leaves of Grass". Well aware of the unusual qualities of his work, the poet sent copies to famous authors, including Ralph Waldo Emerson, dean of American letters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following is the text of the resolution condemning Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, as finally approved by the Senate:
Capital Airlines has exercised its option to buy twenty Viscounts in addition to its earlier order of forty of the British-built turboprop airliners.
A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "The Desperate Hours" on the night of Feb. 1 at a theatre yet to be announced, for the benefit of St. Barnabas House.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Crown Derby, lightweight of the field at 104 pounds, rushed to victory in the six-furlong feature at Tropical Park today. The event was named for the American Medical Association, which just ended its convention in Miami.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The United States Military Academy, recently criticized by some for refusing to let cadets debate recognition of Red China, today offered figurative soap boxes to some 150 college students. There were few takers.
Production last month reached the highest level of the year, according to the National City Bank of New York.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, commander of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division (Reserve), who will retire from the Army at the end of this month, was honored yesterday by Pratt Institute for his services as a citizen-soldier.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 2 -- Mrs. Marilyn Sheppard was the gay center of attention at a family dinner party on July 2, her brother-in-law, Dr. Stephen A. Sheppard, recalled today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Senate voted 67 to 22 tonight to condemn Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican Senator from Wisconsin.
Space-flight enthusiasts got a look yesterday at a new rocket-ship design, blueprinted down to fractions of inches.
ATLANTA, Dec. 2 -- The defending contract bridge champions, B. Jay Becker and George Rapee of New York, and John B. Crawford and Sidney Silodor of Philadelphia, were victors again here today.

Louis E. Wolfson, who is seeking to add Montgomery Ward Co. to the dozen or more corporations under his control, announced yesterday a plan for making Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation a $400,000,000-a-year organization. Its gross income was $70,500,000 in 1953.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -Adlai E. Stevenson, acting as attorney for the Radio Corporation of America, lost his first legal skirmish today after resuming active law practice following an absence of almost eight years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

One of the earliest ski seasons in New England's history is scheduled to get under way this week-end. A heavy storm that hit Vermont and New Hampshire early this week, has caused many ski area managements to speed up the preparation of their facilities.
ROME, Friday, Dec. 3 -- The Vatican announced this morning that Pope Pius XII, gravely stricken, had survived the night. A spokesman said a more detailed bulletin would be issued later today.

Perhaps Ben Hecht was right about the show that didn't go on, the other day, at Spring Valley High School in Rockland County. It should be noted that Rockland County is well populated by people theatrical, such as -- in addition to Mr. Hecht, dramatist -- Helen Hayes and Charles MacArthur, Katharine Cornell and Guthrie McClintock, Maxwell Anderson, Burgess Meredith and others.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 2 -James A. Farley called upon American business men tonight to support religious institutions of higher learning for their contribution to the spiritual defenses of Western civilization.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- More coffee at lower prices is in prospect during 1955, the Food and Agriculture Organization declares in its November Bulletin of Agricultural and Economics Statistics, received here today. The forecast indicates that world production for the forthcoming year will be from 3 to 10 per cent higher than in the preceding twelve months, and that the up-trend is likely to continue for the next five years.

Austria will open in New York today a month-long exhibit of the many products that have figured in her recent steady march to a prosperous world trade. The display at the Austrian Consulate General, 31 East Sixty-ninth Street, will include items ranging from costume jewelry, fashions, ceramics and beer to machine tools and mining equipment.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery last night proposed a new name for the "cold war" with Russia. He said a better name would be the "cold peace."

VIENNA, Dec. 2 -- Eight missing Mozart manuscripts for whose discovery and return an article in the Nov. 7 edition of The New York Times appealed have been found in the Salzburg Carolino Augusteum Museum in somewhat mysterious circumstances.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower, reasserting leadership for his concept of a progressive Republican party, rebuked today the Senate Republican floor leader, William F. Knowland of California, and the party's right wing generally.

"HIT THE TRAIL," which opened at the Mark Hellinger last evening, is the sort of operetta that brings out the native gallantry in show people. In book and score it is decorous but insipid after a style that probably was acceptable years ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- The Court of Appeals today set the week of Jan. 10 for the execution of the three men convicted of the murder of a Readers Digest messenger during a robbery at Chappaqua four years ago.

The Grumman Aircraft Engineering Corporation announced yesterday that its net income for the nine months ended Sept. 30 amounted to $7,175,677, equal to $3.59 a share, after provision of $7,800,000 for taxes.

A three-year-old letter dragged a Rockland County police chief's name into the Brooklyn courtesy-card inquiry yesterday. This evoked his indignant protest that he never had condoned traffic law-breaking and never had honored such cards himself.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Yesterday's heavy selling of grain futures appeared to have been overdone as the markets were generally stronger today. Wheat showed an especially firm tone early, and there was fair support in oats, which led Wednesday's break.

PARIS, Dec. 2 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France agreed today to a week's delay in the opening of the debate for ratification of the London and Paris accords on West German armament and sovereignty. But he made the condition that the vote in the National Assembly must take place before Christmas.
ROME, Friday, Dec. 3 -- Pope Pius XII suffered a collapse at 3:30 o'clock yesterday afternoon due, it is believed, to a perforated ulcer.

The thirteen-story apartment house on plot 100 by 100 feet at 575 West End Avenue, southwest corner of West Eighty-eighth Street, has been sold by Murray Alman to an investing client of Mandel Permutt, attorneys, in a deal negotiated by L. V. Hoffman Co., brokers.
Bard Hall, the City Athletic Club and the Brown Club all scored shutouts in Division I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association tournament play yesterday.

Unfortunately, James Reston's Nov. 19 report, "The A. E. C. in Politics," confuses a critical issue in the Dixon-Yates controversy. He erroneously equates the Dixon-Yates contract with earlier contracts between A.E.C. and Electric Energy, Inc., and Ohio Valley Electric Company. Indeed, if they were the same then the uproar would be considerably less than it is.

By 1976 atomic energy will be used to fuel half of all the electric generating plants then being built, it was predicted yesterday. This forecast was put before the National Association of Manufacturers by Ralph J. Cordiner, president of General Electric.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- Donald K. David, dean of the Harvard Business School, announced today his retirement from the post he had held since 1942, effective next summer.

Events today: Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Nathan Milstein, violinist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Manon," Metropolitan Opera, 8; and a program of operatic excerpts, Malin-Verdi Auditorium, 8:15.

MOSCOW, Dec. 2 -- In a declaration signed in the Kremlin tonight, eight European Communist regimes gave notice that if the Atlantic powers enlisted West Germany in their alliance, an East European defense organization would be created.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 2 -Dr. Sunarjo, Indonesia's Foreign Minister, expressed qualified satisfaction today with the compromise resolution on West New Guinea voted by a United Nations committee.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Chancellor Julius Raab said today the Austrian Government had "worked out" an offer for settling the claims of Jewish victims of nazism.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 2 -- In another development in the conflict between church and state, the Government today abolished the National Department of Religious Teaching, the Inspectorate General of Religious Education and the National Committee of Culture.
New York State has been "lamentably, culpably and criminally negligent" in meeting the problem of juvenile delinquency, Justice J. Irwin Shapiro of the Domestic Relations Court declared yesterday.

May I commend you for your editorial of Nov. 25 pointing out "an abuse of the Presidential press conference" by a correspondent of The Christian Century. Unfortunately, Lawrence Fernsworth not only took unfair advantage of the press conference but he rendered a distinct disservice to the World Council of Churches as well.

The future of "Bus Stop" isn't vague any longer. The William Inge drama, interspersed with comedy, is to be presented by Robert Whitehead and Roger L. Stevens. A Broadway opening in late February is planned. Rehearsals will commence Jan. 3, Harold Clurman directing.

Two courses of action before a "strike" vote were presented to drivers last October at Yonkers Raceway, John Simpson, a driver, testified at the light harness hearings yesterday. George P. Monaghan, the state commissioner, presided.

Simon E. Sobeloff, Solicitor General of the United States, said last night that it was to the interest of the free world that the issues between Israel and the Arab states be resolved and a just peace be established in the Near East.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 2 -- Radcliffe College opened tonight a two-day observance of its seventy-fifth anniversary. A vanguard of an expected 1,600 guests attended a reception in Agassiz House.
The Pennsylvania school building authority sold $23,610,000 of refunding revenue bonds at competitive bidding yesterday at a net interest cost of 2.915 per cent.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- "Peace" came to the United Nations today in the form of a seven-and-a-half-ton bronze statue.

Recovering from two days of uncertainty, the stock market moved ahead yesterday on one of the broadest fronts of the past year. Of the 1,221 issues traded, 738 rose, 261 fell and 222 closed unchanged.

The recently organized Girls Auxiliary of the Madison Square Boys Club will be the beneficiary of a cocktail party to be held on Sunday afternoon and evening in the home of Mrs. Seneca D. Eldredge at 131 East Sixty-sixth Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- During the week ended yesterday member bank reserves increased $24,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower's new Committee for the White House Conference on Education got under way today with a statement by its chairman that states and localities could and should build and pay for their own schools.
Lillian Minges has sold the two-story one-family dwelling at 341 Cornelia Street in Brooklyn to Ludwig Kraus. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

THE reports had not been too encouraging. "Sure he's a fine football player," argued the professional scouts. "He's an excellent runner, pass-catcher, blocker, kicker and tackler. Maybe he was the best all-around performer in college ball. But the National Football League needs standout specialists and Johnny Lattner, just isn't good enough at any department of play to be a success.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The McCarthy debate ended as it began in a spasm of rancor and vindictiveness that will divide the Senate and the country for a long time to come.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 2 -- Charging "double talk" and failure to live up to a contract, radio operators went on strike today against West Coast ships.
By now, in many families, the Thanksgiving turkey is just a glorious memory or a bowl of soup. Homemakers replenishing their larders will find week-end specials widely offered on beef or pork.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 2 -- Turkish leaders believe that Moscow may soon propose a new Soviet-Turkish friendship treaty. This would be part of an intensified campaign to prove Soviet goodwill toward this traditionally anti-Russian country.

Anticipating spring and the arrival of the circus, Mr. Arnold has keyed his new millinery collection to sunshine and the kaleidoscopic colors of the Big Top. It was presented yesterday in the Arnold Showroom, 19 West Fifty-seventh Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower warned today that United States cities were front-line targets for modern weapons "capable of such destruction as to appall the imagination."

PETROPOLIS, Brazil, Dec. 2 -- The twenty-one American republics ended tonight their first general economic conference with agreements on many major points and plans to hold another such meeting within two years.
HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2 (AP) -- The nation's securities dealers are gravely concerned over the speculation in uranium stocks in this country and in shares of Canadian oil and mining ventures.
TOKYO, Dec. 2 -- The leaders of Japan's major political parties now consider national elections inevitable and have begun planning for them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A slight pay rise for service men has President Eisenhower's support, but in his opinion their morale and self-respect depend more on other factors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -Following is the text of the mutual security treaty signed today by the United States and Nationalist China:

In concluding a mutual defense pact with the Nationalist Government of China the United States has taken a logical forward step. We have defined our commitment. We have not extended that commitment to some of the islands that lie close to the mainland. We have made it specific in respect to Formosa and the Pescadores.

Republican legislative leaders are giving serious consideration to relaxing state rent controls outside of the New York metropolitan area, which includes Nassau and Westchester counties as well as New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Following is the unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today. The White House authorized direct quotation of the President in two sections of the text. Elsewhere the President's remarks are given in indirect discourse, as required by conference rules:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A special Senate committee apparently will report to the Senate that a check of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's mail in 1952 was handled as a routine matter by a subcommittee's staff members.

DETROIT, Dec. 2 (AP) -- General Motors Corporation said today its production of passenger cars and trucks in the United States and Canada during November was more than double the production achieved in November, 1953.

ANDROSTOWN, The Bahamas, Dec. 2 -- The angler who flies from Nassau to Androstown, at the mouth of Fresh Creek, spends twenty minutes over water that offers a wide variety of fishing. The short flight is only half over when he wishes he had gone by boat in order to fish some of the spots on the way.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Senator William Langer, Republican of North Dakota, said tonight that he would fight Senate confirmation next year of President Eisenhower's nomination of Judge John Marshall Harlan of New York to the Supreme Court.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 -- Montgomery Ward Co. confirmed today that it had been approached by the spectacular British merchandiser Isaac Wolfson, but denied that any negotiations with Mr. Wolfson were being carried on.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower today nominated Loy W. Henderson, veteran career diplomat now serving as Ambassador to Iran, to be Deputy Under Secretary of State for Administration.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The United States and Nationalist China signed today a mutual defense treaty. The pact pledges their common efforts toward "the preservation of peace and security" in the Far East.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Ambassador Syed Amjad Ali of Pakistan tonight called democracy in Asia a "race against time" requiring "stepped-up technical assistance coupled with vastly increased investment."
The recent Israeli Embassy statement referred to in your article of Nov. 14, "Israeli Arms Decision Based on United States Strategy," mentions two points that need correction and clarification.
Two organizations here that had been circulating petitions for or against the Senate censure of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy suspended their campaigns for new signatures last night.

One of the three Brooklyn adolescents charged with first-degree murder was quoted in Kings County Court yesterday as having said he enjoyed punching homeless men because "it makes me feel big and strong."

A department store, defending its right to meet competing prices on fair-traded merchandise, yesterday forced a manufacturer of such merchandise to withdraw an action seeking to end such sales by the department store.

LONDON, Nov. 29 -- Americans will soon see a painting by an 8-year-old London child who fooled all the grownups and had her picture exhibited along with Britain's big-name artists in a recent show here.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., permanent United States representative to the United Nations, is under consideration at the White House to replace Robert Cutler as special assistant to the President for National Security Affairs.

The first annual advertising awards of the American Merchant Marine Institute were presented yesterday to three companies in allied maritime industries. Presentations were made at a luncheon meeting of industry executives in the Downtown Athletic Club by G. Joseph Minetti, a member of the Federal Maritime Board.

New York University's basketball team downed the New York IState Maritime College quintet, ,75--65, at the Violet's Alumni s Gymnasium in the Bronx last night. It was the ,opening game of the season for both teams.

HOUSTON, Dec. 2 -- The minor leagues concluded their annual convention today. They again moved to rid themselves of the major league radio and TV shackles which, they insist, inevitably will grind them into extiction.

HOLLYWOOD, Fla., Dec. 2 -- Arnold Heeney, Canada's Ambassador to the United States, declared here today that overseas countries would accept United States investments of dollars willingly only if, in the long run, they could sell more of their goods and services here.

Five years of opposition and delay ended yesterday when the Board of Estimate unanimously voted to acquire land for the $21,000,000 middle section of the $86,000,000 Cross-Bronx Expressway. The section extends from Anthony to Longfellow Avenues.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- The United States revealed today that it was seeking United Nations condemnation of the imprisonment by Communist China of eleven American aviators shot down during the Korean war.
A drive to persuade Stephen A. Mitchell to continue as Democratic National Chairman, despite his personal desire to retire, was under way last night.

W. W. Wachtel, president of Calvert Distillers Corporation, long a stout, advocate of fair trade, said yesterday, Ingersoll lost the "dollar watch" because the discounters sold it for 60 cents. He foresaw similar disasters for wines and liquors traded at discounts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy became today the fourth member to be condemned or censured in the 165-year history of the United States Senate.

Prizes totaling $7,500 will be presented to winners of the Student Composers' Radio Awards sponsored by Broadcast Music, Inc., it was anounced yesterday. The deadline for receipt of manuscripts is next Jan. 15.

CHICAGO, Dec. 2 (AP) -- Hog prices generally were down 25 cents today, most types selling at a new low in nearly two years, although the top at $19 was 25 cents above the low top set in October. Salable receipts totaled 14,000.
DETROIT, Dec. 2 (UP) -- Dickie Moore and Bert Olmstead blasted goals in the first period tonight to start the league-leading Montreal Canadiens on a 4-1 rout of the Detroit Red Wings.

Beginning Monday, automobiles and trucks that violate the no-standing rule during evening rush hours will be towed away, Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley announced yesterday. The regulation is in effect on Thirty-fourth and Forty-second Streets between First and Tenth Avenues and on Fifty-seventh Street between First and Eighth Avenues.

By its overwhelming vote against Joseph R. McCarthy the Senate of the United States has done much to redeem itself in the eyes of the American people and to give new assurance of its faithfulness to the principles of orderly democratic government and individual liberty under law.

The American spirit of giving is never more in evidence than when American soldiers in foreign lands share their Christmas cheer with those who have little. This year military personnel of the United States Eighth Army and the Korean Communications Zone will help again to make the holiday brighter for thousands of Korean orphans, needy families and Korean employes of Army units.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Following is a chronology of events in the recent emergence of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy as a "controversial figure" from his Wheeling, West Va. speech on "Communists in the State Department" ing, W. Va., speech on "Comduct today by the United States Senate:

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Harold (Red) Drew, who guided Alabama to three major bowl games in his eight years as head football coach, stepped down today. J. B. Whitworth, former Alabama guard who has been at Oklahoma A. and M., will replace him.

ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 2 -- A sharp controversy over whether New Jersey should have an independent mental health department broke out today at a state-wide conference of social welfare leaders and public officials.

An apartment house site 125 by 100 feet at the northwest corner of Perry Avenue and 209th Street in the Bronx has been purchased by Milton E. Ehrenreich, operator. The York and 72d Street Corporation, represented by Philip Ivers, lawyer, was the seller.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 1 -- Mrs. Joseph R. McCarthy has confessed to friends that her knees were knocking when she mounted the platform at Madison Square Garden Monday night. It was her first public speech, and she was understandably nervous.
Judge Albert Conway, newly elected Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals, was the guest last night at the sixty-sixth annual dinner of the Brooklyn Bar Association.

The future naval striking force may consist of only a handful of large ships able to maintain high speeds in all sea conditions -- perhaps three large aircraft carriers, seven cruisers and two high-speed supply ships -- according to James H. Smith Jr., Assistant Secretary of the Navy for Air.
Goodrich - Gulf Chemicals, Inc., announced yesterday the synthetic production of the true molecule of natural rubber.

Dr. Buell G. Gallagher, president of City College, told an alumni gathering last night that the basketball scandals at the college were nothing as compared with what has been going on at other schools.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 583,515 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 113,831 cars or 16.3 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 12,715 cars or 2.1 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 86,856 cars or 13 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- Five survivors of the crash of a Northeast Airlines plane were plucked by helicopter today from a bleak mountainside near the Maine-New Hampshire border. They had spent forty-five hours on the snow-covered spot in bitter cold.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 2 -- The New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards was told today that "public housing is assured of a prominent spot in the 1956 campaign issues which will not be long in shaping up."

A dollar can still go a long way in the purchase of objects pleasing to the eyes, and useful, too. A Manhattanite must go a bit of a way -- to Brooklyn -- to see this fact demonstrated, but the trip is rewarding.
BOSTON, Dec. 2 -- The General Assembly of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A. stood in a moment of silent prayer this afternoon for Pope Pius XII.

The city is urging the United States Supreme Court to uphold a sixteen-year-old charter requirement under which 200,000 city employes must waive immunity in any questioning about their official conduct -- or lose their jobs.
DETROIT, Mich., Dec. 2 -- Packard will spurt to the lead in the 1955 automotive industry horsepower rivalry, James J. Nance, president of the Studebaker-Packard Corporation, said today.

The concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society last night in Carnegie Hall, when George Szell made his first appearance of the season as its guest conductor, was one of brilliant and admirable entertainment.
Celeste Holm will discontinue her television show after eight performances because the format is unsuitable, the Columbia Broadcasting System announced yesterday.

Arthur Stark, executive director of the New York State Mediation Board, was appointed yesterday by Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell to be impartial adviser in labor disputes on the city-owned transit lines.

Frankie Ryff will oppose Orlando Zulueta of Cuba in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The contest will mark the first Garden main-event showing for Ryff, who has won all his fifteen fights as a professional.
Patrons of the forthcoming benefit for the Mental Hygiene Service of the Morningside Community Center were honored yesterday at a tea given at the Center's headquarters, 360 West 122d Street.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 2 -- Johannes G. Strijdom, South Africa's new Nationalist Prime Minister, has formed his Cabinet. He retained twelve members of Dr. Daniel F. Malan's Cabinet and brought in only two new men to fill vacancies caused by the retirement of Dr. Malan and Nicolaas C. Havenga.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- India and members of the United Nations that helped defend South Korea introduced separate resolutions today expressing the hope that progress could be made toward the unification of Korea.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The movement toward convertibility, or the free interchange of currencies, has slackened appreciably in Britain and other European countries.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The immediate resignation or retirement of Sir Winston Churchill as Prime Minister was demanded today by left-wing elements.

Officials of R. H. Macy Co., Inc., have been meeting with representatives of John Wanamaker to discuss the possible purchase by the Macy organization of the Wanamaker branches in Cross County Center, Westchester, and Great Neck, L. I. Executives of both stores could not be reached yesterday for comment.

John Jacob Astor was directed yesterday to pay his second wife, Mrs. Gertrude Gretsch Astor, $2,500 a month for her maintenance, $1,000 monthly for the support of their child and $7,000 counsel fees pending the trial of her suit for separation. Mr. Astor is contesting the suit.

ALBANY, Dec. 2 -- Over protests by the Attorney General's office, the Albany County Board of Elections approved its official canvass for the fall election today and thus completed the statewide vote count.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 2 -- Dr. Henry H. Kessler, 1954 recipient of the Albert Lasker Award for international service to the physically handicapped, predicted tonight that a majority of the disabled of the world would achieve "productive citizenship" if current interest in their plight was translated into effective action.

Aircraft designers who have passed the sonic barrier -- 750 miles and hour -- and reached the thermal barrier -- more than 2,000 miles an hour -- are finding they may be dependent upon water in their drive toward "escape velocity," or 25,000 miles an hour.
LONDON, Dec. 2 -- The Treasury announced today that the sterling area's gold and dollar reserves had fallen by $11,000,000 during November. At the end of the month they amounted to $2,923,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- President Eisenhower asserted today he was not going to be pushed emotionally into an act of war -such as a naval blockade of Communist China.

BERLIN, Dec. 2 -- The Moscow agreement today visualizing the incorporation of an East German Army into a combined East European military force if West Germany was armed, was not a surprise here. The plan is expected to reduce -- but not cancel -- the effect of the projected Western European Union on the world balance of power.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- A Senate subcommittee is preparing to recommend that coffee futures trading be put under Federal regulation.
Business loans in the New York area registered a moderate rise in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank here reported yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Federal Reserve Board and the Treasury, once bitterly at odds, emphasized anew today that they were now working in harmony toward a common goal.

Since television sets first began to appear in American households their effect on children and the viewing habits of the young have become a source of increasing attention and contention. Each new study of the problem is likely to add a little more kindling to the fire, as is the case with a recent survey of 1,964 third, sixth and eighth grade public school children in South Bend, Ind.

How gossip can make and smash a romance is the theme of a new novel entitled "The Slander of Witches," which Richard Gehman has written. Rinehart will issue it Jan. 20. Set in a small Pennsylvania town, the story is about the lives of a prominent lawyer and his personal secretary.

MARK GOODSON and Bill Todman, entrepreneurs of the television quiz, have brought forth another variation on their most successful property, "What's My Line?" The presentation carries the title "What's Going On?" Judging by the first show, Goodson and Todman are not sure themselves.

An underwriting group headed by White, Weld Co., and including the Robinson-Humphrey Company, Inc., and Clement A. Evans Co., Inc., is offering for public sale today 12,000 shares of Georgia Continental Telephone Company 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock. The shares are priced at par, $25.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 2 (AP) -- Joe's Jeannie gained a two-length victory today in the $4,500 Valenciennes Purse, returning 11 to 2.

Under the leadership of Premier Mendes-France the French National Assembly has at last made a start toward reforming the Constitution of the Fourth Republic for the purpose of giving greater stability to the most unstable Government in the democratic world.

Advertising for Schenley "name brand" holiday whiskies is appearing in more than 450 newspapers on an intensive basis. Schedules are running in papers in forty-six states and the District of Columbia on weekly or bi-weekly time charts, continuing through Christmas Week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended on last Saturday were unchanged from the corresponding period of 1953, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 109.5 per cent of the 1947-49 average in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

THE Metropolitan Opera Association, which has seldom functioned at its best in the performance of French opera, gave last night a performance of Massenet's "Manon" of surpassing distinction, emotional eloquence and dramatic climax.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Liberace signed a $50,000 a-week contract today to open the new Riviera Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., in April.
Although accompanied by the horrors of war, the impact of Western civilization on Korea has had at least one good effect -- the acceleration of the emancipation of its women.

DETROIT, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Ward's Automotive Reports said today that this week's United States automobile production was the highest for any week in a year and a half, with 140,627 units rolling off assembly lines and 20.9 per cent of them coming from Chrysler Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Department of Justice today announced the details of a general reorganization of the Immigration and Naturalization Service. The service is a unit of the department.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, in Berlin to help his party, the Christian Democratic Union, before Sunday's elections, said today that the policy of the Social Democrats would isolate Germany.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Ken Rosewall today won the Victorian tennis championship, defeating the United States champion, Vic Seixas, 6 -- 1, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 1, 7 -- 5.

" The Engineering of Consent," a presentation of the eight "major" phases of public relations, will be published next year by the University of Oklahoma Press. The volume will contain chapters by Sherwood Dodge, Benjamin Fine, Doris E. Fleischman, Brig. Gen. A. Robert Ginsburgh, John Price Jones, Nicholas Samstag, Howard W. Cutler and Edward L. Bernays, Mr. Bernays, editor of the book, presents a survey of the profession in an opening chapter.
HONG KONG Dec. 3 -- The Chinese Communists said tonight their territorial air had again been invaded by United States military aircraft.

ROME, Saturday, Dec. 4 -- After being kept awake until midnight by a bedside consultation of surgical and clinical specialists, Pope Pius XII awoke shortly before 8 o'clock this morning [2 A. M., New York time]. He appeared much refreshed by several hours' sleep.

PARIS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Mr. Catapodis offered evidence today intended to back up his complaint that Mr. Onassis owes him 200,000,000 francs (about $570,000) on a contract for hauling oil from Saudi Arabia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The American Society of Newspaper Editors was told today the Administration's move to prevent nonclassified business information from falling into foreign hands was "censorship of the most offensive and dangerous kind."

Frankie Ryff of the Bronx had little trouble beating the Cuban lightweight, Orlando Zulueta, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night. The undefeated New Yorker made it sixteen in a row as a professional in turning back his experienced foe.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 -- The Soviet Union has abandoned plans for a cultural and industrial exhibit at the Thailand Constitution Trade Fair in Bangkok opening Dec. 8.

An audience of 600 filed out of the Bryant Theatre, 138 West Forty-second Street, yesterday afternoon when a small blaze in a hanging ceiling below the orchestra floor enveloped the theatre in dense, acrid smoke.

An offer to buy the Wanamaker department store property at Broadway and Ninth Street has been made by David Rapoport, an attorney and real estate operator with offices at 280 Broadway, who heads a syndicate of investors, it was learned yesterday.
Leo Durocher yesterday opened the gate to any National League club that wants to propose a deal to him.

The Kinney Corporation has leased the garage space in the building Henry Goelet is erecting at 1145-55 Avenue of the Americas, southwest corner of Forty-fifth Street, for twenty-five years at rentals amounting to $5,000,000.
Luxury line piers on the North River were shut down suddenly yesterday afternoon by a strike of 500 members of "Pistol" Local 824 of the International Longshoremen's Association.

Bill Daly, manager of record of Vince Martinez, a welterweight, was fined $500 by the New York State Athletic Commission yesterday. The penalty was imposed for failure to keep adequate records of financial dealings with the fighter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Four persons indicted for contempt of Congress for refusing to answer questions of the House Un-American Activities Committee pleaded innocent in Federal District Court here today.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Nov. 15 -- A million-square-mile slice of Africa and the 9,000,000 people living in it will go on the block within the next year or so, with Egypt the only active bidder.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- A Greek shipowner filed a $1,600,000 libel suit today against Aristotle S. Onassis, the shipping magnate who owns Monte Carlo.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., is not the man to take "no" for an answer.

With Nat Holman once again in the coach's place on the bench, City College will open its fiftieth intercollegiate basketball season at its gymnasium tonight. The Beavers will he hosts to Adelphi, the college that C. C. N. Y. beat in its first court game in 1905.
CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The Government's anti-trust suit against the du Pont empire, General Motors Corporation and the United States Rubber Company was dismissed today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Wheat prices scored substantial gains early today on commission buying and local covering, but reacted as much as 3 cents from the tops. The weakness in wheat unsettled the markets for corn and oats and started another wave of rye selling. Soybeans held firm.

Former City Magistrate Charles F. Murphy announced yesterday that 70 to 75 per cent of the comic book output early next year would bear the approving seal of the Comics Magazine Association of America. Mr. Murphy was named by the association in October to administer a code of ethics intended to eliminate objectionable comics.
Two fire battalion chiefs, third-ranking officers of the department, heard themselves denounced yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. for taking gratuities of $100 each.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- South Africa reiterated today unyielding opposition to any inquiry by the United Nations into her racial policies.
James C. Herold's future seems much brighter than his past, thanks to the interest of Mrs. Harry G. Hill, wife of a Brooklyn lawyer.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 -- Northern and Southern Democrats agreed tentatively today to drop the troublesome party loyalty oath that had helped split their party in 1952.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Discontent over the state of Britain's aging Royal Navy is being voiced increasingly here as the time approaches for the Government to prepare its defense program for the fiscal year starting April 1.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 3 -- Communist Chinese leaders have assured Premier U Nu of Burma they will "refrain from encouraging or assisting the Communist movement" in his country, according to a special dispatch to The Times of India from Peiping published today.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 3 -- The Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra and fifty players from the Antioch Theatre of Yellow Springs, Ohio, presented here this afternoon what is believed to be the first complete performance in America of Jean Sibelius' score for William Shakespeare's "The Tempest."
Night had lowered and the temperature was 32 degrees when 9-year-old Joseph Besaraba Jr. gave way to a sudden impulse some time after 8 P. M. Thursday.
Nicola Rubbo, a 29 - year - old Italian farmer, met his father for the first time yesterday.

The usual pre-week-end lull cut volume yesterday on the New York futures markets. The activity in most commodities was limited to evening of holdings. Prices closed irregularly lower, with coffee, cocoa, wool, burlap, zinc and copper off; sugar, hides and silk mixed, and rubber, cottonseed oil and potatoes up.
LONDON, Dec. 3 -- The stock markets continued their recovery today. Sentiment was helped by the rally in sterling, good company profit statements and the firmness in Wall Street.

No decision was reached yesterday after day-long talks to persuade Dr. David Dodds Henry, executive vice chancellor of New York University, to accept the presidency of the University of Illinois. Discussions will be resumed today at the Biltmore Hotel.

The first Inter-American economic conference, at which twenty-one American republics discussed their economic problems at Petropolis in Brazil, has come to an end with a significant development of the good neighbor policy into a "good partner policy."
BOSTON, Dec. 3 -- The United States "is ready for a great spiritual awakening and revival."
SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 3 -- President Jose Figueres said today that a threat to invade Costa Rica from Nicaragua was keeping tension high in his country.
Five men were found guilty and three acquitted early today on charges of participating in the theft of and transporting $30,000 worth of coffee beans from Brooklyn to Jersey City last July.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Australia's turbulent tennis situation reached the highest level of Government tonight when Prime Minister Robert Menzies told fretful Lew Hoad to ignore his critics.
Bull Lines has acquired two American-flag C-2 cargo ships in exchange for two Liberty ships ito be transferred to foreign regJistry, it was learned yesterday,i

Chancellor Julius Raab of Austria paid a visit yesterday to Electchester, a $22,000,000 union housing project in Flushing, Queens. The project was constructed by Local 3, International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, A. F. L., and, when completed, will accommodate 2,240 families.
Frederick W. Richmond said here yesterday that he would sell all of the Follansbee Steel Corporation's properties at Follansbee, W. Va., to Cyrus Eaton, Cleveland financier.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- An official of the Federal Trade Commission confirmed today that the agency is investigating tobacco marketing practices in the burley belt of Tennessee and Kentucky.

It would seem an obvious truism in these days of difficult relations with the Soviet Union that it is to the advantage of this country to know more about the Soviet people, their habits and their language. However, a survey by this newspaper shows that the number of students of Russian in American colleges and universities has dropped sharply since 1950.

New York Stock Exchange memberships have been transferred from the late Carroll V. Geran to Oscar R. Foster, from Louis E. Hatzfeld to W. Alston Flagg Jr., from the late Robert Bennett Berman to Robert L. Stott Jr., from David Weld to Charles H. Worthington, from the late Benjamin Stenzler to Fred A. Bartman Jr., from the late Charles Sievers to Thomas M. Evans and from Edward N. Carpenter to Samuel H. Beattie.

Over in New Jersey, less than fifty miles from Broadway, one of America's most pristine bits of hardwood forest has suddenly become famous because someone infamously proposed its destruction. Those who think of the future know that to cut down those woods for ships' timbers, however badly needed, would be like melting down the Liberty Bell for metal because it would make good door knobs.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 3 -- The controversy over the adoption of the national intercollegiate debate topic on United States recognition of Communist China continued here tonight in a debate between teams representing Princeton University and the College of St. Rose of Albany, N. Y.

SOME late art news from France is that Leger, following the example of Picasso and Braque, now has turned his hand to making ceramics. A selection of his pieces may be seen at the Janis Gallery, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street.

The property at 32-16 and 32-20 Thirty-sixth Street in Long Island City, Queens, comprising a four-story eight-family apartment house and a two-family dwelling with two garages on a plot 95 by 100 feet, has been purchased by the Roman Catholic Church of the Most Precious Blood from Frieda D. Powers.

HOUSTON, Dec. 3 -- As the baseball caravans evacuated this metropolis today, they left in their wake a feeling of uneasiness that could not be glossed over. The minor leaguers left for their homes. The major leaguers departed for their annual meetings, which open in New York on Monday.

ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The New York Telephone Company filed suit in Supreme Court today to set aside the Public Service Commission's refusal to grant the company a $68,850,000 rate increase. The case will be argued here next Friday before Justice Isadore Bookstein.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United States will ask the United Nations General Assembly tomorrow to take up the imprisonment of eleven American aviators by Communist China on charges of espionage. Red China has also jailed two American civilians on the charges.

KINGS POINT, L. I., Dec. 3 -- The United States Merchant Marine Academy's basketball team defeated Brooklyn College, 69 -- 65, in O'Hara Hall tonight. The victory was the second straight for the Mariners. The test opened the campaign for the Kingsmen.

ATLANTA, Ga., Dec. 3 -- The twenty-eighth annual contract-bridge winter national championships continued here with thirty-three men's teams and twenty-nine women's teams playing in the men's and women's team-of-four championships.

Stephen J. Griffin has been appointed executive assistant to the vice president in charge of sales of the Gillette Safety Razor Company, Boston. William C. Platzoeder has been named sales service manager.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday. Prices were 7 points higher to 1 point lower than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday granted broad highway trucking authority in eleven central states to Rock Island Motor Transit Company, wholly owned subsidiary of the Chicago, Rock Island and Pacific Railroad.
The basic steel structure for the new approaches to the Whitehall Street terminal of the Staten Island ferry line is nearing completion and modernization work has started on the old terminal itself.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The television industry today reported to Congress that it was placing increased emphasis on avoiding "excessively violent" and "morbid" shows, especially those for children.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Purdue University's basketball team combined its height and superior outside shooting to defeat Rutgers, 77 -- 57, tonight. It was the first game of the season for both schools.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 6 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 7.5 per cent and orders 3 per cent.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Los Angeles open golf tournament, denied the sanction of the Professional Golfers Association, will be staged as scheduled.

ALBANY. Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Appellate Division today cleared the way for early trial of court actions in a dispute between the State University of New York and Syracuse University over medical college endowment funds totaling about $1,250,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The United States and India are discussing means of continuing in effect the provisions of their air rights treaty, scheduled to end Jan. 14, 1955.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 3 -- "Adventures In Politics," the book by Senator Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, will serve as the basis of a motion picture to be produced by Walter Wanger. The film will be released by Allied Artists to coincide with the 1956 political campaign.

Pierre La Mure's dramatization of his novel, "Moulin Rouge," dealing with the celebrated French painter, Toulouse-Lautrec, has been acquired by the new producing team of George Brandt, M. Allen Lewis and Clifford Hayman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A four-day White House Conference on Education was scheduled today to open Nov. 28, 1955.

Cadets and other personnel at the United States Military Academy at West Point gave more than 700 pints of blood in a three-day mass donation, which ended yesterday. The occasion was the ninth visit of a Red Cross blood unit to West Point since 1950, when, with the Korean war on, the academy began contributing twice yearly.

Pete Mangum, a 23-year-old rookie linebacker, yesterday was added to the New York Football Giants' roster. Charley Conerly, the injured first-string quarterback, was placed on the injured reserve list.
An explosive exchange between the state harness racing commissioner and the defense attorney punctuated the testimony of Edward Dougherty, head of the Standardbred Owners Association, yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission, revealed today the development of an atomic furnace able to let any country function in the radioisotope field.

The Federal Reserve Board and the United States Treasury, in separate statements prepared for the Economic Stabilization Subcommittee, have provided the latter with a picture of harmonious relations and complementary policies over the past two years.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Saturday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Nationalist officials hailed the new defense treaty with the United States as a blow to Communist China. The Reds' Peiping radio in turn denounced the pact as "a serious United States provocation."

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Gov. Allen Shivers of Texas denounced today the Federal Power Commission's control of natural gas producers. Such regulation, he charged, brings about the "equivalent of nationalization of the energy resources of the United States."

Clarence B. Randall, special consultant to President Eisenhower on foreign economic policy, predicted last night that the incoming Congress would soon adopt tariff reductions as a spur to world trade.

When President Eisenhower proposed his atoms-for-peace plan to the United Nations General Assembly last December he said that "a special purpose would be to provide abundant electrical energy in the power-starved areas of the world." The "international technical conference" which the Assembly has voted to call "under the auspices of the United Nations" is also to consider, among other things, "the development of atomic power."
E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co. is the world's greatest chemical company in a chemical age.

SEIGNIORY CLUB, Que., Dec. 3 (Canadian Press) -- Seven Canadian and four American rinks gained first-round victories today in the opening round of the fifteenth annual international friendly curling games.
Preliminary surveys for the route of the proposed Long Island Expressway from the city boundary, a key link in the arterial system serving Long Island, have been completed.
A psychiatric patient grabbed a policeman's revolver in Queens last night and killed the patrolman and a woman hospital attendant before he was shot dead.
The Hertz Corporation of Chicago and Metropolitan Distributors, Inc., of New York are talking over terms of a deal by which Hertz would acquire Metropolitan's truck rental business.

ALBANY, Calif., Dec. 3 (UP) -- Determine, the little gray winner of the Kentucky Derby, goes to the post at Golden Gate Fields tomorrow. A muddy track is in prospect as he renews his battle to become the money-winning champion of 1953.
Spurred by optimistic news, the stock market took the bit in its teeth yesterday and raced into new high ground.
ROME, Saturday, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Two physicians who examined Pope Pius XII said early today he no longer was in a desperate condition but still was seriously ill.

The decision of Fire Commissioner Cavanagh to relieve Chief of Department Loftus of all administrative duties apart from his direct control of the men and equipment assigned to fighting and preventing fires should not be taken as evidence of any lack of confidence or as a demotion in any way -- most especially by Chief Loftus himself.
That rotund man who scrambles down chimneys after dark every Dec. 24 may find his pack bulging with United States Savings Bonds this year.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Seven sections of the New England ski belt in Vermont and New Hampshire will open for the week-end tomorrow -- far ahead of schedule -- thanks to early snowfalls of from fourteen to thirty-six inches.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Herbert Morrison, a leader of the Labor party's dominant right wing, asked Sir Winston Churchill tonight to consider resigning from office. He assailed the Prime Minister's speech at Woodford ten days ago as "this clumsy and mischievous piece of exhibitionism," and added:

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- A proposed compat of eight states bordering on the Great Lakes to solve water division, lake levels and other common problems was announced today at the Council of State Governments Assembly.
Manhattan College's basketball team won its opening game of the season by defeating Bridgeport University, 101-63, on the Jasper court last night.

The red-haired stalwart who posed for the policemen's memorial monument is now a grizzled detective. The child who held his hand is a young man of 23. But the statue still stands hidden from public gaze. In a Bronx garage, tarnished and collecting dust as it has for fourteen years, it is still stirring up controversies over a suitable site for it.
A patrolman of the Long Island State Park Commission touched off a new battle with the commission yesterday by refusing to waive immunity before a Brooklyn grand jury.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 3 -- Jusuf Wibisono, parliamentary leader of the Masjumi (Moslem) party, attacked the Cabinet of Premier All Sastroamidjojo here today for its reliance on Communist votes in the Assembly.

Cities Service Company directors yesterday declared an extra year-end dividend of $1 a share, a regular quarterly dividend of $1 a share and a 2 per cent stock dividend, and recommended a 2 1/2-for-1 split of the common stock.
BOWIE, Md., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The trophy in a horse race tomorrow will perpetuate a triple dead heat which was a highlight in the handicapping career of John B. Campbell.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- United States refusal to recognize Red China was upheld and criticized by a group of college students today as "unrealistic" and harmful to the long-term welfare of this country.

The Fort Wayne Pistons, owners of a six-game winning streak, will meet the New York Knickerbockers, winners of two straight, at Madison Square Garden tonight. The National Basketball Association contest will follow a high school game pitting Rice against St. Simon Stock at 7:30.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- A record $69,919,991,000 in Federal taxes was collected during the 1954 fiscal year, which ended last June 30, the Internal Revenue Service reported today.
The New York Newspaper Women's Club presented prize awards for outstanding work in journalism to five newspaper women last night.
Good food with a foreign accent is one of the attractions at the Downtown Community School's sixth annual International Fair, which opened yesterday at 235 East Eleventh Street.
No one ever weeps for joy, not even a mother at her daughter's wedding, a psychiatrist told members of the American Psychoanalytic Association at their semiannual discussions yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The White House announced today the resignation of James S. Kemper as United States Ambassador to Brazil.
Last night's concert in Carnegie Hall wound up the American tour of the great Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam.

The three five-story buildings containing sixty-two apartments at 1475-83 College Avenue in the Bronx have been sold by 537 West 123d Street Corporation to J. E. Management Company, Inc., for cash over mortgages of $141,656.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The National Conference of Mayors got a preview today of the Administration's multi-billion-dollar highway program.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 3 -- Mayor DeLesseps S. Morrison of New Orleans declared today the nations of Latin America were spending millions of dollars on border defenses that should be used instead for education, health and other public services.

Mathematical contributions to the relativity theory, impressionistic paintings, a revolutionary simplification of musical notation, and a novel about the inside of the Paris world of high fashion are among the items put on display yesterday at the Carnegie International Center at East 46 Street and United Nations Plaza.

BERLIN, Dec. 3 -- Five leaders of the West Berlin Jewish community recently have received threatening letters, Heinz Galinski, head of west Berlin Jewish communal organization, said today. Mr. Galinski said the letters were further evidence that anti-Semitic elements were again becoming active.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 3 -- A Government spokesman expressed today praise for the Western powers and doubts of the Soviet bloc on the question of European security.

Contrary to general opinion, the differences between the Soviet position and the United States position on armaments control have been narrowed considerably, at least as they are outlined in the "United States Working Paper on Disarmament Control" and a recent "Soviet Draft Resolution."
Two storm - tossed trans - Atlantic liners, the Cunard liner Queen Mary and the Italian liner Saturnia, made port yesterday, both behind schedule.
Britain's newest liner, the Saxonia, will make her first appearance in New York tomorrow morning.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Alfred Gwynne Vanderbilt, who shunned California for Florida racing this year, launched his campaign auspiciously at Tropical Park today. He sent out two horses, Tarzan and Performance, and won with both.
An account of murder by adolescents was told yesterday in Kings County Court by a 15-year-old boy under indictment for the killing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The National Farmers Union urged the Securities and Exchange Commission today to reject plans for financing the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 3 -- Radcliffe College presented eight honorary citations today at exercises marking its seventy-fifth anniversary. The recipients were seven alumnae and its third president, Mrs. Ada Comstock Notestein, President - emerita, who retired in 1943. She is a graduate of Smith College.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The American Jewish Committee appealed today for equal rights for all citizens in the French protectorates of Morocco and Tunisia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A bottle cap that was patented this week by a Californian explodes when tapped and blows itself off the bottle.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- President Eisenhower's Cabinet is split over a proposed long-range program of economic grants and loans as the free world's chief weapon in the "cold war."

Nine members of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., were continued in $500 bail yesterday by Magistrate Harry G. Andrews in Lower Manhattan Court. They had been arrested on simple assault charges in connection with a union meeting that was broken up Wednesday.

LONDON, Dec. 1 -- Britain's top twelve fashion designers made their once-a-year royal bow today before Queen Mother Elizabeth and Princess Margaret with a showing of their prettiest styles for spring.
Godchaux Sugars, Inc., announced yesterday that it has drawn up a plan of recapitalization which will be submitted to stockholders at a special meeting Dec. 15.

There are, roughly speaking, two kinds of smoking jackets. One is a well-tailored garment advertised and sold as a smoking jacket, possibly of some colorful, soft material and boasting braiding around the collar and cuffs.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The United States gave up today in its long fight involving $179,420 in indemnity payments by the United Nations to eleven of its former employes. The eleven, all United States citizens, were dismissed after having invoked the Fifth Amendment before a Congressional investigating committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Foreign Service Journal said today that the ouster of John Paton Davies Jr. would have "a serious effect on service efficiency and morale."

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 3 -- Averell Harriman today warned those attending the meeting here of the Democratic National Committee that the party would have to stop going to President Eisenhower's defense if it wanted to win the 1956 Presidential election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The first shipment of flood relief food from the United States for people in Soviet-controlled countries arriced today at the East German port of Wismar aboard the Mormacport, the White House announced.
ASBURY PARK, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Today's problem parents were yesterday's untreated adolescents, according to a nationally known psychiatric specialist in family problems.

The Inter-American Press Association announced yesterday that President Anastasio Somoza of Nicaragua had assured it that "within the next few days" he would lift the state of siege effective in Nicaragua since April. The step would automatically abolish domestic press censorship.

BOSTON, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Following is the text of a message, "The Power and Unity of Our Faith," adopted today by the third biennial assembly of the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.:

ANDROS, the Bahamas, Dec. 3 -- According to some of the Bahaman wildfowlers the waterfowl migration to this island has not reached its peak, which would seem to make this something of a duck hunter's heaven.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- A special two-member Senate committee recommended today that the case of a check on Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's mail in 1952 be turned over to the Attorney General "for such action as he deems appropriate."

FORT MONMOUTH, N. J., Dec. 3 (AP) -- Barry S. Bernstein, 35 years old, of Long Branch, an engineer suspended by the Signal Corps after he had appeared at a closed hearing conducted by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, a year ago, has been reinstated.
Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery left for London at 5:17 P. M. yesterday from New York International Airport at Idlewild, Queens.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- Following are excerpts from the ruling by Federal Judge Walter J. LaBuy, dismissing anti-trust charges brought by the Government against the du Pont family, General Motors and United States Rubber.
Earnings of the May Department Stores Company and subsidiaries in the nine months ended Oct. 31 were 19.3 per cent lower than in the corresponding 1953 period, the company reported yesterday.
ALBANY, Dec. 3 -- The Court of Appeals ruled today that a junior operator's license did not permit its holder to drive after dark to attend a school athletic contest.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 3 -- Dr. Stephen A. Sheppard admitted under cross-examination today that he had given testimony that was "not true."

ST. PAUL, Minn., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The home club pro, the backbone of the Professional Golfers Association, will be recognized in the future for the work he does at his club, in his community and with members.

The New York Port Society will sponsor a series of services from Tuesday through Dec. 14 to mark the formal opening and dedication of its new headquarters and Mariners Church at 524 West Forty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Yale Towne Manufacturing Company of New York City today denied Federal Trade Commission charges that its quantity discounts on the sale of industrial trucks represents price discrimination between its customers.

CHICAGO, Dec. 3 -- The Government's anti-trust suit against the du Pont Company and its co- defendants involved the services of forty-four attorneys. For the Government, eleven staffed the prosecution table. The defendants, individuals and corporations, were represented by thirty-three lawyers from six cities.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 - President Eisenhower and the Senate Agriculture Committee aimed at the same target today in the milk situation.

The centenary of the signing by the Viceroy of Egypt of the concession that enabled Ferdinand de Lesseps to carry out his great conception of the Suez Canal is worth commemorating. The canal, a dream as old as the Pharaohs, shortens the route from Britain to Bombay and Calcutta by 4,500 and 3,600 miles respectively.

At 80, J. Gordon Guthrie sees a lot of interesting people through a stained-glass window. Seemingly inspired by the figures he translates into modern design, he is an expert on the lore of St. Francis of Assisi, Joan of Arc, of the sixteenth century Jesuit missionary, St. Isaac Jogues.
Mayor Wagner returned to New York late yesterday afternoon from a trip to Washington and began preparations for a journey to Puerto Rico.

During the bull market in Wall Street this year few investors appeared to be directing any great deal of attention to the Government's anti-trust suit against E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc., and members of the du Pont family.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 3 -- A spokesman for the National Association of Manufacturers told the New Jersey Association of Real Estate boards today that the nation's realtors probably will be selling almost 1,500,000 dwellings a year by 1965.

Following are excerpts from editorial comment in newspapers throughout the country on the Senate's condemnation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, as gathered by The New York Times and The Associated Press.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 (AP) -- The world welterweight champion, Johnny Saxton, today debated the possibility of a title match here with Carmen Basilio early next year.
