WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- Vice President Richard M. Nixon was identified today as the person who had stricken out the last remaining reference to "censure" in the resolution condemning Senator Joseph R. McCarthy.

A film festival, the Golden Age of Silent Cinema, featuring foreign-made screen classics, has been scheduled to begin on Friday, Dec. 17, at the Fifty-fifth Street Playhouse, sponsored by Brandon Films, Inc.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Covent Garden's audience was thrilled and delighted tonight with a new English opera in the grand tradition. Sir William T. Walton's eagerly awaited "Troilus and Cressida" is the work of a composer who has always been governed by a stern self-discipline and who waited until the age of 52 before he felt competent to give the world his first opera.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Judge Miguel Lavalle Fuentes today ordered the arrest of Maj. Jaime Rosenberg, former chief of Guatemala's secret police under the pro-Communist Government and now an exile here.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 3 -- An expansion of the West German frontier defense force from 20,000 to 80,000 men was advocated today by Erich Mende, military expert of the Free Democratic party.

There is no danger of industrial research ever overexpanding, it was said yesterday by Edward R. Weidlein, president of the Mellon Institute of Industrial Research. He spoke at the second annual conference of the presidents' council of the American Institute of Management in the Plaza Hotel.
PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 4 -- The French National Assembly early today gave Premier Pierre Mendes-France a half-hearted vote of approval by 287 to 240.
GAFSA, Tunisia, Dec. 3 -- The expectation at French operational headquarters here tonight was that the bulk of the fellagha (nationalist rebels) in Central Tunisia would surrender their arms shortly.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- A steel sphere about 150 feet in diameter will house Britain's first breeder reactor in an atomic power station soon to be built. The reactor is expected to generate electricity by producing steam to drive conventional machines.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 3 -- The West German Supreme Court dropped today the case against Dr. Werner Naumann, former Nazi official, and seven associates on charges of plotting a Nazi comeback. The decision was based on a "lack of evidence."

The Radio Corporation of America has declared an extra dividend of 35 cents a share and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common stock, it was announced yesterday by David Sarnoff, chairman. Both dividends will be distributed on Jan. 24, to holders of record on Dec. 17.

Veal shoulder roast, being offered now for about 33 cents a pound, is an attractive possibility this week-end. This is a meaty cut. According to the State College of Agriculture and Home Economics at Cornell, 74 per cent of each pound consists of lean meat.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 3 -- A new color television receiver that operates differently from those now on the market and will be sold at a comparably high price was demonstrated here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 (UP) -- The Senate Elections subcommittee has decided to reject a request for a recount in the Oregon Senatorial election, Chairman Frank Barrett, Republican of Wyoming, announced today. This election gave control of the new Senate to the Democrats.

HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Deliberating only ten minutes, a Bergen County jury returned a verdict of not guilty today in the case of Wallace S. De Puy, former first assistant prosecutor. He had been charged with misconduct in office in assertedly failing to make arrests in a 1949 raid on a dice game at Park Ridge.

Plans are progressing for the Holiday Concerts for Young People to be held Dec. 28 and March 29 in the Hunter College Auditorium for the benefit of St. Luke's Hospital Building Fund. Thousands of invitations were issued this week by the committee of doctors wives, headed by Mrs. Edward Patterson Childs.

On the vexed question of a proposed blockade of Red China there is reason to endorse and to applaud the clear statements of President Eisenhower and Secretary Dulles as to our policy. We share the President's rightful wrath at the detention of our nationals by the Communists.
Three women in the Bronx were taken into custody early today on charges of plotting to murder the husband of one of the women so as to collect insurance money and damages from a fake-accident suit.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- Cornell University announced today that Dr. M. H. Abrams, professor of English, had won Phi Beta Kappa's 1954 Christian Gauss Prize of $1,000 for his book, "The Mirror and the Lamp: Romantic Theory and the Critical Tradition."

Events today: "Andrea Chenier," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Guiomar Novaes, pianist, Town Hall, 3; Little Concert Series, Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, 3; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," Metropolitan Opera, 8:15; and the Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Clifford Curzon, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 8:45.

LONDON, Dec. 3 -- Relationships between the British and United States Governments are particularly good these days. This is always important because the girders of free democracy are founded in these relationships. And it is especially important now as the West seeks to clean up some of the messier situations in the world.
The following is a round-up of products that may be of interest to the homemaker for the holidays:

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 3 -- The Assembly of Captive European Nations adopted a resolution today asserting that decisions taken by the Moscow conference on European security were not binding, either morally or legally, on the enslaved peoples of Eastern Europe.

A 24-year-old hold-up man from Brooklyn, brandishing a pistol that turned out to be a toy, was killed last night by a ten-shot fusillade from two detectives concealed in a candy store near Columbus Circle.
ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 3 (AP) -- The Court of Appeals held today that Lester Martin, a dissatisfied stockholder, had a right to look at the books of the Columbia Pictures Corporation.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 -- A four-hour meeting of West Coast shipowners and striking radio operators broke up tonight without producing a solution for a dispute that has virtually immobilized American-flag shipping on this Coast.

The comments of the Ceylonese Prime Minister and the conclusion of our mutual security pact with Nationalist China have again brought attention to the attitude of various Asian states to the agreement that was reached early in September in Manila.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 3 (UP) -- Pierre Langlois of France arrived today for his Dec. 15 world middleweight title bout against Carl (Bobo) Olson. A row over the judges arose immediately.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 3 -- Mayor Charles E. Goudreau of North Plainfield withdrew today a plea of innocent and entered a new plea of no defense to an indictment charging him with seven counts of false swearing. The indictment resulted from a grand jury investigation of anonymous campaign literature distributed in North Plainfield in 1953.
GENEVA, Dec. 3 -- The world trade conference here has been making much more rapid progress than delegates from the major trading nations expected.
New financing next week will total more than $690,000,000 with large blocks of municipal, corporate and public housing issues scheduled for sale.

DALLAS, Dec. 3 (AP) -- Ralph Guglielmi, rated with the finest quarterbacks in Notre Dame history, plays his last game tomorrow. He is a major reason why the Irish are two-touchdown favorites to beat Southern Methodist.
You are to be commended strongly for your fine editorial "City Careers and Pay" which appeared in your Nov. 29 editions.
The city's new traffic code is now in effect, and full enforcement is expected to begin tomorrow.
IN "Wedding Breakfast" the producer can feature the entire cast without overloading the program. There are only four characters in Theodore Reeves' delightful play.

NAPLES -- Within the past two years Italy has acquired what is undoubtedly the world's largest chain of brand new hotels designed expressly for tourists. Known collectively as the Jolly Hotels (Jolly is also the name given to each individual hotel in the chain), thirty-eight of these establishments are now in operation, and it is expected that another five will be completed in 1955.

The American Press Institute at Columbia University will open tomorrow a two-week seminar on new approaches in the coverage of local news. City editors, assistants and news editors from twenty-seven newspapers in eighteen states will attend the sessions, which will end Dec. 17.

NEWARK, Dec. 4 -- The first Negro certified public accountant in New Jersey will be sworn in Monday. He is Wilbur Parker, 28 years old of 214 Sherman Avenue, a former track and fooball start at Cornell University, which had awarded him a scholarship.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- The Bureau of Business Research at the Pennsylvania State University reported today that industrial activity in Pennsylvania during October showed little change from September. It was down however from a year ago.

OPENING a three-day conference of tourist experts in Ottawa, Jean Lesage, Minister of Resources and Development, said last week that he thought Canada should organize special Canadian art, music and drama events and folklore festivals and that encouragement should be given in all parts of Canada to the organization of special events.
WALT DISNEY has been called a genius since shortly after he began work in California film studios almost thirty years ago. Only a handful of detractors would question his right to the designation.
WASHINGTON -- Holiday tradition is being rearranged in the Capital this year with a blare of trumpets from the press agents and a splash of pageantry thrown in.

Superlatives are in order, as they generally are when Guiomar Novaes is in good form. Which she was yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, and once again she demonstrated a quality of polished piano playing unique of its kind.

WITH this, his first adult book, Chad Oliver, author of a number of excellent short stories and a first-rate juvenile, has written what is very likely the best science fiction novel of the year. In a quiet, realistic, entertaining story, he has brought one of the great science fictional themes down to earth.

HARD-DRIVING retailers are determined, to pull Christmas volume ahead of a year ago. Recent increases in department store sales reflect a general pick-up in business volume in the fourth quarter, and the year as a whole promises to end on a note stronger than the faltering one on which it started.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Sunday, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Communist and Nationalist China traded their first blows Saturday over the offshore islands since the United-States - Nationalist mutual defense pact was signed in Washington Thursday, the official Central News Agency said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- About 150 persons have signified a desire to present oral arguments at hearings on a proposed reciprocal trade agreement with Japan. The list is one of the largest on record for hearings of the kind.

TWO yearbooks recently imported from London and Lucerne give opposite impressions of photographic achievement on the international level. They are "FIAP Yearbook 1954" (Lucerne: C. J. Bucher, Ltd.; Philadelphia: Rayelle Publications, $8.50), publication of the International Federation of Photographic Art (which incidentally does not include either English or American membership) and "Photography Year Book 1955" (London: Photography; Philadelphia: Rayelle. $5.95). The latter obviously gives the truer impression.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 4 -- Steel ingot production in the Cleveland-Lorain district soared to 91.5 per cent of capacity, highest of the year, and mills continued to accelerate operations. The rate of operations was five points higher than that of the week before and officials of steel plants are confident that the expanded level of production will carry well into the first quarter of next year.

Despite persistent rumors, the Dodgers will not trade Junior Gilliam and Rob Milliken to the Cincinnati Redlegs. Buzzie Bavasi, the vice president of the Brooks, stated flatly yesterday that a Gilliam and Milliken deal for outfielder Wally Post and catcher Hobie Landrith would not be made.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 4 -- Madison Cottage, a famous tavern that stood at Twenty-third Street and Broadway a hundred years ago, is nearing reconstruction -- in miniature.

PARIS, Dec. 4 -- Gen. Charles de Gaulle urged today that before the Paris agreements were applied there should be "a precise negotiation" in quest of a universal and controlled limitation of armaments.

STONY POINT, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Leland Hastings, the only regular rural mail carrier in Stony Point Township for the last thirty-seven years, has quit that job at the age of 61 to achieve a long-held ambition to run an auto service station.

Inadequate educational facilities in non-Communist Asia and restrictions by Western countries were reported here yesterday to are reported to be forcing thousands of Chinese students to go to Communist China for their university education.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Iona College Gaels opened their basketball campaign tonight by beating Loyola of Baltimore, 73 to 67, at O'Connell Memorial Gymnasium. Iona showed the way at half-time, 34 -- 29.
Phil Brady's goal in the final minute enabled the Squadron A trio to defeat the Meadow Brook Blues, 10 -- 9, in a New York Indoor Polo Association match at the Squadron A Armory last night.
ONIDA, S. D., Dec. 3 -- Carol Terbush, 11 years old, is on the state's payroll for the ability with which she is credited to detect water under the ground with a divining rod of willow.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 4 -- The Navy basketball team rallied in the second half to hand Yale its second defeat in two games, 81 -- 69, in the Payne Whitney gymnasium tonight.

AS many kitchens move to the center of the house, the work units are placed in unconventional positions. Sometimes an "island" contains a sink or counter-top cooking units; sometimes these serve as room dividers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Officials of little schools scattered through 320 square miles of Ozark hills wrote Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, in distress.
WASHINGTON, Nov. 26 -- The problem of cliques, or groups of prisoners who band together to promote causes or create trouble, is a serious one in Federal penitentiaries.

ATLANTA, Dec. 4 -- The open pair championship, final event of the eight-day winter national championships, started this afternoon here at the Atlanta Biltmore Hotel, with 196 contract bridge pairs playing the first of two qualifying sessions.

A LOVING and delightful account has at last been written of man's new ocean, the ocean of air. Everyone who flies, everyone who as a child was fascinated by the watery oceans, all who speculate upon the nature of our world will enjoy this book.

May a one-time Progressive and Republican who voted for Eisenhower for President ask how long the Administration's Far Eastern policy is to be dominated by the prejudices of the Republican leader in the Senate, William F. Knowland?

John F. Stanwell - Fletcher, Arctic explorer, will head a scientific expedition to the north polar regions early next year. His party, which will be gone several months and is privately financed, will comprise fourteen explorers, three Eskimos and eighty-one dogs and will use several airplanes.

EVENTS reminiscent of the Main Stem are taking place here under the warm Florida sun and silk-swishing coconut palms as Hal Wallis re-creates for Paramount's Vista Vision cameras a painstaking, enlarged likeness of Tennessee Williams' Broadway hit, "The Rose Tattoo."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, is preparing to put up a hard fight, if necessary, to keep a promise that organized labor asserts he failed to keep a year ago.

HERE is a novel that explores with a merciless probe one of the most painful of modern problems: how not to be a traitor. The poignancy of the hero's failure is framed in the plaint of that ubiquitous figure of Italian life, the sorrowing mother, to whom all reasons of war and men are nothing and who can only answer, no matter which side wins, "You killed our sons."

IN the home greenhouse, or in any greenhouse for that matter, satisfactory results are not a matter of good luck, but are attained by closely adhering to the rules concerning temperature and airing, and by carrying out a not too difficult schedule of watering, feeding and spraying. Vigilance, in other words, is the price of success.
At the President's press conference last Thursday, this exchange took place:

WHENEVER conversation turns to winter protection of gardens I think of my wildflower garden and realize that one advantage of wildflower gardening is the small amount of effort required for maintenance.

AS always at the approach of Christmas, theatre owners and producers are taking on a fine, convivial glow that stems from perked-up holiday box-office business. Out-of-town visitors, vacationing college students and bestowers of gift theatre tickets all contribute to the seasonal boom between Dec. 20 and the first week of January.

Department stores had difficulty in evaluating their sales last week. They had lost sales in the same week a year ago because newspapers were not publishing as a result of a strike in the city. This year one store was open on four nights which had been closed last year and one was closed on two nights on which it had been open last year.
Billy and Karen still hoped yesterday that someone, perhaps their parents, would come and take them home in time for Christmas.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- There have been Popes in Rome since the dawn of the Christian era. Pius XII, the 261st Pope, can trace his line of apostolic descent all the way back to the Apostle Peter, who met martyrdom in Rome in a year that historians have variously identified as 64 and 67 A. D.

The cardboard dome designed by R. Buckminster Fuller for the Trienale in Milan shown by Betty Pepis in her stimulating layout, "People in Plastic Houses" (Nov. 28), was meant to be plastic impregnated.

"AS I see, so I draw," Boris Artzybasheff disarmingly remarks in his new portfolio of cartoons, "As I See" (Dodd, Mead, $7.50). And in further exploration of his astonishing satires and charades: "Being slightly myopic, all I have to do is to take off my glasses and the world around me looks that way."

BOWIE, Md., Dec. 4 -- Conn McCreary rode the winner of the $29,000 John B. Campbell Memorial Handicap at the Bowie track today. MeCreary was lucky to get back in one piece.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 4 -- Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom said tonight that to prevent an open clash between the races, it might be necessary to intensify South Africa's apartheid or racial separation legislation.

CHICAGO, Dec, 4 -- Employment figures in the Chicago area during the next few months are expected to slip slightly from the peak established late this year despite moderate expansion in manufacturing facilities, the Illinois State Employment Service predicted. Nominal increases in employment in machinery manufacturing and leather goods will be balanced by a considerable offset in transportation equipment.

ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 4 -- Upsala defeated Roanoke, 77 -- 59, in basketball tonight at the Orange Armory. The score was tied 48-all at the five-minute mark of the second half, but then the Vikings spurted for 14 consecutive points.

The $750,000 building, which will bring together under one roof all of the Red Cross services, will be one of the first structures completed in the center. It is scheduled for occupancy early in 1955.

IN my lower connecticut garden, about the last job of the gardening year is "hilling up ' the hybrid tea roses. Hilling up simply means heaping soil about eight or ten inches high around the base of each bush. This keeps the plants from heaving out of the earth during the frequent periods of freezing and thawing that are so characteristic of New England winters.

If rain does not provide it, water must be applied in adequate quantity to help prevent drying of foliage and stems during periods of bright winter sunshine and strong winds.

LONDON, Nov. 11 -- Several famous British physicists are working on the theory that the planets are not made up of substances normally found on earth but are probably composed of gases transformed into a solid metallic state by colossal pressure.

ROBERT EDMOND JONES will be missed by theatre audiences and stage people alike. Most of all, perhaps, he will be mourned by his colleagues, the designers of stage settings. He was the founder of the whole present-day tradition of scene design in the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 3 -- The Supreme Court's reaction to Senatorial delay in confirming the nomination of John Marshal Harlan of New York, to be an Associate Justice, was. a revision of its schedule that apparently postpones most Of. the important work of the court until a full bench is present.
The stock market last week entered the homestretch for 1954 on a strong note after reminding its critics that a bull market makes up its own logic as it goes along.

The Salk anti-polio vaccine is being prepared for the commercial market by at least five pharmaceutical companies in the expectation that nation-wide tests of the preparation Will be successful, Francis C. Brown, president of the Schering Corporation, said yesterday.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 4 -- In this tiny island, where baseball is both the national pastime and the national passion, the incomparable "Weelie Mays of the Nueva York Gigantes" has won the "ultimo" honor.

THERE are countless ways of bringing a boy and a book together and, as Kipling said of writing tribal lays, every one of them is right. The result is what matters -- the wide, new world of the imagination and the young mind expanding in it.

WAPPINGERS FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Home owners along the banks of the Wappingers Creek were restoring bric-a-brac and utensils on mantle-pieces and shelves today after an annoying week of vibrations caused by the waterfall.

ERSTWHILE patrons of the old Theatre Guild on Fifty-second Street, along with those more recent visitors who attended it as the ANTA Theatre when it was housing such revivals as "Desire Under the Elms" and "Golden Boy," hardly will recognize the place on its reopening shortly.

The famous Trudeau Sanatorium at Saranac, N. Y., for the treatment of tuberculosis has closed its doors. Ordinarily such an event would lead to the conclusion that the institution affected was a failure. The truth is that Trudeau Sanatorium was a suc cess.
ROLLING eastward across the great Russian plain, the antique wooden sleeping car that is taking the Western traveler to Moscow creaks gently and drowsily. The traveler himself dozes.

LARGELY as a result of Mr. Crowther's very favorable revew of the new film version of "Aida," I went round to the Little Carnegie when I was in New York, and was bitterly disappointed. I am not writing to you simply because Mr. Crowther's view of the picture differs from mine, but because I think the review -- possibly through no fault of Mr. Crowther's -- was very misleading.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 4 -- Political thinking in Latin America now is being directed toward the concept of Civil Service for municipal employes.

Alan Ameche, All-America fullback from Wisconsin, became the first of the 1954 crop of college football stars yesterday to receive a fat offer from the Canadian Professional League and he got not one but two.

That the lead editorial in The New York Times of Nov. 28 and an article by Prof. Seymour Harris in the Magazine Section dealt acutely with Latin America are salutary signs that the condition described in the editorial (the "anomaly that a region which is supremely important to the United States attracts so much less interest than other parts of the world") may be changing.
The coaches of the participating colleges recommended yesterday that the Eastern sprint regatta be transferred from the Potomac River in Washington to "a more suitable course."

IN his review of "Prelude to Point Four" by Merle Curti and myself, Samuel Flagg Bemis stated that "This book is apparently a doctoral thesis by the disciple [Birr], extended, organized and touched up by the master [Curti]."

WITH passion and dignity, "Fisher of Men" retells the story of Simon Peter, the rough-hewn Galilean who later was to be first among Christ's apostles. The novel opens with 15-year-old Simon vowing to revenge himself on the Roman soldiers who murdered his father and to liberate his people by force of arms.
NEWARK, Dec. 4 -- The New Jersey State Chamber of Commerce today urged the State Assembly to defeat Senate Bill 344, which would establish the formula for fixing gasoline prices to the consumer.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 1 -- A newly-released salary census shows that the poverty of a great part of the white collar class in West Germany continues, despite the startling economic recovery of recent years.

ALBANY, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Determine, the Kentucky Derby winner, came from far off the pace to win the $15,000 added Oakland Handicap today. Andrew Crevolin's racer won in a sea of mud and closed the gap on High Gun in the race for 1954 money winning honors.
The boxer, Ch. Bang Away of Sirrah Crest, achieved his 100th best in show last night. He was chosen by the judge who had put him up for his first top prize four years ago.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- Differences between the Congress of Industrial Organizations and the American Federation of Labor on what should go into a unity compact seemed likely today to complicate plans for a quick merger.

OMAHA, Dec. 4 -- Omaha has before it the question of updating and expanding its City-Wide Plan, which probably has brought the greatest period of civic improvement in its history. The question has been brought to the fore by Mayor John Rosenblatt.

A LITTLE over a year ago, after having let the idea marinate for a couple before that, the New School for Social Research, which likes to encompass all areas of learning in its grave, enlightened embrace, expanded its American Studies section by putting in a course called "Show Business: Work in Progress" and setting two modified hipsters to work teaching it.

ALFRED DUFF COOPER, first Viscount Norwich, died on the first day of this year. He served his country long and ably as soldier, parliamentarian, Cabinet Minister and Ambassador. He gave to contemporary literature a classic biography of Talleyrand, a solid life of Haig and the exquisite short novel "Operation Heartbreak."

WASHINGTON. The most powerful voice raised against many aspects of the Eisenhower foreign policy is that of Senator William F. Knowland, Republican of California, the Senate majority leader in the Eighty-third Congress. In the interview below he elaborates his views in answers to questions put by William S. White of The New York Times Senate staff and Cabell Phillips, Washington correspondent for The Times Sunday Department.

ALTHOUGH the sidewalk superintendents of catastrophe spoke with their usual dreary relish, 1954 in books had by Christmastime produced a variety of notable monuments. The most grandiose was Arnold Toynbee's four-towered and opaquely windowed addition to his already massive "A Study of History."
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 -- Democrats made big strides this week toward fundamental North-South unity in an effort to regain the White House in 1956.
THE advertising commercial in television is like the vermouth in a martini. There has to be some of it but too much spoils the desired effect.

IF ever a gardener were to have a dream lily, the Formosanum lily would be at the top of the list, as far as I am concerned. It has many things to recommend it and practically nothing to its discredit.

DALLAS, Dec. 4 -- Notre Dame's powerful line smothered Southern Methodist's ground game today as Ralph Guglielmi and Joe Heap led the Fighting Irish to a 26-14 victory. A roaring crowd of 75,504 saw the game in the Cotton Bowl.
Two Jewish leaders warned last night that barriers and tensions between nations and a drive for conformity and assimilation had posed serious threats for the survival of the Jewish people.

FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- There was literally dancing in the streets upon the occasion of the opening recently of a new super highway, U. S. 1, from the Gateway at the northern limits of this city down to Sixth Street, a distance of four and a half miles.

THE high sophistication of Japanese art reaches a peak in the painted screens which unfold, in one panel of scrupulous fancy after another, the legends of the race. They have long been collectors' trophies but, largely owing to the Japanese Government's understandable reluctance to give such national treasures exit visas, are increasingly difficult to obtain.

The resolution expressing moral condemnation of Joseph R. McCarthy by his colleagues in the Senate was long overdue; and the three-to-one vote by which it was adopted after the most extreme provocation and careful consideration gives it impressive force.
Optimists outnumber pessimists among the nation's retailers.

For the forty-third year The New York Times opens its appeal for the Hundred Neediest Cases. Over the years the nature of the needs of the neediest has changed. Social security has made some progress. The general level of well-being in this part of the world has increased.

THE psychologists as well as the historian will find this third volume of the monumental diaries of Harold Ickes full of fascinating material. The period covered, which the publishers describe as that of "The Lowering Clouds," includes the ending of the two-term tradition in the American Presidency and the snail-slow, then bomb-violent, entrance of the United States into World War II.

ON these pages today are told the stories of the Hundred Neediest Cases of New York City. They are the stories of neighbors of yours -- good people, overwhelmed by circumstances even as you, except for the turn of fortune, might also have been overwhelmed. On their behalf at this Christmas season, The New York Times makes its forty-third annual appeal.
A Christmas Fair for young and old will be held Saturday morning and afternoon at the Child Educational Foundation, 535 East Eighty-fourth Street.

Most nations that must import oil still find it difficult to obtain the necessary foreign exchange. With the demand increasing as industrial production moves ahead, the problem of payment is aggravated.

MAJOR exhibitions in postwar Europe have been devoted, almost without exception, to individual artists. Caravaggio, Tiepolo, Lotto, Guido Reni, Gauguin, Van Gogh, Picasso: these are the artists on whom attention has been fixed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy failed to leave here today for a Cincinnati speaking engagement and his wife explained tonight his elbow injury had not sufficiently healed to permit him to make the trip.

GLEN COVE, L. I., Dec. 4 -- Mike Musto, mail carrier for thirty-five years and one of Glen Cove's first four carriers is retiring this month. He is 62 years old and says he has walked 100,000 miles with a pack on his back, which he believes is enough for one man.
ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- Residents of New York City earned more last year than residents of all other states except California, Pennsylvania and Illinois.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 4 (UP) -- In defeating his old foe, Vic Seixas of Philadelphia, for the Victorian singles title, Ken Rosewall played as if it were his personal responsibility to restore Australia's lagging tennis prestige.

LESS has been written about the jungle war in Malaya than about most of the other areas of conflict. In what has been written there has been relatively little space given to the origins and inception of the struggle.
The purchase last week by the Minute Maid Corporation of the Snow Crop division of Clinton Foods, Inc., for $39,800,000 will have a number of important effects on the frosted food industry.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Millions of cattle are grazing on plains and millions more are in the feed lots of the Midwest, where corn is king. Millions of hogs are being fattened and sheep and lambs are eating their way toward the dinner table.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 4 -- A program designed to have pupils learn foreign languages earlier and easier is being expanded in the Santa Barbara grade schools. The order for the expansion was issued by the Superintendent of Schools, Einar W. Jacobsen, after a test of a year.

The Long Island State Park Commission frankly was stumped yesterday over what to do about a patrolman who said "I quit," although the law required the commission to say "You're fired." A decision was promised early this week.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The Secretary General of the United Nations and the President Of the George Junior Republic exchanged views today on their problems.

IN the recently publisher last volume of his autobiography Sean O'Casey reports how his mother used to tell him that the small circles bounced on the Dublin sidewalks by the pelting raindrops were pennies, and little Sean felt rich while the rain was falling.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 4 -- Paul Mulholland Butler, 49 years old, practices law here as a member of the corporation law firm Jones, Obenchain and Butler.

TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 2 -- The successful negotiations for a United States-Chinese mutual defense treaty brought new assurance this week to President Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist Government on Formosa.

When Antoine Lavoisier was guillotined in 1794 after judicial proceedings much like those adopted by the Russians when they wish to rid themselves of a commissar who has lost favor with the Government, Lagrange, the famous mathematician remarked: "Only a moment to cut off that head, and a hundred years may not give us another like it."

THE election of 1864 was the first time the American people chose a President in wartime. Aside from the fact that one of their possible choices was Abraham Lincoln, the 1864 referendum is important because it is one of the few instances in the history of democratic government when a people were faced with the issue of whether they wanted to make peace or continue war -- and voted for war.

Adelphi College of Garden City, spoiled Nat Holman's return to college basketball coaching last night. The Panthers routed City College, 107 to 78, at the Beavers' gymnasium. It was the first game of the season for both teams.
DECEMBER. -in Massachusetts means it is time to start putting the garden to bed. Gardeners in more northern sections of New England are already well along on this annual chore.

LOW re-enlistment rates, numerous resignations of regular officers and the continuing effects of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's controversy with the Army have emphasized the unsatisfactory state of service morale.

BACK in 1922 when I was trying to be a poet and supporting myself by writing editorials for The New York World, I found three acres with a house and a waterfall in Rockland County that could be bought for $3,000, $500 down.

Performances of the musical play, "Fanny," on Wednesday and Dec. 14 have been taken over by the Maternity Center Association, 48 East Ninety-second Street. "Fanny," starring Ezio Pinza and Walter Slezak, is at the Majestic Theatre.

A new heat pack has been developed in Britain. It consists of an inner bagful of a dry chemical compound and an outer ventilated waterproof envelope. The addition of two teaspoonfuls of water is enough to start the generation of heat for whatever a hot-water bag or electric pad may be useful. Within a few minutes after adding water the pack has a temperature of 110 degrees F.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 -- Following is the text of an address by Adlai E. Stevenson before the dinner of the Democratic National Committee here tonight:
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 4 -- Democracy was defined today by a Pakistani Government official to mean that the "leader controls every activity of the people."

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations has instructed its executive vice president, John V. Riffe, to stop using his C. I. O. title in connection with his activities in the Moral Re-Armament movement.

THE audacious cantilever that seems to float in space with no visible means of support; the concrete dome, spanning 160 feet, as thin in relation to its surface as an eggshell to its own; steel trusses is delicate as a spider's web; great structures suspended rather than supported, are some of the imaginative feats modern engineers and architects have performed by exploiting the materials -- steel and reinforced concrete --and the techniques of our time.
The Civil Aeronautics Board completed last week its hearings on the application of the Air Coach Transport Association, Inc., to operate an exchange for coordinating civilian transportation.

NOW that winter with hard freezing of the ground is imminent here in West Virginia, I realize that it is time to think of protection for my shrubs, perennials and bulbs. While many plants do not need winter protection, all newly set shrubbery, evergreens, bulbs and perennials require cover for the first winter to prevent roots from heaving out of the ground before they have had time to become established.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The clearest outstanding post-censure fact concerning Senator Joseph R. McCarthy is that whatever his future may now be it will lie outside the Senate.

United States policy in Asia over the past five years has been founded on a grave, calculated risk. The aim of the policy has been to prevent further Communist expansion in the Far East without touching off a big war. The risk has lain in the fact that shooting has been going on in the area almost continuously and shooting is never easy to confine.
Programs for improving train service and railroading were presented here last week at the annual meeting of the American Society of Mechanical Engineers.

Last Tuesday in the cafeteria of the West Hempstead (L. I.) High School, a typical American community dinner was held. Women of the community prepared turkey, high school students provided the music and entertainment, and there was no dais, for this was a "family" party.
WINTERSET, Iowa, Dec. 4 -- The 1954 harvest season is ended in the supper Midwest with corn production slightly below normal in most areas, but with yields of other crops among the best in years.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Sixty South Korean lawmakers returned to the National Assembly today, ending a four-day boycott in protest against passage of a constitutional amendment authorizing President Syngman Rhee to seek re-eelction as often as he wishes.
Wall Street will be asked this week to get up the money to build the biggest bridge in the world.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 4 -- J. Lawton Collins, special United States Ambassador, has warned Premier Ngo Dinh Diem to reform his Government or face the possibility of losing United States backing.

Mr. Hoffman, in pointing out that Swiss neutrality originally applied only to Swiss territory, failed to mention that the very divisions among the cantons brought out the need for certain units to act as conciliators and mediators -- from the Appenzell Treaty of Association in 1411 to the Basle and Schaffhausen Treaties of Confederation in 1501 and the Appenzell Treaty of Confederation in 1513.

Peggy Durdin's "Saigon in the Shadow of Doom" (Nov. 21) is as vivid and realistic a piece of journalism as I have read in a long time. I certainly do get the impression of Saigon lying in the "shadow of doom."

THE story is told of G. K. Chesterton that he was once asked the old chestnut about being left alone on an uninhabited desert island. If he found himself in that situation and could have but one book with him, what book would it be?
BUFFALO, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Niagara scored a 71-65 victory over the Fordham quintet in the first game of a double-header at Memorial Auditorium tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- California political circles are seething in this slack season over the selection of the Assembly Speaker. This ordinarily draws little notice.
Dr. David Dodds Henry, executive vice chancellor of New York University, accepted the presidency of the University of Illinois yesterday after a period of indecision stemming from a misunderstanding.

GENEVA, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Reports of increasing pollution of the two largest of the Finger Lakes, Seneca and Cayuga, have prompted action by the Geneva Common Council. It has ordered a sanitary survey to determine the sources of pollution.

Telford Taylor's "An Inquiry Into Investigations" (Nov. 21), lucidly pointed out the low abusive level to which some of our Congressional investigations have fallen, and at the same time reminded us of what a priceless tool the power to investigate is, or can be.

The "great debate" about the nation's grand strategy was stimulated last week as Senator William F. Knowland again urged a blockade of China and Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery gave the nation some free advice about military organization.

THE fine art of raiding, wherein Americans have always excelled, was never so well practiced as in the Civil War. Achieving little except as psychological warfare, raids perhaps diverted war-bored civilians more than enemy forces.
May I add a bit to C. B. Palmer's vignette on Bluie West 8, Greenland, and its adoption as a stopover by the Scandinavian Airlines System's new Arctic route? ("Arctic Stopover," Nov. 28.)
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 3 -- "Smogville," as some of its residents are bitterly referring to it, appointed itself a "smog czar" this week.
MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- The Soviet Union's foreign policy today -- to paraphrase Theodore Roosevelt's old slogan for the United States -- is to speak softly but not to lay aside the big stick.

BY this time, Messers. Bleiler and Dikty's anthologies are institutions, and this excellent collection of thirteen stories shows why. All are good, some are excellent, and a few are superior. Although most of the author's names are familiar my personal preference was for "Yankee Exodus," in which a newcomer to science fiction, Ruth M. Goldsmith, tells an enchanting tale of what happens when an extra-terrestrial meets a Down-Easter.
HARTFORD, Dec. 1 -- Governor-elect Abraham A. Ribicoff is sharpening his knives to pare the fat off Connecticut.

Radcliffe College officers and undergraduates will gather informally to discuss problems and policies of the college in a series of meetings entitled "Radcliffe Off the Record." Consisting of five topics, the discussions will be led by President Wilbur K. Jordan and the deans of the college.

CHRISTMAS stories have for much longer than it takes to tell been as much a part of the season for children as the star on the tip of the tree. Under the flaring gaslights of the Eighties they listened and laughed to "The Peterkins' Christmas Tree," (Lucretia Hale).

AS the author of "God's Secret Armies" himself says, the episodes in his book are of the cloak-and-dagger type. They are based on a series of articles written by him for The New York Daily Mirror. In one of them fifteen men train for months to become secret religious workers in the U. S. S. R., succeed in entering but are liquidated within a few months because one of them turned traitor to the group.
The annual pre-holiday rush of exhibitions is on in New York galleries with some forty events scheduled for this week.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 4 (AP) -- The Baltimore Colts scored on their fifth field goal with twelve seconds left in the game to beat the Los Angeles Rams, 22 -- 21, today in an exciting National Football League contest.

MOSCOW, Dec. 4 -- "Honestly, bluntly and frankly as befits a soldier," Marshal Alexander Vasilevsky today told Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery that he was "disgusted through and through" by Viscount Montgomery's "preaching of atomic war."

A free lecture on "Interior Decorating as an Art," covering such fields as fabric design, styles and periods of furniture and color harmony, will be given on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.

NOW that the two service academies and a few other colleges have barred their students from debating the intercollegiate debate topic of the year -- namely, diplomatic recognition of Peiping -- the above has become the new informal debate topic in dormitories and student newspapers at colleges across the nation. As might be expected, supporters of the negative are hard to find.
SINCE the New York City Ballet has more leading dancers on its roster than there are leading roles in "The Nutcracker," there is a good deal of rotation in the casting at the City Center these weeks.

CITY roof-top gardeners need not feel completely left out when it comes to attracting birds with plantings of berried shrubs and trees. Although their country cousins will, of course, attract a wider population and variety of birds, there are a few that might be enticed to visit urban areas.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 4 -- The Texas Highway Patrol has resorted to radar in an attempt to enforce the legal speed limit of 60 miles an hour in the daytime and 55 miles at night.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- A plan to hold parents responsible for curfew violations by their children and to prosecute those parents, if possible, has been announced by State's Attorney General John Gutknecht.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 4 -- Harry M. Thompson, executive vice president of the Hampton Roads Maritime Association here, was named this week to head a special committee to study the problems of coordinating sea transport facilities with civil defense plans in the event of war.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 -- Gov.-elect George M. Leader expects to be ready with administrative and legislative proposals to redeem Democratic campaign pledges by Jan. 18, the day of his inauguration.

THIS Sunday marks the beginning of the end of the year. A few things have happened that bring some sort of Yuletide cheer. Ernest Hemingway is able to pay off his debts and Bennett Cerf has put together a book with more humor in it than we thought existed.
BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Massachusetts is preparing to extend its program of more public beaches along the Atlantic Ocean.

SPANISH customs and traditions are so different from those of other European countries that a winter holiday spent in Spain can be a unique and exciting experience. The milder climate is an added attraction, as is the festive spirit that prevails wherever you go -- the Spanish celebrate their holidays with gusto.
A "new look" in France's foreign trade and domestic economy is giving substance to the nation's renewed prestige as a major partner in Western political cooperation.

NEWARK, Dec. 4 -- Mrs. Hortense F. Kessler, president of the Board of Public Utility Commissioners of New Jersey, today appealed to the Lackawanna Railroad to reconsider its scheduled abandonment of service on the Christopher Street ferry on Dec. 15.

CLINTON, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Heavy population movements to the suburbs may lesson some of the political, economic and social conflicts now existing between the Northern and Southern segments of New York State, Dr. David M. Ellis, Hamilton College history professor, declared here today.
Spiritual leaders of Orthodox Judaism have condemned the recent action taken by the Conservative branch in revising the traditional Jewish marriage contract.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 4 -- The Board of Police Commissioners has closed the last three precincts in the city as "relics of the gaslight era," made obsolete by the automotive and radio age.

ROME, Dec. 4 -- Another restful night Friday improved Pope Pius' general condition so much that he was considered tonight to be out of imminent danger. He is thought to have a good chance of recovering, provided he does not suffer a relapse. A relapse, it was feared, would be fatal.

IT is part of the genius of modern American reporting that the reporter tells you as much about himself as about the events which he describes. To those who were brought up in the dignified, third person, foreign correspondent style, a book such as this one seems like the cavortings of a flapper among the dowagers.

The tremendous years of this century, with their drama, terror and greatness, all seemed to unroll before us last week as the world paid tribute to Sir Winston Churchill on his eightieth birthday. It was his week, although there never was, and won't be, any abatement in Britain of healthy partisan politics.
Five college presidents have been elected trustees of the Institute of Internatiinal Education, 1 East Sixty-seventh Street, Arthur H. Houghton Jr., chairman of the board, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Justice Department has decided against perjury prosecution of any witnesses in the Senate's televised Army -McCarthy hearings last spring.

ALBANY, Dec. 4 -- The State Thruway Authority concedes that the opening of the cross-state expressway had reduced business at some gas stations, motels and restaurants along nearby routes, but the agency is convinced that in the long run the problem will not be serious.
A FRESH book by Anthony Trollope, and about Barsetshire at that, ought to be headline news. How it happens, John Hampden explains.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- Legislators have been ingenious in finding more sources of revenue to support public schools and now must turn their attention to defining what they want in education and what they do not want.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 4 -- Although there is widespread doubt that polling will ever take place as scheduled, the nomination of candidates has begun for independent Indonesia's first general elections.

EVERY day thousands of men, women and children are unable to provide for themselves because of sickness, accidents, disabilities, old age, death, unemployment and other conditions which stop wages, exhaust savings and otherwise reduce people to economic and social need.

MONTREAL, Dec. 4 -- A three-day controversy that created an uproar in race and language-conscious Quebec today resulted in the removal of Miss Ida Henderson as nursing matron in eastern Canada's largest veterans' hospital.

ALADDIN rubbed a magic lamp and a fragrant and wonderful feast was set before him, prepared by unseen cooks in unseen kitchens. The epicure of today is not unlike the lucky tailor's son of the Arabian fairy tale.

Your editorial "Toward Freer Trade" is a source of great encouragement to me. I have given forty years of my life to international trade and firmly believe that world peace can result only from satisfactory trading between peoples of all nations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- An effort is being made in Administration circles to bring together President Eisenhower and Senator William F. Knowland for talks to end the Republican split over foreign and domestic policies.

TRENTON, Dec. 4 -- A wave of resentment against major railroads operating between this state and New York is rapidly spreading among North Jersey commuters. It has reached such proportions that the situation is now the subject of serious consideration by two committees of the State Legislature.

THE sea occupies an extraordinarily large part of the globe's surface, and man has been attempting to conquer it for several millennia. He has, moreover, recorded his attempts in staggering detail. To produce a convincing portrait by selecting "a collection of writings about the sea in all its aspects," within the limits of even a substantial quarto, calls for a high measure of poetic imagination on the part of the editor.

SINCE the first Christmas and the subsequent earthly life of Jesus of Nazareth, many writers -- believers and non-believers -- have retold the story of that life. It is not every year, however, that even one notable book on this theme appears. Yet in 1954 there have been two: Daniel-Rops' "Jesus and His Times" (Book Review, Sept. 19) and now Romano Guardini's THE LORD (Regnery, $6.50).

FOR the skeptic who wonders why one complete book on fishing isn't enough to satisfy intelligent men in pursuit of unintelligent fish, the answer lies in the fact that Izaak Walton wrote, rewrote, pruned, subtracted and added to five editions of "The Compleat Angler" during his lifetime.

A collection of essays commemorating the late William Pepperell Montague, head of Barnard College's Philosophy Department for forty years and Johnsonian Professor of Philosophy at Columbia University, has been published by the Barnard trustees.

TODAY more and more movie actors are working behind the cameras as well as in front of them. They aspire to be directors as well as performers -- sometimes because they realize an actor's fame is all too fleeting, sometimes because they find mere acting too limiting artistically.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 2 -- Former President Truman will be back in the thick of a political victory atmosphere Wednesday night when he introduces Averell Harriman, Governor-elect of New York, at a big dinner here.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 4 -- Senator McCarthy was to have made an address here before some 800 persons in the Hotel Sheraton-Gibson at a $10-a-plate dinner sponsored by the Cuvier Press Club.

TYRUS RAYMOND COBB was in town not long ago, still as interested in baseball as when he was compiling his fantastic lifetime batting average of 367. One thought popped into mind on seeing baseball's greatest hitter once again. The fabled Georgia Peach had always insisted that he was a manufactured hitter, not a natural one.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- Cornell opened its basketball season with a 66-53 triumph over Scranton University tonight.
Many tickets have been purchase for the pre-opening performance of "Witness for the Prosecution" on the night of Dec. 15 at Henry Miller's Theatre for the benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild.

The sixteen members of the United Nations that furnished forces to repel the aggression in Korea are now agreed that they must espouse the complaint of the United States against the Red Chinese imprisonment of American aviators shot down in Korea.
TOKYO, Dec. 4 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida apparently has determined to force new national elections as the price of his withdrawal from political leadership.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- In a colorful two-hour ceremony, the Rev. Dr. Anson Phelps Stokes Jr., former rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church in New York, was consecrated today as Coadjutor Bishop of the Diocese of Massachusetts.
An insight into the poverty on the typical Soviet collective farm has been made possible by Soviet publication of data on collective farm income.

LONDON, Dec. 4 -- (UP) -- Communist China gave Britain $1,027,600 today as compensation for shooting down a British commercial airliner. The money includes compensation for three Americans killed in the attack.
Friday's flash strike that hit luxury line piers on the North River was not renewed yesterday, but the stoppage delayed the departure of the Queen Mary and the Saturnia.

BOSTON, Dec. 4 -- Doug Mohns scored two goals to lead the Boston Bruins to a 6-to-3 victory over the New York Rangers tonight. A crowd of 10,104 attended the National Hockey League game in Boston Garden.

Two persons were killed in fires here yesterday, one of them a terror-stricken woman who jumped to her death in a tenement blaze. The other was fatally burned when she fell asleep while smoking in front of a television set.
THE Tenth Annual (1955) National High School Photographic Awards contest is announced by Eastman Kodak Company, the sponsor. There will be 256 prizes totaling $5,000 in cash.

WE suppose there are still some households in this land where, as part of family festivities, the pre-schoolers are called upon to recite a poem or two for the company assembled. We suppose there are -- but it has been years since we've seen one.

FRENCH-BORN 23-year-old Raymond Maufrais literally journeyed to that undiscovered country from whose bourn no traveler returns. In the summer of 1949 he set off from the coastal town of Mana, in French Guiana, to find a way upriver, to the Tumuc-Humac Mountains on the Brazilian border -- a notoriously inhospitable part of the world, where Europeans have been making expeditions since Sir Walter Raleigh.

North Atlantic steamship travel volume will fall short of the unofficial 1,000,000-berth target this year, but is expected to exceed 1953 figures by well over 50,000.

THE American Contract Bridge -- League's national tournament, which has been in progress during the past week at Atlanta, Ga., and is in its final sessions today, has set an unwanted record. For the first time in a dozen years or more it has set no new attendance records.

Members of the Bennington (Vt.) College alumnae benefit committee have completed plans for a theatre party at the Jan. 19 performance of "House of Flowers'' by Harold Arlen and Truman Capote, at the Alvin Theatre. Proceeds will go to the Bennington College Scholarship Fund, which offers assistance to a third of the school's 350 students.

As the festive season approached, New York heard within the last few days from there of the most distinguished makers of French champagnes. All agreed that champagne is irreplaceable for the holidays. With equal unanimity, they urged that it be made the drink of more ordinary occasions.

CANADA is the latest country to institute an international music festival in a bid for summer tourists. The site chosen for it is Stratford, the small Ontario city where Shakespearean festivals have drawn large crowds the last two summers.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 4 (UP) -- Pennsylvania's basketball team fought off a last-ditch Purdue rally tonight to gain a 69-68 victory. The triumph marked Ray Stanley's debut as Penn coach.

I DEEPLY regret that in my review of Miguel Covarrubias' "The Eagle, the Jaguar and the Serpent," I referred to Dr. Robert Heine-Geldern as "the late." This statement was based on information which had been relayed to me from Austria some months ago.

THERE is no record of the first solitary voyager. He may, or may not, have been the "red and strange" man who in a dugout canoe reached the coast of Spain in the Middle Ages and died soon after landing. But the sea chronicles are ample and here are gathered scores of fascinating tales of adventurers who have crossed the oceans in small boats.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The United Nations General Assembly unanimously adopted today a resolution endorsing President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace program. It also expressed the hope that the proposed international atomic energy agency "will be established without delay."
ROCHESTER, Dec. 4 (AP) -- Peter Mueller, former German middleweight champion, gained a split ten-round decision over Ralph (Tiger) Jones tonight, Mueller weighed 156 pounds, Jones 161.

NEWARK, Dec. 4 -- Reported shifts of operations by charity racketeers from New York to New Jersey "will be watched with interest" by officials and legislators in this state.
Fire commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. has taken steps to punish firemen who "unnecessarily and with gross carelessness" lose their badges.

"Aida" is just another long stride down the sodden path of neglected opportunities. It retains the dramatic weaknesses inherent in opera by not realizing the excellent opportunities of the motion picture technique. And it allows the aggrandizement of these weaknesses by giving the insinuation of the camera rampant, unrestrained play.

ANDROS, the Bahamas, Dec. 4 -- Although they are more responsive when the weather is right, the Fresh Creek bonefish will take a fly during a strong wind. They provide plenty of excitement for the angler willing to fish the flats at night.

A GREAT many of the new disks in the current spate of recordings of Spanish music are devoted to that branch of it that has been given the general name of flamenco. One of the most exciting of those disks is Danzas Flamencas, which has been made for Decca by Jose Greco and his company.
LONDON, Dec. 4 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery began an intensive search of his private papers today in an effort to help Sir Winston Churchill out of mounting political difficulties.

CAIRO, Dec, 4 (AP) -- The so-called solar boat of Cheops isn't a boat at all but a pile of disassembled parts of a boat, according to a United States archaeologist who yesterday had the best look yet taken at the famous find.

THE antagonists in "Moby Dick" are not merely Ahab and the White Whale, but in a larger sense the whale and the ship. The "Pequod" is a protagonist as a kind of world in microcosm, just as the great monster is destiny, or evil, or brute force in small.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The running fight over the Dixon-Yates private power contract moves into a new setting Tuesday.

THE tiny island of Saint Roger in the Caribbean was finally struck by a hurricane -- the inhabitants were completely unprepared because they had always assumed that their flourishing little tourist islet was too small to attract the attention of such major phenomena.

LAFAYETTE, Ind., Dec. 4 -- Incorporation of a $1,000,000 community redevelopment foundation to tackle the slum clearance and housing problems of East Chicago, Ind., has been announced by Purdue University officials.

CHICAGO, Dec. 4 -- The world's first nuclear reactor, now abandoned in a near-by Cook County forest preserve, may be set up as a memorial to Dr. Enrico Fermi, an architect of the atomic age and Nobel Prize winner.

MOSCOW, Dec. 3 -- By coincidence a magazine article accusing a United States encyclopedia of falsifying history was published this week simultaneously with the appearance of the latest volume of the Great Soviet Encyclopedia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 4 -- The State Department is withholding $17,000 in back pay and pension contributions due John Paton Davies Jr., dismissed from the Foreign Service a month ago.

The engineer's increasingly frequent role as a leader of industry instead of merely a technician is portrayed in a number of recent surveys. This development has been attributed to industry's growing need for men in executive posts who can keep the firm abreast of scientific and technical developments.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 4 -- The United States has been facing a two-pronged assault -- in hemisphere debate and at the United Nations -- on its reluctance to freeze price relations between raw materials and manufactured goods.

THE first of Arturo Toscanini's celebrated operatic broadcasts with the N. B. C. Symphony Orchestra, the Beethoven Fidelio heard on Dec. 10 and 17, 1944, now is available in a two-disk album from R. C. A. Victor.
The first International Press Ball will be held on Dec. 23 in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the auspices of the Foreign Press Association.
Business throughout the United States during 1955 will be good. This forecast was made yesterday by economists of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, with headquarters in Newark, N. J.

FROM the dedication -- "To Elaine, who steadfastly maintains that the TC was a better car than the TD" -- to one of the last captions -- "Front view of the Bentley Continental, a high-speed luxury car, sold only to drivers who have a reputation of great ability, and $17,000" -- the reader is off in a cloud of sports car gold dust.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 1 -- The Korean Bear, second of three cargo-passenger ships being built for the Pacific Far East Line under contract with the Maritime Commission, will be launched Dec. 11 at the San Francisco shipyard of the Bethlehem Pacific Coast Steel Corporation.

A YEAR before he died John Murray Anderson was spending spare time on his memoirs, now published as "Out Without My Rubbers." Pausing for a quick statistical glance backward, he found that over thirty-six years he had created and produced -- in many cases also written -- thirty-three major musical shows, seven circuses, four aquacades, eleven pageants, sixty-one unit shows and twenty-four night club shows, not to mention one movie and part of another.
Many dinner parties will be given before the Dec. 16 benefit performance at the Majestic Theatre of the musical play, "Fanny," which has been taken over by the Sheltering Arms Children's Service.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 4 -- Building activity in the Ninth Federal Reserve District continued ahead of last year's pace through the first ten months of 1954, the Minneapolis Reserve Bank reported. Only one of the six states in the district -- North Dakota -- reported construction starts below that of 1953 in dollar volume.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 4 (UP) -- The Rebel Stable's Super Devil came from far off the pace today to score a one-and-one-half length triumph over M. E. Affeld's Two Fisted in the $3,500 Governor's Handicap at the Fair Grounds.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Edgar H. Dixon and Eugene A. Yates tonight defended their contract with the Government for feeding private power into the Tennessee Valley Authority as in the public interest.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 4 -- The richest known gold field in the world is beginning to pay off in the sandveld of the northwestern Orange Free State, once South Africa 's most stagnant province.

Elsa Zebranska, a mezzo-soprano who sang at the Metropolitan Opera during the 1940-41 season, gave a recital last night in Town Hall. With Paul Meyer at the piano, she sang music by Marcello, Gluck, Durante, Brahms, Latvian composers (in Latvian), Gretchaninoff, Tchaikovsky and Rachmaninoff (in Russian), American composers, and an aria by Massenet.

All that the New York Rangers could realize in their National Hockey League game with the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden last night was a 3-to-3 tie. From the way the scoring went, though, the Broadway Blues were mighty happy to skate off with the even break, and the crowd of 12,687 shared their satisfaction.
The 1955 Brooklyn Red Cross drive for members and funds will be led by Everett M. Clark, vice president of the Manufacturers Trust Company and a veteran of seventeen years of Red Cross service.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Children's Bureau today cautioned parents against permitting the indiscriminate use of X-ray machines in fitting children's shoes.
The gangster cliche of a criminal seizing an innocent person as a shield was reversed late Saturday night by an ex-Marine who has been a patrolman for two years.
There is this to be said for living in the heart of the city: although there are dozens of things to do or see or listen to every day one does not have to do, see or listen to any of them.

ROME, Dec. 5 -- Thousands of Romans, kneeling in St. Peter's Basilica, wept today as they heard Pope Pius XII impart an apostolic blessing at the end of a beatification cere mony. The Pope's voice, which came through the loudspeakers and over the radio clearly, assuaged fears caused by his grave illness and confirmed the improvement that became manifest yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The work of the Patent Office has become so clogged that the condition is openly deplored by patent lawyers and the inventors they represent.
WALTHAM, Mass., Dec. 5 -- Ground was broken on the Brandies University campus today for the Hayden science building.

The four-year-old bronze-and-granite memorial to the late Gov. Alfred E. Smith has been so badly damaged by vandals that its restoration will cost $3,000, Parks Commissioner Robert, Moses said yesterday.
Frozen fish sticks have proved so popular that meat and Poultry are now being processed in a similar form.
Almost the last undeveloped portion of the historic Manor of Scarsdale in Scarsdale, N. Y., has been purchased by a group of home builders headed by Robert Beckley of New York.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 5 -- Steel production this month will show little if any decline from the 1954 monthly peak reached in November. the output is already exhibiting contraseasonal tendencies: it is not normal for ingot production to rise in December.
The entire seating capacity of the Metropolitan Opera House for the evening performance of "Tosca" on Feb. 5 has been taken over by the Vassar Club of New York as a benefit for its scholarship fund.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Sir Oliver Franks, former British Ambassador to Washington, argued strongly tonight against the continuation of discrimination against the dollar by this country any longer than necessary.

Gifts to the forty-third annual appeal of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from 172 donors have opened the Christmastime drive with $49,191.74.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 5 -- After three and a half weeks of hard bargaining, Spain and Switzerland signed a new trade agreement last week. Both sides acknowledged it to be perfectly satisfactory.

The twelve-story loft building on lot 62 by 98 feet at 42-46 West Thirty-eighth Street has been sold by the Marshall Management Corporation, Louis Sachar, president, and Joseph Rosen to an investor in a deal negotiated by Williams Co., brokers.

Much of the joy of Christmas comes from preparing the home for the holiday. If one is a home craftsman, this annual labor of love may be done with little cash investment. Two new leaflets prepared by the Douglas Fir Plywood Association give instructions for making such decorations.
GRAND JUNCTION, Colo., Dec. 5 (AP) -- A six-story office building will be built here on a turntable so it can keep facing the winter sun.

CEDARHURST, L. I., Dec. 5 -- G. Diehl Mateer Jr., of Philadelphia today became the first player to win the gold squash racquets invitation tournament at the Rockaway Hunt Club four times. He defeated Calvin D. MacCracken of New York in the final.

An electronic oven that cooks an eighteen-pound roast of beef in twenty minutes is being offered to restaurants by the Raytheon Manufacturing Company.
MOSCOW, Dec. 5 -- Cocktail party conversation, commonly regarded in the United States as either a joke or a bore, has lately been made an adjunct of statecraft and diplomacy in Moscow.
BERLIN, Monday, Dec. 6 -- In a surprise return to power the Social Democrats won West Berlin's election yesterday, partly through the poor showing made by the Communists.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 -- The twenty-five-day-old strike of seventy locomotive engineers on the Northwestern Pacific Railroad's 276-mile line from Tiburon to Eureka, Calif., ended today after a week-end of negotiations.

Before the printer's ink was dry on yesterday's announcement of the annual appeal for the Hundred Neediest of New York, their more fortunate neighbors and friends had already sent nearly $50,000 for their assistance during this Christmas season.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- London's critics gave a cool reception today to the performance of the visiting Soviet composer Aram Khatchaturian, who made a conducting debut at Royal Albert Hall.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 5 -- Dallas Symphony audience demonstrated with enthusiasm after Max Rudolf, artistic administrator of the Metropolitan Opera, had finished his concert as guest conductor. To Mr. Rudolf it meant his successful return to the symphonic field after an American career devoted to opera.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Dave Sparks, 26-year-old lineman for the Washington Redskins, died of an apparent heart attack tonight two hours after the Tribe played the Cleveland Browns.

The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday criticized the Government's policy of detaining in prison those aliens who might flee if paroled or whose entry into the United States would not be in the national interest.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Otto Graham passed and ran the Cleveland Browns to a 34-14 victory over the Washington Redskins today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- The General Assembly has received a tentative invitation to hold a commemorative session next June in San Francisco, where the United Nations Charter was signed June 26, 1945.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Senator Wayne Morse, who bolted the Republicans during the 1952 Presidential race, said today that the Republican party was split by "discord and disharmony" and might follow the Whig party into oblivion.
Dr. William G. Barrett, trustee and former president of the San Francisco Psychoanalytic Institute, was elected yesterday as president of the American Psychoanalytic Association.
DETROIT, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings snapped a two-game losing streak tonight with a 4-1 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks before 9,832 fans at Olympia Stadium.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Officials here are watching developments in Communist Hungary with extraordinary interest. The satellite Government there is in trouble not only with Moscow but also with its own people. And what is even more unusual, it is frankly admitting many of its difficulties.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 5 -- Approval of the United States attempt to have the General Assembly debate the Peiping regime's detention of eleven airmen on espionage charges appeared virtually certain tonight. Grover Whalen, long the official "greeter" for the City of New York, is completing his autobiography and Putnam will issue it next year under the title "Mr. New York." Mr. Whalen, present chairman of the board of Coty, Inc., tells of his experiences in politics and merchandising, as Police Commissioner and as head of New York's World's Fair.

Photo-engravers employed on six major New York newspapers accepted yesterday a two-year union contract offered by the Publishers Association of New York City that provides for a $5.80 weekly package increase for 450 workers.
Attorneys for the Civil Aeronautics Board fired both barrels yesterday at North American Airlines in response to a critical brief filed by the non-scheduled airline ten days ago.
A story from Charleston, W. Va., last month told about an experiment in hospitality practiced by high school squads before they met on the gridiron.
The doors of seventy-five homes in Harlem were thrown wide yesterday to welcome ninety-four foreign students, each of whom was adopted by an American family for a day.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Yale's athletic director reported today that one year's experience since the university agreed to pick up the athletic department's check, shows that pressure has been taken off its coaches and players.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 4 -- Efforts to create a northern sphere of defense in the Middle East have run afoul of United States-British differences.

DETROIT, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Detroit Lions, pressured by Philadelphia's big line, rallied for a touchdown in the final four minutes today to tie the Eagles, 13 -- 13. The tie enabled the Lions to clinch their third straight Western Conference title in the National Football League.
EVANSVILLE, Ind., Dec. 5 (AP) -- Jim Zaiser splashed through the mud for two fourth-quarter touchdowns as Delaware defeated Kent State today in the Refrigerator Bowl, 19 -- 7.
Frank Lane, alert for any deal that might help his Chicago White Sox, was as busy as any general manager on hand here yesterday for the major league meetings starting today.

TOKYO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- The Kyodo News Service said yesterday that Japanese trading companies were trying to arrange a deal to buy cashmere wool from Russia, process it in Japan and then export it to the United States.
British sterling continued under pressure again last week, selling down to $2.78 1/2, lowest since October, 1952. Week's close was $2.78 25/32, a net loss of 3/16 cent from the previous week.

BONN, Germany, Dee. 5 -- Simplicissimus, satirical magazine of imperial Germany, has been revived with a loud and continuing roar against the arming of West Germany, the dangers of militarism, the Saar agreement and the new rich of the Federal republic.
Sunday calm along the North River waterfront was shattered early yesterday as the port roared its welcome to the new Cunard liner Saxonia.

PARIS, Dec. 5 -- Three developments of the last week have been important road signs for French economy. They are a rise in industrial production, an increase in prices of articles for family consumption and a Government step to lift the taxes on small savings.

THE medical profession and the television broadcasters should meet at once to decide just how far they should go in showing on the home screen the details of life in a hospital or laboratory. Yesterday afternoon there was a startling succession of programs that left nothing to the imagination. Enough is enough.

For its second telecast of the season, the N. B. C. Opera Theatre repeated yesterday the production of Puccini's "Sister Angelica," which it first gave in March, 1953. Again the production was skillful and imaginative, and the short opera, with its small cast and restricted locale, proved excellently suited for television.

Fate placed Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams and First Deputy Commissioner James R. Kennedy at the scene of an auto crash last night, and in the best traditions of the service they handled the matter with neatness and dispatch.

Auxiliary Bishop Joseph F. Flannelly, administrator of St. Patrick's Cathedral, led Roman Catholics of the Archdiocese of New York yesterday in offering public prayers for Pope Pius XII, who is gravely ill.

SEIGNORY CLUB, Que., Dec. 5 (Canadian Press) -- A. N. Gleason's rink from Utica, N. Y., today retained its championship in the fifteenth annual International Friendly Curling games. Its margin of victory was four points.

Archbishop Makarios of the independent Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus pledged here yesterday that the struggle he was leading to unite that island with Greece would be continued until the objective had been won.

TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida's political opponents introduced a no-confidence motion against him in the Diet (parliament) at 1 P. M. today [11 P. M., Sunday, Eastern standard time].

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert made a sensational comeback to defeat Australia's Rex Hartwig and Mervin Rose, 4 -- 6, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, in the doubles final of the Victorian tennis championships today.
Ethel Colt, daughter of Ethel Barrymore, the actress, presented a program at Carnegie Recital Hall yesterday afternoon under the auspices of the Carl Friedberg Music Foundation.

Bobby Clatterbuck proved a slick-passing quarterback as the New York Giants kept their Eastern Division title hopes faintly alive by whipping the Pittsburgh Steelers, 24 to 3, at the Polo Grounds yesterday.

Prices of cotton futures eased last week on the New York Cotton Exchange. Closing prices at the week-end were off 15 to 37 points, or from 75 cents to $1.85 a bale. Most losses were registered in distant options.

AMSTERDAM, The Netherlands, Dec. 5 -- October foreign trade here reached a new high with imports of 948,000,000 guilders, against 889,000,000 in September, and exports 873,000,000, against 763,000,000. The import surplus for the first ten months of 1954 was 1,254,000,000 guilders against 574,000,000 a year ago.

DENVER, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Hundreds of Denver residents went to northern Colorado's Weld County today in what officials termed the first full-scale test of a rural area's ability to house and feed evacuees in an enemy attack on a major city.
LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Sharp fluctuations in prices of Government securities have, in the last few days, had a disquieting effect on the sock market generally.
