CAIRO, Dec. 5 -- United States Ambassador Jefferson Caffery said today Egypt's future "looked brighter" under her present military rulers than at any time in the past. He declared the people "believe that this regime really wants to do something for them."
ALBANY, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Senator Thomas C. Desmond today called New York's Department of State "a 'Hernando's hide-away' for political bosses" and said he would ask the 1955 Legislature to abolish it.

An interesting, expertly performed program of contemporary Brazilian chamber music was presented yesterday afternoon at the New York Public Library. The concert was given in the library's current series devoted to regional music of Europe and the Americas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The National Education Association today estimated that there were 30,179,357 pupils in public, elementary and high schools. This is about 1,250,000 over last year's enrollment.

PARIS, Nov. 30 -- An effort at coordinating and stimulating the French Government's activities in favor of youth has been begun. It is under the direction of Andre Moynet, a 33-year-old former test pilot and Deputy who practices the kind of dynamism he preaches.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States is making a last-minute effort to tone down the dispute over Cyprus between Britain and Greece. United Nations debate on the issue is to begin Friday.

BOSTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs scored two goals in the last half of the final period tonight to snap a 2-2 deadlock and defeat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 2, before crowd of 9,277 at the Garden.

Michener's last novel, "Sayonara," there was a scene in which the young hero, who had already fallen in love with a Japanese girl and with Japanese culture generally, succumbed at first sight to the charms of Japanese woodblock prints. John Sebastian, whose skill in playing the harmonica has won him fame in night clubs, gave his first full-length recital in New York Saturday night at Town Hall. His program contained nothing but classical music and the level of both the taste and the musicianship was high.

Whenever wo begin to think that maybe now the old International Longshoremen's Association means what it says about acting like a responsible union instead of a mob, we can depend on the I. L. A., itself, to dissipate our fanciful notions and wishful thoughts.

The executive vice president of the Commerce and Industry Association of New York yesterday termed last Friday's wildcat strike on Upper West Side piers "callous disregard for requirements of mature, responsible labor relations."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- Max Thoenission, president of the German Automobile Industry Society, said last week that only 4 per cent of the German passenger cars purchased in Germany were bought by private persons.
HARTFORD, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Archbishop Henry J. O'Brien received today the pallium, sacred emblem of his office, as the metropolitan Roman Catholic Archbishop of the ecclesiastical province of Hartford.

FARMINGDALE, L. I., Dec. 5 -- The union representing 13,000 Republic Aviation Corporation employes will seek complete medical and dental coverage for its members when contract negotiations are opened here next month. The union is Lodge 1987, International Association of Machinists, A. F. L.

Thank you for publishing Jerome Campbell's letter in The New York Times of Nov. 30, thus giving us an opportunity to comment upon his statement concerning the Saturday closing of some of the New York Public Library branches on Staten Island.

KAMAKURA, Japan, Dec. 5 (AP) -- Reynaldo Gorno of Argentina forged through the rain past favored Veikko Karvonen of Finland at the three-quarter mark today to win the eighth Japan international marathon by 120 meters.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- Wheat developed a weak tone in the week's late trading, reacting substantially from new highs for the season. Longs took advantage of the unexpected wave of flour buying to unload, and the market was swamped later with liquidating sales.

LONDON, Dec. 5 -- Contributing to happy Anglo-American relationships is London's increasing confidence in the emotional stability and peace-mindedness of Washington. There have been moments when these have been seriously doubted over here. And Americans should remember that, in a thermonuclear age, when one of our leaders makes a jingo speech the people of this crowded island feel something like villagers on the Vesuvian slopes as the mountain starts to grunt.

The City Stores Company has reported a third-quarter net profit of $1,021,000, or 43 cents a share, against $773,000, or 32 cents, in the corresponding period of 1953. Net sales were $58,307,000, the highest in the company's history, against $55,840,000.
After a brief spell in first place in the American Soccer League race, the Brooklyn Hispanos were deposed yesterday. They lost to the Hakoah eleven, 3 -- 0, on the field in South Brooklyn.
The Christian attitude must always be positive and affirmative and not one that "damns the world and blames its condition on others," the Rev. Charles F. X. Dolan said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- A group of top Post Office Department officials will meet in New York City tomorrow to go over postal problems in the area.

The administration of Local 807 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, A. F. L., was returned to office yesterday after spirited all-day balloting. The election was marked by charges and denials of gangster efforts to capture the union.
NEW ORLEANS, Dee. 5 (AP) -- Mr. Butler said the Democrats intended to stress the charge that President Eisenhower had shown "a lack of capacity" to unify the country.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 5 -- The Brazilian Communist party published today the text of its new program and revised rules. These were approved by the fourth general congress of the party with orders for all members to study and conform to them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- Personal income was at an annual rate of $286,000,000,000 in October, down approximately $700,000,000 as compared with September, the Office of Business Economics of the United States Department of Commerce reported today.

Motifs from around the world are utilized in the new collection of Waverly decorative fabrics. Available now, through decorators, from the fabric concern at 60 West Fortieth Street, the fabrics show Italian, Oriental, French, Scandinavian, and Colonial American influences.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 5 -- Filming on "Oklahoma!" in the new Todd-AO wide-screen process, closest rival to Cinerama yet developed, will wind up tomorrow after 107 days of shooting. The first shots were made on location in Arizona last July.
To meet the needs of a rapidly growing public school system the United States must be prepared to spend substantially more for education.
Republican leaders in New York are weighing the creation of two agencies to cope with the political situation when Gov.-elect Averell Harriman, Democrat-Liberal, takes office Jan. 1.

ROLAND TAYLOR ELY should win mention in academic annals for the grim road he has taken toward a Ph. D. He has been four years at the task, now, toiling in a cavernous New York Public Library subbasement thirty feet under Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 5 -- An armed attack near Kairouan in central Tunisia yesterday suggested that the problem of political lawlessness was not yet entirely liquidated.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman is going upstate today to confer with civic and business leaders of five cities on means for economic conditions.

BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 3 -- The net income of the Panama Canal Company, a corporation owned by the United States Government, as tentatively recorded for the fiscal year that ended June 30, 1954, was $4,160,010.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- San Francisco's Forty-Niners, with Joe Perry rolling up 137 yards to go beyond the 1,000-yard mark for his second straight season, overwhelmed the Green Bay Packers, 35 -- 0, in their National Football League game today.
The number of working women as well as their average salary is continuing to rise, according to the 1954 Handbook on Women Workers issued yesterday by the United States Department of Labor.

JUBA, the Sudan, Nov. 17 -- The most controversial aspect of British rule in the Sudan is the administration of the three southern provinces as "closed districts," virtually cut off from intercourse with the rest of the country.

Three New England transportation executives will oppose a banker and a shipper in a panel discussion of New England transportation problems on Friday afternoon at the Third New England Institute of Transportation.

An increase in the national income of India of 13 or 14 per cent as a result of that nation's first Five-Year Plan was disclosed yesterday by Gaganvihari L. Mehta, Indian Ambassador to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's long-delayed investigation of alleged defense plant Communists will open tomorrow despite the Wisconsin Republican's ailing elbow, it was reported today.

Our eyes tend to accept the commonplace. It takes a returned traveler to apply normal eyesight to what the stay-at-homes come to regard as familiar and normal. Today The Times prints the first of a series of three articles by Harrison Salisbury, who in recent years has been reporting from Moscow.

The Comedie Francaise, the theatrical pride of France and the world's oldest state-supported repertory troupe, will lend its Gallic charm to Broadway next autumn. It will be the first visit to the United States of the celebrated company, which was organized in 1680.

Presiding Justice John Warren Hill of the Domestic Relations Court called attention yesterday to the "deplorable apathy" of the public and "local fiscal authorities" in providing facilities to check juvenile delinquency.

Dolores Perez, a Spanish soprano who in 1953 won first place over 180 contestants from thirty-nine countries in the "Concorso Viotti" at Vercelli, Italy, last evening gave her debut recital at Carnegie Hall.

Apparently the United States has not done a successful job in explaining the concepts and techniques involved in its democracy to some of its foreign friends. Obviously we need to do better, and perhaps one of the first things to do is to get a better understanding ourselves of just what it is that we believe and that we do.

One can sense a general feeling of deep and often devout relief at the better news that has come from the Vatican about the condition of Pope Plus. His health is a matter of the gravest concern to all of his coreligionists. It is also of concern to those of other faiths who recognize the eminence, wisdom and profound humanity of this great world figure.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 5 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations asked the Federal Government today to speed guarantees that automatic factories would not result in mass unemployment and economic disaster.

HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 5 -- De Ormond (Tuss) McLaughry and the Dartmouth College athletic council today announced that he would retire as head coach of football. McLaughry, who has held the post since 1941, will step down when his contract expires, March 30, 1955.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 5 -- The growth of the Indonesian Communist party during the last year is causing concern. The degree of anxiety varies, but there is general agreement the Communist build-up has reached threatening proportions.

The detention in jails of aliens seeking admission to the United States, or awaiting deportation, which has followed the closing of Ellis Island, has justly stirred widespread indignation -- not in the least allayed by last week's statement of Immigration Commissioner Swing that there are "only" fifty-six now incarcerated in New York.
Dr. Alan W. Brown, president of Hobart and William Smith Colleges at Geneva, N. Y., will head the New York committee for the Rhodes Scholarship this year.

The Advertising Council announced yesterday that its campaign for United States Savings Bonds, to begin in January, would be "the biggest magazine advertising campaign ever scheduled for any cause or product." Throughout the year the campaign will appear in 800 magazines of all kinds.

The history of human flight -- from Kitty Hawk to the supersonic age -- will be told in a series of twenty-six half-hour television programs to be produced by the Columbia Broadcasting System in cooperation with the Air Force.

An assemblage of 2,500 persons filled Temple Emanu-El last night for the musical program to celebrate three anniversaries -- the 300th of Jewish settlement in America, the 110th of the founding of Congregation Emanu-El and the twenty-fifth of the dedication of the present temple at Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 5 (UP) -- Members of a union at General Electric voted today to expel Lewis Lubka, accused of conspiring to damage property to aid communism.
ROME, Dec. 5 -- A crackdown designed to dry up the sources of Italian Communist party funds was announced by the Government today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (AP) -- A suggestion that the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry set up the world's first nuclear reactor as a memorial to the late Enrico Fermi brought a noncommittal nod today from a museum official.
The commercial seas of the charter market were confused at the end of last week and so were the crystal balls of the observers.
Adequate diagnosis of mouth disorders cannot be made through X-ray alone, Dr. Joseph P. Weinmann told the American Academy of Dental Medicine at its winter meeting here yesterday.

There is nothing like confidence, but it should be tempered by prudence and wisdom. When a pianist selects Beethoven's "Hammerklavier" Sonata, he is setting himself up on an exalted level and must be judged accordingly.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 5 -- The United States is entering a "new phase" of negotiations with Russia on peaceful uses of atomic power following a Soviet reply to a United States note of last month.
Premier Moshe Sharett of Israel, in a message yesterday, declared that his nation's economic framework must be strengthened to offset the arming of the Arab states.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 5 -- The Honduran Congress was dissolved today and the country will be without a constitutional Government tomorrow.

A 3 1/2-year-old white and black English cocker spaniel, Ch. Elblac's Bugle of Hastern, became best in show last night in the seventh annual event of the Brooklyn Kennel Club at the 106th Infantry Armory.

" Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci" received their second presentations of the season Saturday night at the Metropolitan Opera. Several changes in the cast saw Herva Nelli singing her first Santuzza at the house and Delia Rigal returning to the Metropolitan, after a season's absence, as Nedda.
Stock offerings, several on an exchange basis, will be made today to shareholders of two utilities and a bank.

CHICAGO, Dec. 5 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears took full advantage of mistakes by the Chicago Cardinals today to score a 29-to-7 triumph before 33,594 fans at Comiskey Park. But the Bears' chances for the National League title vanished when Detroit played to a tie with Philadelphia.
Youth came up yesterday with its own formula for combating juvenile delinquency.
CHICAGO, Dec. 5 -- The Crane Company's 'new titanium plant will have the capacity to produce $200,000,000 of. the metal a year by 1956, according to John L. Holloway, president.

The "Strike It Rich" program now televised on Wednesday evenings will be discontinued next month. It will be replaced by a film series titled "The Millionaire," which is tentatively scheduled to start on Jan. 19 from 9 to 9:30 P. M. over the. C. B. S.-TV network.
A new rocket engine -- the first in this country, and perhaps in the world, with throttle control of its output -- has been developed by the Curtiss-Wright Corporation.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Mr. Yoshida's opponents accused him of arrogance and said he was too closely identified with the Allied occupation to give Japan an independent policy.
Traffic Commissioner T. T. Wiley started yesterday to convert the west side of Times Square at Forty-second Street into a model traffic corner.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 7 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida resigned today with his entire Cabinet.

PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Four United States citizens were reported today to be preparing to continue their fight against dismissal from the staff of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.

A discussion and demonstration meeting on the treatment, rehabilitation and home care of polio-handicapped children will be conducted for parents today at 1 P. M. at the Jewish Chronic Disease Hospital, East Forty-ninth Street and Rutland Road, Brooklyn.

DON MARQUIS, who was a columnist in the days when columns were literate and witty, created a philosophic cockroach in The New York Sun in 1916. This cockroach, poet and storyteller, who could type only one letter at a time and therefore could not make capitals, was archy.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- India said today that South Africa's racial policies might lead to "fearful race conflict." She declared only the Communists gained from the denial of democratic rights.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- An autopsy disclosed today that Dave Sparks, Washington Redskins' lineman, died of coronary thrombosis, a condition that was aggravated in the game against the Cleveland Browns yesterday.
An off-duty Queens patrolman, rushing to a neighbor's house when fire broke out yesterday morning, rescued three elderly persons.

The first industrial revolution lay in the substitution of power machines for muscle in doing the work of the world -- producing goods, transporting people and things, farming, housekeeping, communicating. No end can be set to its course. But we are now well into a second, and supplementary, industrial revolution gathering speed with sensational rapidity.

J. Sinclair Armstrong, a member of the Securities and Exchange Commission, announced here yesterday that the commission had started a study of the marketing of United States and Canadian securities across the border.

SCHENECTADY, Dec. 6 -- Gov.-elect Averell Harriman disclosed today that he intended to appoint a woman to his staff to look after the interests of consumers. He declined to reveal her name or what title she would have.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 6 -- The Indonesian Communists are not nearly strong enough to exercise a controlling influence on the Government or to bid for domination of the country. Whether they will be able to attain a commanding position in the future will depend largely on what happens in Indonesian politics during the election year of 1955.
Regular and transit policemen searched for more than an hour early today in the darkness of the IND subway tracks for a hold-up man who fled into a station at 155th Street and St. Nicholas Avenue.
TEGUCIGALPA, Dec. 6 -- In a quiet but persistent way, Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz has made a firm imprint on his country in the last thirty-five years.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 2 -- Col. Carlos Castillo Armas' Government has lowered by almost $4,000,000 the budget approved last June by the deposed regime of Jacobo Arbenz.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Supreme Court agreed today to rule on the validity of compulsory blood tests to determine whether motorists were intoxicated.
Pier 18, North River at Murray Street, the local terminal of the Eastern Steamship Lines since 1924, will go under the hammer on Dec. 15.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations wants insurance companies to be required by law to make public all commissions paid on welfare funds, whether union or management controlled.

A ballot of fourteen metropolitan college basketball coaches yesterday unanimously favored widening of the foul lane for collegiate play. Attending the Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association luncheon at Leone's, the coaches also asserted their views on five other proposals.

A Port Authority policeman, ending a five-day vacation, shot four men during a dispute just before 4 A. M. yesterday in a tavern in Graniteville, S. I. One victim's condition was listed as poor and another's as serious.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Johnny Michelosen, a protege of the old Scot, Dr. Jock Sutherland, today was named head football coach at the University of Pittsburgh. The contract is for three years. Salary terms were not disclosed.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports in livestock trading here today:

City editors, assistants and news editors from eighteen states and Canada evaluated methods of improving local news coverage at the opening yesterday of a two-week seminar of the American Press Institute at Columbia University.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- Harry Bridges was instructed by a Federal court today to answer a pre-trial questionnaire dealing with the subject of Communist party membership.

Directors of the Merchants Ladies Garment Association, Inc., meeting last night at the Sheraton Astor Hotel, elected Samuel Sandhaus president. He succeeds Louis A. Siegel, of Leeds Ltd., who recently resigned. Mr. Sandhaus, who is head of Craftshire Sports, Inc., manufacturer of women's suits, has been a director of the association for fourteen years and prior to that was a member of its advisory board.

The Monterey Oil Company announced yesterday the purchase of the assets of the Fullerton Oil and Gas Corporation for $50,000,000 in cash. Formerly known as the Fullerton Oil Company, the concern has been engaged in petroleum production and exploration since 1900.

Patience -- solitaire -- is an excellent game and it is odd indeed that it is so frowned upon around the house. The attitude seems to be that to play patience is to do nothing at all, that it is to do nothing save throw away good time.
The investment bankers division of the George Junior Republic planned a year-end fund drive at a luncheon meeting yesterday at the Wall Street Club, 40 Wall Street.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today against price cutting by an interstate business to destroy a competitor whose business was entirely within the state.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Coach Eddie Erdelatz and the five assistants who helped him build Navy into a national football power will start work tomorrow on a new task.

Mrs. W. Emlen Roosevelt of 1105 Park Avenue, chairman of the committee for this year's dinner dance for the Yorkville Community Association, gave a luncheon in her home yesterday in honor of her vice chairmen, Mrs. Charles Hill Jones and Mrs. Lathrop Douglas.

An increase of 13 to 14 per cent has been recorded in the national income of India since the introduction of the five-year plan in that country in 1951, according to Gaganvihari L. Mehta, Indian Ambassador to the United States. As a result of the plan, Mr. Mehta reports, industrial production has risen by more than one-third and agricultural production about one-fourth in the last three years.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- President Eisenhower invited nineteen guests to another in a series of stag dinners at the White House tonight.
The pharmaceutical industry was urged yesterday to expand its foreign markets and to eliminate costly distribution practices that limit its domestic sales.

Thirteen years ago today the Japanese Navy attacked at Pearl Harbor. Today, thirteen years, a major and several minor wars later, the world still grapples with the problem of aggression, which haunts it now with the even grimmer specter of an atomic war.

A test of the city's 679 fixed air raid sirens yesterday disclosed that fourteen were inoperative or defective, against five on Nov. 8, the date of the last test. Yesterday four sirens in Manhattan, one siren in the Bronx, three in Brooklyn, five in Queens and one in Richmond failed to perform perfectly.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Bolivia plans to propose tomorrow the formation of a confederation of Korea and the establishment of a Diet in which both South and North Korea would be equally represented.

How little they know New York who know it only as a city of gaiety, of bright lights, of fine stores, of great hotels, of towering apartment houses, of general well-being, health and prosperity! For within this city, which is the one that meets the eye, is another, smaller city of the ill, the unfortunate, the miserable, the abandoned, the home where the blind is drawn.

The training of leaders for this nation's military service, tempered by discipline but motivated by "duty, honor, country," remains in a changing era the basic purpose of the United States Military Academy at West Point.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 -- The San Francisco Board of Supervisors asked Mayor Elmer E. Robinson today to invite the United Nations to hold a tenth commemorative meeting next June in this city, birthplace of the global agency.

A second novel in the late Ernest Haycox's contemplated series describing the growth of the American Northwest will be issued Jan. 3 by Little, Brown, entitled "The Adventurers." Selected by the Literary Guild as its January choice, the novel deals with people confronted with the raw Oregon country at the end of the century.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 6 -- An 18-month-old boy died today in a fire that raced through a house which the City Commission is said to have ordered condemned July 26.

Winter has fourteen days' wait before its official debut, but, for all intents and purposes, it was here today. Subfreezing temperatures and biting winds, starting yesterday, brought sharp discomfort to the city and neighboring areas, with the mercury here dipping to an "autumnal" low of 16 degrees at 3 A. M.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- "Hard money" policies pursued by the Eisenhower Administration at its inception were accused today of smothering a business boom and inducing a recession in 1953.

George A. Hormel Co., meat packer, had a net income of $1,833,440, equal to $3.42 a common share in the year ended on Oct. 31, H. H. Corey, president, reported yesterday. This represented a decline of 39.3 per cent from the $3,019,916, or $5.73 a share, earned in the fiscal year ended on Oct. 30, 1953.

ROME, Dec. 6 -- The Vatican had regained its usual tranquil atmosphere today after the excitement and concern of the last few days. The health of Pope Pius XII continued to improve from last Friday's crisis, which many, including his close associates, had feared would be fatal.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A ship with 100,000 Christmas trees for Hawaii sailed from here tonight amid a flurry of activity that indicated a break in a five-day-old shipping strike.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The acts of the Democratic National Committee at New Orleans last week-end affirmed the view of a large majority that Adlai E. Stevenson is the real as well as the titular leader of the Democratic party in the United States.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 6 -- Potential civil war threatened in a section of South Vietnam today between partisans and opponents of Premier Ngo Dinh Diem.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- A team of three women, experts in designing and execution, stand beside Genevieve Fath as she takes over her late husband's business.
While most of the other clubs were dreaming up, negotiating or discussing deals yesterday, the Chicago White Sox were making 'em.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Without a negative vote and after less than a full day's debate, the General Assembly's economic and financial committee took the first step today toward creation of an International Finance Corporation to aid underdeveloped regions.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 6 -- Puerto Rico's newest experiment in housing is making homes in rural areas possible at a cost of $300.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 6 -- All political factions appeared today to be united behind the Government of Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz, who was installed last midnight as "Supreme Chief of State."
Electricians employed by six New York newspapers ratified yesterday a two-year contract negotiated with the Publishers Association of New York City.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The United Nations General Assembly will start debate Wednesday on the imprisonment of eleven United States airmen by Communist China.

OTTAWA, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Government today estimated that Canadian farm cash income dropped by $300,000,000 in 1954 to a four-year low of $2,400,000,000. But it said there was a "good possibility" it might rise in 1955.

The third event in the series known as Five Enchanted Theatre Evenings will be held tomorrow night at the performance of "Reclining Figure" at the Lyceum Theatre. Proceeds from the series will be donated to the Hospitalized Veterans' Service of the Musicians' Emergency Fund.
The New York Central Railroad announced officially yesterday that it proposed to seek permission to discontinue its West Shore Railroad passenger service and its ferries.

The security of the United States requires the development of a "counter-striking atomic air power of our own," Thomas K. Finletter, former Secretary of the Air Force, declared last night at the annual dinner of the St. Nicholas Society.
Westbrook Pegler, newspaper columnist, last night told supporters of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that they "have been laying some terrible eggs lately -- let's not kid ourselves."

TRENTON, Dec. 6 -- Rent controls in New Jersey will cease on Dec. 31 unless Gov. Robert B. Meyner calls the State Senate into special session and induces it to act favorably on a measure now before it.
ALBANY, Dec. 6 -- The Public Service Commission announced today that it would require buses making over-the-road runs of thirty-five miles or more to carry speed-recording devices.
Italo Scortichini of Fabriano, Italy, slugged out a unanimous ten-round decision over Chico Varona of Havana in the main bout at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
Airplane, rail, chemical and communications issues led another stock market advance yesterday that carried prices to new twenty-five-year highs.

A gift from another land helps give real meaning to Christmas, the feast of international brotherhood. As the holiday shopping season gets into full swing, there are many places to find unusual gifts with a foreign flavor.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 6 (AP) -- American buyers poured out nearly $300,000 for mares and foals today at Tattersall's December sales in a mass buying wave of British thoroughbreds.

In line with the experience of Eastern railroads generally, 1954 has been a difficult year for the Central Railroad of New Jersey, stockholders were told yesterday at their annual meeting in Jersey City.
Cocoa futures showed strength yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange for the first time since Nov. 24.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Television station WTRI, operating on ultra high frequency Channel 35 at Albany, N. Y., today asked the Federal Communications Commission to revoke its recent grant, without hearing, of a permit to the radio commentator, Lowell J. Thomas, and associates to buy a controlling interest in Albany stations WROW and WROW-TV.
Billy Joe Patton, Morganton, N. C. amateur, was named winner of the gold tee award yesterday by the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A Cabinet committee report on how to train more and better scientists and engineers puts primary responsibility on non-Government groups.

Stockholders of the Royal Bank of Canada will vote on a proposal to increase the authorized capitalization to 10,000,000 shares at the annual meeting in Montreal on Jan. 13. The present capitalization consists of 5,000,000 shares, of which 4,171,345 are outstanding.
MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press) -- A forty-three-word telegram with 21,947 signatures was started on its way today to a football player who fizzled a play in the most important game in Canada.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs have risen to the highest point in nearly eleven months. It announced that its latest offering of $1,500,000,000 of ninety-one day bills was sold at a price equal to an annual interest rate of 1.087 per cent.
An article in your columns of Nov. 28 from Ottawa claims the Royal Canadian Mounted Police to be the world's most versatile force.
The Philharmonic-Symphony Society of New York has elected Richard Rodgers, the composer, and two others to its board of directors.

The Southern Pacific Company announced yesterday it had placed orders for 148 Diesel locomotive units, scheduled to go into service by next May. These are in addition to six units delivered within the last month and nine others expected to be delivered soon after the first of the year.

The 4138 Barnes Avenue Corporation sold the six-story apartment house for fifty-four families at that address in the Bronx to investing clients of Charles H. Kelman, attorney, for cash over mortgages amounting to $175,000 in a deal negotiated by Houlihan Sons, brokers.

Your editorial "Breakfast Mail" in your issue of Nov. 30 represents that some New York City people are getting their mail before leaving for business due to a change in having carriers leave on their rounds at 7:15 A. M. instead of 8:30.

CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Much selling of grain and soybean futures held six months or longer appeared to be the main bearish feature in the Board of Trade pit markets today. The demand was fair at times, but offerings increased on all the bulges, with potential buyers disposed to stand by until the selling of six-month holdings was less in evidence.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden rejected today with visible anger the statement of a Labor Member of Parliament that the eleven United States airmen recently sentenced in China were in fact spies.

Tenants of a limited dividend housing corporation applauded yesterday when State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman refused to consider a tax starting in 1956 as a basis for an immediate rent increase.

The judges for the Walter W. Naumburg Musical Foundation sometimes have had difficulty finding singers sufficiently accomplished to receive the foundation's annual awards. But their task must have been easy this year. They had Martha Flowers to pass on, and yesterday afternoon that gifted young soprano enjoyed the reward of their verdict -- her Town Hall debut.

It is the recipes that are of most practical value in "The Jewish Festival Cookbook" (David McKay, 216 pp., $3.50). But this book, written by Mrs. Fannie Engle and Miss Gertrude Blair, is interesting, too, for the brief but vivid accounts of the background and customs of Jewish holidays.
ANDROS TOWN, the Bahamas, Dec. 6 -- The earliest rooster was rousing his flock across the creek at Coakley Town. First light was a faint line of lemon-yellow in the east.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Stock-market trading started briskly today, but a late reaction wiped out the gains in Government securities and gave a ragged appearance to many of the other groups. The undertone in the industrial section, however, remained firm.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 6 -- Federal Trade Commissioner Lowell F. Mason urged the country's health and accident insurance companies today to seek F. T. C. cooperation in setting up an industry-wide code of advertising ethics.
The point raised by my old friend, Brigadier Quilliam, in his letter of Nov. 23 is a valid one and I respect the way in which he has presented it.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Simone de Beauvoir, an associate of Jean-Paul Sartre in the French Existentialist movement, received the coveted Goncourt Prize today for her novel, "Les Mandarins."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- One of the intriguing but useless occupations in Washington is the game of trying to figure out party policy after listening to the contradictory public statements of men who are supposed to know.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams appealed to business leaders at Police Headquarters yesterday to avoid the "evil system" of Christmas gratuities to policemen.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Government's "net worth" formula for determining income tax deficiencies, in use since the days of Al Capone, the gangster, was upheld by the Supreme Court today.
Beware of shady characters offering cut-rate furs for Christmas, because in this cold town today there is a lot of hot mink on the loose.

The Port of New York Authority, operator of Teterboro Airport, will continue next year its policy of not charging take-off fees at the New Jersey field for aircraft weighing less than 2,500 pounds. However, beginning Jan. 1, the pilots of airplanes above that weight will be charged for using the airport's facilities.

LUNDY ISLAND, Bristol Channel, Dec. 6 (Reuters) -- Mr. Harman ruled his "vest-pocket dominion" like a feudal monarch. He coined his own money, issued his own stamps with his portrait on them, and made his own laws.
The New York Knickerbockers will engage the Minneapolis Lakers in the second game of a National Basketball Association twin bill at Madison Square Garden tonight.
A long-range study designed to improve the handling of mail in the New York metropolitan area was begun here yesterday by ten Post Office Department officials.
West Europe is feeling its way toward a more united future, aware of both a common danger and the technical requirements of the age, Dr. Eelco N. van Kleffens of the Netherlands declared last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The railroads and unions representing about 1,000,000 nonoperating employes have dropped the "escalator" clause from their wage agreements.

In what is regarded in the trade as one of the best managerial agreements in years, Harald Bromley, Broadway producer, has signed contracts to produce about ten plays this season for the Shubert Theatre in Washington, with funds supplied by the operators of the playhouse.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Eisenhower Administration has abandoned hope of balancing the budget next year.

The high demand for mortgage money, the upturn in business activity, and the continuing decline in personal savings will cause interest rates to rise over the next few months, the nation's savings bankers were told here yesterday.
In the next ten years Americans probably will earn more, spend more and worry more than ever.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 2 points lower to 3 points higher than on Friday.
Fifty-five or sixty known former Communists are now teaching in the city's public schools.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Navy today defended the role of the aircraft carrier.

OCHO RIOS, Jamaica, Nov. 17 -- The looms of the St. Ann Weavers are busy these days, weaving beautiful cottons and silks. They are preparing for the flood of winter visitors who will come to sun on the island's shores and, the weavers hope, buy their wares.
Helen Keller, 74-year-old blind and deaf educator and author, was named "Woman of the Years" last night by the Federation of Jewish Philanthropies of New York.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 6 -- The first test of legality of Governor General Ghulam Mohammed's action in dissolving the Constituent Assembly two months ago began today before a provincial court.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Egypt announced today her intention to release the ten-man crew and cargo of the Israeli freighter Bat Galim, seized Sept. 28 near the Suez Canal.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Republican command charged the Democrats today with having "thrown into the ash can" promises to cooperate with President Eisenhower.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 6 -- The hearings on the sinking of the merchant ship Mormackite received testimony today on the way in which her cargo was loaded.
LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Martin Coles Harman, former financier who owned the 1,000-acre Lundy Island off the southwest coast of England, died last night at a hospital in Oxted, Surrey. He was 69 years old.
JERSEY CITY, Dec. 6 -- A delicatessen dealer pleaded guilty today to violating a city ordinance by selling bacon on Sunday.
A major drive against lowering of tariffs on soft goods imported from Japan has been started by the leading trade associations representing manufacturers of textiles and apparel.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (UP) -- Democratic sources said today that Adlai E. Stevenson, who may carry the Democratic standard again in 1956, believed the Republicans could be beaten even if President Eisenhower ran again.

Vincent A. G. O'Connor, Commissioner of Marine and Aviation, criticized the Waterfront Commission yesterday. He suggested to the bi-state agency that its purpose was not merely to wipe out waterfront rackets but to attract more business.

THE December exhibition at the City Center Gallery, 131 West Fifty-fifth Street, includes nearly fifty paintings in a wide variety of styles, testifying to the catholicity of taste of the jury, which consisted of Leon Kroll, Julian Levi and I. Rice Pereira.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 6 (AP) -- United States participation in the United Nations-administered cease-fire in Kashmir ended today with the departure of the last two American officers.
LONDON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Peiping radio announced that China put on show today objects "captured from American spies."

A new Visitor Information Center for the New York Convention and Visitors Bureau will be opened at 90 East Forty-second Street early in 1955, according to Bernard F. Gimbel, president and chairman of the board.

LONDON, Dec. 6 -- Britain seeks general agreement with the Soviet Union on disarmament and relaxation of world tension through secret diplomatic negotiations or a high-level conference, Sir Anthony Eden declared tonight
NZARA, the Sudan, Nov. 18 -- Azande tribesmen only one generation away from cannibalism are tending looms here in what must be one of the most isolated outposts of the industrial revolution.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Justice Arthur I. Smith today described as illegal the arrest of Charles Trenet, 40-year-old French singer, in a $141,000 damage suit filed by Hello Paree, Inc., a New York agency.

A Long Island matron recovered $70,000 worth of diamonds, opals and amethysts yesterday when her automobile, which had been stolen Friday night, was found in front of 125 East Fifteenth Street. The valuable jewelry was untouched in the trunk of the car.

Karen, the 3-year-old child who was abandoned last Tuesday with her 16-month-old brother, Billy, saw her mother again yesterday. The visit, however, was brief because the woman was arrested at the Children's Center, 1 East 104th Street, and was taken from there to the East Sixty-seventh Street station.

Domestic steel-making operations, which have been increasing without a setback since early September, were scheduled to edge up to 81.5 per cent of theoretical capacity this week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

A MAN is judged by the company he keeps and birds of a feather flock together. So much for the cliches. Moth-eaten though they be and transparent from overuse as they are, they still serve to illustrate the significance to be found in the fact that Tuss McLaughry of Dartmouth and Lou Little of Columbia are the closest of friends. They are men of character.

In your issue of Nov. 19 C. L. Sulzberger writes: "Egypt's basic problem is too little land for too many people. * * * The British, who governed Egypt for decades, never were able to solve this -- and never seriously tried, despite a leavening of social and industrial reforms."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 6 -- Milovan Djilas, deposed Yugoslav Communist leader, is understood to have been telling foreign visitors lately that "Stalinism" of a domestic type is overtaking this country.

Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran and his wife, Queen Soraya, arrived here by plane yesterday for a two-month "social" visit in the United States. Stepping into shelter from the icy winds that swept New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, the 34-year-old monarch spoke highly of this country and its institutions and said he hoped his visit would "cement the friendship" between it and Iran.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation, Shreveport, La., today started an effort to convince the Federal Power Commission that it should be allowed to reconvert its "Little Inch" natural gas pipeline to the transportation of oil, gasoline and other petroleum products.
Litter and rubbish plague half the cities of America and are turning ribbons of green countryside along the highways into casual dumps.

The tightness in the New York money market continued yesterday, with the lending rate on free balances at the Federal Reserve Bank ranging around 1 7/16 per cent and the reserve position of the New York banks still in deficiency.
City Council President Abe Stark was asked yesterday by a delegation of forty parents of school children to support a move for semi-annual registration of pupils.
A former member of the Federal Trade Commission yesterday advocated legislation to stop manufacturers from allowing selected distributors to ignore fair-trade prices.

Maj. Gen. Julius Ochs Adler, commanding general of the Seventy-seventh Infantry Division of the Army Reserve, was hailed last night by his old comrades in arms. They lauded his battlefield gallantry, his leadership in military training and his service as an adviser to the President on national security.

New York, New Jersey, West Virginia, Pennsylvania have recently been opening new sections of their toll highways. Last week it was Ohio's turn, when motorists began to use the first twenty-two miles of the fine $326,000,000 Turnpike that, before snow flies a year hence, is expected to be open for the complete 241 miles from the Pennsylvania border to the Indiana line.

QUEBEC, Dec. 6 (AP) -- Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec said today it was not reasonable to expect United States enterprises developing natural resources in Quebec's vast north to manufacture finished products in this province.

Attendance at major league baseball games reached 15,935,881 in 1954. The figures, released officially yesterday, showed an increase of 1,552,084 over the previous year. However, eight of the sixteen clubs showed a drop.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- The Yugoslav Ambassador to Washington said today that his country's military, political and cultural links with the United States and other non-Communist countries would not be weakened by Soviet attempts to increase trade with Yugoslavia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Diplomatic conversations with the Soviet Union on President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace plan are to be continued "on a confidential basis," a State Department spokesman said today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 6 -- Montgomery Ward Co. and its directors today filed an answer in Cook County Circuit Court here, denying allegations that Ward's staggered system of electing directors was illegal.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 6 (AP) -- Belair Stud's Hyphasis, 7-to-20 favorite, won the featured Golden Gate Purse at Tropical Park today by a length and a quarter under Ted Atkinson.

HUNTINGTON, L. I., Dec. 6 -- Miss Sherlock and Mr. Holmes, the youngest and most popular rookies on the Huntington Town police force, were put through a brief period of specialized elementary detective training here today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (UP) -- James E. Finke, Research Director of the Citizens Public Expenditure Survey Inc. of New York, said today that evidence did not prove the need for Federal aid in building schools.

A shipload of travel-weary G. I.'s arrived yesterday morning at Pier 10, Tompkinsville, S. I., aboard the Navy transport Gen. M. B. Stewart after a forty-day trip from Inchon, Korea. The transport, with 1,185 military personnel on board, of whom 132 hail from the New York metropolitan area, had called at Honolulu, Hawaii, Guayaquil, Columbia, the Canal Zone and New Orleans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- A behind-the-scenes struggle has developed on water policy.

Trading in the 10-cent par value common stock of Hazel Bishop, Inc., began on the American Stock Exchange yesterday with ceremonies in which officials of the company participated. Raymond Spector, chairman of the Hazel Bishop board, was permitted to record the first deal, 100 shares bought for his account through Hayden, Stone Co., brokers.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 6 -- Dr. Malan, who gave the United Nations the word "apartheid," bowed out of public life today when his resignation from. Parliament became effective.

Navy's eleven was named yesterday the 1954 winner of the August V. Lambert Memorial Trophy, emblematic of collegiate football supremacy in the East. The Midshipmen captured the award for the first time, finishing ahead of Army and Penn State.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 7 (AP) -- America's tennis forces moved on to Brisbane today with revitalized hopes of recovering the Davis Cup.

A. H. Weiler of the motion-picture department of The New York Times yesterday was elected vice chairman of the New York Film Critics at a meeting of the group held at the New York Newspaper Guild Clubhouse, 133 West Forty-fourth Street.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 6 -- Walter P. Reuther declared today that the country had wasted $30,000,000,000 in a year through failure to provide full employment.

Almost half the business concerns in New York will give their employes three-day holiday weekends both on Christmas and New Year's, which fall on Saturdays. The Commerce and Industry Association of New York queried 841 concerns and 41.1 per cent said they would close all day Friday, Dec.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 6 -- Jack Palance will co-star with a female partner yet to be selected in "Pistolero," to be produced early next year by Philip A. Waxman Productions in association with United Artists. David Miller will direct the screen play about the regeneration of a gunman, written by Horace McCoy and Bernard Smith.

Shigeru Yoshida has never gone out of his way to make anybody love him. His consistent lack of tact has been his major personal characteristic. This has given him a reputation as an incorruptible public official, and it has also meant that inevitably, sooner or later, the accumulated resentments of his political enemies would topple him from office.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Citizens Investigating Committee in a final report made public today accused the police of condoning and sharing in the profits of widespread vice operations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Sir John Kotelawala, Prime Minister of Ceylon, conferred with President Eisenhower today on proposals that the United States and West Europe should launch a new program of economic aid for the underdeveloped countries of Asia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy did not appear this afternoon for a scheduled closed meeting of his Senate Permanent Subcommittee on Investigations.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France is trying to find out what the Soviet attitude is toward his proposal for a four-power conference in May.

BOSTON, Dec. 6 -- Harvard's basketball team tonight won its opening game of the season and its first under former freshman coach, Floyd S. Wilson, The Crimson defeated Northeastern, 61 -- 49, at the Huskies' new athletic building.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- Although thirteen years have passed since the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, the United States Air Force has not yet established which of two pilots shot down the first enemy bomber.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 -- The Dixon-Yates private power group challenged today the right of the state of Tennessee and other public groups to participate in hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

A 15-year-old boy, the state's chief witness in the murder trial of three Brooklyn adolescents, admitted in Kings County Court yesterday that he had gone "bum hunting" prior to the murder night last August. The defendants are charged with having beaten a man on a Brooklyn pier and then pushing him into the East River.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 6 -- Two powerful committees of the Westchester Board of Supervisors disapproved today a controversial plan for creating a county library service corporation under the State Education Law.
PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 6 -- Dr. Albert Einstein, the physicist and mathematician, accepted today a memorial gift of $500 worth of antibiotics in behalf of his friend, Dr. Albert Schweitzer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The Association of American Railroads estimated today that the net income of Class I carriers in October was $76,000,000, as compared with $88,000,000 in the same month last year.
The expansion of major league baseball to two ten-club circuits, with California included, took a big stride yesterday. It could happen by 1956.

The nation's largest manufacturer of model trains and accessories has gone to the courts to force some of this city's department stores to maintain fair-trade prices. The Lionel Corporation has brought suit against R. H. Macy Co., Inc., in New York seeking a temporary injunction banning it from cutting prices on trains.
Cardinal Spellman, for the fourth consecutive year, will spend the Christmas season with American military forces in the Pacific, the Chancery Office announced yesterday.

MONTREAL, Dec. 6 (Canadian Press) -- The dip in Canadian business of the last year or so was noteworthy, not because it occurred, but because it was so limited in extent, Gordon R. Ball, president of the Bank of Montreal said today.

That delightful citrus fruit, the tangerine, now is in season. Most plentiful this month and next, the orange-skinned specimens are about 12 cents a pound. Usually they are eaten out of hand, but for variation, they may be presented in a shortcake made with a biscuit mix.
Today will be the second of a two-day blood donation by employes of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company at 32 Avenue of the Americas to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program.

The New York Board of Health was commended last night for recommending fluoridation of this city's water supply. The president of the American Dental Association, Dr. Daniel F. Lynch of Washington, agreed with the board that fluoridation "is the most economical, practical and effective way to improve the dental health of the citizens of New York City."

Representatives of Panama disclosed yesterday that the republic planned to issue postage stamps carrying portraits of all the 259 recognized Popes who have served the Roman Catholic Church. This gallery will be released over a period of years, the initial group presenting Popes Pius I through XII.

Many donors to the forty-third annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund contributed yesterday to commemorate friends and relatives. They were among the 133 contributors who sent $8,426.36 to the fund, bringing the total to $57,618.10.

At the recent C.I.O. hearing on welfare funds a statement was made that the elimination of commissions to life underwriters would help clear up some of the difficulties that have arisen in the writing and servicing of these plans.

HEIDELBERG, Germany, Dec. 6 (AP) -- A United States Army insurance officer today denied allegations that an underwriters' association had gained a "czar-like power" over sale of policies to American soldiers in Europe.

CAMPBELTOWN, Scotland, Dec. 6 (AP) -- The old royal yacht Victoria and Albert, once a symbol of regal splendor, covered her last sea mile today. Her final port of destination was a cluttered ship breaker's yard near here.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 6 -- The portrait of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard and his family continued to develop today.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 6 (UP) -- The University of Tennessee, which recently completed its worst football season in thirty years, discharged Coach Harvey Robinson today. The University is looking for an outstanding "Tennessee man" to bring the Vol's back to the heights they knew under Major Gen. Bob Neyland.
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 6 -- John (Honey) Russell, coach of the Seton Hall University basketball team, has scrapped his plan to employ the two-platoon system this campaign.

The suggestion that the United Nations General Assembly hold a commemorative session next June in San Francisco brings back memories of what now seem more hopeful days. The first United Nations conference met in the San Francisco Opera House on April 26, 1945, just fourteen days after President Roosevelt's death.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 6 -- Thailand may have to go to the United Nations with the case of 50,000 Vietnamese refugees who do not want to be evacuated to South Vietnam, Premier Pibul Songgram said today.

Developments in Honduras provide a typical example of the worst sort of old-fashioned Latin-American maneuvering. Ex-President Tiburcio Carias has calmly thwarted the public will by preventing the popular choice for the Presidency, Ramon Villeda Morales, from taking office.

Sharp changes have taken place in the retail grocery field since 1948, with supermarkets now doing 48 per cent of the grocery stores' total business although representing only 5 per cent of the outlets. This was reported yesterday in a study released by the marketing division of The American Weekly, newspaper supplement.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 7 -- Outspoken comments on the failure of Christianity to make headway in Negro Africa were made today at a multiracial church conference being held here.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Dec. 8 -- Premier Shigeru Yoshida set off a bitter political fight over his successor when he and his Cabinet submitted their group resignation to Parliament yesterday.
Food Fair Stores, Inc., had record sales and net income in the twenty-eight weeks ended on Nov. 13, Louis Stein, president, and Samuel Friedland, chairman, reported yesterday.
Cotton futures yesterday rose 8 to 9points on the New York Cotton Exchange in a quiet market.

This is the time of year when one discovers that nobody knows where the household's snow shovel is. No one remembers when he saw it last, either. That is understandable, because between last winter and this lie a good many lovely, lazy days of sunshine and warmth that could effectively have blotted from anyone's mind knowledge -- if any -- of the household snow shovel.
Baseball's major leagues yesterday finally got around to giving a helping hand to their long-suffering affiliates in the minor leagues.

Former Communists employed in the city's schools and colleges who refuse to identify party associates should not be dismissed solely because of that refusal, the Public Education Association declared yesterday.

The Anna G. Fuchs Estates, Inc., has purchased the apartment house at 3805 Review Place, the Bronx, from Blair Realty Corporation. Alice Cohn and Pearce, Mayer Greer were the brokers and title insurance was furnished by the Inter - County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company.

Enactment of a law that would force employers to give a monthly accounting and monthly payments to commission salesmen will be sought by State Senator Samuel L. Greenberg, Democrat of Brooklyn, at the next session of the Legislature.
A new study of regional transit problems was proposed yesterday by Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission. He estimated the cost at $750,000 to $1,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Senate investigators demanded today that two Bethlehem Steel Company workers be dismissed and possibly deported for refusing to state under oath whether or not they were Communists.

EAST WILLISTON, L. I., Dec. 7 -- George T. Baird of the Brookville Country Club was elected president of the Long Island Golf Association at the annual meeting of the organization held at the Wheatley Hills Golf Club tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- The State Library found itself today in the position of a housewife who had pitched her husband's prized stamp collection into the waste basket and had to search through the whole village dump for it.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The Population Reference Bureau, a private research organization, reported today that the Hutterite religious group had the fastest growing population on earth.

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The threat of a strike hung tonight over the General Motors plant here, which is producing 1,150 Chevrolet cars a day. Company officials said there would be no shutdown unless wildcat walkouts were called.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Under the weight of heavy receipts, hog prices broke sharply today. Department of Agriculture reports on

Three two-day collections of blood for the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program will being today. They will be at Columbia University's John Jay Hall, 114th Street and Amsterdam Avenue; Ford Monmouth, N. J., and the New York Telephone Company, 101 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn. Today also a bloodmobile will visit Rockwood Co., 88 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 -- Mario Martinelli, Italy's Foreign Trade Minister, arrived here today for a three-day visit. The visit will be followed by Italian-Yugoslav trade talks to renew a treaty due to expire at the end of this month.

Underwriting syndicates will place on the market today $152,300,000 of debt and preferred stock securities of gas transmission, public utility and railroad companies. Money raised by the transactions will be used to refund outstanding higher-cost debt, to pay off bank loans, and to finance expansion and the purchase of new equipment.

A combined national campaign for $2,340,000 in behalf of American Reform Judaism was started last night. This was announced at a dinner at the Waldorf- Astoria Hotel, attended by 600 Reform Jewish leaders from various sections of the country.

Events tonight: "Faust," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Leontyne Price, soprano, Mary McMurray, contralto, Earl Ringland, tenor, and Schola Cantorum, Carnegie Hall, 8:45; Nell Tangeman, mezzo-soprano, Town Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- A substantial block of Republican and Democratic Senators, including the Senate Republican leader, William F. Knowland, dissented today from Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's attack on President Eisenhower.

Orlando, Fla., awarded $4,000,000 of water and electric revenue bonds, due from 1956 to 1975, to Kidder, Peabody Co. and associates on a bid of 100.0999 for a combination of bonds bearing interest at 4, 2 and 2 1/4 per cent for a net interest cost of 2.25 per cent. Reoffering was at prices scaled to yield interest returns ranging from .90 per cent to 2.30 per cent.

Carl (Bobo) Olson, middleweight champion of the world, was selected yesterday as the "fighter of the year." The distinction was voted the Hawaiian-born resident of San Francisco by the New York Boxing Writers Association, and he will receive the Edward J. Neil Memorial Plaque at the organization's dinner at the Hotel New Yorker on Jan. 13.

John Bauer, 22-year-old guard from Illinois, returned to the active list of the New York Football Giants yesterday. The 6-foot 3-inch 240 pounder, acquired from Green Bay, was injured on the first play of the regular season at Chicago.
St. Francis College has scoring strength, but Coach Dan Lynch's Terrier basketball team is weak defensively.

LUXEMBOURG, Dec. 7 -- The European Coal and Steel Community approved tonight the substance of an agreement virtually assuring close British association with but not membership in the community, a well-informed source said.
Statements made by three Brooklyn adolescents shortly after they allegedly tortured and murdered an intoxicated man last August were offered as evidence in Kings County Court yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary Oveta Culp Hobby today put air and water pollution high on the list of health problems now needing federal-state-local cooperative solutions.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Federal court jury today convicted Evan R. Dale and James Bateman, Southern Illinois labor leaders, of labor racketeering in connection with construction of a multi-million dollar power plant at Joppa, Ill.
The cornerstone for the new Red Cross chapter house in Brooklyn was unveiled yesterday. The building will be a part of the borough's new Civic Center at Washington and High Streets.
In Moscow the commissar for street cleaning would be sent to Siberia if Red Square got as dirty as Times Square.
FRESH CREEK, Andros, Bahamas, Dec. 7 -- We decided to concentrate on the bonefish possibilities on the upper flats of this large island today.

DETROIT, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Under Secretary of Commerce Robert B. Murray Jr. said today "outmoded and unrealistic" Federal regulation policies were seriously impending railroad progress. Under existing restraints, he said, the railroads are prevented from setting prices based on their specific economic characteristics and are thus prevented from getting the business they might best be suited to handle.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Holiday sales this year will average 5 per cent greater than in the 1953 Christmas season, according to a spot cheek conducted this week by the Department of Commerce in thirty-three key cities.

Stocks rose to new highs in early trading yesterday, fell sharply, and then fought their way back in a final rally to recover about half what they had lost. The market ended the day in the plus column by an eyelash.
Art Luppino's 166 points for Arizona have made the sophomore star the fourth highest scorer in major-college football history and the season's leader by a runaway margin.
One advertisement was a factor in the loss of an account worth more than $1,000,000 a year in billings. This is how it came about:

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 7 -- Paul M. Butler, new Democratic National Chairman, asserted tonight that if Adlai E. Stevenson obtained the party's 1956 Presidential nomination, he would have to seek it "vigorously" and would not be drafted.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman is reported to have offered the post of Superintendent of Public Works in the new Democrat-Liberal state administration to John W. Johnson, a Buffalo engineer.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 7 (AP) -- British pounds and patriotism outbid the American dollar today at the annual Newmarket bloodstock sales.

The best year yet is expected in 1955 by packers of both advertised and unadvertised brands of frozen orange juice. This was brought out yesterday by speakers representing some of the leading producers at a luncheon meeting of the Eastern Frosted Food Association in the Belmont-Plaza Hotel.

The two five-story apartment houses on plot 80 by 100 feet at 48 and 50 Convent Avenue have been sold by 48 Convent, Inc., to an investing customer of A. J. Clarke-Salzman, Inc., broker in the transaction.

Many a furrowed brow will smooth these days at the news that $15 or less can solve the gift dilemma in a really exciting manner. For every woman on your Christmas list, from ancient aunties to fashion-minded young cousins, the stores are filled with selections of Yuletide pretties that not only look worth many times their price but also have a discriminating air.
New York University will construct a $3,000,000 student center at its Washington Square division.
The Bank of the Manhattan Company has been holding "conversations" concerning the possibility of other banks merging into it, J. Stewart Baker, chairman, disclosed yesterday.

By this time there could hardly have been much doubt about Senator McCarthy's willingness to make a complete break with the Administration. His statement of yesterday puts the final seal on a decision that the Administration itself should have made long ago.

THE more hair-raising the possibilities of tomorrow's history become the more eagerly scholars turn to the examination of past history. They hope to find in the long story of mankind some clue to the immediate future. How comforting it would be, for instance, if we felt sure that we would not blow each other up!

On the heels of two transient attractions ("All Summer Long" and "The Traveling Lady"), the Playwrights Company has a hunch that Maxwell Anderson will change the pace by coming up with a hit in "The Bad Seed." The group's third entry of the season will be presented as a Theatre Guild subscription offering.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 7 -- Don Finn scored 14 of his 15 points in the second half to lead St. Peter's to a 74-69 basketball victory over Adelphi in Collins Gymnasium tonight. The teams were deadlocked, 37 -- 37, at the half. Don Payne of the visitors was high scorer with 23 points and Dick Onderdonk paced St. Peter's with 21.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles and Ralph Demmler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today congratulated the Foreign Bondholders. Protective Council on the work it had done since its organization in 1933.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The Ukraine charged today that the racial discrimination policies of the Union of South Africa constituted a threat to world peace.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Eisenhower Administration plans no further cuts in defense spending unless there is a definite improvement in the international climate.

The forty-third annual appeal for New York City's Neediest has only just begun, and yet the gifts are pouring in with every mail. The eagerness and speed with which readers of this newspaper have for years, even for decades, responded to the plight of their less fortunate neighbors is even more significant than the size of their individual contributions.

An American edition of Simone de Beauvoir's "Les Mandarins," which won this year's Prix Goncourt, will be issued in the spring by World Publishing Company. Entitled "The Mandarins," the story is about left-wing intelectuals in and out of the Communist party.
Using an aerial fire ladder as a hoist, firemen lowered an unconscious woman and her grandson four stories to safety during a two-alarm apartment blaze in Brooklyn early yesterday morning.
CARBONDALE, Ill., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Shawfield Glenfire, owned by Andrew W. Porter of Oxford, Md., today won the second annual national cocker spaniel field trial.

Fred J. Schwartz, president of Distributors Corporation of America, announced yesterday that the company's first offering of $1,000,000 of preferred stock had been sold to motion picture exhibitors. He also said the company had earmarked $12,000,000 for production and distribution.
LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Peter Thorneycroft, President of the Board of Trade, said today that Britain was more prosperous than ever before.

Separation of power among the three Government branches was raised yesterday in the United States Court of Appeals by two men who refused to give Senator Joseph R. McCarthy records of their loyalty hearings when they were employed at Fort Monmouth.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Prof. Albert Edward Richardson, architect, was elected the eighteenth president of the Royal Academy tonight, to succeed Sir Gerald Kelly, who has reached the retirement age of 75. Professor Richardson is 74. Sir Joshua Reynolds was the first president of the academy.

Carl Braun and Sweetwater Clifton played the entire forty-eight minutes and sparked the New York Knickerbockers to a 97-89 triumph over the champion Minneapolis Lakers at Madison Square Garden last night. In the curtain-raiser of the National Basketball Association double-header, the Boston Celtics turned back the Rochester Royals, 95 -- 93.

A check yesterday of letters sent to Santa Claus showed no subversion in the loyalty of children to him. This conclusion is based on a fair sampling of 4,708 missives rounded up at the New York Post Office for forwarding to the North Pole.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Following are the texts of a letter by Henry Cabot Lodge Jr., United States representative, listing four more United States airmen held captive by Peiping, and of a resolution submitted to the General Assembly by sixteen member nations that fought in Korea on the imprisonment of eleven United States airmen by Communist China:

Coach Lou Little and the Columbia football squad will be guests of honor tonight at a dinner tendered by the gridiron section of the Varsity "C' Club at the Men's Faculty Club, 117th Street and Morningside Drive.

LONDON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Prime Minister Churchill has forbidden the scheduled television appearance next week of three of Britain's top armed service chiefs, it was reported today. The television program was to have been on the future of the British navy in an atomic war.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 7 -- The Communists foresee the possibility that next year's general elections will be followed by a coalition Government for Indonesia, including the Communists and "other democratic parties and groups."
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 7 -- Top hats and lions' mane headdresses, stiff court etiquette and wild spear-brandishing dances welcomed Emperor Haile Selassie home from his travels today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The favored Lily-Ann Stable's Fly-Lo, making his second start of the Florida season, defeated ten other sprinters today in the featured Biscayne Terrace Purse at Tropical Park.
The New York State Thruway Authority carried the permanent financing of its 562-mile express-way system another step forward yesterday with the sale of $50,000,000 of general revenue bonds, series B.

Stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange improved their market prices by an average of 8.4 per cent in November, the exchange reported yesterday. The average share value rose from $47.91 at the end of October to $51.93 on Nov. 30.

Following is the text of a statement by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy in Washington yesterday criticizing President Eisenhower on the Communist issue; the texts of two statements cited by the White House in reply, and a reply by Senator Arthur V. Watkins, Republican of Utah, as carried by The Associated Press.

MIAMI, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Professionals Harold D. Paddock Jr., Chagrin Falls, Ohio, and Charles Harter, Logansport, Ind., led a field of eighty-five qualifiers for the thirtieth annual Miami open golf tournament today with scores of 69.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The concept of an independent Federal Reserve System, with broad freedom to influence the cost and supply of credit, emerged unscathed today from a Congressional review of monetary and debt-management policies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- John Foster Dulles, the Secretary of State, said today that the Eisenhower Administration expected to submit to the next Congress a program for economic development in Asia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (UP) -- Arrangements were announced today for letting additional American oil companies join in the combine operating Iran's oil industry at some future date. The State Department said five American companies already participating in the eight-member group "are prepared to transfer at cost a portion of their participation" in the alliance to other American oil companies.

THERE was a mischievous gleam in Casey Stengel's eyes when he spotted the newest arrival among the lobby sitters at yesterday's baseball gathering. The newcomer was a press-box refugee who had written a couple of columns about Ty Cobb.

Testifying yesterday before a subcommittee on Economic Stabilization of the Senate-House Committee on the Economic Report, Secretary of the Treasury Humphrey defended the coordinated monetary and fiscal record of the past two years under the Eisenhower Administration.
OMAHA, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Omaha's Triple-A baseball emissary, Al Sorensen, said today, "I believe that within twenty-four hours Omaha will be in the American Association."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The First Lady's secretarial staff is getting out more than three thousand Christmas cards as she wraps her own gift packages.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has invited the United States, the Soviet Union and five other nations to name representatives on an advisory committee for an international scientific conference on peaceful uses of atomic energy.

PARIS, Dec. 7 -- During this era of possible coexistence the first problem facing United States diplomacy is not how to apply the politically popular but practically meaningless slogans of "liberation" and "roll back." Right now the question isn't how to shrink the massive Soviet empire and free the restless peoples under its domination.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- A nationally known medical educator said here today that he was convinced that smoking had nothing to do with lung cancer.

After piloting Japan through seven eventful years of the post-war era, from the chaos of defeat to peace and freedom in close alliance with the West, Premier Yoshida has now been forced to resign. Japan now enters an uncertain period that raises many question marks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Building construction set a new record for November with expenditures of $3,263,000. The Departments of Labor and Commerce in a joint report said that the seasonally adjusted outlays for November were at an annual rate of $38,100,000,000, the highest level ever.
LOCUST VALLEY, L. I., Wednesday, Dec. 8 -- Six firemen were injured early today in a fire that destroyed the thirty-room house on the estate here of Louis J. Horowitz, a retired building executive.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Iona College's basketball team scored its second victory in as many starts by defeating Brooklyn College, 78 -- 57, at O'Connell Memorial Gymnasium here tonight.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations cleared the track today for unity with the American Federation of Labor.

The Canadian National Railways estimated yesterday it would tote some 9,000,000 Christmas trees in 3,000 flatcars to homes in Canada and the United States. Seventy per cent of the trees will come to this country to fill 25 per cent of the demand here.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- France has more than 70,000 troops in Algeria, Francois Mitterand, Minister of the Interior, reported today to the Assembly of the French Union.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 7 -- A strike of seagoing radio operators that had disrupted West Coast shipping for five days was called off at 2:30 A. M. today. Ships began moving out of coastal ports.

The Oil and Chemical Terminal, Inc., of New York has purchased the industrial property at 146-76 Doremus Avenue in Newark, N. J., from the Gulf Oil Corporation which is moving its facilities to a new plant in Linden.
The universality of music brought together last night in a church parish house here a group as diverse in ages as in occupations.
Thanks to the alertness of three New York detectives, twenty Jacksonville, Fla., relatives and friends of two young women here will receive Christmas gifts that almost went astray.

JERSEY CITY, N. J., Dec. 7 -- The books on the celebrated conspiracy case involving former Hoboken Police Chief Edward J. McFeely were closed yesterday when Superior Court Judge Gene R. Mariano dismissed the charge.

It is a source of regret, but it has also become an inescapable duty, to express a deep sense of disappointment and shock over political trends in Turkey. The steady drive toward democracy that was so gratifying in this vital Near Eastern country has ended -- one hopes temporarily.

SALZBURG, Austria, Dec. 7 -- A new reception and emigration center established under the United States program to assist refugees from behind the Iron Curtain was opened today in Glasenbach, near Salzburg.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 7 -- Dr. Richard N. Sheppard introduced today some variations on the defense theme at the murder trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, his younger brother and osteopathic colleague. He acknowledged that there had been "minor" disputes between "Dr. Sam" and the latter's wife, Marilyn, 31, the victim.
