Mrs. Edward C. W. Oelsner, whose parked automobile was stolen Saturday, with the result that she lost $10,000 in clothing and furs but recovered $70,000 in jewels, has a new problem to face today.

Many young women from New York and other cities in the eastern part of the country will attend the annual Debutantes New Year's Ball to be held on the night of Jan. 1 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- James C. Hagerty, White House press secretary, labeled as "newspaper fiction" today a proposal making the rounds of Presidential advisers that some means be found to effect a rapprochement between President Eisenhower and Senator William F. Knowland.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 7 -- The french Resident General in Tunisia tonight pronounced "operation fellaga" a success.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The two-year delay in bringing Britain's new jet fighter planes into frontline Royal Air Force squadrons has been worrying top air commanders here privately. Now criticism is being voiced publicly.
CHICAGO, Dec. 7 -- Corn and soybeans were again weakest in early trading on the Board of Trade today. Wheat was firm at times, and oats showed sustained strength.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- The stock market was quieter today under the threat of a railway strike in support of wage claims. A modest rally in British funds on the success of the conversion offer was not maintained.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi and member of the censure committee commented on Senator McCarthy's attack:
ALBANY, Dec. 7 (AP) -- A Republican State Senator said today that Gov.-elect Averell Harriman's proposal to set up a business development corporation in the state was not new.
The initial showing in this country by L'Association des Couturiers Canadiens was presented yesterday at the Pierre Hotel.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 7 -- President Eisenhower's chief labor officer called today for repeal of state "right to work" laws.
The New York Port Society, a 136-year-old interdenominational welfare organization for seamen, last night opened its new quarters at 524 West Forty-second Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The United States informed the United Nations tonight that four United States airmen shot down during the Korean War were being held by Communist China in violation of the armistice. These are in addition to the eleven previously named.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Army Times said today that Roy M. Cohn, former committee aide to Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin, had failed to attend the required number of New York National Guard drills.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 7 -- Julio Lozano Diaz, Chief of State, granted amnesty today to all political prisoners and to persons indicted for political offenses. This was the third decree he had issued since taking office Sunday.
TRENTON, Dec. 7 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, sharply rebuked the Republican-controlled State Senate today for its apparent willingness to end rent controls in New Jersey on Dec. 31.
When Madeline Wade boards an airplane here today, she will be starting on her 69,273d air-mile of commuting between classes on the East and West coasts.
ROME, Dec. 7 -- Papal physicians were reported today to be "moderately optimistic" that Pope Pius XII would recover from his ailment.

Twelve hundred persons heard eleven speakers last night praise the late Vito Marcantonio at a memorial for the former Representative at the Manhattan Center, 311 West Thirty-fourth Street. The gathering marked the fifty-second anniversary of the East Harlem leader's birth. He died last August.

With athletic directors, coaches, public-relations officers and faculty representatives from nearly 200 colleges in attendance, the eighteenth annual schedule-making convention of the Eastern College Athletic Conference resumed yesterday at the Hotel Biltmore.

THE irresistible genius of Richard Strauss was again manifested last night when the Philadelphia Orchestra, Eugene Ormandy, conductor, with Phyllis Curtin, soprano, gave a complete program of early and late compositions by that master in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A Congressional investigation into the gasoline price wars now being waged in New Jersey is under way.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 7 -- Mayor Wagner of New York declared tonight that it was unfortunate that more people, particularly state and Federal officials, were not aware of the intimate relationship between municipal government and the people.
The resumption of "The Marriage," a domestic situation comedy co-starring Hume Cronyn and Jessica Tandy, is a distinct possibility after the first of the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- President Eisenhower accepted today the resignation of Robert B. Murray Jr. as Under Secretary of Commerce for Transportation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Two New York insurance companies and three New York banks will put up nearly 95 per cent of the $105,415,000 capital needed by the Dixon-Yates private power group to carry out its Government contract.
For the first time since 1947, underwriters here will make a public offering today of the dollar bonds of a foreign nation other than Canada.
America's business leaders were urged yesterday to make themselves more aware of general economic conditions and the re-emergence of the individual in our society.

In asserting that the "over-all transit problem of the vast New York-New Jersey metropolitan area has reached a crisis where debate must be replaced with action" Charles H. Tuttle, speaking before the twenty-fifth annual meeting of the Regional Plan Association, cannot be accused of being premature.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Further adjustment of the Federal income tax structure to encourage more individual and corporate contributions to colleges and universities was urged today.

Many problems befall a rapidly expanding metropolitan area and public transit constitutes one of the most complicated and costly. Amid higher fares, proposed abandonments and bankruptcies, suburban rail service is permitted to degenerate without adequate recognition of the seriousness of this development.

AS a part of the Museum of Modern Art's twenty-fifth anniversary program of special events, and as a pendant to the recent show of American twentieth century prints, this museum is opening today an exhibition entitled "100 Masterprints of Europe."
MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 7 -- A twenty-two-man executive board that included one Soviet bloc delegate was elected today by the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- The United Nations was asked today to condemn the Egyptian Government for its suppression of Al Misri, one of the leading newspapers in the Middle East.

THE good people who have lived for years in the six old red-brick houses in Grove Court sleep restlessly these nights. Their waking hours are troubled, too. They think they are under Blind Progress' lifted heel.

MAX LIEBMAN'S latest color spectacular, "Spotlight," seen on Sunday evening over N. B. C., was much his best of the season. The program had lilt and style, did not take itself seriously and was engagingly varied. All in all, good fun, which, for spectaculars, is progress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Ceylon's Prime Minister said today, that if the United States would give free Asia economic and technical aid, it "can safely leave to Asia the job of defending herself against communism.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Kimla A. Ghedemah, Minister of Finance of the Gold Coast, reported today to the General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee what he termed a situation of "buoyant revenue" in his own country.

ALBANY, Dec. 7 -- State Education Commissioner Lewis A. Wilson refused today to grant a rehearing to four members of the Lindenhurst, L. I., Board of Education, whom he had removed from office last month for disobeying his orders.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 7 -- Anthony Thieme of Rockport, Mass., a landscape painter well known in the American art world for nearly forty years, shot and killed himself at 8:20 o'clock this morning in his bathroom in the Pickwick Arms Hotel.

Geese are arriving in the market this fall in a new size. The long-domesticated bird, enjoyed by the ancient Egyptians, is available for the first time in the East in a "junior" size of four to six pounds ready-to-cook weight. Geese more commonly range from eight to twelve pounds.
HEIDELBERG, Germany, Dec. 7 (UP) -- The United States Army issued an order to its troops in Europe today that said, in effect, "get the fat off so you can be ready to fight."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A youngster setting the table, buying stamps or returning "deposit" bottles to the grocery store is not only being helpful to his family -- he also is learning arithmetic in a way that will stick.

Short covering following the recent declines raised coffee prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was switching out of December in anticipation of the first notice date, today. Profit taking and light hedge-selling limited the rise.

The Chicago Black Hawks will skate against the New York Rangers in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden tonight. Muzz Patrick's sextet has yet to beat the Windy City outfit on the local ice. However, the New Yorkers have beaten Chicago on the road.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 7 -- The election of Representative George H. Bender, Republican of Cleveland, to the United States Senate was certified here today. The action followed completion of a recount of votes in twenty-five counties, demanded by Senator Thomas A. Burke, defeated Democratic candidate.
The appointment of Robert Barrie as executive director of the New York State Society for Mental Health of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, was announced yesterday.

YONKERS, Dec. 7 -- Welfare organizations here were urged today by the un-American activities committee of the Westchester County American Legion to boycott a meeting that is to be addressed tomorrow by Dr. Harold Taylor, president of Sarah Lawrence College.
A spokesman for protectionists charged yesterday that the Executive branch of the Government had abused reciprocal trade agreement powers delegated to it by Congress.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy broke his long-deteriorating relations with President Eisenhower today.

LONDON, Dec. 7 -- Sir Winston Churchill told the House of Commons today that the message to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery mentioned in his Woodford speech had not been found in the field marshal's papers.

Dana X. Bible received the Touchdown Club of New York's annual award for "unusual service to football" last night. The athletic director of the University of Texas, a football coach for thirty-four years, produced a total of fourteen major conference champions at Texas A. and M., Nebraska and Texas.
That's a pretty good essay in Topics of The Times for Dec. 3 about the school kids who were not sufficiently interested in doing "Arsenic and Old Lace" to learn their lines.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 7 -- The Communist Government and the Yugoslav Roman Catholic hierarchy resumed contact today for the first time in eighteen months.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 7 -- Egypt said today that she would not allow Israeli ships to pass through the Suez Canal. She declared that aggressive Israeli acts required this "legitimate defense."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- A conference of United States and Latin American business men will be held at New Orleans early next year in an effort to reverse the decline in United States investment in Latin America.
The Yankees announced yesterday the signing of Elston Howard, a catcher-outfielder. Howard hopes to be the first Negro ever to wear a Yankee uniform in a regular season game.

ROME, Dec. 7 -- Those who believe that smoking a moderate amount of tobacco is not injurious received support from an unexpected quarter today. The fortnightly magazine Civilta Cattolica, official organ of the Jesuit order and one of the most authoritative publications in the Roman Catholic world, entirely agrees with them.
MIAMI, Dec. 7 -- The nation's maritime industries took an inward look today in a group effort at self-analysis.

An entertainment, known as a Spanish evening, has been arranged under the auspices of the American Friends of Spain Foundation, Inc., for the night of Dec. 17 in the Sert Room of the Waldorf-Astoria. Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney heads the committee for the event, proceeds of which will be donated to the International Scholarship Fund maintained by the foundation.
Babies who sleep on their stomachs too much may develop deformities of the face and jaw, it was reported here yesterday at the Greater New York Dental Meeting.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The White House was taken by surprise today by the attack of James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, on state "right to work" laws.
Attempts to curtail social services until world peace is achieved would be "lunacy," a nationwide meeting of welfare agency leaders was told yesterday.

More than $500,000 was appropriated last year by the China Medical Board, Inc., for medical and nursing programs in the Orient. This was announced in the annual report of the board, made public yesterday, for the period ended June 30, 1954.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson said today indications point to a price support rate of 90 per cent of parity for the 1955 cotton crop -- the support level in effect since World War II.

Are we to have censorship on the posing of legitimate questions at the Presidential press conferences? This disturbing question is prompted by your editorial concerning the questions asked by this correspondent on behalf of The Christian Century -- questions referring to the recent pronouncements on war and peace by the Evanston Assembly of the World Council of Churches.

Michigan sold $60,000,000 of Korea veterans' bonds in the public market yesterday at a net interest cost of 1.83425 per cent. Proceeds from the financing will be used for the payment of a bonus to residents of the state who served in the armed forces during the Korean War.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The United States Government would welcome the return of normal, informal relations between Western diplomats and Soviet officials in Moscow.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Rex Hartwig, a member of Australia's Davis Cup team, apparently was stricken with mumps today and was counted out of the tennis challenge round at Sydney Dec. 27-29.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- The Hardboard Association today began a battle to convince the Tariff Commission that their product should be classed as wood and not as paper.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 7 -- President Eisenhower will appoint Nelson A. Rockefeller of New York as a White House administrative assistant on foreign policy.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 7 (AP) -- The Commissioner of Motor Vehicles appointed today a twelve-member advisory committee to consult with the Motor Vehicle Bureau on compulsory safety inspection of automobiles.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 7 -- French and United States officials sat down together today in the first of a series of meetings designed to coordinate their policy in Vietnam.
AN exhibition of characteristic work by painters of the pre-World War I group in Germany known as Der Blaue Reiter opens today at the Curt Valentin Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.
STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 7 -- Fifteen nations of West Europe will be represented here in a discussion of all the present major European political issues beginning tomorrow.
The police yesterday seized furs, jewelry and other items estimated at a value of $250,000, as the loot from a series of recent Queens burglaries. The alleged burglar was still at large last night.
The story of a little girl whose mother died recently moved a young reader of the Times Neediest Cases to send $1 to help her. She also composed a stirring letter in praise of her own family.
WEST MEMPHIS, Ark., Dec. 7 (AP) -- Adlai Stevenson learned something new today about the controversial Dixon-Yates power plant. The proposed site has been changed.
Old-fashioned hospitality will have the benefit of new fashions in entertaining accessories this year. Gifts for the hostess or the home meet the eye in almost every shop.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams commended and promoted yesterday six detectives and two patrolmen who participated recently in outstanding police action.

ANDROS, Bahamas, Dec. 8 -- During the coming months this island, the largest of the Bahamas, will play host to a legion of sportsmen seeking a brief escape from the northern chill. Probably no area of comparable size offers such diverse opportunities over a wide "expense" range.

Retirement payments and pensions amounting to $1,679,189 for 2,088 college professors and their widows were granted during the year ending June 30 by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, it was announced last week.

NEWARK, Dec. 8 -- A rent-control ordinance was passed here tonight at an emergency meeting of the City Council. Its passage on first reading will freeze rents immediately, although it will not become a law formally until Dec. 22.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- With buyers still restrained by the railway men's renewed claim for higher wages, light end-of-the-year selling brought declines today in all markets.
A record number of tourists will visit New York next summer if the plans of the New York Convention and Tourists Bureau are successful, hotel executives were told yesterday.

Today's new film is "Deep In My Heart," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer musical drama in color based on the life of Sigmund Romberg, at the Radio City Music Hall, Jose Ferrer, as the composer, heads a cast featuring Merle Oberon, Helen Traubel, Doe Avedon, Walter Pidgeon, Paul Henreid and Tamara Toumanova.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The New York Commissioner of Health asserted today that protection of the public against radiation was "clearly a problem that concerns every state and local health department."
The Federal Food and Drug Administrator, George P. Larrick, said yesterday that his agency was understaffed and faced a serious problem from increased promotion of fake medical products.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- Douglas McKay, Secretary of the Interior, urged western foresters and conservationists today to support proposed legislation that would provide safeguards against abuses of mining laws.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Two executives of aircraft manufacturing concerns were named today by the National Aeronautic Association as recipients of the 1953 Collier Trophy for "outstanding achievement in aviation."

Egypt's new Premier, Gamal Abdel Nasser, has written an autobiography that will be published early in January by Public Affairs Press of Washington. In the volume the Premier gives a first-hand account of the deposing of King Farouk in 1952.
Although the playthings industry expects to slip below the record 1953 production figure this year, the table game segment looks forward to a 5 per cent increase.

Commodity futures prices were irregular yesterday on the New York Exchanges. Volume was light in most markets. Sugar, potatoes, burlap and zinc ended mixed; wool, hides and rubber declined, and cocoa, coffee, cottonseed oil and soybean oil rose.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Pedestrians in Britain will be liable to a 20 ($56) fine for disobeying a policeman's traffic directions under the new road bill published today.

ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- The State Motor Vehicle Commissioner, James R. Macduff, today issued samples of the forms on which garages may apply for licenses as official stations for the compulsory automobile inspection program that goes into effect next year.
Bob Turley and Billy Hunter, recently acquired by the Yankees in the deal with Baltimore, signed their 1955 contracts in the Yankee offices yesterday.

The notion that America is "a house divided against itself and all but inundated by a lawless, anti-intellectual flood," was decried last night by Dr. A. Whitney Griswold, president of Yale University.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 8 -- The national council of the Protestant Episcopal Church, made up of 6,000 parishes, called upon churchmen today to support the Supreme Court's decision barring segregation in public schools.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed firm yesterday, 16 to 23 points net higher than Tuesday on active months.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- The close ties between the Democratic party and the Congress of Industrial Organizations were condemned here today by Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union.

Chicago's Black Hawks continued to demonstrate a liking for the New York Rangers' ice last night. The last-place sextet in the National Hockey League carved a 2-to-1 victory over the Broadway Blues at Madison Square Garden for one of the Hawks' few successes this season.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Slim, carrying the silks of Mrs. Wallace Gilroy, opened his winter campaign with a front-running victory in the featured sixth race at Tropical Park today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 8 -- Two Canadian stock salesmen, wanted in Michigan for alleged violations of the United States Securities Act, will learn on Dec. 17 whether or not they are to extradited from Canada.

ADMIRERS of Eugene Speicher who have had little chance to see his work in recent years should be delighted by the exhibition of new flower paintings by the artist at Wildenstein's, 19 East Sixty-fourth Street.

ERIE, Pa., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Mayor Thomas W. Flatley, a leader in the Erie County Democratic party, pleaded guilty today to charges of conspiracy and violating his oath of office. The charges stemmed from a gambling raid.

The second annual luncheon and card party of the Council Chapter of United Hias Service will be given at noon Monday, Dec. 13, in the Tapestry Room of the Park Lane for the benefit of Hias Women's Division.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The General Assembly's Special Political Committee voted 34 to 9 today to have a United Nations commission continue to watch South Africa's complex policy of racial segregation. It did so in the face of a blunt warning from South Africa that she "cannot and will not cooperate."
Students and faculty at the Baruch School of Business and Public Administration, City College, gave 317 pints of blood to the regional Red Cross blood program Tuesday.

Patrolman Andrew Hunter, for seventeen years a policeman, was found dead with a bullet wound in his head yesterday. A note in his pocket in effect blamed the Brooklyn traffic courtesy-card investigation for his death.
BERLIN, Dec. 8 -- East Germany's leaders confirmed today that the "People's Police in Barracks" would become the nucleus of East Germany's projected army.
The average New Yorker's chances of avoiding accidental death are better today than at any time since the coming of the automobile, according to the odds posted by the Department of Health.

The New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street, will benefit from the proceeds of the opening performance of the Technicolor film, "Tonight's the Night," at the Fifty-second Street Trans-Lux Theatre on Dec. 22.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Manager Jean Bretonnel asked today that judging of the December 15 title fight between France's Pierre Langlois and Bobo Olson, world middleweight champion, be done by a French-Canadian and a California official not from San Fancisco.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United States reported "steady progress" today toward fulfillment of President Eisenhower's year-old atoms-for-peace plan.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- Gales, snow and floods brought death and destruction on and around the British Isles today. A minor tornado -- a rare visitation in Britain -- struck London and the surrounding counties tonight. Winds of hurricane force whipped the seas and shipping was in distress around the coasts.
The county's press was virtually unanimous yesterday in denouncing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy for his attack on President Eisenhower.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- A proposal for free elections in all Korea, supervised by the United Nations, was adopted today by the General Assembly's Political and Security Committee. One aim of the elections would be the reunification of Korea.
The Government began hearings yesterday to determine whether the Isbrandtsen Steamship Company is a common carrier using only American-flag ships.

Many thanks for your fine editorial "Parking for Doctors." It is terse and to the point. A few of my colleagues have abused the "rights and privileges" with which our profession is honored but, as you say, the abuses are relatively few as compared with the advantages to the public as well as to the medical profession.

A warning that the United States must not support colonialism in Asia if it hopes to stop Soviet and Chinese Communist aggression was sounded last night by Maj. Gen. William J. Donovan, former Ambassador to Thailand.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Leaders of the four qualified dairy organizations in the New York milkshed were reported to have agreed today that a Federal-state milk marketing order was necessary for northern New Jersey.
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Bob Kleberg of the King Ranch of Texas turned in one of the highest bids today as the Newmarket bloodstock sales lagged after two days of brisk business.

A shoe buyer employed by Saks Fifth Avenue was charged yesterday with violation of the commercial bribery section of the Penal Law in that he was alleged to have received $15,863 in kickbacks for orders.
The State Insurance Department disclosed yesterday how Alphonse C. Corcillo had developed, with union welfare funds, an insurance business that brought him lush profits.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Taking almost a detached view of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's attack on him, President Eisenhower said today he did not indulge in personal vituperation.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- An admitted former Communist testified today that twelve Congressmen "initiated" a coalition of organizations in 1948 that the Communist party took over that same year under the name of the Civil Rights Congress.
The selection of Ralph Guglielmi of Notre Dame on the 1954 Associated Press All-America football team yesterday follows a tradition.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The British Chiefs of Staff have been threshing out issues that may affect Britain's role as a world military power and as the United States' chief ally.
Twenty-seven faculty members in the municipal colleges are under "active investigation" for possible Communist party membership, the Board of Higher Education said yesterday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 8 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was depicted today as a steady, even-tempered young man, skilled in osteopathic Surgery and the "best" kind of neighbor. He was described as provident, considerate, sometimes boyishly enthusiastic and apparently ideally suited to the wife he is accused of having murdered.

United States electric power production last week rose to a new high of 9,612,0D0,000 kilowatt-hours, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. Lower temperatures over extensive areas together with accelerated industrial activity, were credited with the jump from the preceding week's output of 9,087,000,000 kilowatt-hours.
LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The British Government opposes the idea of any new approaches to the Soviet Union for a four-power meeting until after the agreements on West Germany have been ratified.

Lou Little and his 1954 football team were honored at a dinner of the Columbia Varsity "C" Club at the Men's Faculty Club on Morningside Heights last night. The affair commemorated Little's twenty-fifth anniversary as head coach at Columbia.
An old-fashioned taffy pull is great fun.

Fordham, heavily favored to defeat Syracuse in its home basketball debut, had to go down to the wire to subdue the scrappy Orange quintet, 60 -- 56, before 2,000 spectators at the Fordham gymnasium last night.
BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 8 -- Two Long Island State Park policemen admitted today they had accepted so-called courtesy cards from certain parkway speeders last summer and had failed to issue summonses.

Orders on hand in private shipyards throughout the country increased by 165,300 deadweight tons last month, the Shipbuilders Council of America reported yesterday. It was the first time in three years that an increase of this size was noted in the council's monthly report.

LEWIS CARROLL (1832-98) wrote this morning's poem, "Facts," at the age of 13 or thereabouts. It appears in what is now published as the first of his writings -- "Useful and Instructive Poetry"* -- intended to beguile his even younger relatives and certain to beguile all the Carrollians on earth.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower said today that his Secretary of Labor, James P. Mitchell, did not necessarily represent Administration views when he came out strongly against state right-to-work laws.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Producers cut hog marketings sharply today and the market steadied after the previous day's share break. Salable receipts at 11,000 head were 3,000 under the advance estimate. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
Study of the worn teeth of Eskimo and Australian aborigines has resulted in the development of an improved artificial denture.
Persons active in behalf of the Ball of the Roses attended the cocktail party given last evening by Garrard B. Winston, president of Roosevelt Hospital, in his home at 7 East Ninety-second Street.

Baby sitting is a noble profession. Many belong to it, and the tangible results, as seen around the house, are excellent. Being self-supporting, baby sitters no longer demand a weekly allowance, or, if they do, the request can be brushed casually aside.
The Brooklyn College basketball team has lost, through injuries, its top scorer and playmaker, Artie Cohen.
Christmas comes to babies, too. Little ones too young to know what all the excitement is about are not too young to receive gifts with mothers acting as their proxies.
Ford Frick, commissioner of baseball, believes that three eight-club major leagues will be the answer to the problem of expansion.

Mrs. Siegfried Kramarsky of 101 Central Park West, is one of the rare home cooks in this city who never uses canned or frozen foods. Meat, fish, fruits and vegetables are fresh when they arrive in her kitchen.

A study of foreign, cookbooks- tells Ks. there are many ,ways to flavor s: duck. The Chinese, who have been famous for their duck dishes since the time of arco Polo, raay rub the .inside of. the bird with a mixture of chopped scallion, a chopped clover'of garlic, soy sauce, sugar, fresh, ginger or cinnamon and a bit of rice wine.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 8 -- The Rev. S. W. T. Luzipho, Negro minister of the Congregational Church, told a multi-racial conference of church leaders here today that it was "futile" for churchmen to come together to solve their differences while men were denied human dignity because of their color.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Senator Allen J. Ellender answered Cuban attacks on his sugar quota stand today by saying they show "I'm telling the truth." Cuban newspapers, which fear that the Louisiana Democrat will win an increase in United States production that would cut Cuban sugar imports to this country, said that considerable unemployment and an economic recession had hit their industry.

Events today: John Ferris, organist, St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University, noon; City College of New York vocal ensemble and string quartet, Townsend Harris Hall, 12:30 P. M.; Composers Group of New York, Mason Hamlin salon, 3 East Forty-third Street, 7.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- The captain and four officers of the 1,929-ton British steamer Admiral Hardy resigned because they would not subject their crew to "Communist intimidation" on the China mainland, it was disclosed here today.

EVERYONE who read the late William March's "The Bad Seed" was horrified and terrified. That is likely to be the case with playgoers who see Maxwell Anderson's drama version, which opened at the Forty-sixth Street last evening.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (UP) -- The Government said today it was going ahead with plans to sell a Government-owned foundry at New Castle, Pa., after failing to reach a satisfactory leasing agreement with the United Engineering and Foundry Company of Pittsburgh.

THE heap big chief of the Indians, Hank Greenberg, and his noble medicine man, Al Lopez, were relaxing in a hotel suite the other day between innings of the winter baseball meetings. The hair on their heads looked black and luxuriant. There were no outward signs of the horrendous scalping the Giants had given them in the world series.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 8 -- A study of transportation by the national Administration will result in recommendations inimical to water transport and favorable to railroads, shipping men were warned here today.

Directing the major departments within the New York City government is a large responsibility, in terms of money handled, in number of personnel employed and in service performed for the people of the city. The salary for such Commissioners should reflect the responsibility.
TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras Dec. 8 -- Dr. Julio Lozano Diaz, Chief of State, apparently has given the labor movement just the encouragement it needed to seek to establish unions under official protection.
Arnold Constable presented a collection of budget-priced resort fashions yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
VIENNA, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Poland's Communist Government conceded today that its hand-picked candidates in eleven districts had failed to win Sunday's local council elections.

The prosecution rested its case yesterday against three Brooklyn adolescents charged with the first degree murder of a factory worker on an East River pier after what one of the boys described as a "hunt for bums" to abuse.
The Transit Authority has backed away from a move to suppress the views of Harris J. Klein, its minority of one, Mr. Klein said yesterday.
The spirit of Father Christmas settled over the arts and crafts shop of Hart Island yesterday as seventy inmates began to breathe new life into old toys for poor children.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse as required by conference rules, except where direct quotation is authorized by the White House:

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 -- "Beau James," Gene Fowler's affectionate biography of the late James J. Walker, former Mayor of New York, will be brought to the screen by Bob Hope Enterprises and Scribe Productions. It will be the first of three pictures the producing combine plans to make during the next five years in accordance with a newly completed agreement.

Columbia University announced yesterday the formation of an Institute of Accounting. The institute, which will offer an undergraduate program in public and private accounting, will open next fall. James L. Dohr, Professor of Accounting at the Columbia Graduate School of Business, has been appointed director of the new unit.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The revised Senate investigation of alleged Communist infiltration into American defense production plants brought witnesses into a battle royal today.

LONDON, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -The Polish Security Minister was relieved of his post today after a thorough reorganization of his Ministry following the recent release of Hermann Field, United States architect.
With trading at 4,150,000 shares, heaviest in four years, the stock market fought all day yesterday to recover early losses. It managed to close on the plus side by the narrowest of margins.

No one will ever know whether the Government's suit against "the du Pont empire," General Motors and the U. S. Rubber Company was worth all the colossal trouble and expense which it involved. It took five years to settle and over a hundred days of actual sessions of the court; the record and briefs ran to 10,000 printed pages and the expenses of the defendants alone are said to have been $5,000,000.
As long as a person has a friend, he has no reason to consider life useless, a contributor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund remarked in a letter yesterday.

The Madison Square Garden season of college basketball double-headers will begin tonight, with Seton Hall facing Western Kentucky in the feature. The game will follow a contest between Manhattan and St. Joseph's of Philadelphia.

The world premiere of an aria by Alan Hovhaness and several rarely heard Verdi songs were on the program that Nell Tangeman, mezzo-soprano, sang last night in Town Hall, Miss Tangeman, always an intelligent and perceptive singer, generally does come up with something out of the routine.
There were indications yesterday that the Eastern College Athletic Conference is preparing to take a more positive position on football television than it has in the past.

DETROIT, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The conference football coaches endorsed a new plan of substitution at the Big Ten meeting today. Ray Eliot presented the proposal. The Illinois coach is the chairman of an American Football Coaches Association committee studying the substitution rule.
Brooklyn police Operation 73 had its first major crime last night. A hold-up man escaped with $200 from a shoe store in the Brownsville section.
ROME, Dec. 8 -- Pope Pius XII closed the Marian Year today with an invocation to the Virgin and a solemn blessing broadcast from his bedroom in the Vatican Palace.
North American Airlines issued a sharp rebuttal yesterday to charges made against it Sunday by attorneys for the Civil Aeronautics Board.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 8 -- Columbia successfully opened its basketball season by trouncing once-beaten Rutgers, 85 -- 61, tonight.

QUEBEC, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Premier Maurice Duplessis of Quebec has described as "wild" a statement by Nathaniel Goldstein, the New York State Attorney General, that he had "ignored appeals for cooperation in halting security frauds originating in Montreal."

When Robert R. Young, chairman of the New York Central Railroad, meets the road's directors next month he will recommend that the board put the company's stock on a regular dividend basis of 50 cents a share each quarter.

HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- Communist China warned the United States tonight that it would have to assume "all the grave consequences" if it did not withdraw "all its armed forces" from Formosa, the Pescadores Islands and Formosa Strait.
The something-for-nothing concept, however much it might be deplored, does a first-class job in moving merchandise. Three examples in the day's Madison Avenue grist:

Chief Magistrate John M. Murtagh yesterday fined Mrs. Edward C. W. Oelsner, a Long Island woman, $115 for three traffic tickets. He then fined her son, Warren, $700 for fourteen summonses.
The Louisiana parishes of Jefferson and St. Tammany sold to underwriters yesterday an issue of $46,000,000 of revenue bonds, paving the way for the construction of the longest bridge in the world.

The good people who live in the six, old red-brick houses in Grove Court were breathing more easily yesterday. For the City Planning Commission abandoned all thought of approving a school playground that would have wiped out their picturesque neighborhood.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old, a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.
Shopping centers are growing increasingly important as arteries for the distribution of consumer products, the Merchandising Executives Club of New York was told yesterday.
Three companies announced plans yesterday to join in a project to build a $5,000,000 chemicals plant in the Sao Paulo area of Brazil.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The United States reminded the Communist world today that this country's doors were always open to victims of oppression behind the Iron Curtain.

The colorful denizens of Catfish Row as drawn and set to music in the renowned American opera, "Porgy and Bess," will be brought to life for the first time in the university city of Zagreb, Yugoslavia, on Saturday evening.

James J. Braddock, a former world heavyweight champion, and the undefeated lightweight, Frankie Ryff of the Bronx, were named yesterday as award winners by the New York Boxing Writers Association. Braddock was selected for the James J. Walker Memorial Plaque, for long and meritorious service to boxing.
PARIS, Dec. 8 -- According to French officials here, the first sounding in Moscow on new negotiations between the Soviet Union and the West was confined to the question of an Austrian state treaty.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8 -- Virginia scored its third straight victory of the basketball season by defeating Navy, 79 -- 69, today.
GENEVA, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Four European nations are increasingly saving dollars by obtaining raw materials from their overseas dependencies, according to an economic report published tonight.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The ton of historical state records that was accidentally sold for waste paper two months ago was never under the jurisdiction of the State Library, Dr. Charles F. Gosnell, State Librarian, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy delivered his attack on President Eisenhower yesterday despite warnings by Senator Karl E. Mundt that the statement would have "unfortunate repercussions."
BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- The Government is considering ways of stimulating enthusiasm for the creation of a West German Army.
The New York Times of Nov. 30 carries a message from Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain preparing the public for the pounding of garbage cans on collection trucks.
Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc., was honored yesterday as "the dean of the coat and suit industry."

Carolyn Schnurer's lively sense of design comes into full play in her use of pattern and color. In her resort collection of swim suits and sundresses, shown yesterday by B. Altman at the Pierre Hotel, she utilized all manner of novel motifs in interesting combinations of color.
Directors of the Corning Glass Works yesterday proposed a 2 1/2-for-1 stock split and declared an extra dividend of $2 and a quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on the common.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- State Department officials appeared assured tonight that the new French approaches to the Soviet Union had not exceeded the Western Big Three agreement on the prospects for a four-power conference.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture announced today another increase of 2.7 per cent in its final estimate of this year's Government-restricted cotton crop, putting production at 13,569,000 bales of 500 pounds each.
I have read with much interest the letter to The Times by Judge Samuel H. Hofstadter with reference to the courts and arbitration and must express a strong dissent to his views.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- The United States asked the General Assembly tonight to "engage its moral authority" in bringing about the release of all United Nations prisoners of war still held by Communist China.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. served notice yesterday that he would not tolerate the acceptance of Christmas gifts by city firemen in connection with performance of official duties.

The Oklahoma Turnpike Authority financed the construction of an eighty-eight-mile extension of the Turner Turnpike yesterday by the sale of $68,000,000 of revenue bonds to a banking syndicate headed by First Boston Corporation.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 8 -- Former President Truman and Paul M. Butler, newly elected Democratic National Chairman, made peace today and buried the hatchet -- in the Republican party.
The recent cold snap cut sharply into the heavy inventories of fuel oil.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- Charles and George Finn, the flying twins, won a victory over the Government today after more than two years' litigation for possession of a C-46 war-surplus plane.

Facts about rheumatic fever and information on the treatment necessary to prevent serious heart damage from the disease are presented in a film "The Valiant Heart." The picture, which had its first New York showing yesterday at the Plaza Hotel, was produced for the American Heart Association and will be distributed nationally by the organization.

The first phase of the improvement of the west side of Times Square at Forty-second Street to make it a model traffic corner was completed yesterday when over-the-road signal lights were put into opera tion.

Details of the Federal Government's "all-out program" to improve control of the dense air traffic in the metropolitan area were disclosed yesterday by Frederick B. Lee, administrator of civil aeronautics for the Department of Commerce.

LONDON, Dec. 8 -- The German Dornier Aircraft Manufacturing company has side-stepped Allied curbs on aviation activities in Germany by setting up a subsidiary company in Spain and building its first post-war aircraft there.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Dec. 8 -- Indignant townsfolk, jealous of commuters' pre-empting a choice parking lot within convenient sprinting distance of the station, have staged one raid on it and plan another soon.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 8 -- Swift ratification of the agreements on West German armament and sovereignty was urged here today. All speakers in the first session of a two-day debate on European policy in the Consultative Assembly of the Council of Europe advocated such action.
The lighting of the Christmas tree in Rockefeller Plaza will be televised over Channel 4 today during the "Howdy Doody" program from 5:30 to 6 P. M.
Part of the hull of one of the early Dutch ships to enter New York waters has been set up as an exhibit in the Marine Gallery of the Museum of the City of New York, Fifth Avenue and 103d Street.

Mayor Wagner was hailed last night as a future Governor and as eventually President of the United States. In response, he made a plea for better understanding of this country's South and Central American neighbors and warned against a unilateral policy toward the nations he said were economically and militarily essential to this country's well-being.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower has called Republican Congressional leaders to a conference involving his legislative program and the split in his party. These leaders, including Senator William F. Knowland of California, who has broken with the President both on high foreign policy and the condemnation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy of Wisconsin, will meet the President at the White House on Monday.
Business will continue to gain throughout the United States in 1955 and 1956, barring any major change in the international situation.

Common sense and moderation have won a notable victory in Tunisia, where the uprising of the fellaga is now reported to be virtually over. These bandit - nationalists' yielded peacefully when the true Tunisian nationalists, represented by the Neo Destour party, joined with the French in pleading for surrender and promising amnesty.

The first performance in New York of Samuel Barber's "Prayers of Kierkegaard," a work of imposing dimensions and grand and severe line was given last night at Carnegie Hall by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, with the Schola Cantorum (director Hugh Ross), and Leontyne Price, Mary McMurray and Earl Ringland as solo singers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The number of unemployed throughout the country stood at 2,893,000 in early November, a rise of 152,000 from October.

John J. Wilson, president and founder of the Doelcam Corporation, Boston, manufacturer of synchro motors, has been elected a director and vice president of the Minneapolis-Honeywell Regulator Company. Minneapolis-Honeywell purchased Doelcam last month and will operate it as a division.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, has ordered the Army, Navy and Air Force to avoid concentrating defense orders in the plants of a few suppliers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A new effort to pin down the origin of the Dixon-Yates private power contract was made today before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

In the Chattanooga area of Tennessee there has been a perceptible decline in race prejudice and an improvement in job opportunities for Negroes. This is the finding reported by Prof. William H. Wesson Jr. of the University of Chattanooga following a survey he made for the Committee of the South.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Robert R. Young's Alleghany Corporation asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today in effect to sanction its continued control of the New York Central Railroad System.

MONTREAL, Dec. 8 (Canadian Press) -- A proposal to offer shareholders rights to subscribe to additional shares of Aluminium, Ltd., was approved today. The offer will be on the basis of one share for each ten held, at a price not higher than $46 a share in Canadian money.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The St. Louis Cardinals today acquired Frank Smith, a relief pitcher, from the Cincinnati Redlegs. In exchange, the Redlegs got a third baseman, Ray Jablonski; a pitcher, Gerry Staley, and a minor league player to be named later.
CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- Grain futures did not get far in either direction today. Increased selling erased moderate rallies.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations authorized today the maintenance of a permanent committee to police its multibillion-dollar welfare funds.

The number of refugees from Communist-ruled Eastern Europe who have found refuge in the United States or other parts of the free world is by now reckoned in the hundreds of thousands. That these brave souls, willing to leave their homes and suffer hardship rather than live under slavery, should have much that is valuable to contribute to the free world is self-evident.
ATLANTA, Dec. 8 -- The Georgia Education Commission proposed today that the state's Legislature meeting in January pass three laws designed to preserve separate schools for Negroes and whites.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 8 (AP) -- It's the $125,000 added Kentucky Derby now.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 8 (Reuters) -- Maj. Gen. O. Noerresoe, Inspector General of Infantry in the Danish Army, has been discharged following disclosures that a group of cadets were given Nazi indoctrination at the Danish Army Officers School, it was announced here today.

In a drawing contributed by Lucile Patterson Marsh to the Hundred Neediest Cases a small, wide-eyed girl clutches her doll closely. Her pudgy little hand grips the plaything with a maternal gesture. Little girls have a way of taking care of their dolls -- of dressing them and feeding them and mending their broken arms and legs.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 8 -- Eugene Cook, Attorney General of Georgia, asserted here today that the Federal Supreme Court had usurped legislative power and abridged state sovereignty in disregard of stable constitutional government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today sales by wholesalers were sligthly lower in October than in September and inventories of wholesalers increased.

Parker, vice president of the Knox division of the Hat Corporation of America, estimated yesterday that between now and Christmas women would spend $33,000,000 for hats -- not for their own pretty heads but for the noggins of the men in their lives.

All America is hopeful that Austria, so essential to the free world, will attain full sovereignty very soon. WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 8 -- Trailing by 8 points midway in the second half, the Colgate basketball team rallied to defeat Cornell, 73 -- 52, tonight.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- President Eisenhower had Joe McCarthy on the ropes today, wide open. He measured him carefully, drew a bead on his outstretched chin, wheeled and knocked the new Chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Paul M. Butler, right out of the ring.

OTTAWA, Dec. 7 -- Pakistan has more "ambassadors" in Ottawa than any other country. A group of Ottawa women has made this city's school children familiar with and interested in the everyday life of school children in Pakistan.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 8 -- The Soviet Union and five of its satellite states endorsed today a resolution calling upon members of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization "to assure freedom of expression and to remove barriers to the free flow of undistorted information."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The dismissal by Federal Judge LaBuy of the so-called du Pont case is the fourth Government prosecution in the same general field to be demolished in the courts recently, and the situation presents an important policy issue to Attorney General Brownell.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 8 -- A prediction that unemployment in 1955 would exceed this year's level was put before the C. I. O. Committee on Economic Policy today by its research director, Stanley Ruttenberg.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Navy's football squad began training today for its Sugar Bowl game on Jan. 1 with Mississippi. The middies had had a ten-day rest following their 27-20 victory over Army at the end of the regular season.

TORONTO, Dec. 8 (UP) -- Ron Stewart fired a goal in every period tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-1 victory over the Montreal Canadiens and move the Leafs to within 2 points of first place in the National Hockey League.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 8 -- Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator of New York, told the International City Managers Association convention tonight that the professional manager's use of "advance programming in public affairs" has made a unique social contribution.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago is studying the possibility of distributing all of its remaining stockholdings in the Northern Illinois Gas Company to Edison stockholders in the first six months of 1955.
The General Electric Company will market next year a new one-half-horsepower room air conditioner that uses less electric current than a flatiron or toaster.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 8 (AP) -- Gladys George, stage and screen actress, died in a hospital today under circumstances the police described as mysterious. She was 50 years old.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 8 -- Brown's basketball team pulled away in the final ten minutes to defeat Harvard, 51 -- 38, at the Athletic Building tonight. It was the Ivy League opener for both teams.

Brass and glass are emphasized in both a collection of lighting fixtures and one of lamps introduced here this week. The fixtures designed by the Finnish craftsman Paavo Tynell, are at Finland House, 41 East Fiftieth Street, and the lamps by Maurizio Tempestini, an Italian architect, at Lightolier, 11 East Thirty-sixth Street.

BOSTON, Dec. 8 (AP) -- Jack George scored 21 points tonight to lead the Philadelphia Warriors to an 86-77 victory over the New York Knickerbockers in a National Basketball Association game at Boston Garden.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- The world fears global war less now than any other time since 1951, President Eisenhower said today.
ALBANY, Dec. 8 -- George M. Shapiro, counsel to Governor Dewey since May, 1951, will join the New York City law firm of Proskauer, Rose, Goetz and Mendelsohn as a partner beginning Jan. 1.
HONG KONG, Dec. 8 -- The Hanoi radio reported today that the Vietminh had protested against an announced United States plan to train South Vietnam's army.

Don Haggerty of the Yale Club and Norman Forster of the New York A. C. advanced to the second round of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis Association handicap tournament at the Columbia University Club yesterday.
The results of mass trials on thousands of dental patients throughout the nation appear to indicate that the new "painless" ultrasonic drill is safe and effective.
TOKYO, Friday, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Premier Hatoyama named Mamoru Shigemitsu, wartime Foreign Minister, to the top post in his Cabinet today. Mr. Shigemitsu becomes Deputy Premier and Foreign Minister.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The United States voted today against its own resolution, under which $179,420 in indemnity awards would be paid to eleven former United States employes of the United Nations.
Two young men tied up four women in a private home in Brooklyn yesterday and took a $3,000 fur coat and a camera and rings worth $765.

Everyone who has followed the adventures of Joseph R. McCarthy during the past several months must be familiar with his plea that the hearings and inquiries to which he has been subjected have all along been preventing the exposure of numerous Communists in defense plants.
Five firemen responding to alarms in Brooklyn were slightly injured in two separate accidents yesterday when their trucks collided with other vehicles.

Madison Square Garden's twenty-first season of college basketball got off with a couple of bangs last night as St. Joseph's of Philadelphia upset Manhattan, 78 -- 68, and Seton Hall overcame Western Kentucky, 98 -- 85.

SHELLMAN, Ga., Dec. 9 (AP) -- A young Baptist minister who last June hailed the Supreme Court ruling against segregation in the schools as a just decision has been ousted as pastor of the Shellman Baptist Church.

In the office at 80 Centre Street that he will leave on Dec. 31 State Industrial Commissioner Edward Corsi lunched and conferred for two hours yesterday with his successor-designate, Dr. Isador Lubin.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 9 -- Judges took the witness stand here today and clashed over whether the state courts were too lenient with youthful offenders.

Member banks' business loans in the New York area turned downward in the week ended on Wednesdays after moving up for three successive weeks, the Federal Reserve Bank here reported yesterday. The decline was small, however, amounting to only $8,000,000.
The Jockey Club's designation of Frank E. Kilroe as general racing secretary and handicapper for thoroughbred racing in New York State was approved yesterday by the State Racing Commission.

A syndicate headed by Harry Klein, operator, has purchased four buildings containing fifty-one apartments and seventeen stores on a triangular plot fronting on Boston Road, Home Street and Jackson Avenue in the Bronx. The addresses of the buildings are 1154-78 Boston Road, 705 Home Street and 1157-59 Jackson Avenue.

Japanese shipments of textiles to the United States are averaging considerably more than the 10,000,000 yards that were shipped monthly in August and September, according to W. Ray Bell, president of the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York, Inc.

HONG KONG, Dec. 9 -- The Hanoi radio said today that Prince Souphanouvong, head of the "Free Laos" movement, had "welcomed" Premier Katay Sahorith's reported readiness to negotiate with the Vietminh- sponsored opposition in Laos.

THE ballplayers always said that Bill McGowan was the best umpire in the American League. No higher praise ever could be given an umpire and perhaps that can serve as McGowan's epitaph. He'd have liked it that way because he was as devoted to his profession as Bill Klem had been. The American League had retired the ailing McGowan earlier in the week on a handsome pension.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Union gave ground slightly today in its attempt to justify the imprisonment of eleven American airmen by Communist China.
MIAMI, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Julius Boros, playing despite an injured right hand, carded an opening-round 66 today for a one-stroke lead in the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament.
CHICAGO, Dec. 9 -- Weakness in corn in the morning was one feature of the grain trade here today, and strength in January soybeans was another.

KANSAS CITY, Kan., Dec. 9 (UP) -- Irving Potash, one of the eleven top Communists imprisoned in 1951, became today the first to be freed from prison. He immediately asked protection against "the same thing that happened to Remington."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 9 -- Iwa Kusumasumantri, Minister of National Defense, said today new attacks by rebel bands on military posts in the South Moluccas were insignificant. He told the Government-sponsored Antara news agency that "the Government completely dominates the situation."

The American Broadcasting Company came into unexpected good fortune yesterday. Just as its television executives were lamenting the cancellation of a one-hour weekly drama series -- a heavy loss of revenue -- another sponsor moved in to continue the show uninterrupted.
Cotton futures were up 6 points to down 1 at the close of trading yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Scott Frost, the winter book favorite for the $100,000 Hambletonian next August, has been named the champion 2-year-old colt of 1954, the United States Trotting Association said today.
The man-made fiber industry's ability to produce is expected to increase steadily into late 1956, according to a study by the Textile Economics Bureau released yesterday.
Prepared for one of the earliest invasions of skiers in the sport's history during the coming week-end, managers of resort areas found themselves anxiously awaiting developments last night.

Two teen-aged youths, who had been held for five months in the City Prison on a rape charge that was based on what the complainant "imagined had happened," were freed yesterday by Judge Harold A Stevens in General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- This is budget week in Washington, the week when the harried "Indians" in the Pentagon scurry about from office to office of the "Big Chiefs" with great piles of papers and columns of statistics.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 9 -Jane Russell will co-star in "The Tall Men," Clark Gable's next picture for Twentieth Century-Fox, barring some unforeseen upset in the new employment contract her representatives are negotiating with Howard Hughes.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Representatives of America's sheepmen approved a plan today which they hope will increase the Nation's wool production by 70,000,000 pounds a year -- and create a demand for it in the market place.
The Composers Group of New York presented its third program of the season late yesterday afternoon at the Mason Hamlin Salon, 3 East Forty-third Street.

As it had done on Wednesday, the stock market tried to rally yesterday and recover early losses. But this time the effort came too late and was not extensive enough. For the first time in six sessions and the second in thirteen, the market closed lower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- On several occasions in the past this department has been privileged to disclose reports on the state of the Union from the celebrated roving comrade, Astigmatoff, to his masters in the Kremlin. For some time American authorities feared a mishap had befallen the Comrade, and that hence a reliable channel to the Soviet rulers of misinformation about United States conditions was closed.

Carmine G. DeSapio, leader of Tammany, told a Democratic victory rally last night that one of the party's biggest assets in New York was the fact that it was more united than at any time in recent years.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations convention gave an ovation today to the leaders of a right-wing bolt from the International Fur and Leather Workers Union. The union was expelled from the C. I. O. five years ago on the charge of Communist domination.

A large subscription has been reported for the performance of "Quadrille" on Monday night at the Coronet Theatre for the benefit of the Youth Consultation Service of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of New York. Co-chairmen of the benefit committee are Mrs. Dayton Beguelin, H. Howard Babcock, Mrs. Roland F. Elliman, Mrs. W. Barton Eddison, Mrs. Edgar W. Garbisch and Mrs. Frederick M. E. Schaefer.

BABYLON, L. I., Dec. 9 -- When a "mystery" witness failed to appear today, the Long Island State Park Commission wound up its departmental trials of three patrolmen accused of accepting courtesy-cards from speeders and failing to issue summonses.

Extension of the alternate-side parking program to 131 square blocks of the lower East Side will go into effect Monday. The newest area to be restricted for three hours every other day will provide an unbroken sector from South Street north to 155th Street where sanitation crews can mechanically clean the streets.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Outlays for new plant and equipment planned for the first quarter of 1955 will run at an annual rate of $26,000,000,000, slightly below the fourth quarter 1954 rate, a Government survey indicates.
Willie Turnesa, a former British and United States amateur golf champion, became president of the Metropolitan Golf Association yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A slight, gray-haired man who was identified as a Communist by a Congressional witness in 1950 disclosed today that he was an undercover informant for the Federal Bureau of Investigation all the time.

Justice Felix C. Benvenga yesterday reserved decision on whether he would issue a temporary injunction forbidding certain New York stores from selling Lionel model trains at less than fair-traded prices.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The November average of basic commodity prices and spot primary market prices for the Nov. 30-Dec. 7 period, follow:
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 9 -- Walter P. Reuther charged today that President Eisenhower had excluded James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, from any real place in the Cabinet.

LAGOS, Nigeria, Dec. 7 -- The most hectic battle of Nigeria's Federal elections is being fought here on the question whether this capital should, like Washington, be a city apart or fall within a particular territory.

There is nothing quite like a new holiday season to stir memories of yesterday's holidays. Of course when one has reached a point from which a number of yesterday's holidays can be looked back upon, the short weeks between Thanksgiving and Christmas may have changed from a period of excited expectation to one of careful calculation involving nice balancing of income versus anticipated outgo.
The 1955 Jeep line of Willys Motors, Inc., went on display yesterday in dealer showrooms in the metropolitan area. The utility and commercial vehicles have been restyled and made more colorful.

GENEVA, Nov. 20 -- In a small factory near Rangoon, forty Burmese textile makers are performing a miracle, the modern miracle of mixing streamlined technique with the long slumbering civilization of the East.

Several thousand colored lights covering this year's giant Christmas tree and Channel Gardens decorations went on last night in ceremonies starting Rockefeller Center's twenty-second annual Christmas display.

Commission house liquidation and hedge selling dropped wool prices yesterday on the New York Cotton Exchange. Only scale-down support was in evidence. Tops ended 2.5 to 4.2 cents a pound lower and grease wool was off 2.5 to 3.4 cents.

A chicken in the pot, the frying pan, or the broiler can make a thrifty dish this week-end. One big chain is selling broilers and fryers at 35 cents a pound, ready to cook; another offers them at 39 cents a pound.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Nine New York City department stores have filed action here to intervene in the case involving a proposed rate increase of $68,850,000 a year for the New York Telephone Company.

The Statue of Liberty on Bedloes Island provided the setting yesterday morning for the presentation of a Torch of Freedom, symbolizing the triumph of the Jews under Judas Maccabaeus over Syrian oppression more than 2,000 years ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The state police patrol on the Thruway will be strengthened by the addition of twenty-two troopers, purchase of fifty-seven more police cars and construction of eleven substations along the express highway.

BALLSTON SPA, N. Y., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Patrick Grennan, 62 years old, of Schenectady, was acquitted today of extortion charges in connection with the state's investigation of gambling in Saratoga County.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The premiere performance of "Lawrence of Arabia" was presented last evening by an all-male cast of thirty-three Ithaca College drama students. It will run for four days.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service has rescinded the controversial order that has sent all detained aliens to Federal prisons since Ellis Island was closed early last month.
RIVERHEAD, L. I., Dec. 9 -- The police said today they had smashed a ring that had forged up to 5,000 automobile licenses and sold them for $5 or $10 to illiterate migrant farm workers.

Edward Dougherty, president of the Standardbred Owners Association, was the only witness yesterday when the light harness racing hearings were resumed here. Eight drivers and Dougherty have been suspended by George P. Monaghan, the state commissioner, over a short drivers' rebellion at the Yonkers Raceway last October.
The City Administration was accused yesterday of using "steamroller tactics" in "ramming through" a bill designed to correct defects in the Multiple Dwelling Law.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 9 (UP) -- The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization voted today to expand its activities in all fields and to double its present budget to more than $20,000,000.

CHICAGO, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Most types of hogs sold at the lowest level in about two years today, in a steady to 50 cents lower market. The top remained unchanged at $19 for one deck of choice 200-pound butchers.

LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Following is the text of a Soviet note to France, broadcast from Moscow, on the Western power's rejection of the Moscow call to a Nov. 29 conference on Europe: (Similar notes went to the United States and Britain.)

The Louisiana State Building Authority sold yesterday $2,500,000 of bonds due from 1959 to 1983 and callable in 1962 to a syndicate headed by Blyth Co., Inc., at a bid of 100.048 for obligations bearing interest of 2 3/4 and 2 per cent, equal to an interest cost of 2.696 per cent.

MOSCOW, Dec. 9 -- In notes to London, Paris and Washington the Soviet Government declared today that ratification of the Western plans for arming the Bonn Republic "would exclude the possibility" of agreement on Germany's reunification.
Domestic steel production last month was 8,074,000 net tons -- the greatest since November last year, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.
Ralph Branca signed a contract yesterday to pitch next year for Minneapolis, the New York Giants' American Association farm club.

MONTREAL, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Young Charlie Hodge scored the first shutout of his brief National Hockey League career tonight as the Montreal Canadiens blanked the Toronto Maple Leafs, 2 -- 0, before 14,013 fans at the Forum.

Jack Lenor Larsen, a designer of textiles, has gone to the spice cabinet for inspiration. One can almost taste the flavors reproduced in his series of fabrics on display at 60 East Fify-eighth Street.
LONDON, Dec. 9 -- "Athletic coexistence" was proclaimed today as the slogan under which Britain would welcome Soviet tennis players at Wimbledon if they wanted to enter the British championships.

BLOOMFIELD, N. J., Dec. 9 -- The twenty-seven-day strike of employes of the General Electric air conditioning division plant ended today as maintenance workers returned to their jobs. By union agreement all 1,200 production workers will return within four days.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- Ichiro Hatoyama realized a lifelong ambition tonight when Japan's Parliament selected him as the nation's Premier.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- Syria proposed today the calling of an international conference to consider the unification of Morocco as a sovereign, independent state.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 9 -- The first reading of the Paris and Saar agreements will be held tomorrow in the Bundesrat, or upper House of Parliament, under the impact of a serious political defeat in Bavaria today for Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

DENVER, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Senator Edwin C. Johnson of Colorado, president of the Class A Western League, said today the circuit had cleared the way for its Omaha member to be taken into the American Association.

GEORGE SZELL, conducting the Philharmonic - Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, opened the program with an unforgettable performance of the "Sinfonietta" of Leos Janacek, played in honor of the 100th anniversary of the Czech master's birth.
ALBANY, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- George Taniguchi, the only American of Japanese descent riding on major tracks in the United States, booted home five winners at Golden Gate Fields today.

LA TUQUE, Que., Dec. 9 (Canadian Press) -- Vernon E. Johnson, president of the Canadian International Paper Company, today announced a $15,000,000 expansion program at La Tuque, which will include what is described as the largest board machine in the world.

ROME, Dec. 9 -- Pope Pius XII was examined today by four doctors. At the end of a three-hour consultation a medical report said his condition had "progressively improved" since he suffered the grave crisis a week ago.

ALBANY, Dec. 9 (AP) -- The New York National Guard disclosed today that Roy M. Cohn had been excused from required drills in 1951 and 1952 to pursue subversives and said his attendance had been "below the minimum requirement."

Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. lashed out at "firetrap landlords" last night in disclosing that inspectors in the last ten days had found stairway sprinkler systems inoperative in fourteen single-exit multiple dwellings.
LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Two upsets marked the opening today of the national hardcourt tennis championships at the La Jolla Beach and Tennis Club.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 9 -- An overwhelming sentiment in favor of rapid ratification of the Paris accords on arming West Germany developed in the debate today in the Consulatative Assembly of the Council of Europe.
PHENIX CITY, Ala., Dec. 9 (AP) -- Two of the reputed bosses of Phenix City were indicted today for the murder of A. L. Patterson, the man who had sworn to drive the racketeers out of the city.

TRENTON, Dec. 9 -- There were strong indications tonight that the Republican-controlled State Legislature would reconvene here on Monday and extend rent control, on a local option basis, for at least six months more.

Events today: Haarlem Philharmonic Society, Waldorf - Astoria, 11 A. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Daniel Wayenberg, pianist, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.; "Andrea Chenier," Metropolitan Opera, 8; and Little Orchestra Society, Thomas Scherman conducting; Mary Davenport, contralto; Martial Singher, baritone; Leopold Simoneau, tenor; Donald Gramm, base; Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Fernando Valenti, harpsicordist, French Institute Auditorium, 22 East Sixtieth Street, 8:45.

THE television show that Bob Hope prepared several weeks ago in London finally reached the National Broadcasting Company airwaves via kinescope on Tuesday night. Anglo-American relations probably will survive.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A new British attempt to wrest international civil aviation supremacy from the United States was forecast today with the announcement that Rolls-Royce Ltd., was developing a revolutionary turbine-propeller aero engine of 4,000 pounds horsepower.

Serving milk to primary school pupils in the Brie Department, as reported in The Times of Dec. 8, is certainly an innovation, and this district was probably chosen for the "experiment" because it is one of France's dairy centers, noted for its cheeses.
DETROIT, Dec, 9. (UP) -- Ted Lindsay's goal with less than two minutes remaining tonight gave the Detroit Red Wings a 3-2 victory over the New York Rangers before 8,395 fans at Olympia.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Representative Dewey Short, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, predicted today that Congress would reject the Administration's modified Universal Military Training plan.
MADRID, Dec. 9 -- Madrid's new British-American Hospital was opened today in a ceremony attended by leading members of the British and United States colonies here and Spanish Government officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Harold E. Stassen, foreign aid chief, said today the expanded economic aid program for Asia being formulated by the Administration should be carried out with a minimum of United States funds.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 9 -- Last night's gathering of Roman Catholics in Plaza Mayo to celebrate the close of the Marian year, provoked President Juan D. Peron into a spirited reply today. He reaffirmed his belief that the clericals were associated with the oligarchy in opposition to the people, and added, the best remedy was popular self-defense.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The United States was urged today to strive for a realistic understanding with Communist China without sacrificing prestige or national interest.

Negotiations for the sale of the seven-story building at 58 Park Avenue, near Thirty-seventh Street, were reported well advanced yesterday. The property is 25 by 105 feet and is being sold by the Library of Intercultural Activities, Inc., which has occupied it since 1952 as a general library for several foreign countries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The International Bank for Reconstruction and Development announced today that India and Pakistan had accepted its proposals for solution of their dispute over use of Indus basin waters as a basis for a resumption of negotiations that broke down last June.

Patrolman Donald S. Goodrich, under suspension since his arraignment last Nov. 10 as a material witness in the Brooklyn traffic courtesy-card inquiry, resigned yesterday and was officially dropped from the rolls.

THERE'S happy poetic balance in N. O. R. C., the International Business Machine Corporation's newest supercalculator endlessly chattering on the fifth floor at 612 West 115th Street. That's the old Parnassus Club Building, a hangout for Columbia University coeds.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 9 -- Jawaharlal Nehru said today he believed Communist China had adopted a policy of avoiding provocative actions that "might invite interference by other powers."

The uncertainty shrouding Japan's future course deepened yesterday when Ichiro Hatoyama won his long-standing feud with former Premier Yoshida and became the new Premier by grace of a precarious coalition between his new Democratic party and the Socialists.
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 9 -- More than 2,000 Navy men have asked for transfer from their West Coast-bound vessels so as to remain on Atlantic duty.

Once more an instrument of the United Nations has gone on the record in the Korean case. The Political and Security Committee of the General Assembly has approved a fifteen-nation resolution that calls for the unification of Korea through a free election under United Nations supervision.

Two plots comprising nearly eight acres in Carle Place, L. I., have been purchased by Kane-Schwartz Enterprises for development with stores. One parcel is at the southeast corner of Glen Cove Road and Westbury Avenue and the other forms an "L" around the northeast corner of the intersection.
