To hear Ella Kazan discuss the status of "Cat on a Tin Roof" the other day in Beverly Hills, Calif., one would think the new Tennessee Williams play was still a waif. By no means reticent, Mr. Kazan, who is to direct the drama about a Southern family domiciled in the Mississippi delta, wasn't exactly communicative anent specific details.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery found himself today in a dangerous, advanced position under heavy fire in the House of Commons. He is being widely attacked for having become involved in a bitter political issue.

BEACON, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- This city is suing the Dutchess County Board of Supervisors and its budget director, Wilbur Creswell, to force the county to apply $1,500,000 in surplus funds against the 1955 county tax levy.
For the first time in forty-five years common stockholders of the Chicago Great Western Railway are going to share in the company's profits.
FOUR abstract artists -- a sculptor and three painters -- co-exist happily in the current show at the Bertha Schaefer Gallery, 32 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Governor-erect Averell Harriman sharply denounced last night "the continuation of our restrictive immigration policy." He termed the policy "morally evil" and a "stupid blunder" that would not gain friends in the battle for democracy.

DUBLIN, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Flood waters surged through almost all the low-lying northern area of Dublin today, keeping thousands in their homes. It was the worst flood in the memory of this Irish capital of more than 500,000 population.
Domestic zinc smelters, with an assist in the form of substantial orders from Government stockpilers, shipped 97,598 tons of zinc last month -- the largest tonnage in at least seven years.

Columbia University students and faculty gave 132 pints of blood to the regional Red Cross blood program Wednesday on the first day of a two-day donation. At the New York Telephone Company office at 101 Willoughby Street, Brooklyn, 125 pints of blood were collected.

Almost ten tons of toys donated by West German toymakers to American orphans were received yesterday by the Army Quartermaster Association for distribution. The acceptance ceremony was held at the Fort Jay Young Men's Christian Association, Governors Island.
TOKYO, Dec. 9 -- The Japanese Parliament picked Ichiro Hatoyama, a conservative politician, tonight to serve as Japan's Premier until national elections are held in the spring.

I have read recent articles reporting the attacks of the Zionist Organization and the American Christian Palestine Committee upon the policies of the United States Government toward the Arab countries. May I be permitted to raise a few questions carefully avoided in the clamor demanding weakness and denouncing strength in this strategic area?
Yogi Berra, the Yankees' catcher, yesterday won the American League's most valuable player award for the second time.
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France successfully resisted today efforts to delay ratification of the Paris agreements.

Advertising setting forth that "automatic living" in the machine age leaves much to be desired is being scheduled by Steinway Sons for its places. Copy refers to the child and his relationship to his push-button environment, it was explained by John H. Steinway, advertising manager.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 9 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard took the witness stand this afternoon in defense against the charge that he murdered his wife Marilyn July 4 in the couple's Bay Village home near here.
Senator Fulbright is apparently the most recent Democratic prophet of doom. He alleges that McCarthy has started a "prairie fire" of fear and hatred which threatens to gut our country.
JOHNSVILLE, Pa., Dec. 9 (UP) -- A four-engined super-Constellation "flying radar laboratory" carrying twenty men crashed and turned over in landing here today.
Memories of their own personal tragedies prompted many of yesterday's 517 donors to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to lend help to others in need.
The four majority members of the Transit Authority denied yesterday that they ever had intended to gag Harris J. Klein, the minority member.

Representatives of the nation's organized scientific community are seeking a radical change in the Administration's basic concept of internal security. They favor switching from a policy "that attempts almost exclusively to minimize our losses to one that places greatlyincreased emphasis on maximizing our gains."
PARIS, Dec. 9 -- Former Prepier Rene Mayer reaffirmed in the National Assembly tonight France's intention to remain in North Africa.
The combining of various materials in one piece of furniture and a generally softened line are repeated in two collections of contemporary pieces that were introduced here this week.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 9 -- Officials of Radio Free Europe attributed today a large role in the dissolution of Poland's Ministry of Security to an exceptionally heavy campaign carried on by their station.

A decline in net income of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation was reported yesterday. For the nine months ended Sept. 30, 1954, the parent concern, head of a world-wide communications and manufacturing concern, cleared $5,555,626, after special charges.
Dock workers in the Port of New York are scheduled to vote today on a new contract between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 9 -- States' rights in the fields of subversive activities control and habeas corpus proceedings were asserted here today at the conference of the National Association of Attorneys General.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Republican National Chairman asserted today that Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's attack on President Eisenhower would be followed by "even greater unity" within the Republican party.
The text of a statement issued yesterday by the Board of Directors of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, entitled "Strengthening the Basis of National Security," follows:
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- A high Defense Department official said today none of the steel workers called before Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigating subcommittee had access to defense secrets.

The right of political refuge goes far back in history -- back to the ancient Hebrews and the ancient Greeks, back to the churches and monasteries of the Middle Ages. In more modern times it has been a source of pride in France, in Britain and in the United States that political exiles might take shelter there and would not be sent back to be dealt with by their enemies.
Supreme Court Justice Benjamin Brenner disclosed yesterday that he had reluctantly certified four elderly sane persons as mentally ill to get for them the custodial care they need.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The Post Office Department today listed for the public these rules to assure speedier delivery of Christmas mail:

So much interest has been aroused by the treatment of the deportees from Ellis Island that I thought you might be interested in this letter which I have had from my personal friends, two very fine intelligent Chinese, whom I have known for many years.
Vince Martinez, a Paterson welterweight, will resume action against Al Andrews of Superior, Wisc., in a scheduled ten-round bout at Madison Square Garden tonight.

GLENWOOD LANDING, L. I., Dec. 9 -- The Glen Players, Inc., an amateur group of actors that has given benefit performances for five years for scholarship funds, presented "Death of a Salesman" tonight in the auditorium of the Glenwood Landing School, the first of three performances this week.
The murder charge against Jerome Lieberman, one of three Brooklyn teen-agers on trial for the torture slaying of an intoxicated man, was dismissed in Kings County Court yesterday.

One of the most appealing aspects of Christmas is the thought, for thousands of fortunate persons, of going home. It is the central idea of many varieties of Christmas greetings and of countless yuletide lyrics and poems. For Christmas is the time for family reunions.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Australia's tennis "twins," Lewis Hoad and Ken Rosewall, said tonight they were interested in a suggestion that they play professional tennis under the banner of the American promoter, Jack Kramer.

The Bigelow-Sanford Carpet Company is studying consolidation of "some or all'" of its woven carpet production under one roof at either Amsterdam, N. Y., or Thompsonville, Conn., James D. Wise, president, announced yesterday.
Hailing from such diverse markets as New York, California, Florida, Honolulu and Italy, Ohrbach's resort fashions, shown yesterday at the Plaza Hotel, represented a lively blend of news.

The three winners of the essay contest, "Why the United States Needs the United Nations?" were announced yesterday by John Golden, chairman, and Mrs. Robert F. Wagner, co-chairman of the contest committee.

There would seem to be room for at least cautious optimism in the latest Government report on employment and unemployment, a report covering early November. What the report says essentially is that the normal seasonal decline in employment and seasonal rise in unemployment usually experienced between October and November were less severe this year than was to be expected.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves increased $129,000,000, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. The principal changes supplying reserves were decreases of $392,000,000 in Treasury deposits with Federal reserve banks $28,000,000 in foreign deposits with Federal reserve banks, and $10,000,000 in other deposits with Federal reserve banks.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The Soviet Union asked the United Nations today to condemn the United States for "acts of aggression" against Communist China. C. D. Jack- ...

The Royal Netherlands Steamship Company and the Venezuelan Line have set up a joint cargo service between Continental Europe and Venezuela. The new service, which will be started by four vessels, will be operated on a weekly basis in each direction on a schedule of a fourteen-day crossing between Europe and Venezuela.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- The State Department wants to be hospitable to foreign visitors but, frankly, it would like fewer next year.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 9 (AP) -- King Jolie broke a long losing spell as he came off a scorching early pace to capture the feature race at Tropical Park today. It was his first success since the last summer.
A medical and legal appeal for the civil rights of the nation's 1,500,000 victims of epileptic seizures was made here yesterday at a meeting of the American League Againt Epilepsy.
Today's new film is "Passion," an R. K. O. adventure of Old California, in Technicolor, co-starring Cornel Wilde and Yvonne DeCarlo, at the Palace.

TRENTON, Dec. 9 -- Democratic Representative Charles R. Howell plans to concede on or before Monday the election of his Republican opponent, Clifford P. Case, as United States Senator from New Jersey.
The Newspaper and Mail Deliverers Union, independent, is to vote Sunday on a "final" proposal for a contract with the Publishers Association of New York City.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Secretary of Labor James P. Mitchell's attack on state right-to-work laws before the Congress of Industrial Organizations in Los Angeles Tuesday, brought a retailer's protest to the White House today.
The merger of Nash-Kelvinator and Hudson operations is being accomplished in less time and at less cost than anticipated, according to George Romney, president of the American Motors Corporation.

The first contract, of $8,177,179, for improving Manhattan's streets to accommodate the extra traffic that will be generated by completion of the third tube of the Lincoln Tunnel in 1957, was awarded yesterday by the Port of New York Authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Eddie LeBaron, one of the best T-formation quarterbacks in the business, signed a contract for 1955 with the Washington Redskins today. He had played for the Calgary team in Canada during the past season.

When a foreign dignitary comes to Washington he gets what may be called, for the purposes of these paragraphs, the works. The works come in different sizes and degrees. A Queen or head of state gets the full treatment, usually including a few days at the White House.

The Tishman Realty Construction Company announced yesterday that it had selected Carson Lundin as the architects for the proposed thirty-four-story office building to be erected on the west side of Fifth Avenue between Fifty-second and Fifty-third Streets.
LONDON, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Dr. Roger Bannister tonight ruled that business came before pleasure. The first man to run a mile in less than 4 minutes announced his retirement from track competition.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 9 -- The Propeller Club of the United States ended the business sessions of its convention here today. Raymond M. Hicks, executive vice president of the United States Lines, was elected president for 1955.
Mayor Wagner praised yesterday the "partnership" between private enterprise and government in solving the city's health and welfare problems.

It was well below freezing early Tuesday and David Smith, 27 years old, sought shelter, as he often had in Pennsylvania Station. About 3:25 A. M. a cleaner heard a show window crash in the John W. Ryan men's clothing shop in the Thirty-third Street concourse inside the station on the subway level.
A wide variety of tastes will be satisfied by sleep sofas now available through decorators from Chesapeake-Siegel-Land, Inc., 932 Broadway.
Stockholders of the Burlington Mills Corporation will be asked to approve a new corporate name that will embrace its subsidiaries and affiliates, according to J. Spencer Love, chairman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 (UP) -- Two of the sharpest critics of the Eisenhower Administration's military buying policies praised Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, today for moves to increase the number of plants turning out military goods.

ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 9 -- The state's farmers served notice today on the Governor-elect, Averell Harriman, that they would oppose vigorously any attempt to treat urban and rural districts alike in distributing state education aid.

An investment banking syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers will place on the market today 300,000 new shares of Monterey Oil Company, a producer of oil and natural gas in California, Texas and other Western states. The stock is priced at $36.50.

Fred Bucci, 21-year old guard from Beverly, Mass., yesterday was elected captain of the 1955 Columbia football team. Bucci, 200-pound junior, succeeds Neil Opdyke. He is the third consecutive guard to captain the Light Blue eleven.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 661,797 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 78,282 cars, or 13.4 per cent more than for the preceding week, which included the Thanksgiving Day holiday, 229 cars, or .03 per cent fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 57,527 cars or 8 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Dec. 9 -- A slight rally allowed the stock market here to close on a steady note today after another session of receding prices. The rally left British funds with net losses of much as 5 shillings (70 cents).

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 1 per cent above sales in the same period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the Board's weekly report on sales by districts follow, in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Manufacturers' and distributors' inventories were $4,400,000,000 lower at the end of October than at the corresponding time last year, the Office of Business Economics of the Department of Commerce reported today.

The price of 'Moly' has gone up for the first time in four years. Climax Molybdenum Company, largest domestic producer of the metal most difficult to pronounce -- it's moe-LIB-den-um -- announced yesterday it is henceforth billing its basic molybdic oxide at $1.25 a pound. That figure is about 10 per cent above that set in December, 1950.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 9 -Government supporters strongly defended the record of the leftnationalist cabinet of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo last night. The defense was voiced during a continuation of the debates on a non-confidence motion offered by the opposition parties.
NEWMARKET, Eng., Dec. 9 (AP) -- The Newmarket bloodstock sales today broke an eight-year-old British record. The total passed the old mark of 926,281 ($2,593,586) with another day to go.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 9 (AP) -- Carl Braun registered 10 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter tonight to pace the New York Knickerbockers to a 98-96 victory over the Philadelphia Warriors in a National Basketball Association game.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 9 -- Twelve more members of President Syngman Rhee's Liberal party in the National Assembly resigned from the party today. At the same time a motion to censure an opposition leader was defeated on the floor of the Legislature.

"The Marriage of Figaro" had its first performance of the season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, and praise be, it had shed the bargain-basement look it wore last season. This cheerful feat was accomplished by the simple process of junking the low-priced, half-way "new" production introduced last year and bringing back the one that had been seeing service since 1940.

LISBON CREEK, Andros, Bahamas, Dec. 9 -- The "greener pastures" theory pushed us into a two-hour boat trip to this tiny village which has more to offer the angler than bonefish. It offers a serenity that has not been affected by the impact of modern civilization.

A new biography of Sir Walter Scott is planned for Jan.5 publication by Harper. It is said to be "the first full-length biography of Scott since the publication of his collected letters and the authentic edition of his journal." The author is Hesketh Pearson, who has written biographies of Oscar Wilde, George Bernard Shaw, Dickens, Disraeli and Whistler.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 9 -- Opponents of the Dixon-Yates power contract won a major victory today.
Roy M. Cohn, former Senate investigator, cited instances last night of what he considered slanted reporting of exposures of communism.
Alan Ameche, Wisconsin's stellar fullback, received the Heisman Memorial Trophy last night at the Downtown A. C.
The athletic ties binding the eight Ivy Group colleges were tightened yesterday.

The world's largest communications enterprise, the $12,000,000,000 American Telephone and Telegraph Company, reported yesterday that this country has more than half of the 89,000,000 telephones in operation throughout the world.

PHENIX CITY, Ala., Dec. 10 (UP) -- A blue ribbon grand jury that has returned 741 true bills in a vice clean-up ended its four-month campaign today with a report which said this one-time gambling and prostitution center was no longer a "modern Sodom and Gomorrah."

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The agreements to arm West Germany were approved by the Foreign Affairs Committee of the National Assembly today. This was done by a nominal majority of one which actually was a minority of the committee because eleven members declined to vote.
BOSTON, Dec. 10 -- Military transport systems were scored today as competitors of private commercial carriers.

The former foundry building occupied by J. P. Keegan Son at 183-187 Christie Street, in Newark, N. J., has been leased by Service Porcelain Enamel, Inc. Flusser for Factories was the broker. The lessee will use the property for the processing of porcelain enameling for the building and sign trades.

ALBANY, Dec. 10 -- Supreme Court Justice Isadore Bookstein today granted New York City permission to intervene in the action being brought by the New York Telephone Company in its effort to obtain $68,500,000 rate increase.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- How far the North Atlantic alliance shall be committed to atomic warfare is expected to be a major issue at the meeting next week of the foreign ministers of the fourteen member nations.

Walter Reuther is indeed to be congratulated for his anti-featherbedding, progressive approach to "automation.'' Your editorial of Dec. 7 was therefore a well-deserved tribute to a responsible labor leader. That labor as well as the country at large will obtain a substantial, net gain is clear.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Diplomats here think the latest Soviet note to the Western powers will hasten rather than delay ratification of the Paris agreements in West Germany and France.

The General Assembly of the United Nations voted overwhelmingly yesterday to condemn Communist China for its imprisonment of the American airmen. The condemnation is richly deserved. What action the Chinese Communists will take, in response to the demand for the release of those prisoners, remains to be seen.

BOSTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Massachusetts Supreme Court today took under advisement a petition of Puget Sound Power and Light Company to reverse a Superior Court order to officers of the company to make available its stockholder lists to a stockholders' committee.
Arthur H. Dean said yesterday that his name was included erroneously among the signatures attached to a statement calling for a realistic understanding between the United States and Communist China.
A thousand eager children poured into Gimbels yesterday morning to participate in the fourth annual Christmas shopping tour arranged by the Young Men's Board of Trade.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- The Cutty Sark, famous British clipper that used to sail half way around the world with cargoes from the Far East, made her last voyage today.

Latest studies have provided the most suggestive evidence so far that the anti-polio vaccine will end the crippling form of the disease as soon as the susceptible age groups are properly vaccinated. The immunity agent is prepared with killed viruses of the three types of polio.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 -- Fifty debaters from twenty-four colleges and universities began a two-day debate tournament at the University of Pittsburgh today. The subject was: Should the United States Recognize the Communist Government of China?
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The General Assembly tonight rejected a resolution seeking new negotiations between the Netherlands and Indonesia over the disputed territory of West New Guinea.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Movements were mixed on the Stock Exchange here today. Government funds continued to slide while industrials were steadier, though most prices again closed lower.

PINEHURST, N. C., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Dick Chapman and Harold Calloway, a pro, both of Pinehurst, shot a 68 today to win the pro - amateur low - gross tournament as the twentieth championship of the Southern Senior Golf Association opened.

After showing selected strength for much of the session yesterday, stocks dragged in late dealings. Closing prices as measured by The New York Times' composite index of fifty representative issues were lower for the second consecutive session.
BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- Die Neue Zeitung, the newspaper that for nine years has carried the official United States view to the German people, will close down next month.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 (AP) -All parties in the West German Bundestag (lower house) sharply criticized today delays in paying restitution to individuals persecuted by the Nazis.
Prices of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange moved 2 points higher to 7 points lower yesterday.

The Department of Justice has acted wisely in revoking the order that resulted in the imprisonment of aliens who were detained pending final disposition of their cases. The order should never have been issued, in the first place. Even though those involved were considered by immigration agents "likely to abscond" or to act in a way "adverse to the national security" they had not been convicted of any crime.
Prospects for a three-day Christmas holiday on Wall Street are dim right now, but there is a faint glimmer of hope.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 10 -An inter-racial church conference, which supported the Government's policy of apartheid segregation of races, resolved today to ask the Government to spend $28,000,000 more annually for social, economic, educational and industrial development of South Africa's 8,600,000 Negroes and 1,100,000 persons of mixed blood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- November's retail sales totaled $14,600,000,000, according to the "flash" report of the Department of Commerce released today. The figure is 2 per cent above those of last October and of November, 1953.

CHICAGO, Dee. 10 -- Directors of Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago today increased the bank's surplus account to $125,000,000 by transferring $25,000,000 into surplus from undivided profits. Capital stock remained unchanged at $75,000,000.

Explorations of "strange worlds" will be featured by Cinema 16 on Tuesday and Wednesday at 9:30 P. M. in the Central Needle Trades High School Auditorium and on Sunday mornings, Dec. 12 and 19, at the Beekman Theatre.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- House Speaker Joseph W. Martin Jr. said today he did not expect Senator McCarthy or his followers to start a third party, but he predicted the Democrats would suffer most if they did.

IS one good picture worth a thousand words? That theory is frequently bandied about by pundits of the graphic arts. And the obvious fact that one picture often has many more lines in it than there are in a thousand words is only part of the argument. You can put the matter to a test of sorts by comparing two of this morning's books.

TOKYO, Saturday, Dec. 11 -Mamoru Shigemitsu, Japan's new Foreign Minister, gave strong assurances today that the conservative Government that took power yesterday will continue close cooperation with the free nations, especially the United States.

A bandit held up two young women employes of the Personal Finance Company's Greenpoint office in Brooklyn yesterday. He added insult to injury by taking their Christmas shopping money and a sandwich belonging to one of the girls along with the company's $1,165.
Wagner College's quintet, in front all the way, defeated Brooklyn College, 86 -- 68, on the Kingsmen's court last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that an Immigration Service inquiry officer had ordered Cedric H. Belfrage, a New York writer, deported "on grounds of Communist party membership."

Improvements in court procedure to obtain speedier trials, quicker adjudications and a reduction in expense to the litigants have become imperative in New York State. Only an aroused public can do something about this.

OMAHA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Bill Bergesch, general manager of the Omaha Cardinals made "the happiest announcement of my life today." He reported the transfer of the Columbus American Association baseball franchise to Omaha.

NASSAU, The Bahamas, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Erwin Goldschmidt of New York today piloted the red Ferrari that won last month's Pan-American road race in Mexico. He was clocked at a top speed of 150.8 miles an hour here on the straightaway at Windsor Air Field.

Vince Martinez battered Al Andrews of Superior, Wis., into defeat at Madison Square Garden last night. The Paterson fighter did everything except floor his foe as he gained the unanimous decision in the feature bout of ten rounds.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- This country's shipbuilding picture was called brighter now than six months ago by Representative Thor C. Tollefson, Republican of Washington, today.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 10 (UP) -- P. Studioso's Midyear, a 64-to-1 item in the wagering, dashed through the stretch at Tropical Park today to score a half-length triumph in the Propeller Club purse.

The New York commodity exchanges were quiet yesterday. Limited trading generally involved evening of holdings for the week-end. Only potatoes and rubber had good volume and hides and coffee registered fair activity.

In accordance with the wish of the President, the nation's security-risk program is to be examined and, if necessary, corrected. A statement on the subject by the Board of Directors of the American Association for the Advancement of Science comes at the right time because it analyzes the current method of dealing with possible security risks and makes constructive recommendations.
OTTAWA, Dec. 10 -Canada has urged Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India to continue his efforts to obtain the release of the United States airmen held by Communist China as spies.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 10 (UP) -- The Wisconsin Republican party's executive committee today commended both Senator Joseph R. McCarthy and President Eisenhower for fighting communism, but deplored personality clashes as a threat to party unity.
ERIE, Pa., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Two more men, one a Democratic leader named in testimony as "the real boss of the Erie Police Department,'' were found guilty of bribery charges today.

Television kept two children quiet yesterday morning while a smooth-talking burglar who told them he was a friend of their father started to ransack their apartment at 40-16 Vernon Boulevard, Long Island City.

Potted palms, hanging baskets of ferns, floor-to-ceiling mirrors framed in ornately carved mahogany give Johnny Nicholson's new restaurant at 146 East Fifty-seventh Street, a pleasing Victorian quality.
CHICAGO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today.
ARMONK, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- The Nyctea scandiaca, or snowy owl, has apparently begun an off-beat invasion of our Northern states from the Arctic, the National Audubon Society announced today.

Chicken roasted with herbs was featured at a press luncheon earlier this week at the new Nicholson restaurant. The lunch was given by John Wagner Sons, Philadelphia spice packer and, according to the menu, "purveyor to epicures since 1847."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Average primary market prices declined 0.2 per cent to 109.3 per cent of the 1947-49 level in the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

Events today: "Die Meistersinger," Metropolitan Opera, 1:30 P. M.; Boston Symphony Orchestra, Charles Munch conducting, Carnegie Hall, 2:30; Richard Davies, baritone, Towa Hall, 2:30; Little Concert Series, Associated American Artists Galleries, 711 Fifth Avenue, 3; "Manon," Metropolitan Opera, 8; and Philharmonic-Symphony, George Szell conducting, Gary Graffman, pianist, Carnegia Hall, 8:45.
In 1951, when Thomas Scherman introduced the seldom-heard "L'Enfance du Christ" by Berlioz to Little Orchestra Society listeners, little did he know that he was starting a Christmas-time tradition.
The dean of the Columbia University Faculty of Library Service since 1943 announced his resignation from that post yesterday.

The average market price of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined in November to $100.13 for each $100 of par value, the Exchange reported yesterday. This was the lowest month-end average since $100 on May 31 and compared with $100.39 on Oct. 31.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower and former President Truman joined today in paying tribute to General of the Army George C. Marshall. The former Army Chief of Staff was honored here tonight by the American Veterans of World War II and Korea.

May I express the appreciation of the Medical Society of the County of New York, the physicians of Manhattan, for the lucid and realistic editorial in The New York Times of Dec. 2 entitled "Parking for Doctors."

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Membership in the Methodist Church in the United States and its possessions now stands at 9,223,152, a net gain of 71,628 over the 9,151,524 reported a year ago. The official 1954 figures were announced by the Rev. Albert C. Hoover of Chicago, church statistician.
A check for $10,000 from Mr. and Mrs. Alfred P. Sloan Jr. to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday sent the total soaring to $117,003.35 on the sixth day of the forty-third annual appeal.

THREE-MILE HARBOR, L. I., Dec. 10 -- The Long Island wildfowlers who have been bemoaning the mild weather and the resulting low return in ducks have added a few layers of clothing and are burning up a lot of ammunition.
The results of studies on major traffic - improvement proposals will be made public about Jan. 15.
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Representative Dewey Short, a staunch opponent of Universal Military Training in the past, said today the Administration's new modified plan was the "best thing I've seen so far." He added that he might support it.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 -- The cornerstones for the new $90,000,000 suspension bridge across the Delaware River were sealed today in a two-state ceremony.

WINNIPEG, Alta., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Terry Hind, manager of the Winnipeg Maroons, the Western Senior Hockey League finalists last season, said today his club had been nominated to fulfill a Russian request that a Canadian hockey club play an exhibition series in Russia.

The explosive question of football television again is threatening to split asunder the National Collegiate Athletic Association. That became evident yesterday when two leading components of the N. C. A. A. took firm opposing stands on television control.
BENTWATERS, England, Dec. 10 -- The United States is supplying its crack atomic air unit here with the newest-type jet fighter-bomber, the Republic F-84F Thunderstreak.

Headed by a twin bill at Madison Square Garden and a game at Columbia, where the Lions will open their home season against C. C. N. Y., tonight's program will be a busy one for metropolitan quintets. In all, nine games involving local squads are listed.

In a few short years Larry Rivers, whose new paintings are at the de Nagy Gallery, 206 East Fifty-third Street; has moved from a vital, if sometimes reckless, semi-abstract style to a delicate, searching realism.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Justice Department said today that twenty-six detained aliens in the New York area were being held in Federal detention houses and eleven were quartered in hotels.

HONG KONG, Saturday, Dec. 11 -- The Burmese Premier, U Nu, addressed a public appeal to Chinese Communists in Peiping last night for an "understanding" between Red China and the United States as a means of relaxing tension in the Far East.
The affiliated agencies of the United Jewish Appeal will require $119,521,275 next year to meet the needs of 472,000 Jewish men women and children in twenty-four countries, particularly in Israel.

Two members of the Park Avenue Christian Church, at Eighty-fifth Street, will attend the dedication in Haiti today of a hospital in honor of Dr. Albert Schweitzer, famed medical missionary, musician and philosopher.

ROCKS AND SEA" is the general title of the exhibition of recent paintings by Vaclav Vytlacil at the Feigl Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue. The individual pictures are merely numbered and need no titles, for they constitute a music-like theme and variations.

THERE were changes in two of the three central roles in last night's repetition of "Andrea Chenier" at the Metropolitan Opera House. Herva Nelli took over the role of Maddalena, and Ettore Bastianini that of Gerard.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 10 -- "Mister Roberts" will go back before the cameras at Warner Brothers for filming of added sequences that are expected to take three days to complete.
Thousands of homeward-bound travelers were delayed at the height of the rush hour last night by two subway tie-ups.
The cooperative efforts of three blood banks have given a good chance for life to a desperately ill truck driver at Bellevue Hospital.

The Congress of Industrial Organizations deserves commendation for drafting what might be called a "fair union welfare fund practice code" and for appointing a standing committee, under the Chairmanship of President Jacob S. Potofsky of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers, to police it.

A talking mynah bird that likes to whistle at women was sought by the police yesterday. Julius Bronson, the owner, told them that Joe, a female mynah he valued at $1,000, had been stolen Wednesday from his pet shop at 149 Fort George Avenue.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., Dec. 10 -- Herbert Brownell Jr. tonight urged cooperation between the Federal and state Governments in the enforcement of anti-trust laws and the control of narcotics addiction.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 5 -- The West German Government has provided restitution for public employes who had got into trouble for protesting against crimes of the Hitler regime.

Once a household necessity, the candle today is a delightful luxury. Although its primary function of giving light has passed, the symbolism has intensified. Today candles are prized for their romantic and religious connotations and their decorative appeal.
Two new tankers have been added to the fleet of Stavros G. Livanos this week, raising it above the 600,000-deadweight-ton mark. His fleet now comprises forty-one tankers and dry cargo ships.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The present draft of a pending report on a Senate investigation into the housing scandal has divided the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

AUBURNDALE, Fla., Dec. 10 (AP) -- Gen. James A. Van Fleet today informed Senator Joseph R. McCarthy that he no longer could support him after his "bitter personal attack against" President Eisenhower.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Tariff Commission will include a statement of findings as to the proper tariff classification of hardboard in a report to the Senate Finance Committee in February, Edgar B. Brossard, Commission chairman, announced today.
The runner-up a year ago, Henry R. (Red) Sanders yesterday was named the football coach of the year.
TORONTO, Dec. 10 -- The Toronto Stock Exchange today delisted shares of Pontiac Petroleums, Ltd., a Calgary-based oil producer with interests in Alberta, Israel and Teaxs.

ROME, Dec. 10 -- The Pope sat at a desk in his study today and worked for nearly two hours after having spent a "comfortable night." His improvement is considered to be so satisfactory that today or the first time Vatican circles close to the Pontiff said he had entered the "preconvalescence period."
Neglected teeth can have a profound effect on health, even to shortening life, it was reported here yesterday at the Greater New York Dental Meeting.

PARIS, Dec. 10 -- The least necessary crisis within the Allied world comes to a head next week when the United Nations debate on Cyprus finally commences. The lovely island home of the Goddess Aphrodite has now become an emotional cockpit capable of destroying democratic harmony in the eastern Mediterranean.

The question of whether Fordham will continue football in 1955 is "under advisement," a university spokesman admitted yesterday. The ultimate decision rests with the Rev. Laurence J. McGinley, S. J., president of Fordham.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 10 -- The Paris agreements on West German arming and sovereignty passed their first reading in the Bundesrat today with a substantial majority. But the upper house of the West German Parliament decided unanimously to defer action on the Saar settlement with France until the Government had obtained satisfactory clarifications of the accord.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- High Government officials are continuing to watch the booming stock market closely, but the extent of their concern appears to have been exaggerated in some Wall Street quarters.

MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- Denying Western assertions that Soviet artists are restricted in their activity, Dmitri Shostakovich, the composer, declared recently that the Soviet system "provides the conditions most favorable to artistic creation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 10 -- The Brazilian Government has defeated a move that would have intensified the growing currency inflation here but still is not yet in position to halt the inflationary spiral.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -Paul F. Mickey, vice president of the American Watch Manufacturers Association, asserted here that Representative Celler's statement "is another instance of his obvious prejudice on the problem of maintaining a jeweled-watch industry in the United States."

The five-story apartment house accommodating twenty families at 170 West Eighty-ninth Street has been sold by Florence G. Walsh to the Bloom-Grossman Associates for investment. The property occupies a plot 50 by 100 feet and is assessed at $64,000.

Hospital officials were asked yesterday to join with health authorities in combating carbon-monoxide poisoning from defective gas appliances. Thus far this year the toll is 363 persons, of whom 100 have died.

Jean Ritchie, author of "The Swapping Song Book," has written a volume of reminiscences entitled "Singing Family of the Cumberlands." It is a story of the author's family -- her parents and thirteen brothers and sisters -- growing up in an isolated part of the Kentucky mountains.

BERN, Switzerland, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Representative Emanuel Celler, Democrat of New York, told Swiss watchmakers here today that the Democratic majority in the new Congress would try to persuade or compel President Eisenhower to cancel the recent increase in watch tariffs.

THURMONT, Md., Dec. 10 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower today motored to Camp David, the Presidential retreat in the near-by Catoctin Mountains, for an over-night stay and a visit tomorrow to their Gettysburg, Pa., farm.

LONDON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- Dr. Roger Bannister, who gave the world of sport one of its electrifying moments last May 6 when he cracked the four-minute mile barrier, said today he might reconsider his decision to retire. But only after a two-year tour of duty as house surgeon in St. Mary's Hospital, he added.
A group of municipal officials, urged yesterday that state law be changed to permit them to make certain purchases without competitive public bidding.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 10 -- Officials of Jersey City and Seton Hall University today signed a $275,000 lease whereby the university takes part of the Jersey City Medical Center for a medical and dental college.

DETROIT, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Ward's Reports, Inc., said today that production of the six-millionth motor vehicle of 1954 and continuance of heavy overtime operations highlighted this week in the United States auto industry.
Wanted: Advertising agency interested in the recruiting account of the United States Air Force Reserve.
Playing to red-checked, foot-stamping audiences, some of the most popular shows in town during the next two weeks will be those in the windows of the stores.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -- The Navy today identified the thirty-three warships, including two cruisers and sixteen destroyers, that it is shifting from the East to the West Coast.
PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 11 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France won the French National Assembly's approval of his North African policy early this morning by a vote of 294 to 265.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 -- A near capacity crowd of almost 3,700 turned out tonight to hear the world premiere of the Symphony No. 3 by Nikolai Lopatnikoff, presented by the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra.

Tom Courtney of Fordham, anchor man on the Rams world-record two-mile relay team last spring, captured the 600-yard handicap race from scratch last night in a Metropolitan Association Amateur Athletic Union development track meet.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- Offerings increased on small bulges in all grains today, and there was a generally heavy tone, due in part to week-end evening up. There was not much aggressive buying at any time.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Paul M. Butler, Democratic National Chairman-elect, today expanded his criticism of President Eisenhower.

George John Warren of Buffalo, presiding judge at Yonkers Raceway during the fall meeting, testified at the harness racing hearings yesterday that three separate post times were set for the second race on Oct. 30.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Following is the text of a statement today by Paul M. Butler, Chairman-elect of the Democratic National Committee:

Most of us have learned to live and to achieve happiness in this world of fears and insecurities. But, then, we are the fortunate ones who have known the warmth of secure homes and loving parents. Others are not so fortunate, and when they are children it becomes a matter of concern to all of us.
The Dodgers yesterday signed their "hospital battery," Karl Spooner and Roy Campanella, to 1955 contracts.
The Maritime Administration announced yesterday that it had given permission for the transfer of the veteran American liner Aleutian to Liberian colors.
MIAMI, Dec. 10 (AP) -- Bo Wininger of Oklahoma City putted brilliantly today and gained the lead in the Miami open golf tournament.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 -- Winners of the 1954 Nobel prizes received them today from King Gustaf Adolf.
STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 10 -A renewal of the conflict over the status of the Saar appeared in moves introduced today by West German representatives in the Council of Europe.
A 41-year-old convict who has spent twenty-three years behind prison bars won his freedom yesterday after a thirteen-year legal fight.

TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras, Dec. 10 (UP) -- A fifty-nine-man Council of State, representing the country s three political parties, was installed today and pledged its support to the de facto Government of Chief of State Julio Lozano Diaz.

The principles of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights were lauded yesterday by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt in a City Hall ceremony commemorating the sixth anniversary of Human Rights Day. Mrs. Roosevelt was the first chairman of the United Nations Human Rights Commission.

SOMERVILLE, N. J., Dec. 10 -- Charles E. Goudreau, former Mayor of North Plainfield, received suspended prison terms and fines totaling $2,000 and was placed on probation for five years today for false swearing in grand jury testimony. He automatically was disfranchised for two years.
WINNIPEG, Dec. 10 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Wheat Board today increased its selling price on top grades of milling wheat a full cent a bushel, the first such increase in more than a year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission stayed today the effective date of its order authorizing the abandonment of the Christopher Street ferry across the Hudson from Hoboken, N. J., to Manhattan.

The four-story factory at 21-29 Belvedere Street in Brooklyn has been sold by R. A. Cohen to the 20 Starr Corporation. The property was leased by the new owner to the Acme Lantern Company for the manufacture and assembly of lighting fixtures and equipment.
The first increases since June, 1953, in prices of nickel-bearing stainless steels were announced yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation.
Nearly two-thirds of the fund sought for 1955 by the Young Men's Christian Association of New York remains to be raised, it was announced yesterday at the first report meeting of the campaign.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard repeatedly denied today that it was he who had killed his wife, Marilyn.

BUFFALO, Dec. 10 (AP) -- E. E. Willkie, president of the National Canners Association, said today that the food canning industry had increased its productivity by about 50 per cent in the last ten years with "direct benefits to the consumers."
NEWMARKET, England, Dec. 10 (AP) -- American bloodstock buyers paid $177,870 for three fillies today at the final session of Newmarket's December blood-stock sales.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Association of State Health Officers voted today to ask access to classifiedatomic energy information to prevent health hazards.
PHILLIPSBURG, N. J., Dec. 10 -- The Ingersoll-Rand Company today was accused of violation of contract by the United Electrical Workers Union, Local 451.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 10 (UP) -Duquesne registered a 67-45 victory over Fordham tonight in the second round of the fourth annual Steel Bowl basketball tournament. Si Green of the victors scored 26 points to lead both teams.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- A motor vehicle that offers the ultimate in parking convenience was patented this week. It is a folding motor scooter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- Gov. Frank G. Clement of Tennessee lashed out today at "Nixon, Dixon and Yates" as representing "a lowering of the American standard of public morals." The Democratic Governor asserted that there was a "moral similarity" between the methods employed in the Dixon-Yates private power contract and the technique used by Vice President Richard M. Nixon in the recent Congressional campaign.

Lumber product on in the week ended last Saturday was 12.5 per cent above the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times from regional associations. Shipments were up 12.7 per cent and orders 15.7 per cent.

Another active week of securities underwriting faces Wall Street. Major bond issues scheduled for distribution total more than $130,000,000, with corporate enterprises and both local and foreign governments figuring in the borrowings.

Somerset Maugham ended his recent serialized version of "Ten Novels and Their Authors" in The Sunday Times of London with an imaginary party. Mr. Maugham's book describes ten famous books and their creators. There are those who will disagree with Mr. Maugham's restive remarks on Emily Bronte and Charles Dickens, but Mr. Maugham has always been cheerful about people who disagree with him.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 10 -- Premier Ali Sastroamidjojo made a spirited defense of his Government in a two-and-a-half-hour speech in Parliament here tonight.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 10 -- The Fifth District Coast Guard has proposed a plan for the registration of all motor boats in the United States on an annual fee basis and a revolutionary numbering system for all power boats.

Two thousand persons attended the eighth annual Christmas party of Cardinal Spellman yesterday afternoon for the benefit of the children of the New York Foundling Hospital, 175 East Sixty-eighth Street.
Nine firemen were overcome by smoke, and twenty families were made homeless early today when a four-alarm fire swept through two five-story Harlem tenements.
The nation's chain and mail-order stores are rapidly overtaking the high sales levels of 1953, a survey by The New York Times reveals.
Warner Bros. Pictures, Inc., and subsidiaries cleared a consolidated net profit of $3, 976,000 for the year ended on Aug. 31, it was announced yesterday.

DAVID ZELAG GOODMAN, a new playwright, has written an odd but interesting drama called "High Named Today," which was put on at the Theatre de Lys last evening. It is odd because it requires a mother to will the death of a son whom she adores.
Dr. Millicent C. McIntosh, president of Barnard College, suggested to a group of scientists last night that they take time now and then to enjoy a little poetry, a play or a visit to a museum.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Navy is planning a break in the carrier-a-year shipbuilding program it started four years ago with the 59,650-ton Forrestal.
BERLIN, Dec. 10 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to take part in a global effort to study the physics of the earth, its atmosphere and the space through which it is flying.
Intensive inspections of rooming houses and multiple dwellings within the last few weeks have uncovered many sprinkler systems without water connections.
LONDON, Dec. 10 -- Three hundred workers in the machine shop of the Staveley Iron and Chemical Company in Staveley, Derbyshire, ended tonight their year-long boycott of a workmate.
Dock workers in the Port of New York rejected yesterday an agreement negotiated Thanksgiving Day between the International Longshoremen's Association and the New York Shipping Association.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (UP) -A former Army officer misused at least $170,000 to build a seven-hole golf course and riding stables at an isolated desert post in Utah, the General Accounting Office reported today.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations charged today that United States foreign aid was being nullified by the eagerness of "management - minded diplomats to please cartel-minded management in Europe."
TRENTON, Dec. 10 -- George E. Brunner, Democratic state chairman, charged here today there was evidence of "gross over-registration'' of voters in at least thirty New Jersey communities.
This is the season of love thy neighbor, so it may be in order to comment upon the dismal dispatch in The Times of Nov. 27 on the reported rise of German anti-Semitism.

The election of Hugh A. Davies of Chicago, director general of Latin-American operations of the International Harvester Company, as chairman of the United States Inter-American Council has been announced.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Philadelphia Phillies today purchased Connie Mack Stadium, their home park, from the Kansas City Athletics of the American League.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 10 -- A resolution condemning "the trial and conviction of prisoners of war illegally detained" after the date fixed by the Korean armistice, was adopted today by the General Assembly.

Reginald Owen, who recently portrayed the starring role of the wealthy California politician in "Open House," the Victor Young-Francis Swann farce, at the Hilltop Theatre in Baltimore, may repeat the acting assignment on Broadway this season.

CHICAGO, Dec. 10 -- The Executive Council of the American Federation of Labor will receive Wednesday a report on progress by the Amalgamated Meat Cutters and Butcher Workmen toward a merger with the left-wing International Fur and Leather Workers Union, independent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- President Eisenhower today received the Eisenhower Presidential medal.
PARIS, Dec. 6 -- Neckwear, jabots, collars and kerchiefs inspire fabulous pieces in the Christmas exhibits of big-name jewelers, here.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 10 -- Dr. Luther Evans, director general of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization, announced tonight he had taken direct action on seven of the eight employes whose dismissal the United States sought on loyalty grounds.
The theft on Nov. 1 of six pieces of jewelry worth $63,300 was disclosed belatedly yesterday by the police.
Conversations are in progress toward the merger of two and possibly three drug chains, it was confirmed yesterday.

" Civic leader" is a label so freely and loosely used that it has become somewhat debased. Yet there is no finer term of tribute to be applied to Richard S. Childs, who is being given the La Guardia Memorial Award today at a luncheon of the La Guardia Memorial Association.
MOSCOW, Dec. 10 -- A public appeal to France against the arming of West Germany was made here tonight on the tenth anniversary the signing of the French-Soviet mutual aid treaty.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The United States has slowly permitted Chinese students in this country to return to their homes on the China mainland. However, about thirty-five Chinese have so far not received permits because skills they have acquired in this country might be useful to the Communist Government now ruling their homeland.

Alexander Smith, Inc., manufacturer of carpets and other textile products, incurred a net loss of $1,926,797 on net sales of $27,118,455 in the nine months ended Sept. 30, the company reported yesterday.

Norman Thomas, the Socialist leader whose seventieth birthday was recently celebrated, received last night the 1954 award of the New York chapter of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Community Church, 40 East Thirty-fifth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today forecast this season's crop of citrus fruits at 202,195,000 boxes, compared with 195,430,000 last season and the ten-year (1943-52) average of 176,401,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 -- The Soviet Union's latest warning against West German armament will be discussed in conferences
The defense rested yesterday after producing one witness on behalf of one of two Brooklyn teen-agers on trial for the torture slaying of an intoxicated man.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 10 (AP) -- The Treasury said today that sales of series "E" and "H" savings bonds in November amounted to $384,000,000, 13 per cent more than a year before. The sales were the best for a November since 1945.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman plans to name a special commission to study and report on a long-range program for an equitable fiscal relationship between the state and New York City.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 10 (AP) -- West Germany made some amends to Carl von Ossietzky, Nobel Peace Prize winner who died in 1938 without ever having received a cent from his $39,303 award made two years earlier. Hitler's hate, Gestapo thievery and a lawyer all deprived him of the money.
NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Dec. 11 -- A respected name was added to the Navy list today as the greatest warship ever built in this country, and the largest man-of-war afloat, was christened Forrestal.

It has been said before, but it bears repeating, that winter comes on its own schedule, not that of the calendar. Anyone in the Northeast will vouch for that this year, and the Weather Bureau people who have insisted that a few warm seasons don't necessarily constitute a trend are probably smiling to themselves.

SUSTAINED demand for both hard and soft lines reflects general confidence in the business outlook. Manufacturers and distributors have raised their sights considerably beyond the year-end and have shown a willingness to prepare for selling seasons well into 1955.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 11 -- Leaders of the Turkish minority in Cyprus left Ankara today en route the United Nations. They will oppose Greece's demand for a plebiscite.
MORE than 400 photographs have been selected and the date of Jan. 26 has been set for the "Family of Man" exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art, according to announcement by the museum last week.

A NEW type of photographic exhibition plan was announced last week by Joseph Gans, art director of Creative Galleries, 108 West Fifty-sixth Street. Photographers are invited to submit six mounted prints, in black-and-white or color, which if selected will be included in three gallery group shows, two prints in each show, during a period of six months.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- After a year of domestic and international discussions and frustrations, President Eisenhower's "atoms-for-peace" plan is beginning to take organizational form.
Skippy, a small cross-bred terrier, received a medal and certificate of merit from the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 10 -- The West Coast has become the training ground for German airline pilots and flight engineers preparing to fly West Coast-built airliners for the revived Deutsche Lufthansa, West Germany's commercial airline.
NORFOLK, Dec. 11 -- Three locomotives that puff away day and night and never go anywhere keep the Oceana Naval Air Station and its hundreds of jets in full operation.

MADRID, Dec. 1 -- The civil Governor of Pamplona Province, who apparently interfered with the ancient "soverign" rights of the people of Navarra, has just been removed by Generalissimo Francisco Franco. This decision was made after months during which relations between the provincial authorities and the Governor reached the breaking point.

TODAY a rather unique open house is being held across the river in Wood-Ridge, N. J., for massive quantities of poinsettias, in full array, will be on display at the greenhouses of Madsen and Christensen, wholesale growers, 304 Hackensack Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Senator John C. Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, said today that President Eisenhower and military leaders must throw their full weight behind Universal Military Training if they wanted Congress to pass it next year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--Senator William F. Knowland of California called today for Republican unity behind the Eisenhower legislative program.

IN all discussions of the so-called "Death of the Novel," one thing that seems to be over-looked is the difficulty of writing a modern novel. In the eighteenth century, of course, it was comparatively easy. Unless you were an absolute Munchausen anything you said could scarcely be contradicted.
A "post-high school institution" for mediocre students is advocated by Dr. Edwin S. Burdell, president of Cooper Union in his sixteenth annual report to the trustees.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- Business activity in California declined less than 1 per cent during October, as measured by the Wells Fargo Bank's seasonably adjusted index. The level of business activity in October was 1.2 per cent above that of the same month in 1953 and 4 per cent below the peak in mid-1953.

MOTORING in Central America is fast becoming a pleasant way to spend a vacation. It is rapidly losing the qualities of rugged pioneering by which it has been characterized in the past, although it is not yet possible to drive all the way to South America, nor even as far as Guatemala -- the Pan-American Highway is still largely a dream.

A lecture on art for those who find unusual modern forms in painting difficult to understand, or implausible, will be held on Tuesday at 6:15 P. M. at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and Forty-second Street.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Pakistan suggested today that the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development "take over" France's "enormous financial interest" in Morocco.
ONE frosty autumn afternoon about fourteen years ago the Kingsbridge Trojan semi-professional football team was having a rough afternoon with an opposing eleven in Van Cortland Stadium in the Bronx.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Gene Rossides, whose mastery of the "bootleg play" made him a famous football back of the Nineteen Forties, is now, according to himself, in "bootleg' diplomacy in behalf of the Greek cause in Cyprus.

WHITE PLAINS, N Y., De. 11 -- Demands by some public libraries in Westchester for creation of a county library service corporation under the state Education Law will be carried to the floor of the Board of Supervisors on Monday.
ALBANY, Calif., Dec. 11 -- Determine, the little gray colt that never quits, came from far back today to win the Golden Gate Handicap and the money-winning championship of the United States for 1954.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- Following is the text of President Eisenhower's letter to Joseph M. Dodge appointing him head of a Cabinet-level Council on Foreign Economic Policy:

LESSER men have given up the search by now, but historical novelist Don Tracy is still trying to find the colony Sir Walter Raleigh lost in 1587. Who carved the cryptic message on the deserted shore of Roanoke Island? he asks.

THE recent death of Anrei Vishinsky aroused memories once again of the fantastic Moscow purge trials of the Nineteen Thirties and adds to the timeliness of this absorbing study of those trials. "Ritual of Liquidation" has more than merely historic importance, for its subtle and unique analysis of Thoughtcrime, Doublethink and Newspeak, Soviet style, throws a bright searchlight on the mental processes of those who now rule in the Kremlin.

ALL civilizations have symbolized their medical concepts in the personalities of gods, goddesses or historical characters. Asklepios was the healer-god of Greece, to whose temples the crippled and sick came for treatment. Hygieia was the goddess of hygiene, concerned with the maintenance of health through rational conduct.

STRASBOURG, France, Dec. 11 -- Europe's Consultative Assembly of fifteen nations decisively approved today a resolution asking for early ratification of the Paris agreements on the arming of West Germany.

THE current dash back toward the Twenties has not caught the recording companies napping. They can match any of the other purveyors of the arts nostalgia for nostalgia, and they have no compunctions about a little coat-tail riding in the process.

At a special conference held in New York City, the legislative committee of the American League Against Epilepsy discussed and recommended reform of outmoded state laws that require sterilization of epileptics, prohibit their marriage, limit their employment opportunities and restrict their right to drive cars.
Georgetown University of Washington took top honors yesterday in a debate among teams from twenty-nine schools on the question of whether the United States should recognize Red China.

With five of its six components showing substantial gains, The New York Times Weekly Index of Business Activity rose to a new high of 192.6 in the week ended on Dec. 4. This compared with 191.5 in the previous week, highest figure up to that time.

ALL India was upset recently, as by an earthquake, when Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru proposed publicly that he retire from office, "at least temporarily." At 65, Nehru is at the age when the Brahmin by immemorial custom retires from day-to-day cares to a life of contemplation and advice to younger men. His Brahmin heritage may be asserting itself now, though he is a self-professed agnostic.

SANTA BARBARA, Calif., Dec. 4 -- Having seen the elimination of most horror, crime and lurid "comic" books in Santa Barbara, Parent-Teacher Associations of the city's eleven elementary schools have set up pocket-book lending libraries to supply children with recreational reading.

CHICAGO, Dec. 8 -- The nation's employers plan to hire more college and university graduates in 1955 than they did in 1954, and pay higher salaries, Dr. Frank S. Endicott, director of placement at Northwestern University, said this week.

WATCHING the Music Hall's current film, long-time admirers of one of the world's most accomplished Wagnerian sopranos may find themselves wondering why Helen Traubel hasn't simply made a career of something equally musical, her laughter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -President Eisenhower's spending budget for the fiscal year 1956 tentatively is shaping up at about $63,000,000,000, with a deficit of about $3,500,000,000 informed sources said tonight.

THEY "blame my thing and say it is not ancient in style and thus is not good," complains Albrecht Durer, referring to an altar painting for the House of German Merchants in Venice, in a letter written home to a Nuremberg friend in 1506.
QUEBEC, Dec. 7 -- The Province of Quebec's ancient Civil Code, which has always discriminated against married women in favor of their husbands, is to be modified.

PIERRE MONTEUX will be 80 on April 4. So far we have heard of no special honor for him on the actual birthday, but next fall he will be honored by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony. Dimitri Mitropoulos, the orchestra's musical director, was the man who instigated the tribute.
But where Disraeli was pliant, Gladstone was firm; the Queen must be made to realize that she was only a titular and not a real executive.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Ed Sanders, the 1952 Olympic heavyweight champion now serving with the United States Navy in Boston, apparently suffered a serious injury tonight when he was knocked out in the eleventh round of a scheduled twelve-rounder in Boston Garden.

SOMETIMES it seems as though almost every literate person who was ever a Communist and then stopped being a Communist has written a book about it. Sometimes it seems as though practically none of these repentent left-wingers throw light on why Americans become Communist.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, Dec. 10 -- Costa Rica's economy, rapidly expanding a year ago, apparently has reached a plateau. Many observers believe that unless it can pick up momentum soon there will be at least a minor crisis.

The Russian notes of last Thursday to the Western Powers spoke of "creating an effective system of collective security." Their tenor was that the "peace-loving" Communist-dominated nations of Europe wanted such a system, whereas the Western democracies did not. Yet, as the Russians and everybody else know, an effective system of security is not only what all free men desire but what all sane men desire.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Strong strategic, economic and political pressures for an East-West conference and an accommodation with the Soviet Union are held in check in Britain at the moment by the Government's resolve to base its policy toward Russia on the principles implanted by nine years of tedious and largely unsuccessful negotiation since the end of World War II.

Something is being done at last about the wines produced in New York State. Long overshadowed by the flood of low-priced regional French, Italian and German wines and by the far more vigorously merchandised wines of California, the Finger Lakes region of New York is taking steps to revive its great wine tradition.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 8 -- West Germany is watching closely the United States efforts to enlarge the market in that country for Japanese goods and to induce other Western countries to open new markets for Japan.
ROME, Dec. 11 -- Pope Pius XII's physician's admonished him today that he was overexerting himself by working too much too soon after his illness.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- The famous old cruiser Olympia, whose derring-do furnished a glorious chapter in the history of the United States Navy, will end up in the junkyard next month unless rescued by some civic group.

The John Wanamaker department store at Broadway and Ninth Street will close its doors next Saturday and the State Labor Department will begin tomorrow to try to find jobs for the company's 1,800 employees.
New tenants can get a refund from a landlord if they had to paint their apartments at their own expense before moving in, according to State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick.

BOSTON -- New England ski resort operators are placing their faith in New Hampshire's "Old Farmers Almanac" and proceeding on the theory that the coming season will bring plenty of snow. Plagued by scant falls in recent years, and by predictions that Yankeeland's weather is each year becoming more tropical, the operators plan to be ready for the best instead of the worst.
The question whether advertising is a major part of management has been neatly solved at the F. M. Schaefer Brewing Company. Rudy Schaefer, the president, is an old advertising hand.

Thus, in college courses devoted to the history of Western philosophy it is common procedure to jump with a few "transition lectures" from the Hellenistic Stoics and Epicureans directly to Descartes and the beginning of "modern thought."
Within the last few days, two international leaders .in rehabilitation have received ,merited recognition' for their contributions to services for the handicapped.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 11 -- Indians' attitude toward Communist China seems to have undergone a change since Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru's visit to Peiping in October.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A fight for the presidency of the Board of Trade was assured when petitions nominating Thomas E. Hosty were filed with the board's secretary yesterday. Mr. Hosty is senior partner in Sincere Co., commission house.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 8 -- An Indian Government proposal concerning the removal of hundreds of British monuments throughout the country has elicited varying reactions from the state governments.
HARTFORD, Dec. 10 -- Construction of a railroad station on the outskirts of Hartford was announced this week by Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -- An analysis of bank mergers in the Third Federal Reserve district shows that stockholders of the absorbed banks made out well. In the typical merger stockholders of the absorbed bank got $1.05 in cash or book value in the combined bank for every one dollar of their former holdings.

Dr. R. Stuart Mackay of the University of California describes in Science how he makes three-dimensional shadows on flat walls. The trick lies not so much in making the shadows or the equipment that produces them but in the way they are looked at.

Proceeds from the exhibition and sales of antiques at the East Side House Winter Antiques Show, to be held at the Seventh Regiment Armory from Jan. 24 through Jan. 29, will be devoted to three affiliated philanthropies. SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 11 (UP) -- Premier Ngo Dinh Diem announced tonight that Gen. Le Van Ty would take over as Chief of Staff of the 300,000-man South Vietnam Army Monday.

THERE will be uncommon interest in Dimitri Mitropoulos' first appearance as opera conductor at the Metropolitan Opera on Wednesday evening. He will direct Richard Strauss' "Salome." Later, in January, he will be heard in Verdi's "Masked Ball."
An Air Force plane sighted the ketch Ingegard III yesterday and reported that the small craft, which has been the object of a five-day Caribbean search, signaled that all was well.

Mayor Wagner assured 2,000 parents and educators yesterday that he would consult with their representatives before filling vacancies on the Board of Education.

THE recent boom that created a theatre shortage and prevented new plays from coming in during a large part of the autumn is now over. London drama critics, who were almost idle for that period, are now at work again, but mainly on frivolous lightweight fare designed to meet the mood of the Christmas holidays.

OTTAWA, Dec. 11 -- An eight-nation committee will petition the Council of Ministers of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization next week to implement Article 2 of the Charter, providing for closer political and economic unity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Army-Navy-Air Force Register today published a 1947 memorandum recommending that the Navy assume the major offensive role in any future war and said it should stimulate a "complete re-examination of military policy."

The Cleveland Browns have it in their power to resolve a knotty situation in professional football. If the Browns beat or tie the Pittsburgh Steelers in Cleveland today, they will clinch the National League's Eastern Division title for the fifth straight year.

MANSFIELD, Ohio, Dec. 9 -- The farm in Morrow County, Ohio, where President Warren G. Harding was born is being sold out of the Harding family for the first time in more than a century.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The scope of the nation's anti-trust laws was broadened by a court ruling this week. In a unanimous decision the Supreme Court held that a chain bakery operating outlets in two states had violated the anti-trust laws when it drove an independent bakery in one town out of business by price cuts it put into effect in the one community.

ATLANTA, Dec. 4 -- The southern pulp and paper industry now accounts for 60 per cent of the total national pulpwood consumption, H. J. Malsberger, forester for the Southern Pulpwood Conservation Association, reported recently.

THE airlines appear to have an inexhaustible capacity for devising new winter-travel lures. Imaginative sales departments annually come up with new package plans, new purchasing plans and, with faster airplanes, new places to go.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 11 -United States reliance on the doctrine of "massive retaliation" is criticized in a memorandum published today by Princeton University's Center of International Studies. NEWARK, Dec. 11 -- Three small children died in a fire in the bedroom in which they were sleeping early this afternoon. The fire started when an oil stove exploded in the first floor room.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -One of the major plums of the Eastern dog show year went to a black cocker spaniel tonight. He was Ch. Taylor's Dark Knight, a 1 1/2-year-old dog belonging to Dr. Gilbert H. Taylor of Glen Cove, L. I.

When the American veterans of World War II and Korea -- AMVETS for short -- honored General of the Army George C. Marshall on Friday night, they also honored themselves. DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The greatest production capacity the auto industry ever has developed may get a workout next year.

DALLAS, Dec. 11 -- The fast pace that Christmas shoppers have set in stores of the Eleventh Federal District in recent weeks was generally maintained last week, merchants reported. Most store officials still were predicting sales volume as good or better than last year, although a few said business was trailing slightly.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- The Massachusetts Legislature will face a record work load of 3,084 measures at the 1955 session. At the close of filing, the bills numbered 121 more than in 1953, when the previous record was set. The Legislature convenes Jan. 5.

In the western parts of Haiti the high - velocity winds of Hurricane Hazel unroofed and sometimes collapsed buildings, overturned and broke trees and left standing trees completely leafless. The hurricane was accompanied by torrential rains which extended over a much greater radius than the area of violent winds and which lasted for days after the hurricane had passed.

A PLAYWRIGHT, a man with a conspicuously Gothic outlook, a fairly long list of successes and a gift for free association, remarked recently that a Broadway opening -- for him, at any rate -- was an apocalyptic experience. He even thought that the sensation could be raised to the level of a general principle.

CHRISTMAS, Fla. -- Tourists come here by the thousands throughout the year, but they come with a rush during the pre-holiday period to get the Christmas postmark on their mail. Last year more than 300,000 pieces of mail, mostly greeting cards, were sent out from this post office.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 11 -- Making his first major policy statement, Johannes G. Strijdom, South Africa's new Prime Minister, said tonight that the rights of courts would be respected. But it must be clearly understood, he added, that Parliament is, after God, the highest authority in the land and the courts have no right against it.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- The General Assembly adopted today a resolution calling for all-Korean elections aimed at the reunification of that war-torn and divided country.

Entitled "This Is Our Story," it stresses the development of special services in the fields of health, guidance and psychological testing.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 8 -- "The Progress of Time," a new permanent exhibit depicting the evolution of the watch of today, was opened this week at the Franklin Institute.

The single-salary schedule for teachers in elementary and secondary schools, which has become a controversial issue here, appears to be working satisfactorily in many of the nation's twenty-five largest cities.

Floridians, especially Miamians, believe in first things first. They see no merit in waiting until next summer when a major-sized international speed-boat regatta can be held in December. For several years they have been taking advantage of the huge influx of Orange Bowl football game visitors.

The principles of municipal government advocated by the late Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia were praised yesterday by former associates at the fourth annual luncheon of the La Guardia Memorial Association in the Sheraton Astor Hotel.

Columbia's basketball team made a successful home debut last night by defeating City College, 66 -- 56, before 2,500 spectators at University Hall. The contest was the first between the neighboring institutions in thirty-two years.
