STAR of Bethlehem, a new and increasingly popular floral sign of the season, is once again making its annual pilgrimage from the mountain areas of South Africa to the United States. The bulk of this year's importation of 6,000,000 flower-laden stems arrived here this past week.

Three men who allegedly did a booming business selling television sets that they had stolen from homes in the Bedford-Stuyvesant district were arraigned yesterday in Brooklyn Felony Court on charges of burglary.

Applications are now available for the municipal life guard training course conducted each year to train young men for the position of life guard at municipal pools and beaches, the Parks Department announced last week. Applications may be obtained at Borough headquarters of the department and the Parks Department School at 342 East Fifty-fourth Street Pool, Manhattan. Tuition is free.

MIAMI BEACH -- This city is now reaching the chronological maturity that will permit it to observe during I955 its fortieth anniversary as a legal entity. It has been a long time since they dredged up out of the ocean what is now Collins Avenue and Lincoln Road and lovely Pine Tree Drive, and it is nearly three decades since the explosive real estate boom of the mid-Twenties.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 11 -- The slogan "One Nation, One People, One Language" fired the spirits of Indonesians during the long struggle which brought them freedom from three centuries of Dutch colonial rule.

The Yankees and Dodgers, whose plans for another world series meeting last October were slightly disrupted when the Giants and Indians moved into the act, are not letting a little thing like that interfere with their traditional rivalry.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 7 -- A more detailed economic evaluation of the effects of conservation farming is needed to help individual farmers in planning profitable programs for use of soil resources.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Japan's one-day-old conservative Government told the nation today it planned no drastic new policies during its brief tenure. But it promised to try to improve on the performance of the conservative regime it replaced.

THE celebration of the bicentennial of the death of Bach four years ago was like a bandwagon that many musical organizations jumped on. But the celebration of the bicentennial of the birth of Mozart the year after next will be like a carefully prepared landslide.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers rapidly pulled away from a tie early in the second half tonight to post a 97-87 National Basketball Association victory over the Milwaukee Hawks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 -- Business in the Chicago area continued to improve in November, but failed to hold the rapid pace set in the previous two months, the monthly survey conducted by the Purchasing Agents Association of Chicago showed. The upturn was tempered by downward tendencies in employment, production and backlog of orders, as well as a tendency toward faster deliveries by venders.

AVIATION enthusiasts who would like to be rocketed through the atmosphere at hypersonic speeds but find no such trip tickets available may read "Skyrocketing Into the Unknown'' by Charles Coombs; it is a superb second choice.

SARASOTA -- In the mid-Eighties a group of Scotsmen, apparently canny souls, bought, sight unseen, a vast piece of land and settled in what is now Sarasota, a city with a population of 40,000 dominating the Florida county whose name it beats.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 11 -- The job market is on the rise in greater Cleveland for the first time since July, 1953, according to the Bureau of Unemployment Compensation. Employment of wage and salary workers was estimated at 639,000, representing an increase of 6,500 since the bureau's October survey.
Two caps for underprivileged boys will be the beneficiaries the annual Groton-St. Mark's School dance to be help on Friday in the Roosevelt Hotel.

Arab-Israel truce line, travelers here will feel as perhaps never before how precious is the Christmas season's promise of peace and goodwill.

Small and weak premature infants have a five-to-one chance of survival if they reach one of the ten approved hospital centers for them in the city. If not, their chances so far this year have been just under three-to- two.

BRADENTON, Fla. -- There are in Florida about 4,000 trailer parks. Their number is constantly increasing and it is now estimated that 250,000 persons are living here in this manner. Many have become year-round citizens and their trailers are as permanent fixtures as any house.

SALT LAKE CITY -- The U. S. Forest Service has just reported that twenty-six winter sports areas now exist in the sixteen National Forests of Idaho, Utah, Nevada and Wyoming, which comprise the Federal agency's Intermountain Region.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- President Eisenhower attended the winter dinner of the Gridiron Club tonight and, with other notables of public and private life, enjoyed a ribbing of his Administration and its political opponents.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 8 -- New York's experience in hospital planning was cited this week as a guide for San Francisco.

EVERY school official or teacher faced with desegregation and integration to conform to Supreme Court rulings can get a preview of his problems and headaches by reading this excellent account of how desegregation has worked in twenty-four communities.

THE publication of "The Death of Christopher Marlowe" in 1925, two short years after the author had won his Doctorate of Philosophy at Harvard, established Leslie Hotson as the foremost literary detective of his generation. Here was a man who combined the dogged pertinacity of the police force with the intuition of M. Hercule Poirot, and who could write with brilliance and color.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 11 -The 10,000,000 members of the American Federation of Labor have been "disillusioned, penalized and disgusted with punitive legislation" during the last two years.

WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Army's fifty - third basketball season began on a dismal, note today as the cadets were defeated by a surprising Ithaca College quintet, 89 -- 76. Superior work by the visitors from the penalty stripe made the big difference.

CHRISTMAS is what you make it, and making it memorable with festive decorations is a part of the joyous tradition. Besides being easy and fun, it is one pre-Christmas activity that can be shared by the whole family.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 11 (UP) -- Indiana tallied eight points in the last seventy-five seconds today to beat Notre Dame, 73 to 70, in the first televised game of the Big Ten winter basketball program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- A baseball scout turned diplomat said today Italians and Yugoslavs sometimes had forgotten their bitter dispute over Trieste long enough to play on the same ball team.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 11 -- Philadelphia defeated Boston, 5 -- 2, as the inter-city squash racquets tournament for the Arthur Lockett Trophy began at the Field Club today.

WINTER motor tourists going south or north are beginning to get the benefits of the large amount of highway construction during the last few years. JERSEY CITY, Dec. 11 (AP) -A Hudson County judge this week upheld a $3,262 workmen's compensation award for 47-year-old Mrs. Catherine Hylander of West New York, who said she was frightened by a mouse.
PARIS, Dec. 11 -- The first submarine built in France for the French Navy since World War II was launched today at Cherbourg.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 11 -- The Government-sponsored Antara news agency published today a report that arrangements had been worked out to send an anti-Communist Chinese leader to Formosa rather than to Communist China.

WASHINGTON. THE Internal Revenue Service the other day reported that individual income taxes (plus old-age and unemployment insurance taxes) for the fiscal year 1954, which ended last June 30, were up by almost $700,000,000 over the previous year, despite a cut in rates.

Leaders of the nation's $25,000,000,000 electric light and power industry have come to the conclusion that they must build nuclear reactors. This decision has been reached despite the greater efficiency of coal at present for generating steam for power.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- An official of the Veterans Administration predicted today that the Government soon would declare an end to the Korean war emergency, thus cutting off some veterans' benefits for future soldiers.

SEBRING, Fla. -- The "ridge country of Florida" is a narrow strip of elevated and slightly rolling land in the central part of the state. U. S. 27, the Orange Blossom Trail, crosses most of this area and, just as Orlando dominates it in the north and Lakeland in the middle, so does ,Sebring in the south.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 10 -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations advised its unions today to fight for the abolition of sales and payroll taxes at the state and municipal level.

DENVER, Colo. -- The Rocky Mountain winter sports season opens this week with more enthusiasm, more glittering new resort facilities and more fabulous plans than at any time since 1947 when Walter Paepcke unveiled Aspen's celebrated chair lift to the stars.

WAITSFIELD, Vt. -- How can a ski area reduce waiting times on ski lift lines? Even the ardor of skiers can be cooled when they find they have to form in long queues for their uphill transportation, and at some of the more overcrowded areas these waits can be between one and two hours.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 11 -- The news that the United Nations had declined to favor talks between the Netherlands and Indonesia on West New Guinea caused sharp disappointment in Government quarters here. It had been felt that the compromise resolution had a good chance of being approved.

THE seventy years of European printmaking, 1883-1954, covered in the current exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art are a period so fertile in invention and achievement that the one hundred prints on view can hardly do more than skim the cream.

JERUSALEM (Jordanian Sector), Nov. 24 -- For the first time since the 1948 division of Jerusalem, the Arab sector will soon have a first-class hotel. FROM first to last, Joseph Foldes' "The Practical Way to Perfect Enlargements" (San Francisco: Camera Craft Publishing Company, $5) is a how-to-do-it manual on the subject. WEST PALM BEACH -- Polo is one of the new attractions for winter visitors in the Palm Beach area. SCORE another triumph for that peerless anthologist, Judith Merril. Her fifth anthology is, in many ways, her best; assuredly it is her most original, for each of these nineteen stories explores, in one direction or another, the misty potential of the human mind.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 11 -- Retail business is moving along briskly in the Tenth Federal Reserve District and gains over the like 1953 period are classed as moderate. C., and the Virginia communities.

SPOKANE, Wash., Dec. 11 (AP) -- Sandy Saddler flew back to New York today with a puffed lip, a bloody nose and $6,000 after taking a unanimous ten-round decision from Bobby Woods in a non-title match.

The Institute of Comparative Law, New York University, will open a three-day international conference on Monday, Dee. 13, commemorating the anniversary of the Code Napoleon. Distinguished jurists and legal educators will discuss "The French Code and the Common-Law World."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- A year ago this month the first steps were taken by the Administration which led to negotiation of the controversial Dixon-Yates power contract that is now being scrutinized at hearings before the Securities and Exchange Commission.

IN recent years more American parents have been traveling abroad than ever before. In addition to looking at Buckingham Palace and Versailles, St. Mark's and the Colosseum they also are seeing and commenting on European children -- the Swiss with their placidity, the decorous British, the methodical Dutch, the French, restrained and polite, the Italian, sweet and gentle.

HARTFORD, Dec. 1 -- Trinity College has announced the formation of an organization known as the Trinity College Associates to conduct a "pioneer program for the advancement of business, industry and higer education" in the Hartford area.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 -- Like one of the volcanoes which dot the landscape of this island nation, Japan's political structure has been rumbling and smoking for some months. This week it erupted, but with more noise and confusion than real damage.

The Second Section of The Times today again presents the appeal of the Neediest of this city for a friendly hand at Christmas time. A reading of these cases and of others we have published will show the thoughtful reader whose memory goes back even one generation how the nature of the need for private philanthropy has altered.
BANGKOK, Thailand, Dec. 10 -- Participants from fourteen Asian nations ended today a three-week discussion of land problems in Asia and the Far East.

FURTHER notes on 1954: It was a weak year for new mystery novelists. There were plenty of them -- about one mystery out of five was a first -- but no such startling standouts as Nineteen Fifty-three's Charlotte Jay and Ira Levin.

WE were talking last week about the value of books as a record of man's outer and inner experience. Since then I have been reading Marguerite Yourcenar's remarkable "Memoirs of Hadrian," a passage from which, bearing on that subject, appears in today's Treasure Chest.

BOSTON, Dec. 11 -- One New England industry which is definitely better than a year ago is the winter resort business. Not for many years has there been so much snow so early in the North Country. Manufacturing continues to show spotty improvement.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: A little judicious pruning of evergreens provides material for making Christmas wreaths and other decorations. Until they are to be used, lay branches flat in a cool place (40. to 50 degrees) and cover with damp paper. Wrap bunches of berries in paper; stand in water. AND IF THERE IS TIME: Mulch trees and shrubs planted this year and perennials set out this fall. . . .
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -President and Mrs. Eisenhower had their first meal today in their still unfinished home on their Gettysburg, Pa., farm.

Boyd M. Johnson has been named general manager of the refractories division of the Carborundum Company, Niagara Falls, N. Y., producer of manufactured abrasives. He succeeds Clarence E. Hawke, who retires from active direction of the division but remains as a vice president of the company.
Lieut. Stanley R. Swanson of the United States Air Force was honored last night for his deeds as a college lacrosse player.

Bishop Loughlin, St. Francis Prep and a 14-year-old sophomore from La Salle Military Academy shared the spotlight last night in the fifth annual Catholic High Schools Athletic Association relay carnival at the 102d Engineers Armory.

The art world's Christmas season is as full of novelties as another, the sole historical show of the week being that Spanish Medieval art at The Cloisters. This exhibition will open on Wednesday, featuring objects lent from public and private collections.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 11 (AP) -- The Marquis de Portago, the daring Spaniard, pushed his swift black ferrari to victory today in the 105-mile Bahamas Auto Club race. He defeated Masten Gregory of Kansas City, Mo., by half a mile.

THE American Theatre Wing revue, "On the Wing," may yet get off the ground. Only this time, if it does -- and proves worthy -- its range will be strictly limited. No more flights of fancy in the stratosphere such as occurred last season when the first edition made such a strong impression in its single showing that a movement began to give it a public hearing.
KANSAS CITY, Dec. 11 (AP) -Oklahoma A. and M. College of Stillwater today ran just shy of support needed to make it a member of the Big Seven Conference.

ABOUT as good a place as any to observe the strange and wonderful workings of the human brain is the United States Patent Office. By the end of this year, 34,000 patents will have been issued, the great majority of them prosaic, practical additions to the American culture.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- Very few indeed are the Americans who have ever seen them, but they are the worst ambassadors their country has had in many a day. They are the "horror comics," frequently equated here with "the American comics," about which a one-sided debate has been raging for weeks.

A SHORT lived movement of a generation ago whose influence is still felt is the subject of the current exhibition at the Curt Valentin Gallery. A dozen painters who participated in the activities of the Blaue Reiter group in Munich are represented in the show including Kandinsky, Feininger and Klee, as well as the ill-fated August Macke and Franz Marc who met death as their powers were unfolding during the first World War.
City College's fencing team yesterday came within one bout of upsetting Columbia, the defending National Collegiate co-champion. But the Beavers finally bowed, 14 to 13, on their home strip.

IN her article "The Writer Must Become as a Child," Rumer Godden refers to the stories of the Scaramouches, which she read as a child in England. She admits that she doesn't know the author. These stories appeared in Aunt Judy's magazine.
NOW that the wintry blasts have begun, a seasonal malady, marked by a pronounce itching of the feet, is affecting many northern sportsmen.

Accused of passing a worthless check in Memphis, Tenn., last month, Leon Sonnenschein, 43 years old, who gave his address as 104 Hackensack Street, Wood-Ridge, N. J., was held in $15,000 bail yesterday in the Federal Building. United States Commissioner Earle N. Bishop set a hearing for Dec. 27.

HONG KONG, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Burmese Premier U Nu announced in Peiping today that he planned to visit the United States soon in an effort to bring about an understanding between Chinese Communist and American leaders, the Peiping radio said.

UNTIL recently travelers who had to keep an eye on their expenses automatically ruled South America out of bounds. For one thing, the cost of transportation alone put such a holiday out of the realm of possibility.

HERNDON DAVIS, American artist, who once painted "a face on the bar room floor" in a Colorado gold rush community, has been commissioned by the Republic of Panama to place on canvas the likenesses of the 259 "recognized" Roman Catholic pontiffs from Saint Peter through Pius XII.

The telescope and the electronic computer have been combined to locate so-called "lost" planets. With the combination Dr. Paul Herget, director of the Cincinnati Observatory, rediscovered the planet Athalia, lost for fifty years. He used the General Electric Company's giant IBM 701 computer to figure the orbit.

SALT LAKE CITY, Utah, Dec. 11 -- Democratic and Republican members of Congress from this region formed yesterday a coalition to push the billion-dollar Upper Colorado River water storage project through the Eighty-fourth Congress.

TRENTON, Dec. 11 -- The State Legislature is expected to reconvene within the next ten days to extend rent controls on a local option basis. When it does an effort will be made by Gov. Robert B. Meyner, Democrat, to induce it to consider other pending legislation.

ATTRACTIVE opportunities to purchase photographic prints for exhibiting at home or for Christmas giving are offered by two local galleries. The Limelight Gallery, 91 Seventh Avenue South, has on display through this month a highly diversified group of almost fifty pictures by nineteen photographers, both American and European.

TUCSON, Ariz., Dec. 7 -A high school building for the vocational education of Roman Catholic boys and girls of Tucson, planned by John J. Raskob before the financier's death in October, 1949, is now under construction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 -- The San Francisco Forty-Niners wound up a disappointing National Football League season today by gaining a 10-7 victory over the last-place Baltimore Colts on a slippery field.

A few weeks ago this department noted the apprehension with which theatre owners viewed the day when the box office in the home television may become a reality. The opposition is strong and some theatre spokesmen have even gone so far as to contend they are concerned with protecting the public interests.

Governor-elect George M. Leader of Pennsylvania, first Democrat to hold that office in twenty years, told the Pennsylvania Society here last night that the day of "impregnable political machines" was past.
After more than seventy years of trading on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange, it appears that the coffee futures market will be placed under Federal supervision.
MIAMI, Dec. 10 -- Tramp shipping should be fostered by the Government, the Propeller Club of the United States declares.

The New York Chapter of the American-Scandinavian Foundation will give its annual Christmas dinner dance on Thursday in the Pierre Roof. Rolf T. Michelson is president of the chapter, which is one of ten throughout the country.
BRISBANE, Australia, Dec. 11 -- Unless he shows marked improvement in the next four days, Tony Trabert may be replaced by Hamilton Richardson in the interzone Davis Cup finals against Sweden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- During informal talks with the Chinese Reds earlier this year in Geneva, the United States did not specifically label imprisoned American airmen as "prisoners of war illegally detained," State Department sources said tonight.
HARTFORD, Dec. 10 -- With the biennial session of Connecticut's General Assembly slated to begin Jan. 5, neither of the two major parties has yet organized its legislative leadership.
Thanks to the provocative deeds and words of Communist China, the angry debate the past week in the United Nations General Assembly ended with at least a propaganda victory for the United States.

TORONTO, Dec. 8 -- Canadian engineers and construction gangs have begun to push a long finger of steel and concrete into the racing Niagara River above the Falls in one of man's most unusual conservation projects.
WHETHER or not the legend is true that comedians frequently "borrow" jokes from other comedians, there is no doubt that TV comics are beginning to lay hold to one another's thinking in one respect.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The United States will take over the training of South Vietnam's National Army about Jan. 1 if negotiations now under way are successful.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 11 -- Dr. Arcot L. Mudaliar, vice chancellor of Madras University of India, was elected chairman of the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization's executive board today.

ROME, Dec. 11 -- The police removed a sign from the Rome headquarters of the Church of Christ, an American Protestant denomination, today. The sign had been replaced only yesterday on the assumption that an Italian court had permitted the church to do so.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Dec. 7 -- Unchecked depletion of the country's soil fertility could result in the eventual destruction of its complex industrial economy.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) -- Two substitutes, Ken Rode and Don Morchower, went into the game in the last half tonight to help Georgetown University's basketball team score a 77-68 victory over St. Peter's College of Jersey City.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 11 -- The Navy will unveil a revolutionary idea in the handling of ammunition barges here in April with the completion of a $678,000 specially designed docking facility in the Hampton Roads area.
The fifty-year-old fireboat George B. McClellan has come to the end of its cruise and is about to be sold.

This chart illustrates the relative positions of the United States and the rest of the world in steel production in 1953, when the nation turned out a record 111,610,000 net tons of ingots and steel for castings.
PARIS, Nov. 24 -- Hundreds of French teen-age students daily are visiting a small left-bank museum to learn, through vivid illustration, what the Germans did to their countrymen during World War II.

The Metropolitan Opera Fund will be the beneficiary of a performance of Berlioz' "The Damnation of Faust" on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall by members of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, the Schola Cantorum and the Boys Choir of St. Thomas Protestant Episcopal Church.

ATLANTA, Dec. 11 -- Christmas buying continues well ahead of last year in the Southeast. Further predictions that department store sales would set a new record were made by many merchants this week. Non-agricultural employment in the Southeast advanced 44,300 during October to 5,991,300, the Regional Bureau of Labor Statistics announced.
KLAMATH FALLS, Ore., Dec. 11 -- Ralph Weiser, 128 pounds, died today after a knockout in a fight last night he would have won if he hadn't tried to give fans a run for their money.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 11 -- Michael G. Zeigler of Fairborn, Ohio, was elected captain of the 1955 Army football squad at a meeting of the letter men today.

The big work on yesterday afternoon's concert by the Boston Symphony in Carnegie Hall was a repeat performance of Samuel Barber's "Prayers of Kierkegaard," for mixed chorus, soprano solo and orchestra. It had been introduced to New York audiences Wednesday.

WITH a taste of below-freezing weather last week adding a special zest to preparations for winter resort travel, the Pennsylvania, Atlantic Coast Line, Seaboard and Florida East Coast lines were set for the southland rush.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11--President Eisenhower today created a new Cabinet-level agency, the Council of Foreign Economic Policy, to coordinate foreign aid activities and to develop other foreign economic policies of the Government.

SANTIAGO, Cuba -- A young U. S. naval officer, Lieut. Richmond Pearson Hobson, brought Santiago de Cuba dramatically to the attention of the American people one night fifty-six years ago when he sank the coaling ship Merrimac in the narrow mouth of the harbor in an effort to bottle up the Spanish fleet.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 11 -- Undefeated Seton Hall University rolled to its fourth-straight basketball triumph, 84 -- 65, over Wheaton College before 2,700 last night. It was the fourth loss in five starts for the Illinois quintet.
MIAMI, Dec. 11 -- Ed Furgol, the national open champion, carded a 69 today and pulled into a three-way tie for first place after three rounds of the $10,000 Miami open golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- By all the normal tests of politics, President Eisenhower would seem to be in serious trouble for the first time.

John D. Rockefeller 3d sent a check for $500 to the Neediest Cases Fund of The New York Times yesterday. Mr. Rockefeller's gift was one of the largest in the day's mail, the other $500 contribution coming in from Mr. and Mrs. Paul Moore.

The Long Island Rough Riders defeated the Meadow Brooks Raiders beat the New York Ath Blues, 17 -- 12, and the Manhattan Raiders beat the New York Athletic Club, 16 -- 4, in the New York Indoor Polo League doubleheader at the Squadron A Armory last night.

Prospects of a reduction in the nation's cotton surplus this season have virtually disappeared. The final report of the year, issued last week by the Department of Agriculture, estimated the crop at 13,569,000 bales -- just about the expected total of domestic consumption and exports this season.

Development of the hydrogen bomb and intensive industrial promotion have raised the world's lightest metal, lithium, from obscurity to a stellar role in half a dozen civilian and defense industries in the last five years.

LIKE everyone else I have at my disposal only three means of evaluating human existence: the study of self, which is the most difficult and most dangerous method, but also the most fruitful; the observation of our fellow men, who usually arrange to hide their secrets from us, or to make us believe that they have secrets; and books, with the particular errors of perspective to which they inevitably give rise.

Many distributors of large household appliances fear that General Electric Company's recent "local option" move may soon touch off widespread price wars and false pricing in the products they sell to stores.

OF the really great political biographies -- and there are not too many of them -- one is certainly Lord Morley's three-volume "Life of Gladstone" which appeared in 1903, only five years after its subject's death. In his introduction Lord Morley frankly said that his closeness to Gladstone, politically and personally, made "perspective, scale, relation" difficult to adjust.

SANTA ts heading south with wondrous surprises for house! plant enthusiasts, according to North Pole headquarters. And even I, a conservative indoor gardener, am giving way to unrestrained flights of fancies.

THE Village Camera Club presented one of the best and largest membership shows in its history last week in competition for the annual print - of - the - year award. There was ample evidence that the members had made considerable individual progress over the years and apparently were now in full stride toward purposeful personal goals.

Four hundred preparatory schools and colleges are now enrolled in the Tuition Plan, designed to permit parents to pay for their children's education on the pay-as-you-learn basis. A report issued last week brought out that more parents are now using the "installment plan" in sending their children to school or college than ever before.

DALLAS, Tex., Dec. 11 (AP) -- An agreement transferring assets valued on the stock market at $170,000,000 was completed here yesterday. It involves oil, gas and mineral assets held by the Texas Pacific Land Trust.

Wiser judgment has prevailed, we believe, in the refusal of the United Nations General Assembly to accept the resolution calling for renewed Dutch-Indonesian discussion on western New Guinea and for a progress report to the United Nations on that discussion.

For the first time in recent years, the problems of American Education are being studied on a nation-wide scale. Every state, and to a large extent, towns, villages and hamlets across the country will make an educational inventory which will provide the basis for a national conference next year at the White House.

A GREAT many styles and techniques are being re-explored in the current renaissance of tapestries, rug-making and needlework. These decorative textiles meant for use on walls, floors, or even as space dividers are as highly individualized as a painting and are often used in place of one. Sometimes they are one of a kind.

LONDON, Dec. 11 (Reuters) -- Bishop Auckland, Northern League amateur squad, surprised in the second round of the English Football Association Cup competition today by beating Crystal Palace of the professional third division, 4 -- 2. Three goals by J. Major, center forward, clinched the victory for Auckland, which trailed by 2 -- 1 at half time.

IF you are toying with the idea of driving to Florida this winter, don't let some kill-joy talk you out of it. Far from being the dismal drudgery of dust and distance that it is often pictured, the trip can be a stimulating and rewarding experience.

ON the afternoon of Dec. 19, 1944, we were loaded into trucks and driven south to reinforce some troops in Belgium. We were glad to go, for we were sick of the mud and pillboxes of the Siegfried Line. The next few days, we saw a lot of Belgium from the back of our truck, although we didn't do much except travel round and round, picking up fresh eggs wherever possible.

Temple University in Philadelphia has received from the Ford Foundation's Fund for the Advancement of Education an initial grant of $53,150 to cover the first year's budget of a five-year experiment in teacher education.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The most important questions of the day are (1) what will be the nature of the President's national and party leadership in the remaining two years of his current term and (2) how successful will it be as measured on the yardsticks of world peace and the prospects of the Republican party?
OTTAWA, Dec. 5 -- The most extensive of the annual depletions of the bison herd at Wood Buffalo National Park started this week and will continue for two weeks.

LONDON, Dec. 11 -- In the year 2000 A. D. a single plastic dome will cover this huge capital. Letters will be shot to Australia by rocket and replies received in a day. Pedestrians will shop on moving sidewalks at second-story level, with traffic below and out of sight. And means will have been found to neutralize atomic bombs at a great distance.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 11 (AP) -- George Washington, the champion of the Southern Conference, beat undermanned Duquesne, 71 -- 64, tonight to win the fourth annual Steel Bowl basketball tournament.
American companies are joiners. They form trade associations, big and little, and hold conventions at which they swap technical data, success stories and anecdotes and discuss industry problems.

HONOLULU -- Waikiki will celebrate the new year with five new beach hotels and the prospect of more to come, and for the first time in three years the tourist industry is looking forward to a day when it will not have to turn away prospective visitors because of a shortage of rooms.

The Brooklyn Museum announced yesterday the resignation of its director, Charles Nagel, effective as of July 1, 1955. Mr. Nagel has been with the museum nearly nine years, and was formerly acting director of the St. Louis City Art Museum at St. Louis.

ROUBEN MAMOULIAN, whose "long-range dream" of producing and directing a feature-length screen version of "Carmen" is approaching reality, last week made known the fact that he was also preparing Rossini's "The Barber of Seville'' for eventual filming.
LONDON, Dec. 10 (Reuters) -The soaring cost of tea, the British national beverage, has become a political issue.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 -- A $2,500,000 Roman Catholic monastery and a parochial school for the training of Negro children will be developed on a forty-acre southwest Atlanta site.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 11 (UP) -- Halfback Olin Renfroe raced to touchdowns on jaunts of 51 and 64 yards today to give Hinds Junior College of Raymond, Miss., a 13-to-7 victory over El Camino of California in the ninth Junior Rose Bowl football game.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 -- The Detroit Red Wings scored two goals in each of the last two periods tonight to rout the New York Rangers, 4 -- 1, in a National Hockey League game before 10,843 fans at Olympia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 -- The Army disclosed today that radar had been put to work as the infantryman's ally in tracking down enemy mortar fire.

THIS correspondent, who has had a conspicuous career as an international wallflower, wrote an article for these pages some years ago telling how he was excluded from King Farouk's palace in Cairo because he was wearing a tuxedo instead of a tailcoat.

IN "Close Contact" Brig. C. H. Dewhurst relates his experiences from March, 1951, to March, 1953, when he served as Chief of the British Mission to the Soviet Forces in Eastern Germany with headquarters at Potsdam. The author's assignment ended on the day of Stalin's death.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UP) -Maxwell M. Rabb, Secretary to President Eisenhower's cabinet, said today that General Eisenhower's "devotion to duty" must be considered in any question whether he would run for re-election in 1956.

MOSCOW, Sunday, Dec. 12 -- The Soviet Government has rejected a United States protest over the shooting up of a United States B-29. The reconnaissance plane crashed in northern Japan Nov. 7 after a clash with Russian fighters.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y. Dec. 11 -- The General Assembly's Trusteeship Committee completed today its work for this session.

Stores are burning the wires in last-minute hunts for holiday merchandise, but virtually none is available, according to resident buying offices. Most manufacturers have already started to ship cruise-wear and spring lines. A tight situation also is indicated in the toy field, where demand is heavy for items that have been taken off sale.

GREENSBORO, N. C., Dec. 11 (UP) -The Atlantic Coast Conference today deferred action on the controversial National Collegiate A. A. football television plan. The group voted to name a committee to report on the issue in May.
Bobby Avila, brilliant second sacker of the Indians, carried off the American League 1954 individual batting championship with a mark of .341, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

The Grand Jury Association of New York County, Inc., has criticized a proposal by the state's Temporary Commission on the Courts that youth courts instead of grand juries handle cases of juvenile delinquents.
Richard Davies, a Cleveland-born baritone who now lives in California, gave his first New York recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 8 -- A "leaders' guide on intergroup education" has been co-operatively prepared and published here for use in education toward school desegregation.

Mrs. C. P. Greenough Fuller, chairman of the Art Workshop of the Rivington Neighborhood Association, has announced a benefit theatre party to be held on Feb. 10 at "The Desperate Hours." The play, a drmatization of the Joseph Hayes novel, will star Karl Malden and Nancy Coleman.

SMALL electric appliances, especially the handsomely designed ones, suggest themselves for at-the-table cookery, a function formerly reserved for the chafing dish. The new electric skillets and attractive fryer-cookers and the more common sandwich grills can add excitement to the coming season of holiday feasting.

Two bandits, posing as hitchhiking sailors, held up a motorist on the West Side Highway Friday night, locked him in trunk, compartment of his car and drove around for hours looking for another victim.
EVERY day our modern mechanical work giants perform feats that challenge thought and imagination. Here are five books which enable the child to see commonplace objects on a new, exciting level.
PATERSON, N. J., Dec. 11 -Rotary clubs from Passaic, Bergen and Hudson counties have donated $870 to pay for twenty-nine portable libraries for distribution to the free nations of the world.

It was indeed fitting that we in the United States joined the British Commonwealth in honoring Sir Winston Churchill on his eightieth birthday. Drew Middleton's article, "If Churchill Had Not Lived -- " (Nov. 28), certainly expressed the thankfulness we have for his presence in time of need.
Now being merchandised as an appliance, pre-fabricated garages are enjoying boom sales.

SALVADOR DALI has twisted the mustache into a surrealist art form with a book of photographs showing himself and his waxed, weapon-like growth in various attitudes. Male models promoting drinks, clothes, food and shoes are sporting mustaches with abandon, whereas only a few years back the hairy lip in advertising was a character prop.

HONOLULU, Dec. 12 (AP) -- An atomic scientist from Ohio who never before had gone to sea on his own was so elated today over his forty-eight-day, 3,900-mile trip in a two-masted ketch from Japan to Hawaii that he talked of more ocean voyages.
The basic difference between "dogmatic" Christianity and Unitarianism is that the former holds that faith alone is necessary for salvation, the Rev. Dr. Frederick May Eliot of Boston said yesterday.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Harold Keller, State Commerce Commissioner, urged today a thorough state study of atomic energy in industry as a step toward encouraging its use and establishing safety regulations.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Lincoln Electric Company has distributed its twenty-first annual incentive pay bonus. This time 1,161 employes received a total of $4,458,629.

Once more the charge is being made that the 1953-54 recession was initiated by the "tight-money" policy of the Eisenhower Administration in the spring of 1953. John D. Clark, a former member of the Council of Economic Advisers, claims that the tight- money policy "smothered" the boom and "induced" the recession.

LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Despite the brilliant success of the Government's big conversion loan, a decided turn for the better in sterling, the record steel production, and the firmness in Wall Street and other smaller bull points, the London stock markets are again trending downward.
Twelve hundred Jewish leaders adopted yesterday a goal of $99,521,275 for the 1955 United Jewish Appeal campaign to meet urgent Jewish needs throughout the world.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 (UP) -- West Coast martime troubles forced delay of the departure of the round-the-world passenger-cargo liner President Monroe one week until next Friday, the American President Lines reported today.

Ninety per cent of Harlem has undergone a house-to-house, block-by-block check by inspectors of the Department of Housing and Buildings in the last ten months, Deputy Commissioner Bernice P. Rogers said yesterday.

Mara Linden, young American soprano, was heard in her second local recital yesterday afternoon at Town Hall. Ably assisted at the piano by Tibor Kozma, Miss Linden presented an unusual and carefully devised program, part of which was given over to duets sung with her sister, Janelle Jaynes, mezzo-soprano.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Mayor Joseph S. Clark Jr. said today that he would meet tomorrow with management and union representatives in a bid to prevent a strike of 9,000 Philadelphia Transportation Company employes scheduled for 12:01 A. M. Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Dec, 12 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commisison has accused a liquid fertilizer company of false advertising. The agency also announced today that another such company had agreed to stop representing its fertilizer as a "new discovery."

A merger that may be unique in the history of American advertising agencies was announced over the week-end. The agreement is between McCann-Erickson, Inc., one of the biggest agencies, and the Marschalk Pratt Company, Inc., for thirty years an important specialist in industrial advertising.

" What makes a pound cake fail to rise?" This question from several readers was prompted by a recipe for a white fruit cake in the Sunday Times Magazine in October. The cake was essentially a pound cake with fruits.

St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., has turned out many fine hockey teams. The task had become much more difficult in recent years because of the warmer winters. Nevertheless, coaches at the New Hampshire school somehow were able to keep the caliber of their sextets on a high level.
Four newspaper craft unions approved yesterday two-year contracts negotiated with the Publishers Association of New York City.

LA JOLLA, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Gilbert Shea of Los Angeles won the men's national hard-court tennis championship by defeating Eddie Moylan of Trenton, 6 -- 1, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 4, at the La Jolla Beach and Tennis Club today.
A $10,000,000 program to enlarge and modernize Lenox Hill Hospital was announced yesterday.

Rene Kuehn spent an hour with us the other day in the delegates' lounge of the United Nations discussing wine. He did not speak in any of his official capacities -- as a French delegate to the United Nations, as a member of the French Chamber of Deputies or as Mayor of Ammerschwihr in Alsace.

From the sidewalks of New York came $3.08 for the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. This amount represented fifty-two coins picked up off the streets in the year by Mr. and Mrs. Elias Wabnick; who included their own $21.92 in a check for $25, which the Brooklyn couple sent to the forty-third annual appeal by the fund.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Bernie (Boom-Boom) Geoffrion scored his twentieth goal of the season in the third period tonight to give the Montreal Canadiens a 2-2 tie with the Boston Bruins before a crowd of 10,145.
British sterling moved irregularly last week. After a firm start which saw the pound held around the $2.79 level, lower London cables later partially canceled the earlier improvement.

" BACKGROUND," the National Broadcasting Company's commendable effort to find the meaning behind the day's headlines, undertook at 5:30 yesterday afternoon one of its most difficult assignments: an examination of the problem of morale in the United States Foreign Service.
Last week this column discussed the human propensity for patterns, such as the repetition of historic incidents, and for reading into them analogies that could not possibly stand close scrutiny.

Irmgard Seefried, Viennese soprano, gave a recital Saturday night in Hunter College Auditorium. She was the fourth artist to appear in the school's current concert serices, and scored as heavily with her large audience as at her previous hearings in the same surroundings.
Dr. Leonard Greenburg, Commissioner of Air Pollution Control, said yesterday that the city would provide quarters for the commission's laboratory after it loses its present home.

The arts are famous for being fraternal, in an exclusive sort of way, and there seems to be a need among their operatives for getting together. Where one found Ben Jonson it seems, there would be his friend from Stratford, each having dropped in for a quick one at the Mermaid.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The French Government has asked its economic experts to draw up a plan for a customs union within the franc zone to reinforce existing ties between France and her overseas territories.
The prolific tanker building program of Stavros S. Niarchos, wealthy Greek shipowner, has been extended into 1957 with the ordering of two supertankers from the Kockums Shipyard at Malmo, Sweden.

The John and Mary R. Markle Foundation, 511 Fifth Avenue, so far has granted $3,229,000 to medical schools in the United States and Canada for aid of faculty members through the foundation's "Scholar in Medical Science" program, John M. Russell, executive director and vice president of the fund, reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Government should be permitted to insure bank loans for water conservation projects just the way it now insures private home mortgages, a Texas Representative said today.

It is obviously the desire of the Administration, in creating a new instrument in the Executive branch in the field of economic foreign policy, to reduce rather than add to some of the present duplications. The new Council of Foreign Economic Policy, which is to be headed by former Budget Director Joseph M. Dodge, ought to be a strongly integrating factor in operations that are now often overlapping and confusing.

Dock workers in the Port of New York have ignored the advice of their leaders in the International Longshoremen's Association and have turned down the agreement negotiated on Thanksgiving Day with the New York Shipping Association. This newspaper thought the settlement a good one, with its promise of two strike-free years on the waterfront and provision for arbitration of pierside disputes.

Ninety-nine per cent of Christmas celebrations in the world have "almost no discoverable kinship with Christ's coming," the Rev. Dr. Henry P. Van Dusen, president of Union. Theological Seminary, declared yesterday.
LONDON, Dec. 12 -- Britain's exports and industrial production have increase this year, but at a slower rate than those of West Germany, one of her most active competitors.

In the rotunda of Low Memorial Library, Columbia University, where many degrees have been conferred on men and women of learning and high achievement, twenty-six neighborhood tradesmen and women were honored yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 12 -- It was clear last week that steel output would continue at high levels into the first quarter of next year -- except for a mild slowdown for the holidays. There were those who felt that the strength of steel demand would spill over into the second quarter, too.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 -- Irregular price changes were the rule in grain futures on the Board of Trade last week, but there was an undercurrent of strength which resulted in rallies in wheat and partial recoveries in corn and oats.

The thorny dispute over Cyprus is about to come before the United Nations Political Committee. Here is another problem of nationalism, this time dividing allies, with Greece on one side and Britain and Turkey on the other. The rest of the Western World can only sit back unhappily and wish the British had been more deft in their handling, of the issue and the Greek more understanding and patient.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Administration officials have become concerned about Allied shipments of certain industrial goods, such as generators and Diesel engines, to the Communist world.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 12 -- The Monkey King is a big hit in New Delhi these days. So is the rest of an expertly designed Chinese Communist package of culture, entertainment and propaganda.
Customs receipts for November soared $5,000,000 above the total received in October in the Port of New York, F. B. Laughlin, Assistant Collector of the port, announced yesterday.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 12 -A Syrian Airways Dakota was intercepted by Israeli fighter planes this morning and escorted to Lydda Airport. Four passengers' and five crew members were detained, but one passenger, an American citizen, was released.
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 12. (AP) -- The Peron Government has arrested a ninth Roman Catholic priest since the start of its feud with the church more than a month ago, the federal police said today.

THE Societa Corelli, a remarkable organization of players of stringed instruments, made its Town Hall debut yesterday afternoon. The Societa made its first appearance in greater New York at the Brooklyn Academy of Music last January, but this was its first hearing this side of the Brooklyn Bridge.

A concert in honor of the sixth anniversary of the proclamation of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights was given last night by the Boston Symphony under Charles Munch. The event took place in the General Assembly Hall of the United Nations.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 12 -- The Social Democratic party has decided to wage an all-out fight against the Paris agreements. These provide for the arming of a virtually sovereign West Germany and its incorporation into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization and the projected Western European Union.

A paroled robber, who had been taken for a gangland ride just about a year ago and somehow had survived four bullet wounds, was caught again yesterday morning by killers. They fired four more shots and left him dying in the middle of a Bath Beach street in Brooklyn.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The United States has decided to oppose any Greek proposals to the United Nations General Assembly that raise the possibility of a change of British sovereignty over Cyprus.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -Because the private papers of so many Presidents have been kept haphazardly, former President Truman hopes that the Government some day will publish such papers to be easily available, particularly to historians.

Although the problem of traffic is with us every hour of every day the emphasis here has been on congestion, and the equally important problem of traffic accidents has been all but forgotten. Harried officials keep thinking of new methods to move vehicles and do little to cut the appalling toll of pedestrian or motor vehicle mishaps.
DORTMUND, Germany, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Rex Layne of Lewiston, Utah, and Heinz Neuhaus of Germany, European heavyweight champion, battled to a ten-round draw tonight before 15,000 excited fans.
MONTREAL, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Johnny Greco, former Canadian welterweight champion, was killed early today in a car accident here.
Tankers seized the initiative in the charter market last week with one of the busiest and best weeks in two years.

A Brooklyn woman who worried because her husband did not return home from work on time early yesterday morning set in motion a series of events that prevented a $10,000 theft and enabled the police to rout a burglary gang and capture one thug.

HUNDREDS of curious ordinances that were stale and outmoded several generations back still clutter the municipal codes, according to Dick Hyman, a townsman who studies the subject more or less as a hobby, though he never took up law.

Written by, for and about the Roman Catholic in the legal profession, a new quarterly magazine, The Catholic Lawyer, will come from the presses in January, with later issues in April, July and October.
The Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Long Island presided yesterday at the 11 A. M. high mass commemorating the patronal festival of the Church of St. Mary the Virgin.
TOKYO, Dec. 12 -- All press dispatches from ships or installations of the United States Seventh Fleet in the Formosa area will be subject to censorship.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Al Dorow's four touchdown passes paced the Washington Redskins to a 37-20 victory over the Chicago Cardinals today in a game the Tribe dedicated to their dead team-mate, Dave Sparks.

In the last four or five years Burl Ives has been so busy writing books, singing for the radio and making television, movie and theatrical appearances that he has not given a New York recital. But on Saturday night the folk singer returned to Town Hall to give the first of two programs he is giving there this season.

Instead of steaming south to the warm waters of the Caribbean and South America, the Moore-McCormack passenger liner Brazil will spend the next five days at her Canal Street berth, because of engine trouble.

Lawrence and Elisabeth Hanson, an English husband-and-wife writing team, have a new biography on Random House's list for early next year. It is "Nobel Savage: The Life of Paul Gaugin," which includes new material on the Van Gogh-Gaugin friendship.

MOUNTAINSIDE, N. J., Dec. 12. (AP) -- Nat Holman, City College of New York basketball coach, asserted today that there was just as much gambling on basketball games as ever. He predicted further college scandals.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman said last night that a way must be found to improve and expand educational facilities in state and nation.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- Anthony Nutting said today that Britain stood "foursquare" behind Washington in efforts to obtain the release of United States airmen imprisoned in Communist China.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 12 -- Second place in the Eastern Conference of the National Football League went to the Philadelphia Eagles today. Jim Trimble's hard-hitting men amassed 20 points in the first half and defeated the New York Giants, 29 -- 14, before 28,449 fans at Connie Mack Stadium.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 12 -- Several Dutch economists under the lead of Prof. F. De Roos are strongly advocating revaluation of the guilder. In a speech last week Professor De Roos said that alterations in exchange rates were allowed as an instrument of economic policy.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 3 -- Turkey is preparing to train a new type of Army officer to help her play the role of diplomatic and military pivot between Europe and the Middle East.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 12 (AP) --The Naval Academy said tonight that three students from the University of Mississippi, Navy's opponent in the New Year's Day Sugar Bowl football game, were caught attempting to kidnap Navy's mascot goat early today.

MINNEAPOLIS, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Minneapolis Lakers broke the Knicks' three-game hold over them by winning, 80 -- 73, today Clyde Lovellette pitched in 22 points and the Lakers controlled the game after the first minutes of the National Basketball Association game.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The United Nations reported tonight that no reply had yet been received to Mr. Hammarskjold's message to Chou En-lai, the Chinese Communist Premier, regarding the United States airmen held prisoner.

PARIS, Dec. 12 -- The Organization for European Economic Cooperation reported today a marked upswing in France's economy. However, the continued deficit in her balance of payments was cited to show that she is far from complete recovery.

MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 12 -Bavaria is involved in a church-state struggle that has run through centuries of European history. The issue constitutes a latent threat to the unity of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's Christian Democratic Union and the political stability of West Germany.
Seven new films, including imports from Japan and France, are slated to arrive in first-run theatres this week. The programs follow:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 -- All-white neighborhoods in San Francisco are accepting Negroes, Chinese - Americans and members of other minorities without fuss or bother.

MANHASSET, L. I., Dec. 12 -- Long Island won the Payne Whitney Memorial court tennis doubles tournament today. In the final round in the Greentree court of John Hay (Jock) Whitney it defeated New York, 3 -- 0.
MOSCOW, Dec. 12 -- Tamara Kyrillovna Kareva, a blonde 30-year-old lawyer, Communist party member and former railroad conductor, had an easy victory at the polls in Moscow today.

With the resignation of Charles Nagel, director of the Brooklyn Museum, an outstanding cultural institution, the Borough of Brooklyn and, in fact, all of New York will lose an inspired and dedicated worker for the public good.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Agriculture Secretary Ezra T. Benson is expected to announce early this week how much sugar the United States plans to consume in 1955.

Details of the Board of Education's school building program for 1955 -- the largest in city history -- were announced yesterday by Charles J. Bensley, chairman of the board's buildings and sites committee.

ROME, Dec. 12 -- Scenes of religious fervor and devotion to Pius XII occurred in St. Peter's Basilica this morning when a broadcast carried the Pope's voice to many thousands gathered in the largest church in Christendom.
Noah Webster himself would be hard put to keep up with today's bewildering variety of fabric terms. Here are some new fabrics and some older ones that have been improved:

THE Folksbiene, the dramatic group of the fraternal Workmen's Circle, opened its fortieth season Saturday night on the Lower East Side with the first production in this country of the late Sammy Groneman's comedy with music, "The King and the Cobbler.''
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The country's total tax burden is being borne more and more by moderate -income and low-income families, the Congress of Industrial Organizations contended today.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Hal Wallis, bubbling with enthusiasm over the way his filmed version of Tennessee Williams' "The Rose Tattoo" is taking shape at the Paramount studio, has begun discussions with the playwright about putting his "Summer and Smoke" before the cameras next fall.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Representatives of Lloyd's of London said today the $3,000,000 fine imposed on Aristotle Socrates Onassis' whaler fleet by the Peruvian Government would be paid tomorrow. The penalty was imposed for allegedly operating in waters claimed by Peru as territorial.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 -- Ed Sanders, Navy heavyweight boxer hurt in a professional bout last night, died at 4:30 P. M. today in Massachusetts General Hospital.
The Rockefeller Foundation yesterday reinforced its recent admonition against possible Congressional attempts to regulate or control educational foundations.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 12 (UP) -- Merton Tice, National Commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, urged Americans tonight to stop buying Christmas ornaments and decorations manufactured in Soviet Russia or her satellites.

LONDON, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- A 57-year-old widow was promoted to the rank of Deputy Premier of Czechoslovakia today. She became the woman with the biggest Government post behind the Iron Curtain since Rumania ousted Mme. Ana Pauker as Foreign Minister.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Chicago Bears' rookie quarter-backs, Zeke Bratkowski and Ed Brown, passed for three touchdowns today for a 28-to-24 upset victory over the Detroit Lions before 37,240 fans. The triumph enabled the Bears to capture second place in the Western Conference of the National Football League.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 12 -- Mr. Richardson said in Brisbane today that his Rhodes scholarship would not affect his tennis career. He was a happy man as he acknowledged a flood of congratulations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- As Mrs. Richard M. Nixon sees it, this city's newsmen "are all such individualists" they cannot get together on their kicking -- even in a chorus line.

COLOMBO, Ceylon, Dec. 12 -The Ceylonese Government will impose a temporary ban on the export of the rare herb ekaweriya, which is who being sent in quantities to the United States for medicinal preparations in the treatment of high blood pressure.
Without a doubt, "Lunatics and Lovers," which takes over the Broadhurst at 8 o'clock this evening, represents a complete about-face for the author, Sidney Kingsley.

BALTIMORE, Dec. 12 (UP) -- Assistant Secretary of Labor J. Ernest Wilkins said today that there was danger the world would be broken up into racial blocs such as "Asia for the Asians, Africa for Negroes, Europe for white people and America for whoever can get in."

Richard Thenebe, a pianist of West Hartford, Conn., gave his first New York recital last night at Town Hall. Schubert's Sonata in B flat, Op. Post., was his major selection. His program also included the Bach-Busoni Organ Prelude and Fugue in E flat, Mozart's A minor Rondo and a Chopin group.

Just when it appeared that the New York Rangers were only skating uphill at Madison Square Garden last night, they scored a goal. It was an important one, too, for it enabled them to tie the score at 1 -- 1 with the Toronto Maple Leafs.

Some of the city's department heads and their deputies have notified Mayor Wagner that they will be forced to quit their jobs for more lucrative positions unless they receive salary increases. The Mayor disclosed this situation last night in response to questions from reporters who took part in his monthly Mayor's Conference panel televised from station WABD. He declined after the broadcast to name the men involved.

In this world of fear and threatened violence the voices of men who act without fear and who threaten no violence can still be heard. This is the significance of the situation created by the resolution of the United Nations Assembly declaring the detention by the Chinese of eleven American airmen illegal and calling upon Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold to take "continuing and unremitting steps" to obtain their release.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., Dec. 12 -- Hamilton Richardson Jr., a student at Tulane University and one of the principal hopes of the United States for recapturing the Davis Cup from Australia; was among thirty-two named today to Rhodes Scholarships.
A collection of twelve paintings by twelve American artists was presented yesterday to the Government of Israel by Mrs. Herman Shulman, owner of a large collection of contemporary art.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The Bill of Rights was validated in blood here nearly two hundred years ago and has since been validated in blood first by France and later by other nations inspired by this country's example, Pierre Donzelot said here today.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) -- Bob Rosburg of San Francisco, a 28-year-old newcomer to big-time golf, sank long putts all over the course today and won the $10,000 Miami open tournament with a 7 under par 273.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -John Paton Davies Jr., diplomat who was dismissed a month ago, said today there was virtually no job security in the Foreign Service and a candidate for a diplomatic career would be prudent to "know another trade."
The Transit Authority is trying to hold the fare on the city-owned lines at 15 cents by doing "what it has to do" despite criticism, Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey declared yesterday.
CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 12 -- A sound, spirited Airedale, Ch. Weycroft Wyldboy of Clairedale, became best in show tonight in the twenty-third event of the Camden County Kennel Club.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -Senator J. William Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, one of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's sharpest critics, has received an apology from a McCarthy supporter who sent him an abusive letter during the recent censure debate.
LONDON, Monday, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- Official figures published here today showed that American exports to Canada have increased in the last four years while British exports have fallen.
GENEVA, Dec. 12 -- Hugh S. Gibson, retired United States diplomat and director of the Intergovernmental Committee for European Migration, died this morning at the age of 71.

Events tonight: "La Traviata," Metropolitan Opera, 8:30; Madeline Foley, 'cellist, Town Hall, 8:30; Mannes Chamber Orchestra, Mannes College of Music, 8:30; Mieczyslaw Horszowski, pianist, Lexington Avenue Y. M. Y. W. H. A., 8:40; Music in the Making, Cooper Union Great Hail, 8:30.
The United States Olympic hockey committee yesterday established a goal of $25,000 to cover expenses to send a team to the winter games in Italy in January, 1956.
Maternity fashions are offered in today's patterns. Scooped necklines, wide collars, circular skirts and fine pleating are all available in styles designed for the mother-to-be.

NASSAU, Bahamas, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Masten Gregory, young sports car pilot from Kansas City, drove his Ferrari to victory in Nassau's first trophy race today. Marquis de Portago of Spain was second in the thrilling 210-mile contest.

An invitation to play the 1956 North-South game at Hobart College, Geneva, N. Y., was accepted yesterday in the closing session of the United States Intercollegiate Lacrosse Association's annual meeting at the Statler Hotel.

Copies of "Do and Dare," "Brave and Bold," "Luck and Pluck" and the other Horatio Alger Jr. classics can still be found in second-hand bookshops. At the drop of a coin they will resume their preachments of selfless devotion to an always-appreciative boss.
Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, who shoulders a large responsibility for the earth's atomic destiny, took the optimistic view yesterday about the outcome of nuclear warfare.
NOT long ago Gil McDougald of the Yankees dropped by for a brief hello. "Whom do you like for Most Valuable Player in our league?" he asked.

Second-grade school children will be substituted for pregnant women in the mass inoculations against polio scheduled for next Spring, Basil O'Connor, president of the National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis, announced here yesterday.

VIENNA, Dec. 12 -- The suspicion that the West German Republic still regards Austria as part of Germany and fear that Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will be unable to persuade his followers to annul the Austro-German Anschluss (union) Act of 1938 seems to be growing in Vienna.

DUESSELDORF, Germany, Dec. 12 West Germany on the eve of rearmament is a very reluctant dragon. Its young men don't want to be soldiers. Its old men object to higher taxes in order to finance an army. Its industrialists are unenthusiastic about the prospects of making weapons.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 12 -- American college enrollments this fall have shown an increase for the second consecutive year, according to Dr. Raymond Walters, president of the University of Cincinnati.
Sidney M. McChain, who spent most of his 96 years setting type on stories about other people, can read some type about himself this morning.

The Hakoah eleven of the American Soccer League downed the Gjoa S. C. of the National League, 5 to 0, at the Brooklyn Soccer Field yesterday. The defeat eliminated Gjoa from the National Challenge Cup competition sponsored by the United States Soccer Football Association.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (UP) -- The Los Angeles Rams honored their retiring team-mate, End Elroy (Crazylegs) Hirsch, today by defeating the Green Bay Packers, 35 -- 27, before 38,839 fans in Memorial Coliseum.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 12 -- A municipal committee has been working since Wednesday to halt conflicts over differences on religious questions here. Its members are Deputy Mayor Eliahu Eliachar of the General Zionist party; Rabbi Moshe Porush, also a Deputy Mayor, of the orthodox Agudath Israel party, and Mordecai Friedman of the Histadrut, the national labor federation.
BRYAN, Tex., Dec. 12 (AP) -- superintendent of schools in Duval County stands convicted of pocketing school funds and faces a two-year prison term.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -- President and Mrs. Eisenhower attended services today at the National Presbyterian Church, where a missionary who had been imprisoned and "brainwashed" by the Chinese Communists helped administer Holy Communion to them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) -- The Census Bureau reported today it was ready to begin "immediately after the first of the year" its biggest counting operation since 1950 -- the 1954 censuses of business, manufactures and mineral industries.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (UP) -The National Labor Relations Board refused today to consider a California radio-television labor dispute in the first application of its policy against handling some types of cases.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 12 -- The leader of the Awami (People's) League said tonight he would demand that Governor General Ghulam Mohammed immediately restore the People's League Government in East Pakistan.

The United States Department of Agriculture's December estimate for the 1954-55 cotton crop pushed prices of cotton futures higher last week. Active contracts traded on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 80 cents to $1.90 a bale.
A new effort to expand the nation's chemurgic research program was announced yesterday by the National Farm Chemurgic Council, Inc.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- The trustees of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace honored Dr. James T. Shotwell, president emeritus of the institution, tonight at a dinner in the international center of the Carnegie building, 345 East Forty-sixth Street.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 12 (AP) -- Cleveland today became the first team in history to win a National Football League division championship five consecutive years.

WHEN William Ewart Gladstone died in 1898 at the age of 88 he was "the most venerated and influential statesman in the world." Five years later he was the subject of one of the most admired biographies in English, Lord Morley's "Gladstone." Nevertheless, time has not been kind to the reputation of "the grand old man" of English politics.

The holiday season swept into New York yesterday, as the memorial trees were lighted along Park Avenue, and crowds jammed the midtown area to view the Christmas displays. All afternoon and into the evening automobiles edged bumper to bumper along Fifth, Madison and Park Avenues and in the cross streets from Forty-second to Fifty-second.

The seventh week of opera at the Metropolitan, which opens with a performance of Mozart's "Le Nozze di Figaro" on Monday evening, Dec. 20, will be featured by the return of Puccini's "Tosca" to the repertory.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 12 -- A special meeting of stockholders of the German Gold Discount Bank, convened by court order in accordance with the statutory rights of a minority, will be held in Berlin on Thursday. It will tackle one of the toughest problems arising in the process of settlement of German pre-war foreign debts -- the claims of the foreign holders of its preferential shares.

Since 1947, the Soviet Government has made available to its people the writings of only about half a dozen prominent American writers and has rigidly excluded most American writings "which do not directly support the official Soviet thesis of American decadence."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- President Eisenhower will move this week to enlist strong bipartisan support for his legislative program in the incoming Democratic-controlled Congress.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 12 -- Dr. Robley C. Williams, University of California biophysicist has been selected for the John Scott medal, one of America's oldest and most coveted scientific awards.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The long dispute between the United States and Panama over money and land in the Canal Zone seems to be about over. A new treaty may be signed next month, replacing the treaty of 1903.

Suppose you found yourself in some grim situation of life -- the serious illness of a loved one, a disabling injury, a shattered home life -- then suddenly found at your side thousands of friends offering whatever help they could muster. Would not some of the gloom of the moment vanish and life look brighter?
The pledge of the Legion of Decency was renewed by congregations attending masses in all churches of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York yesterday.
Moura Lympany, after a three-year absence from the local scene, returned to Carnegie Hall last night for a piano recital.
LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 12 -- Arthur Knapp Jr., at the helm of his Agony, won today's frostbite regatta at the Larchmont Yacht Club.

I have recently returned from Afghanistan. This is a country now in a vortex of international political maneuvering, caught as it is between the efforts of its powerful neighbor, Russia, to win it over, and the attempts by the United States to prevent this possibility.

The fifteen players of the Collegium Musicum of New York presented their second concert of the season late yesterday afternoon at Carl Fischer Hall. As in the past, they combined in various groupings for different works. This time Jack Kreiselman, clarinetist, was their assisting artist.

When mother and dad go out to buy new shoes for junior, they naturally expect to get the right fit for a pair of young feet that sometimes appear to have grown overnight. Selecting toys "to fit" the ever-changing stages of a young child's development also is important, a child study specialist reminds parents in a recently published leaflet.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 -- The American Red Cross today set a 1955 goal of $85,000,000. It appointed Stanley C. Allyn, president of the National Cash Register Company of Dayton, Ohio, national campaign chairman.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $71,084,587,242. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:

HONG KONG, Dec. 12 (Reuters) -- Communist China announced details today of a Chinese-Burmese agreement for closer trade and diplomatic relations. The announcement came as Premier U Nu concluded his visit to Peiping.
An Army chaplain urged members of a church congregation yesterday to prepare their sons spiritually for service in the armed forces.
TOKYO, Monday, Dec. 13 -- Communist China asserted today that the case of the thirteen Americans -- eleven airmen and two civilians -- arrested as "spies" was none of the United Nations' business.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Great Britain's top soccer team, the Wolves, beat the best Hungarian eleven, 3 -- 2, at Wolverhampton tonight to restore the luster of Britain's prowess in her national game.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Ambitious cultural as well as official meetings of the United Nations have been planned for the tenth anniversary celebration next June in San Francisco.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Glenn L. Emmons, Indian Commissioner, said today there was no truth in reports that "liquidation'' of the Bureau of Indian Affairs was desired so that Indian land might be bought by whites "for a song."

Twelve trains of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad were delayed up to an hour toward the end of the evening rush hour yesterday when an eastbound commuters' train was stopped by mechanical trouble. Nine of the other trains carried commuters to Westchester and Connecticut, and two were through trains to Boston and to New Haven.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- After the first session of the Administration's all-day briefing at the White House of the Republican leaders in Congress Senator Millikin of Colorado reported that everything was "harmonious -- like a cooing dove." Undoubtedly discordant notes will recur in the party symphony as time goes on.
Business circles, with isolated exceptions, were not surprised yesterday at the word of White House plans to ask that the corporate and excise tax structure be retained.

NEWARK, Dec. 13 -- A union longshoreman told the Waterfront Commission today that he had paid more than $500 to an official of the International Longshoremen's Association to get work on the Newark piers.

Short and trade covering firmed coffee prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Strength in the December positions was reflected across the board. The gains wiped out the losses of the two previous trading days.
Glamour goes to the feet with this season's at-home slippers. They range from brightly colored felt boots to mink mules.

A narrative history of the adventures and explorers of ancient times who discovered new seas and shores around the globe has been written by Paul Herrmann. It will be called "Conquest by Man." The author recounts the activities of Stone Age amber traders, Egyptian incense merchants, Trojan warlords, Arab slavers and Viking seafarers who did much to expand the world of their day.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- President Eisenhower feels the United States now must concentrate on developing economic weapons in the "cold war" because "we are going to hear less gunfire and see less blood flow."

In 1934 Bill Terry, then the manager of the world champion Giants, inquired: "Is Brooklyn still in the league?" To this day he probably regrets having asked the question. For the sixth-place Dodgers knocked the Giants out of the pennant race that season.
Old friends clashed yesterday when Nat Holman, head basketball coach at C. C. N. Y., repeated his assertion that gambling on the outcome of court games is going on now as much as ever.
JERUSALEM, Dec. 13 -- Premier Moshe Sharett tonight voiced in the Knesset (Parliament) the "indignation" of Israel over the trial of eleven Jews in Egypt.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Senator Clinton P. Anderson called on the Securities and Exchange Commission today to defer approval of the financing plan for the Dixon-Yates power contract. The New Mexico Democrat suggested a delay until the new Democratic-controlled Congress had a chance to review the disputed contract next month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Rear Admiral Lewis L. Strauss, head of the Atomic Energy Commission, said today the United States was "making very rapid and satisfactory progress" and continued to lead Russia in the nuclear weapons field.

An allocation of $93,740,000 in the city's capital budget for construction of water works at Cannonsville on the Delaware has been attacked more than once by the Citizens Budget Commission. Ultimately, the works will cost this city at least $200,000,000, yet this expenditure will enable the city to meet its water needs for little more than thirty years.

THE ascent of Mount Everest in 1953 by the British expedition led by Sir John Hunt was a triumph of skill and courage which deserves the world acclaim it has received. But the cheering, official ceremonies, books, lectures and general hoop-la have obscured a pertinent fact of some interest: Everest may not be the highest mountain in the world.

CHARLESTON, S. C., Dec. 13 (AP) -- John E. Sauer, West Point quarterback ten years ago, today received a five-year contract as head football coach at the Citadel. The announcement of Sauer's appointment was made by Gen. Mark W. Clark, president of the military college.
St. Francis College gained a 9-0 lead at the outset and went on to defeat Toronto University, 90 -- 49, at the Second Corp Armory in Brooklyn last night.
