CORNING, N. Y., Dec. 13--Dr. Edward U. Condon has resigned as director of research and development for the Corning Glass Works, the company announced today.
Rudy Garcia, hard-hitting Californian, moved up another notch in his bid for the featherweight boxing title by winning at the Eastern Parkway Arena in Brooklyn last night.

Reading descriptions of the Neediest Cases is painful experience to many of us. It is painful not only because we read of pain, but because we read of pain that is strange to us. Modern living is compartmentalized. We live in neighborhoods where the economic reach above and below our own station is limited.

VANCOUVER, Dec. 13 (Canadian Press) -- Premier W. A. C. Bennett of British Columbia announced late today that an agreement has been signed for construction of a natural gas pipeline from the Peace River area through British Columbia to the United States border.
GALVESTON, Tex., Dec. 13 (UP) -- Alabama's Attorney General was arrested today in a mental hospital on a charge of murder in the shooting of the anti-vice crusader who was nominated to succeed him.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- President Eisenhower held a stag dinner tonight for nineteen guests, including friends from the Augusta, Ga., National Golf Club and the Cedar Point Club at Toledo, Ohio, where the President recently hunted.
Carmine G. DeSapio, Democratic national committeeman and leader of the New York County Democratic organization, has decided not to seek re-election as a member of the Board of Elections.

Working hit and miss, trial and error, the United Nations seems to be setting up a body of precedents on the tricky problem of what is a "domestic" issue. The U. N. is specifically ordered by its Charter to keep out of the internal affairs of its member states.

A murder trial witness threw the "coins of Judas" at the feet of an assistant district attorney yesterday, and accused him of offering leniency in the courts in return for testimony that would send another man to death.

After seventy years of self-government, according to a story in the financial section of this newspaper on Sunday, the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange may shortly be added to the list of commodity markets coming under the regulation of the Commodity Exchange Authority.

WESTPORT, Conn., Dec. 13 -A 200-year-old farmhouse here will be burned to the ground Wednesday night in a fund-raising drive to aid a victim of poliomyelitis. The building is situated on the Boston Post Road, opposite the state police barracks.

Thomas J. Curran, leader of the New York County Republican organization, implied last night that the defeat of all but one of the Republican candidates on the state ticket this fall could be attributed to poor strategy.

The obituary of Prof. Marjorie Anderson which appeared in The Times on Dec. 1 gave a modest account of her scholarly achievements. But this great scholar was as great a teacher as she was a scholar. It is therefore fitting that a few words of praise be spoken in her memory by one who was her student.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 (AP) -- R. Burdell Bixby, secretary to Governor Dewey since 1950, will become one of Mr. Dewey's law partners when the Democrats take over the State Administration.
The money market continued firm yesterday and Federal funds were quoted at 1 7/16 per cent, unchanged from Friday's level.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The United States charged today that the Soviet Union was shipping jet fuel to Communist China for its long-planned attack on Formosa. In the last year, the United States said, 90,000 tons of petroleum were shipped from Black Sea ports to China.

Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams said yesterday that he preferred "far fewer" arrests as against those made "indiscriminately" to pad a policeman's record. He added that he had little use for a policeman "who goes around building up an arrest record."

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Commissioner Bert Bell of the National Football League today lifted a seven-year suspension against Merle Hapes. The former Giants halfback now is an assistant coach of the Hamilton Tiger-Cats of the Canadian League.

BALBOA, C. Z., Dec. 12 -- Commissary purchasing privileges for 17,000 Panamanians living outside the Canal Zone will be withdrawn under the provisions of the Panama-United States canal treaty about to be concluded.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Redlegs, who have operated at a loss for every National League baseball season since 1949, wound up in 1954 with a net profit of $68,065.62.

A community collection of blood will take place today from noon to 6 P. M. at the Central Red Cross Chapter of Queens, 92-32 Union Hall Street Jamaica, Queens. Appointments may be made by calling REpublic 9-6880.

Damage suits totaling $200,000 were filed yesterday in Federal Court against Mrs. Elizabeth N. Graham, known in the cosmetic field as Elizabeth Arden, who owns the Maine Chance Farm racing stable. The suits are in connection with a head - on collision last Oct. 17 at Belmont Park between two horses.

One hundred and sixty-three years after adoption of the Bill of Rights as part of the American Constitution we still cannot afford to take it for granted. Sometimes crudely and sometimes subtly, assaults are constantly being made on the guarantees of individual freedom that are embedded in the Bill of Rights.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Never again I've had enough." With those words, Tommy Collins, a featherweight boxer, said today he"%vas retiring from the ring for the third and last time.

R. Leslie Mullen has been elected executive vice president of the Lehigh Structural Steel Company, Allentown, Pa., succeeding William H. Mohr, a co-founder of the company, who recently resigned as executive vice president and plant manager.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 13 -- The Indonesian Government has promised "further efforts" to gain control of West New Guinea.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Syria contemplates asking the Security Council to take up the airliner case, Ahmed Shukairi, vice chairman of Syria's delegation to the United Nations, announced today.
The board of directors of the Transportation Association of America has elected Harold F. Hammond of Washington executive vice president of the organization, succeeding the late Donald D. Conn.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 13 -- A meeting to lay plans to combat desegregation in the Methodist Church has been called here for tomorrow morning. It may draw Methodist laymen and ministers from five Southeastern states.

On Dec. 14, 1911 -- forty-three years ago today -- Roald Amundsen, Norwegian explorer, reached the South Pole. He had been planning an expedition to the North Pole when the news of Peary's conquest of that objective reached him.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Some 1,250,000 cotton farmers Continued on Page 58, Column 3 in twenty states will be eligible to vote tomorrow for or against a sharp cutback in 1955 cotton acreage.

MONTREAL, Dec. 13 (Canadian Press) -- The designer and buyer of a new British airliner said today "the various modifications made for Trans-Canada Air Lines were almost without exception," to insure reliable operations under North American climate conditions.
Kenny Lane, 136 3/4, of Muskegon, Mich., won a split decision from Danny Jo Perez in a ten-round fight at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. Perez, who lives on New York's West Side, weighed 139 3/4.
The cotton futures market was barely steady on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday. Prices eased 6 to 11 points in a moderate volume of business.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 13 -- The High Authority of the European Coal and Steel Community, with headquarters at Luxembourg, allocated loans today totaling almost $60,000,000 to collieries and iron ore mines of member countries. The funds are to be used for modernizing equipment and increasing productivity.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- A White House spokesman said tonight it would be "foolhardy" for the Republican party to approach the 1956 elections with any other idea than to draft President Eisenhower for a second term.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would receive bids Dec. 21 on $28,855,000 of six-month notes for the temporary financing of two State-aided low-rent developments, Carver Houses, Manhattan, and Forest Houses, the Bronx. The notes will be dated Jan. 17 and will come due July 18.
The Chain Belt Company, supplier of materials-handling, power-transmission and waste-treatment equipment, had a net profit in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 of $2,363,625 on sales of $39,550,978.

Short sales "ain't what they used to be" as an indication of market trends. The practice of selling borrowed stock in the hope of replacing it later at a lower price has continued at such a pace throughout the steady rise of the market since Election Day as to prompt a market letter on it yesterday from Jacques Coe Co.
Directors of the Chicago and North Western Railway Company omitted dividend action yesterday on both the preferred and common stocks for 1954.
ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 5 -- The tour of American and European capitals by Emperor Haile Selassie this year is symbolic of this nation's effort to break out of its 3,000-year isolation.

An around-the-clock ban on parking on Fifth Avenue between Forty-second and Sixtieth Streets will go into effect Thursday. Heretofore parking has been prohibited there only from 8 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday through Friday.
In the absence of the views of Tammany Hall, Queens Democrats failed yesterday for the second time in a month to break a deadlock over choice of a county leader.
By the end of this month approximately 1,100 Kentuckians will have visited New York for a four-day whirl, taking in some of the Broadway shows and other sights.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (UP) -- The life insurance industry told Congress today that the Federal tax rate on insurance companies was "an onerous burden on thrift."

"The Senate vote of Dec. 2 was a clear condemnation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy but not a clear repudiation of the "ism" associated with the Wisconsin Republican's name, Senator Herbert H. Lehman declared last night.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Lawrence T. (Buck) Shaw, who produced seventy-one victories against thirty-nine defeats and four ties as the only head coach the San Francisco Forty-Niners have had in nine years of professional football, was discharged today.

Officials of the United States Council of the International Chamber of Commerce expressed gratification yesterday over United Nations action urging under-developed countries to take practical steps for encouraging private foreign investment.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 13 -- The Government warned today it would deal severely with male Turks who wore fezzes, turbans or other traditional Moslem headgear outlawed in 1925 by Mustafa Kemal Ataturk, founder of the Turkish republic. In an effort to break with Turkey's Ottoman past, he decreed that Turkish men must wear hats with brims.
Edward J. Shaughnessy, district director of the Immigration and Naturalization Service, said yesterday that he had not been instructed to change the policy of where detained aliens are to be held.
Arbitration may be attempted to reconcile the differences between the Saudi Arabian Government and the Arabian American Oil Company (Aramco) over the A. S. Onassis tanker arrangement.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- An Army board of review has upheld the ten-year prison sentence for Cpl. Edward S. Dickenson, 23 years old, who was convicted of collaboration with the enemy while a prisoner in Korea.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 13 -- The second of the twelve American Federation of Labor unions involved in the thirteen-month-old department store strike ended its walkout today.

The steel industry's operating rate, which has been climbing steadily since the first week in September, is scheduled to dip slightly this week to 81.5 per cent of theoretical capacity, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- British Government securities continued to fall today and many of the industrial leaders declined in sympathy. However, a late rally in gilt edged stocks reduced losses in most cases to around one-quarter of 1 per cent and most of the changes elsewhere were not big.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 13 -- The Israelis released today five passengers of a Syrian Airways plane that was forced by Israeli fighters to land at Lydda Airport yesterday. A sixth passenger, an American, already had been released.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The Foreign Office had no comment tonight on the remarks of Anthony Nutting, chief British delegate to the United Nations, that a Communist attack on Formosa would involve Britain as a member of the United Nations. Mr. Nutting's remarks were made on a Washington television program.

A new program of aid to education, involving total contributions of $450,000 to 138 privately supported colleges and universities, was announced yesterday by the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey). The gifts are to be used for undergraduate study.

People like beer, and its popularity as a beverage for home consumption is at a record high. This is the finding of a national survey made for the United States Brewers Foundation by Crossley, Inc., market research organization.

CAIRO, Dec. 13 -- Ralph K. Hansen, the American aboard the plane, said tonight that he planned to sue the Israeli Government for $100,000 damages. The Wayne, N. J., resident charged that Israel had kidnapped the plane and its passengers.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 13 -- Senator Herman Welker called today for corrective legislation if the Justice Department found itself unable to "deal adequately" with John W. Powell, editor of the now-defunct China Monthly Review.

RENOUNCING gravity for the moment, Sidney Kingsley has written a farce. "Lunatics and Lovers," which opened at the Broadhurst last evening, is in the tradition of "Up In Mabel's Room" and "Getting Gertie's Garter."
Your recent articles and pictures comparing the streets of New York City with other streets in large cities throughout the world with regard to cleanliness are very interesting.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- United Nations officials said tonight that no reply had been received to Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold's proposal that he go to Peiping to discuss the release of eleven imprisoned United States airmen.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The North Atlantic Council, meeting here this week, is expected to authorize military planning based on the use of atomic and other new weapons. But the Council is likely to leave the final decision on these arms to the member Governments.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 13 -- Knowledgeable Americans and Indians in this city are beginning to talk -- with some caution -- of a coming upturn in relations between their countries.

A rent cut to $1 a month on all apartments in two Harlem tenements was ordered yesterday by State Rent Administrator Joseph D. McGoldrick as the result of a recent fire in which one man lost his life and nine firemen were overcome.

BRINKLEY, Ark., Dec. 13 (AP) -- An ex-convict and two women were held for questioning today in the slaying yesterday of Mrs. Milton Fuller. Mrs. Fuller, 25 years old, was beaten to death with a piece of stovewood in the bedroom of her home here.

If architectural plans do not miscarry, the quietest spot in the vicinity of La Guardia Airport will be the new hotel close by it that will be opened tomorrow morning. Hotel La Guardia is at 100th Street and Ditmars Boulevard.

The home craftsman with workshop facilities can now obtain kits with which he may make reproductions of eighteenth century furniture. There are sixteen items in a collection modeled from authentic pieces from the Philadelphia Museum and from private collections.

LONDON, Dec. 13--Britain has been making discreet inquiries in Peiping and among friendly Asian statesmen about the chances of getting the release of the United States airmen imprisoned in Communist China. The results so far have been depressing.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Treasury reported tonight that its short-term borrowing costs have risen to the highest point in eleven months.

An annual scholarship for attendance at the Vassar College Summer Institute in Family and Community Living has been set up to honor Dr. and Mrs. Henry Noble MacCracken. Announcement of the award was made yesterday at a meeting of the sponsoring group, the board of directors of the Manhattan-Westchester region of the National Conference of Christians and Jews.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- Former President Truman gave his support today to President Eisenhower's policy of patience and calmness in dealing with the Communists. Mr. Truman declared that the criticism aimed at his successor by Senator Joseph R. McCarthy was not justified.
Retailers who predicted that this year's Christmas business in New York would top last year's by 5 per cent are wondering now whether they weren't too conservative.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -Senator William F. Knowland, Senate Republican leader, said today that proposed changes in rules for Senate investigating committees "undoubtedly will be taken up" early in the next session of Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- United States manufacturers of electric light bulbs led the opposition here today to any tariff cuts affecting their products in a proposed reciprocal trade agreement with Japan.

The Society for Social Responsibility of Science, a group of 300 scientists and engineers dedicated to the promotion of the uses of science for peaceful ends, has failed in its effort to become affiliated with the American Association for the Advancement of Science, it was learned yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) The Federal Power Commission said today it could not consider granting the full amount of a $12,127,000-a-year increase in wholesale natural gas rates sought by the Panhandle Eastern Pipe Line Company.

The National Securities and Research Corporation announced yesterday the formation of an atomic energy and electronics division. Henry J. Simon Jr., president of the mutual fund organization, in making the announcement said: "The future development of, atomic energy and electronics undoubtedl ,qll have an increasing influence on most of the corporations whose securities are included in the assets of the National Securities Series of mu!tual investment funds now agi gregating more thah $200,000,000."
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture report on today's livestock markets follows:

THE beak-busting business is a sorry trade at best. But boxing is probably too tough ever to be killed, although the folks who make their living by it seem to be trying hard to strangle it. Of recent weeks there have been charges and countercharges, stories of new fixes and old fixes, two deaths in the ring last week-end and other evidences of tattletale gray in pugilism's dirty wash.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- Sir Anthony Eden, Foreign Secretary, told the House of Commons today that a report published by a Parliamentary select committee had given rise to "misleading impressions" about the amount of money spent on Britain's foreign service.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The Shah of Iran, Mohammed Riza Pahlevi, and Queen Soraya were received in Washington today with a twenty-one-gun salute and full military honors.

Allan B. Kline, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation, predicted yesterday that opponents of the new flexible farm-price support system would be unable to restore rigid supports in the next Congress.
MOSCOW, Dec. 13 -- With each passing day the policy that Moscow proposes to follow if West Germany is armed seems to become clearer and firmer.
A three-for-two stock split was approved yesterday by directors of the Harris-Seybold Company, Cleveland manufacturers of printing machinery and associated equipment.

BRISBANE, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Confident Americans and upset-minded Swedes got a look at the closely guarded center court today in a final three-hour workout for the week-end's interzone Davis Cup tennis finals.
PARIS, Dec. 13 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced today a program for spending $226,800,000 in 1955 on air and naval bases, pipelines and communications.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Carl Braden, a newspaper man, tonight was convicted of advocating sedition. His punishment was fixed at fifteen years' imprisonment and a $5,000 fine.

BEERSHEBA, Israel, Nov. 22 -- Israeli pioneers of the new generation are cutting their eyeteeth on the Negev. The popular idea of a vast mineral and agricultural potential in the desert is not for them. They are chewing away on the limited number of possibilities that they can make pay off.
Industrial Arts students at New York University are employing Thodar, a seven-foot robot, to play Santa Clause for needy children.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 13 -- Erich Ollenhauer, leader of the Social Democratic Opposition, rejected today Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's plea for cooperation. The latter asked for moderation in Wednesday's foreign policy debate and Socialist assistance in formulating this country's military conscription laws after ratification of the Paris agreements.

A selected group of shareholders, each owning 200 or more shares of Rice-Stix, Inc., common, will be offered 50 cents a share for options on their stock until Dec. 24, according to Reliance Manufacturing Company. Reliance recently closed its books on an offer of $42 a share for Rice-Stix common.

More publicity than usual has been given to the Rhodes Scholar selections this year because included is Hamilton Richardson from Tulane, one of the world's finest tennis players. This is not the first time that famous "name" athletes have been chosen. We can remember Eddie Eagan and Whizzer White.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The British Broadcasting Corporation has become the center of one of the bitterest controversies in its history as the result of its vivid television dramatization last night of the late George Orwell's novel, "Nineteen Eighty-four."

Members of the parents guild of the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest will hold their annual dance for the benefit of the parish's youth program on the night of Feb. 11 at Squadron A Armory, Madison Avenue at Ninety-fourth Street.

In the Dec. 10 Times M. Kamil Abdul Rahim, representative of the Arab League, questions the criticism (not an "attack") of the American Christian Palestine Committee of the policies of the United States Government in granting arms to the Arab states in what we believe is a misguided effort of our Government in its avowed purpose of "strengthening the security of the entire Middle East."

Steamship cargoes, which have lagged through most of this year, perked up moderately in the last month and made appreciable gains in the last two weeks. This unexpected improvement gives hope for a return next year to the near-boom levels of 1951.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- News has been received by radio that a party of eighteen Britons has reoccupied six bases in the Palmer Peninsula of the Antarctic Continent. The party also is considering the occupation of a seventh at Marquerite Bay, about 150 miles south of the Antarctic Circle.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--President Eisenhower revealed to Republican Congressional leaders today the structure of a proposed domestic legislative program that appeared to be without major innovations.
Dr. Basil C. MacLean, Commissioner of Hospitals, said yesterday that voluntary hospitals should fill their many empty ward beds with patients for whom there is no room in municipal facilities.

Learning that "it is more blessed to give than to receive" cannot start too young, according to recent reports from child care experts. And Christmas is an excellent time for youngsters to start discovering the happiness that comes from doing for others, the specialists agree.

What's cooking at the Waldorf-Astoria? Yesterday there was plenty doing on the range when the sixth annual Bake-Off, co-sponsored by Pillsbury Mills and General Electric, got under way in the ballroom.

Your Education Editor, Dr. Benjamin Fine, recently deplored the falling-off of the study of Russian in American colleges. I believe, however, that he and the majority of the language experts he quotes are mistaken in attributing this phenomenon to a factor of "fear."

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The controversial central library plan for unification of the thirty-seven public libraries in Westchester was rejected this evening by the County Board of Supervisors. The vote, taken after long debate, was 34 to 9.
BERLIN, Dec. 13 --Two important West Germans who in recent months defected to East Germany were reported today to have received comparatively non-political jobs in the East.

Events tonight: "Andrea Chernier,'' Metropolitan Opera, 8; "The Damnation of Faust," Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Alma Trio, Town Hall, 8:30; Yale University School of Music Chorus and Chamber Orchestra, St. Thomas Chapel, 8; Chris Tubbs, "variety showcase," Carnegie Recital Hall, 8:30.
IT has been alleged that there are two ways of hunting broadbill -- the easy way, and from a scooter.
BOSTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Art Quimby, center, scored 49 points tonight as Connecticut swamped Boston College, 117-74, in the second half of a college basketball double-header at the Boston Garden.

Christmas was definitely in the air at City Hall yesterday. It was announced that ceremonies at 5 P. M. tomorrow would mark the lighting of the sixty-foot Christmas tree that for two weeks has stood ornamented but dark in the park in front of City Hall.

The modernized St. Vincent's Hospital Clinic on Seventh Avenue between Eleventh and Twelfth Streets was renamed the Leon Lowenstein Building yesterday in honor of the textile industrialist and member of the hospital's advisory board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13--John Paton Davies Jr., dismissed diplomat, today told the Women's National Democratic Club that a business run like the State Department "might well bewilder personnel and leave the enterprise bankrupt."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen is opposing an application of nine railroads to buy the Illinois Terminal Railroad Company.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 -- Wheat and soybean futures made a show of strength in early trading today, but both reacted sharply later.

Verne Gagne, 220, of Excelsior, Minn., defeated Ray McClarity, 231, Winnipeg, Canada, in a best two-out-of-three fall exhibition that headed the wrestling card at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 11,091 watched the program.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 13 -- With five players hitting in double figures, the unbeaten Seton Hall University basketball team swept over Providence College, 95 -- 67, tonight. It was the fifth victory in a row for the Pirates.
The name John Wanamaker, which has been part of the metropolitan New York retail scene for fifty-eight years, is scheduled to disappear here.
Fire Capt. Walter W. Vail testified yesterday that he visited a novelty concern to buy some knick-knacks, not to demand a $50 gratuity.
The New York City Transit Authority will complete tomorrow the first eighteen months of its management of the city-owned subway, elevated, bus and trolley lines.
DOVER, Del., Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Delaware Supreme Court was asked today to rule on an order permitting Negro pupils to enroll in the now all-white Milford High School.

The New York Knickerbockers will oppose the pace-setting Syracuse Nationals in the feature game of a National Basketball Association double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The preliminary, starting at 7:30, will send the Boston Celtics against the Minneapolis Lakers.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Level Rippey made good for the form players when she whipped a field of fillies and mares in the seventh and best race at Tropical Park today.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Playing against a zone defense, Iona College's basketball team did not score a field goal in the second half tonight. However, the Gaels gained a 42-38 victory over American University at O'Connell Memorial gymnasium.

Mrs. Connie Rastelli, a 43-year-old housewife, of 59-39 Fifty-eighth Drive, Maspeth, Queens, was held in $50,000 bail yesterday on a charge of attempting to bribe a witness. Arraigned before Magistrate John R. Starkey in Brooklyn Felony Court, she will get a hearing next Monday.
Representative Emanuel Celler asserted yesterday that Scott McLeod's administration of the Refugee Relief Act of 1953 was "insane, arbitrary and savage."
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The C. I. O. Transport Workers Union today called off a strike scheduled for Wednesday night.
Water-front contract talks will be resumed today but seem doomed to deadlock even before they start.

The 'cellist Madeline Foley, just back from a European tour, played a recital of unusual interest at Town Hall last evening. Miss Foley is a fluent performer who has a tone of remarkable richness and suavity. In her hands the 'cello never rasps or growls; its tone is always a singing tone, sung in tune.

"Professional Father," a situation comedy program, will make its debut over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Saturday, Jan. 8, from 10 to 10:30 P. M. It replaces "That's My Boy."
President Eisenhower paid tribute last night to the free American press and its reporters in a special message from Washington.

Election of John R. McMillan as executive vice president of the Monterey Oil Company was announced yesterday by Howard C. Pyle, president. Mr. McMillan was president of the Fullerton Oil and Gas Corporation when that company was purchased recently by Monterey.

The 100 kilograms (220 pounds) of purified uranium 235 that the United States has offered to the proposed international atomic energy agency is enough to construct fifteen modern research reactors. This was reported here yesterday at the opening of technical sessions of the forty-seventh annual meeting of the American Institute of Chemical Engineers.
CHICAGO, Dec. 13 (UP) -- Superior Court Judge Gibson E. Gorman ruled today that a "test tube" baby born of artificial insemination was illegitimate when the donor was a third party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra Taft Benson today reduced price supports for small feed grains -- oats, rye, barley and grain sorghums -- and eased production controls set up earlier to hold down plantings next year.
Two Brooklyn youths on trial for the murder of an inebriated man on a Brooklyn pier last August were characterized by a defense lawer yesterday as "children" who were "bent on mischief."
Members of the City Council have put in their bid for slice of the $350,000 pay-increase pie being baked by the city fathers for deserving office-holders.

The four-story building containing three stores and six apartments at 5001 Fourth Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Frieda J. Natanson and Freda Notes to Giuseppe Montalto. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.

LONDON, Dec. 13 -- United States and British defense officials gathered at a Royal Air Force station at Wyton, Huntingdonshire, today to inspect the latest deliveries of British jet bomber and fighter aircraft to the R. A. F. under the United States Mutual Security appropriations legislation.

HARRIMAN, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- The recent growth of this country's surplus of farm products has created among the public a livelier interest in agricultural problems than ever before, Prof. William H. Nicholls, former agricultural economist for the President's Council of Economic Advisers, said today.

The existence and the very lives of the 100,000 Turks on Cyprus would be in "grave danger" should Cyprus be placed under the administration of Greece, Mufti Muderan Dana of Cyprus declared here yesterday.

SYRACUSE, N. Y., Dec. 13 (AP) -- Directors of Carrier Corporation, big manufacturer of air-conditioning devices, and Affiliated Gas Equipment Company, producer of Bryant home furnaces, have agreed to merge the two companies into a $227,000,000 combine, it was announced today.
While rails held about even all day, prices of industrial stocks on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday rocked gently back and forth and ended on a dip.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 13 -- Danny Kaye and Paramount Pictures are discussing an arrangement for the comedian to star in "The Red Nichols Story," originally announced under the title "Intermission."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- Despite the United States opposition, the Asian-African bloc succeeded today in keeping the Moroccan dispute alive.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.
A 9-year-old girl celebrated her birthday as usual this week by sending her saving to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Secretary of State Dulles, accompanied by a large delegation, will fly to Paris tomorrow for a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Council.

Major Roy P. Johnson of the United States Air Force yesterday was named as the new manager of this country's Pan American basketball squad. The team will compete in Mexico City next March along with other teams from this country.
The board of trustees of the Bowery Savings Bank yesterday elected Fred K. Cordes and Chester W. Schmidt as vice presidents. They had been assistant vice presidents.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 13 -- The Delaware River port area had a record foreign water-borne commerce in the first six months of this year, according to a report today.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Dec. 13 (AP) -- A Kansas City baseball club official talked with civic leaders in the Tampa Bay area today and said he would have a definite proposition to make tomorrow on transferring the Class AAA Ottawa franchise.

Nineteen labor leaders from the European Coal and Steel Community have spent four weeks studying how Americans cope with technological advances that spell short-range dislocations for labor but lead to Long-range benefits.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 13 -- Yugopress, semi-official news agency, asserted tonight that there were indications the Vatican was changing its attitude toward the Government-backed priests' associations. Heretofore the Holy See has condemned them.
NEW LONDON, Conn., Dec. 13 -- The submarine Barb, battle seasoned in the Japanese theater in World War II, became a unit of Italy's navy today, in ceremonies at the United States Submarine Base here.

PARIS, Dec. 13 -- Premier Mendes-France declared today that the Saar agreement was a "capital element in the Paris-London accords." He made this statement in introducing the bill on the accord on the Saar he had reached with the West German Chancellor.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 13 -- The Vietnamese Army apparently has retained virtual autonomy despite the appointment by Premier Ngo Dinh Diem of Gen. Le Van Ty as Chief of Staff and Gen. Nguyen Van Vy as Inspector General.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 13 -- For five hours today Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was cross-examined concerning his admittedly vague and incomplete story of the night of July 3 and the following early morning hours. The 30-year-old osteopathic surgeon is on trial for the murder of his wife, Marilyn, 31, at that time.
A 59-year-old man was found dead last night in a room filled with fumes from a gas radiator, marking the 101st fatality caused here this year by defective gas appliances.
LONDON, Dec. 13 -- The British Government will propose civilian-political control over the tactical use of nuclear weapons when the North Atlantic Council meets in Paris this week.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- The incoming chairman of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the House of Representatives expressed fear today that Vietnam would be lost to Communism unless the French got out 100 per cent -- militarily, economically and politically.
ROME, Dec. 13 -- The Pope's health suffered a slight setback today, or at least did not maintain the same rate of progress as in the last few days.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 13 -- Lawyers for Owen Lattimore argued in court today that a perjury indictment against him should be dismissed because it violated constitutional guarantees of freedom of speech.
Francis Henry Taylor, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art for fifteen years, will resign his post on June 30, 1955.
PORTLAND, Me., Dec. 13 (AP) -- An aerial search of coastal waters failed today to turn up a freighter overdue here three days with a crew of twenty-four and a cargo of sulphur.

CINCINNATI, Dec. 13 (AP) -- The Cincinnati Times-Star said today that Sandy Koufax, 18-year-old University of Cincinnati southpaw pitching star, will be signed by the Brooklyn Dodgers for an estimated $20,000 bonus.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 13 (Reuters) -- An agent of Aristotle Onassis today paid a fine of $3,000,000 levied by the Government of Peru for hunting of whales in territorial waters declared to extend 200 miles off the coast.

One hundred mortgages, in Greater New York and New Jersey totaling more than $1,003,305 will be offered at auction today. The sale will be held at 1:45 P. M. at the Roosevelt Hotel under the direction of the New York Mortgagee Exchange, of which Harry Fromkes is president.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson puts his world middleweight title on the block tomorrow night for the third time in eight months. He tangles with France's Pierre Langlois, the No. 1 challenger.
The space under the Christmas tree is going to be mighty crowded, to judge by the volume of holiday buying.

Mrs. David A. Gimbel gave a tea yesterday afternoon in her home at 895 Park Avenue for members of the committee working for the success of the Yuletide Assembly Ball. During the afternoon, final plans were made for the forthcoming fete, which will be held on Dec. 27 in the ballroom of the Ambassador for the benefit of Boys Harbor, Inc., in East Hampton, L. I.

Events tonight: "Vittorio" (first performance) and "Salome," Metropolitan Opera, 8; Collegiate Chorale, Ralph Hunter conducting, Carnegie Hall, 8:30; Giovanni Bagarotti, violinist-conductor, Town Hall, 8:30; David Tudor and John Cage, duo-pianists, Carl Fischer Concert Hall, 8:30.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Agatha Christie's comedy-thriller, "Spider's Web," was well received by the audience at its opening at the Savoy Theatre tonight, but there was a lack of warmth in the verdicts of the newspaper reviewers.

ALBUQUERQUE, N. M., Dec. 14 -- J. Edgar Hoover has assured the editor of a University of New Mexico student publication that the Federal Bureau of Investigation "would never engage in any activity which might result in stifling academic freedom."

One hundred and eight members of Queen Elizabeth's Household Troops, the Scots Guards Band with Massed Pipers and Dancers, will make a ten-week tour of the United States beginning next October. it was announced yesterday by S. Hurok, concert manager.
The Commonwealth Fund reported yesterday that it had appropriated $3,321,738 in the last fiscal year for medical education, experimental health services and medical research.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Pitt's basketball team went on from a 32-32 halftime tie to beat Colgate, 80 -- 67, tonight. It was Colgate's first defeat in four games.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- The Government's Farm Crop Insurance Corporation lost between $5,500,000 and $6,000,000 this year, an official estimated today.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 14 -- More than 200 Methodist laymen and ministers from six Southern states who are opposed to desegregation in their churches met here today to outline plans to combat the breakdown of segregation within the church.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- The military report that has caused alarm recently among some members of the Atlantic alliance says its forces should be able to respond immediately in kind to an atomic attack.

The Forty - ninth Plymouth Corporation, which was formed by Stanley Stahl, a realty operator, bought the leasehold on the seventeen-story Plymouth Hotel at 143 West Forty-ninth Street, near Times Square, from the Selpaul Hotel Operating Corporation in a deal negotiated by Des Gabor, vice president of the M. Morgenthau - Seixas Company, broker. The building contains 400 rooms, all with bath, a restaurant, a bar and coffee shop.

I am wondering whether our economists, statisticians or sociologists have given consideration to the problems raised by the ever-increasing number of people obliged to hold dual jobs in order to maintain their homes and their accustomed standard of life.

BURTONWOOD, England, Dec. 14 (UP) -- A United States B-29 carried 12,000 letters addressed to Santa Claus, North Pole, over the Arctic Circle today and dropped them as close as possible to the address. The letters were written by British children and given to the Air Force by the post office.

Directors of the Rockland-Atlas National Bank of Boston voted at a special meeting yesterday to recommend to shareholders at their annual meeting on Jan. 25 a two-for-one split in the capital stock and an increase in capital through the sale of 37,500 additional shares of capital stock.

UNITED NATIONS., N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Britain and Turkey won an important victory over Greece today in their fight to block a United Nations endorsement of the "principle of self-determination" for the inhabitants of Cyprus.

WELL suited to the holiday season, an exhibition of Spanish medieval art will open today at The Cloisters, the uptown branch of the Metropolitan Museum of Art in Fort Tryon Park to remain on view through January.

Duckworth Realty Company has moved from Springfield Gardens, Queens, to 1022 Old Country Road in Westbury, L. I. The concern is headed by Alice Duckworth and F. Ronald Eltringham. The Title Abstract Company, headed by Albert W. Duckworth, has offices at the same address.

The New York City Center, the municipal theatre which has been offering theatrical and musical entertainment at popular prices since, 1932, will be honored today "as a cultural institution of international importance" by the United Nations.

The tugboat Ann Moran fought sixty-mile-an-hour winds and twenty-five-foot waves all day yesterday to keep a barge loaded with high-test aviation gasoline from piling up on the shore at Barnegat, N. J.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Three years from now the most modern and efficient army in Europe will probably be German. It will be organized in small divisions each split into three regimental combat teams ready for any task. These fast, mobile, light units will have highly concentrated fire power and be able to disperse speedily when threatened with nuclear attack.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- President Eisenhower gave Joseph Campbell a recess appointment as United States Controller General today.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Britain will not be involved in a state of war with Communist China should the Peiping regime invade Formosa, it was stated here today.

On sales of $78,033,435 the Beech Aircraft Corporation in the fiscal year ended on Sept. 30 realized a net income of $3,386,089, equal to $5.64 a share. This was in contrast to a net loss of $2,321,052 in the previous fiscal year, when sales were $140,457,780.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Senator Olin D. Johnston, Democrat of South Carolina, today charged the Eisenhower Administration with "willful neglect" of farmers and said the South's econ-

UNITED NATIONS N. Y., Dec. 14 -- The United States, defeated in an earlier effort to establish the principle of judicial review of judgments of the United Nations Administrative Tribunal, will again seek approval of the principle when the General Assembly takes up the tribunal's indemnity awards on Friday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- A wage increase of 11 cents an hour for West Coast dock workers was approved today by negotiators for the Pacific Maritime Association and the International Longshoremen's and Warehousemen's Union, unaffiliated.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- William P. Rogers, Deputy Attorney General, said today that the Government would continue for "some time" to combat through voluntary practices discriminatory hiring on Government contract jobs.

CORNING, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Dr. William H. Armistead was appointed today by the Corning Glass Works to succeed Dr. Edward U. Condon as director of research and development. Dr. Condon resigned yesterday and abandoned an appeal for Federal Government security clearance to give him access to classified information.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 14 -- The Government won a test of confidence tonight by a margin of twenty-three votes in Parliament. Out of a record number of 213 members of Parliament present, the Cabinet received the approval of 115.

David Fluegelman, in a letter in your issue of Dec. 7, makes the surprising statement concerning the corruption which has appeared in a small minority of union welfare funds that the "responsibility * * * properly belongs in the laps of the unions themselves."
BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 14 -- Argentina's House of Deputies passed a bill today making divorce legal.

Firestone Tire and Rubber Company voted a dividend of $1 a share on the common stock yesterday, payable on Jan. 20. The company paid 75 cents a share in previous quarters, plus an extra dividend of 75 cents a share on Dec. 1.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Backers of the Kansas City Athletics announced plans today for a mass flight of private planes and chartered airliners to carry 1,000 rooters to West Palm Beach, Fla., next March for the club's first exhibition game.

A one-story taxpayer containing three stories at 43-02 to 43-06 Bell Boulevard in Bayside, Queens, has been sold by Albert D. Phelps to an investing customer of the Herman A. Acker Corporation, broker in the transaction. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
A dramatic attempt to set a traffic safety standard for the future will take place today, designated by President Eisenhower as Safe Driving Day.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Prices rose on the stock markets here today, the last for dealings for the last bookkeeping account of 1954.

LONDON, Dec. 14 -- Thirty-nine unions representing nearly 3,000,000 workers are asking wage increases that would cost employers in British shipbuilding and engineering industries the equivalent of about $300,000,000 a year.
NIAGARA FALLS, N. Y., Dec. 15 (UP) -- Niagara University scored its fourth victory in five basketball starts tonight by turning back Cornell University, 71 -- 65.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Six hand-painted service plates commemorating the tercentenary of the oldest Jewish congregation in the United States were presented to Mrs. Dwight D. Eisenhower at the White House today.

An American League team pitching record by the Indians and a marked domination of right-handed hurling provide the high-lights of the junior circuit's official 1954 mound averages, announced yesterday.
Darling Stores Corporation purchased fifty-three women's fashion stores yesterday from Spiegel, Inc., Chicago company, for approximately $3,000,000.

DYLAN THOMAS, the wild Welsh poet and wandering minstrel who chanted his own verses with incomparable resonance and relish in his own performance, died only a little more than a year ago. But his cult goes marching on. His voice can still be heard on phonograph records and a voice worth hearing it certainly is, rich, vibrant and magical, with some thing in it of an evangelical preacher and something of a nineteenth-century Shakespearean actor.

Michael Garcia, 24-year-old witness in a Queens murder case, who also has been accused of various crimes, attempted suicide last week at the Bronx County Jail, Assistant District Attorney James McGrattan of Queens revealed yesterday.

The Board of Estimate was told in executive session yesterday that the city would need $80,000,000 to $100,000,000 above the current record $1,639,438,325 expense budget in 1955-56 to meet minimum requirements.
OTTAWA, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) -- The Canadian Repertory Theatre, the capital's only professional theatre, will suspend productions next month because of a lack of funds.

Mrs. Bernard A. Koteen, plump, 37-year-old housewife of Washington, who holds a doctor's degree in archaeology from the University of Chicago, yesterday won the top prize of $25,000 in the sixth annual Pillsbury Grand National Recipe Contest.
Steadily, year by year, the Constitution's guarantees of civil rights are being applied more widely in everyday life in America, the American Jewish Committee said yesterday.

Today's new film is "The Country Girl," a Paramount drama co-starring Bing Crosby, Grace Kelly and William Holden, at the Criterion. William Perlberg produced and George Seaton directed and wrote the screen play, an adaptation of the stage work by Clifford Odets.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 14 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has authorized the William Morris Agency to consider offers for a motion picture biography of the late President. Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Halsted, daughter of Mrs. Roosevelt, confirmed today that Abe Lastvogel, agency executive, recently had obtained the permission from Mrs. Roosevelt.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 14 -- The Regents of the University of California have paid in full the claims of five former professors involved in a loyalty-oath controversy.

The building at 21 Herkimer Place in Brooklyn has been leased by Leonard Electric Products, Inc. The structure, containing about 5,000 square feet of space; will be used for the manufacture of electrical novelties.
MELBOURNE, Australia, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- The touring English Marylebone Cricket Club and Victoria ended their four-day match in a draw today.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation will have sold and shipped a record $1,600,000,000 worth of heavy electrical apparatus and home appliances by the end of the year, Gwilym A. Price, president, said yesterday.

NEWARK, Dec. 14 -- Two longshoremen testified here today before the Waterfront Commission that they had done house repairs on company time for a woman friend of their union boss while drawing pier pay.

PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Guy La Chambre, Minister for the Associated States of Indochina, reportedly told Deputies today that France would reduce her forces in Indochina next year from 125,000 to 70,000 men.
LONDON, Dec. 14 -- The Royal Navy replied sharply today to Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery and other critics of the aircraft carrier and of a navy's offensive mission in modern war.

Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks predicted here last night that 1955 would be a better year than 1954. But he declined to say whether the indications were that it would surpass the top year, 1953.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 14 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer will face a confused and tense Bundestag tomorrow in the first round of the ratification debate on the Paris and Saar agreements.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 -- The final stages of the murder trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard neared today as the 30-year-old osteopathic surgeon completed fifteen hours on the witness stand.

Employes of E. R. Squibb Sons, 25 Columbia Heights, Brooklyn, gave 209 pints of blood on Monday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood Program, and personnel of the New York Group of the Atlantic Reserve Fleet donated 145 pints at the Naval Shipyard at Bayonne, N. J. Monday's total was 568 pints.

In a debate at Columbia University last night, two New York lawyers, both Democrats, joined in criticizing the Federal program on security risks, but disagreed on what was wrong and what should be done about it. Roy M. Cohn said it was still too lax and ought to be tightened.

" Andrea Chenier" was performed at the Metropolitan Opera last evening, with Charles Anthony singing the role of the Spy for the first time. Mr. Anthony's clear, well-focused voice proved well able to cope with the music of the part, and visually it was a convincing performance.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Mrs. Ben F. Whitaker's Tahitian King, on the sidelines almost seventeen months, returned to the races at Tropical Park today before a crowd of 7,469. The 4-year-old son of Polynesian -- Carolyn finished a creditable second to the more seasoned Mintaway in the featured six-furlong seventh event.
The Forrestal, launched at Newport News, Va., Saturday, not only is the largest ship of any type ever built in the United States but also may be the largest ship ever built anywhere.

Thirteen charitable organizations will share the $80,000 residuary estate of Nelson A. Bartow, former credit manager of the Nassau Smelter Company, it was learned yesterday when his will was filed in Surrogate's Court.

MOSCOW, Dec. 14 -- For the first time in twenty years an All-Union Congress of Writers will be convened here tomorrow. It will consider a constantly recurring issue of Soviet intellectual life: What is the duty of the writer in a Communist state and how can he fulfill it?

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower promised today to allow the newly dominant Congressional Democrats, and the Republicans as well, to participate in evolving national policy on defense and foreign affairs.

The management of A. M. Byers Company, ninety-year-old Pittsburgh wrought iron producer, charged that unidentified persons who do not control the company have recently offered its plants for sale for $10,000,000 to at least six other Pittsburgh companies.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The solution of Japan's economic problems must be part of a general expansion of the economies of the countries of free Asia, the director of a new mission to Japan of the Foreign Operations Administration said today.
Edward Corsi, State Industrial Commissioner, took a strong position yesterday against the passage of any right-to-work legislation, or "little Taft-Hartley Law," in this state.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Red Sails, voted 1954's aged pacer of the year, died today at Castleton Farm.

A speedy way to slice hard crystallized fruits for holiday cake and cookies is to soften them first by steaming, then to cut them with a razor-sharp knife. The knife should be dipped frequently in hot water to keep the blade from becoming sticky.

Suzy Perette has given a fresh look to her successful molded-bodice-full-skirt silhouette by using bright prints in her new resort and holiday collection. The group was shown yesterday at Russeks Fifth Avenue.
The Radio Voice of Christian Korea will go on the air officially for the first time today, according to an announcement by the National Council of the Churches of Christ in the U. S. A.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Nicholas Bela, Hungarian-born actor and writer, related to the House Un - American Activities Committee today experiences as a Communist party member in Hollywood from 1937 to 1943.
Success in the White House, Carl Sandburg said yesterday, requires that a President be "diabolically cunning."

The National Boxing Association withdrew recognition of Sandy Saddler as world featherweight champion yesterday. Charlie Johnston, the boxer's manager, defiantly said Saddler would defend "when he's ready and that will be February."

WINNIPEG, Canada, Dec. 14 (Canadian Press) -- A Vickers Viscount airliner cut one hour off the regular flying time of Trans-Canada Air Lines' North Stars during a flight from Toronto to Winnipeg yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 14 -- Heads of the four Provincial Governments and six of the ten Princely States in West Pakistan voted today to merge their semi-autonomous units into a single province.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

MEN sometimes set themselves to curious objectives. Cmdr. Thomas J. Keane, 65 years old today, hopes to complete next Sunday afternoon, if the weather is bright, a project he started a little less than four years ago -- to walk in every street, avenue, alley, square and court on Manhattan Island.

Orson Bean, the comedian, will star in a special two-hour variety program, "New Year's in New York," to be televised over the Columbia Broadcasting System's Channel 2 beginning at 11:30 P. M. on Friday, Dec. 31.
YONKERS, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Yonkers Raceway announced today the two richest purses in the history of night harness racing would be assured for 3-year-olds in the twin futurities of 1955.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Authorities decided today that 23-year-old Sallie Wood, Government analyst, had been killed accidentally by a shotgun as she wrapped Christmas presents in her locked apartment.
Two of New York's leading citizens, Cardinal Spellman and Bernard M. Baruch, were among the 541 who sent contributions yesterday that added $11,724 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

Perhaps it's no longer profitable for the cobbler to stick to his last. Two important corporations have stepped out of their own fields to offer the most modern of lasts -- radiation and electronics -- to all industry.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The United States will not make any "deal" to exchange thirty-five Chinese students denied permission to leave this country for eleven American airmen imprisoned in China.

Television is "bound to go ahead" in 1955, with radio "struggling" and newspapers and magazines "irregular," Edwin B. George, economist of Dun Bradstreet, Inc., credit-reporting agency, predicted yesterday.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Government's seven-year-old civil anti-trust suit against National City Lines, Inc., was settled by agreement of both parties in Federal Court today. The company operates urban and interurban bus lines throughout the nation.

A call to Americans to show the rest of the world "the worth of our freedom" was made last night by Paul G. Hoffman, chairman of the Studebaker - Packard Corporation and former administrator of the Economic Cooperation Administration.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Ralph Kiner, who has been leading the fight for higher salaries for major league baseball players for "seven long years," today voluntarily asked the Cleveland Indians to cut his salary from $65,000 to $40,000, or more than the legal 25 per cent limit.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 13 -- On behalf of the City of New York, Mayor Wagner presented $2,500 today to the United Nations International Children's Fund.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- Hearings on the financing of the St. Lawrence power project and other phases of the development of power from public waterways are planned for January by the Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee.

Large gifts to the Neediest Cases Fund are necessary to assure that, as in the past, adequate help will be given not only to those whose misfortunes are narrated during this Christmas appeal but to many similar cases also on the rolls of the seven participating social service agencies.
The Republic Aviation Corporation announced that it had paid $2,000,000 in Christmas bonuses to its employes, including those who left the company during the year for services in the armed forces.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- By a vote of 46 to 0, with the single abstention of the United States, the General Assembly approved today a request to the Food and Agriculture Organization to prepare a comprehensive report on moves made to set up a world food reserve.
ATHENS, Dec. 14 -- A crowd of 4,000 to 5,000 Greeks clashed with the police today in several attempts to reach the United States Embassy to protest Washington's stand on the Cyprus issue.

Your issue of Dec. 8 carried a most timely editorial titled "Rail Transit 'Crisis.'" The article summed up the generally deteriorating transportation picture in that while auto traffic is becoming increasingly congested, rail traffic grows constantly more sparse. You outline the several alternatives and conclude with the masterful sentence: "Inaction would, itself, be a policy-making decision."

Many single women and widows past the age of 65 years living on small annuities or pensions find it very difficult to live nicely in moderate-priced hotels where they have companionship and a certain amount of security.
MONT ROLLAND, Que., Dec. 14 -- A task force from Almany reported tonight that about 500 pounds of historical documents, accidentally tossed away as trash, had been recovered.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The Shah of Iran made a bid today for Western military and economic assistance for his country.
PARIS, Dec. 10 -- Jean Desses has started his first ready-to-wear collection, manufactured by Amedee Prouvost Sons.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The political philosophers in America are going to have to rewrite the textbooks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of an address by Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi of Iran at a press, radio and television luncheon today: Ladies and Gentlemen:

The first financial partnership linking the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development with the private capital market here was effected yesterday in the form of a $50,000,000 credit to Belgium.
The International Longshoremen's Association, making its second turn through the revolving door of waterfront contract negotiations, presented twelve new demands to the pier employers yesterday.

James Reston's report from Washington that the President will appoint Nelson Rockefeller as his administrative assistant on foreign policy is one of the few bright gleams in our murky handling of foreign affairs today.
ROME, Dec. 14 -- The lack of religious instruction in public schools in the United States was termed a "tragedy" today by L'Osservatore Romano, the Vatican newspaper.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- Following is the text of a statement issued by the White House after a meeting of President Eisenhower with Republican and Democratic Congressional leaders:
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 14 -- Two Chinese students living in Pasadena, who say they have received no reply from the United States Government on petitions to be
Although the Dodgers haven't got around to making one of those big deals they reportedly have been plotting, they did manage yesterday to clear the decks a bit. They also signed a bonus player.
The dry cargo segment of American-flag East Coast and Gulf shipping may be affected by a walkout of C. I. O. radio operators a minute after midnight tonight.

Present statistics and experience indicate that 1955 will be a very good year for alert businesses, according to Henry H. Heimann, economist and executive vice president of the National Association of Credit Men.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., Dec. 14 -- We had to travel all the way to Texas to find a new and foolproof method of obtaining game -- have the game dinner before you leave on the hunting trip.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The favored Ernie Durando of Bayonne, N. J., scoring effectively at long range, won a split ten-round decision tonight over Jesse Turner of St. Louis. Durando weighed 160 1/2 pounds, Turner 159.

All cocoa options fell the daily limit of 1 cent a pound yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Trading was influenced by a lower London market and a report by the Department of Agriculture that world production is increasing.

Chief Assistant District Attorney J. Kenneth McCabe, prosecutor in yesterday's felony murder verdict against two Brooklyn teen-agers, once won a 1948 case that led to upholding discretionary power of judges here to accept or reject mercy recommendations of juries in such cases.

TRIESTE, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- A precious 600-year-old Latin manuscript of Petrarch's epic poem "De Africa" has been returned to the Trieste civic library nine years after an American G. I. bought it in Naples for a song.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- John Foster Dulles left here today for another conference in Paris.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- The Atomic Scientists of Chicago condemned today "political abuse of the nation's security system" and called for "a new and constructive approach to the security problem."

The five years which have passed since the Shah of Iran last visited the United States have been truly extraordinary for his nation. In fact, only a year ago last summer Iran was a bankrupt country, ruled by the fantastic and fanatical demagogue, Dr. Mossadegh, a nation full of xenophobia and disorder with a powerful Communist movement in the Tudeh party, and with the vast oil industry at a standstill.

Two Brooklyn youths who went out one night last August to rid the Williamsburg streets of "bums" were found guilty yesterday of murder. An all-male jury in Kings County Court recommended life imprisonment.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower declared today that Americans "must learn" to use the abundance of their land wisely.
Two news issues of public utility bonds totaling $36,000,000 will be placed on the market today by underwriting syndicates following their sale at competitive bidding yesterday.
The Detroit Red Wings, the defending champions in the National Hockel League, will be seeking their fifth straight triumph tonight. They will oppose the New York Rangers at Madison Square Garden.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- President Eisenhower today pinned on the coat lapel of James Thomas Welch, 19 - year - old Rochester, N. Y., youth, the Young American Medal "for service." The youth gave a piece of bone from his leg to an 11-year-old neighbor girl, Mary Ranney, suffering from a crippling disease.

CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- Adlai E. Stevenson, the 1952 Democratic Presidential nominee, announced today that his law partner would be Prof. W. Williard Wirtz of the Northwestern University Law School, minority member of the State Liquor Control Commission.
PARIS, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- The French Ministry of Justice ordered a new investigation tonight into the triple murder of a British family following reports of new "sensational disclosures."
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France obtained authority from his cabinet today to ask for a vote of confidence on the Paris agreements and, whenever he desired on the 1955 budget.
The departmental trial of Fire Capt. Walter W. Vail ended yesterday on a note of high drama.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 14 -- Turkey is planning to request United States nuclear material under President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace program.
STAMFORD, Conn., Dec. 14 -- Pegging commutation rates to the cost of living is being considered by the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

The possibility of increased international cooperation in the field of seaman's recreation centers in overseas ports was reported here yesterday by Otho J. Hicks, executive director of the United Seaman's Service.
The appointment of Mrs. Simon Ottinger of 912 Fifth Avenue as chairman of the Manhattan motor transport service of the American Women's Voluntary Services, Inc., has been announced.

The President has informed Republican leaders in Congress that he will ask a further postponement of two tax reductions scheduled to take effect April 1 of next year. These are (1) the drop of five points in the corporate income tax rate, from the present 52 per cent to 47 per cent; and (2) cuts in the existing excise tax rates on autos, tobacco, liquor and gasoline.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 14 -- Navy's football team is beginning to get fretful. The weather was rainy again today and, with time running out on home base, preparations for the Sugar Bowl game with Mississippi at New Orleans on Jan. 1, the midshipmen have yet to have a fully satisfactory practice session.

A limitation on the responsibility of the American Kennel Club to provide official determinations on dogs in breeds in which height or color are show factors was placed by the A. K. C. delegates at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday.

The New York Knickerbockers wasted an early 10-point lead and bowed to the Syracuse Nationals, 91 -- 82, last night at Madison Square Garden. The defeat before 7,655 fans followed a record-breaking 115 -- 108 victory for the Boston Celtics over the Minneapolis Lakers.
Carmine G. DeSapio is to be the Secretary of State of New York.

ONE of the best trades the Dodgers ever made was the slick deal whereby Branch Rickey pried Preacher Roe and Billy Cox away from the Pirates. In exchange the wily Mahatma yielded Hal Gregg, a pitcher who never lived up to his promise; Vic Lombardi, a pitcher who had no promise to live up to, and Dixie Walker, an outfielder who already had fulfilled all promises and whose future was behind him.

CLAYTON, Ala., Dec. 14 (UP) -- Royall Reynolds, the informal banker of the town of Clio, was acquitted today of an embezzlement charge that grew out of his mysterious disappearance last March. He formerly operated an unchartered bank.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- A railroad official testified today that if freight rates on imported iron ore for New York, Boston and Philadelphia were equal, Baltimore would get only a small share of Labrador imports.
Waves of selling hit an already soggy stock market late yesterday afternoon and brought the widest losses since Oct. 14.

Compelled by circumstances to conduct a kind of "airplane diplomacy," Secretary Dulles has left for another trip to Paris, this time to attend a meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Council that will take a new look at our global strategy. The global aspect arises because, in the last analysis, and despite the specific treaty provisions, the power of the North Atlantic alliance is not confined to the defense of the Atlantic community alone.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 14 (AP) -- Dr. Charles D. Byrne announced today that he was quitting as chancellor of the Oregon system of higher education. Dr. John R. Richards, vice chancellor, was named to succeed him.

Nothing escapes the vigilant eye of Carolyn Schnurer when she goes on a voyage of fashion discovery. Her eighth and latest journey in search of inspiration for her casual and play styles took her to enchanting Norway. The trip was made under the auspices of Peck Peck and Everglaze.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today it has arranged for the sale of 2,860,000 bushels of Government corn to Western Germany.

Net income of Dresser Industries, Inc., manufacturer of oil, gas and chemical equipment, in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 was 43 per cent higher than in the prior year, H. N. Mallon, the president, reported yesterday.

TOKYO, Dec. 14 (Reuters) -- Japan will discontinue some of the international trading practices which helped to raise her exports this year to probably more than $1,500,000,000, compared with $1,244,000,000 last year, the director of the International Trade Bureau, Osamu Itagaki, said today.
Two business men were arrested yesterday on charges of receiving stolen goods, as the police recovered $100,000 of mink pelts stolen Wednesday from a truck parked outside Bloomingdale's.

The board of directors of the National Health Council chose Dr. Hugh Rodman Leavell yesterday as president-elect at a meeting in the New York Athletic Club. He will become president at the council's annual meeting next March, succeeding Dr. T. Duckett Jones, who died on Nov. 22.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission heard today that the Southern Company had decided to go out of its normal area to join in building a new power plant near the Tennessee Valley after officials of the Eisenhower Administration expressed a desire that it do so.

TALLULAH, La., Dec. 14 -- Associate Justice William O. Douglas of the Supreme Court and Mrs. Mercedes Hester Davidson were married here late today. The bride did research for the Justice's last three books.

The increase of lawlessness in our city is most frightening. Because of highjacking, bank and messenger hold-ups, muggings and rape attacks we are developing fear to a point that we are reluctant to walk the streets in residential districts.

The Broadway stage debut of Robert Donat, in "The Sleeping Prince," looms as a distinct possibility. Reports that Mr. Donat was willing to come here and act in Terence Rattigan's "occasional fairy tale," steeped in a Graustarkian atmosphere, were verified yesterday by John C. Wilson, who has been striving to hurdle vexing casting problems.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The American Locomotive Company has been selected to design and build a 2,000-kilowatt nuclear power plant at Fort Belvoir, Va., at a lump-sum price of $2,096,753.

We owe it to Robert Lawrence, who conducted the performance of Berlioz' "Damnation of Faust" for the benefit of the Metropolitan Opera Fund last night in Carnegie Hall, that we were enabled to hear this remarkable score for the first time in twelve years in this city, and perhaps for the first time in its complete and definitive form.
Know a little boy who'd like a dinosaur for Christmas? You can find it in miniature size, at least, at the American Museum of Natural History.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 14 -- Three leaders of Belgium's Communist party have been removed from top positions in the party's fifty-five-member Central Committee, which is responsible for policy.
CHICAGO, Dec. 14 -- All grains fell sharply early today in the wake of last evening's announcement that the Government was cutting supports on the small feed grains from 85 to 70 per cent of parity.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 14 -- WHYY, new educational FM radio station of this metropolitan district, opened regular broadcasts tonight at a dedication dinner attended by 150 persons in the Franklin Institute.

The sharply strained relations between Government and scientists will surely not be eased by the decision of Dr. Edward U. Condon to give up his fight for security clearance with the statement that "I do not feel there is any possibility of my securing a fair and independent judgment" at the present time.
TALLULAH, La., Dec. 14 (UP) -- Friends said the bride and the Justice had arrived at Tallulah from Vicksburg, Miss., late today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 -- The House Committee on Un-American Activities is expected to approve soon a staff report striking hard at neo-Fascist and extreme Right "hate" groups.

Money borrowed to finance margin trading for their clients by member firms of the New York Stock Exchange continued to rise in November. But the proportion of such borrowings to the market value of listed securities continued to fall.

A Polish sea captain said yesterday that his wife and children had been evicted and robbed because of his escape from Communist tyranny. It was Communist tyranny, he said, that forced him to transport fuel for Communist jets in Korea.

The American farmer, whose surplus products have piled up to a record $6,627,000,000, was warned yesterday that over-anxiety to dispose of food abroad could have serious effects on international relations.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 14 -- Bill Thieben registered 30 points, 20 in the last half, in pacing Hofstra College's basketball team to a 71-51 victory over American University on the winner's court tonight. This was the seventh straight triumph for the undefeated Flying Dutchman.
ROME, Dec. 14 -- For the second day in succession there has been no improvement in the Pope's condition, which again caused some apprehension in the Vatican today.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Britain served notice today that her next contribution to Korean aid would be a final one. It is intended to help the United Nations Korean Reconstruction Agency wind up its operations satisfactorily, her spokesman said.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 14 -- Forced labor as a means of political punishment was condemned today by the General Assembly's Social, Humanitarian and Cultural Committee. The vote was 31 to 5, the Communist bloc offering the only opposition.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 14 -- Brazilian coffee interests view any move by the United States Government to place controls over coffee trading as an unfriendly act toward Latin-American producing nations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (UP) -- Cotton farmers voted overwhelmingly today in favor of the strictest acreage controls in history next year in order to retain relatively high Government price supports.
PARIS, Dec. 14 -- Deputies of the Foreign Ministers Committee of the Council of Europe agreed today to place the plight of European refugees on the agenda of the ministers, who will meet here Sunday.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 14 -- Led by Bart Leach and Joe Sturgis, who combined for 48 points, Pennsylvania defeated Navy, 77 -- 65, in basketball today.

Mayor Wagner must leave City Hall. Not that the Republicans are driving the Democratic executive out of his office, however. It is the noise and dust created by air hammers pounding the exterior stonework off the municipal structure that is forcing him to move.
Prices of cotton futures rose 5 to 14 points yesterday in light trading on the New York Cotton Exchange.

A new biography of the Rev. C. L. Dodgson, author of "Alice in Wonderland," will be issued by Macmillan Jan. 18, entitled "Lewis Carroll." The author is Derek Hudson Who has based his book on the recently published Carroll diaries, Carroll's correspondence with his publishers and many letters now in the hands of American collectors and on new material discovered at Christ Church, Oxford.

Gen. Matthew B. Ridgway, Army Chief of Staff, told the West Point Society of New York yesterday that the Communist bloc presented to the United States a "military threat unique in its history." He warned that an adequate defense was possible only with the help of other free nations.
Four officers of a company that earned a net profit of $22.53 after paying $24.99 for the printing of its annual report were honored yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 14 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today found the Studebaker Corporation innocent of unfair labor practices in the suspension of nineteen workers who owned cars other than Studebakers.
" DATELINE," the Overseas Press Club presentation on Monday evening over the National Broadcasting Company network, happily fulfilled a number of purposes.

In his "President's Review" section of the Rockefeller Foundation Report for 1953, made public this week, Dean Rusk has expressed with eloquence and clarity the place of the foundation in American life. Both freedom of enterprise and freedom from taxation are deeply involved in foundation operations and in any Government measures to deal with them.

TRENTON, Dec. 14 -- The State Board of Canvassers met here today and certified the election of Clifford P. Case, Republican, as United States Senator from New Jersey. The board stipulated, however, that if the recount of ballots should result in defeat for Mr. Case, the certification would be rescinded.
The Puerto Rico Water Resources Authority borrowed $12,500,000 yesterday on an issue of serial bonds maturing from 1957 to 1990 at an interest cost of 3.3999 per cent.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Tony Trabert of the United States will meet Sven Davidson of Sweden in the first singles match of the Davis Cup interzone final tomorrow. In the second match, the American champion, Vic Seixas, will oppose Lennart Bergelin.
JERUSALEM (Israeli Sector) Dec. 13 (AP) -- Israel released today a Syrian DC-3 airliner and two remaining passengers and two crew members held in custody here since Sunday.
ROME, Dec. 15 -- The Pope was a little better today. The apprehensions to which his condition had given rise yesterday were somewhat allayed.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- A resolution blocking action on the Cyprus question at this session of the United Nations General Assembly was approved today by a key committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A counterclaim for $100,000,000 damages was filed in District Court here today for twenty-three Western railroads against Riss Co., Kansas City trucking concern.

For the first time in many years the Metropolitan Opera presented last night a new ballet in a full-scale production, with a large company, a special score and all the trimmings.
