Created by the company's young ballet director, Zachary Solov, it is called "Vittorio," and is set to unfamiliar music from a dozen Verdi operas, arranged by Julius Burger.
Robert Moses made it clear yesterday that the hydroelectric development of the St. Lawrence River would be carried out along the strictest business lines.
A $2,000,000 New York State subsidy to improve probation service in the courts was proposed yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Carl (Bobo) Olson of San Francisco, the world middleweight champion, tonight scored an eleventh round technical knockout over Pierre Langlois of France in their title fight slated for fifteen rounds.

Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today. "There's No Business Like Show Business," a Twentieth Century-Fox musical comedy in CinemaScope and color with Ethel Merman, Donald O'Connor, Marilyn Monroe, Dan Dailey, Johnnie Ray and Mitzi Gaynor, is at the Roxy.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Industrial share prices continued to advance on the stock markets here today. Selective buying, encouraged by the opening of the first account for settlement in the new year found prices responsive.

Directors of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad nominated yesterday ten candidates for board seats now occupied by Frederic C. Dumaine Jr. and his associates. Mr. Dumaine was president of the railroad until last spring, when he lost control to Patrick B. McGinnis.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed very steady yesterday, 1 point lower to 17 points higher than on Tuesday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower acted quickly today to make consultation with the Democrats on foreign and military policy a "must" for Administration officials.
The Illinois Central Railroad borrowed $18,000,000 yesterday through the sale of an issue of twenty-five-year sinking fund debentures to a banking syndicate headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc.

KANSAS CITY, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The National Collegiate Athletic Association said today its New York convention would study five proposals for televising football in 1955, including the possibility of regional TV presentations.

The Central Chapter of Queens, Red Cross, 92-32 Union Hall Street, Jamaica, will begin Christmas activities tonight, when 200 Red Cross volunteer hostesses will attend the formal Christmas dance at St. Albans Naval Hospital.
MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- Soviet writers were pointedly reminded today that their duty was to serve the cause of communism.
Donors at the Red Cross Blood Center, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, began yesterday the traditional ceremony of hanging cardboard bottle ornaments on the Christmas tree.
ALBANY, Dec.15 -- Governor-elect Averell Harriman will be sworn in as the state's fiftieth Governor before midnight Dec. 31 in the Executive Mansion here. The ceremony will be private.
Inviting the children into the kitchen for a session of Christmas cookie-making is a pleasant, old-fashioned custom that persists in many households.
New Orleans borrowed $8,100,000 in the public market yesterday to finance the construction of a civic center and the purchase of a railway station.
THE HAGUE, The Netherlands, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Netherlands gave self-rule to the former colonies of Surinam and the Dutch Antilles today except in foreign policy and defense.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower made the following main points at his news conference today:

A substantial increase in last-half orders will not prevent General Electric Company's 1954 sales from dropping 5 per cent from the record $3,128,127,000 chalked up last year, according to Ralph J. Cordiner, president.

Intercollegiate football has lost another former bulwark. Fordham University, which first fielded a team in 1883 and whose 1940 and 1941 squads played in major bowl games, announced last night its decision to discontinue the sport. "Continuing financial loss" was given as the reason.

Irving Potash, first of the eleven convicted top Communist leaders to be released after serv-, ing a sentence for conspiracy to violate the Smith Act, was heldi in $5,000 bail yesterday in Fed. eral Court on another Indictment. This one charged membership in an organization that taught and advocated the violent overthrow of the Government.
Harrison Smith indignantly withdrew yesterday from a proposed discussion of Sinclair Lewis, charging the Library of Congress with trying to "ghostwrite my contribution."

As the holiday season gathers momentum and splendor an interesting phenomenon may be observed: while no one was looking, lately, the age of black and white has quietly been sinking into the past. This year, brighter than ever, chromatic fantasies of Christmas cheer glitter in shop windows, tides of dazzling and frenetic color flood the Great White Way and luminous necklaces bejewel the boughs of evergreens.

Elmer Davis' new book will be called "Two Minutes to Midnight." The title is taken from the clock illustration on the cover of the Bulletin of the Atomic Scientists, which used to be set at eight minutes before midnight. Mr. Davis says that "when the Russians displayed their atomic bomb it went up to three minutes before, and their hydrogen bomb moved it a minute closer."
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 15 -- The United States won a point today against Soviet allegations that it had committed piracy in the China seas.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Substantial progress has been made in the last year in the production of food in South and Southeast Asia, the third annual report of the Colombo Plan said today.

The Schools Motion Picture Committee, a voluntary organization composed of teachers and parents of pupils in local public and private elementary and high schools, recommends as suitable for children between 8 and 14 years old a group of motion pictures to be shown tomorrow through Sunday, unless otherwise specified.

Collectively and in a number of individual spots, the Chicago White Sox were the best defensive club in the American League last summer, according to the official 1954 fielding averages released for publication today.

NEWARK, Dec. 15 -- More testimony by longshoremen that they had been forced to pay job kick-backs to a union official to get work on Newark piers was presented here today in the third day of public hearings by the New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission.

Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, has approached experts to determine the possibility of building an underground conveyor belt from Times Square to Pennsylvania Station.

BRISBANE, Australia, Thursday, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Tony Trabert, who apparently snapped out of his slump overnight, met Sweden's Sven Davidson today in the first singles match of the United States-Sweden interzone Davis Cup final.

The Sheraton Corporation of America reported yesterday a net profit of $7,024,031 for the six months through October. This was 134 per cent more than the $3,001,463 cleared in the corresponding period of 1953.

The 1954 Edison Medal has been awarded by the American Institute of Electrical Engineers to Dr. Oliver T. Buckley of Maplewood, N. J. He is a retired president of Bell Telephone Laboratories, Inc. The medal, one of engineering's major awards, will be presented Feb. 2 at the institute's winter meeting.

MOSCOW, Dec. 15 -- The Soviet Government proclaimed tonight its "full support" for the Chinese Communist demand that United States forces be withdrawn from Formosa, the Pescadores Islands and the Strait of Formosa.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 15 -- The parliamentary duel over the Paris agreements began today as tensions were building up over rearmament, reunification and the "sellout" to the French.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 16 -- The Communists are stepping up their propaganda campaign directed at Japan.
GRIMSBY, England, Dec. 15 -- The dispute between the fishermen of Iceland and Britain eventually may erupt in the United Nations.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Dec. 15 -- Columbia's basketball team scored a decisive triumph in opening its Ivy League season against Yale tonight.
An old North River steamship pier changed hands yesterday at public auction, Pier 18 at Murray Street will still serve transportation, but instead of ships it will be automobiles.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 15 -- Fazlul Huq, called a traitor after he was reported to have planned to make East Pakistan an independent country, arrived here tonight in response to an urgent invitation from Prime Minister Mohammed Ali.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 14 -- About thirty of India's powerless princes have agreed to a cut in their take-home pensions.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Confirmation of reports that the Administration would ask Congress to extend existing corporation and excise tax rates for another year came from President Eisenhower today. The rates are scheduled to be reduced next April 1.

Philips-Bruce, Inc., a new concern specializing in French Provincial and antique reproductions, opened yesterday at 944 Third Avenue. The company will manufacture and import furniture pieces for living, dining and bedrooms and has a drapery and upholstery workshop. Its wares will be available through decorators.

Commodity prices moved irregularly higher yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, potatoes, rubber, hides, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and silk were stronger, coffee and wool showed mixed changes and sugar, burlap, zinc and tin ended lower.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Industrial production and retail sales picked up last month, the Federal Reserve Board reported tonight.
Somewhere in Brooklyn a sloppy thug, if he reads the papers, will be kicking himself today for having thrown out $700.
An installation that permits passengers to enter or leave airliners without the usual exposure to the weather went into operation yesterday at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

Electric power production for the week ended last Saturday rose to 9,846,000,000 kilowatt hours, topping the previous week's record high figure of 9,612,000,000, the Edison Electric Institute reported yesterday. The figure for the week ended Dec. 12, 1953, was 8,661,000,000. Increased industrial use and continued cold weather are given as reasons for the rise.

An aged person who is mentally ill and a pauper has a good chance of being cared for in a public institution. On the other hand, if an aged person's mind is "normal" and he cannot prove himself destitute, he has a good chance of walking the streets uncared for or living with relatives who do not want him.

ATHENS, Dec. 15 -- Three men who had not previously held portfolios became Cabinet Ministers today -- Leon Maccas, for Commerce; Stavros Polizogopoulos, social welfare, and Lieut. Gen. George Kosmas as Governor General of Northern Greece.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower said today an Air Force official had assured him that flying saucers were not invading the earth from outer space.

Representatives of hospitals and health and welfare agencies affiliated with the Greater New York Fund gathered in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday to receive checks representing their allocations from $5,497,685 raised in this year's campaign.
Tugs, tankers, liners and lighters dug their noses deep into the storm-tossed furrows of the Atlantic yesterday.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- France's Minister of the Interior has proposed that a "jury of honor" judge accusations that he was partly responsible for "leaks" of secret defense information.

Traditionally the yuletide is associated with sparkling crystal and glassware. For more than two centuries a good percentage of the glasses lifted in toasts throughout the world during the holiday season have been blown, molded and pressed in Sweden's oldest and largest glassworks, situated here.
An opposition group took over a special meeting called by the management of the Blair Holdings Corporation yesterday, after the president in a one-minute appearance declared the meeting adjourned.

An electrical scientist predicted here yesterday that energy taken from sunlight, using solar batteries of pure silicon as converters, probably could provide power for household needs in sunny areas some day. He said, however, that the energy would not be sufficient to drive automobiles and other vehicles.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 15 -- The Philco Corporation was charged today with violations of the anti-trust laws in a civil suit filed by the Department of Justice in United States District Court here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A new defense program to reduce the number of men in uniform and rely in emergencies on better trained reserves was outlined today by President Eisenhower.

The General Tire and Rubber Company has offered stockholders of the Motor Products Corporation one share of General Tire's 5 1/2 per cent cumulative preference stock in exchange for 4 1/2 shares of Motor Products common.

On his first visit to New York, Carlo Guggenheim, member of one of the youngest couture houses in Rome, expressed his delight this week over the warm-heartedness of the city. A squirrel scampering across the sidewalk in Central Park symbolized the friendly spirit of the city to him.

A FRIEND of mine who knows the earth's great cities says he'd like to spend the rest of his life as a citizen of San Francisco -- provided that he can have at least eight months of every year in New York. He may get his wish. Who knows? But if he does, he'll undoubtedly use up most of his stay on Manhattan Island complaining bitterly, as usual, about the traffic, dirt and clamor.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Sales of butter to Russia and her satellites, both directly and through third countries, will be considered by the Cabinet here on Friday.
A district attorney has broad powers to help even the worst kind of wrongdoer whom he may need as a witness in state's evidence. The problem of using such informants arises almost daily.
United States efforts to free the American prisoners of war held by the Chinese Communists face some of the same imponderables that have defied rational military analysis.
Citations for brave and meritorious service were awarded yesterday to 289 members of the Police Department.
A third-period goal by Danny Lewicki enabled the New York Rangers to tie the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 3 to 3.
LONDON, Dec. 15 -- Officials here say the Arab nations are coordinating their defenses and moving toward closer military cooperation with the West.
City and state facilities for handling delinquent boys are "shockingly inadequate," a lawyers' group asserted yesterday.
A Salvation Army truck driver, two radio car patrolmen and an apartment doorman took part yesterday in a three-block chase along Riverside Drive in which a mugging suspect was captured.

BOSTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Center Ray Felix tossed in 27 points for New York tonight as the Knickerbockers defeated the Eastern Division leading Syracuse Nationals, 88 -- 81, in a National Basketball Association game.

CHICAGO, Dec. l5 -- Directors of Hertz Corporation, Chicago, approved a contract today to purchase for $6,750,000 the common stock of Metropolitan Distributors, Inc., New York City truck leasing concern.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Today's report of the livestock markets here by the Department of Agriculture follows:

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Three sets of playing schedules for a possible ten - club American League, involving combination of six new areas, are being drafted by a league committee exploring expansion problems.

Some time ago you printed an editorial on the National Woodrow Wilson Fellowship Program at Princeton University which, you stated, is designed to produce more "promising young men and women for college teaching careers in the humanities and social sciences -- academic areas of acute personnel shortages."
Steels and oils, rallying in the closing hour of the session, led the stock market higher yesterday.

Thirteen children, badly in need themselves, sacrificed their little spending money to help two blind babies whose need they decided was greater than their own. They sent $4 to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

NICE, France, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Aristotle Onassis, Greek-born ship operator, said today that the International Court of Justice in The Hague eventually might have to rule on the validity of his contract with the Saudi Arabian Government for the shipment of oil.

MONTREAL, Dec. 15 (Canadian Press) -- Pulp and paper production in Canada will set a record this year of about 9,900,000 tons, R. M. Fowler, president of the Canadian Pulp and Paper Association, said today in a year-end review.
Recent Harlem fire disasters were attributed yesterday to a shortage of firemen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Ralph H. Demmler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, today cut off questioning about defense aspects of the Government's contract for the proposed Dixon-Yates power plant.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The United States and the Phillipine Republic signed today a revised trade agreement on terms that promise to strengthen Manila's lagging economy. The new agreement is subject to approval by the Congresses of both countries.

A perjury indictment against a suspended policeman was dismissed yesterday in Kings County Court. The defendant's attorney announced he would seek his client's reinstatement in the department with a request for $16,000 in back salary.

The action of the Public Service Commission in "railroading through" the reorganization of the Long Island Rail Road was attacked again yesterday by the city. A brief opposing the P. S. C. order was filed in the Supreme Court in Albany.
BAGHDAD, Iraq, Dec. 15 -- Premier Nuri al-Said informed Parliament today that it was his Government's intention to terminate the treaty of alliance with Britain before its expiration date.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 15 -- The Cowles Commission for Research in Economics will be transferred from Chicago to Yale University July 1.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Stenographer, a 3-year-old filly that most horsemen figured would have a dismal year, today was voted the harness horse of the year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Following is an unofficial transcript of President Eisenhower's news conference today, with the President's remarks in indirect discourse according to conference rules.
INDIANAPOLIS, Dec. 15 -- A Government-industry team gave the first public demonstration today of a new airplane fuel tank it believed would greatly increase chances of crash survival.

The indications from Washington are that a genuine era of bipartisan cooperation in the field of foreign affairs and national defense may be commencing once again. In a White House conference with Congressional leaders of both parties President Eisenhower has said he would consult with Democrats as well as Republicans in this area before making his recommendations to Congress.

DOVER, Del., Dec. 15 (UP) -- Charges against Bryan D. Bowles, head of the Association for the Advancement of White Persons, for seeking to block integration of Negro children in Delaware public schools were dismissed today in the Court of Common Pleas.
A two-door freezer-refrigerator unit, in which the smaller freezer stands upright beside the refrigerator, was shown by Kelvinator yesterday at the Essex House.
Waterfront employers turned thumbs down yesterday on a dozen contract demands resurrected by the International Longshoremen's Association after its members had spurned a Thanksgiving Day agreement.

NUECES, Tex., Dec. 15 -- If an Eastern hunter had trailed us this afternoon, he would have shared our conclusion that Texas sportsmen not only possess boundless enthusiasm but also are willing to hunt the hard way.
LONDON, Dec. 15 (Reuters) -- Hungary's championship Red Banner soccer team today gained a 2-2 tie witth Chelsea after trailing, 2 -- 1, at the half.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Representative Kit Clardy, Republican of Michigan, said today the "kingpin" who allegedly had placed Communists in Government departments had been identified in a closed session.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The American Federation of Labor rejected today a plea by an affiliate to take in a union ousted by the Congress of Industrial Organizations five years ago on charges of Communist domination.

An extremely exciting, if, on the stage side of the business, excessively and unnecessarily raw presentation of Strauss' "Salome" was given last night at the Metropolitan, with a new Salome in the person of Christel Goltz. Dimitri Mitropoulos also made his first appearance in the Metropolitan Opera House as the conductor and a well-nigh incomparable interpreter of the score.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Secretary of the Navy Charles Thomas today denied that intervention of Vice President Richard M. Nixon was responsible for the Navy's refusing security clearance to Dr. Edward U. Condon, former chief of the United States Bureau of Standards.
The president of the State Congress of Industrial Organizations called on Governor-elect Averell Harriman yesterday to press for a state-wide minimum wage of $1.25 an hour.
The Commerce and Industry Association of New York, Inc., proposed yesterday that picketing to force an employe to join a union be forbidden by law.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 15 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was denounced today as his wife's murderer and defended as an innocent victim of blundering detective work.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- A bill to be submitted to the next Congress would enable the United States Government to pay for emergency transportation and some kinds of emergency medical expenses of the dependents of Americans serving Government agencies abroad.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 15 (AP) -- The Judy-Bob Stable's Crown Derby captured his second purse of the Tropical Park meeting today. The consistent son of Jack High defeated eight other sprinters in the featured optional claiming handicap before 8,011 fans and paid $13.50 for $2.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 15 -- Warner Brothers announced today that Bruce Manning had been signed to write the screen play of "The Lion's Share" for Clark Gable.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 15 -- Eight men from Ireland who took part in the Irish Republican Army's new campaign of violence against Northern Ireland were jailed in Belfast today. They were sentenced to terms of ten to twelve years for an armed raid on the Omagh military barracks in County Tyrone in October.

NEWARK, Dec. 15 -- New Jersey Turnpike Authority officials are impatiently awaiting the appearance of a fog in this area. Their four fog-dispelling devices, installed experimentally early in October at a cost of $20,000, are still untested because the right kind of fog has not appeared.
SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 15 -- South Korea's first independent radio station was dedicated here today. The 5,000-watt station will be known as the Seoul Christian Radio, with the call letters HLKY.
A union official was sentenced yesterday to eight years in prison for trying to "fix" an income tax investigation.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 15 -- The Pakistani Government, which entered the commercial aviation field six months ago, will begin tri-weekly, round-trip, non-stop service between Karachi and Bombay tomorrow.

Four hundred Jewish leaders formally opened last night a $3,500,000 campaign of the United Hias Service, the recently consolidated international Jewish migration agency, at a dinner at the Biltmore Hotel.

AS elsewhere, art galleries put forward their best and most salable work at Christmas time. And the miscellany of paintings and sculpture that is to be found in and about Fifty-seventh Street provides an excellent means of judging the character of a particular gallery.
The second chapter of the book of Genesis admonishes us that "It is not good that the man should be alone."

Manhattan College's basketball team opened an 8-point lead at the half and went on to a 68-58 victory over Wagner on the Seahawks' court in Grymes Hill, Staten Island, last night. The triumph was the second in three games for the Jaspers.
The country experimented yesterday with Safe Driving Day. The results were inconclusive.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 (UP) -- Two national safety organizations issued today an "urgent warning" against highly flammable imported Christmas toys now on sale throughout the country.
MADRID, Dec. 15 -- A bill that would empower the Government not only to control but actually to manage all of Spain's privately owned daily newspapers has been drafted.
MUNICH, Germany, Dec. 14 -- The tentative program for forming a foreign legion of former Eastern Europeans fascists within the new German army has been put aside.

The Times of Dec. 10 had an article quoting Roy M. Cohn, former chief counsel of McCarthy's Senate Investigations Subcommittee, as saying that The Baltimore Sun published a "fabrication" regarding this young man's expenses on his investigative trip to Europe with G. David Schine and that The Sun later "retracted." This is not true.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Toronto Maple Leafs set a season scoring record for the National Hockey League tonight as they took undisputed possession of second place with an 8-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks. The Leafs had been tied for second with Detroit.
Stewart B. Iglehart of Delray Beach, Fla.; Cecil Smith, San Antonio, and Bob Skene, Beverly Hills, Calif., again head this country's outdoor polo players.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- About one in every twenty babies born in the United States now arrives prematurely.

Eugene Ormandy will conduct the Philadelphia Orchestra in a special program of Christmas music on Channel 13 tonight from 8 to 9 o'clock. The Trapp Family Singers and the Anthony Tudor Ballet also will appear on the program, which will originate at the Academy of Music in Philadelphia.
The Administration is considering the sale of surplus butter and other farm products to Russia.

Henry Brant's "December" was revealed in all its avant-garde glory to an unsuspecting Carnegie Hall audience last night. The work, which received its first performance, had been commissioned by the Collegiate Chorale and was sung by them under the direction of Ralph Hunter.

Two goals within twenty seconds in the closing minutes of the game gave the St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., a 5-3 victory over the Princeton Freshmen in their annual benefit hockey game at Madison Square Garden yesterday.
MONT ROLLAND, Que., Dec. 15 (AP) -- Four Albany archivists left for home today with twelve boxes of New York State documents that almost landed in a bath of acid.

Details of plans for redevelopment of the St. Lawrence River Valley around Massena were contained in a report released yesterday by the New York State Power Authority. The area will be affected physically by the St. Lawrence Power and Seaway projects.
ALBANY, Dec. 15 -- Republican leaders declared today that they would fight any attempt by Governor-elect Averell Harriman to increase taxes to balance the 1955-56 budget.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman told a Bill of Rights Day gathering at the Brooklyn Borough Hall yesterday that the nation could not meet threats from the outside with "weakness or retreat."

Anderson Cairns, Inc., advertising agency, announced yesterday the engagement of a business research organization to forecast the business outlook for its clients, and promptly heard from the group's head a gloomy forecast for the next year and more.
An object to use at home might provide a solution to the "difficult" person on the gift list, from the man of the family to its youngest member.

Along the shores of Europe, from Norway to the Mediterranean, is found a species of shellfish known in natural science circles as the Homarus gammarus, or common lobster. It is smaller than the Maine lobster (H. americanus), but very good to eat.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 15 (AP) -- Carmine G. DeSapio, New York County Democratic leader and the state's next Secretary of State, outlined today a plan for extending the operations of his home county organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The Government is investigating charges that bribes have been offered to members of Congress in an effort to induce them to vote for Federal pay rise legislation.
St. John's University of Brooklyn and Iona College of New Rochelle, N. Y., risk unbeaten records tonight in the collegiate basketball double-header at Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Alfred Cowles 3d, Calvin Fentress Jr. and Carsten E. Ronning have been nominated as directors of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, it was disclosed today in the proxy statement sent to stockholders.

The flier-inventor-industrialist-capitalist, Howard Hughes, again left the financial world wondering last night. He failed to tender his 1,262,120 shares of RKO Pictures Corporation to the company for redemption at $6 a share, under an offer first made last April and which expired yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The State Department backed away today from one position it had taken in the United States dispute with Communist China.

The progress report on the St. Lawrence Power Project made by Robert Moses yesterday was full of good news and -- as was to have been expected -- strong words. Mr. Moses, whose speech had to be read for him at Ogdensburg because the weather kept him away, was on this occasion acting as chairman of the New York State Power Authority.
PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Problems extending from Europe to Asia, including atomic defense of the West, will be discussed in overlapping conferences of Western leaders beginning here tomorrow.
The New Jersey Legislature will reconvene on Monday to extend rent control, on a local option basis, for eighteen months. The present control law expires Dec. 31.
Heavy withdrawals of fuel oil from storage continued last week.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 15 -- Explosions at widely separated points in the Tunis area last night were followed today by a series of official pronouncements of dismay and condemnation.

PARIS, Dec. 15 -- Lord Ismay, Secretary General of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, said today the alliance must decide how to authorize the use of atomic weapons in a hurry in the event of an attack. The decision and the machinery to implement it are problems for the political authorities of the alliance, alone, he said.
CHICAGO, Dec. 15 -- Wheat showed a strong tone for much of yesterday's session, but the demand slowed on the rallies, with buyers not especially confident.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The President has made the most elaborate plan yet devised to try to achieve what has become known as '"bipartisanship" in foreign policy, and has increased all past dimensions of the effort by adding national defense and collective security policies to its scope.

SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 15 -- C. E. Hooper, nationally known originator of the Hooper method of radio surveys, was killed here late today in a boat accident at the Lake Front Duck Club on the Great Salt Lake.

The spirit of Christmas received a hearty welcome on the Columbia College campus yesterday when 400 students, faculty members and guests took part in the traditional Yule log-lighting ceremony. Carols and eggnog followed the lighting of the log by Dr. Grayson Kirk, president of Co lumbia.

A program of what by stretching the definition a bit might be called contemporary piano music was presented at Carl Fischer Concert Hall last evening by John Cage, composer-pianist, and David Tudor, pianist.
William McChesney Martin, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, denounced here yesterday the idea that the Federal Reserve System can maintain overwhelming control over interest rates.

Local No. 2 of the New York Newspaper Printing Pressmen's Union, A. F. L., voted last night to accept a two-year contract with the Publishers Association of New York City. The contract calls for a $5.80 weekly wage-welfare package increase.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- Ambassador Henri Bonnet of France compared the press of the United States today to "the little glass of white wine that the workman in my country still prefers to milk before setting out on his hard day's work."

The imprisonment of aliens who are being detained by the Immigration Service pending final disposition of their cases has stirred widespread, and well-justified, indignation. As we have said repeatedly, it is both inhuman and un-American to throw anyone into jail who has not been convicted of some crime or misdemeanor in court by due process of law.
Agatha Christie's murder mystery thriller, "Witness for the Prosecution," opens at Henry Miller's Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock under the auspices of Gilbert Miller and Peter Saunders.

The appointment of John C. Williams to the new office of chairman of L. Bamberger Co. was announced yesterday by Jack I. Straus, president of R. H. Macy Co., Inc. David L. Yunich, senior vice president of Macy's New York, was appointed president of the Newark store to succeed Mr. Williams.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 8, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 -- President Eisenhower was naturally cautious today about discussing the use of atomic weapons in defense of Western Europe.

The highest award of the Federal Republic of Germany, the Commander's Cross of the Order of Merit, was presented last night to Dr. Alvin Johnson, president emeritus of the New School for Social Research.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Four employes of the State Historian's office returned from Mont Rolland, Quebec, this afternoon.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Averell Harriman was elected Governor Nov. 2 by an official plurality of 11,125 votes.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- A milder and more forgiving attitude toward Soviet authors who violate the literary canons of communism has been proclaimed here.
Ford C. Frick, the commissioner of baseball, revealed yesterday that he was withholding approval of Ralph Kiner's new contract with the Cleveland Indians.

Willie Mays, 23-year-old centerfielder of the world champion Giants, was established yesterday as the winner of the National League's most valuable player award for 1954. The official announcement confirmed a judgment reached by most baseball fans even before the season had ended.

Even those little gifts for stuffing into Christmas stockings have their full share of glamour this year. Priced at $2 and less -- and many are comfortably close to or below the dollar mark -- are novel items that are practical, fun or fashionable.
Use of Ellis Island and seven state-operated tuberculosis hospitals as homes for the aged is being considered by public officials.

Directors of the Mid-Continent Petroleum Corporation at a meeting here yesterday recommended a four-for-one split in the capital stock of the company. They also called a special meeting of stockholders for Feb. 15 to take the necessary action to put the split into effect, including an increase in authorized stock to 10,000,000 shares from 3,000,000.
Choice of a director is holding up "Janus," in which Margaret Sullavan would like to appear.

On a sales increase of 1.7 per cent, North American Aviation, Inc., lifted its net income by 73.6 per cent to a record $22,179,736 in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30. Net income was $12,773,361 in the previous year.
Rank-and-file moves for an immediate dock strike were checked yesterday by leaders of the International Longshoremen's Association.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- The proposal to establish uniform youth courts throughout the state received an enthusiastic reception at a public hearing here today.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Industrial share prices continued to rise today after publication of more favorable company profit statements. Buying was still selective and directed mainly to the better class shares. The tobacco group was specially prominent and stores again were stimulated by reports of good Christmas trade.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Sentiment in favor of trying to exchange Chinese students in this country for Americans held in Communist China appeared to be growing on Capitol Hill today.
Periodic mass purges in Russia were attributed to the corresponding "dangerous mentality" of the Russian people in a lecture given by Dr. Nicholas Laskovsky at Fordham University last night.

The New York Typographical Union, No. 6, A. F. L., broke off contract negotiations yesterday with the Publishers Association of New York City. Francis Barrett, president of the local, an affiliate of the International Typographical Union, said its members would meet at 2:30 P. M. Sunday in Stuyvesant High School, First Avenue and Fifteenth Street, to decide the union's course.

Today's new film is "Port of Hell," an Allied Artists melodrama with Wayne Morris, Dane Clark and Carole Mathews, at the Palace. Robert Nunes and Harold Schuster directed from a screen play by Tom Hubbard, Fred Eggers and Gil Doud and an original story by Mr. Doud and D. D. Beauchamp.

One of the biggest and newest power cranes in the world took its stance at the Forty-fifth Street end of Shubert Alley yesterday morning and in two and one-half hours neatly deposited sixty tons of steel on the sixteenth floor setback of the Picadilly Hotel.

VIENNA, Dec. 16 -- A member of a Western diplomatic mission has reported from Budapest that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty had been released. The report was published by the Catholic press agency here but has not been confirmed in Rome. The Cardinal was sentenced to life imprisonment in 1949 by the Hungarian Communist regime.

C. P. Goepel in his letter in your issue of Dec. 11 discusses reform of our judicial set-up and procedures. I agree with him that "improvements in court procedures to obtain speedier trials, quicker adjudications and a reduction in expense to the litigants have become imperative."

The directors of the Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company approved yesterday a plan of merger with the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway. The plan provides for the exchange of one and one-half shares of L. N. common stock of $50 par value for each share of $100 par value common of the other road.

The heady spirit of Christmas pervades even grocery counters this week-end. Turkeys, oysters, cranberries, chestnuts, fresh dates, candied cherries and all their festive like crowd the shelves, or, as in the case of turkeys, are offered for order.

ADDIS ABABA, Ethiopia, Dec. 6 -- Ethiopia's relations with the rest of the world are conditioned by two considerations: recognition of the need for foreign assistance and proud determination to escape foreign domination.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Dec. 16 -- Governor-elect Averell Harriman warned Republican legislators last night that if they refused to cooperate with him he would battle them in the same way former President Truman fought the Eightieth Congress.

EAST HAMPTON; L. I., Dec. 16 -- The bells of Christmas are ringing all over this old village today. The bell motif was struck by the 1954 Christmas Decoration Committee, headed by Robert Vetault, early in November.

ATHENS, Dec. 16 -- Premier Alexander Papagos dismissed both the Acting Governor of Northern Greece and the chief of the security forces in the area tonight for having allowed manifestations "against friends and allies."
Next year Congress will be urged by the American Parents Committee to appropriate $15,000,000 for crippled children's services in 1956, or $4,200,000 more than the 1955 appropriation.

Parents, in making plans for their children, minimize the pressures that changing world conditions will put on these youngsters by the time they reach college age, a leading military chaplain said here yesterday.

NUECES, Tex., Dec. 16 -- Once this column is out of the way, we will relax for a few moments before taking up the task of pulling cactus spines from our legs and daubing iodine on the cat-claw scratches.
In a move that surprised many in Wall Street, the governors of the New York Stock Exchange voted yesterday to close their market on Dec. 24, Christmas Eve.
Representative Adam Clayton Powell's personal secretary and her husband were indicted yesterday in an intricate tax fraud scheme.
HARTFORD, Dec. 16 -- Governor-elect Abraham A. Ribcoff today announced the appointment of eleven civilians as military and naval aides.

The fifteen-story and penthouse apartment building for fifty-nine families at the northeast corner of Madison Avenue and Eighty-eighth Street has been sold by Hugh K. McGovern and Louis Denberg, operators.

This Christmas season marks a double golden anniversary. Two separate events that took place in 1904 on opposite sides of the Atlantic in the intervening fifty years have merged into one of the traditionally important parts of the annual celebration of this most cheerful of our holidays.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Ralph H. Demmler, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission today moved to expedite hearings on financing arrangements for the Dixon-Yates electric power contract.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- In the three coordinate branches of the Government today the news that an editor had spurned the assistance of the Library of Congress in preparing a speech for an official occasion evoked a combination of amazement and alarm.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 16 -- Frank Sinatra has agreed to star for Jesse L. Lasky in "The Big Brass Band."
The Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith yesterday urged that the House Un-American Activities Committee be "encouraged" to expand its investigation of neo - Fascists and "hate" groups.
BERN, Switzerland, Dec. 16 (Reuters) -- Max Petitpierre was in effect elected president of Switzerland for 1955 by the Swiss Federal Assembly here today, both chambers voting together.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The outlook for business and credit is more favorable now than it has been for many years, George S. Moore, executive vice president of the National City Bank of New York, said here today.
The Transit Authority voted yesterday to open its regular weekly meetings to the press.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Administration is expected to propose tomorrow a military training program for all young men.

Election of R. E. McNeill Jr. as a director of the Continental Insurance Company, one of the five companies comprising the America Fore Insurance Group, was announced yesterday by Frank A. Christensen, president of the group.

CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- In moderately active trading yesterday, December wheat rose sharply, while other deliveries were inclined to lag. With only a few more days of trading in the current wheat delivery, shorts appeared to be getting nervous, as deliveries were negligible and both red and hard winter wheat held at good premiums.

Three dances, known as the Holiday Dances, will be held in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The first in the series, the Middle Holiday Dance, will be held on Monday night. The Senior Holiday Dance will take place on Wednesday night, and the Junior Holiday Dance on the night of Dec. 27.

The Citizens Budget Commission and a group of allied civic organizations carried to the City Council yesterday their campaign for use of the Hudson River as the next new source of water supply for the city.

STEUBENVILLE, Ohio, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Arrangements for the acquisition of the Follansbee Steel Corporation's mill at Follansbee, W. Va., by Cleveland industrialist Cyrus Eaton are being handled by the newly chartered F. S. Corporation of West Virginia.

United Cigar-Whelan Stores Corporation and Sun Ray Drug Company have reached a basis for a possible merger, it was announced yesterday. The resulting concern, which would operate under the United Cigar name, would have an annual sales volume of about $100,000,000.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Evening Tribune says today an intercontinental rocket designed to travel across oceans at great speeds is being built at an aircraft plant here.

In a recent article reviewing the Cyprus question C. L. Sulzberger states that "largely as a result of Mr. Kyrou's persistence the Papagos Government has vigorously taken up the irredentist cause." This is not accurate, as in a statment issued Dec. 13 the Greek Foreign Minister, S.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -Senator William Langer said today he would fight against Senate confirmation of John Marshall Harlan to the Supreme Court to stress his protest that no Justice has ever been named from his state and some others.
New York University will raise its faculty salaries and student tuition charges next year.
BRUSSELS, Belgium, Dec. 16 -- The tenth anniversary of the Battle of the Bulge and the heroism of the United States garrison of Bastogne was commemorated in the Hall of Academies here today.
MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The names of the Canadian golfers who will oppose the American squad in the fourth annual Hopkins Trophy matches next month were announced today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 16 (AP) -- An insurgent group of stockholders in the A. M. Byers Company submitted the names of a proposed new board of directors to the Securities and Exchange Commission today, their attorney announced.

IN the program for "Witness for the Prosecution," which opened at Henry Miller's last evening, the instructions to the theatregoers are as follows: "The audience is requested not to divulge the solution of the plot to those who have not seen the play."

The National Steel Corporation trimmed its prices in the Detroit area by $1 a ton yesterday. At least three other steel companies said they would meet the competition, and others were reported studying similar action.
Bob Baker, a Pittsburgh heavyweight, and Coley Wallace of Harlem will meet in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight.

THERE is a feeling of sadness akin to desolation at the news that Fordham is abandoning intercollegiate football. It's almost like the death of someone dear after an incurable, lingering illness. Death was to be preferred to suffering and yet, when it came, it still hit with shocking impact.
Charles Plumb, a harness racing steward, gave his version yesterday of the alleged "sitdown" by eight drivers at Yonkers Raceway on Oct. 30.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The California State Athletic Commission today imposed a two-week suspension on George Kanter, the American representative of the French boxer, Pierre Langlois. The ban is subject to revocation if Kanter apologizes by letter for statements concerning last night's world middleweight title bout.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- A Federal Court ruled today that the Postmaster General could not prevent, in effect, continued publication of a magazine because certain issues contained obscene matter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- James P. Mitchell, Labor Secretary, said today he intended to establish the first Federal minimum wage for soft-coal miners.

The President of the United States, conferring, as it is quaintly put, with the press, is expected to know everything and to answer any question if the interests of the country permit. Mr. Eisenhower was therefore asked on Wednesday if he had reason to believe that flying saucers were coming into our atmosphere from outer space.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Federal Trade Commission said today that Ann H. Hartman, trading as Fashion Academy of New York City at 812 Fifth Avenue, has agreed to an order forbidding representation that the "Fashion Academy gold medal award" is given to products on a competitive basis as an award for outstanding design.
CAIRO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Archaeologists excavating Cheops' solar boat from its stone crypt disclosed today the discovery of what they believe to be the first copper coupling joint from ancient Egypt.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Columbus business interests are considering an International League baseball franchise as a possibility for the vacant Red Bird Stadium.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- The Republican majority leader of the Senate promised tonight to investigate every nominee to Governor-elect Averell Harriman's Cabinet.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The Duke of Edinburgh met forty leaders of industry and trade unions today to plan for a Commonwealth and Empire conference on "the human problems of industrial communities."

Franco Spain is apparently to have a new press law. Its form, according to the new Spanish Ambassador to Washington, Senor Areilza, is yet to be decided and may or may not, as our Madrid correspondent wrote, provide for all-powerful newspaper editors appointed by the Government.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Navy has been assigned administrative control over United States military assistance programs in the Pacific and Southeast Asia.

BRISBANE, Australia, Friday, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas sent the United States into the challenge round of the Davis Cup competition today by whipping Sweden's Sven Davidson and Lennart Bergelin, 6 -- 3, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3.
New York City is soon to have 21,628 patrolmen -- the largest police force in its history.

Events todsy: Philharmo Symphony, Bruno Walter conducting, Irmgard Seefried, so* prano, George London, base-baritone, Carnegie Hall, 2:30 P. M.I National Association for Ameri* can Composers hnd Conductors, Town Hall, 5:30; "Cavalleria Rusticana" and "Pagliacci," fet /mlitan Opera, 8:15.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Sir Winston Churchill apologized to the House of Commons today for his facetiousness. It was the second apology he had made this month.

A detective answered a summons for help yesterday from a man whose apartment had been ransacked. He found nothing was missing, not even twelve unanswered traffic summonses. Five more turned up later, and the man who had called for police action got it quickly. Bail was set at $250.

With reference to the editorial of Dec. 4 deploring the current apparent lack of interest in Russian studies in the United States I venture to suggest that part of the reason for this state of affairs may be found in the peculiarly uncoordinated security clearance policies of some of our federal agencies.
A modest woman with a friendly smile delivered her usual crisp $1,000 bill to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday, chatted with a cashier and went on her way, as anonymously as ever.

MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Soviet Union's top soldier, Marshal Georgi K. Zhukov, accused Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill and Field Marshal Viscount Montgomery today of treachery during World War II.
Three months of negotiations were nullified yesterday with the announcement that more than 300 lighter captains had rejected an employer proposal.

BUFFALO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Badget Mine Stripping Corporation of Madisonville, Ky., submitted today the low bid of $1,372,800 for the first project in the United States phase of the St. Lawrence Seaway. It was less than half of the Government estimate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- During the week ended yesterday, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves increased $489,000,000.

Domestic copper shipments soared to 122,908 tons last month -- the largest tonnage since June of 1953 -- as fabricators sought to rebuild inventories nearly exhausted during the widespread copper strikes last fall.

The new chief judge of the New York State Court of Appeals, Albert Conway, was sworn in yesterday. The oath was administered by the retiring chief judge, Edmund H. Lewis, in the Brooklyn Appellate Division Court House, 45 Monroe Place.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Fullback Jim Decker was dropped from Southern California's Rose Bowl squad today after physicians reported that his knee could not take the grind of daily practice for the New Year's Day game.
CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE, N. J., Dec. 16 (AP) -- A state trooper on a routine patrol today captured Allen Bodine Scott, one-time mental patient sought since July in the slaying of his grandmother.
The gold clause -- the pledge that a bondholder will be paid back money having the same value in terms of gold as that which he invested -- is in the courts again.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 10 -- Scientists in several African states are working on a problem caused by a change in the eating habits of the African native.
Not very much is to be said of the performances of Schubert's "Unfinished" Symphony and Brahms' "Requiem" given under Bruno Walter's direction last night in Carnegie Hall.
An all-male jury was deliberating early today the fate of 21-year-old William Brown, a Queens auto mechanic, accused of murdering a 19-year-old girl last March 13.

REGINALD ROSE, who previously this season contributed two superior dramatic works, "Twelve Angry Men" and "An Almanac of Liberty," to "Studio One," fell short of his mark this week. His newest play, "12:32 A. M.," dealing with the gulf that may separate the adult and child worlds, never quite fulfilled the promise of its theme.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 16 (AP) -- The First Unitarian Church of Berkeley said today it had decided to pay annual taxes of more than $2,200 rather than sign a loyalty oath.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 16 -- In a first test the Bundestag defeated tonight a motion to postpone ratification of the Paris agreements.

In an election year it was too much to expect that Congressmen would raise their own salaries, though the political dynamite involved in such a step has, we think, been exaggerated. In any case, 1955 is not an election year, and perhaps Representative Walter's bill to give adequate pay increases to members of Congress and of the federal judiciary will meet with success.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- The Navy said today it was planning a $1,000,000 remodeling job on the newly launched supercarrier Forrestal.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet threat to annul the French-Soviet alliance if France should ratify the Paris accords had no deterring impact on French plans today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- An Air Force captain who resigned after he reportedly had given a secret document to a House Committee was found employed on its staff today.

THERE were four Pizarro brothers and the youngest, Gonzalo, achieved a career almost as spectacular as that of Francisco himself. Like his more famous brother, Gonzalo was illegitimate and illiterate, a magnificent soldier, brave, daring, resourceful and completely unscrupulous. Francisco conquered the Inca Empire by treachery and brutal cruelty and died a marquis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Administration announced plans today to certify all Air Force air traffic controllers to handle civil air traffic as well.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet Union informed Japan today that it was ready to negotiate for normal relations if Japan were likewise willing.
BOMBAY, India, Dec. 16 -- Marshal Tito, President of Yugoslavia, arrived in Bombay today. He is the first non-Asian head of state to visit independent India.
In the opinion of its sponsors, if not the experts, Safe Driving Day was a success.

TRENTON, Dec. 16 -- Representative Charles R. Howell late today conceded the election of Clifford P. Case as Senator from New Jersey. Simultaneously, he ordered his attorneys to end the recount of ballots immediately.

American farmers announced yesterday that they did not like the draft system or the proposed Universal Military Training. They also did not want private power companies to move into areas now covered by the Tennessee Valley Authority.

A new group of wallpapers, printed fabrics and paints that match is now available through decorators. Titled "Color Symphony," the collection was designed by Isabel Barringer Associates, Inc., for Cheney, Greef Co. and Murals, Inc.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange rose 2 to 8 points yesterday.
Two women and a 4-year-old boy were burned on the face and hands yesterday when naphtha cleaning fluid ignited and touched off a two-alarm blaze that swept a Brooklyn paint store.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (UP) -- The Montreal Canadiens ended their scoring slump with a 5-1 victory over the New York Rangers tonight. Maurice (Rocket) Richard tallied his 399th goal before 14,296 Forum fans.
ATLANTA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Influenza hit three Georgia Tech centers today and threatened to sideline a reserve guard.
Led by the rails, the stock market made a general advance that continued until the final hour and brought the best gains since Nov. 4.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Nelson A. Rockefeller was appointed today Special Assistant to President Eisenhower.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Arab League states have decided to form an Arab mutual defense pact, the Syrian Premier, Faris el-Khouri, said today.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Dr. Charles Laughead denied today he had predicted the end of the world next Tuesday, but said he believed there might be "violent upheavals" on the earth's surface then.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 16 -- Lieut. Gen. John W. (Iron Mike) O'Daniel declared today that South Vietnam -- weak and divided as it now is -- could still be saved from communism.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization was asked today to widen its activity beyond the military field. This request was contained in an international declaration on Atlantic unity, which was presented to Atlantic Alliance officials.

Business loans by member banks in the New York area declined $9,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday, the Federal Reserve Bank reported here yesterday. It was the second consecutive week of a decline in such loans.

A dinner in honor of Abraham Feinberg, who was recently elected chairman of the board of trustees of Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., was held last night at the Pierre Hotel. The dinner was sponsored by the Fellows of Brandeis University.

ALTHOUGH it seems a chilling idea in this frigid season, the hour-long dive into the briny afforded by "Hunters of the Deep" is a worthwhile excursion into "the twilight world" of the oceans. For the documentary, photographed in Eastman color, that arrived at the Sixtieth Street Trans-Lux yesterday is a serious and informative adventure.
OXFORD, Miss., Dec. 16 -- The University of Mississippi football team has leveled off to serious preparation for its Jan. 1 Sugar Bowl engagement. The Rebels are determined but a little puzzled.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP)--The Navy identified today six Navy airmen the Chinese Reds are believed to have captured, but never accounted for, after shooting down their plane off the South China coast in January, 1953.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Peronista party today expelled Senator Elvira Rodriguez Leonarde de Rosales, who refused to go along with the party in voting for Argentina's new divorce bill. Shortly afterward, Senora de Rosales resigned from the Senate.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 16 -- Plans for guided missile bases at Roosevelt Field and the North Shore village of Mill Neck were canceled and a survey started yesterday for alternate sites further east on Long Island.

Commodity futures prices closed irregularly higher on the New York exchanges yesterday. Trading in cottonseed oil was the fourth most active of the year, and hides and rubber also registered sizable volumes.

The stories of the Neediest daily bring forth a wide range of human reaction from readers. Many express their feelings simply by sending a check. Others offer varying comments, thoughtful and heartwarming, along with their contribution. One of our readers put himself in the position of a neighbor living next door to some of the Neediest.

MILES CITY, Mont., Dec. 16 (UP) -- At least eighteen persons were injured today when a broken rail derailed nine cars of the Northern Pacific Railroad's eastbound Mainstreeter, a passenger train, near this community [cross on map].
Final terms of the proposed merger of the American Woolen Company, Robbins Mills and Textron Incorporated into a single textile company to be known as Textron American were announced yesterday.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- United Nations consideration of the Tunisian issue has, in effect, been postponed at least until next year. The General Assembly's Political and Security Commission approved, 55 to 0, a resolution to put off "for the time being" discussion of the difficulties between France and Tunisia.

The Soviets have formally notified France that ratification of the Paris pacts will annul the twenty-year French-Soviet alliance treaty. This is on the alleged ground that France will then have joined an anti-Soviet military grouping bent on preparing new war.

The East River Savings Bank made a building and permanent loan of $1,500,000 to David Rose Associates, owners and builders of a sixteen-story and penthouse building under construction at 20 East Sixty-eighth Street, southwest corner of Madison Avenue.
PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Leaders of the Western powers discussed today how to strengthen their alliance and their defenses. At the same time the Soviet Union made another attempt to block this process.
ROME, Dec. 16 -- Pope Pius XII's recent collapse and present serious condition are due to a small hernia of the hiatus of the esophagus. This was disclosed today by a two-hour X-ray examination.

A year ago attention was centered on some phenomena in the Soviet literary world. A new atmosphere of comparative freedom seemed to be apparent, one in which writers could and did expose the sham and hypocrisy of the hack work to which Stalin, before his death, had reduced them.
ALBANY, Dec. 16 -- Governor Dewey appointed the permanent fifteen-member Board of Trustees of the six-year-old State University today.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Following is the text of the Soviet Union's note to France on the mutual assistance treaty:
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Despite bitter protests, the British Broadcasting Corporation repeated tonight its hard-hitting televised dramatization of the late George Orwell's novel, "Nineteen Eighty-Four."

It is not necessarily the function of Ambassadors to win the affection as well as the respect and trust of the nation to which they are accredited. Ambassador Henri Bonnet of France is retiring from his post in Washington and from his foreign service with a record that will rank him among the great French envoys to the United States.

The big General Post Office on Eighth Avenue between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets "really got rolling" yesterday on the annual Christmas rush of mail. By the time the flood tapers off next Thursday night the total volume handled should be 5 per cent above that of last year, according to Acting Postmaster John Sheehan.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Bridge tolls for three classes of trucks are being increased effective Dec. 30 on three Hudson River spans.

LONDON, Dec. 16 -- Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill rejected Laborite demands in Parliament today for a royal commission to investigate serious delays in supplying modern, swept-wing jet fighter aircraft to the Royal Air Force.
THE dignified retail establishment founded by Alexander Turney Stewart, first of the city's great merchant princes, will close its doors forever at 4 o'clock tomorrow afternoon.

MONTREAL, Dec. 16 (Canadian Press) -- A registration statement covering an offering to shareholders of up to 921,923 additional shares of Aluminium, Ltd., was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Library of Congress officials expressed surprise today over Harrison Smith's charge that it had tried to "ghostwrite" his part in a discussion of Sinclair Lewis.
Columbia's undefeated basketball team will meet Navy at University Hall tonight. The contest will be the twenty-third between the teams since 1932.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 16 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold has an appointment in Stockholm this weekend with Keng Pao, Communist China's Ambassador to Sweden. Mr. Hammarskjold plans to leave by air tomorrow evening.
Happy because the recent rains and mild weather did not do much damage to snow covers, owners of many ski centers in the northlands were ready to open their seasons officially today.

Demand deposit turnover, the rate at which depositors use their checking accounts, rose more than 5 per cent in November both in New York City and in the rest of the nation, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 16 -- The greatness of "Porgy and Bess" was illustrated again tonight, this time before an audience at the National Theatre that demanded thirteen curtain calls.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Department store sales in the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding week of last year. This was reported today by the Federal Reserve Board, which listed the following percentage changes from like periods of 1953:
The United States Supreme Court received a brief yesterday on behalf of a retired patrolman who is invoking his constitutional right against self-incrimination.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 16 (UP) -- Frank Smith rode three winners and the Brookmeade Stable's Dutch Lane accounted for the featured allowance purse today at Tropical Park.

Military and civilian personnel at Camp Kilmer, New Brunswick, N. J., gave 264 pints of blood to the New York Red Cross blood program Wednesday, when the program collected a total of 861 pints. Other large contributors were Brooklyn Polytechnic Institute, 195, and the staff of the Veterans Administration Hospital, the Bronx, 174.
One hundred and one Fordham seniors protested yesterday "the irrational attempt to equate our Catholic faith with a special political doctrine."
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Dec. 16 -- Delivery of twenty-five Mustang fighter planes from Sweden is expected here shortly.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The British Labor party will undertake a national propaganda and organization campaign early next year in anticipation of a general election in 1955.

It was possible to reach some important agreements on the revision of the trade relationship between the United States and the Philippines in a relatively short time because of the atmosphere of goodwill and friendship that prevailed in the negotiations.

Heavy cuts in military manpower, including a sharp reduction in the size of the Army and lesser but sizable reductions in the Navy and Marine Corps, are recommended in the President's proposed budget for the next (1956) fiscal year.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 16 -- A key Cabinet post was offered today to Hussain Shaheed, Suhrawardy, leader of the opposition United Front party, by Governor General Ghulam Mohammed.
Stockholders of the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company, Ltd., at a special meeting in London yesterday approved a capital adjustment plan and changed the concern's name to the British Petroleum Company, Ltd.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (UP) -- Farmers received $3,200,000,000 for crops and livestock in November, down 10 per cent from October and 6 per cent from a year earlier, the Department of Agriculture reported today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Gen. Nathan F. Twining, Air Force Chief of Staff, declared today that the striking power of his combat squadron might be hobbled in war by an obsolete supply system.
After trailing most of the first half, Fordham vanquished Colgate's basketball team, 55 to 51, last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy returned today from his vacation trip. He reportedly was much improved from an arm ailment, which hospitalized him during the recent censure debate in the Senate.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 16 (UP) The Ohio State football coach, Woody Hayes, received good news today about his two injured backfield stars as the Buckeyes held their final home practice for the Rose Bowl game.

CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 16 (AP) -- Jimmy Bloodworth, 37, a major league infielder for nine years, tonight was named manager of the Charlotte Baseball Club of the Class A South Atlantic Baseball League.

CAMDEN, N. J., Dec. 16 -- A Federal grand jury indicted here today a trade association, four corporations and ten individuals on charges of violating the Sherman Anti-Trust Act in the sale and installation of electrical equipment in South Jersey.
Broadcasting is well on its way toward becoming a billion-dollar industry.

In your Dec. 10 editorial "Light on the Economy" you refer to my suggestion that "unemployment next year may rise to 4,000,000 or 5,000,000." However, the editorial failed to include the rationale behind this prediction. By omitting any reference to The Times story from Los Angeles on Dec. 9, the editorial implies that I have conjured a dragon of doom from nothingness.
LONDON, Dec. 16 -- The latest Russian attack on Prime Minister Churchill and Field Marshal Montgomery failed today to worry the British Government.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 16 -- Five states were rocked today by earth shocks centered in a desolate area of northern Nevada, to the northeast of Fallon. Sleepers were awakened in California, Nevada, Oregon, Idaho and Utah, but physical damage was minor, despite the strength of the earth movements.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on last Saturday totaled 653,531 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today. This was 8,266 cars or 1.2 per cent fewer than for the preceding week, 1,580 cars or 0.2 per cent more than for the corresponding week last year and 67,811 cars, or 9.4 per cent fewer than during the corresponding week two years ago.

This metropolitan area, the richest in the country, is assayed, along with every other in the nation, in the 620-page market guide to be issued as a supplement to the issue of Editor and Publisher, newspaper trade magazine, out tomorrow.

Remington Rand, Inc., has borrowed $35,000,000 from two insurance companies and eleven banks, it was announced yesterday. Twenty million dollars of the loan, which bears interest at 3 7/8 per cent and matures in 1974, was obtained from the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States.
The New York, New Haven in Hartford Railroad borrowed $3,345,000 in the public market yesterday to help finance the acquisition of ten passenger train locomotives estimated to cost $4,477,000.
The New York-New Jersey Waterfront Commission will suspend the work permits of about 13,000 part-time longshoremen early next year, it was announced last night.
Temple University proved last night in Madison Square Garden that it isn't absolutely necessary to have towering players to have an effective basketball team.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Manager Casey Stengel of the New York Yankees told the city council today that major league baseball could be brought to Los Angeles only by the enlargement of Wrigley Field and its acquisition as a municipal institution.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 16 -- The Eastern Steamship Lines, Inc., formerly operator of the Old Dominion Line, which was established shortly after the Civil War, will liquidate its final holdings here tomorrow.
MOSCOW, Dec. 16 -- The Soviet Union formally notified France today that if she ratified the Paris agreements their mutual aid treaty of 1944 would be annulled.
Admission of Spain to the United Nations, along with unspecified "other" nations, was urged yestedray by Jose Maria de Areilza, Count of Motrico, the new Spanish Ambassador to the United States.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 16 -- Defense and prosecution attorneys presented their last arguments today in the trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard in the murder of his wife.
Dr. William F. (Billy) Graham will conduct an "extended" evangelistic campaign in New York during 1956 or 1957.

Henry Sears of Greenwich Conn., was elected commodore of the New York Yacht Club at the annual meeting last night in the West Forty-fourth Street clubhouse. He was elevated from vice commodore to succeed John Nicholas Brown, the commodore for three years.

The American Merchant Marine Institute, which represents sixty major steamship companies, urged the State Department and the Senate yesterday to act immediately to defer the establishment of the United Nations Inter-governmental Maritime Consultative Organization.

The election of four new members of the American Academy of Arts and Letters was announced yesterday. They are W. H. Auden, poet; Aaron Copland, composer, and Allan Nevins, historian, all of New York, and Joseph Wood Krutch, author and critic, of Arizona, Election to the academy is an honor designating each nominee as a creative artist whose works are most likely to achieve a permanent place in American culture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 16 -- Borrowers may find loans slightly harder to get and interest rates slightly higher as a result of a recent "shift in policy emphasis" by Federal Reserve System authorities.
CHICAGO, Dec. 16 -- The Atomic Scientists of Chicago replied tonight to a statement issued yesterday in California by Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, about the case of Dr. Edward U. Condon.

HAVANA, Dec. 16 (AP) -- Shelley Mayfield of Chicopee, Mass., and Tommy Bolt of Houston fired 7-under-par 65's today to tie for the lead in the opening round of the $15,000 Havana invitation and pro-amateur golf tournament.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- An automatic camera for use in catching automobile speeders was demonstrated near here today.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 17 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer appealed today to Walter Freitag, head of the West German Trade Union Federation, to end its anti-armament campaign. The Chancellor, also urged Herr Freitag to pledge the cooperation of the trade unions when the time came to create the 500,000-man military establishment under the terms of the Paris agreements.
Cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday unchanged to 6 points higher than on Thursday.

The most recent statements of our representatives in Vietnam are encouraging. There are really three big problems to be solved. The first is to build up a military establishment that can defend the country against a probable Communist assault whenever Western forces are withdrawn.
The heads of all city departments were warned yesterday to limit their 1955-56 budget requests to the amounts needed merely to continue existing programs.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Cornell's basketball team defeated Brown, 52 -- 44, in Barton Hall tonight. It was Cornell's second straight Ivy League victory and Brown's first loss in three games.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The president of the Onondaga Historical Association said today that the state's early records were in "chaotic condition."
Stocks continued their vigorous advance yesterday and established new high marks for the year and for the upward movement.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 17 -- Indian Army troops were called out today to arrest 500 Calcutta policemen hunger-striking for higher pay.
The day is past when the ill humor of nagging wives or surly husbands was nobody's business but their own.
MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- A demand for simplification and standardization of Soviet buildings and for more speed and efficiency in completing them was published here today.

NEWARK, Dec. 17 -- Initiation fees in excess of $100 paid to Charles Martin, longshoreman boss at Port Newark, for membership in Local 1261 of the Clerks and Checkers Union, International Longshoremen's Association, never reached the union office, the Waterfront Commission was told today.
The campus newspaper demanded yesterday in a front-page editorial that intercollegiate football be brought back to New York University because "it deserves another chance."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The National Coal Association today designated a "special committee on competitive fuels" to press for legislation aiding the depressed soft coal industry.
BIRMINGHAM, Ala., Dec. 17 -- A group of North Alabama Conference Methodist Ministers and highly placed laymen today urged a temperate approach to the segregation issue.

PRINCETON, N. J., Dec. 17 -- St. Paul's School of Concord, N. H., participating for the first time in the annual Lawrenceville invitation hockey tournament, registered two fine performances today as play in the seventh schoolboy competition started at the Hobey Baker Rink.
ALBANY, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Safety inspection stickers will be the first general exception to the State Motor Vehicle Commissioner's rule that automobile windshields must be kept clear.
A man who preferred to keep his savings in a cigar box instead of a bank was robbed yesterday of seven $1,000 bills and a diamond ring valued at $2,450.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- Harry Bridges stated today that he was not a member of the Communist party when he became a United States citizen in 1945.

Encore Concerts, in one of the finest evenings it has presented, brought together six musicians for a concert of chamber music last night in Carnegie. Recital Hall. The participants were John Wummer, flutist; Harry Shulman, oboist; David Weber, Clarinetist; Elias Carmen, bassoonist; Fred Klein, French horn player and Leonid Hambro, pianist.
The city's securities are "very good" investments and will continue to be, Dr. Luther H. Gulick, City Administrator, declared yesterday.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China agreed today to receive Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold in Peiping.

SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 17 -- The Easterner planning his first hunting trip to Texas, whether he is after deer, turkeys or javelina, will be surprised to find that the "great open spaces" are not open to public hunting.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Government began splitting up its half-billion-dollar synthetic rubber monopoly and selling it off to private business today. The prices were not immediately disclosed. No sale will be final until Congress has had a sixty-day look at it.

The Brooklyn Museum announced yesterday the appointment of Edgar Graig Schenck as director, effective Aug. 1, 1955. Mr. Schenck, who is descended from early Brooklyn settlers, succeeds Charles Nagel, who resigned the post to become director of the City Art Museum of St. Louis.

The appointment of Dr. John W. Davis to head a new department of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., was announced yesterday by Thurgood Marshall, director of the fund.

JOHANNESBURG, Dec. 17 -- S. G. Menell, chairman of Ango-Transvaal Consolidated Investment Company, one of Johannesburg's seven big mining corporations, urged today that South African gold and uranium stocks be listed on the New York Stock Exchange.

The French -- the arbiters of cooking of the western world -- greet Christmas Day with a reveillon, a gay meal eaten in the early hours of the morning. It usually follows attendance at midnight mass, may be eaten at home or in a restaurant, and, like all French gastronomical celebrations, delights the eye and the palate.
The Cantata Singers, under the direction of Alfred Mann, presented a Christmas program at St. Michael's Protestant Episcopal Church last evening.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- A wide gap between British and Greek interpretations of the General Assembly's resolution on Cyprus was disclosed today.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- More good company profit statements inspired another advance in industrial shares on the Stock Exchange today. A further stimulus was continued reports of heavy Christmas shopping which lifted store shares.
The holidays will cause little if any slowdown in the distribution of new securities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (AP) -- A spokesman for the television-radio industry said tonight the new Congress would be urged to reduce the excise (sales) tax on radio and television receivers to the same rate as that on household appliances.
