UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- The ninth session of the United Nations General Assembly ended today at 5:05 P. M. The session began Sept. 21. The last major controversial item, the payment of $179,420 in indemnity awards to eleven former United States employesof the world body, was approved just before adjournment.
MADRID, Dec. 17 -- Journalistic circles said today a fine of $4,000 a year had been imposed on A. B. C., regarded as the newspaper of the Monarchists.

The Jewish festival of lights, known as Hanukkah, will begin at sunset tomorrow with the kindling of the first candles in menorahs in Jewish homes and temples. Thus will begin the observance of the rededication in 165 B. C. of the temple in Jerusalem.

BRISBANE, Australia, Saturday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Just as Capt. Billy Talbert had predicted, the United States made a clean sweep of Sweden in the Davis Cup interzone final today when Tony Trabert and Hamilton Richardson scored easy victories.

Seven wreaths were placed yesterday at the base of the bronze statue of Simon Bolivar, liberator of Venezuela, at the southern entrance to Central Park and the Avenue, of the Americas. The ceremony marked the anniversary of Bolivar's death in 1830.
The Christmas story will be told in drama and music at churches all next week.
The fifteenth Annual Mayfair Assembly, a subscription dance for debutantes, post-debutantes and their escorts, was held last night in the St. Regis Roof.
The nation's top-ranked collegiate basketball team, La Salle, and its All-America center, Tom Gola, make their first Madison Square Garden appearance of the season tonight.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 -- Approval of secession of the Cleveland Chapter from the National Conference of Christians and Jews is expected Jan. 15.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- A decision generally taken to mean that aggression in Europe would be met by atomic and other new weapons was nade today by the North Atlantic Council.

BERLIN, Dec. 17 -- Two current Broadway shows are playing to sold-out houses in Berlin. They are "The Teahouse of the August Moon" and "The Caine Mutiny Court Martial." In addition to the qualities that made them hits at home they have a special appeal to Berliners.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- The Eisenhower Administration's tax reforms to date are merely a start toward the comprehensive revision that the country needs, J. Cameron Thomson, president of the Northwest Bancorporation, said today.

TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- Former Representative Fred A. Hartley Jr. warned New Jersey Republican leaders today that the extreme right-wing group within the party expected to be a potent force before the 1956 campaign.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 17 (Reuters) -- Effective Australian bowling and brilliant fielding dealt the English cricket team a severe blow as the second test match opened today. The visiting team was all out for only 154 runs in 4 hours 15 minutes.

EDGEWOOD, Md., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Pvt. Bruce A. Wallace was reprimanded by his commanding general today. He had failed to salute the American flag during retreat ceremonies at the Army chemical center here last month.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 17 -- Everyone at the Naval Academy, from Rear Admiral Walter F. Boone, the superintendent, to the lowest-ranking plebe, is enthusiastic about the fact that Navy's football team is going to the Sugar Bowl.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Bill Cleary registered six goals and two assists to pace Harvard's hockey team to a 10-3 victory over Providence College at the Boston Garden tonight.
DETROIT, Dec. 17 -- The auto industry is expecting a Merry Christmas.
PARIS, Saturday, Dec. 18 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France, after suffering a near-defeat, early today asked a vote of confidence on the passage of the budget for the Indochina Associated States.
When Prof. Fritz Jahoda conducts the City College orchestra and chorus in the second act finale from Beethoven's opera "Fidelio" tonight, he will be finishing a job he started sixteen years ago.

Man's vaulting ambition, not content with the conquest of the sonic barrier, now impels him to prepare for the day when he will leap over the last obstacle in the way of escape from the gravitational pull of his planet.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Plans for a new steel mill for New England, a specialty plant far different from the $250,000,000 enterprise proposed in 1950, were announced today by a new company, the Northeastern Steel Corporation. The mill will be at Bridgeport, Conn.
CANTON, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- St. Lawrence University's second hockey line, all sophomores and Canadians, accounted for seven goals tonight as the Larries defeated Dartmouth, 12 -- 1, in Appleton Arena.
More than half the points and exactly half the field goals were made by Chet Forte in Columbia's 77-70 victory over Navy in the University Hall gymnasium last night.

Events today: Little Orchestra Society, young people's concert, Hunter College, 11 A. M.; Manon," Metropolitan Opera, 2 P. M.; Philharmonic-Symphony, young people's concert, Town Hall, 3; Trapp Family Singers, Town Hall, 5:30; "The Messiah," Oratorio Society of New York Carnegie Hall, 8.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- Next year will be the "hinge year" for the North Atlantic alliance, in the view of its military experts, de-cause they will swing into plans for defense of the West with nuclear weapons.
An "elder statesman" of religion was honored last night on the completion of fifty years in the ministry.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Following are the texts of cablegrams exchanged today between Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China and Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations:

Lumber production in the week ended Dec. 11 was 9.4 per cent above that in the like week of last year according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 9.9 per cent and orders 4.7 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A House committee deplored today the reappearance of what it called "subversion from the extreme right."
The following is a round-up of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Seton Hall's undefeated quintet bettered its scoring record for one game when it downed William and Mary, 109 -- 89, tonight.

Prices closed higher yesterday on the New York commodity exchanges in generally dull trading. But the domestic sugar contract, which has been inactive for some time, registered the most sales since Sept. 9. Sugar, coffee, cocoa, hides, wool, cottonseed oil, soybean oil and copper ended firmer; rubber and potatoes were mixed, and zinc closed lower.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- "This bright Christmas must not be followed -- ever -- by a Christmas of universal tragedy," President Eisenhower declared tonight.
The stream of gold that has spouted from fire hydrants for thirty years for politically favored "hydrant inspectors" will be clamped off New Year's Eve.

PARIS, Dec. 17 -- "Les Sorcieres de Salem," a translation of Arthur Miller's "The Crucible," was well received by the Paris press today. Adapted to the French stage by Marcel Ayme the play opened here last night at the Sarah Bernhardt Theatre.
Two jumpy bandits held up a savings and loan office in Queens yesterday -- and their nerves are probably even more frazzled now.
Sadao Iguchi, Japanese Ambassador to the United States, said last night the most effective deterrent to Communist penetration in Asia was the existence of healthy economic condtions there.
The National Association of American Composers and Conductors presented a program in Town Hall yesterday afternoon that had as a highlight the fine singing of the baritone Floyd Worthington.

Your able correspondent M. S. Handler has written an interesting story on the revival of Simplicissimus, for many decades an internationally famous German satirical magazine. His dispatch of Dec. 5 does not tell the whole story, however.

Full proceeds from the gala premiere of Twentieth Century- Fox' "There's No Business Like Show Business," which was held at the Roxy Theatre Thursday night, will go to the Actors Fund of America and six allied theatrical groups, Walter Vincent, president of the Actors Fund, said yesterday.
The Coast Guard abandoned hope yesterday for the twenty-four-man crew of the freighter Southern Districts, which was last heard from two weeks ago.

In your editorial of Dec. 6 on "controlled" democracy you imply that the trouble comes from a lack of understanding. If this is really a genuine case of misunderstanding, it seems likely that the basic cause of it all lies in the magic to be found in the word "democracy."
ALBANY, Dec. 17 -- The American Labor party lost its name as well as its place on the ballot in last month's election.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- Following is a summary of the major decisions taken at the ninth session of the United Nations General Assembly, which adjourned today:
The United Nations Children's Fund (UNICEF), celebrating its eighth birthday, recently released some current figures to the public:
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 17 -- Nashville civic leaders today stepped up their campaign to block merging of the Nashville, Chattanooga and St. Louis Railway with the Louisville and Nashville Railroad.

Cardinal Spellman left New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, yesterday morning on the first leg of his fourth annual Christmas visit to members of the armed services in Alaska and the Far East.

CHICAGO, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Hogs rebounded front their two-year low today, both butchers and sows selling steady to 25 cents higher in active dealings. Department of Agriculture reports on liverstock trading here today:

HAVANA, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Al Besselink of Grossinger, N. Y., displaying his best golf since he injured his right hand a year ago, shot a 67 today for a 134 total and a stroke lead in the second round of the $15,000 Havana invitation and pro-amateur tournament.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Frederick C. Miller, prominent brewer and sports figure, died tonight after a plane crash.

After an interval of seven days, presumably devoted to consultations with Moscow, Premier Chou En-lai has at last acknowledged Secretary General Hammarskjold's offer to go to Peiping. Mr. Hammarskjold is told that he is welcome to "visit China" to discuss "pertinent questions" dealing with "peace and relaxation of international tension."
NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 17 -- Fairfield County's Civil Defense test had to compete with the Christmas shopping rush tonight, but even so it came off satisfactorily.

Dr. Alvin Johnson, who will be 80 years old today, has pioneered in the field of adult education and has helped to extend educational opportunities for all, regardless of race, creed or color. At his fourscore milestone he is still a driving force in American education.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 17 -- William Goetz Productions plans to start filming next spring on "The Babylonians," an adaptation of the novel by Nathaniel Norsen Weinreb.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- Herbert Morrison, 66-year-old deputy leader of the Labor party, and Miss Edith Meadowcroft of Rochdale, Lancashire, are to be married Jan. 6.
Eight Chinese students volunteered yesterday to be exchanged for the eleven United States airmen imprisoned as spies in Communist China, The United Press said.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today upheld the validity of "hot cargo" clauses in labor contracts.
HENDERSONVILLE, N. C., Dec. 17 -- The General Electric Company announced today that it would establish a multi-million-dollar factory in this western North Carolina mountain community.
Jacob K. Javits urged Republicans yesterday to seek "feasible alternatives" when major clashes occur between the Republican Legislature and the Democratic Administration of Averell Harriman.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The National Labor Relations Board today ordered an election test as soon as possible between the rival West Coast seamen's unions headed by Harry Lundeberg and Harry Bridges.

HANOVER, N. H., Dec. 17 (AP) -- Ron Judson connected with a jump shot and a free throw to break an 18-18 tie after 12 minutes of play and unbeaten Dartmouth went on to trounce Harvard, 74 -- 57, tonight in an Ivy League basketball game.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 17 -- Equipping of the United States overseas information program with further "manpower, mind-power and money" was the subject of a conference here today.

MONTREAL, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Application by the United States Department of Justice to extradite to Michigan two Montreal stock salesmen was rejected today, but the two were immediately arrested on charges brought by the Quebec Attorney General.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Communist China's invitation to Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations, for talks in Peiping was met with mingled hope and skepticism here today.

In keeping with his announced policy of hiring talent from the literary field for the development of stage products, Richard Charlton, head of American Productions, has signed a playwright's contract with Evan Hunter.

ROME, Dec. 17 -- After the exertion of yesterday's X-ray examination the Pope was somewhat worse today. His doctors attributed his state chiefly to an "indigestion" brought about by the barium meal he was obliged to take yesterday.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 17 -- A goal of about $300,000,000 is authoritatively reported to have been worked out here for United States aid to South Vietnam in 1955.
Major league baseball players are about to have their inning again.

The letter of Kenneth Munzert published Dec. 10 gives further circulation to a myth which for some reason has been accepted by many sincere persons -- namely, that pressure groups special interests and economic bloc appeared for the first time in the day of the New Deal.
CARLE PLACE, L. I., Dec. 17 -- In the kitchen of a modest home next door to a toy factory here, a little schoolboy with a big heart is looking forward to Christmas morning.
BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- J. Spencer Love was elected chairman of the board and J. Neal Dow president of Pacific Mills, it was announced today at the annual stockholders' meeting.
PARIS, Dec. 17 -- United States officials are trying to undo the tangle into which the armistice in Indochina threw French-American financial relations.

" Daughter of the Khans," an autobiography by Liang Yen, will be issued Jan. 3 by Norton. It is an account of how the author broke away from the conservatism of her wealthy Mongol family in Peiping and of her successful efforts to make a life of her own.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Jay Lovestone said today he would welcome a chance to deny any allegation that he was the "kingpin" of a world-wide Red network.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) -- Senator William E. Jenner said today college students should debate the question of United States recognition of Communist China.

We suppose it is necessary to be of a certain age, when birthdays are happiest forgotten, to be sentimental about the closing of an old place of business like the John Wanamaker store on lower Broadway. But to some of us at least it seemed more than a store. It had an air of sober respectability, of gentility, of courtesy, of the leisure of time passed, of spaciousness appropriate to the carriage trade.
Columbus, Ohio, announced yesterday that it would offer for sale on Jan. 11 an issue of $4,000,000 of city school district building bonds.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 17 -- The Labor Board's order paves the way for a "lead pipe cinch" victory of the A. F. L. among unlicensed personnel on West Coast ships, Mr. Lundeberg said here.

ONCE upon a time the American mountain men and the traders at Bent's Fort on the Arkansas ruled a wild empire that ran from southern Wyoming to the challenged lands of Texas and from the middle of Kansas to the peaks of the Rockies.

Several Christmas shoppers sent contributions to the Neediest yesterday in lieu of gifts to persons on their Yule lists. The total contributions to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund rose to $190,374.73, from 4,967 donors.
WIESBADEN, Germany, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Hesse State Parliament re-elected Socialist Georg August Zinn as Minister-President today. Herr Zinn said he would announce his Cabinet next month.

ESSEN, Germany, Dec. 17 -- The new look of the next German army is strictly non-Prussian. It is to be middle class, minus Junkers, minus martinets, and minus heel-clicking disciplinarians. Its front man will almost certainly be Ludwig Cruewell, who resembles a successful Ruhr business man -- which he is. Its ambassador will be Hans Speidel, who resembles a professor of philosophy -- which he is.
A sewer explosion sent fifty 190-pound manhole covers flying like saucers over a thirty-block area of the West Bronx shortly after noon yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The New York Central Railroad asked the Interstate Commerce Commission today for authority to acquire direct control of the Boston and Albany Railroad and two smaller carriers in Massachusetts.

Children must play an active and willing role as members of a family, whether helping with routine household chores or sharing in the more important family matters. This was the consensus six junior high school pupils who took part yesterday in the New York Times Youth Forum.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Cabinet took no action today on permitting Russia to buy surplus butter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Under the new National Reserve Plan proposed by the Defense Department today the youth at 17 would have these alternatives:
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 17 -- Semi - autonomous administrations in four provinces, ten princely states and a tribal belt along the northwestern border of West Pakistan were wiped out today.
RUTHERFORD, N. J. Dec. 17 -- American University gained its first basketball victory in ten games tonight by defeating Fairleigh Dickinson, 67 to 63.

BRAMPTON, Ont., Saturday, Dec. 18 (AP) -- A Trans - Canada Super-Constellation airliner bound from Tampa, Fla., to Toronto crashed and burned on a farmer's field near here last night. At least twenty-seven persons were injured, apparently none seriously.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Lucian C. Warren, Washington correspondent of The Buffalo Courier - Express, was elected president of the National Press Club today.
A Christmas tree that was air-expressed to Havana yesterday may be the forerunner of a revolution in future shipments of such trees to tropical climates, according to National Airlines.

A witness who created an uproar in a Queens murder trial last Monday was committed yesterday to Kings County Hospital for mental examination. A few hours earlier the defendant in that trial was acquitted of the charge that he killed his fiancee.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 17 -- The murder case against Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard went to the jury today.
WASHINGTON,. Dec. 17 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 109.4 per cent of the 1947-49 level over the week ended on Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
AUSTIN, Tex., Dec. 17 (AP) -- The State Railroad Commission today increased Texas' January crude oil allowable production 257,307 barrels a day.

The regional Red Cross blood program will send bloodmobiles or blood collection units today to Manhattan City Prison, 125 White Street, and Brooklyn City Prison, 149 Ashland Place. On Monday, a bloodmobile will visit Vasa Temple, 120 East 149th Street, the Bronx, where Knights of Pythias will give blood.

The five-story business building at the southeast corner of Delancey and Ludlow Streets has been sold by the Sarnoff Irving interests to Samuel Edelman, real estate investor. Leon, Weill Mahony were attorneys for the seller and J. George Langfelder acted for the buyer.

The wonderful spirit that is Christmas too often recedes in direct proportion to the number of days away from that great holiday. In the anticlimactic days of the post-Yule season high spirits will dissipate rapidly; the world will look a little grayer; viewpoints will narrow; purse strings, and the hands that hold them, will be drawn tighter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today cotton consumption for the period of Oct. 31 to Nov. 27 averaged 36,087 bales for each working day. This compared with an average of 35,127 bales for the corresponding period a year ago, and with 35,777 for the October period this year.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 17 -- On its sixtieth anniversary, the James K. Hand Walking Association is at the end of its trail.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (UP) The National Labor Relations Board upheld today the dismissal of six Hickory, N. C., strikers on the ground that they had cursed in concert at nonstrikers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture, in its final report of 1954, said crop production this year was the fifth largest on record.

International Air Transport Association, floor in 500 5th Ave; Raymond-Whitcomb Inc, travel agents, in 600 5th Ave through Leonard J. Beck Inc; S. Peter Shumavon, engineer, in 67 W 44th St; Allied Travel Inc, in 103 Park Ave -- Richard T. Tindale, broken.
Bob Baker, the big boy from Pittsburgh, walloped his way to an easy decision over Coley Wallace, the big boy from Harlem, in the main bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden last night.

The transfer of American-flag Liberty ships to foreign flags was summarily cut off yesterday by Maritime Administrator Louis S. Rothschild. The policy of permitting the Liberty transfers had been put into effect only four months ago to aid owners.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- A new role for aviation in the "cold war" was outlined here tonight.

RANGING over a wide field of techniques, styles and subject-matter, the exhibition of "Sculpture, 1954" at the Sculpture Center, 167 East Sixty-ninth Street, includes work by no less than fifty-eight artists. Abstractists jostle romantics; marble and bronze sidle up to plastics and welded metal.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. opened yesterday a "get tough" war on negligent tenement landlords.
Your excellent editorial of Dec. 15 on "A Visit From the Shah" rightly calls attention to the significant role the United States is playing in the development of Iran.
Early Christmas travelers bent upon beating the holiday rush accounted for thirty-four extra trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad yesterday.
DETROIT, Dec. 17 -- The city of Detroit found itself in the oil business today.

The Wagner administration is making good on its promise to strengthen the police force. The Board of Estimate has increased the authorized strength from 20,878 to 21,628. Authorized strength is, in effect, the official view of the minimum manpower necessary to police the city adequately, or the maximum that can be supported financially.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, formally proposed today a new National Military Reserve plan. The plan would train all fit young men for the armed services and provide a Reserve of 5,000,000 trained men by 1959.
The International Longshoremen's Association has summoned the leaders of its outport locals to a session here Monday to discuss their actions in case of a strike in the Port of New York.
Aviation pioneers enlisted a helicopter yesterday for the unveiling of a monument to historic early flights to and from Governors Island.

The International Scholarship Fund of the American Friends of Spain Foundation, Inc., was the beneficiary of a dinner dance called An Evening in Spain, which was held last night in the Serf Room of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Leo Durocher, who finished a brilliant masterminding year by leading the New York Giants to a four-game sweep over the Cleveland Indians in the world series, yesterday was named manager of the year by a landslide vote.

Willie Mays of the New York Giants and Yogi Berra of the New York Yankees, the most valuable players of their respective leagues, head the 1954 Associated Press' major league all-star team, which was released yesterday.

LIMA, Peru, Dec. 17 -- Measures designed to protect women workers in Latin America, improve their working conditions and better utilize their services were approved today in the final session of the International Labor Organization's Technical Reunion.

The four-story building at 280 East Ninety - first Street in Brooklyn, containing a store and thirty-two apartments, has been sold by Abraham Feinerman to Abe Schneiderman. Azer, Shapiro Zolondick were the brokers and title was insured by the Lawyers Mortgage and Title Company.
CHICAGO, Dec. 17 -- Wheat developed considerable strength late today, corn and oats rose and rye had a good rally from its sharp decline.

MOSCOW, Dec. 17 -- Soviet notes tonight upbraided seven or more governments that turned down invitations to the recent Moscow conference on European security. The Moscow Government accused them of supporting the "dangerous remilitarization of Germany."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- President Eisenhower made it easier today for foreign suppliers to compete for Government business.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) A young Silver Spring, Md., housewife can thank the new technique of "ice cube surgery" for saving her life.

Harry Some has purchased the thirty-one-family apartment house at 2554 Hudson Boulevard in Jersey City, N. J., from the 2554 Holding Corporation in a transaction negotiated by J. I. Kislak, Inc., as broker. Max Druz was attorney for the seller and Jacob Stern acted for the buyer.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Chairman of the Atomic Energy Commission said today that he had only one regret about the Dixon-Yates power contract.
A Long Island State Park patrolman whose resignation had been rejected was dismissed yesterday. He had been involved in the traffic ticket courtesy card investigation.

Your lead editorial on "Colonies at the U. N." in the Dec. 14 issue raised anew the controversial nature of "domestic jurisdiction" as contained the U. N. Charter. This provision specifies that the organization cannot interfere in the internal affairs of a state.

BOSTON, Dec. 17 -- Dr. Wendell H. Furry, associate professor of physics at Harvard University, and Leon J. Kamin, a former research assistant there, were indicted today on charges of contempt of the United States Senate.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Gurdon Saltonstall Worcester of Boston, a consulting psychologist, received this week a patent for a vest that enables men to wear varied and gaudy plumage.

Second degree murder indictments were dismissed yesterday in General Sessions against a man and a woman after the District Attorney's office said that neither knew the nature of their acts when they committed the crimes.
This is an answer to Irving Sweet's letter in which he expresses some anxiety about dual jobs.
LONDON, Dec. 17 -- The Conservative party put its "remarkable record of achievement" before the British electorate today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- The Public Health Service today disclosed that during the past year some 300 Alaskan Indians with tuberculosis were flown to hospitals in the state of Washington for treatment.
J. P. Stevens Co., Inc., experienced a sharp drop in earnings in the fiscal year ended Oct. 31 from those of the preceding year.

The difficulties and dangers faced by American investors abroad have attracted more attention than the opportunities which promise both profit to us and to other countries as well. This creates special public interest for the National Planning Association's report of the highly successful operations of W. R. Grace Co. in Peru.
Faculty members' salaries and students' tuition will soon be increased in many colleges and universities, according to Dr. Henry T. Heald, chancellor of New York University.

TRENTON, Dec. 17 -- In what might be held an example of desegregation in reverse, the state today ordered the closing next June of the all-Negro State Manual Training and Industrial School for Youths at Bordentown.
OTTAWA, Dec. 17 -- An officer of the Royal Canadian Air Force said today he believed he had bought freedom by signing a false confession while a prisoner of Communist China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 (AP) -- Alva C. Carpenter, chief counsel, said today that the Senate Interal Security subcommittee, in listing fromer Korean prisoners of war who reportedly made broadcasts for the Communists, was not in any way passing on their loyalty.

LONDON, Dec. 17 -- British European Airways dismissed today nearly a quarter of the engineering staff at its base at London Airport for "flagrant defiance" of a managerial ruling. The action was taken to enforce labor discipline in the knowledge that a sympathetic walkout by the rest of the airport staff could ground the line.
An art collection owned by Nelson A. Rockefeller, reflecting achievements of early civilizations, will form the nucleus of a new museum.

Rudolf G. Sonneborn, outgoing general chairman of the United Israel Appeal, reported yesterday that the appeal's agencies had provided $254,563,000 in the last four years to carry out relief, rehabilitation and resettlement in Israel.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 14 -- With the outbreak of terrorist agitation on Nov. 1, Algerian nationalism pushed into a conspicuous place among the revolutionary movements of Africa and Asia.

EVERY night at 9 o'clock, except on Sundays and three Mondays out of four, Patrolman James Raymond Fitzgerald unlocks a steel box on the hat shelf in the bedroom closet of his third-floor walk-up Brooklyn apartment and takes out a small .38 caliber police pistol.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 -- Approximately $136,000,000 was distributed this month to members of Christmas Clubs of Pennsylvania banks. A survey by the Pennsylvania Bankers Association shows that more than 1,381,000 residents of the state participated in the weekly savings plan this year.

The appointment of Simon H. Fabian, head of Cinerama, Stanley Warner and Fabian Theatres, as chairman of the annual dinner-concert of the American Fund for Israel Institutions was announced last night.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 18 -- Dag Hammarskjold, on his arrival here today, parried questions on his mission to Communist China.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 15 (AP) -- India is considering whether or not to enforce a seventy-six-year-old British law barring foreign vessels carrying arms in transit from stopping at Indian ports.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 18--Still unable to reach a verdict after eighteen hours of deliberation, the jury in the murder trial of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard recessed at 10:04 o'clock tonight.
PARIS, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The French Government and the Compagnie Generale Transatlantique (French Line) consider they have no responsibility in the explosion of the Grandcamp.

TWO sharply contrasting extremes of experience in the life of young Martin Reitsma provide the drama of "Gala Day," underlying all of the novel's turns and overtones. One experience stems from Martin's background, an insulated, rigidly Calvinist Dutch-American community, a pocket of the Old World transplanted and sustaining itself in Wisconsin.

THE chain of islands called Keys that stretch from the Florida mainland more than a hundred miles down to Key West once teemed with wildlife. They are still a sportsman's paradise, but, with the building of the highway linking the islands, game is no longer so plentiful.

All that remains of a once large and active fleet of water boats, workhorses of a marine activity that has been intimately associated with the Port of New York since its infancy, is the venerable Commodore.
Six of the passengers killed in the Italian Airlines plane crash were identified last night in the Queens County Morgue, where the bodies of five female and three male victims had been removed.

LONDON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Chelsea moved into a challenging position in the English Soccer League standings today as the three top teams -- Wolverhampton, Sunderland and Manchester United -- all were tied.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 -- Planned expenditures for industrial facilities in the Chicago area announced during November totaled $13,651,000 compared with $10,185,000 in the same month last year, the Chicago Association of Commerce and Industry reported. So far this year each month has registered a total in excess of the same month in 1953.
The United Nations, whose principal concern is the security of nations, is securing the welfare of its staff with investments in United States securities.

IN reading history, one is often moved to shout advice back down the vistas of time. A man feels, for example, that if he had been living during the witchcraft persecutions he would have spoken sense and that that particular installment in the serial calamity of humanity would never have been.

The Wagner College basketball team scored its third victory of the season by defeating City College, 67 -- 59, at Grymes Hill, Staten Island, last night. City's record is now one victory and three setbacks.

Britain's first atomic-powered electricity generating station will be in full production by 1960 and may begin operation earlier. For security reasons officials will not say when the plant will be in operation or what the output of electricity will be. British newsmen believe that 1956 is a likely date.

ON Dec. 27 "The Boy Who Wouldn't Grow Up" will be celebrating his fiftieth birthday. Should he drop in from the Never Never Land to see how well he is remembered, it will be to find a new and lavish production in London of the original play, and a magnificent musical version playing to packed houses on Broadway.

IT was the first day of rehearsal for "What Every Woman Knows," which, as each one of them does know, will open the City Center's winter season on Wednesday. It was the first day, and, going through the part of Maggie Wylie, Helen Hayes was rehearsing with a fierce and fixed purpose.

As one who has been engaged for fifteen years in writing the life of one of our early Presidents, I cannot too heartily endorse the general tenor of former President Truman's published comments on preservation of the papers of our Chief Executives.

WHEN a writer dies, it is much better that he should be rhapsodized over in the tradition of the wake than damned with faint praise in the tradition of the smart obituary. Since, however, the near-apotheosis of Dylan Thomas (1914-53) has already provoked certain spiteful reactions in England, it is time we got certain things straight.
SAN SALVADOR, El Salvador, Dec. 17 -- This country, coming into a big dollar-earning coffee crop, gives an appearance of being the only Central American republic without immediate problems.

Although Hanson W. Baldwin's article in the Dec. 5 issue was entitled "The Problem of Army Morale," it seems clear from the article's content that it was intended to apply equally to the other branches of the armed forces.

WHEN Johann Gutenberg invented movable type, his thoughts were on the Bible and not a fourth grade reader. And when the creators of the cathode ray produced television, they undoubtedly considered it a source of entertainment, not a classroom in the parlor.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Amherst's unbeaten basketball team made it five straight today by defeating Army, 68 to 50, at the Field House.

HONG KONG, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- Communist China today called for another conference of all countries concerned to settle the problem of divided Korea. A statement by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, broadcast over the Peiping radio, said the Korean question could not remain unsettled.

NEW ZEALAND'S recent export of its national emblem -- a live kiwi -- to the San Diego zoo will be no boon to daytime visitors who want to see this rare and unbeautiful bird at its best. The kiwi, or wingless bird, is nocturnal, preferring to sniff out worms after dark with its long, slender, slightly curved beak and to remain concealed in holes during the day.
The North Atlantic Treaty Organization Council took up in Paris last week the vexing question of when a war becomes an atomic war.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- A conscious, calculated effort by a White House staff member to stimulate a draft movement for a second term for President Eisenhower served notice on members of the Republican "Old Guard" this week that the Eisenhower forces will fight them to the finish for control of the party now, in 1956, and thereafter.

In the spring of 1944, the State Department was working on plans for the Dumbarton Oaks conference, which would lay the groundwork for an international security organization. The two political parties were preparing for a wartime election. At this time Secretary of State Cordell Hull began meeting with Congressional leaders in both parties.

Two American medical students at the Italian University of Padua, returning home for the Christmas holidays, were among the six survivors of yesterday's airliner crash at New York International Airport,

"IF the director hasn't loused it up, it should be a hell of a good picture." Thus Stanley Kramer, the producer of "Not As a Stranger," summed up his estimation of the film version of the Morton Thompson novel as directed by Stanley Kramer.

EDWARD R. MURROW and Fred W. Friendly, co-editors of "See It Now," are presenting a two-part documentary on the Union of South Africa, the scene for so many years of acute racial hatred, and its new extremist Prime Minister, Johannes Gerhardus Strijdom.
Highway safety specialists representing eleven Northeastern states have urged that legislatures in the area enact laws requiring periodic examinations for automobile drivers.

THE islands of the Netherlands West Indies which have been without scheduled ship connections for several years have been since last month linked up on a twice-monthly ship service. The 500-ton Antilia now leaves Curacao the first of each month making stops at Aruba, Bonaire, St. Maarten, Saba, St. Eustatius and St. Kitts, the last belonging to the British-Leeward group.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Iona's Gaels won their fifth basketball game in six starts by overwhelming Lafayette College, 101 -- 68, at the Westchester County Center tonight. The Gaels sank thirty-five field goals in seventy-three attempts. Dick Barry and Wally McCarvill paced Iona with 20 points each, Barry scoring 14 in the second half.

PARALLELING the present popularity of contemporary Italian furniture design is the revival of interest in Italian furniture of an earlier time. "Italian Directoire" is the label currently being applied by both decorators and merchants to this style.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Syracuse University's basketball team outplayed Brown decisively tonight, whipping the New Englanders, 74 -- 60.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The 10,000-ton steamship Gulfwater has been seized by the United States Government.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The New York Knickerbockers defeated Milwaukee, 91 -- 85, today before a crowd of 3,226 and a national television audience to notch their third National Basketball Association triumph over the Hawks this season.

THE news has flashed around the civilized world that Simone de Beauvoir has just taken France's biggest literary prize, the Goncourt. She did it with a novel called "The Mandarins." It is entirely possible that when Mlle. de Beauvoir wrote "The Second Sex," she put men everywhere on the defensive.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Bob Burrow, a 6-foot 7-inch center, scored 27 points tonight to lead Kentucky to a 79-61 basketball victory over Temple.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 18 -- Sales of new automobiles declined to 1,320 from last week's four-month peak of 1,472 units, but for the third consecutive, week they exceeded the corresponding periods a year ago. New-car sales outnumbered used-car transactions for the second straight week as dealers continued to push sales of 1955 models.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- President Eisenhower today ordered into effect a program to aid farmers hurt by floods, drought or soil erosion.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18--The United States Chamber of Commerce today predicted better business for next year.

GIAN-CARLO MENOTTI'S first opera, Amelia al ballo (Amelia Goes to the Ball) is now available on an Angel disk, as recorded by the cast that gave the work its first La Scala performance in March of this year.

CAPE MAY, N. J., Dec. 18 -- An oil tanker and a cargo vessel collided in the Delaware Bay about twenty-two miles northwest of here today in driving rain and heavy fog. The collision occurred at 8:20 A. M., when visibility was reported at less than a mile.
BOSTON, Dec. 18 -- Wing Dick Heerter's goal with thirteen seconds left gave Northeastern a 3-2 victory over Princeton's hockey team at the Boston Garden today.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 18 -- French military, authorities have complained to the International Armistice Commission that "important quantities" of materiel have been imported by Vietminh forces from China.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Mr. Ladejinsky had a key role in formulating the occupation program for Japan of breaking up the estates and political power of a relatively small group of landowners. He helped draft a law limiting the amount of land one family could own and permitting tenant farmers to buy the land they worked.

Newspaper and magazine writers who have written medical or health articles during 1954 are eligible for the sixth annual Albert Lasker Medical Journalism Awards competition, the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation has announced.
THOUGH the week before Christmas is notoriously a slack one in the theatre, the schedule of dance events is not nearly so slack this year as it sometimes is.

CENTRAL VALLEY, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Governor-elect Averell Harriman today promised exposures of what he charged were failures hidden by Governor Dewey's Administration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Eisenhower today sent Christmas and New Year greetings to members of the armed forces.
The Moore-McCormack liner Brazil sailed to sunny southern regions yesterday, although for a while port watchers could not make out whether she was coming or going.
AS Christmas draws near and the city glows with the Yuletide light, our thoughts turn to friends and neighbors and the joy we shall share with them -- and the goodwill.

MOSCOW, Dec. 18 -- The first Yugoslav Government delegation to come to this country since 1948 arrived in Moscow today. The delegation will negotiate on the terms and conditions for regular trade between Yugoslavia and the Soviet Union.

The silence of winter begins to take over the house, in the evening, after the light goes out in the kitchen and one by one the family's members go upstairs to bed -- bringing up the rear being the lady of the house, gathering carelessly discarded sweaters and woolen gloves as she goes.

Better recreational boats and thousands more of them are going to be made if the American Boat and Yacht Council has its way. This high-minded new body, which was organized a year ago, will have its first four-day annual meeting Jan. 17 through 20 at the Kingsbridge Armory in the Bronx, during the National Motor Boat Show.

This is the in-between season for garment manufacturers. Retailers are concentrating on selling holiday merchandise and their only interest in the wholesale market is to get fill-in goods, according to resident buying offices.

PURCHASE, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- A pilot and co-pilot were crushed to death and a girl passenger escaped with apparently minor injuries this afternoon in the crash of a corporation executive's twin-engined plane. The plane plowed into a hillside one and a half miles northwest of Westchester County Airport.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Dec. 17 -- Labor stoppages at the Joppa project of the Atomic Energy Commission appear to have ended.

The demand for cultured pearls is improving and retail volume this year will top the record level of 1953, importers predict. Promotional efforts by major concerns to increase fashion acceptance of the gem have made pearls more popular than ever.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The United States will begin soon to tell its Allies in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization what it knows about the use and effect of atomic weapons.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 18--British troops resorted to firing at demonstrators today as protest strikes and student rioting over the Cyprus issue spread. Tear gas was employed. The firing was against rioters at the town of Limassol.

HARTFORD, Dec. 18 -- The judges of the state's Common Pleas Court are acting to end a log-jam of cases that has existed for many years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- As far back as 1938, Sumner Welles, then Under Secretary of State, declared that Chinese Communists were aiming to Sovietize China, hitherto secret documents showed today.

This may be a long haul. At his press conference last Wednesday the President spoke of a defense establishment that might have to be "carried for fifty years."

A FEW years back Margaret Widdemer wrote "Lady of the Mohawks," a historical novel based on the love story of Sir William Johnson, a British key figure in the French and Indian wars, and his Indian bride, Molly. Sir William's 16-year-old daughter, Mary, is the heroine of "The Golden Wildcat."
The Congress of Industrial Organizations unveiled yesterday the ammunition it will use in a drive to nullify state "right to work" laws next year.

HAVANA, Dec. 18 -- Al Besselink of Grossinger, N. Y., overcoming a hand injury which has plagued him all year, today fired a 68 for a 54-hole total of 202 and a three-stroke lead in the $15,000 Havana invitation and pro-amateur golf tournament.

SOME five miles east of La Junta, Colo., north of Highway 50 and the shallow Arkansas River, a simple marker indicates the site of Bent's Fort, once the largest and most pretentious structure between the Missouri frontier and the Pacific.

Sermons in anticipation of the traditional celebration by Jews of Hanukkah, their ancient Feast of Lights, were preached by many rabbis here yesterday. The celebration begins at sundown today and lasts for eight days.

SCARBOROUGH, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- In a holiday setting of silver and blue foliage, the Sleepy Hollow Assembly was held here tonight at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club. Mrs. William O. Rockwood headed the committee for the fete. Mrs. Kenneth C. Crouse, honorary chairman, introduced the debutantes.

Officials of the Civil Aeronautics Authority at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, said last night that the Italian Airlines pilot had made four instrument approaches to the field and had been warned three times that he was below the normal glide path.

OUR neighbors south of the border have, it seems to me, a most poetic and descriptive name for the flaming flower of the year-end holidays. They call it flor de pascuas, flower of Christmas, while we matter-of-fact Americans have given it the more prosaic name, poinsettia.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Colonialism is an issue that has bulked large in United Nation debates ever since the world organization was founded. It is an issue seldom discussed here on the merits of the specific case before the General Assembly.

DETROIT, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Detroit Red Wings scored twice in each of the first two periods tonight to defeat the Boston Bruins, 4 -- 1, and extend their unbeaten string to seven straight games.

PRODUCER of the Johns Hopkins TV Science Review, Lynn Poole has used a series of case histories and briefly sketched in accounts of crimes -- real or fictional -- to discuss the latest methods and devices used in detecting criminals.

COMMEMORATING the termination of Catholicism's Marian Year, Vatican City has issued multicolor 20-lire, 35L and 60L stamps in a design based on a religious painting which has disappeared from its resting place in Vilna, Poland, because Communist authorities objected to public worship of its subject, a Madonna, by Polish anti-Communists.

The New York Public Library's Fifth Avenue building will be open as usual on Christmas Day. The Main Reading Room and Information Desk will be available from 1 to 10 P. M. All other divisions and branch libraries will be closed.

LONDON, Dec. 18 -- A parliamentary organ of the Polish Government-in-exile was formally inaugurated here tonight. In the presence of the emigre Polish President, August Zaleski, fifty-four representatives were installed, as the Fifth Council of the Polish Republic.

During the sharp advance in stock prices since Election Day, most hesitations in the market have been short-lived. This was again the situation last week. After three days of moderate profit-taking, the list resumed on Thursday the powerful upward push that Wall Streeters have been so familiar with for more than fifteen months.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 18 -- A surge in holiday buying highlighted business activity in the Kansas City area last week, and retail sales were nearly 10 per cent above a year ago and a week ago. Merchants said that emphasis was on quality goods and the big ticket items moved well.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- The key to the size and shape of future economic aid to the underdeveloped countries of Asia has been handed to Joseph M. Dodge, a hard man with a dollar.

The Christmas program of the Trapp Family Singers has become a regular feature of the New York musical scene, and late yesterday afternoon the group brought it to town again. The members performed it at Town Hall, where they will give it again this afternoon.

JEBRAIL, Lebanon, Dec. 8 -- How to keep 'em down on the farm might be the motto of the Jebrail Fundamental Education Center here. The center's aim is to give teenagers the kind of education they need to make life in the rich farmland around Jebrail more satisfying.

Agencies, both public and private, that deal with the comfort and welfare of the trans-Atlantic passenger as he comes ashore in the nation's greatest port are making laudable efforts to improve the systems of examination to which the traveler must submit when he gets here.
There probably will be fewer toys and other presents and less food for needy families this year in the Christmas parties to be held in some of the city's police stations.

Colgate University has closed its fiscal year with its operations in the black by a narrow margin. This balancing of the budget was made possible through gifts totaling $363,957 from alumni and friends. The largest item of expense during the year was for academic salaries and wages.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Democrats served notice today that they would fight Senate confirmation of Joseph Campbell as Controller General.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 18 -- A motion jointly sponsored by all the Opposition groups in the Lok Sabha, or lower house of parliament, expressing no confidence in the impartiality of the Speaker, G. V. Mavalankar, was defeated today.

RICHMOND, Dec. 18 -- Cumulative sales in Fifth District department stores are even with the 1953 figure to date and it is expected that 1954 will be a banner retail year. The gain for the first half of December was registered in spite of unfavorable shopping weather.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The Los Angeles Daily News, morning newspaper, published its last edition and was sold today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 18 -- Department scores in the Twelfth District showed a gain of 2 per cent in the week ending Dec. 11. Tacoma stores, with a gain of 11 per cent, led all reporting areas, followed by Los Angeles and Seattle. San Francisco and Oakland stores were down 3 per cent.

ONE Saturday afternoon in February, 1915, a lady took her two young sons up to the first balcony of a Broadway theatre to see the first matinee of a play by Anatole France called "The Man Who Married a Dumb Wife."

Children's attitudes toward people outside their families are determined, in large measure, by their school experience, according to a study on "Children's Social Attitudes," just published by Teachers College, Columbia University. It is a report of a two-year research project conducted by seventy staff members of the Springfield, Mo., public schools and three consultants from the Horace Mann-Lincoln Institute of School Experimentation.
Gray Ladies from the Brooklyn chapter of the Red Cross will distribute gifts and refreshments at a Christmas party at the Holy Family Hospital today.

A SUMMARY and explanation of just what went on at last summer's Second Assembly of the World Council of Churches in Evanston, Ill., is already off the press. It is James H. Nichols' EVANSTON: An Interpretation (Harper, $2). This is a swift job of writing and publishing, but it is not a superficial one.

THE 1936 Pulitzer Prize in poetry went to Marya Zaturenska for her second volume, "Cold Morning Sky." Two other books of poetry followed this one, and in "Selected Poems" she has now brought together her favorites from four works, plus nineteen new poems.

I'VE been hearing that overproduction and high costs are killing the theatre, but I don't know that I actually worried about such things until I saw "Snowflaketime," the third-grade Christmas play at a school in New Rochelle. Then it all came clear to me.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, Dec. 18 -- The Cabinet has approved a report that paves the way for the settlement of a long dispute between a United States oil-refining company and the Government over gasoline prices at the new refinery near Sidon.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Dec. 18 -- The Capuava oil refinery, constructed in fourteen months, was dedicated today in Sao Paulo.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 18 -- The brighter industrial picture in this area during November was further affirmed through additional statistics released this week. Debits at twenty-seven banks here, exclusive of those against Government accounts and interbanking deposits, were 4 per cent above a year ago.

Department store sales in the week ended Dec. 11 in the United States were 3 per cent higher than the like week a year ago, according to the Federal Reserve Board. In the previous week they were up 1 per cent, for the four weeks ended Dec. 11 they were up 2 per cent, but for the year to that date they were 1 per cent below the like periods of 1953.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- The United Nations, in addition to scouting for world peace, is planning ports, chartering ships, sorting out maritime regulations and statistics and keeping an eye on the health of seamen.
An appeal has been sent to Mr. Hammarskjold by thirty-one Chinese who came to this country as students and since the Korean war have been unable to obtain exit permits.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Commodity Credit Corporation's losses on surplus foods purchases this fiscal year will hit a new high, possibly double last year's.

DALLAS, Dec. 18 -- Department store sales were booming over the Southwest this week and most merchants expected holiday sales to equal or better 1953 business. In Dallas, for example, one merchant said: "It's the best buying season we've had since wartime." Another said stocks were running low, particularly in toy lines.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Forty-eight college seniors arrived today and started getting ready for the Blue-Gray gridiron game on Christmas Day.
Two overtime games between all-star combinations marked the holiday festival of indoor polo at the Squadron A Armory last night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- The Veterans Administration reported today on the first ten years of G. I. loans.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- Federal machinery for processing unfair labor practice complaints faces a possible breakdown next week.

OVER the years nearly every country that celebrates the Nativity has used spices in its Christmas breads, cakes, cookies and beverages. In America we have taken these spicy symbols of Christmas for our own and made them into treasured family traditions.

For the first time since 1939, Jean Renoir is directing a film in his native France. Having spent the last fifteen years in America, India and Italy, making movies like "The Southerner," "The River" and "The
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Senator Estes Kefauver accused Admiral Lewis L. Strauss today of trying to "blackmail" Tennessee Valley members of Congress into compliance on the Dixon-Yates contract.
Mayor Wagner and his family were among the hundreds of travelers stranded for three hours or more at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, after yesterday's crash.

Salle Santelli won the intermediate foil team fencing competition on the strips of the Grand Central Y. M. C. A. yesterday. The triumphant squad scored its victory on touches against, having registered 92 to 93 for the Fencers Club A team.

MANILA, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Atsushi Miyagi of Japan today defeated second-seeded Johnny Jose of the Philippines, 6 -- 0, 9 -- 7, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, to reach the final round of the Philippine Tennis Association singles championship.

CHRISTMAS themes in various patterns will dominate radio and television programs this week. The Yuletide keynote, which will center around holiday gaiety, Christmas music and religious observances, can be found in many regularly scheduled programs as well as special attractions.

SYDNEY, Dec. 18 (Reuters) -- After having experienced trouble on the opening day of the second test, the English touring cricket team fought back with such determination today that it restricted Australia to a first innings lead of 74.
PARIS, Dec. 18-- The defense budget of almost every North Atlantic ally of the United States will be lower for 1955 than for 1954. But almost every one will actually spend more on defense.

AS 1954 draws to a close, the business community is briefing itself on what to expect in the coming year. The consensus among economists is that 1955 will see a further expansion of gross national product and that the recovery from the 1953-54 recession will continue.

Teachers' colleges have begun to recognize that the most important and most difficult period in the training of a teacher is the first few years of transition from student to instructor. As a result, more and more emphasis is being placed on follow-up programs to assist new teachers in making the transition.
A five-alarm fire started by a child playing with matches swept the upper floors of two five-story old-law tenements at Eight Avenue and 153d Street in Harlem last night.

TWENTY-FIVE photographs are among the works from the collection of the Museum of Modern Art in "Masters of Modern Art" (New York: The Museum of Modern Art; distributed by Simon Schuster. $15), just published.

On Dec. 31 Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams will complete a year in office in which he has done all he can to get better police protection for the people. He is seeking, also, to obtain more pay for the men and a much larger force.
STOWE, Vt., Dec. 18 (AP) -- A new double-chair ski lift on Spruce Peak was dedicated today amid alternating downpours and drizzles of rain that washed out virtually everything but enthusiasm.

Ralph Kiner, already known in baseball circles as the "man who hates money," will negotiate a new contract with the Cleveland Indians. The high-priced outfielder, recently sold by the Chicago Cubs to the Cleveland Indians, on his own volition sought and received a 40 per cent cut in salary.
STATE COLLEGE, Pa., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Rutgers was no match for Penn State tonight as Jesse Arnelle led the Nittany Lions to a 106-69 victory over the Scarlet. Arnelle's 41 points set a new Lion record.
NEW HAVEN, Dec. 14 -- A master plan has been drafted for the redevelopment of a forty-square-block area between the main business district and the Union Station area here.

DOLLAR-HUNGRY Latin America appears to be belatedly turning her attention to the booming United States tourist industry as a means of alleviating her economic woes. Under renewed prodding by Washington, the South American governments agreed at the recent inter-American economic conference in Petropolis, Brazil, to make a serious bid for a larger share of the billion-dollar "invisible trade" represented by mounting outlays by American vacationists.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 -- President Eisenhower hit a popular delusion right in the solar plexus this week when he said flying saucers do not come from outer space.

THE customer out shopping for a 1955 automobile can be forgiven if he is overwhelmed by the excess of riches flashed before him by the automobile industry. The new cars offer a variety of engines, transmissions, paint jobs and upholstery color combinations, power steering and braking, and many other accessories, some of them now standard equipment.

In his article, "The Job of a Supreme Court Justice" (Nov. 28), Justice Felix Frankfurter expresses his opinion that "a judge should be compounded of the faculty of a prophet" in addition to that of the philosopher and the historian.
KINGSTON, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- Manhattan College set two school scoring records and gained its third victory of the basketball season tonight by crushing Hartwick College of Oneonta, N. Y., 105 -- 62.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 18 -- Dr. Edward U. Condon, the physicist, arrived here today to take up residence.

There are increasing signs that the Iron Curtain is no longer so impenetrable as it used to be. As compared with conditions in the last years of the Stalin regime, a relative flood of foreigners has been visiting the Soviet Union in recent months and, similarly, an impressive throng of Soviet citizens has been going abroad.

SINCE the announcement in these columns two months ago of the return of Escudero to this country in February there has been an unprecedented stream of inquiries about how to secure seats, how to obtain copies of his "Decalogue" for flamenco dancers, and other details. Certainly his public has not forgotten him in the twenty years since he was last here.
The privately owned United States-flag ocean merchant fleet decreased by seventeen ships and more than 185,000 deadweight tons last month, the American Merchant Marine Institute reported last week.

BEING an elderly party and calm with its 163 years, the Massachusetts Historical Society, the oldest historical society in the country, is accustomed to taking things pretty much as they may come. Yet even the society might be pardoned a certain pride in what now goes on among its upper-floor archives.
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 18 -- With the approach of the new year, Westchester is cutting a $102,000 pattern for golden treatment of its golden-age citizens.

MEXICO CITY--Although in the hinterlands of Mexico the Christmas season is still celebrated much as it has been for generations, within cosmopolitan Mexico City traditional native observances are strongly mingled today with American-style festivities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) --The Minneapolis Tribune, which was first to publish the story of the removal of Mr. Ladejinski, said in a copyrighted Washington dispatch that Mr. Ladejinsky "apparently" was dismissed because of his birthplace and be cause "in 1931 he worked for Amtorg, Russian trading agency, as an interpreter."

Betty Crocker, who is quite a good cook, is so busy that she actually is some four dozen women. This is as it should be, since she gets more than 2,000 letters a day, on the average, from women appealing for help in feeding a peckish husband or in stopping a layer cake from going soggy.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 18 -- Premier Adnan Menderes called tonight for improved relations between Greece and Turkey following the United Nations General Assembly's decision to "put an end to the Cyprus question."
Antibiotics are being overused and abused, according to the committee on child welfare of the New York County Medical Society.
Defeat caught up with the celebrated Tom Gola and the La Salle College basketball team for the first time this season last night at Madison Square Garden.
EAST ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 18 (AP) -- William O. Barnes Jr., Republican floor leader of the Essex County delegation in the State Assembly, has been picked for majority leader of next year's Assembly.

PHOENIX, Ariz. -- Shaped like a slightly warped jelly bean, a blob on one of the U. S. Weather Bureau's basic maps covers a southern segment of California, half of Arizona and the southwestern portion of New Mexico.
MOSCOW, Dec. 18--Official Soviet comment on international relations has somewhat changed its tune in the past month.

TORONTO, Dec. 18 -- Ted Kennedy, one of the National Hockey League's oldest and best centers, score one goal and assisted on two others tonight to give the Toronto Maple Leafs a 3-1 victory over the New York Rangers.

IT isn't every author who urges her audience to take a year to read her book, but Miss Robinson's "All the Year Round" is not a usual item for young people. It is a very personal, informal week-by-week record or almanac of the seasons.
Parents were warned yesterday by Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. not to buy highly flammable Christmas toys imported from Japan.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France renewed tonight his plea for a conference with the Soviet Union next May. He did so in a broadcast speech made after the final session of the North Atlantic Council and a long meeting of the foreign ministers of the United States, Britain and France.

The first man to reach the scene of the fatal crash of the Italian Airlines plane at New York International Airport yesterday afternoon was the manager of the airport, George M. McSherry. He participated in the rescue of three or four of the survivors.

THE Film Council of America reports a lively response to its recent announcement of the second annual American Film Assembly to be held here next April, and small wonder. With the twelve categories now increased to twenty-six, entries in the open competition continue to arrive at Council headquarters, 600 Davis Street, Evanston, Ill., prior to the Jan. 15 deadline.
Gray skies and a gentle rain provided an apt setting yesterday for the final closing of the big John Wanamaker store on Broadway between Eighth and Ninth Streets.

The sixth annual Forest Hills Gardens Cotillion will be held on Dec. 28 in the Community House, Forest Hills Gardens, Queens. Sixteen young women will be presented formally at the fete, which will serve also to raise funds for the Brooklyn Home for Children.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 17 -- A World Bank mission will visit here next month to confer with the Government on Indonesia's financial difficulties. The bank, officially known as the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development, is expected to make a close study of the country's budgetary and balance of payments position.
Just up the East River north of the United Nations last Monday afternoon, another international group met to observe the second birthday of the East Harlem Day Center for Older Persons.

Despite the Christmas lull a number of art shows are opening this week. Included among those opening tomorrow is an exhibition of collages by Robert Courtright at the New Gallery, 601 Madison Avenue; sculpture by Richard Stankiewicz at the Hansa Gallery, 210 Central Park South, and an invitation group at the Tanager Gallery, 90 East Tenth Street.
The best Christmas in history for both moppets and merchants is only six days away.

Willie Mays, spectacular center fielder of the world champion Giants, captured the National League batting championship after one of the most thrilling three-cornered struggles in more than twenty years, according to the official averages released for publication today.

MIDDLETOWN, N. J., Dec. 18 (AP) -- An Army representative notified township officials this week that a guided missile base would be constructed here soon as part of the defense of the New York metropolitan area.

On the evening of Jan. 12 a shy-looking woman will get up in a ballroom crowded with retail trade notables at the St. Regis Hotel and present a "Retailer of the Year" award to David L. Rike, president of the Rike-Kumler Company of Dayton, Ohio.
Victor Seixas of Philadelphia and Tony Trabert of Cincinnati have been recommended for the first and second places, respectively, in the United States tennis rankings for 1954.
Weekly discussions are being held on the possible sale of city-owned bus lines in Manhattan and Queens to private operators.
DUNLAY, Tex., Dec. 18 -- Yesterday we tried the rough-and-ready method of deer hunting. We climbed up and skidded down slopes, ridges and canyons covered with cactus, cat-claw and mesquite.
CHAMPAIGN, Ill., Dec. 18 (AP) -- Undefeated Illinois, the No. 3 team in the nation, swept to its fifth victory tonight, downing Notre Dame, 66 -- 57, in a game dominated by defensive basketball.

When the Virginia State Highway Department completes the bridge-tunnel across Hampton Roads, on which work is now commencing, a historic water gap between Norfolk and Newport News and the Virginia Peninsula will have been crossed. The project will take an interesting place in engineering annals.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (AP) -- The United States is considering the joint use of civil and military radar.

New York City is going to get more policemen. Last Thursday the Board of Estimate boosted the authorized strength of the Police Department from 20,878 to 21,628, highest figure in its history. Some 750 new policemen are to be appointed as quickly as possible.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- When Premier Pierre Mendes-France was in Washington last month he had no trouble declaring in perfectly good faith that the Paris agreements creating Western European Union and providing for German sovereignty and rearmament would be ratified by the French National Assembly by the end of the year.

LAST year there were some beautiful Christmas recordings -- disks that showed both taste and invention on the part of those responsible. One remembers especially Esoteric's "English Medieval Christmas Carols" and Contemporary's "Contemporary Christmas Carols."

BONN, Germany, Dec. 18 -- At least fourteen persons were killed and more than sixty injured when two passenger trains, collided', head-on near Dortmund, in the Ruhr Valley, early this morning. Thirty of the injured were seriously hurt.

IT would be hard to imagine a man better equipped than Padraic Colum to do a popular book of Irish folklore. Born in the Midlands of Ireland, in Oliver Goldsmith's country, he spent his early years in the workhouse of which his father was master, where he got to know not only the Irish country people but the men and women of the roads -- ballad singers, tinkers, pipers, fiddlers.
DETROIT, Dec. 16 -- Motorists guilty of serious traffic offenses in Detroit in the pre-Christmas period face holiday dinners in jail.

CHICAGO, Dec. 18 (UP) -- Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored his 400th National Hockey League goal in the third period tonight to help the league-leading Montreal Canadiens gain a 4-2 victory over the last-place Chicago Black Hawks before 6,380 fans.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 18 -- United States officials here have been increasingly disturbed by Turkey's failure to carry out an economic stabilization program announced last spring.

The election of James T. Farrell, novelist and short story writer, as chairman of the American Committee for Cultural Freedom, has been announced. His most famous work is his "Studs Lonigan" trilogy. Now a New Yorker, he formerly lived in Chicago, the milieu of much of his writing.

BONN, Dec. 18 -- The Bundestag debate on the first reading of the Paris and Saar agreements reflected on the conscious political level the uncertain state of public opinion concerning the correctness of Western foreign policy with reference to Germany's future.

Paced by Ed Conlin, the Fordham basketball team registered a decisive triumph over Yale last night on the uptown court. The rangy Conlin accounted for 34 points as his team set down the Bulldogs by the count of 78 to 58.

MIAMI, Dec. 18 (UP) -- High Gun, the 3-year-old champion of 1954 who was retired for the year two days before the Washington, D. C., International at Laurel Nov. 3, will return to competition at Hialeah Park, Trainer Max Hirsch said today.

The Empire State Foundation of Liberal Arts Colleges has called upon business and industry to join institutions of higher learning as partners in preparing young men and women for leadership. In a publication, "The Strength to Grow," the foundation pointed to the achievements of the state's colleges and universities.
Ted Williams, Larry Doby and Yogi Berra were the American League's leading sluggers in 1954, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

NEW ENGLAND is keeping pace with the national trend toward networks of superhighways to the extent of 1,000,000,000. At a recent meeting officials of the six state highway departments agreed that the joint drive on regional road problems was beginning to provide a measure of traffic relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 18 (UP) -- A fateful warning by John Carter Vincent was revealed today. The former career diplomat told the United States in July, 1938, that it must bolster Nationalist China if it wanted to avoid an eventual clash with Japanese militarism.
A huge new extrusion press made its public debut in Rochester, N. Y., last week in the midst of a lively squabble over which company would eventually be chosen by the Air Force to operate it.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 18 (AP) -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India and visiting President Tito of Yugoslavia conferred privately for three hours today on their two viewpoints of "peaceful coexistence," well-informed sources reported.

Contributors to the Neediest Cases Fund of the New York Times showed yesterday that "absence makes the heart grow fonder." From far away came gifts that, added to those from the city itself, brought $8,371.72 to the appeal from 331 donors.

FORT LEE, N. J., Dec. 18 -- A two-mile section of the Palisades Interstate Parkway extending from the George Washington Bridge to Palisade Avenue in Englewood Cliffs was opened to traffic at 11 A. M. today by the Palisades Interstate Park Commission.

NOT only the life and the music of J. S. Bach, but also the lives and the works of seven generations of his incredible family of musicians are examined and newly assessed by Karl Geiringer in an engrossing book, "The Bach Family: Seven Generations of Creative Genius," just issued by the Oxford Press.
Twenty-six persons died yesterday when an Italian Airlines plane from Rome and Milan crashed and burned on a pier in Jamaica Bay.

CHORE FOR THE WEEK: When choosing a cut Christmas tree the best one is the one with twigs and needles that feel resilient, not dry and crumbly. Fir with soft needles lasts longest indoors. Spruce with prickly needles and Scotch pine are other favorites. Anchor the tree firmly in a container of water indoors.

New York International Airport, popularly known as Idlewild, has had a relatively good safety record. In operation since July, 1948, its first fatal airliner accident did not occur until more than five years later.

WITH "The Bad Seed" successfully launched on Broadway and a road company already being talked about, Maxwell Anderson is planning the completion of "Twain on the River." This is the musical adaptation of three Mark Twain novels, on which Mr. Anderson and Joshua Logan did considerable work in 1949.

Vanderbilt Armold will end a fifty-two-year railroading career on Jan. 1 when he retires as chairman of the trunk line-central passenger committee of the eastern railroads. His retirement was announced last week at a testimonial dinner in the Biltmore Hotel.

To many who purchase poinsettias before Dec. 25 comes around each year it is probably just another pleasure of the season. But to the growers who are behind the scenes of these handsome blooms, it is the final chapter of a long annual operation.

Christmas trees are an almost explosive hazard -- as everyone knows who has seen one burst into fire at the touch of a flame. Fire Commissioner Cavanagh has warned the public not to have trees at all unless precautions are taken which should become part of the ritual of Christmas.

BONN, Dec. 19 -- The largest transaction believed to have been arranged to date for the transfer of the capital holding in Germany of an American citizen who originally left Germany to escape National Socialist racial persecution has just been completed here.

The realty business of Williams Co. is being carried on today in modern offices at 15 West Forty-fourth Street where a formal opening was held last Friday. The company had maintained quarters at Broadway and Twenty-eighth Street for almost thirty years.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -- Government clerks have come up with something new and certainly dramatic in the way of a protest demonstration. But there does not seem much chance of its catching on in labor movements elsewhere.
