City College will open its semi-annual Community Chest drive today at the Baruch School of Business. Eight charities, selected by student vote, will share the proceeds.

In discussing "Control of Armaments," a recent correspondent in your column presents an illogical viewpoint. Obviously, an enforceable disarmament procedure has not yet been achieved, but why that should discourage efforts to achieve collective security is hard to fathom.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Sporting News today announced the selection of Lou Groza, Cleveland Browns place-kicker, as the most valuable player in the National Football League. This is a new award.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 14 -A sweeping revision of Tennessee's penal and correctional system is recommended in a Citizen's Commission report.

PORT CHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 19 (AP) -- Eighteen-year-old Lillis Lanphier, who walked away yesterday from a plane crash that killed the pilot and co-pilot, was in good condition t0day, but still in a hospital.
Adolphs of Emme has designed for Patterns of The Times four cocktail hats that can still be made at home in time for the holidays.
In the State Racing Commission's 1954 report, which was made public yesterday, there is a past-tense reference to New York as "the big apple" of horse racing.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 19 -- The Guatemalan Government will begin early this week spending the $3,400,000 of a United States grant for the Pacific Highway project.

WORCESTER, Mass., Dec. 19 -- Ch. Silver Spray of Wychwood, a Samoyed owned by Bernice B. Ashdown of Manhasset, N. Y., captured best in show honors today at the annual Worcester County Kennel Club show.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Premier Gamal Abdel Nasser of Egypt and Israel's Chief of Staff, Maj. Gen. Moshe Dayan, assert the peaceful intentions of their respective countries in articles in the January issue of Foreign Affairs Quarterly.

Christianity has an "outreach" greater than any other world view, the Rev. Leopold W. Bernhard said in a Christmas sermon yesterday morning in St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue and Fifty-fourth Street.
A Christmas festival for children was held yesterday morning at St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square at East Sixteenth Street.
The Christmas holiday should not be thought of as a dreamy interlude in the real drama of life, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman declared yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 19 -- Archaeologists are complaining that the 4,000 year old graves of some of Britain's most ancient and aristocratic dead are being ripped open and flattened by an agricultural machine imported from the United States called a "prairie buster."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 19 (UP) -- The Detroit Lions, who make a habit of beating Cleveland in the closing minutes, scored a touchdown with fifty seconds remaining today and defeated the Browns, 14 -- 10. The two teams ended the National Football League's regular 1954 season in a sub-freezing snowstorm.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 19 -- The Communist regimes in Eastern Europe are campaigning vigorously against widespread indifference among young people. The report comes from United States and German monitoring stations that regularly follow Government broadcasts.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The captain of a Swedish cargo vessel stood on her bridge and went down as she sank in the Sound of Mull, off the western coast of Scotland, late last night.

ROME, Dec. 19 -- Pope Pius passed an agitated and largely sleepless night. This morning he still was troubled by hiccups. Nevertheless, his doctors found a slight improvement in his general condition.

CHICAGO, Dec. 19 (AP) -Mayor Martin H. Kennelly, rejected yeterday by a Democratic slate-making committee, says he thinks he can win renomination. The committee designated Richard J. Daley, Cook County Clerk.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 19 -- Far from the ice-covered slopes of Nepal, in a laboratory at the State University's women's college here, there may be found the clue to the identity of the mysterious scourge of the Himalayas, the Abominable Snowman.
LONDON, Dec. 19 -- The dismissal of 315 maintenance workers employed by British European Airways at London Airport was threatening tonight to lead to further labor trouble at the field.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 19 -- The candles of Hanukkah, the feast of dedication, spring up throughout Israel tonight. Along with religious feeling, they signalize a national upsurge of good cheer and of sympathetic interest in the lonely settlers of the new villages.
ATLANTA, Dec. 1 -- Irrigation is rapidly becoming integral in the humid areas of the Southern states.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -The Government's farm parity formula is as outdated as the farm mule, Agriculture Department experts say.
Five hours after arriving in this country for the first time, a German doctor discovered last night that he has a near-fatal allergy to salted peanuts.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 19 -By Government decree, the lion is about to chase the tiger out of the jungles of central India.

HAVANA, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The United States open golf champion, Ed Furgol of Clayton, Mo., won the $15,000 Havana invitation tournament today with a 273. Furgol fired a 5-under-par 67 for a one-stroke victory over Walt Burkemo in the 72-hole competition.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- The National Planning Association suggested procedures today for coordinating Federal economic and fiscal policies, with emphasis on long-range activity.

SHIPS standing in from the sea by way of Gravesend Bay and the Narrows are sometimes greeted on dark nights by an unlisted station that blinks messages at them with a strong light, from a point just inshore at Fort Eamilton.

American and Philippine representatives affixed their signatures last week to a document that, if approved by the national legislatures of the two countries, should place their commercial relations on a more satisfactory basis and contribute to the stabilization and strength of the young Philippine Republic.

All that the New York Rangers could do in their game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night was to gain a 3-3 tie. But, judging from the cheers that went up at the outcome, one would have thought that Muzz Patrick's skaters had just qualified for the Stanley Cup.

All that the New York Rangers could do in their game with the Toronto Maple Leafs at Madison Square Garden last night was to gain a 3-3 tie. But, judging from the cheers that went up at the outcome, one would have thought that Muzz Patrick's skaters had just qualified for the Stanley Cup.
Beginning Jan. 14 the Transit Authority will institute faster rush-hour service on the Broadway line of the I. R. T. subway system.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -Some of the country's leading human relations experts are helping the Government to find out what makes a good soldier and how he can become a better one.
A tradition of several years' standing was observed yesterday at 5 P. M. when Gian-Carlo Menotti's "Amahl and the Night Visitors'' was broadcast by the N. B. C. Opera Theatre over N. B. C.-TV.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Dec. 19 (Reuters) -- Count Helmut von Zborowski announced tonight that his "coleopter" -- a cross between a helicopter and a jet airliner -- had been tested in wind tunnels and could fly within two years.

For the most part, in its Town Hall concert last night, the New York Concert Choir, conducted by Margaret Hillis, upheld its reputation for clear, spirited singing. Four Poulenc Motets were presented with real style, and Haydn's "Theresenmesse," a work that seldom is heard in New York concert halls, was handled with precision.

ATHENS, Dec. 19 -- The Athens press gave great prominence today to United States Secretary of State Dulles' statement expressing his "confidence that the long tradition of friendship between the Greek and American peoples will continue unimpaired" and adding, "misunderstandings that have cropped up are unfortunately inevitable even between peoples who have the deepest respect for each other."

Five sightless men from Brooklyn were among the jolliest bearers of Christmas cheer at parties given here yesterday. They journeyed from Brooklyn to the Bronx to entertain an old pal and his fellow patients at the Concourse Nursing Home, 1072 Grand Concourse.
The presidents of two of the largest foundations labeled false yesterday the findings of a Congressional committee whose report had attacked them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (AP) -- The Agriculture Department said today that the movement of hogs and higher quality beef cattle to slaughter markets would be relatively large this winter to assure bountiful supplies of meat.
Wally Moon, 24-year-old St. Louis Cardinal outfielder, was named the National League's Rookie of the Year by the Baseball Writers Association of America yesterday.

In this season of peace and goodwill the fact that peace is so precarious and that goodwill is badly diminished by an ideological conflict is the more distressing. The Soviet spokesmen, for their own purposes, talk as though the democratic Powers were still behaving and conspiring like nineteenth-century imperialisms.

BIRDSBORO, Pa., Dec. 19 (AP) -- The formal sale of the Birdsboro Steel Foundry and Machinery Company to a group headed by Frederick W. Richmond of New York for $3,970.000 was announced over the week-end.

" Versailles" ("Si Versailles M'Etait Conte"), a French feature-length historical-spectacle, has been temporarily detained by the United States Customs Department, it was made known yesterday by Jean Goldwurm, president of the Times Film Corporation, importers of the picture.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 -- Nelson Rockefeller, one of the five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr., is now among the most promising young men of the Eisenhower team.
Edward J. Noble, chairman of the finance committee of the American Broadcasting-Paramount Theatres, Inc., has given $5,000,000 more to the Edward John Noble Foundation.

ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 19 -- Instead of 9 billion Deutsche marks yearly as figured in the budget estimates for 1955, now before the German Federal Parliament, the cost of rearmament will have to be raised to nearly 16 billion, it was said last week.

Delegates to the Assembly of Captive European Nations decided unanimously yesterday to seek affiliation with the Council of Europe. Represented in the Assembly are exile groups of nine eastern European countries now under Soviet domination.
A four-door "hardtop" automobile that eliminates center-post pillars between the front and rear doors was announced, yesterday by the Buick division of General Motors Corporation.
The Citizens Committee on Children has sent Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein a memorandum recommending seventeen steps the city can take immediately to bolster its fight against juvenile delinquency.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 19 (UP) -- There was a decline in the traffic toll on Wednesday, Safe Driving Day.
A four-door "hardtop" automobile that eliminates center-post pillars between the front and rear doors was announced, yesterday by the Buick division of General Motors Corporation.
The Citizens Committee on Children has sent Deputy Mayor Henry Epstein a memorandum recommending seventeen steps the city can take immediately to bolster its fight against juvenile delinquency.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Strength in December futures of oats and wheat featured the markets on the Board of Trade today.

Paul R. Tully, an assistant to the starter at Yonkers Raceway, explained yesterday why the bell that customarily calls racers onto the track was not rung on schedule before the second race last Oct. 30.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Congressional investigation of the fund-raising methods of the Disabled American Veterans was said today to have cost the organization $700,000 in revenue.
Jacob K. Javits, State Attorney General-elect, proposed last night the inclusion of Israel in a Near East defense organization.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The British Government is unruffled by the Soviet threat to denounce the British-Soviet treaty if the Paris agreements are ratified.
Ralph,A. Coxhead Corp, manufacturer 0 varitype printing machines, showroom space on the ground floor of 99 Park Ave--] Cushman Wakefield Inc, agents.
DETROIT, Dec. 20 -- A non-Government operation organized to achieve President Eisenhower's atoms-for-peace program was announced today.
Ten of thirteen rooming-house owners, threatened with forced evacuation of their tenements as firetraps, put their sprinkler systems into operating order over the week-end.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Government contracted today to sell two synthetic rubber plants at Borger, Tex., to the Phillips Chemical Company, their present operator.
Advocates of the Hudson River as a future supply of water for New York City lost virtually their last position yesterday in their fight against further development of Delaware River sources.

The Great Northern Paper Company, after more than a year of experimental operation, has started full commercial production of newsprint incorporating hardwood pulp at its mill in East Millinocket, Me.

When Heinrich Harrer escaped from internment in India, he turned north. He described his adventures in "Seven Years in Tibet," which Dutton published this year. Two others who also escaped with Herr Harrer -- Rolf Magener and Heins von Have -- turned south.

PARIS, Dec. 16 -- Magnificent cottons, especially cotton warp prints, are outstanding in the fabric collections for summer of 1955. No evening coat of silk or satin could surpass in opulence one in a Ducharne shadowy warp print in orange sherbert tints on heavy white cotton.

" On the Waterfront," the smashing drama about racketeering on local docksides, was voted the best motion picture of 1954 by the committee on exceptional films of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- The Army has developed a new kind of housing for soldiers on Arctic duty. The shelters gradually sink into the soft snow of the northern wastelands.
A range combining gas burners and oven with an infra-red rotisserie unit was shown by the Caloric Appliance Corporation yesterday at the Ambassador Hotel.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Britain will bind herself tomorrow with the European Coal and Steel Community -- but without surrendering a bit of control over her own coal and steel affairs.

CAIRO, Dec. 20 -- The split in the Sudan's Cabinet widened today. Mirghany Hamza, leader of a dissident group of three ministers, charged that Premier Ismail el-Azhary was trying to dominate the Sudan's foreign and domestic policy with the aid of an inner circle of ministers in an atmosphere of secrecy and suspicion.

A French Premier's lot is not a happy one. Life is one long, succession of battles. Premier Mendes- France has now lasted six months, which is good going for the Fourth Republic, and yesterday he won another vote of confidence.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The post of general counsel of the National Labor Relations Board became vacant today with no indication from the White House on the immediate naming of a successor.

VIENNA, Dec. 20 -- The Austrian Catholic Press Service said it had received "eyewitness confirmation" of' its report that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Primate of Hungary, had been released from prison.

DIXIE VALLEY, Nev., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Cartographers may have to do some revising of their maps as the result of last Thursday's earthquake. The shake caused marked changes in the terrain of this sparsely settled area.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The recent campaign may have been the first one in American history when the party out of power contended that it would be better for the program of a President if his party lost control of Congress after his term was half over.

A fine new string ensemble made its concert debut last night at Town Hall. In a dedicate compliment to the Juilliard School of Music, the foursome has taken the name of the Claremont Quartet, after the avenue on which the Juilliard stands.
For the youngsters of Manhattan, life had begun to approach the status of one big party by yesterday afternoon.

An electric - powered patrol car as a replacement for foot patrolmen was tested by the Port of New York Authority last night along a 2,200-foot section of the catwalk of the New York-bound tube of the Holland Tunnel.

North Carolina State's basketball team, undefeated in eight contests and averaging 92 points a game, will oppose St. John's in the opener of a college double-header at Madison Square Garden tonight. The afterpiece will send Manhattan College against Connecticut.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The head of Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation denied today that conversion of the company's "Little Inch" natural gas pipeline to the transportation of petroleum products might weaken the company financially.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A Federal Communications Commission examiner recommended today that the F. C. C. direct the Western Union Telegraph Company to get rid of its $8,000,000- a-year international telegraph operations.
CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Chicago was asked today to curtail its use of electricity as the supply was reduced by a powerhouse explosion.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 20 -- Nassau County moved today to set up a system of permanent personal registration for the county's 500,000 voters.

An advertising campaign projected tentatively for eighteen months is being worked out by the Economic Development Administration of Puerto Rico. The purpose of the drive, which will be handled by Ogilvy, Benson Mather, Inc., will be to promote the island's industrial development.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -President Eisenhower held two important political pow-wows today that might have a bearing on his second term plans, if any.
The National Association of Manufacturers maintained yesterday that there should be less rather than more Government-provided old-age security.
A majority of a group of distinguished economists looks for a moderate but sustained business recovery throughout 1955.
Arthur Levitt said yesterday that he would resign as president of the Board of Education on Thursday. His successor may be elected at a scheduled board meeting that afternoon.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A University of Mississippi dean said today the university was pressured in connection with his appearance for opponents of the Dixon-Yates power project.
A Japanese woman who offered her life to save his own was named yesterday as heiress to the $40,000 estate left by Daniel Boone Langford, 70-year-old civilian Navy employe.

An automobile sponsor agreed yesterday to pay Jackie Gleason Enterprises $6,142,500 for a series of seventy-eight television films to be shown over a two-year period. The half-hour films starring the comedian will be presented by the Columbia Broadcasting System beginning next autumn.

The New York City Housing Authority announced yesterday that it would take bids on Jan. 4 for an issue of $31,600,000 of notes to continue the temporary financing of two Federally aided low-rent projects, Baruch Houses, Manhattan, and Brevoort Houses, Brooklyn.

ATHENS, Dec. 20 -- King Paul counseled the people of Greece tonight to be patient and understanding on the Cyprus issue.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 20 -- Opposition forces won today a six-month fight with the Moslem League for partial control of the Central Government. They immediately pressed their demand for early elections throughout West Pakistan.

Personnel at the Naval Supply Depot at Twenty-ninth Street and Third Avenue, Brooklyn, gave 201 pints of blood on Friday to the New York Regional Red Cross Blood program. Employes of Sears Roebuck Co, 360 West Thirty-first Street, gave 158 pints. Friday's total was 652.

The trustee for the bankruptI New York, Ontario and Westerni 'Railway Company filed with Fed-I ?ral Judge Edward A. Conger! here yesterday, a reorganization 'plan that called,for the continu: ance of the ros[d's main I{neS for !ten years. A duplicate plan will be filed with the Interstate Com,merce Commission for approval.

Kirsten Flagstad, who made three "farewells" to New York's musical stages in 1952, is coming out of retirement to aid the Symphony of the Air. She will sing with that ensemble in an all-Wagnerian program on March 20 at Carnegie Hall.
TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- The United States' reputation in Japan and the morale of its public servants here fell sharply today.
DESPITE the current interest in small caliber, high velocity big game rifles, the .30 '06 is still popular with a large percentage of the hunters.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Navy's famed mascot, Billy XIV, was loaded on a truck today with 7,500 pounds of football equipment for a trip to New Orleans and Navy's Sugar Bowl game Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Nationalist China's Foreign Minister, George K. C. Yeh, said today that he believed the Chinese Communists might release the eleven imprisoned United States airmen after the Communists "get what they want."

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 20 -- The Government detailed today a delicately balanced financial policy. It is aimed at increasing state control in some sectors of the economy while trying to attract business investment, foreign and domestic.
Cotton futures rose 5 to 10 points on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday.

Samuel Reshevsky, international grand master, gained his second consecutive victory last night in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club, He defeated Larry Evans, national open champion, in thirty-nine moves when his opponent overstepped the time limit.
Two firemen were injured yesterday when they were thrown from the rear platform of a hook and ladder truck as it braked and swerved to avoid a collision with a fire engine.

TOKYO, Dec. 20 -- Japan's Cabinet meets today to give formal approval to the treaty of peace with Burma. Agreements granting the Rangoon Government $250,000,000 in reparations payments during the next ten years also are expected to be adopted.
James A. Phillips was chosen yesterday as Democratic leader of Queens.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 20 -- Durban, South Africa's third and most English city, is in a considerable predicament because the all-Afrikaner National Government has instructed public prosecutors not to prosecute anyone breaking municipal laws promulgated in English only.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that 13,038,895 running bales of cotton from the 1954 crop had been ginned prior to Dec. 13.

MOSCOW, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet Union notified Britain today that if London ratified the Paris agreements for arming West Germany, the British-Soviet treaty for mutual aid against German aggression would be annulled.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Government spokesmen denied today that Britain had any obligation to defend Formosa, save that arising from membership in the United Nations. They gave equivocal answers to queries about Formosa's status in the world organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The United States has rejected Communist Hungary's protest against a balloon barrage that has been dropping 15,000,000 "freedom leaflets" a month on Hungarian territory.

Kentucky's Wildcats, unbeaten since the start of the 1953-54 basketball season, took a comfortable lead over the rest of the field yesterday in the second weekly Associated Press ranking poll of the season.

In easing the requirements of the Buy American Act by Executive order President Eisenhower has now taken a much-needed step in the direction recommended to him by the Randall Commission on Foreign Economic Policy nearly a year ago.

DETROIT, Dec. 20 (AP) -- An arbitrator today reinstated twenty-five of twenty-seven employes discharged in connection with violence in the Square D Company strike last summer. Some of the employes will receive back pay ranging up to seven weeks.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The flow of goods, services and aid between the United States and the rest of the world dropped off in the third quarter of this year, the Department of Commerce said today.

A corporation and two officers who circulated a report of financial backing from the Chinese Nationalist Government in a Tungsten ore venture were indicted yesterday. They were accused of defrauding stock purchasers of $299,999.

Directors of the National Radii ator Company and of the United States Radiator Corporation have approved a basis, for merging the two companies, it was announced iointlv yesterday by Theodore B. i'ocke', president of Natidnal, and William C. McCord, president of U. S. Radiator.

Gerald M. Loeb, partner in E. F. Hutton Co., attracted a good deal of attention a couple of years ago by advising speculators to use only a tenth of their available funds, but to play them to double every year. His book, "The Battle for Investment Survival," is in its ninth printing.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 20 (UP) -- Boston Doge, an unbeaten 2-year-old colt from the New England circuit, accounted for his fifth straight victory today when he outclassed a field of twelve in the Fontainebleu Purse at Tropical Park.

Jerome Lieberman, 17-year-old Brooklyn high school student, who won an acquittal at his murder trial Dec' 9, yesterday was released on $7,500 bail pending trial on a manslaughter charge. Lieberman was one of the four youths originally charged with the murder of Willard Menter, 34-year-old factory worker.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- A fourth wicket stand of 116 by two young amateurs, Peter May (98 not out) and Colin Cowdrey (54), left England with a fighting chance against Australia at the end of the third day of their second cricket test today.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- More than 100 of the 315 British European Airways maintenance men who were dismissed at London airport Friday when they held a meeting during working hours were rehired today.
In the small, less crowded shops, there are many unusual gifts that a woman could give a man for Christmas.

Myriads of pink blossoms, flowering plants and trees, interspersed with pink lights, silvered foliage and smilax, transformed the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria into a garden setting for the nineteenth annual Debutante Cotillion and Christmas Ball, which was held last night. Underwritten by Jacqueline Cochran Cosmetics, the fete served to raise funds for the New York Infirmary, of which Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip is president.
The C. I. T. Col2ooration, an industrial financing concern, has extended its ten-year installment purchase pl.an to textile machinery, according to Sydney D. Maddock, president.

The three-year-old New Jersey Turnpike is now carrying more than double its predicted volume of traffic. As a result, sixty-one miles of the 118-mile toll expressway will be widened soon from four to six lanes.
The Times reported on Dec. 13 that in the opinion of Maj. Gen. Hugh J. Casey, Chairman of the Transit Authority, services Supplied by the city transit lines "have improved."
The critical report on foundations issued Sunday by a House subcommittee was denounced yesterday as the "product of a kangaroo court."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Democrats outpolled the Republicans by 2,185,327 in the aggregate vote Nov. 2 for seats in the House of Representatives.
RANGOON, Burma, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Premier U Nu of Burma hinted today there would be a development "very soon" in the case of the eleven United States airmen imprisoned as "spies" by the Peiping regime.

One of those crises that occasionally make the annals of opera read like a Grade B movie script took place before the performance of "The Marriage of Figaro" at the Metropolitan last evening. An artist became indisposed at the last minute and another, on short notice, essayed a difficult new role with great success.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Soviet Foreign Minister, Vyacheslav M. Molotov, has recently been acting like the terrible-tempered Mr. Bang, but Washington is remarkably unconcerned.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Thieves who combined a talent for realism in art with safe-cracking stole $10,133 from Genung's Department Store over the week-end. The money was in, a 5-by-3 1/2-foot steel safe. And the management had placed the safe in a second-story window, brilliantly floodlighted.
Sanitation Commissioner Andrew W. Mulrain yesterday called New York perhaps the world's worst city in point of "avoidable street dirt" and public indifference.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Dec. 20 -- Twenty-three persons were arrested this morning when striking Underwood Corporation workers battled the police as thirty supervisors tried to enter the plant, strikebound since Nov. 5.

QUANTICO, Va., Dec. 20 (AP) -- By employing a fast break against their taller opponents, Wabash College of Crawfordsville, Ind., tonight defeated Fairleigh Dickinson, Rutherford, N. J., 86 -- 68, in the Quantico Marine Base basketball tournament.

NEWROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- Willis I. Thomson, 60 years old, has resigned as principal of New Rochelle High School while facing "charges of a grave nature,'' the Board of Education said today. He had been a principal of secondary schools here for twenty-six years.

The report of the Committee of the House of Representatives appointed to investigate tax-exempt foundations is receiving more attention than its practical importance deserves -- largely because of its sensational and irresponsible charge that the nation's leading foundations have "directly supported subversion."

The New York and New Jersey Dry Dock Association has urged a House subcommittee to adopt an effective system of qualifying or rating ship repair yards to perform work for Governmental agencies. The suggestion, one of four designed to aid the "sick" ship repair industry, was aimed at the smaller shipyards or "bicycle shops" that dot New York Harbor.
The North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris last week discussed, but did not resolve, the problem of when atomic weapons should be utilized in the event of war and who should authorize their use.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 20 -- The Outlook for Turkish-Egyptian cooperation in the Middle East defense system has brightened since Cairo's military junta opened a drive to destroy the Moslem Brotherhood.

LONDON, Dec. 20 -- The Colonial Secretary, Alan T. Lennox-Boyd told Parliament today that the disturbances in Cyprus were over and that the Governor's handling of the situation there "could not have been more excellent."

ROME, Dec. 20 -- Pope Pius XII still is a very sick man despite his improvement during the last two weeks. He will not be well enough on Christmas Eve to broadcast the message he has addressed to the world on that time every year since his elevation to the Pontificate in 1939.
OTTAWA, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Canada will investigate next summer diversion of flood waters for hydroelectric power from the Columbia into the Fraser River system in British Columbia.

They are ready for Christmas -- the gingerbread men with white frosting eyes, the panettone dotted with fruit and the other delicacies prepared especially for the holiday by bakeries of foreign background.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The 33-year-old minister of the First Reformed Church will pull up clerical stakes this week to carry the gospel to the booming oil fields of North Dakota.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Dec. 20 -- A Christmas message to the Boy Scouts of America from President Eisenhower has been made public by the Scouts' national council here. The President's message follows:

Operations in the nation's steel industry declined last week for the first time since the Labor Day week. Last week's 81.8 per cent of theo. retical capacity compared with 82.1 per cent the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The high-scoring Duke University basketball team from Durham, N. C., poured it on in the last half tonight to overwhelm Pitt, 90 -- 68, and win its fifth victory in six starts. Pitt led, 37 -- 35, at the half.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 -- Cudahy Packing Company reported today a net loss of $7,162,254 in the fiscal year ended Oct. 30, including expenses of about $1,000,- 000 incurred in closing unprofitable plants and branches. In the preceding year there was a net profit of $542,677.

Robert A. Wagner las been elected president of the TenantOwned Apartment Association, Inc., sudceeding Brewster Ires, who had served since 1952. Mr. Wagner is vice president of Albert B. Ashforth, Inc.

The Assembly of Captive European Nations adjourned its first plenary session last night after adopting unanimously an appeal to the free nations of the world. It urged withdrawal of recognition of Soviet-dominated regimes in nine Eastern European countries. Representatives of exiles of these countries constitute the assembly.

Jennifer Jones, winner of the film industry's Academy Award, makes her Broadway stage debut at the ANTA Theatre tonight at 8 o'clock in "Portrait of a Lady," William Archibald's dramatization of the Henry James novel.
" Squash," said King Prajadhipok, "is nothing less than a godsend to a country like Siam."

Roger Campbell of Princeton, the defending champion and No. 1 seeded player, gained two straight-game victories yesterday to reach the third round in the University Club's annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament.
A Navy salvage crew recovered yesterday a thirty-foot rear section of the cabin of the Italian Airlines plane that crashed and burned at the edge of Jamaica Bay Saturday afternoon.
Eight persons were taken to a hospital last night after being jolted or knocked about when a subway train was halted suddenly as a passenger pulled the emergency cord.
The election of Earl B. Schwulst, chairman and president of the Bowery Savings Bank, to the board of trustees of Barnard College was announced yesterday by Mrs. Ogden Reid, chairman of the board.
ROTTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A new trans-Atlantic ship service, the Europe-Canada Line, will start operations next April.
Ted Williams, who wasn't stopped by inactivity, a fractured collar bone, pneumonia or a constant desire to get away from baseball and go fishing, was the "comeback" baseball player of 1954.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Clem D. Johnston, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce, called tonight for a 25 per cent slash in Federal spending.
Sales of land in Westchester Comity to home builders wer reported by realty broke .yesterday,

Between Nov. 15 and Dec. 15 the aggregate short interest on the New York Stock Exchange fell 45,904 shares, the Exchange reported yesterday. A short position is created when borrowed shares are sold to be replaced later, preferably at a lower price.
Burglars forced a safe at 1650 Broadway over the week-end and made off with $100,000 in industrial diamonds.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Butchers gained 25 to 75 cents a hundred pounds and sows 50 cents today in a market featured by small arrivals. Salable receipts, at 14,000 head, were 5,000 fewer than a week ago.
Franchises in the National Basketball Association are being sought by interested parties in four cities, Maurice Podoloff, president of the professional league, disclosed yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Department of Agriculture apparently will review the case of Wolf Ladejinsky.

The profligate cost of the madness that afflicts labor conditions on the New York waterfront is revealed with painful clarity in tonnage statistics for the first six months of 1954. The principal competing customs districts on the North Atlantic and Gulf coasts showed a 7.3 per cent increase in the volume of general cargo handled, as compared with a 19.3 per cent reduction in New York.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 20 -- The Westchester Board of Supervisors adopted by 36 to 7 today a 1955 gross county budget of $45,959,417. It was the same as the County Executive had proposed Nov. 15 and produced a tax rate of $8.36 for each $1,000 of assessed valuation, a reduction of 11 cents.

BERLIN, Dec. 20 (UP) -- A young German woman accused of having charmed secrets from United States intelligence agents may have been "blackmailed" by the Communists into serving as a spy, her friends said today.

CHICAGO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A three-man group has obtained a controlling stock interest in the Thor Corporation, appliance manufacturer, the head of the group said today. Arnold H. Maremont, president of the Maremont Automotive Products, Inc., is head of the group.

Sidewalk superintendents in Times Square thought they had caught a sign painter in a big mistake yesterday afternoon. He was painting "Rector's" on a construction barricade around Hector's restaurant at Forty-third Street and Seventh Avenue.

PEORIA, Ill., Dec. 20 (AP) -- A light airplane crashed and burned today, killing three persons -- one of them Clinton McNear, member of a prominent Peoria family plagued by a series of violent deaths.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Seaboard Finance Company reported today that profits for he twelve months nded Sept. 30 climbed to a record $4,711,021, compared with 4,3S,913 in the mPrevlous fiscal year.
Pete Adams, Newark middleweight, gained a majority decision over Jimmy Martinez of Glendale, Ariz., in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night.
PARIS, Dec. 20 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France won a surprisingly large majority tonight when the National Assembly gave him a 310-172 vote of confidence on his Indochina policy.

A client of Nassoit Sulzberger C(i.', Ine., brokers, has bought the five-tory dv/elling' o'n'a Blot 20 by 100 feet at 29 East Sixtythird Street, betw. een Park and Madison Avenues, J, iV[. Berlinger is preparing plans for convers, ion of the building into an apartment house with offices for physicians.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 (AP) -- Ralph Guglielmi cried today. And he wasn't ashamed about the tears.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The White House today made public some of the details of President Eisenhower's plans for Christmas at Augusta, Ga.

STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 20 -- Before an assembly of royalty, officialdom and men of letters, Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General, was ceremoniously installed this afternoon in the Swedish Academy. He succeeds his late father, the first member to do so in the 168-year-old history of the Academy.
A new and spirited bundle of horsepower has been entered in the race to provide the airlines with power plants that would put their planes in the 500-mile-an-hour class.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- The Treasury's short-term borrowing costs rose again today, when its ninety-day Treasury bills went at an average annual interest rate of 1.333 per cent -- the highest since those dated Jan. 14, 1954, were sold at an annual rate of 1.336 per cent.

THAT was a tremendous football game which the Detroit Lions and the Cleveland Browns played behind the veil of a raging snow-storm the other day. Just in case you tuned in late, it had better be hastily mentioned that the Lions won from the Browns, 14 -- 10, with a touchdown in the final fifty seconds. The victory kept unbroken Detroit's unique record of never having lost to the Clevelanders.
LONDON, Dec. 20 -- Industrial equities moved irregularly on the stock market today, losing a little of their buoyancy in sympathy with British Government securities, which dipped.

It is clear, even now, that the social season over the Christmas holidays will be something to remember. From those away at school or college the correspondence flows with increased intensity, speaking not of marks but of new invitations to parties and the pressing need for new dresses.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- A publisher and an ambassador were among President Eisenhower's visitors today.

Trading in commodity futures was fast and furious on the New York exchanges yesterday. Potato prices fell as much as the 1/4-cent-a-pound daily limit, several cocoa positions fell the 1-cent-a-pound limit and some rubber options soared 1 cent a pound. Cottonseed oil had the most active day of the year and hide volume was the fourth heaviest.
The Board of Higher Education announced last night that its budget requests for 1955-56 totaled $25,264,385, an increase of $2,121,147 over the current figure.
Two new films open at first-run theatres today.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 20 -- Nationalistic sentiments have received strong emphasis at the congress of the Nationalist party now going on at Bandung. The dominant party in the present Indonesian Government, the Nationalists, are meeting to elect new leaders and decide plans and programs for next year's first Indonesian national elections.

PARIS, Dec. 20 -- In his successful quest for the National Assembly's confidence today, Premier Mendes-France received votes from every group in the Chamber except the Communists, who have ninety-four seats.
HARTFORD, Dec. 20 -- The Connecticut Republican party reported an $18,650 deficit today.
TRENTON, Dec. 20 -- The State Legislature extended rent control today until June 30, 1956, but restricted its application to the sixty-five municipalities where it is now in effect.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 20 -- The Sheppard jury completed its fourth day of deliberation at 10:23 o'clock tonight without reaching a verdict.
The Federal Government earmarked $950,000 in loans yesterday so that New York City could start to plan housing for 8,000 more low-income families.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, denied today that he had ever turned his back on the Marshall broad-production-base policies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- A conference of the foreign ministers of the Manila pact powers is tentatively planned for late February in Bangkok, Thailand.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Department of Commerce said today manufacturing corporations put $115,000,000,000 into production facilities and new working capital from 1946 through mid-1954, and paid nearly three-quarters of the bill from their own earnings.

The forty-third annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund received $33,959.70 yesterday from 428 donors. This sum brought the total for the current campaign to $239,488.40 from 6,028 contributors. The corresponding total last year was $325,261.41 from 7,773 donors.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Harry Hopman tabbed Tony Trabert as the No. 1 threat to Australia's hold on the Davis Cup today. Hopman made the statement after the challenge round rivals whipped through a brisk four-hour workout at White City Stadium.
LONDON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Moscow radio announced tonight the winners of nine Stalin international peace prizes for 1954. Tomorrow is the seventy-fifth anniversary of Stalin's birth.

BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Judge Charles E. Wyzanski Jr. of the Boston Federal District Court disqualified himself today from sitting at a trial of a present and a former Harvard faculty member for contempt of the United States Senate.

The Brick Church Appliance Company yesterday filed anti-trust suits against the Philco Corporation and the Admiral Corporation in Federal District Court here. Last week the Government filed a civil anti-trust suit against Philco in Philadelphia.
BOSTON, Dec. 20 -- Massachusetts joined today a movement to give the handicapped an equal chance to compete for jobs in industry.

Some examples of behavior that may indicate trouble ahead for a child were described yesterday by William Karp, president of Vocational Consulting Associates, a guidance organization. He addressed a meeting of the Kehilath Jeshurun Sisterhood in the auditorium of the congregation, 125 East Eighty-fifth Street.

RIVERHEAD, L. I. Dec. 20 -- Suffolk County husbands, particularly those whose wives have been pestering them to install an extra shelf, put up a curtain rod or build a bookcase, may be in for an easier winter this year. A female carpentry project designed to teach the housewife the use of simple tools is being sponsored by the county's Home Bureau, with thirty-four of the sixty Home Bureau units participating.
David L. Freed of Salt Lake City yesterday was named the nation's No. 1 senior tennis player by the United States Lawn Tennis Association's ranking committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -Charles E. Wilson announced stepped-up manpower cuts today to reduce the Armed Forces from 3,218,000 men to 2,815,000 by mid-1956.

SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 20 -- In the town of Docmo, just forty miles northeast of here, 6,642 North Vietnamese refugees have begun life anew on an upland tract quite different from the water-logged rice fields of their native Red River delta.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (UP) -- Senator Thomas H. Kuchel said today the Army had rejected all bids for equipment for the hydroelectric plant at The Dalles, Ore., after a foreign concern was low bidder.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Representative Oakley Hunter was appointed General Counsel of the Housing and Home Finance Agency today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 20 -The University of California has accepted a $1,000,000 grant from the Rockefeller Foundation to explore ocean resources and "bring the sea into the labaratory."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y, Dec. 20 -- Israel requested today an early meeting of the Security Council to renew consideration of her complaint against Egyptian restrictions on the passage of Israeli ships through the Suez Canal.
MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 20 (AP) -- Rocky Marciano plans to defend his heavyweight boxing title twice in 1955. The first one will be staged on the Pacific Coast, Al Weill, his manager, said today.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -- Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's legal adviser contended today that the Paris agreements would become invalid and inapplicable after Germany's reunification.

Broadway celebrated a joyous event last night -- the rededication by the American National Theatre and Academy of what amounts to a virtually new playhouse. The ceremony took place at the ANTA Theatre, 245 West Fifty-second Street, just before the curtain went up on the preview of "Portrait of a Lady," which marks the Broadway stage debut of Jennifer Jones.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 -- Pledges of Federal-state cooperation in the anti-trust field were exchanged today by Herbert Brownell Jr. and Jacob K. Javits.
A batting average that sagged to .251 and a brief falling out with his manager did not affect the new contract Carroll (Whitey) Lockman has signed with the Giants.

LONDON, Dec. 20 (Reuters) -- British exports set a record high in the first eleven months of 1954 despite the crippling dock strikes in October and November, the official Board of Trade announce today.
A man and a woman, both aliens, were under arrest here yesterday after an unsuccessful attempt to smuggle $10,000 in Swiss watch movements into the country.

The free world's production of the strategic metal nickel will set a record this year of 390,000,000 pounds, Dr. John F. Thompson, chairman of the International Nickel Company of Canada, Ltd., estimated yesterday.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman reserved decision yesterday on an application to increase, by an average of $2.81 a room, the rents in Knickerbocker Village, on Manhattan's lower East Side. He indicated that some increase would be granted.

If he had lived, Joseph Stalin would have been 75 today. The Soviet press is marking today's anniversary by hailing Stalin as the "great continuer of Lenin's cause." There is one aspect of Stalin's career, however, which the Soviet press is not mentioning -- his historic role as the most brutal conqueror of colonies and the creator of the most harshly oppressed colonial system of modern times.
John L. Lewis lost a foothold in the Port of New York yesterday and the American Federation of Labor gained one.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 20 -- Two story purchases by independent producers were announced today. Cornel Wilde, who owns Theodora Productions, bought "Storm Fear," the Clinton Seeley novel. He intends to film it in the summer with himself and Mrs. Wilde, Jean Wallace, playing two of the six leading roles.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 20 -- The Communist party is jubilant over the success of its lawyers in halting for six weeks the West German Government's effort to ban the party.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 20 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture today predicted the 1955 winter wheat crop would be a good deal smaller than usual, but not small enough to materially cut into the huge surplus of some 900 million bushels.
For the fourth successive session, stocks clambered to new highs yesterday. For the third successive session, The New York Times' combined average gained more than 3 points.
Radar and radio patrol cars will replace motorcycles for catching speeders here early next year.
PARIS, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The purse of Roy Ankarah has been held up pending an investigation of his losing performance against the world bantamweight champion, Robert Cohen, in Paris last night.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Toledo, Peoria and Western Railroad, the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and Oscar Gruss Son, member firm of the New York Stock Exchange, have been allowed to intervene in a proposal by nine railroads to buy the Illinois Terminal Railroad Company.

The validity of the New York State harness racing rules was challenged yesterday. This occurred at the hearing on the suspension of nine horsemen and brought a shouted argument that halted proceedings in mid-afternoon.

Johnny Antonelli, who was known last summer as "Milwaukee's gift to the Polo Grounds," was even something more than that. He was just about the best pitcher in the National League in 1954, viewed from any angle, according to the official pitching averages announced yesterday.
Gov. Robert B. Meyner of New Jersey likes the outlook for the Democratic party.

Congregation B'nai Jeshurun, marking its 130th anniversary as the second oldest Jewish congregation in New York, staged a Hanukkah celebration last night in the auditorium of its Community Center at 270 West Eighty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Bureau of the Census reported today that the cotton spinning industry operated during November at 134.6 per cent of capacity, as figured on a two-shift, eighty-hour-week basis.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board has slashed transatlantic mail rates the Government pays to Pan American World Airways.
Stocks went through an inconclusive session yesterday. Volume was about the same as on Monday, more issues rose than fell, and The New York Times' combined average had an inconsequential decline.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Government today set a record initial quota for sugar, fixing the amount of new sugar that may be marketed in the United States next year at 8,200,000 short tons.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Harry J. O'Donnell, who has handled Governor Dewey's press relations for the last two and one-half years, will become research director of the Republican State Committee Jan. 1.
Representatives of three major dairymen's cooperatives completed plans yesterday for a mass meeting of dairymen and officials interested in dairying in the New York milkshed.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today that half the nation's adult population might be jobless in twenty years unless prejudices about hiring older workers were overcome.

ATHENS, Dec. 21 -- Alexis Kyrou, Director General of the Foreign Ministry, said tonight that Greece would protest to Turkey against the "sharp and anti-Greek tone" he asserted had been used by Selim Sarper, Turkish delegate to the United Nations, at the recent General Assembly session.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -- Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia said today the new leaders of the Soviet Union had brought about a definite change in Moscow's domestic and foreign policies.

Winter, with temperatures down to 15 degrees and less, will arrive officially today. It will be a calendar occasion, however, because yesterday brought New York another in the series of frigid foretastes that have preceded the season's official arrival.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Herbert Brownell Jr. appeared today as a defense witness before a Federal judge hearing the Government's criminal suit against the Philadelphia Marine Corporation.

HENRY JAMES' "The Portrait of a Lady" makes a decorous but colorless play. In the stage version by William Archibald it is called "Portrait of a Lady" and it was put on at the refurbished ANTA Theatre last evening. Jennifer Jones plays the leading part.
The aggregate short interest jumped 31,124 shares on the American Stock Exchange between Nov. 15 and Dec. 15, the exchange reported yesterday.
Three leaders of the New York United Service Organizations Defense Fund were cited yesterday for their services in behalf of military and civil defense personnel.
ALBANY, Dec. 21 -- Twenty-eight Dewey Administration appointees were "frozen" today into jobs worth about $145,000 a year.
" THESE things are pleasant to know," says Alan Priest in his "Aspects of Chinese Painting,"* referring to certain features of Chinese painting.

DEBRECEN, Hungary, Dec. 21 -- Matyas Rakosi, first secretary of the Central Committee of the Communist party, was a principal speaker here today as Hungary observed the tenth anniversary of the Parliamentary meeting that followed the ousting of the Nazis.

On Christmas day in this country last year twenty-three persons died in fires in their homes and, over the holiday week-end, the toll rose to eighty-three. A week later, over New Year's, twenty-eight more persons lost their lives in such fires.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 21 -- The Cabinet sent to Parliament today a bill declaring that Hitler's annexation of Austria to Germany "has become without significance."

The proposed Coast Guard system of periodic physical and mental examinations to test a seaman's ability to do his job is an "outright power grab for iron-fisted military control" of this country's 60,000 merchant seamen, according to a seamen's union.

The near-by potato options closed higher and the deferred months were easier yesterday on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Continued liquidation weakened the market, but short covering, new long speculator buying and trade hedge lifting steadied prices.

EAST ST. LOUIS, Ill., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Evan R. Dale, labor leader convicted of recketeering, was sentenced today to fifteen years in prison by a Federal judge who denounced him as a bully and a menace.

DETROIT, Dec. 21 (AP) -- L. L. Colbert, president of Chrysler Corporation, said today that less than a month after introduction of the 1955 line of Chrysler cars 448,000 dealer orders had been received for the new vehicles.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The House Un-American Activities Committee said today that March of Labor might be "an innocuous - sounding publication" but it actually was a Communist front.
The Merritt-Chapman Scott Corporation announced yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission covering its proposed acquisition of three companies.

On snow-sprinkled corners and lots throughout the city yesterday, bundled men paced up and down in front of stacked green islands of balsam fir. The annual Yule tree buying was slowly getting under way.

The tug Philadelphia, latest addition to the Pennsylvania Railroad's "Navy," was previewed yesterday afternoon at Pier 1, Hudson River, preparatory to entering service hauling barges between South Amboy, N. J., and New York Harbor.

CAIRO, Dec. 21 -- One of thirteen defendants in the trial of an alleged Zionist espionage ring here was found dead in his prison cell today. His wrists were slashed and police authorities listed the death as suicide.
Price of cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday closed 4 points lower to 14 points higher than on Monday. The far months showed the most strength.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- A Congressional investigative staff reported today that American Negroes had defeated Moscow's plans to capture the minority group for the Communists.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman announced yesterday that he would appoint Jonathan B. Bingham as secretary to the Governor.

Bob Grim of the New York Yankees has been named the American League rookie of the year for 1954. The pitcher was the overwhelming choice of a twenty-four-man Baseball Writers Association of America committee, whose vote was made known yesterday.
LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Kentucky surged from 7 points behind in eight minutes tonight to beat Utah, 70 -- 65, in a contest between top-ranked collegiate basketball teams.
Miss Molly 'Wheaton Paine was guest of honor at a dinner dance given las't evening in the Star-: light Roof of the Waldorf-Astoria by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Hugh E. Paine' of 1 Beckman Place.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Spanish Ambassador Jose Maria de Areilza, said today that reports of Spanish Government measures to control the Spanish press were based on misunderstanding.
The plan to harness the International Rapids of the St. Lawrence River for power development passed the financing stage yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission ended two weeks of hearings on the disputed Dixon-Yates power contract today.
The attainment of a long-envisioned scientific goal -- a method of amplifying light somewhat as electronic tubes amplify weak electrical impulses -- was demonstrated here yesterday.
A behind-the-scenes controversy led yesterday to the resignation of Joseph J. Traficanti, legislative assistant to Stanley M. Isaacs, City Council minority leader.
Miss Eva Taubner, a secretary with a fighting heart, saved her Christmas money yesterday by slugging it out with a man who was so foolish as to try to rob her.

In the midst of last-minute dinner preparations, the chore of mashing potatoes often requires more time than can easily be allotted to it. As an alternative, we suggest baking and stuffing either white or sweet potatoes sometime ahead and reheating them in a hot oven while the gravy is being made.
NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- The New Rochelle High School football coach was accused today of assaulting a 16-year-old pupil.
" Rubber stamp" charges flew yesterday before the City Council, by a vote of 21 to 1, adopted a record $717,686,653 capital budget for 1955.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The average age of men being drafted in thirty-five states is 21, a survey of state draft directors showed today.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A fierce outcry against the Sassenach Government in London, which has taken the guga off the holiday menu of Gaelic gourmets, has arisen on the island of Lewis, off the northwest coast of Scotland.

I have followed with exceptional interest the comments of your editorial page on the policy of our Government with respect to anti-trust legislation. Dean Arthur Upgren suggests that it might be helpful if the Government, in proceedings, "present the general economic evidence for an industry being sued as well as any indictment."
The Appellate Division ordered new trials yesterday for Michael Clemente, dock boss, and John E. Gleason Jr., former city official, both convicted of perjury.
Harold Wise, 58-year-old board chairman of Macfadden Publications, was found dead yesterday afternoon in the bedroom of his smoked-filled penthouse apartment at 200 Madison Avenue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Contracts for the sale of five more Government-owned synthetic rubber plants to private industry were announced today, subject to approval by Congress.
TORONTO, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- A good year ahead was predicted today by B. S. Vanstone, president of the Bank of Toronto, in his address to the bank's annual meeting.
ROME, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Italy is going all out to lure the Olympic Games to Rome in 1960.
CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Grain futures prices sagged badly today, following a generally firm start. There was no follow-up buying to maintain initial bulges, and long liquidation found a thin market.

A widely representative committee to examine Federal loyalty-security programs is being appointed by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York. The study will be made under a $100,000 grant by the Fund for the Republic, Inc., a Ford Foundation subsidiary.

Reindeer are here for Christmas. We do not mean the fleet-footed creatures that will pull Santa Claus' sleigh Friday night but rather reindeer meat, imported from Norway. It is offered by Joseph in the Washington Market for Yuletide feasting.

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 21 -- The Foreign Office announced today that the Pakistani Government had "extended recognition" to Communist-ruled North Vietnam and the independent States of South Vietnam, Cambodia and Laos in Indochina.
The directors of the Fidelity Union Trust Company elected Roy F. Duke as president yesterday to succeed Horace K. Corbin, who was named chairman of the board and chief executive officer.
Baseball's Willie Mays and golf's Babe Didrikson Zaharias were named yesterday as the male and female athletes of the year for 1954 in the annual year-end polls conducted by The Associated Press.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, Dec. 21 -- His supporters call him "Die Leeu" (the lion). However, South Africa's new Prime Minister Johannes G. Strijdom is acting as placidly as a dove. Statements made by him today contained the following points:
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 -- A 25 per cent seat dividend for members of the San Francisco Stock Exchange was proposed today by the board of governors.
Jackie Gleason Enterprises, the television production company headed by the comedian, will play a major role in the Columbia Broadcasting System's Saturday night schedule next fall.
Social pressures and a pattern set by the Federal Government are nullifying "to an alarming extent" the freedom of speech and of the press, Senator Estes Kefauver charged yesterday.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 21 -- The remaining political prisoners who have not been indicted will be freed this week, the Government announced today.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- A court of chivalry was called today for the first time in 217 years. It decided that a variety theatre had no right to use the armorial bearings of the city of Manchester without its permission.

The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., announced yesterday a demand for wage increases of 17 cents an hour for 34,000 workers who operate the city's subway, elevated, bus and trolley lines. Michael J. Quill, president of the union, asserted that the New York City Transit Authority could put the higher pay scales into effect without increasing the 15-cent fare.
Two new films will arrive at first-run theatres today.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Britain bound herself today to a formal association for the next fifty years with the six-nation European Coal and Steel Community.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- The stock market was subdued today by a seasonal contraction of business before the Christmas holiday. The only really firm groups were rubber, tea and mining shares, particularly South African gold minings.

The future welfare of New York City's hard-pressed school system can be seriously affected by the action that the Board of Education takes, or refuses to take, at its scheduled meeting tomorrow afternoon.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Butchers sold steady to 25 cents higher today, while sows were steady to strong on the livestock market. Salable receipts at 11,000 head fell 5,000 below the advance estimate.

YORK, Pa., Dec. 21 (UP) -- Harold Uhrich, 42 years old, a mechanical engineer and his pilot, Edward Lubischer, 40, formerly of Elizabeth, N. J., were killed today when their plane crashed and exploded.
PARIS, Dec. 21 -- The Paris accords to arm West Germany within the North Atlantic alliance were vigorously denounced today by Jacques Soustelle, long a follower of Gen. Charles de Gaulle.

It does not seem possible that friendly, sane people, in this free and generous land, can be so impatient and intolerant of one another's opinions. Our clergy exhort us to love one another: our intellectuals plead for objectivity and open-mindedness; our lawyers urge an impartial view of the facts.
BONN, Dec. 21 -- West Germany's industrial production has doubled in five years, according to a report issued by the Ministry of Economics.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Administration plans a general review of the Government's statistical gathering activities after the first of the year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Herman M. Greenspun, Las Vegas, Nev., newspaper publisher, said today his indictment on charges of publishing matter "tending to incite murder or assassination" of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy grew from a "conspiracy."

MOSCOW, Dec. 21 -- During the Soviet writers' congress in Moscow favorable mention has been given to the works of several authors who were formerly condemned for ideological deviations and banished from the pages of Soviet publications.
JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Mississippi voters today approved by apparently more than two to one a constitutional amendment designed to continue school segregation.

I have recently enjoyed traveling almost half the distance of the new Thruway (Newburgh to Utica), and although this is certainly a magnificent and sorely needed addition to the state's highway network, its design seems obsolescent and open to serious criticism.

The one-story building at 108-08 Northern Boulevard in Corona, Queens, has been purchased by Martay Co., Inc., wholesaler and distributor of automotive equipment. The property was acquired from Urban Woodcrafts, Inc., in a transaction negotiated by the Greiner-Maltz Company and Charles Richardson as co-brokers.
FRONT ROYAL, Va., Dec. 21 -- President Eisenhower had that "Gettysburg look" in his eyes today.

James L. Bradshaw Jr. has been named assistant general sales manager of the Buick Motor division of General Motors Corporation, Flint, Mich. Edward C. Loppnow has been appointed regional manager of the Southwest sales region.

PARIS, Dec. 18 -- "Well bred" is the term evoked by the subtleties of woolens for next summer. The discretion of pastel coloring in shetlands, fleeces and tweeds for coats is matched by the firmness and restraint of worsteds and alpaca types for suits and dresses.

A hundred volunteers and staff members of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, are expected to "practice what they preach" today by giving blood as a Christmas "gift of life." The blood will be given at the New York Chapter House, Thirty-eighth Street and Lexington Avenue, to the New York Regional Red Cross program.

TORONTO, Dec. 21 (Canadian Press) -- Abitibi Power and Paper Company, Ltd., received $9,838,281 for the 40,000 common shares of Alaska Pine and Cellulose, Ltd., of Vancouver, which recently sold to Rayonier, Inc., of New York.

LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Prime Minister Churchill told the House of Commons today that the Government might recreate the wartime Ministry of Aircraft Production to stimulate lagging jet-fighter and jet-bomber production here.
James Butler, president of the trackless Empire City Racing Association, moved back into thoroughbred racing picture yesterday.

Ed Furgol of Clayton, Mo., the United States open golf champion and recent victor of the Havana invitation tournament, yesterday was named the winner of the Ben Hogan Trophy by the Metropolitan Golf Writers Association. He will receive the award at the annual dinner of the Golf Writers at the Plaza Hotel on Jan. 27.
A stubborn and smoky two-alarm fire wrecked the two upper floors of a four-story building at 628 Eighth Avenue yesterday. It is across the street from the Port of New York Authority Bus Terminal.

TENNIS is supposed to be the most formful of all sports and yet this has been a year of frequent upsets. Take, for example, the four major championships. Mervyn Rose of Australia Whisked away with the Australian crown; Jaroslav Drobny, the bouncing Czech exile, won at Wimbledon; Tony Trabert of the United States captured the French championship, and Vic Seixas, also of the United States, triumphed in our nationals at Forest Hills.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 21 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru declared in Parliament today that India had the most stable political and economic structure of any country in Asia except Communist China.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Some thirty-nine players and coaches of the original Shrine football game will be honored at the thirtieth annual game Jan. 1. One of the players will fly 10,000 miles to attend.

Defeating the United States champion, Arthur B. Bisguier, in the third round last night, Samuel Reshevsky increased his lead to 3 -- 0 in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- Britain was put on notice tonight that there would be a strike on the nationally owned railways after the Christmas holidays unless extraordinary measures were taken.
SYRACUSE, Dec. 21 (AP) -- Cornell toppled Syracuse to its first home loss of the season, 72 -- 62, tonight. Chuck Rolles and Jack Sheehy paced the Big Red victory.
Three bandits were shot by a detective yesterday afternoon while they were attempting to hold up a Harlem apartment that was then being searched in a narcotics raid.

In anticipation of the biggest winter cruise season in a decade, ship operators have added some 3,500 berths to high seas winter vacation schedules. Yet on the basis of current indications some of these extra berths will remain unsold between now and the end of March, unless a considerable improvement develops in some segments of the business.

CHICAGO, Dec. 21 -- Details of the settlement of Sewell L. Avery's suit against the Cadillac-Soo Lumber Company protesting payment of dividends were disclosed today by Mr. Avery's attorney, Robert S. Cushman.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 -- All of Yugoslavia is singing today. The workers and the peasants are singing. The Communist officials, the man in the street, the students, all are singing the songs of George Gershwin and the praises of the cast of the folk opera, "Porgy and Bess," which left this truly heartbroken country this morning.

Anna Cora Mowatt, nineteenth century American actress and author, is the subject of "The Lady of Fashion," a biography by Eric Wollencott Barnes. Mrs. Mowatt was the daughter of one of New York's most prominent families and she became an actress at a time when such a choice made a woman a "social leper."

The death of a 65-year-old man and his invalid wife in a fire caused by explosion of a kerosene heater in the kitchen of their cold-water flat in Brooklyn is tragic new evidence of the need for ridding the city of unsafe methods of heating living quarters. The accident occurred in a four-story frame house.
IN WINTRY gloaming yesterday, 120 mixed voices, richly amplified in the snow-tipped Rockefeller Center canyon, sweetened the early evening with perfectly blended carols.
Roger Campbell of Princeton, the defending champion, was eliminated from the University Club's annual invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament in the quarter-final round yesterday.

Who of us, enamored of Manhattan, does not suffer the pangs of unrealized love? The only one we know is Comdr. Thomas J. Keane. Walking one day back in 1950 from Fulton to Washington Street, Commander Keane was taken with a sudden passion for the island and vowed to cover on foot every mile of its many thoroughfares.

GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 21 -- The Right Rev. James P. De Wolfe, Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Diocese of Long Island, marked the thirty-fifth anniversary of his ordination today by celebrating communion at the Cathedral of the Incarnation.
A NUMBER of art exhibitions, rewarding in one way or another, enliven Christmas week in New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The Defense Department said today the combined efforts of the military services were being devoted to studies of "earth satellites."

The building containing seventy apartments and five stores at 2364 Tiebout Avenue in the Bronx has been sold by Kern, Inc., to the 2364 Realty Corporation, represented by L. Greenspan, lawyer. The property is assessed at $340,000 and was sold subject to a first mortgage of $238,000.

Scarcely a day passes but what figures make their appearance showing changes that have taken place over the previous week, the previous month or the previous quarter in some particular "series" of economic indicators. When, as will eventually be the case, these figures are all brought together and assigned their proper weights, we shall know what has been happening in terms of the business cycle.

The De Vilbiss Company has authorized payment of a 25 per cent stock dividend on Jan. 24 to holders of record on Jan. 7, it was announced yesterday by Howard P. De Vilbiss, president. Directors also declared a quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share on the common, payable on Feb. 7.

The Wolfpack of North Carolina State and the Huskies of Connecticut continued unbeaten last night at Madison Square Garden. A 76-75 overtime victory over the St. John's quintet gave North Carolina State a 9-0 record for the season. Then Connecticut sped to a 6-0 mark with a 90-79 triumph over Manhattan.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 21 -- Warner Brothers will sponsor the screen comeback of Mario Lanza in a film adaptation of the James M. Cain story "Serenade."

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 21 -- The Council of the Socialist International, which concluded its two-day meeting here today, issued a strongly worded protest against the persecution of Czech Socialists by the Czechoslovak Government.

LONDON, Dec. 15 -- It is becoming increasingly difficult in this welfare state to dispense many of the 15,000 ancient and narrowly specific Christmas bequests Englishmen seem to enjoy leaving when they die.

" The Tenor," a very bad one-act comic opera by Hugo Weisgall, had its first performance by Opera '55 at the Provincetown Playhouse last evening. The libretto, by Karl Shapiro and John R. Allen, is based on "Der Kammersaenger," by Frank Wedekind.

NEWARK, Dec. 21 -- A charge that the American Federation of Labor used the facilities of the bi-state Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor to further organizational waterfront drives was made here today.

The three-story loft building at 1467 Myrtle Avenue in Brooklyn has been sold by Sebastian and Anthony DeSalvo to Louis, Nat, Joseph and Irving Hollander, doing business as the Metal Novelty Manufacturing Company. Title was insured by the Title Guarantee and Trust Company.
A railroad conductor spent 72 cents of his own money yesterday on behalf of a commuter who had forgotten her package of unstamped, unmailed Christmas cards.

MADRID, Dec. 21 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco has reached an understanding with Don Juan, pretender to the Spanish throne, generally expected to pave the way for an eventual restoration of the monarchy.
THE reports seem to be in on last season's salmon fishing. According to those we have received, embracing even some of the more "fabulous" rivers, the fishing left much to be desired.
EUREKA, Calif., Dec. 21 -- A violent earthquake shook northern California and southern Oregon today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Secretary of State John Foster Dulles indicated today that aggression in Western Europe would be met with tactical atomic weapons.
WASHINGTON, -- Dec. 21 (AP) -- Following is the text of Secretary of State Dulles' statement today on the recent North Atlantic Council meeting in Paris:

Helen Hayes returns to the New York stage at 8 o'clock tonight in "What Every Woman Knows" at the City Center. Members of her entourage will include such experienced performers as Kent Smith, John Cromwell, Betsy von Furstenberg, Viola Roache, Philip Bourneuf and William Lanteau.

MADRID, Dec. 21 -- The official censorship bureau prohibited today the sale in Spain of the Dec. 16 and Dec. 18 issues of The New York Times presumably because they contained news displeasing to Government policy.

Sixteen domestic producers of collapsible metal containers announced yesterday the formation of the Collapsible Tube Manufacturers Council "to unite the thinking and energies of the industry in promoting the important packaging role" played by their products.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 21 (Reuters) -- Australia ended today's play in its match with England with eight wickets standing and needing 151 runs to win and become two up in the five-game series.

PARKERSBURG, W. Va., Dec. 21 (AP) -- An order clearing the way for the sale of the Follansbee Steel Corporations physical assets to Frederick W. Richmond was issued today by Federal Judge Herbert S. Boreman.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Two leaders in the new Democratic Congress said today the Administration would be asked to justify its new military manpower cuts.
Professors became waiters and took orders from students yesterday in the cafeteria of City College.

A step in the right direction is always worth taking, even if it be a short one. The British have now agreed to cooperate in some ways with the European Coal and Steel Community. There will be a permanent "Council of Association" with four British members and four from the six countries which belong to the Schuman Plan (France, West Germany, Italy, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg).
CLEVELAND, Dec. 21 -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard was convicted this afternoon of murder in the second degree.
RIDGEWOOD, N. J., Dec. 21 -- Bomb scares here emptied two public schools of 2,700 pupils for an hour early this afternoon.
TRENTON, Dec. 21 -- Ransford J. Abbott, former State Highway Commissioner, was discharged today as executive director of the New Jersey Highway Authority.

The Mennen Company of Morristown, N. J., is adding a new twist to its advertising on television. The company, seventy-five years in business, uses all media to promote its line of men's toiletries and baby items.
Four vice presidents have been elected by the General Cable Corporation, effective on Jan. 1, it was announced yesterday by James R. MacDonald, president.
Indoors, outdoors, all around the town, New Yorkers did their Yuletide best yesterday to make Christmas feel at home here.

GLASGOW, Scotland, Wednesday, Dec. 22 (AP) -- At least seven ships sent out calls for help early today as the fiercest winds of this stormy year howled across the North Sea and the British Isles. A Royal Air Force airfield registered one gust at 104 miles an hour.
GARDEN CITY, L. I., Dec. 21 -- The Air Force has an immediate need for accountants to fill positions at its European bases.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 21 (AP) -- Brig. Gen. Francis Howard, Camp Gordon commander, has upheld the Court-Martial conviction of an officer accused of cruelty to trainees.
THE news department of the National Broadcasting Company goes to the head of the class for its Sunday evening documentary on Ernest Hemingway. It was excellent radio, nothing less.
The Dana Corporation and its subsidiaries had a net profit of $2,059,910 in the quarter ended Nov. 30, against $2,397,478 in the similar quarter last year, it reported yesterday.

Domestic makers of rubber products consumed 110,376 long tons of new rubber last month, a decline of nearly 3 per cent from the previous month but an increase of more than 7 per cent from November last year, The Rubber Manufacturers Association reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- Refugee representatives of the 80,000,000 inhabitants of East European nations held captive by the Soviet Union exchanged Christmas greetings and hopes for freedom in the future today with John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold is expected to reach Peiping the first week in January. He is to negotiate there on the release of the United Nations prisoners of the Korean war, including eleven United States airmen imprisoned as spies.
