WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The St. Lawrence Seaway was expected today to lead to "a vast expansion of wealth" in the United States and Canada.
The first-year class of Public School 90 in Manhattan went without its cookies the other day so a crippled child might have something more essential -- a proper pair of shoes.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 21 -- A spokesman for the Eastman Kodak Company said tonight that there would be an immediate reduction in the price of Kodachrome and Kodacolor films as a result of today's consent decree.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 21 -- A check for $28,571,428.58 to aid refugees was turned over today by Gen. J. Lawton Collins, President Eisenhower's special envoy to South Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The scheduled airlines have asked the Defense Department to investigate their complaints of questionable practices by non-scheduled lines bidding for military business.

The Times of Dec. 15 mentioned and pictured the frantic search, partly successful, partly fruitless, of a task force from Albany's State Historian's office seeking lost documents which had through error been condemned for scrap and maceration. Some, unfortunately, have become pulp, others were recovered after much backbreaking toil.

JACKSON, Miss., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Dixie Conference, embracing the athletic programs of six colleges, disbanded today. Operational difficulties and limited competition between members were cited as the reasons for the move.

Don't be unduly alarmed if things in general seem a little below par today. There is nothing really wrong and you may not even notice the difference, but December 22 happens to be the low point of the year for the northern hemisphere.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 21 -- Reports that are gaining credence in Belgrade indicate that the Yugoslav Communist League is about to cleanse its ranks of several high officials who were involved in last year's Djilas affair.
Those who receive presents of nuts for Christmas, as well as those who give them, might bear in mind some tips on storing them.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (N. A. A. C. P.) today asked the Navy to repudiate the condition printed on tickets for the Sugar Bowl game restricting attendance to Caucasians only.
LONDON, Dec. 21 -- When does a physician's obligation to preserve the secrets of his patients conflict with his duty to disclose information to prevent harm or danger to others?

MIAMI, Dec. 21 (UP) -- The North team today named Alan Ameche, Wisconsin's All-America fullback, and Frank Varrichione, Notre Dame tackle, as co-captains for the annual All-Star college football game in the Orange Bowl Christmas night.

The Soviets have now pulled out all stops in their thunder against the free world and are well along on a campaign of bluster and blackmail without precedent in recent years. Within the past few weeks they have sent nearly a score of formal notes to more than a dozen nations, upbraiding some for not attending the Moscow "security" conference, threatening others with annulment of wartime alliances.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (UP) -- Senator Hubert H. Humphrey demanded today that the Secretary of Agriculture tell Congress why he removed Wolf Ladejinsky as United States agricultural attache in Japan.

The New York City Housing Authority has postponed until today the scheduled sale of $28,855,000 of six-month notes to further the temporary financing of two state-aided projects, Carver Houses in Manhattan and Forest Houses in the Bronx.

PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Stalinist methods are again asserting influence in Soviet policy. Moscow's recent notes to the French and British Governments are far more reminiscent of the late dictator's brutal tactics than of Malenkov's suave "new look." The Russians again threaten rather than blandish.
VIENNA, Dec. 21 -- The Soviet High Commissioner charged today that the United States was illegally expanding its occupation zone in Austria and extending the "aggressive" North Atlantic Treaty bloc.

Many appealingly fresh ideas brighten southern resort fashions. There's the jumper shirt with mock inset blouse, worn over shorts and belted at the waist. And coat dresses take to miniature form for play, cut way above the knees and worn over brief panties.
Laurance D. Sibley has been appointed vice president of the combustion control division of Electronics Corporation of America, Cambridge, Mass.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 (AP) -- A House of Representatives committee said today there should be changes in the law that, in thousands of cases, provided for a serviceman's survivors receiving bigger benefit payments than he earned while alive.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 21 -- The Eastman Kodak Company agreed today to end color film-processing practices alleged to be monopolistic.

A recent heavy run of imports may be causing headaches to custodians of Colombia's foreign exchange reserves, but to employes of the Government's exchange control board in Bogota, the development is something of a break.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 21 (AP) -- The Duntreath Farm's Van Crosby, inactive for fifteen months, staged an impressive comeback at Tropical Park today as he turned back seven seasoned opponents in the seventh and best race of the chilly afternoon.
The following book, published recently, may be of special interest to parents of mentally retarded children:
The New York Rangers will be seeking their first victory since Nov. 28 when they meet the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League clash at Madison Square Garden tonight.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 (Reuters) -- Bullet-like bowling by Frank Tyson today led England to a 38-run victory over Australia in their second test cricket match, leveling the five-game series at one each.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 2 -- In the absence of Marshal Tito, who is in India, his Communist organization appears to be on the verge of a new internal battle. Communist leaders have quietly reopened the Djilas case. It is said that further liberalization of Yugoslavia's domestic political policy is at stake.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- A new type of investment corporation intended to stimulate lagging private capital investment will be established in India in January. It will have backing from private interests in the United States, Britain and India, the World Bank and the Foreign Operations Administration.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Tidewater, an unpredictable colt owned by Abe Levinson of New York, outran eight clever sprinters in the featured seventh race at Tropical Park today.

Plans for altering the five-story private dwelling at 57 East Eighty-second Street into eight apartments and offices for doctors were announced yesterday by Samuel J. Landau, broker, who reported the sale of the house for Ira Senz to a client of Benjamin Herskowitz of Siegel Mark, attorneys.

Commodity futures prices were regular yesterday on the New York exchanges. Cocoa, sugar and soybean oil moved mixed; potatoes, coffee, rubber, zinc and tin led higher, and wool, hides, cottonseed oil and burlap closed lower.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The Soviet threat to the free world is undiminished, but the unity of the West provides a basis for negotiation if Moscow wishes it, Sir Anthony Eden declared today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The Army's germ warfare authority said today it would be "an act of barbarism" to deny American troops the use of biological weapons in a war.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- New members of the Senate and the House of Representatives will not have to worry about what to do when the Eighty-fourth Congress convenes at noon, Wednesday, Jan. 5.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The National Union of Railwaymen, the largest organization of employes on the nationalized railroads, began preparations today for the country-wide strike it has called for midnight, Jan. 9.

The Firestone Tire and Rubber Company had a net income of $40,509,944 in the fiscal year year ended on last Oct. 31, compared with $46,748,971 earned in the preceding fiscal year. The respective earnings are equal to $10.04 and $11.77 a share.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- The State Mental Hygiene Council said today the present policy on releasing mental patients from state hospitals was "fundamentally sound and conscientiously administered."
Samuel Reshevsky, the leader in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament, was held to a draw in the fourth round by Donald Byrne at the Manhattan Chess Club last night after a five-hour session.

LEXINGTON, Ky., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Kentucky brushed off a La Salle comback attempt tonight to beat the Explorers, 63 -- 54, and win the final of its own invitation tournament for the second straight year.

ATAQ FORT, Western Aden Protectorate, Dec. 15 -- British air and ground forces here are engaged in almost daily action. They are combating sniping tribesmen under conditions reminiscent of the North-West Frontier campaigns in British India.

DETROIT, Dec. 22 (UP) -- The former world middleweight and welterweight boxing king, Sugar Ray Robinson, got back into the good graces of boxing officials today by signing to meet Joe Rindone in a ten-round bout at Olympia Jan. 5.

Many festal celebrations have been scheduled for Christmas Eve and will be attended by thousands of devout Christians. They will include the usual pageantry of services by candlelight. The customary midnight masses will be held for Roman Catholics.

NORWALK, Conn., Dec. 22 -- The Veterans of Foreign Wars of Fairfield County has come out against art works that "any known Communists or subversives" offer for display in public buildings. The move stems from a proposal by a grandmother, who calls herself a pacifist, to paint four murals for a new school here.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Loyola of New Orleans paid tribute to an assistant coach killed in an auto accident today and scored a 72-66 victory tonight over Illinois, the nation's third-ranked basketball team.

The National City Bank of New York was the indicated buyer yesterday of $28,855,000 of six-months notes of the New York City Housing Authority for the financing of two state-aided low-rent projects, Carver Houses in Manhattan and Forest Houses, the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Department of Agriculture announced today that Wolf Ladejinsky failed to meet "security requirements" to continue as agricultural attache in Tokyo.
Misfortune overtook the Milwaukee Braves on a number of counts last summer to affect their pitching and batting. Defensively, however, they still were the best club in their league.

CAIRO, Dec. 22 -- All the hotels in Egypt are booked virtually solid through the end of March, Mohyeddin Shazly, Director of Tourism, said today. International travel agencies had informed him they had been obliged to turn down thousands of overflow requests for reservations.
A large one-stop discount shopping center is expected to begin operation on Long Island early in March.

For accomplishments in medical rehabilitation Dr. Howard A. Rusk, chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of New York University, received yesterday the third annual national AMVETS award.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Hogs lost 25 to 50 cents in fairly active trading today. Salable receipts at 13,000 head were 3,000 more than expected. Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:

IRVINGTON - ON - HUDSON, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- A mother of three was killed by a shotgun blast tonight as she sat in a chair beside a lighted Christmas tree. Her husband was arrested on a charge of second-degree murder.

Two new films open today at first-run theatres. At the Astor is "20,000 Leagues Under the Sea," Walt Disney's film version of the Jules Verne adventure story. Kirk Douglas, James Mason, Paul Lukas and Peter Lorre head the cast of the Cinema-Scope, color production.

Directors of the New York Telephone Company yesterday elected to the board George Lyon Hinman, senior partner in the Binghamton, N. Y., law firm of Hinman, Howard Kattell, John D. Dodd, assistant vice president, was at same time appointed vice president of the company's operating staff.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- New storms roared on the battered coasts of Northern Europe tonight while many rescue craft searched for nineteen seamen feared lost on the 2,000-ton Belgian freighter Henri Deweert. Another vessel, the 1,317-ton Swedish freighter Petra, believed lost with twenty-one men in last night's big blow, was located early tonight by search craft and her crew was reported unhurt.

A color presentation of Franz Lehar's "The Merry Widow" will be televised from 5 to 6:30 P. M. on Sunday by the Columbia Broadcasting System network as a feature of the "Omnibus" program. Patrice Munsell will sing the title role and Eugene Ormandy will conduct the performance.

An increase of 1,125,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks last week was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end they amounted to 151,778,000 barrels, compared with 150,653,000 a week earlier and 151,490,000 a year earlier.
TUNIS, Tunisia, Dec. 22 -- The political atmosphere here is charged with apprehension as the negotiations in Paris on the basis for Tunisian home rule reach a critical phase.

WHETHER it is Helen Hayes serving James M. Barrie or the other way round, is an unsolvable problem. She and "What Every Woman Knows" are perfectly matched. As put on at the City Center last evening, the sentimental play she has acted several times before is still ideally suited to her modesty and gleaming style of comedy.
The holiday migration is expected to begin building up at transportation centers and on the highways today.
GENEVA, Dec. 22 -- The Geneva trade conference adjourned today for Christmas in an atmosphere lacking in holiday cheer.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 22 -- Admiral Arthur W. Radford arrived here by plane today to get an on-the-spot "appreciation of the situation" in South Vietnam from Gen. J. Lawton Collins.

THE cold weather has brought excellent duck shooting to most of the Long Island bays, and has improved the bags on the Rhode Island and Connecticut shore of Long Island Sound, as well as on Barnegat Bay.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 -- A 10-cent toll on the Northern State Parkway and two similar tolls on the Taconic State Parkway are under consideration by a special state commission.

Because of conflicting applications by the Metropolitan Jockey Club and the Empire City Racing Association, the New York Racing Commission deferred action yesterday on the allotment of thoroughbred racing dates for 1955.
MOSCOW, Dec. 22 -- U. V. Yusupov, Premier of the Uzbek Soviet Republic, has been subjected to extremely severe criticism by the Communist party leadership.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A Public Health Service officer who was dismissed for undisclosed reasons two years ago has been ordered reinstated to his job by court action.
LONDON, Dec. 22 -- Despite mounting criticism in Parliament, Prime Minister Churchill again refused today to order a Government inquiry into protracted delays in Britain's military aircraft build-up.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Senate Democratic hierarchy will proceed only slowly and carefully in offering counter-proposals to the Eisenhower legislative program.

Peter Gussow, a Manhattan manufacturer, is a man who practices liberality the year round -- not just at Christmas. Yesterday the police reported that Mr. Gussow's generosity had backfired. Jewelry and furs valued at $30,000 had been stolen from his home, together with a 1952 Cadillac sedan.
The American Civil Liberties Union yesterday urged a Congressional study of the "investigative practices involved" in a report critical of tax-exempt foundations.

The Appellate Division has upheld two lower court rulings denying motions by Walter Winchell and others to dismiss a $1,525,000 libel suit brought by The New York Post and its editor, James A. Wechsler, it was learned yesterday.

The Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences and the American Physical Society each presented a bronze plaque to Columbia University yesterday in appreciation of the university's role in the founding and continuing activities of the two organizations.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The United States and Panama announced agreement today on a new Canal Zone treaty.
STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Swedish housewives promise to break all records this year with their purchases of pigs' heads, ham, sausage, lutfisk and other delicacies for Christmas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 2 (UP) -- The Government signed contracts today for the sale of all but six of its remaining rubber factories today.
BERLIN, Dec. 22 -- The East German Interior Ministry announced today that the former head of West Germany's counter intelligence service had sought asylum in the East and had been turned down.
Lewis Burton, the vice president and general manager of Yonkers Raceway, yesterday gave the track's version of the dispute that led to the delay of the second race there last Oct. 30.
TROMSO, Norway, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Norwegian authorities announced today they had demanded the Soviet Union return herds of wandering reindeer that have strayed across the Iron Curtain border.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The Government moved today to bring 41,000 overseas Federal jobs into the competitive Civil Service system by the end of 1955.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 -- Three million "Liberty head" silver dollars, valued in numismatists' catalogues at $2 to $17 each, were placed in circulation this week. They were released inadvertently by the United States Mint here.

Christmas turkeys, chickens and ducks all cost less than they did last year. The city's Department of Markets reported yesterday that chains selling dressed turkeys last year at 57 cents a pound were offering them this year at 43 to 51 cents a pound.

The Adam Hat Stores, now under the management of Harold N. Leitman, are making plans for an extensive advertising campaign next year. Current advertising, making use of full-page copy in metropolitan newspapers on the slogan, "The Smart Eve Gives an Adam," is paving the way for still more of a splash after the holidays are over.

PITTSBURGH, Thursday, Dec. 23 -- A DC-3 chartered by the Army to fly twenty-three soldiers home for Christmas crash-landed in the Monongahela River last night. At least twenty of the twenty-eight aboard -- who included five crew members -- were saved.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 21 -- The main task of the Prime Ministers of Indonesia, Pakistan, India, Ceylon and Burma when they meet in Bogor near here next week will be to settle the difficult problem of whom to invite to a projected African-Asian conference.
EUREKA, Calif., Dec. 22 -- The possibility of a water famine was held out today to residents of Eureka after yesterday's earthquake.

The Spanish monarchy is getting like the Greek calends. It never materializes. In theory, Spain right now is a monarchy -- but she has no monarch. Generalissimo Franco has played a cat-and-mouse game, first with the sons of Alfonso XIII, especially Don Juan, and now with the grandson, Don Juan Carlos.

PARIS, Dec. 22 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France appealed to a confused and hesitant National Assembly today for a large majority for the Paris accords to arm West Germany. He said ratification by a small majority would have the same disadvantages as rejection.

CHICAGO, Dec. 22 -- Wheat futures scored an impressive rally today, although at the start the market was a little lower following yesterday's sell-off. Buying was induced by the fact the Commodity Credit Corporation raised its selling price of red winter wheat 2 cents a bushel.

Cellars and stores were flooded yesterday and street traffic was disrupted when a water main burst at Amsterdam Avenue and 125th Street. Property damage was estimated at $100,000. The sixty-inch main broke at 1:40 A. M.
ROME, Dec. 22 -- The Paris agreements arming West Germany and establishing the Western European Union are expected to be ratified by the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow by a sizable majority.
The cotton futures market on the New York cotton Exchange was quiet yesterday, easing 1 to 8 points on active months.

THIS morning's poem is by H. Faber, the noted belles-lettrist and war correspondent, who views all pointing with pride with alarm and particularly deplores many of the season's choices of outstanding books of the year:
The Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., proposed yesterday designation of an arbitrator whose decisions would be "final and binding" in disputes with the New York City Transit Authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The statistics of the Nov. 2 election compiled by The Associated Press expand the warning the voters gave in 1952 to the professional politicians and party managers. This can be summarized as: "Don't depend any more on political ancestor worship or other guides to our previous behavior."
Brandeis University's basketball team, paced by Roger Morgan and Jim Houston, trounced Brooklyn College, 104 -- 60, on the Kingsmen's court last night. Morgan and Houston scored 24 points each.

The first general-trucking pension checks for thirty-four retired teamsters were presented yesterday. Both employer and union spokesmen hailed the ceremony as the beginning of a new era of peace in the trucking industry.

For many months it has been evident that the federal loyalty-security program has not been working out very satisfactorily. The nation must be protected from subversion; but the individual must also be protected from infringement of his rights as a free American, and the Government's own eyes and ears must be protected from any blind insistence on conformity or adherence to a "party line."

The Rangers were held to a tie by the Detroit Red Wings in the National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. Goals by Glen Skov and Marty Pavelich of the visitors matched tallies registered by Bob Chrystal and Edgar Laprade in the 2-to-2 contest that was witnessed by a crowd of 8,630.

The fifty-fifth annual bird count of the National Audubon Society will be held in the United States, Canada and Alaska during the Christmas-New Year's holiday week. At various times between Dec. 25 and Jan. 2, 8,000 "birders" will cover assigned areas of North America to count and identify the wild birds they see.

The first-degree murder indictment against Robert Trachtenberg, 16-year-old Brooklyn high school student, was dismissed yesterday by Kings County Judge Hyman Barshay on the motion of the youth's attorney, Lloyd Paul Stryker.
HOLLYWOOD, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A television appeal to help expand a Negro school in a small Mississippi community has brought an estimated $400,000 in a week.
One policeman was cleared and decision was reserved in the case of another yesterday after a departmental trial resulting from the alleged passing of a bribe by a motorist in Brooklyn.
This port's 3,500 tugboat men have asked for a 25-cent hourly wage increase in presenting a demand pattern that departs radically from the practice of past years.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 22 -- Germany's six major economic research institutes have warned Germany that its pace of development, which has brought about the so-called "German miracle" of recovery, should be checked.

BOSTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Chief Justice Elijah Adlow of the Boston Municipal Court conducted a closed inquest today into the boxing death Dec. 12 of Edward Sanders, a Navy enlisted man. Sanders was knocked out in a Boston Garden fight the night before.

Effective Jan. 1, John P. Mansfield, vice president of the Chrysler Corporation and president of its Plymouth division, will become a director of the corporation. James C. Brady, a director, will then become a member of the finance committee.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The White House Christmas season opened today.

For the third consecutive week, electric power production last week reached a new high. The Edison Electric Institute reported it at 9,909,000,000 kilowatt hours. In the preceeding week it was 9,846,000,000, and it was 8,896,000,000 in the week ended Dec. 19, 1953.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Col. Rogelio Cruz Wer, former head of Guatemalan Civil Guard under the Communist-influenced Arbenz Government, surrendered himself at the Federal District Penitentiary today to face extradition proceedings.
The first concert in the third season of the Bennington Composers Conference Series took place last night at the Lexington Avenue Y. M. Y. W. H. A.

The Automatic Canteen Company disclosed plans yesterday for buying 262,500 shares, or 52 per cent, of the common stock of the Rowe Corporation for "nearly $4,000,000." The shares are those of Robert Z. Greene, president of Rowe, and his associates.

If 8-month-old Ida, a pretty baby, were your child, wouldn't you give her the patient and loving care that the doctors say can correct her deformed left foot? Wouldn't you see to it that Ida had the correct remedial exercises, the special shoe she will need when she begins to walk? Of course you would -- if she were your child and you were her parents.
John Foster Dulles, Secretary of State, contradicted Charles E. Wilson, Secretary of Defense, in his press conference Tuesday and then indulged in a lengthy discussion of military policy.
ALBANY, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The president of the State Civil Service Commission said today that no political people were frozen into jobs under yesterday's order.

WESTFIELD, N. J., Dec. 22 -- A war veteran who had been building a house here for his family for the last eight months died last night at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield, of injuries he received when he fell off a ladder in the uncompleted residence.
With almost six weeks to go before the end of its fiscal year, Stern Brothers yesterday surpassed its sales for the entire 1953 fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The great tondo of the "Adoration of the Magi" by Fra Angelico and Fra Filippo Lippi was placed on view here yesterday at the National Gallery of Art.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The American Council on Education said today there was an "ever present danger" that the Government would use its security program to dictate the choice of personnel in schools and colleges.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- The threat of a railway strike after the turn of the year caused widespread declines in the securities markets here today, some of them rather sharp. Though industrials steadied in the afternoon, Government funds were still falling at the close.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The United States non-playing captain, Bill Talbert, today predicted a 5-0 American victory in the Davis Cup challenge round against Australia next week.

Eugene Haynes, pianist, played a debut recital at Town Hall last evening. A product of the Juilliard School, where he studied with Katherine Bacon, Mr. Haynes also studied in Europe with Nadia Boulanger. He was a recipient of the Morris Loeb prize at Juilliard and has appeared as soloist with the American Youth and St. Louis Symphony Orchestras.

The Teachers Guild Associates wishes to congratulate The Times on its editorial of Dec. 20. You have dealt with the filling of the two vacancies caused by the resignations of George A. Timone and Arthur Levitt.
TOKYO, Thursday, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Moscow radio, in a broadcast to Japan, said last night the Soviet Union "would be willing to consider normalizing relations with Japan with concrete proposals.''

A LATE entry in the let's-do-something-for-racing sweepstakes, young Jim Butler, has demonstrated a surprising burst of speed. The dynamic and personable head of the Empire City Racing Association the other day offered a new plan for modernizing the New York racing structure and his friendly rivals in the sweepstakes were too startled yesterday to figure out whether he'll keep winging to the wire or fold fast in the homestretch.
As prospects of their own Merry Christmas loomed large, scores of children paused to reflect on their own good fortune and sent messages and gifts for the Neediest yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- President Eisenhower was pictured today as much interested in the idea of "exporting brain power" to underdeveloped nations under an American private enterprise program.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 -- Defense attorneys were busy today with details of their fight to obtain a reversal of the second-degree murder conviction of Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- West Coast shipowners appealed to the Secretary of Labor today to help bring peace to the shipping industry.

The steel inventory reduction that took place this year will result in a closer relationship between steel consumption and production during 1955, C. M. White, president of the Republic Steel Corporation, said yesterday in a year-end statement.

The Isbrandtsen Company, Inc., one of the largest unsubsidized American steamship companies, has filed suit in Federal Court against the Government to recover $225,000. The company contends the Federal Maritime Board overcharged it that amount for charter hire on Government-owned vessels.
A youthful bandit held up a hotel off Fifth Avenue last night while the police were looking for him in another hotel across the street.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 22 (AP) -- Dr. Sheppard was safe from the electric chair almost from the first, a juror said today.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation finished negotiations today for the purchase of the steel warehouse business of W. J. Holliday Co., Inc., of Indianapolis and Hammond, Ind.
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 22 (AP) -- A sister of Dr. Charles Laughead, former Michigan State College physician, today petitioned the courts to declare him and his wife, Lillian, mentally ill.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 22 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold said today that he was not going to Peiping to "beg anybody for anything." The question of freeing the prisoners of war in Communist Chinese jails is the item on the agenda, he explained.

Eighty-one staff members and volunteers of the New York Chapter, American Red Cross, gave blood yesterday at the Chapter House, Lexington Avenue and Thirty-eighth Street. Many more of the Red Cross workers are scheduled to be donors in a Christmas "gift of life" gesture in the holiday season.

The City Planning Commission approved four possible sites yesterday for the proposed $7,700,000 building for the Fashion Institute of Technology. All are in the area west of Seventh Avenue between Twenty-seventh and Fifty-third Streets.

LONDON, Dec. 22 -- John Clarence, 27-year-old former convict and former British soldier, was sentenced today to five years imprisonment for obtaining and recording secret military information for the Soviet authorities.
The Dodgers and Yankees each came up with a contract signer yesterday in the over-all campaign to keep as many of the athletes as possible happy over the holidays.
The Maritime Administration has again changed its policy on the transfer of "distressed" American-flag ship tonnage to foreign flag.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 22 -- Walter Wanger's production plan for next year underwent a change today when the producer closed negotiations for the purchase of rights to "The Body Snatchers," the magazine serial by Jack Finney.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Securities and Exchange Commission started a new study today to devise a United States-Canadian program to curb fraudulent offerings of Canadian securities to investors in this country.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Foremost Dairies, Inc., announced today it had entered into agreements for the purchase of 65,000 to 70,000 additional shares of common stock of Philadelphia Dairy Products Company and for acquisition of the assets of Blue Moon Foods, Inc., Thorp, Wis., including its subsidiary, June Dairy Products, Inc.
Headwinds over the Atlantic are narrowing the chances of spending Christmas at home for thousands of inbound travelers.

TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner signed into law today a measure permitting sixty-five New Jersey municipalities to continue under rent control until June 30, 1956. The present control law, which contains a local option clause, expires Dec. 31.

AUSTWELL, Tex., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Three whooping cranes are missing. The United States Fish and Wildlife Service said it could find only twenty-one in the 47,000-acre winter refuge here on the Texas Gulf Coast. That is three less than last year's total.

Mr: and Mrs.' Laurafice B. Rockefeller of 834 Fifth Avenue e and Pocantico .Hills,, Tarrytown, N. Y., gave a 'dinner dance last night in the Rainbow Room to introduce to" society thcir daugh-i ter, Miss Laura Spelman Rockefeller.
Announcement that the Kingdom of Belgium has completed arrangements here for raising $50 millions for the modernization of its inland waterways is interesting in a number of respects.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 22 (UP) -- Governor-elect George M. Leader's incoming administration will review the virtually scrapped plan proposed by the Interstate Commission on the Delaware River Basin, known as Incodel.
ROME, Dec. 22 -- Pope Pius XIII has urged Chinese Roman Catholics to resist attempts to enlist their support for a national, schismatic Catholic church of China.

The McGraw Electric Company has purchased the business, excluding real estate, of International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation's Coolerator division for an undisclosed price. This was announced jointly yesterday by Alfred Bersted, McGraw vice president, and Stanley Luke, Coolerator president.
Bowing to the request of many civic groups, the Board of Education has postponed today's scheduled election of a new president.
Time cannot wither nor custom stale the infinite variety of the casserole, which represents an easy method of cooking that is particularly valued during the busy Christmas holidays.

The American Christian Palestine Committee letter of Dec. 14, in its answer to Ambassador Kamal Abdul Rahim, decries the proposed shipment of arms to Arab countries as an unwarranted act of favoritism likely to increase Arab-Israeli tensions. This is a good time to examine the record and see in what way past United States behavior has affected this deep-seated Middle East antagonism.
Fire Commissioner Edward F. Cavanagh Jr. established a new administrative set-up in his department yesterday and demanded complete cooperation from all ranks.

The transition of the Griesedieck Company from a brewer to an investing concern seemed likelier yesterday. In St. Louis Edward D. Jones, president, revealed details of a plan to satisfy dissident stockholders. A meeting will be called soon to discuss proposals to buy the common for $19.20 a share from holders who do not want to go along into the investing field.

An issue of $88,000,000 of toll bridge revenue bonds to finance the construction of the Calumet Skyway, to link Chicago with the Indiana state line, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate of 101 investment houses. The group is headed by Blyth Co., Inc., and John W. Clarke, Inc.
DETROIT, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Harold Johnson of Philadelphia, gained a ten-round decision tonight over Marty Marshall of Detroit.

The head of the house at long last has a chopping block. It stands at the rear of the yard near the sawbuck, massive and heavy. It took a machine to get it there, and nothing on earth now can move it. It stands waiting whatever use the head of the house will make of it, and, in truth, the head has not yet decided.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 15, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

"Black-Eyed Susan," a new comedy by A. B. Shiffrin, opens at the Playhouse tonight at 8 with Vincent Price starred. The production has been sponsored by Gordon W. Pollock in association with Everett Hart and James Goodman.

Benjamin Heckscher, a Harvard sophomore, won the eighteenth annual University Club invitation intercollegiate squash racquets tournament yesterday. He defeated Oliver Stafford of Williams, 15 -- 4, 17 -- 16, 17 -- 14, in the final round.

TORONTO, Dec. 22 (Canadian Press) -- The shareholders of the Dominion Bank approved today a proposal for amalgamation with the Bank of Toronto. Similar action had been taken yesterday by the stockholders of the Bank of Toronto.

FORT MYERS, Fla., Dec. 22 (UP) -- Connie Mack, still brokenhearted over the departure of his beloved Athletics from Philadelphia to Kansas City, will observe his ninety-second birthday without fanfare tomorrow.
A "German Phrase Book" for G. I.'s helped save the day yesterday as the famed Vienna Choir Boys met the St. Thomas Episcopal Church Choir to exchange Christmas greetings.

Directors of the McQuay-Norris Manufacturing Company have authorized payment of a 20 per cent stock dividend on the common stock on March 1, it was announced yesterday. The previously declared 25-cent, quarterly cash dividend will be paid on Feb. 1.
Isn't science wonderful? We carry our mail from coast to coast at supersonic speed, and when it gets to New York City it goes by snail-back.

ROME, N. Y., Dec. 22 (AP) -- Martin Levine, 29-year-old civilian electronics engineer, was cleared and reinstated to his job at Griffis Air Force Base today. He said he was suspended Nov. 23, 1953, on charges of Communist leanings and violation of security regulations.
BERN, Switzerland, Dec. 22 (Reuters) -- Rodolphe Rubattel, Swiss President, accused the United States today of having prejudiced Swiss sovereignty.

The Christmas season is no time of joy for the Sanitation Department. Like the burdened mailman, the Sanitation worker views the approach of the year-end holidays with apprehension and foreboding. For these are the days when the mountains of paper and disposable refuse in New York City mount to epic proportions.
November was a good month for department stores in the Second District, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

The New York Stock Exchange saw flurries of strength every hour yesterday by individual issues but the market as a whole drifted downward and closed near its lows for the day. In the course of the session, however. The New York Times' industrial and combined averages registered new 1954 highs.
ROME, Dec. 22 -- The Pope was not quite so well today as yester day. His doctors were not alarmed, however.

The Pennsylvania Railroad Company was still unable, through last month, to reverse a decline in its gross operating revenues in effect for more than a year. But the company managed to continue in the black.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 22 -- Joseph S. Petersen admitted today that he had used secret information "in a manner prejudicial to the safety and interest of the United States."
TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- Public Service Coordinated Transport is seeking an increase in its local bus fares throughout New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- In the twelve years that Mrs. Victoria Geaney has been housekeeper for the Government's guest houses she never has seen such a rush of top-ranking guests as in the last twelve months.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Government of President Carlos Ibanez del Campo declared tonight it would ignore a resolution voted today by the Congress to lift Chile's state of siege. This is a modified form of martial law under which Chile has been living for more than three months.

ALBANY, N. Y., Dec. 22 (AP) -- The Public Service Commission today denied the Kings County Lighting Company's request to gain control of the New York and Richmond Gas Company by purchasing a major share of Richmond's voting stock.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., Dec. 22 -- Joseph S. Petersen admitted today that he had used secret information "in a manner prejudicial to the safety and interest of the United States."
TRENTON, Dec. 22 -- Public Service Coordinated Transport is seeking an increase in its local bus fares throughout New Jersey.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 22 (UP) -- Fordham, sparked by the all-round play of Ed Conlin, defeated St. Joseph's College, 61 -- 52, tonight before 2,000 fans at the Memorial Field House.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 (AP) -- A drive to clamp restrictions on baseball's long-disputed reserve clause is expected to get under way next year shortly after the Democrats assume control of Congress.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 22--The American Type Founders, Inc., said today it. would neither reopen its plant here nor transfer any of 185 strikers to the main plant at'Elizabeth, N, J.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 22 -- The United States Consumers Price Index rose one-tenth of 1 per cent last month -- the first upturn in three months.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 23 (AP) -- It just couldn't happen that both teams will win Saturday's Blue-Gray football game, but one got weird ideas like that today by listening to the gloomy predictions of the rival coaches.
Trading in cotton futures was quiet on the New York Cotton Exchange yesterday and prices for active months rose 2 to 9 points.
A fete with international flavor was given last night in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria under the sponsorship of the Foreign Press Association.

The Board of Education authorized yesterday the creation of a special commission to examine the racial composition of the city's schools. The purpose is to provide "effective democratic education for all of the children."

The unilateral Reece-Wolcott report on the foundations of this country is indicative of the desires of certain segments of our nation, happily a minority, to cast doubt on the integrity of our country's scientists and men of letters as well as on the colleges and universities that are the foundation for enlightenment and freedom.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Department-store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 3 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today. Figures from the board's weekly report on sales by districts follow in terms of percentage changes from like periods of 1953:

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- President Eisenhower will ask the new Congress to cut income taxes on most foreign investments in an effort to channel American capital into underdeveloped parts of the world.

JERUSALEM, Dec. 23 -- Many hundreds of visitors will go along the Judean ridge tomorrow from here to Bethlehem. Millions of people all over the world will make this same pilgrimage in imagination. The magnet is the story of the Nativity.

Another fatal fire in a rooming house where there were violations of the fire safety laws occurred yesterday afternoon in Harlem. The death was the third this week in slum tenement house fires. A man and a woman died in a tenement fire in Brooklyn on Monday night.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams made some last-minute promotions and changes yesterday before he started his week-end Christmas holiday.
Sparks flew in a worthy cause at City College yesterday.

HOUND music is ringing from the hills of the Catskills and "jugged hare" will be on a lot of holiday menus. For reports indicate that the varying hare, otherwise known as the snowshoe, is plentiful in most areas.
Father Knickerbocker was presented yesterday with a claim for $500,815 resulting from a burial error.

THE creche on the high lawn at the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue at Sixty-eighth Street is triply significant. It represents the Stable at Bethlehem. The word creche, according to Webster, means a nursery, sometimes a foundling hospital.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Frank N. Belgrano Jr., president of Transamerica Corporation, said today the bank holding company paid off all its bank loans and 1954 ends as "a very successful year" for the corporation.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 23 -- Communists are threatening the judges of the Supreme Constitutional Court at Karlsruhe with death if they decide the Communist party is an unconstitutional organization.

NOT very long ago Jerrard Tickell, an Irish-born English novelist, went for a vacation cruise on a French banana boat through the Caribbean. And, since Mr. Tickell is a highly professional writer who knows the value of an observant eye, he paid strict attention to the climate, the scenery, the local customs and the vessel's refrigerating system.
The Transit Authority is considering timetables for night subway riders.

A program of contemporary music, including the premiere of a work by Paul Hindemith, will be played in Carnegie Hall on the evening of Jan. 19 by the Symphony of the Air. Don Gillis, president of the Symphony Society of America, announced yesterday scheduling of the performance.

SOONER or later a direct competitor to "Dragnet" was bound to come along and it has this season in the form of "The Lineup," presented at 10 o'clock Friday evenings over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network.
Twenty-three young Brooklyn women were introduced to society last night at the thirty-sixth annual Yuletide Ball held in the ballroom of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Mrs. Jean Butler, a former member of the United States Communist party, has been ordered to leave Britain after five and a half years' stay.

Hope that an unwanted child might spend the next Christmas in a new home of his own, surrounded by the joys of the season, was expressed by more than one donor to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday as Christmas Eve approached.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP) -- An inquiry began today to determine why a civilian airplane carrying twenty-three soldiers ran out of fuel and crash-landed in the Monongahela River.
PARIS, Dec. 21 -- Several hundred United States soldiers stationed in France will pass their Christmas and New Year's holidays with French families.

"Thomas Mann," by J. M. Lindsay, lecturer in German at the University of St. Andrews, will be issued Jan. 18 by Macmillan. Mr. Lindsay traces the main influences that have affected Mr. Mann's work, from "Buddenbrooks" to "The Black Swan," and that "help to explain the mental complexities of modern Germany."
Commuters on the Gladstone, N. J., branch of the Delaware, Lackawanna and Western Railroad gave a Christmas party aboard the train yesterday morning for Frank Schwartz, their popular conductor.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 -- Wheat futures today continued the upswing that started yesterday, and there was enough broadening of demand to absorb occasional profit-taking.

One year ago today the Soviet press announced the conviction and immediate execution of Lavrenti P. Beria. Today's anniversary is an interesting one if only because we can note that in the past twelve months none of the Kremlin hierarchs who sent their comrade to his death has himself been purged.

The curtain was just about drawn for the rest of the year on the new-issue market with the sale this week of $423,000,000 of tax-exempt bonds to finance major hydroelectric development and toll bridge projects.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- Dmitri Shostakovich, the composer, declared in an article published here today that the Soviet people intended "to broaden cultural relations" with all people and "in particular with the American people."

The movement to extend the legal hours of overnight street parking may be well intentioned, but it is entirely in the wrong direction, unless accompanied by some form of parking fee and by strict enforcement of the traffic regulations.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- Mayor Wagner has revived the idea of a passenger conveyor belt between the United Nations area and Grand Central Terminal.

Denaturalization suits against six Communist party members were ordered consolidated yesterday by Senior Federal Judge John C. Knox on a Government motion. United States Attorney J. Edward Lumbard said he would seek early trial of the civil cases.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 23 -- Continuation of Indonesia's neutralist and nationalistic policies has been endorsed by the Nationalist party congress. The party is the dominant faction in the coalition Cabinet of Dr. Ali Sastroamidjojo.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 23 -- The story of Gautama Buddha, founder of the Buddhist religion, will be dramatized on the screen by Metro-Goldwn-Mayer.
QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Official political sources said tonight that President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra had apparently put down an attempted revolt by high officers of the Army.
A shrewd fugitive lost a battle of wits to the police last night, less than a day after they had innocently aided him in escaping from Rikers Island Penitentiary.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Government announced today it had signed a contract for sale of a rubber plant at Louisville, Ky., to the American Synthetic Rubber Corporation.
LONDON, Dec. 23 -- If money is the measure of merriment, Britain is in for one of her merriest Christmas holidays.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 23 -- A plot to assassinate Paul Hall, a top official of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L., was foiled this afternoon, officials here said tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The breach between the State and Agriculture Departments over security checks in the case of Wolf Ladejinsky appeared headed today for a White House showdown.

An amazing blunder has happened in Japan. It could damage us grievously throughout Asia. Wolf Ladejinsky has been fired by Secretary Ezra Taft Benson from his job as agricultural attache to the United States Embassy in Tokyo. Security has been suggested as the cause.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Treasury received a $100,000,000 check today from the now defunct Reconstruction Finance Corporation. There is more to come.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 23 -- A $50,000 fund has been established at the Harvard Graduate School of Business Administration in honor of Sidney J. Weinberg by his partners in the New York investment banking firm of Goldman, Sachs and Company.
FORT MYERS, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Connie Mack, looking and acting like a sprightly youngster of 70, celebrated his 92d birthday anniversary today.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Norman (Red) Strader, 50, became head coach today of the championship-hungry San Francisco Forty-Niners' pro football club.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) Thousands of needy children will be happier on Christmas Day because patients in veterans hospitasl conducted "Operation Santa Claus."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Alleghany Corporation told the Interstate Commerce Commission today that it would not request the commission to approve its control of the New York Central Railroad.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- A report sharply criticizing the Administration's power policy is being drafted by the Senate anti-monopoly subcommittee.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Frederick W. Richmond, 30-year-old New York financier, bought Follansbee Steel Corporation today for $9,286,620 and immediately sold parts of the concern to two other financial groups.
Mediation meetings in the contract dispute between the port's longshoremen and their employers were held for five hours yesterday without result. Another meeting has been scheduled for next Tuesday.

The United States and Panama appear to have reached a fair and generous settlement of the longstanding differences between them over the Canal Zone and related problems. The old, unhappy past of "Yankee imperialism," color bars, labor discrimination, extraterritorial rights and other privileges lasted longer in Panama than in any other Latin-American country.
MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 24 (AP) The text of the Soviet Government announcement in Izvestia today on the sentencing and execution of former associates of Beria:
TOLEDO, Ohio, Dec. 23 -- Twelve railroads operating in Ohio today reversed their historic opposition to port authorities in this state.

'TWAS the night before Christmas when all through the house -- well, tonight's the night when the jolly old elf will come tumbling down chimneys with bulging sack. Before his presents are spilled out under the tree, it may not be a bad idea to peek for a glimpse of what Santa may have for some of our sports folks.

CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Live hogs were fairly active and strong to 25 cents higher today, with most of the advance on weights over 230 pounds. One deck of choice 200 pounders sold at a top of $19.25 per hundred pounds.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 23 -- President Eisenhower today provided a West Point cadet with a memorable tale to tell his folks for Christmas. The President, with Mrs. Eisen hower, took William G. Peters of Albany, Ga., a hitch-hiking cadet, aboard the Columbine 3d at Washington. Washington this morning, twenty minutes before the President was to depart for Augusta. Cadet Peters, hoping to find a Regular Army plane ready to depart, appealed to the transport officer.

JERSEY CITY, Dec. 23 -- Superior Court Judge Haydn Proctor today signed an order terminating public hearings in the twenty-month-old court investigation of Jersey City's municipal financial transactions. One hundred and twenty-six hearings were held and 12,000 pages of testimony recorded.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Navy said today it had ignored a "White-only" notice on 13,000 tickets for the Sugar Bowl football game in New Orleans New Year's Day between the Naval Academy and the University of Mississippi.
ALBANY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Governor Dewey shortened today the prison sentences of five murderers and two robbers.

What has happened to the educational television station planned for the metropolitan New York area? The Federal Communications Commission has allocated Channel 25. A nonprofit corporation was established to operate this projected ETV station.
MILWAUKEE, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The National Boxing Association championship committee today withdrew recognition of Robert Cohen as world bantamweight champion and declared the title vacant.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- During the week ended yesterday, member bank reserves decreased $195,000,000.
More than half the passengers on the Incres-Nassau liner Nassau left New York for Canada under guard after the vessel berthed yesterday morning from Italy.
The arrival of a plane in Honolulu today will mark journey's end for a young German bride. She is crossing two oceans and a broad continent to be with her soldier-husband on Christmas Eve.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today extended until Feb. 15 its authorization to railroads to reduce rates on shipments of hay to drought - hit areas in eighteen states.
ALBANY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Governor Dewey today appointed Frank Del Vecchio of Syrasuse, the unsuccessful candidate for Controller, to the bench of the State Supreme Court, effective tomorrow.
A new blow to the prestige of the Soviet secret police and enhancement of the army's standing is indicated in news of the new executions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Following are excerpts from the opinion of the Federal Court of Appeals upholding the Subversive Activities Control Act of 1950.

TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- Crown Prince Akihito, who will one day rule Japan as head of the world's oldest royal dynasty, became 21 years old today and rumors spread that palace officials were looking about for a future Empress.

Michael J. Quill, president of the Transport Workers Union, C. I. O., sent a telegram yesterday to James P. Newell, vice president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, to say that a move to transfer heavy equipment from the shops in Wilmington to Altoona, was an invitation to labor trouble.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Bertrand Russell proposed tonight that neutral powers impress upon East and West that the use of hydrogen bombs in a new world war would be likely to lead to the extermination of mankind.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 (Reuters) -- The text of a joint statement today by Marshal Tito of Yugoslavia and Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru of India:
A spokesman for the Government of South Vietnam said yesterday it would be "wonderful" if Bao Dai, the Chief of State, would remove himself from the Vietnamese picture.
RYE, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- Contractors have offered to build the New England Thruway from Mamaroneck to Rye for 22 per cent less than engineers had figured.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Authorities indicated today that they wanted to question Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard again in an effort to persuade him to confess the slaying of his wife Marilyn last July 4.

At a repeat performance of Giordano's "Andrea Chenier," last night at the Metropolitan Opera, there was one major change in cast. Richard Tucker sang his first Chenier at the opera house, though the fact would have been hard to guess.

MOSCOW, Friday, Dec. 24 -- Viktor Semeyonovitch Abakumov, former Soviet Minister of State Security, and three of his assistants have been executed by shooting. They were accused of having been accomplices of the late Lavrenti P. Beria.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 25 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold met today with the permanent representatives of the United States and France in preparation for his forthcoming trip to Peiping.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A jury today returned verdicts of guilty for three members of the Nationalist party accused of advocating the overthrow by force of the Puerto Rican Government. Twelve others were acquitted.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 23 (UP) -- Cleveland fans who hoped the Browns played under wraps in last Sunday's game against the Detroit Lions got a jolt today when Coach Paul Brown said he would play it the same way all over again if he had "the same conditions."
Harlon Hill, an unheralded ball-hawk who went to the Chicago Bears from Alabama Teachers College, was named yesterday the National Football League's rookie of the year in the United Press poll.
OUR last pre-Christmas look New York art galleries takes in five current exhibitions.
Schenley Industries, Inc., cleared $4,416,399, equal to $1.01 a common share, in the three months through November, it was announced yesterday.

Joseph Szigeti was violin soloist at the Philharmonic-Symphony Society's concert, directed by Bruno Walter last night in Carnegie Hall. The Bach concerto he played, in G minor, is the transcription for violin of the F minor concerto for harpsichord.
It seems the three local major league ball clubs are working on a rotation system in bringing their players into the fold. Yesterday the Giants and Dodgers came up with one each.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The United States is going to blanket Iron Curtain countries this year with the Christmas story.
CHICAGO, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Bishop Sheil Foundation received today a charter from the Illinois Secretary of State's office.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman announced yesterday the appointment of four more members of his official family.
Milton H. Biow, chairman of the Biow Company, acted yesterday to quiet rumors arising as a result of a series of changes in personnel and accounts.
Paint manufacturers are profiting handsomely from the Eisenhower Administration's policy of withdrawing from competition with private industry.

More than 600 coffee delivery notices were issued yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. Despite the large number, trading was orderly and the notices were well received. The steadiness of the spot December option was reflected across the board.

Jacques Abram, pianist, married Miss Christine Dorsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leighton Spence Dorsey of Wilmington, Del., yesterday afternoon in the Community Church. The Rev. Donald Harrington performed the ceremony.
NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 23 -- Order has been restored to this Island.
KHARTUM, the Sudan, Dec. 23 (AP) -- Three rebellious Sudanese Cabinet ministers were dismissed tonight on charges they had conspired to overthrow Prime Minister Ismail el Azhari's Government.

Business loans by banks in the New York area have declined for the third consecutive week. The Federal Reserve Bank here reported yesterday that in the period ended Wednesday such borrowings fell by $11,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Yemen's legation said today that its Government was not inspiring attacks by tribesmen in the Western Aden Protectorate.

The cause of peace won another resounding victory on the eve of Christmas when the Italian Chamber of Deputies approved the pacts of Paris by one of the largest majorities in its history. The pacts must still be approved by the Italian Senate, but the action of the Chamber, in which all parties except the Communists and crypto-Communist Socialists lined up in their support, assures Italy's final ratification.

All over the world this Christmas there must be thousands of men and women who are looking back with very happy memories to the time they spent as foreign students at American unversities, but there are few ways of showing our gratitude for all the hospitality and kindness we received.

MIAMI, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The North team happily received news today that it was a 7-point shortender in the odds as the College All-Stars held final workouts for the annual Shrine charity football game in the Orange Bowl Christmas night.

Two half-hour drama programs -- one on film, the other live -- are scheduled for television premieres early next year. The film series, titled "The Star and the Story," will have Henry Fonda as host and narrator.

An overflow audience of 20,000 persons filled Madison Square Garden last night in celebration of Hanukkah. This is the Jewish festival marking the victory of Judas Maccabaeus and the people of ancient Israel over Syrian tyranny more than 2,000 years ago.

Most of the more important Government economic indices have been revised in recent years, with such standard bench marks as the Consumer Price Index and the Wholesale Price Index of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, and the Federal Reserve Index of Industrial Production re-established on a basis which assumes the period 1947-49 equals 100.

Ron Howell, a 19-year-old all-around athlete, will be in the line-up for the New York Rangers when they oppose the Canadiens in Montreal tomorrow night. Frank Boucher, manager of the Broadway Blues, decided yesterday to bring up the youth from the Guelph team of the Ontario Hockey League.
Navy divers brought up yesterday the bodies of six more persons killed in last Saturday's crash of an Italian Airlines plane at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens.

The clearing of the Philadelphia Marine Corporation on charges of having made fraudulent statements in connection with the purchase of a Government-owned tanker was hailed here yesterday in shipping quarters.
Two top-ranking-leaders of the Protestant and Roman Catholic faiths in this country issued Christmas messages yesterday from the other side of the world.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 23 -- Egypt announced today that she would release the ten-man crew of the seized Israeli freighter Bat Galim on Jan. 1. She also represented herself as prepared to free the vessel and cargo.

Full of the wrong kind of Christmas spirit and in no shape to drive his reindeer -- if he had any -- a street-corner Santa Claus was stripped of his uniform and chimney command yesterday morning. This occurred after he began expressing some purple opinions about passers-by who did not drop coins into his chimney collection box.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (UP) -- The Government granted $10,275,533 to medical research institutes today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Eisenhower Administration was accused today of having promoted a Negro woman leader last January with the idea of dropping her later.
"Sailor's Delight" finally is coming to New York. With Eva Gabor and Paul McGrath in the principal roles, the product of various mutations will hang out its shingle at the Imperial on Jan. 13.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The Civil Aeronautics Board authorized Trans-Canada Air Lines today to continue to operate its Montreal-Mexico service through Tampa, Fla. The board also approved its continued use of Kinross Airport, Mich., to serve Sault Ste. Marie, Ont.

A smoky two-alarm fire in the Record Collector Shop, 113 West Forty-seventh Street, just west of the Avenue of the Americas, drove holiday customers and upper-story tenants into the street at 4:15 P. M. yesterday.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 23 (AP) -- H. H. Polk's Zuyder Zee, a 2-1 choice, snapped the streak of losing favorites at Tropical Park today as he sped to victory in the Emerald Isle Purse before a crowd of 7,817.

Samuel Reshevsky continued undefeated in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Manhattan Chess Club last night. He set back George Kramer of Philadelphia in forty-one moves and increased his score to 4 1/2 to 1/2.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 23 -- Pakistan will oppose the formation of an African-Asian bloc at the Colombo powers' conference.

A Queens housewife who dropped a bankbook containing $175 in cash outside her home yesterday morning got it back intact. A Sanitation Department loader had found it near the garbage can and reported the discovery to his superiors.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The analysts of political action in this country occupy safer ground than the prophets because their deductions are after the fact and can't be proved or disproved, whereas the soundness of prophecy must undergo the test of the event.

A storm such as the one which now pours its wrath upon the shores of northwestern Europe is the most awesome of all nature's products. We have been conditioned from childhood to think of storms as the prelude or the aftermath of evil deeds. A swirling hurricane or a whipping gale appears in countless children's stories as a manifestation of divine displeasure.
ALBANY, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The state's Republican leaders today put at the head of their legislative list for 1955 a bill to retain state aid for education at current rates for an additional year.
The New York Stock Exchange membership of Morton Weinress has been transferred to George H. Moss Jr.

Despite a rally led by the rails near the close, the stock market had a small loss yesterday for the third successive day. For the week, however, it showed a good gain, owing to the advance on Monday.
AUGUSTA, Me., Dec. 23 (UP) -- Gov. Burton M. Cross granted a Christmas pardon today to the man he accused of offering him a bribe.

ROME, Dec. 23 (AP) -- L'Osservatore Romano, which usually reflects Vatican views, denounced Argentine authorities today. The paper charged President Juan D. Peron's regime had muzzled religious freedom by jailing priests and subverted morals by legalizing divorce.

Several members of the Norway Ski Club yesterday were discussing the possibilities of taking off for the northlands for a weekend of skiing. Conditions were good at many of the old standbys and there seemed nothing to prevent making a trip.

Most market men are surprisingly frank in admitting that winter tomatoes lack the bright color and, more important, the fine flavor of those that come from near by in the summer. Despite this inferiority there is what the trade describes as "a definite minimum demand for tomatoes" in winter from hotels, restaurants and householders.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- The depression of the last few days gave way to brightness in the stock markets today. Prices improved under the lead of British Government stocks, though business was seasonably restricted.
PARIS, Friday, Dec. 24 -- The National Assembly voted down German rearmament at 4 o'clock this morning by 280 to 259.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 -- Prime Minister Jawaharlal Nehru and President Tito of Yugoslavia denounced today any idea that countries trying to stand aside from the East-West conflict should get together as a "third force" in the world.
No inveterate doubter can hold out any longer against the idea that Christmas is coming.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Federal Court of Appeals, in a 2-to-1 decision, upheld today the law requiring the Communist party to register as a subversive organization dominated by Soviet Russia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- A committee headed by Dr. Vannevar Bush has recommended gradual mechanization of search work in the Patent Office.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 23 (AP) -- The contest between Australia and the United States next week for the Davis Cup shapes up as so close that the outcome may depend on the result of Saturday's draw.
SEOUL, Dec. 23 -- Banners and signs throughout the city welcomed Francis Cardinal Spellman, Archbishop of New York, on his arrival today to spend his fourth Christmas with United States troops.
ROME, Dec. 23 -- The Italian Chamber of Deputies ratified today the Paris agreements on the Western European Union. The vote was 335 to 215 at the end of an eight-hour session.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- President Eisenhower, in two separate actions today, emphasized anew his unwillingness to raise the barriers to international trade.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 23 -- The bottom dropped out of the market today for "Liberty Head" silver dollars struck at the United States mint here in the Eighteen Eighties.

Silver and blue Christmas trees, silvered smilax and blue balloons provided a holiday decor for the season's second and last Junior Assembly, which was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza.
TOKYO, Dec. 23 -- The apparent softening of Soviet conditions for the signing of a peace treaty with Japan has had a mixed reaction in political circles here.

Lumber production in the week ended last Saturday was 1.6 per cent below that of the like week last year, according to reports wired yesterday to The New York Times by regional associations. Shipments were up 10.6 per cent and orders 17.9 per cent.

HEMPSTEAD, L, I., Dec. 23 (AP) -- Marietta College of Ohio was picked today as the team to beat in the fourth annual Hofstra College Christmas invitation basketball tournament. The event will get under way Monday at the Hofstra College gymnasium.
ANYONE can see that "Black-Eyed Susan," which opened at the Playhouse last evening, is a dirty show. But is it funny?
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended last Saturday, totaled 641,871 cars, the Association of American Railroads announced today.

This holiday period from Thanksgiving to Christmas has been marked these past few years in a unique way. Each year since the end of the war the American Bible Society has sponsored a world-wide Bible-reading program, passing from the day that gives gratitude for the harvest to the day that memorializes the birth of Christ.
Kid Gavilan, still upset over the loss of his prized world welterweight crown, said yesterday he would fight no more for Manager Angel Lopez.
The latest repercussion of the purge of Lavrenti P. Beria is probably related to a new intensification of the hidden Kremlin struggle for power, diplomatic observers suggested last night.

One of the most important acts of Governor Dewey in his final month has been the appointment of the permanent fifteen-member Board of Trustees of the State University. The names will presumably be forwarded to the Senate for confirmation by Governor-elect Harriman after taking office. Mr. Dewey selected as chairman of the board Frank C. Moore, former Lieutenant Governor and State Controller, who is now president of the Government Affairs Foundation.
Buyers of rare old coins took their telephones off the hooks and barricaded their doors here and across the nation yesterday.

Christmas has a meaning all its own to each of us. This is the day for children, when a thousand tiny sparkles start to dance. Into their minds drift candy soldiers, peppermint sticks, a dancing doll, a fluffy bear. Christmas Eve with little sleep, then early up to see the tree, standing green with shimmering strips of silver, shining glints of red and yellow and blue.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 23 (AP) -- A libel suit for $1,000,000 was filed here today by the former president of an anti-vice organization who contended a nationally televised program implied he was the slayer of the crime fighter, A. L. Patterson.
The New York Post Office did a land office business during the pre-Christmas rush this month and its exhausted employes will enjoy a well-earned rest tomorrow.

The Great Northern Railway announced yesterday a net income of $3,137,531 for November, compared with $3,091,571 in the like month last year. In releasing its statement the management noted that earnings in November, 1953, included a non-recurring credit of $1,367,000.
Financial markets are extending the Christmas holiday this year. Banks will be open as usual, but both the New York Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange will be closed all day today.

Each country has its own traditions in the Christmas season. Ceremonies may begin as early as the first Sunday in Advent, with the lighting of the candles on the Advent wreath in Germany, or last as long as the feast of the Epiphany on Jan. 6, when the Three Kings give presents to children in Latin countries.
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., Dec. 23 (UP) -- Governor-elect Leroy Collins said today that a state racing commission headed by J. Saxton Lloyd, a Daytona Beach automobile dealer, had been appointed.

Hundreds of young Santa Clauses here have been working hard in the last few weeks to make sure their parents have a Merry Christmas, too. Their workshops are the classrooms in the schools, from the kindergartens up to those of the lofty teen-agers.

Three new films will open at first-run theatres this morning. "Green Fire," a Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer drama in CinemaScope and color with Stewart Granger, Grace Kelly, Paul Douglas and John Ericson, is at the Mayfair. Armand Deutsch produced and Andrew Marton directed from a screen play by Ivan Goff and Ben Roberts.
Robert W. Dill, Collector of Customs, said yesterday that he would oppose a proposed system of high seas customs inspection aboard inbound passenger liners.

Mississippi this week joined Georgia, South Carolina and Louisiana in an effort to evade the Supreme Court decision against segregation in the schools. Under an amendment to the State Constitution Mississippi would authorize its Legislature to abolish public schools and pay tuition for students attending private schools.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- It was understood today that Pope Pius had recorded a Christmas greeting, lasting four or five minutes, for broadcast to the world tomorrow. Only the apostolic benediction to the faithful will be a "live" broadcast.

New York and California once again proved to be the hotbeds of thoroughbred racing in 1954, a United Press survey revealed yesterday, as the attendance continued to soar but the wagering dropped slightly.

LONDON, Dec. 23 -- Sea defenses along the English and European coasts of the North Sea held out tonight against flood tides driven before a fierce north-westerly gale. However, anxious watch was being maintained along the low-lying coasts toward the "bottleneck" between England and the Low Countries.

MOSCOW, Dec. 23 -- A Soviet review of current American literature has been presented to the Writers Congress now in session here without mentioning more than two or three authors whom Americans would consider important.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- Colombia obtained $25,000,000 (U. S.) for pesos from the International Monetary Fund today to enable importers to pay off some of their bills to United States exporters.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 23 -- The Soviet Union has agreed to return to the United States twenty-seven small naval craft. The vessels, received on loan under the World War II lend- lease program, are to be turned over at the port of Maizura, Japan, in June and July, 1955.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 24 -- Government commissioners in several towns of this British colony told heads of Greek secondary schools today pupils would be liable to expulsion if they participated in "unlawful demonstrations."
Two men held up two employes at the. S. Klein department store, 6 Union Square, at 1:30 P. M. yesterday. The men then ran out into crowded Union Square amid cries of "Stop, thief."
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- The stock market here was in a holiday mood today and attendance was thin. But despite the scarcity of business, prices made a good showing in most sections.
Public response to newspaper appeals for the needy was generous this year.
ALBANY, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:

Activity on the New York commodity exchanges was very dull yesterday, with many markets trading only half a day and others not opening at all. The New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange and the Commodity Exchange, which deals in copper, hides, lead, burlap, rubber, tin, zinc and silk, were closed.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Mrs. Jane M. Spaulding, Negro woman leader who allegedly was forced out of one Government job and put in another, is now under consideration for a new Government post.

This is a time of turbulence and trouble in some parts of the world that have seen happier Christmas seasons in the past. In East Asia peace is precarious. For some persons in Korea, in Japan, in Formosa and in Vietnam the season will be better than it could have been had there not been the warm desire to do what could be done to alleviate suffering.

SUFFERN, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Both the Italian and American Governments are studying a method for feeding poor people that has resulted in a trend away from Left-Wing tickets in recent elections in one Italian community.
During National Airlines' first full year of operation of Douglas DC-7's, which ended ten days ago, it made more than 3,000 flights between New York and Florida with the 365-mile-an-hour aircraft.

MONTREAL, Dec. 24 -- Because Quebec's civil code is largely derived from the old custom of Paris, a foot isn't really a foot, but only about 11 3/4 inches. As a result, a Montreal court today ordered the owners of a building to block some of their windows because they were 4 4/5 inches too close to their neighbors' property.

MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Twenty-five players selected individually for three other post-season games will be among the forty-eight who turn professional in the sixth annual Senior Bowl football game here Jan. 8.

Harry Kesend, in a purchase for investment, has acquired the seven-story loft building at 164-70 Tillary Street in Brooklyn from the American Safety Razor Company. Two and one-half floors have been leased to the Brooklyn Eagle Press, Inc., which now occupies space in the Brooklyn Eagle Building which is to be razed for the new civic center.

OTTAWA, Dec. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Canadians sold abroad $7,700,000 more in securities than they bought during October. The month saw the highest volume of securities exports and imports in three years -- $160,000,000.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24 -- Three Indian political parties agreed tonight to join forces to fight the strong Communist bid to take over Andhra, India's newest state.

The story of Police Commissioner Adams' first year in office, as related by Guy Passant in The Times of Dec. 19, merits commendation not only for the writer whose acumen produced it but particularly for the subject of his all too brief essay.
With the exception of one adjourned game, the first half of the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament was completed yesterday at the Manhattan Chess Club.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- About sixty United States soldiers stationed in this region came to Paris tonight to meet the French families who will be their hosts for Christmas. In all, several hundred American soldiers will pass the holidays with French hosts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- Ezra Taft Benson pledged to Wolf Ladejinsky today a "fair, impartial and equitable" hearing.
OMAHA, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The Strategic Air Command will expand its operations in 1955 to meet its "global commitments," Gen. Curtis E. LeMay, Commander, said today.
