A Christmas present in the form of extended benefits be hospitalized seamen of the National Maritime Union, C. I. O., was announced yesterday by the trustees o fthe union welfare fund.
MARATHON, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Harold A. Clark Sr., millionaire real estate developer and former racing figure, was found dead in his swimming pool here today.
Marian Anderson took a step yesterday to make her dream of opera come true.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Sideline quarterbacks are sputtering with indecision over tomorrow's Blue-Gray game.

Christmas is a holiday celebrated throughout the Western World and this year particularly there is much for Europeans, as well as Americans, to be happy about. There is not merely the negative absence of war but also the positive growth of democratic strength.
The sports oddity of the year occurred on Jan. 1, 1954. That's an oddity in itself.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 24 -- The Indian Parliament ended today a six-week session in which several important and controversial measures were approved.

DETROIT, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Working four and a half days this week, the auto industry assembled 123,272 cars and 18,291 trucks, Ward's Automotive Reports said today. Last week 151,924 cars and 21,909 trucks were built, and in the comparable week of 1953, 67,308 cars and 17,951 trucks.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 17 -- Mrs. Truxton Beale, who has willed her historic Decatur House to the nation, has added the gift of its documentation.
The latest executions in the Soviet Union have thrown new light on the role of the Soviet Army in the removal and execution of Lavrenti P. Beria, former Interior Minister and Deputy Premier.

"Merry Christmas!" Around the world there are now no two more joyous words than these. "Merry Christmas!" They go forth uniting mankind in a wish for a truly merry day, a day of happiness for all. "Merry Christmas!"

The net income of the New York Central Railroad and its leased lines during November was 173.8 per cent greater than a year earlier, erasing the deficit that plagued the road for the first ten months of the year.

WITH SEVENTH DIVISION, Korea, Saturday, Dec. 25 (AP) -- Francis Cardinal Spellman told 2,000 soldiers at a Christmas Eve midnight mass that he was in Korea because the Red Star of communism "has risen in our time to challenge the star of Bethlehem."
A bewildered ex-convict questioned yesterday the Christmas spirit of freedom and justice.
On the Eve of Christmas, the generosity of children and a teacher's touching tribute to a pupil who died this week were among the outstanding gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Prolonged negotiations concerning the Ottawa International League baseball franchise wound up today on a "to be continued" note.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The Communist party prepared today to fight for reversal of the court decision upholding the law requiring it to register as a Soviet-dominated subversive organization.

This is Thanksgiving Day as well as Christmas for the hundred and more households helped by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. On this morning when we traditionally give an accounting of our stewardship we are happy to report that gifts to the fund have reached $301,713.86 and that this represents the generosity of 8,826 donors.
Krystyna Bujnowska, prima ballerina of Poland, arrived at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens at 9 o' clock last night from Paris after fleeing the Polish ballet while it was in Paris.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Two Republican Senators predicted today that their colleagues generally would support. President Eisenhower and his program despite their sharp split over condemnation of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy, Republican of Wisconsin.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The Air Line Pilots Association, A. F. L., today assailed a proposed new Federal regulation that would permit irregular airlines to operate two-pilot flights for ten hours. Eight hours is now the standard for these lines.
VIENNA, Dec. 24 -- Noel and Herta Field, who were released by Hungary Nov. 17 after five years' imprisonment for alleged espionage, have sought and received asylum in that country.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 24 -Thousands of tons of American foodstuffs, desperately needed by citizens of nations behind the Iron Curtain, were being delivered today as a timely "Christmas gift" from the United States.

WASHINGTON, Dec 24 -- President Eisenhower and his highest diplomatic counselors viewed with grave concern today the French vote against the controlled armament of West Germany.
Harry Gross, serving a six-year term for bookmaking, will be credited with the 184 days he spent in prison as a material witness.
LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Sir Walter Monckton, Minister of Labor, today set up a three-man court to inquire into the dispute threatening to cause a nation-wide railroad strike on Jan. 9.
TOKYO, Dec. 24 -- Some light appeared to break today in the murky relations between Japan and South Korea.
MOBILE, Ala., Dec. 23 -- The production capacity of the Courtaulds viscose rayon plant at suburban LeMoyne will be tripled under an expansion program approved today by the company's directors.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -Right on the heels of Santa Claus will come a less welcome visitor to millions of American homes, the mailman with the 1954 income tax forms.

PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Premier Mendes-France wishes his fellow countrymen peace and happiness in a Christmas Eve radio address tonight. But he added: "It all depends on us."
NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 24 (UP) -The Coast Guard will begin an investigation from New Orleans next month into the mysterious disappearance of the freighter Southern Districts.

Bearing lanterns, aglow in the dusk of Christmas Eve, 250 children of the Protestant Episcopal Chapel of the Intercession (Trinity Parish) made their annual pilgrimage yesterday to the grave of their favorite Yuletide poet.

Two nonfatal incidents of carbon monoxide poisoning from defective air-cooled gas refrigerators in rooming houses were reported yesterday by the Health Department.
TAIPEI, Formosa, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Nationalist China's Defense Ministry announced today that Nationalist commandos raided the Chinese mainland early yesterday, catching the Communists asleep.

The shipment of television sets to dealers during the first ten months of the year was slightly greater than in the 1953 period, the Radio - Electronic - Television Manufacturers Association reported yesterday. During October deliveries were 30 per cent higher than in the corresponding month last year.
The Real Estate Board of New York has named a committee to cooperate with the City Administration in the enforcement of laws relating to multifamily dwellings.

Six new films will open at first-run theatres as holiday entertainment today. "Vera Cruz," a United Artists adventure made in Superscope and color, and costarring Gary Cooper and Burt Lancaster, is at the Capitol.

PITTSFIELD, Maine, Dec. 24 (AP) -- This central Maine town (population 3,900) got a Christmas present today -- news that a modern new woolen mill would be built to replace one idle since September, 1953.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- Christmas this year has brought a breaking down of the frontier between Soviet - controlled East Germany and the West German Federal Republic on a scale not experienced before.

LONDON, Dec. 24 -- Five Labor members of Parliament interceded with the Home Office today in an effort to help Mrs. Jean Butler, an American who had been told she must leave the country by next Tuesday.
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 24 -- The Belfast police reunited with her parents today a 4-year-old girl kidnapped from her baby carriage in Dublin four years ago.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- William T. Faricy, president of the Association of American Railroads, said today the Government should put the railroad industry on what he called an equal competitive basis with other forms of transportation.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (Reuters) -- The Duke of Edinburgh has sent a gold medal to the British marathon runner, Jim Peters, who collapsed at the Vancouver Empire Games last August. Peters had run, a plucky race which earned him world-wide acclaim.
Since 1939, often regarded as an "average" pre-war year, prices for machinery have risen less than half as much as wage rates paid by the manufacturers.
The Christian world ended its preparations for Christmas last night.

The New York Knickerbockers will have the opportunity of replacing Syracuse in first place in the National Basketball Association's Eastern Division tonight when the teams meet at Madison Square Garden. The locals will be seeking their fourth victory in a row.

A group of prominent Americans will broadcast Christmas greetings to countries behind the Iron Curtain. Transmitted in the Czech, Slovak, Hungarian, Polish, Rumanian and Bulgarian languages, the messages will be broadcast in the coming week over Radio Free Europe's twenty-nine transmitters.

COLUMBIA, S. C., Dec. 24 (AP) -- Senator Charles E. Daniel has resigned and Gov. James F. Byrnes today announced the appointment of Senator-elect J. Strom Thurmond for the final eleven days of the term.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -James H. (Dutch) Kindelbergor, chairman of the board of North American Aviation, Inc., once watched as a group of news photographers tried to take pictures while clinging to lamp posts.

DES MOINES, Iowa, Dec. 24 -- Scores of the "rare" silver dollars recently placed in circulation by the United States Mint in Philadelphia turned up at Christmas parties held today by two Des Moines firms.
BOSTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Tomorrow will be sunny and cold, according to the weather forecast. The ski conditions reported in New England follow:

DANVILLE, Va., Dec. 24 -- A generous hand extended from the White House will bring an added measure of Christmas cheer tomorrow to the young inmates of Faith Home.
The advance in electronic data-handling devices was described yesterday as the outstanding accomplishment in the business machines industry in 1954.
CHICAGO, Dec. 24 -- The wheat market showed considerable strength today, both old and newcrop futures making new seasonal highs.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Detroit's Lions, seeking a record third straight championship, will move into Municipal Stadium Sunday for their third consecutive National Football League play-off off against Cleveland's Browns.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec, 24 -- Dr. Sunarjo, Indonesian Foreign Minister, expressed confidence today that next week's meeting of the Colombo powers would help ease world tension. An unemployed salesman held up a Bronx bank yesterday and fled with $3,760, but a bank guard seized him before he had gone a hundred feet.

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Dec. 24 -- John Cardinal D'Alton, head of the Roman Catholic Church in Ireland, today denounced the new outbreak of violence against Northern Ireland. His words were directed against the revolutionary Irish Republican Army, which twice this year has raided British Army bases.

Two hundred million dollars and 5,000 ships ago, Nathaniel D. Arnot decided that selling insurance was not his forte.
The Port of New York rolled out the welcome mat to 163 new ships this year.
PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France will make a decisive attempt next week to break the seeming impasse in the French-Tunisian negotiations.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- For the first time at Christmas mankind is haunted by the fear that it may utterly destroy itself and by the belief that this is scientifically possible. Subconscious terror underlies any peace or goodwill engendered by the customary spirit of this season.
MOSCOW, Dec. 24 -- Nikita S. Khrushchev has denied that there is a bread "crisis" in the Soviet Union.

TORONTO, Dec 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Ontario Securities Commisison says it will welcome any constructive move by the Securities and Exchange Commission to crack down on fraudulent sales of Canadian stock in the United States.
PRESTWICK, Scotland, Saturday, Dec. 25 -- A British Overseas Airways plane crashed and burned on a runway at Prestwick Airport today. Twenty-eight persons were killed.
PRESTWICK, Saturday, Dec. 25 -- (UP) -- Some survivors of the B. O. A. C. Stratocruiser crash were taken to near-by Ayr County hospital.
MOSCOW, Saturday, Dec. 25 -There was only one public place in Moscow tonight where it was Christmas Eve for Soviet citizens.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 24 -- The Eisenhower cottage bore a general resemblance tonight to hundreds of thousands of homes throughout the nation. The "Little White House" in the grounds of the Augusta National Golf Club was a gaily decorated manse.

Two five-story store and apartment buildings at 710-12 Lexington Avenue have been sold by Maurice Epstein as president of the 53d Park-Madison Corporation to a client of John J. Phelan, attorney. Nathan Miller was the broker and Benjamin A. Hartstein was attorney for the seller.

MIAMI, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The College All-Star football game in the Orange Bowl tomorrow night shapes up as a test of the North's passing prowess, plus Alan Ameche, against the South's deception and running ability.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 24 -- The adverse French vote on the arming of West Germany aroused acute alarm in the Federal Government. However, it raised the spirits of the Social Democrats, who are seeking the total defeat of Chancellor Konrad Adenauer's foreign policy.
ROME, Dec. 24 -- Communist labor unions have taken severe defeats in two important elections for shop stewards in Italian industrial plants.

During this Christmas week those New Yorkers within view of the thirty-nine-story slab that rises above the East River at the foot of Forty-third Street may have wondered whether the holiday spirit had penetrated there, too. It had. Within this unique and dedicated building there were Christmas decorations in many offices, some Christmas parties and programs of the sort familiar in the outside world and some carol singing.
ASHLAND, Ohio, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The spirit of giving and goodwill toward men has a richer, fuller meaning this Christmas for John Roseboro and his wife, Geraldine.

Christmas is a day when, in one mood, we live very much in the present and in another look back through the centuries. We tend to think of the past as the "good" old days, but they were not necessarily wholly good. Christmas Day a hundred years ago in New York was, in the editorial words of The Times on Dec. 25, 1854, a day in the midst of "hard times."

ROME, Dec. 24 -- The partial rejection by the French National Assembly of the Paris agreements on the Western European Union only a few hours after the Italian Chamber of Deputies had ratified them was regarded in Italian official circles as a major defeat for the West.
For the first time in twelve months, the number of persons in the city receiving public assistance declined in November.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 24 -- Milovan Djilas, former Vice President of Yugoslavia, appealed today for the formation of a new democratic Socialist party and thus for a two-party system. He said undemocratic forces in the present Government had halted a trend toward democracy.
Four men were held yesterday as partners in a plot to kill Paul Hall, secretary-treasurer of the Atlantic Coast District of the Seafarers International Union, A. F. L.
SAIGON, Vietnam, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Vietnam's new Minister of Defense has persuaded the leader of 4,000 rebels in southwest Vietnam to stop fighting.

PARIS, Dec. 24 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France will renew on Monday his fight for ratification of the Paris accords to make West Germany an armed ally of the Western coalition.

Ruth Draper, the renowned solo performer, will return to Broadway tomorrow evening at the Bijou Theatre in a joint program with her nephew, Paul Draper. The opening night curtain will rise at 8 o'clock.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 24 -- The marked increase this season in the traffic of screen personalities between the movies and television is demonstrated by the line-up of important acting talent obtained by the General Electric Theatre for its 1954-55 production program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 (AP) -The Department of Commerce said today that the United States increased its newsprint production by 9.4 per cent in the first nine months of 1954.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 24 -- The announcement in Budapest that Noel and Herta Field had asked for asylum in Hungary added another chapter to the mystery of the Field family.
HARTFORD, Dec. 24 -- Connecticut's sports writers and boxing enthusiasts are working hard to keep the state athletic department from being abolished.

CHICAGO, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Hayes Alan Jenkins of Colorado Springs, Colo., seeking a third straight title, and Boston's Tenley Albright, trying to recapture the women's crown, lead a 20-member United States team named today for the 1955 world figure skating meet at Vienna, Feb. 14-18.
The eve of the birth of the Christ Child was reverently observed last night as thousands of New York churchgoers paid devout homage to the founder of their faith.

PARIS, Dec. 24 (AP) -- Edouard Rabret, the French general secretary of the World Boxing Federation, said today the decision of the National Boxing Association of the United States declaring the world bantamweight championship vacant was "without value."

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 24 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold let it be known today that he felt he could not take news correspondents with him on his trip to Peiping. He would be "very happy" to have the press cover the trip, but arrangements to do so would have to be made directly with Communist China, a spokesman here said today.
From the basement flats of Greenwich Village to the penthouses high above Park Avenue, New York presents a shined-up, bedecked appearance this morning.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 24 (AP) - America's Davis Cup players spent a quiet Christmas eve after the most sparkling workout of their Australia visit.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Dec. 24 -- Christmas in Bermuda has become almost exactly like Christmas in the United States. When the first colonists here celebrated the Feast of the Nativity, it was with prayer and thanks and such goodies as birds' eggs, roast wild pig and palmetto wine.

LONDON, Dec. 24 (UP) -- The Soviet Union tonight accused Britain of exerting "gross pressure" on France in an attempt to force ratification of the agreements to admit West Germany to the Western European Union.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 24 (AP) -- William M. Wickham's Weal or Woe, third in his first start this winter, came back with a superb effort as he captured the featured race at Tropical Park today before a crowd of 8,330.

QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 24 (AP) -- The conflict between President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra and Ecuador's armed forces, which yesterday imperiled his rule, eased tonight, but tension and a feeling of crisis continued.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 24 -Members of the A. F. L. Sailors Union of the Pacific and of the Marine Firemen's Union planned today to do no work aboard West Coast American-flag ships from this evening until Tuesday morning.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed steady yesterday with active months 8 to 16 points higher than on Thursday.

Harrison Salisbury's articles concerning our dirty city deserve praise and much publicity. Before we have a plague due to our accumulated filth a national alarm should be sounded and a definite program pursued.

The challenge his ideas invariably offer to the student of international affairs is heightened today by the parlous state of the great movements toward European union about which he writes.

TORONTO, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Two goals by Bill Dineen, one of them in the third period, gave the Detroit Red Wings a 3-2 decision over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight and a tighter hold on second place in the National Hockey League.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 25 -- The names, numbers, college affiliations and positions of the players for tomorrow's Cleveland Browns-Detroit Lions professional championship football game at Cleveland Municipal Stadium follow:

When the United States and Canadian teams meet in the International Professional Golfers Association matches for the Hopkins Trophy next month at the La Jolla, Calif., Country Club, Gene Littler, who holds the course record, will be watching from the sidelines.
NEWARK, Dec. 25 (AP) -- The Newark Athletic Club today named Alex Webster of Kearny and Eddie Moylan of Trenton as New Jersey's professional and amateur athletes of 1954, respectively.

ASMARA, Eritrea, Dec. 12 -- Out of a patchwork of conflicting economic, national and religious interests in this former Italian colony there appears to be emerging a trend toward full union with Ethiopia. Eritrea is now federated with Ethiopia.

Christians the world over, and others who gratefully share the blessings of Christmas, drew from it yesterday joy, consolation and hope in an era of uneasy peace.

PARIS, Dec. 25 -- The displeasure expressed m Washington, and London at the French National Assembly's vote against German rearmament was reflected in large headlines in today's French newspapers.

Apparent necessity to do last-minute Christmas chores resulted in lethargic markets in Wall Street on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday. But the list closed the week with a net gain. This was due almost entirely to persistent strength on Monday, which carried The New York Times rail average to its best level since early in 1931 and the industrial index to the mid-October, 1929, mark.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- President Eisenhower today faced fights on two fronts in the new Democratic-controlled Congress.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Mrs. J. H. Woodcock's Epic King, who has finished out of the money only once this year, scored a front-running half-length triumph today in the $5,000 Christmas Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

Thousands of Christians attended Christmas services yesterday, starting with midnight mass for Roman Catholics and holy communion for many Protestant congregations. Special music programs were conducted at these and other services in the morning.

MIAMI, Dec. 25 -- Carl Garrigus, Miami's great ball-faking quarterback, scored in the last two minutes of play tonight to give the South's college all-stars a 20-17 comeback victory over the North in the Shrine's seventh annual football benefit classic.

Cyprus passed into British hands in 1878 as part of the "peace with honor" which Disraeli and Lord Salisbury brought back from the Congress of Berlin. Three persons, including an 8-year-old boy, died in two Manhattan tenement fires yesterday.

ST. PETER, sitting in his chair outside the gates of the Promised Land, was reading the "Arrivals" column in the newspaper, which he held folded in halves, the way a former commuter had showed him to do it.

Hayes Alan Jenkins of Colorado Springs, Colo., and Tenley Albright of Newton Center, Mass., were outstanding in figure skating in 1954. Jenkins captured both the world and United States championships for the second straight year.

The School of Advanced International Studies of the Johns Hopkins University is creating a new unit, to be known as the Bologna Center and to be located in Bologna, Italy. It will begin. its first semester of operation next March. The Center will stress European studies and will concentrate on Austria, Germany, France and Italy. Eventually it plans to cover a larger portion of Western continental Europe.

IT was a good year 1954 for bridge players, all things considered. No one told the average player he should forget all the old systems and learn a new one, and no change was made in the laws and scoring.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Dec. 25 -- A late shopping surge shoved Christmas sales to a new high level last week and the aggregate was about 2 per cent ahead of the previous banner season of 1952. Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N. J., founded in 1916 for underprivileged children of New Jersey, will have its annual theatre benefit here on Jan. 15.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 25 -- Two independent Presbyterian publications have announced plans to merge on Jan. 1. LONDON, Dec. 25 (UP) -- Europe celebrated its biggest and gayest Christmas since the war today.

That the largest warship in the world and one of the most formidable weapons in the nuclear age should bear the name of James V. Forrestal seems fitting. To keep order in the Times Square area New Year's Eve, the Police Department will assign a force of twenty officers and thirty sergeants and 500 men to the district. An additional score of men will be on reserve at near-by precinct houses, making the total 570.

Rocky Marciano of Brockton, Mass., made two successful defenses of the heavyweight championship of the world. Each was against Ezzard Charles of Cincinnati. The latter made a surprisingly close fight of it in the first meeting, at the Yankee Stadium on June 17.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 25 -- France's final decision on the Paris accords for arming West Germany was awaited in official Washington today with anxiety and apparent lack of optimism that the Atlantic alliance plans would progress smoothly.
Department stores here had the benefit of an extra shopping day in the final week before Christmas Day and sales volume gained accordingly in the year- to-year comparison.

IN a burst of generosity and sartorial spirit befitting the holiday season, an unknown lady recently contributed a shiny silk hat to one of the carriage drivers up Central Park way. PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 25 -- Wage payments and working time rose 1 per cent in Pennsylvania factories from October to November, but the number of workers remained unchanged at about 1,200,000. MATSU-NO-UCHI -- Japanese for the first seven days of the New Year -- are a time for fun and feasting. In Japan, homes are festooned at their entrances with greens, new kimonos are worn, debts settled, calls made, cards sent, gifts presented and foods eaten that have a special symbolism.

CHICAGO'S Midway Airport, handling a flow of air traffic hardly dreamed of when it was built, soon will get some major relief. TRENTON, Dec. 25 -- The New Jersey Turnpike is financially the most successful toll road yet constructed in this country.

SYDNEY, Australia, Sunday, Dec. 26 -- America got the break in the draw, and so Tony Trabert will meet Australia's Lewis Hoad in the big "pressure match" that will open the 1954 Davis Cup challenge round at the White City tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 15 (UP) -- The Senate's own private security clearance program was dead today.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 25 -- Two editorial officials of a defunct opposition newspaper each were sentenced to a year in prison today for having "insulted the moral personality of Turkish justice." Basketball regained considerable prestige this year. Attendances rose, as evidenced by the 221,678 fans who witnessed twenty-four college programs at Madison Square Garden. The professionals fared even better. They drew 221,079 spectators on nineteen Garden dates.

WHAT John Randolph once called a "talent for turbulence'' was Gen. Ben Butler's principal attribute. It was at first merely a part of his natural inheritance, but by practice he developed it into a high art. As the conqueror of New Orleans he earned the sobriquet "the beast."

Goddard College (Plainfield, Vt.) will sponsor a "Great Ideas in Education" meeting on Jan. 16, at the Carnegie Endowment Building, taking the theme "Anti-Intellectualism in America Today." The conference will consist of two panel sessions with speakers reviewing the effects of the current trend of anti-intellectualism in all phases of American life.

At the end of great masses of figures on population, "in-migration,'' working forces, manufacturing employment, age groups and economic fluctuations in California, Margaret S. Gordon comes to some disturbing conclusions: More than any other state, California is dependent upon a high level of defense spending, especially for aircraft.

A recent Supreme Court decision has opened the door to challenge of many conditions imposed in recent years by the Maritime Administration in connection with the transfer of American vessels to foreign flags, the Association of American Ship Owners declared yesterday.
Overcrowding in the city's prisons has become a dangerous and worsening problem.
This is the second of three articles on Russia food. The third will appear next Monday.
The Rev. Dr. Robert McAfee Brown outlined yesterday what he called the perils involved if one is to take Christmas seriously.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy announced today a speaking drive after the first of the year to press his demand for a "blockade" of Red China.

The election of Charles J. Stewart as a director of the Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company was announced yesterday. Mr. Stewart is a general partner in the New York Stock Exchange firm of Lazard Freres Co.
Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the atomic scientist who has had his own troubles this year, pictured all men yesterday as struggling in a changing world.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 26 (AP) -The East and West squads held only one drill each today in preparation for their Shrine football classic in San Francisco's Kezar Stadium on New Year's Day.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Robert Lee Sherrod, Far East representative for The Saturday Evening Post, will become the magazine's managing editor sometime next spring.

Following is the text of an address on "Prospects in the Arts and Sciences" by Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, director of the Institute for Advanced Study, Princeton, N. J., which closed yesterday the year-long Columbia University bicentennial celebration:

The 1954 accomplishments of the Maritime Administration and Federal Maritime Board were called "sound, progressive achievements'' in a year-end review issued yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, who heads both agencies.
Shipping men, brokers and agents found more cargo under their Christmas trees this year than they could handle. It contrasted to last year's "Valley Forge" observance of the charter industry.

Max Wylie, novelist and author of two textbooks on radio and television writing, has a new book on Funk Wagnalls' list for Jan. 10 publication. In "Clear Channels: Television and the American People," Mr. Wylie takes a look at the problems of television, replies to the medium's detractors and details its faults.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Senator A. S. Mike Monroney, co-sponsor of a 1946 law to streamline Congress, said today there was still room for improvement.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 26 (UP) -- A Swiss police official said today that Hermann Field showed little surprise at his brother Noel's decision to remain behind the Iron Curtain.

PASADENA, Calif., Dec. 26 (AP) -Three coaches and one player who met both Rose Bowl teams in battle this year looked into their Christmas crystal balls today and came up with some opinions about the Ohio State-Southern California game next Saturday.
CAIRO, Dec. 26 -- Members of the Moslem Brotherhood now in prison may have their sentences reduced if they respond favorably to a proposed rehabilitation program.

The Prime Ministers of the "Colombo Powers," Burma, Ceylon, India, Indonesia and Pakistan, are scheduled to meet tomorrow in Indonesia. They will be there at the invitation of the Indonesians to discuss a meeting next spring of the so-called African-Asian group.
PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Political observers agreed tonight that Premier Pierre Mendes-France had a chance of persuading the French National Assembly tomorrow to ratify the arming of West Germany.

A rugged individualist endowed with multiple capacities, Gian-Carlo Menotti again aims to demonstrate his versatility as composer-author-lyricist-director-orchestrator of his latest opus, "The Saint of Bleecker Street."

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Dec. 27, (AP) -- Tony Trabert sent the United States into a 1-0 lead over Australia in the Davis Cup challenge round today with a 6-4, 2-6, 12-10, 6-3 victory over Lew Hoad.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Consumers in sixty-six areas will be tapped during the next two months for information on their spending and saving habits and plans. The canvass is the Federal Reserve Board's tenth annual survey of consumer finances.

SOME of the older patrons of John Wanamaker's have worried over what might happen to the solid gold World War I-II memorial plaque with the names of the dead store's war dead. One woman said, "It may even be that the management today doesn't realize that the memorial is gold, and may scrap it."

KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 26 -Moslem leaders in fourteen countries, from Morocco to Indonesia, have begun a propaganda campaign in support of Pakistan in her seven-year-old dispute with India over Kashmir.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Representative Frederic R. Cou dert Jr., Republican of Manhattan, said today he and Senator Karl E. Mundt, Republican of South Dakota, would sponsor companion bills in the next Congress to revise the Presidential election procedure.

Victory eluded the New York Rangers once more at Madison Square Garden last night. Muzz Patrick's skaters were ahead through most of their National Hockey League clash with the Chicago Black Hawks, but when it was all over the best the New Yorkers could show was a 4 to 4 tie.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Postmaster General Arthur E. Summerfield warned today against offers of free diamonds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -Senator Hubert H. Humphrey urged today that Congress investigate the dismissal of Wolf Ladejinsky as agricultural attache in Japan and its bearing on the United States attitude toward "world land reform."
Rocky Marciano, the world heavyweight champion, yesterday was chosen as the "fighter of the year" by Ring Magazine.
ROME, Dec. 26 -- Pope Pius was said to be "getting on very nicely" this morning after another restful night.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Senator McCarthy said the United States should free Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek to attack the "soft underbelly" of the China mainland.

The St. Mark's-Hill School hockey rivalry to be resumed at Madison Square Garden next Thursday afternoon apparently is here to stay. Although the series began only last season, the two head coaches are envisioning an annual schoolboy classic.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, Dec. 26 -- The Netherlands Government is to issue a 3 1/4 per cent forty-year loan at par for an amount to be fixed after subscription to consolidate the internal debt and finance redemption of foreign debt.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 (UP) -- A distinguished atomic scientist said today that Americans might be giving the Soviet Union too little credit for nuclear and military progress.

Well, it is over now. It has gone for another year, vanished into the vale of departed days. Remember just a little back how the world felt sorry for Scrooge, or at least for the Scrooge before the closing moments and his redemption? Remember that?
The Eintracht eleven of the German-American Soccer League blanked Brookhattan-Galicia of the American League, 3 to 0, at Zerega Oval in the Bronx yesterday.

A bill will be offered in the Legislature to create a Judicial Conference of nine judges. Its purpose is to administer more efficiently the complex system of courts that costs New York State $40,000,000 a year.

Fire Commissioner Cavanagh deserves the thanks, and the sympathy, of the public in his forthright efforts to stamp out gratuities to firemen for expected favors -- sympathy because it is hard to have to sentence offenders who have had otherwise excellent records in the service, some with brave rescues to their credit. These considerations have probably warranted him in not imposing on some offenders the full punishment of dismissal which the department regulations provide.
The Wife of Morton Sobell, an engineer convicted of conspiracy to commit espionage, appeal to President Eisenhower yesterday to have her husband transferred from Alcatraz to a regular Federal prison.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 26 --The John Andrews-Don McClave boat, Tide Water, took the lead, on unofficial tabulation, for the Indian Harbor Yacht Club winter championship today. '

Lawrence H. Berlin, United States Vice Consul in Nagasaki, Japan, sent $25 to the Neediest Cases Fund of The New York Times. The gift was made in honor of his father, Dr. Henry Berlin, who died Dec. 9.

Teams representing Columbia, Fordham and Swarthmore triumphed in the first round of the biennial tournament for the team championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League yesterday in John Jay Hall at Columbia University.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 26 -United Productions of America will undertake production of three full-length cartoon movies in color, with the first to be a production of the James Thurber story, "The White Deer."

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 -- It was confirmed today that Mlle. Mitra Mitrovic, one of Yugoslavia's leading Communists, had been called to account for her political attitudes. She appeared before a control board of the Communist Central Committee, of which she is a member.

DUBLIN, Dec. 26 -- The Golden Jubilee of the Abbey Theatre is being celebrated in Dublin tomorrow with special performances of two of the plays with which it opened, "On Baile's Strand," by W. B. Yeats, and "Spreading the News," by Lady Gregory.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 26 -- President Eisenhower was prepared tonight to cut short his Christmas vacation if the French National Assembly voted tomorrow against arming West Germany. Although the President did not say so himself, some of his aides indicated his concern over the French situation.

The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has bought the entire blockfront on the west side of Fifth Avenue from Forty-fourth to Forty-fifth Streets from the Bank of New York for improvement with an office building in which the bank has leased back space.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 26 -- Expansion of the existing frontier defense force into a regular army may be taken under advisement should the French assembly reject the Paris agreements.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 22 -- Another crossing of San Francisco Bay may be put under construction by the middle of 1956.
CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- The situation in the West and Southwest, where the hard winter wheat crop is endangered by the protracted drought, came to the front as a market factor late last week.

The announcement that President Eisenhower will press for a liberalized foreign-trade program in the Eighty-fourth Congress is news only in the prominence and emphasis given it. In his role of middle-of-the-road Republican Mr. Eisenhower has stood consistently for extending the Reciprocal Trade Agreements Act.
Apparently not satisfied that "Fanny" seldom plays to an empty seat at the Majestic, the musical's producers are trying to stir up additional trade -- from abroad.

ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- The appointment of Theron A. Johnson as administrator of the Education Practices Act was announced today. The State Commissioner of Education, Lewis A. Wilson, said Mr. Johnson would succeed Dr. Frederick H. Blair, who has been named adviser to the Ministry of Education of Ethiopia.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 26 (Reuters) -- The Serbian Orthodox Church has launched a drive against what it calls the serious danger of proselytizing activities by Protestant sects, who are winning over many of its believers.

IF Herb Sheldon is in the house, wrap up all the Peabody awards and give them to the guy. There may be others in television who from time to time perform a public service, but Herb merits a citation embossed in the purest gold.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The makers of British policy spent an uneasy holiday estimating the Value and viability of a Western European alliance without the French.

Sunny weather, holiday services and family visiting brought out large crowds here yesterday for a Sunday-after-Christmas celebration. Pleasant echoes of the Yuletide were still strong in the city and the suburbs.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 26 (AP) -Navy is favored to defeat Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl football game Saturday, but a young college coach is positive the midshipmen will have to be at their best to do it.

Cotton prices in the domestic market generally were higher last week. At the close of its abbreviated session on Friday active future contracts on the New York Cotton Exchange were up 14 to 40 points from the close of the preceding week.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 26 (AP) -Billy Kenville's tap-in basket broke an overtime tie and started the Syracuse Nationals to a 97-92 victory over the New York Knickbockers tonight. The Nationals thus regained the lead in the Eastern division of the National Basketball Association.
DETROIT, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Gordie Howe's third-period goal lifted the Detroit Red Wings to a 1-1 tie with the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight before 13,105 fans at Olympia.

Invitation tournaments dominate collegiate basketball this week, and one of the spotlights will be focused on Madison Square Garden today, where day-night double-headers are booked for the third Holiday Festival play.
JASPER, Tex., Dec. 26 (UP) -- A Christmas Day gun battle in the East Texas range country left one man dead and three wounded today.
Interest in the foreign exchanges last week was affected by pre-holiday dullness and except in isolated instances rates were maintained without major change.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -The C. I. O. today urged members of the Eighty-fourth Congress to give active support to increased economic and military aid to friendly nations.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A State Attorney said tonight that no evidence in the Sheppard case was concealed by the prosecutor's office.

THIS is the high tide of Himalayan mountaineering. In the past few years brave men have climbed high mountains in the Himalayas that never had been climbed before. Anapurna was conquered by the French, Everest by the British, Nanga Parbat by Germans and Austrians and K2, the second highest mountain in the world, was ascended last July by an Italian expedition led by Ardito Desio.

Thomas E. Dewey retires from public office at the end of this week after a period of service to the people of New York State extraordinary both for its length and its fine quality. The only Governor elected to three successive four-year terms, he has served with unflagging interest in that office longer than any Chief Executive save New York's first, George Clinton.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 (UP) -Coach Paul Brown appeared more excited than his Cleveland Browns players today after they won the National Football League title.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- Christmas was not an occasion of merriment this year for Pierre Mendes-France. His Reveillon, the famous French gastronomical performance on the night of the twenty-fourth, was a simple dinner at home with his wife. They drank water.
Death was the victor in a fight early yesterday between two youths and an off-duty patrolman.
The National Foundation for Infantile Paralysis has granted $98,317 for research at Mount Sinai Hospital on the importance of hormones and brown fat in resistance to polio.
HONG KONG, Dec. 26 -- Chou En-lai has declared that Britain's support of the United States on the Formosa question has impaired London's relations with Peiping.

In this era of big things there is an attraction about little things. It is at least a momentary relief to turn from the vast areas and populations of the great Powers to consider Andorra, which has 191 square miles; Lichtenstein, which has 65 square miles; San Marino, which has 38 square miles, and Monaco, which has developed some characteristics all its own inside frontiers enclosing a little over half a square mile.
ZURICH, Switzerland, Dec. 26 -- The rate of exchange of the Dutch florin, or guilder, in multilateral arbitrage in European Payments Union currencies has unexpectedly resumed its upward trend.
Marian Anderson will make her debut at the Metropolitan Opera as Ulrica in Verdi's "Un Ballo in Maschera" on Friday evening, Jan. 7. The opera is being revived after a six-season absence.
Lewis L. Strauss says that his present Government post will be "my last public job on earth."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- President Eisenhower is taking a greater interest in the machinery of Republican politics right now than ever before.
SALT LAKE CITY, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Mike Katsanevas' six Christmas presents stepped off an airliner today, filling his arms and his heart.

Puccini's "Tosca," missing for a season, returned to the Metropolitan Saturday evening. No really new faces were cast, though Licia Albanese, who sang the title role, had done so only once previously in her Metropolitan career.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 26 -- The Cleveland Browns upset the Detroit Lions, 56 -- 10, today to win the professional football championship of the nation. Otto Graham, the Browns' great quarterback, was the outstanding player.

I'd like to take issue with Martin Hellman's letter approving dual jobs. Having averaged five jobs a year for the past twenty years, I can testify that one pays a price in poor health, neglect of wholesome family life, not giving of one's self wholly to the one main job.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The Post Office Department's continued delivery of "junk mail" is headed for trouble with the incoming Congress.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -An Administration tax-cutting plan to encourage investment of private American capital in foreign lands won the backing today of a Senate advisory committee composed of 125 labor, agriculture, business and banking leaders.
Firemen rescued early yesterday a barge captain who had fallen into the East River between a barge and the stringpiece at Thirty-third Street.

A five-story building containing seven apartments and two stores and occupying a lot 17 by 100 feet at 57 West Fifty-fifth Street, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues, has been sold by Robert J. Sabatini to an investing client of the Devon Improvement Corporation. Walter Scott Co. were the brokers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The American Merchant Marine Institute called on Congress today to rejuvenate the United States commercial fleet as "the fourth arm of national defense."
JERUSALEM, Dec. 14 -- Government and city authorities who have been trying to curb pork consumption through administrative action are running into the law.

In the College Point section of Queens, the neighbors have stopped laughing at Anders Person and telling him he was crazy to think he could build a welded-steel sea-going boat alone. The boat, a sixty-foot ketch, is in the waters of a cove off Flushing Bay.
Individuals today should have a "universal" outlook on religion, the Rev. Robert Cope said here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -Pay rises and other benefits to be sought for the armed services next year are aimed primarily at the Air Force and in keeping skilled military technicians in uniform, Fred A. Seaton, Assistant Secretary of Defense, said today.

Financial and automotive advertising showed the sharpest rises over 1953 levels both in November and in the year to date, according to a report yesterday by Media Records on newspaper linage in fifty-two cities.

The directors of the Baldwin-Lima-Hamilton Corporation announced over the week-end the promotion of McClure Kelley to executive vice president and of Oliver DeG. Vanderbilt 3d to director and vice president in charge of all commercial activities.

In the temple of the Vedanta Society of New York at 34 West Seventy-first Street, the Swami Pavitrananda spoke yesterday of the essential unity behind the Christian and Hindu religions and all of the other religions and sects of mankind.
Plans for the scheduling of daily all-cargo trans-Atlantic flights before the end of 1955 have been disclosed by Juan T. Trippe, president of Pan American World Airways.

To Prof. Theodore Nichols' recent letter on the problem of "job shortages" for Ph. D.'s in the social sciences and humanities, may I add "Amen" and also note that the problem has even deeper roots than Professor Nichols has suggested.

Prayers for the persecuted people behind the Iron Curtain were offered yesterday at St. Patrick's Cathedral. The prayers were part of the celebration of the Feast of St. Stephen, the first Christian martyr.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -The Treasury changed its regulations today to let more investors buy savings bonds and two World War II issues of Government securities. The changes go into effect Jan. 1.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- Members of President Eisenhower's Cabinet vowed today to continue in 1955 to strive for lasting world peace through economic and military strength.
The following is a list of new products that may be of interest to the homemaker:
Four and 5 year olds may not know their mother's first name.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 26 -- About four-fifths of Germany's investment in her bid to return to the airways in the coming year is going into establishing a transatlantic service to New York.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 26 -- Steel output did not decline as much as seasonally last week. Though finishing mills were shut down, many furnaces continued to make steel over the holidays -- another sign of the strength in the steel market.
Two new films, including an import from England, are due this week as the year's final first-run offerings. The programs follow:

CHICAGO, Dec. 26 -- The Stewart - Warner Corporation announced today that its electric division would withdraw from the manufacture and sale of home radio and television receivers and phonographs within the United States.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- United Nations and United States efforts to bring about Israeli Arab acceptance of a plan for joint development of the Jordan River valley are now "approaching a climax."
MOSCOW, Dec. 26 -- At least three authors whose works had been severely criticized here in the past appeared today on the new board of directors elected by the Union of Soviet Writers.

LONDON, Dec. 26 -- Although there is no mistaking the strong bullish tone that still underlies the stock markets, they were somewhat overshadowed on the eve of the Christmas holiday by the threat of a general railway strike early in the new year and by continued nervousness over the course of money rates.

OTTAWA, Dec. 26 -- Both the United States and Canada suffered from "an inventory recession" in 1954 but the prospects for continued prosperity in 1955 are good, C. D. Howe, Minister of Trade and Commerce, declared today in his annual review of Canada's economy.

The Erie Railroad Company will earn about $1.78 a share on its common stock this year before capital and sinking funds, compared with $4.31 last year, Paul W. Johnston, president, informed stockholders over the week-end.

A sturdy, mentally alert little woman noted her ninety-first birthday yesterday. She is Mrs. Regina Margareten, still active as treasurer and director of Horowitz Brothers Margareten, manufacturers of kosher food products.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The National Planning Association predicted today that unemployment would rise next year and thereafter unless Government and industry acted to increase consumer buying power and industrial production.

VIENNA, Dec. 26 (UP) -- A "security leak" today bared the hush-hush Christmas mission here of two United States State Department couriers. Their usual assignment is carrying secret diplomatic dispatches to United States offices behind the Iron Curtain.

LARCHMONT, N. Y., Dec. 26 -Corny Shields, with Dainty, and Howie McMichael, with Chicken, led the Larchmont Yacht Club frostbite fleet today, each with 296 points. Eight races were sailed in the opening regatta of the mid - winter championship series.

Yesterday evening's concert by the "Y" Symphonic Workshop at the Lexington Avenue Young Men's Hebrew Association turned out to be an operatic workshop as well. The opening half of the program was devoted to symphonic music by Bach-Ormandy and Mendelssohn (the First Symphony) conducted by Maurice Levine.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- Dairy leaders are pressing a world milk-barter plan.

The aftermath of the holidays may leave rings on the marble coffee table and tinsel ground into rugs, as well as a sizable supply of dirty laundry. Not a very pleasant vista. New booklets dealing with these household problems may give information that will make the post-holiday clean-up easier.
ALBANY, Dec. 26 -- Governor Dewey appointed today a twenty-one-member committee to represent the state at the White House Conference on Education next fall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -- The Ambassador of Pakistan said today that any small-scale United States economic aid to Asia would be canceled by Asia's population growth.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, Dec. 26 (AP) -- A 32-year-old American woman who had been ordered to leave Britain by Tuesday flew here from London today with her husband-to-be. He is a British subject and she will receive British citizenship by marrying him here.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The Home Loan Bank Board announced over the week-end the names of directors elected to Federal Home Loan banks in the various districts.

Grants Made to Institutions From Which 16 Executives Were Graduated Grants to fourteen colleges and universities were announced yesterday by the C. B. S. Foundation, Inc., which handles philanthropic matters for the Columbia Broadcasting System.

ONCE upon a time the Rose Bowl brought together the two best college football teams in the country for the equivalent of the national championship. One of the most momentous and memorable of all Rose Bowl games was waged thirty years ago this Saturday -- which demonstrates how swiftly time whisks along.

The Grand Union Company, a food chain, had a net profit of $801,401 in the quarter ended Nov. 27, the highest for any three-month period in its eighty-two-year history. This was reported by Lansing P. Shield, company president, in a statement issued for release today.

Direct obligations of the United States Government in the hands of the public that will mature within twelve months amount to $71,324,761,442. They consist of Treasury bonds, certificates of indebtedness, bills and notes as follows:
A post-Christmas present of pier peace was promised yesterday to the Port of New York.
HILLSDALE, N. J., Dec. 26 -- Churchgoers who plan to celebrate the beginning of a new year this week-end were cautioned today to "observe sobriety and act as a Christian, not as a pagan."

Five tenement and rooming-house fires in New York last week killed six people outright and injured several others who barely managed to escape with their lives. How, far these tragedies might have been avoided -- or at least the victims given a fighting chance of survival -- can never be known.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman has accepted an invitation to address a special meeting of the state executive board of the Congress of Industrial Organizations in Albany on Jan. 12.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 26 -- Israel has furnished credit facilities to expand trade and re-emphasize her ties with Turkey.

Industries concerned with the nation's health have never before faced greater research opportunities or obligations, Robert Wood Johnson, board chairman of John son Johnson, declared yesterday in a year-end statement.

The United States has been unable to confirm reports that Joseph Cardinal Mindszenty, Roman Catholic Primate of Hungary, has been released from a Communist prison, Representative Alvin M. Bentley, Republican of Michigan, said yesterday.

Donald Byrne of the University of Michigan was the sole winner in the sixth round of the Lessing J. Rosenwald trophy chess tournament yesterday. He defeated George Kramer of Philadelphia in thirty-three moves at the Marshall Chess Club.

The fifty-fifth annual bird Count of the National Audubon Society got under way yesterday in this country, Canada and Alaska. It will continue through Jan. 2. Reports on the tally will be filed with the society's headquarters, 1130 Fifth Avenue, by Jan. 17.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (AP) -- The aircraft industry, largest manufacturing employer in the United States, said today that its 1954 sales totaled $8,600,000,000, a hundred million dollars more than last year.

MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 26 (AP) -- Howard Abbey, Miami Shores, piloted his 200-horsepower twenty-foot runabout around the island of Miami Beach this afternoon at an average speed of 41 miles an hour to win the twenty-four mile marathon race that opened the Orange Bowl regatta.

FINDING two Drapers in one's Christmas stocking is rare luck indeed, particularly in view of the fact that Ruth Draper had announced earlier this year that she would not return to New York. Evidently her devotees would have none of her farewells, for here she is again, this time at the Bijou, lovingly rolling out her drawer of verbal cameos.
Six New York University faculty members will fly today to Ankara, Turkey, to participate in the new $1,500,000 educational assistance program at the University of Ankara.

SYOSSET, L. I., Dec. 26 -- Ground was broken here today for the new $40,000 synagogue and religious school building of the North Shore Jewish Congregation, a Reform group. Construction will start tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -The Cities Service Oil Company has received special tax benefits on the construction cost of its new $6,800,000 facilities for processing natural gasoline at Midland County, Tex., the Office of Defense Mobilization announced today.

Last July, under the heading, "World Economic Panorama," this writer dedicated three consecutive pieces here to a project he had long promised himself he would one day undertake. The articles dealt with the then recently issued 1953-1954 report of the Bank for International Settlements, the twenty-fourth of these annual reviews of world economic developments since that institution established its headquarters at Basle, Switzerland, in 1930.

The question, "Is coexistence possible?" or "Is coexistence desirable?" is like the question, "Do you believe in baptism?" It appears to make the self-evident debatable, and to give forensic victories to those who have in effect said nothing at all.
HARTFORD, Dec. 26 -- Abraham A. Ribicoff is expected to take a "middle of the road" approach to Connecticut problems in his inaugural message as Governor Jan. 5.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 26 -- Sixty-five hundred students are enrolled in the University of Maryland's College for Members of the Armed Forces Overseas.

PARIS, Dec. 26 -- A new conflict has developed over the liberalizing of French trade. The Government recently announced that in January 75 per cent of the quota restrictions would be lifted, leaving customs duties as the sole means of protection.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 (UP) -The Army has developed an adhesive that can take the place of soft solder in the joining of certain metals.

The appointment of John Trubin as first assistant Attorney General of New York State was announced yesterday by Attorney General-elect Jacob K. Javits. Mr. Trubin, chief counsel to the Moreland Act Commission on Workmen's Compensation, served as Mr. Javits' campaign manager in his successful race against Franklin D. Roosevelt Jr.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 26 -- The stirrings of the new political and Congressional year were felt today in this quiet capital as the old year was dying.
The Very Rev. Dr. James A. Pike assailed United States military authorities yesterday for a tentative agreement with Spanish military authorities on marriages of American personnel in Spain.
The city mapped plans yesterday to "throw the book" at landlords judged to be responsible for the mounting toll of illuminating gas poisonings and deaths.
May I extend for two brief paragraphs the editorial "'Porgy' Makes a Hit," in the Dec. 23 issue?

The slogan, "There's a Ford in Your Future," became a reality yesterday for three youths in the Bronx. Each acquired a 1954 model without going through the usual formalities. And so, after a weird series of collisions, three names were added to the police blotter at the Bathgate Avenue station.

The Indians had the pitching and they had the power, so it was not surprising when the Clevelanders were made the 18-10 favorities to win the world series from the New York Giants. Certainly, the Giants had a chance, and if you had money to burn, you could get 20-1 against a New York sweep.
The body of another victim of the Dec. 18 Italian Airlines crash at New York International Airport, Idlewild, Queens, was recovered today by Navy divers.

J. Thomas Freeston has been elected a director of Ethicon, Inc., New Brunswick, N. J. He is personnel director of the company and previously was training director of Johnson Johnson Company, the parent company of Ethicon.
The Long Island Transit Authority said yesterday its mission had been accomplished but it was compelled to remain in existence anyway.
CINCINNATI, Tuesday, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The father of Tony Trabert said today the Davis Cup victory of his son and Vic Seixas was predicted by Tony Christmas night.

The eighty-six-foot fishing vessel Catherine C. and the tanker Gulfstream collided about thirty-five miles south of Ambrose Lightship last night, but no one was reported injured. Both ships were able to proceed under their own power toward New York.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Dec. 27 -- A professorship of Slavic languages and literature has been established at Harvard University by Curt Hugo Reisinger of 730 Fifth Avenue, New York. It will bear his name.

The communications media contributed a large share of yesterday's gifts to the forty-third annual appeal of the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. The amount received for the day was $8,978,22 from 447 donors.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 27 -- John Barrymore Jr. has been signed to star in "Walker Dick and his All-American Boys" to be produced independently by Sidney Salkow, the writer-director.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 27 -- President Eisenhower conferred today with his chief advisers on budgetary and fiscal matters.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Supreme Court was asked today to safeguard the right of due process of law under the Government's personnel security program.

THERE was a strange and eerie parallel between the 56-10 rout of the Detroit Lions by the Cleveland Browns in the championship play-off the other day and the 73-0 humiliation of the Washington Redskins by the Chicago Bears in the historic title show of 1940. It isn't an exact parallel, of course. But there are striking similarities.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Duntreath Farm's heavily backed Van Crosby suffered an unexpected defeat by W. L. Curles' Mintaway in the seventh race at Tropical Park today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Believers in Moral Re-Armament, an international movement hoping to improve mankind, assemble here tomorrow to explore "an idea to win the world."

Arthur Garfield Hays, lawyer, who died Dec. 14 at the age of 73, left his estate of undetermined value in trust for the benefit of his two daughters and a friend. His will was filed for probate yesterday in Surrogate's Court.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Representative Francis E. Walter, Democrat of Pennsylvania, said today the House Committee on Un-American Activities might put its forthcoming hearings in Newark, N. J., on television if allowed to do so.
Columbia and City College shared the lead after the second round of the biennial National Intercollegiate Chess League championship at John Jay Hall, Columbia University, yesterday.
A drastic reduction in the price of Victor records was announced yesterday. The new prices, for both classical and popular music in the 33 and 45 r.p.m. disks, will go into effect next Monday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- Vice President Edvard Kardelj delivered a scathing attack today upon Milovan Djilas, ousted former Vice President, and Vladimir Dedijer, biographer of President Tito. The expulsion of M. Dedijer from the Communist party Central Committee is now a foregone conclusion.

A Soviet textbook on international law, published by the Institute of Law of the Academy of Sciences of U. S. S. R. (Moscow, 1951), contains a section on "Scouts and Spies." On Page 525 of the official textbook we read: "A scout is considered to be a person in military uniform who penetrated into the lines and the rear of the enemy and collects information necessary to his commanders."
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Government today contracted to sell two more synthetic rubber plants -- one at El Segundo, Calif., and one at Baton Rouge, La.
ITHACA, N. Y., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Cornell University today announced the formation of an advisory council for its School of Business and Public Administration.
TRENTON, Dec. 27 -- Gov. Robert B. Meyner announced today that he would appoint a citizens committee to decide the fate of Morven, the proposed Executive Mansion, in near-by Princeton.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Average primary market prices remained unchanged at 109.4 in the week ended last Tuesday, according to the Bureau of Labor Statistics. A slight increase in the index for farm products was balanced by lower prices for meats.

JIMMA, Ethiopia, Dec. 7 -- Nine young instructors from the Oklahoma Agricultural and Mechanical College have developed a thriving agricultural technical school here. The group is under contract to the United States Foreign Operations Administrations mission (Point Four).

The New York Knickerbockers, toppled from the Eastern Division lead in the National Basketball Association Sunday night at Syracuse, will have an opportunity to regain first place tonight at Madison Square Garden.

The holiday atmosphere continued in the New York futures markets yesterday. Activity was very light on almost all commodities. Hides, however, registered their greatest daily sales in more than two years, and rubber volume was substantial.
GREENWICH, Conn., Dec. 27 -- The Oppenheim Collins Department Store on the Boston Post Road failed to open its doors here today because, it was declared, "this is a very poor business community.''
LONDON, Dec; 27 (AP) -- Sunderland moved to the top of the English Soccer League standings today as the mighty Wolverhampton Wanderers suffered their second defeat in three days.

Public housing and redevelopment authorities having subsidy contracts with the Public Housing Administration and the Federal Housing and Home Finance Agency plan to borrow more than $255,000,000 next month.
CHICAGO, Dec, 27 (AP) -- Butchers lost about 50 cents a hundred pounds, while sows were steady to 25 cents lower today. Salable receipts were quite large, at 19,000 head, 5,000 more than a week ago.
FLINT, Mich., Dec. 27 (AP) -- Charles S. Mott, a General Motors Corporation director and Flint philanthropist, today was named "big brother of the year."
The Cessna Aircraft Company in the fiscal year ended Sept. 30 increased its net income to $2,175,433 from $1,127,000 earned in the preceding fiscal year.
Davis Cup competition began in 1900 when a United States team defeated the British Isles, 5 -- 0, on the Longwood Cricket Club courts in Boston.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- Ending twenty years of resistance, the Westchester Park Commission proposed today that preferential treatment for county residents be provided experimentally next year at a public golf course.

PARIS, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -- France's acceptance of West Germany as an armed ally in the Western coalition appeared assured early today. The National Assembly voted, 289 to 251, to ratify a protocol inviting the Bonn Republic to join the fourteen nations adhering to the North Atlantic Treaty.

Without political background before he was catapulted to the Presidency, Dwight D. Eisenhower can hardly be blamed for not having known much about the intricacies of party machinery. But Mr. Eisenhower has had two years to learn; and there are indications now that he is determined to take positive steps to mold the Republican party in the direction of that progressive moderation which he has set as his ideal.

NEWARK, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Newark Airport will be enlarged during the next twenty years to handle more flights to points within the United States, the Port of New York Authority aviation director said today.

Massachusetts may seek an investigation of the purchase of stock in the Boston and Maine Railroad Company by three individuals frinedly to Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad.

Although the buying power of the American people should be somewhat greater in 1955 than in 1954, business must "aggressively create new markets if the economy is to show more than modest gains, over 1954," Dr. Leland I. Doan, president of the Dow Chemical Company, said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Short-term borrowing costs of the Treasury dipped today from the eleven months' high reported last Monday.

Gross operating revenues and net income of the Baltimore land Ohio Railroad for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 were 18.7 per cent and 50.3 per cent, respectively, below results achieved in the corresponding period of 1953.
Cash registers played a merry Christmas tune in New York City's department stores. Sales surpassed expectations and may have set a new record for the holiday season.

GIAN - CARLO MENOTTI'S "The Saint of Bleecker Street," superbly performed at its premiere last night in the Broadway Theatre, is Italian "verismo" opera, with a dash of modern psychology added to it, and thrust home with a technique of the musical theatre of which Mr. Menotti is the unique master.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A manufacturer's news release indicated today that the supersecret Snark intercontinental pilotless bomber had been transferred to the East Coast for testing.
BUFFALO, Dec. 27 (UP) -- St. Bonaventure defeated Columbia, 73 -- 71, in the first Queen City invitation basketball tournament tonight.

The Western World escaped a major crisis last night -- and France avoided another Government upheaval. This fortunate turn came when the French National Assembly began to reverse its irresponsible pre-holiday rejection of a Western European Union and in a more sober mood voted to admit a rearmed Germany into the North Atlantic alliance.

A broad background of travel copy will tie together advertising for five British products in a six-page unfolding advertising section in the January issue of Vogue. The section, developed much like a travel folder, will carry the running headline, "Fashions From Britain, in Fashion Everywhere."
Woodrow Wilson's contribution to humanity and American higher education was extolled yesterday, on the eve of the ninety-eighth anniversary of his birth on Dec. 28, 1856, in Staunton, Va.
A little Brooklyn girl, who for nearly five years has battled pain and disease to keep up with her playmates, will go on her first long trip tomorrow
WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- A Westchester grand jury investigation of use of policy courtesy cards by county motorists to avoid traffic tickets was ordered today.
KALO, the blacksmith of Jharma village in Bengal, was a simple man with a vast ignorance.

The Manhattan Society for Mental Health was organized yesterday at a meeting at the Union League Club, 38 East Thirty-seventh Street. G. Montagu Miller, vice president of Young Rubicam, Inc., advertising agency, was elected president of the new group, which will work to prevent and treat mental and emotional illness.

The New Year will bring a fresh start on labor unity efforts. Committees representing the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations will meet in Washington Jan. 4 to renew their search for a unity compact.
ROME, Dec. 27 -- The Vatican news service commented officially today on the considerable distance Pope Pius has traveled toward recovery in the last few days.

As one of his final administrative acts Governor Dewey has appointed a broadly representative twenty-one-member committee to speak for New York State at the White House Conference on Education late next fall. Its chairman will be Kenneth C. Royall, former Secretary of War, and its vice chairman Tracy S. Voorhees.

The year 1954 has seen the profits of American industry hold up remarkably well. It is also important to note that 1954 has seen considerable gains for the consumer in the form of lower prices, better quality goods and higher pay. The Bureau of Labor Statistics reports that such basic foods as oranges, bacon, eggs and coffee are all down in price, while meats, poultry and fish have dropped to pre-Korea levels.

Thomas Rust Chadwick, general sales manager of the Thor Corporation, predicts chaos in the marketing of the major household appliances in which his company specializes if other manufacturers cease to "suggest" retail prices.
TOKYO, Dec. 27 -- Communist China stepped up its campaign for Japanese friendship today with an invitation to fishing experts to visit Peiping.

John J. Mann, a former page boy on the old New York Curb Market, yesterday became the first man to be nominated for a fifth term as chairman of the board of the market, now known as the American Stock Exchange. The annual election is to be held on Feb. 14.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The announcement today reported that Colonel Stapp, who has both M. D. and Ph.D. degrees, made the rocket sled test on Dec. 10.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange was quiet but steady yesterday and closing prices were unchanged to 16 points up. The far months were relatively strong.
A Bronx grand jury will investigate a street fight in which an off-duty patrolman shot and killed a sailor early Sunday morning.

" Civilization and Foreign Policy," an analysis by Louis J. Halle, will be published Jan. 5 by Harper. The author, until recently a member of the State Department policy-planning staff, discusses the fundamentals of western civilization and explores its character.

Verdi's "Don Carlo" received its second presentation of the season last night at the Metropolitan Opera. Two of the singers were heard in the opera for the first time this season. Jerome Hines sang the role of Philip II and Delia Rigal substituted as Elizabeth for an indisposed Eleanor Steber.

A total reduction of $4,500,000 in the assessments for the three tax years 1951 through 1953 on the thirty-six-story office building at 100 Park Avenue has been ordered by the First Department of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court.
MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 27 -- A Nassau County highway patrolman arrived an hour late for duty today, but his superiors were not angry. On his way to work he saved a boy from drowning.
ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 27 -- Turkey told the Arab states today they must collaborate closely with the rest of the free world if a viable defense system was to be created in the Middle East.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 27 -- The ratification debate in the French National Assembly was followed tonight by the West German Government and its coalition parties with a resignation born of despair.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Attorney General Nathaniel L. Goldstein said today that Indians must obey the New York State conservation laws.
CAIRO, Dec. 27 -- Five large rowing oars were found today on the 4,700-year-old solar barque of the Pharaoh Cheops.
The Yuletide Assembly Ball was held last night in the ballroom suite of the Ambassador. The ballroom was decorated to resemble the interior of the sixteenth century palace of Felipe II of Spain.

A 68-year-old inventor who is world-renowned, and yet isn't, turned up recently with a new aircraft design that bears watching. In an office in Kew Gardens, Queens, he and a small engineering staff are drawing blueprints for a novel helicopter.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- They used to say of the late Senator Borah that he was "always in session," whether or not Congress was. That was because, being politically entrenched in Idaho, Borah stayed in Washington and was often the only --and ever-productive -- Congressional news source in the capital.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Coach Eddie Erdelatz took one look today at the plump Navy football players scheduled to oppose Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl game Saturday and ordered a double workout.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., Dec. 27 -- A third-degree assault charge against Lou Amonson, football coach and physical education teacher at New Rochelle High School, was dismissed this afternoon by City Judge Christopher J. Murphy.
Americans counted a ghastly two-day Christmas death toll yesterday, higher by far than they had ever known.

With the largest backlog of orders it has had in six months, and with new products in production for every principal customer market, American Locomotive Company enters 1955 as a decidedly different company from what it was a year ago.
Most of the city's businesses expect 1955 to be a better year than 1954, according to the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
Humberto (Chico) Fernandez, the infield star who may push Capt. Peewee Reese of the Dodgers from his familiar shortstop post to second base, was signed by the Brooklyn club yesterday.
Billy McNeece, Central Islip, L. I., middleweight, gained a split decision over Bobby Dykes, Miami, Fla., in the main bout of ten rounds at the Eastern Parkway Arena, Brooklyn, last night.

MADRID, Dec. 27 -- Three issues of The New York Times of last week have been banned from Spain by the Government Censorship Bureau. According to local distributors, they were those of Dec. 20, 22 and 23, which contained dispatches from Madrid and an editorial that evidently met with official disfavor.
The experienced skier has definite ideas on fashions for this sport. No snowbunny, as the amateur is called, she eschews gadgety frills and likes the most functional and workmanlike of designs.

RALEIGH N. C., Dec. 27 (UP) -- North Carolina State and Duke, co-favorites, breezed to victories, while North Carolina staged an upset and Minnesota won a hard-fought contest in the opening round of the sixth annual Dixie basketball classic today.
The Shrine football game in San Francisco between college players of theEast and West will be presented over the DuMont television network beginning at 4:45 P:M on Saturday.
GENEVA, Dec. 27 -- Distribution was started today of United States gifts of food and medicine to victims of recent Danube Valley floods, most of them residents of places behind the Iron Curtain.
Police Commissioner Francis W. H. Adams announced yesterday that 750 men would be sworn in Friday as probationary patrolmen.
LOS ANGELES, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Desert winds swept out of the canyons in gusts reaching hurricane force today. They contributed to millions in damage in the Los Angeles area.
Shipping employers joined union leaders yesterday in predicting a new waterfront peace agreement today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The French National Assembly's vote admitting West Germany to the Atlantic alliance evoked a sigh of relief, but hardly jubilation, in official Washington. The State Department had no immediate comment. In Augusta, Ga., where President Eisenhower is vacationing, his press secretary, James C. Hagerty, said the President "is gratified at the turn the proceedings have taken."

CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Scattered showers and snow flurries in the southwest drought area took the edge off demand for wheat futures today. Old crop deliveries held better than new crop futures, the latter being off nearly cents before support steadied the market.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 27 (AP) -- The discovery of a mysterious system of "brakes" that helps control growth was described today at another association symposium.

Baker, Weeks Co., members of the New York Stock Exchange and other exchanges, announced that coincident with the thirtieth anniversary of the firm's founding it would open an office in Montreal and a representative's office in Geneva, Switzerland, on Friday.
