Herbert K. Crabtree and Arthur A. McLaughlin will become resident partners in the Montreal office.
LONDON, Dec. 27 -- Shipyards on the Clyde River in Scotland, Britain's chief shipbuilding center, have established a postwar record by producing this year 177,204 gross tons of shipping.

The oath was administered yesterday to Adrian P. Burke, new associate judge of the Court of Appeals, at a ceremony in the Appellate Division Court House, 45 Monroe Place, Brooklyn. Mr. Burke, now City Corporation Counsel, was elected to the fourteen-year term on Nov. 2.

DETROIT, Dec. 27 (UP) -- A wildcat strike by forty-two metal grinders at the Mack plant of the Chrysler Corporation automotive body division spread to the night shift tonight, and made idle 17,000 workers.
Dr. Miles Atkinson wrote an indignant prescription yesterday for the City of New York.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 27 -- The Malverne L. I., Little Lions today were named the national 100-pound football champions by the Pop Warner Football Conference.

THE southern fishing season will open with a flash of silver and a flurry of spray, for the International Light Tackle Sailfish Tournament is scheduled for the Palm Beaches from Jan. 10 to 14, inclusive.
ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- Governor Dewey announced today the appointment of a nine-member council for the State University's Maritime Colege at Fort Schuyler in the Bronx.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 23 -- Scientists in Southeast Asia are warning that time is running out in man's battle against one of his most deadly enemies -- malaria.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- The Illinois Toll Highway Commission suffered a legal setback today in its program to build 191 miles of toll roads at a cost of $390,000,000.

MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Dec. 27 (UP) -- A group of educators and intellectuals from nine American countries cabled Argentine President Juan D. Peron today asking for the release of several hundred university students imprisoned for more than two months.
Mr. and Mrs. Edward Cox Brewster of 969 Fifth Avenue gave a large supper dance last night at the St. Regis Roof and Penthouse to introduce their daughter, Miss Diana Brewster.
A 27-year-old beer salesman was booked on a charge of grand larceny in Long Island City, Queens, yesterday, charged with garnering $50,000 in the last two years through a car-selling fraud.

The second annual Joseph Burstyn Award for the best foreign-language picture of the year was presented yesterday to "Gate of Hell," the first Japanese color feature to be shown here. The presentation was made by Independent Motion Picture Distributors Association of America at a luncheon ceremony at Rosoff's Restaurant, 147 West Forty-third Street.

SINCE Mr. Menotti's work is an opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street," which opened at the Broadway last evening, is being reviewed by Olin Downes, an old friend and colleague, in the adjoining cubicle.
A miniature United Nations is the Student Holiday Center here. This is an information and social center for the several hundred foreign students who visit New York during Christmas vacation.
DETROIT, Dec. 27 (AP) -- A Navy officer and a Roman Catholic pastor took the witness stand today in behalf of Famous Lockett, a Navy civilian employe who is battling suspension on security grounds.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (AP) -- The Commercial Travelers Insurance Company of Salt Lake City, Utah, has agreed to a consent order barring false and misleading advertising of its health and accident benefits, the Federal Trade Commission announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 (UP) -- The Department of Commerce placed rigid restrictions today on the export of fifty-three categories of classified technical information.
MADRID, Dec. 27 (UP) -- Three of Germany's top aircraft designers under Adolf Hitler have "kept their hand in" since 1949 by working closely with aeronautical factories in Spain.

Sihugo Green led Duquesne and Tom Gola paced La Salle into the semi-finals of the Holiday Festival college basketball tournament in the day-night competition at Madison Square Garden yesterday. Joining the two top-favored quintets in tomorrow night's round of four were U. C. L. A. and Dayton.

An agency set up to help improve the lot of the Japanese farm wife is observing its seventh anniversary this month. It is the Home Extension Program of the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture. Mrs. Mary W. Standlee describes its work in the current issue of The Journal of Home Economics.

Red China's quite articulate Premier, Chou En-lai, has done some more fulminating against Great Britain because Britain persists in being too friendly to the arch-fiend, the United States. This has a hollow ring. It sounds very much as if Chou's divisive tactics had not been as successful as he had hoped.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -- Closer relations between Japan and the Soviet Union and Communist China were urged today by Premier Ichiro Hatoyama.

Twenty-five hundred children, land a few adults who managed to talk their way in by saying they were brought by their youngsters, attended yesterday a post-Christmas party given by Carmine G. DeSapio.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Defense and State Departments moved today to nip a controversy over a proposed agreement on religious rights of Americans at United States air bases in Spain.

The last two troupes of Vienna Choir Boys who have toured this country have by-passed New York, so the twenty-two boys who sang at Town Hall last night were the first choristers from the famous choir school to sing here since the Christmas holiday season of 1949.

With inventories below normal, retailers are buying briskly for spring, it was reported yesterday during the second day of the showing of lines by members of the Metropolitan Juvenile Style Mart, Inc.

SOUTH ORANGE, N. J., Dec. 27 -- Russ Lawler's one-handed push shot from the side as the final buzzer went off gave Stanford a 65-63 victory over previously unbeaten Seton Hall University before 3,224 here tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec, 27 (UP) -- The Navy announced today a stepped-up program for training officers in nuclear engineering. The aim is to provide men for atomic-powered vessels.
Pierre Bezin and Paul Arpejou ought to know what they are doing at La Potiniere, the small restaurant they have just opened at 47 West Fifty-fifth Street.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- The Board of Regents announced today the granting of a charter to the Firehouse Nursery School at East Meadow, L. I., even though it had forced the school to move out of the firehouse from which it gets its name.

The Reece Report has much to say about the Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences. What it has to say touches my honor as an editor and a scholar, as I was associate editor, responsible for the whole scholarly content of the work.

The Misses Mary-Elizabeth Allen and Sidney Bacon, debutantes of this season, were honored at a dinner dance given last night in the Pierre Roof by Miss Bacon's godfather, Lauder Green-way of New York and Kincraig, Greenwich, Conn.

For the first time since the war we Japanese feel that we are beginning to have a democratic Government -- a Government run by a man who is courageous enough to go among the people, talk with the people and listen to their voices.

Burglars broke into the office of a novelty factory at 345 West Twenty-sixth Street over the week-end and escaped with $10,000 in cash and $25,000 of jewelry and merchandise, the owner reported to the police.
SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 27 -- Gov. Luis Munoz Marin has acted to remove the first threat of a scandal in his fourteen-year administration.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 27 -- The Prime Ministers of Pakistan, India and Burma received elaborate state welcomes today. They arrived here to attend a meeting of the five Colombo powers.
The Way was paved yesterday for the election later this week of Albert V. Maniscalco as Borough President of Richmond.

HARTFORD, Conn., Dec. 27 (AP) -- A 20-to-1 split in Travelers Insurance Company's stock will be recommended to the stockholders if the Connecticut General Assembly authorizes the company to amend its charter, it was reported here today.

Operations in the nation's steel plants dropped to 72.4 per cent of theoretical capacity last week as a result of curtailments for the Christmas holidays, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday. The rate for the previous week had been 81.8 per cent.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 27 -- The United States has promised to grant Yugoslavia 850,000 tons of wheat to tide her over a critical shortage until the next harvest. Only half of that amount had been announced previously by the United States.
Shipping men here report a "hardening" in the once friendly and solicitous attitude of Japanese shipyards toward foreign shipowners discussing new tonnage to be built in the Far Eastern nation.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 27 -- The Government and the United Fruit Company signed this afternoon a new operating contract giving Guatemala 30 per cent of the company's yearly profits in taxes.
The General Dynamics Corporation has elected three new directors, John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president of the aircraft, submarine and electronics producer, announced yesterday.
CHICAGO, Dec. 27 -- Officials of Kenner Hospital here announced today that they were withdrawing the institution from the Blue Cross insurance plan.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 27 -- Observations of 800 galaxies show that the material universe was born in a gigantic cosmic explosion some five and a half billion years ago.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The United States Public Health Service urges school systems to give pupils time off to go to the dentist.

It is good news that Eric Johnston, going to the Near East next month as the President's special envoy, has a fair chance to get an agreement between Israel and the Arab states for the joint development of the waters of the river Jordan. Agreement "in principle" was reached last June.

SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Dec. 28 -- After four years of bitter frustration, the United States won back the Davis Cup today. Half a world from home, Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas defeated Australia's Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall, 6 -- 2, 4 -- 6, 6 -- 2, 10 -- 8, in the doubles match to decide the challenge round.

Except for a short-lived rally in the fourth hour, the stock market declined steadily yesterday. Motors, oils and chemicals were soft, as tax considerations appeared to govern the thinking of traders.

QUITO, Ecuador, Dec. 27 (AP) -- Usually reliable sources said today that the police had arrested Lieut. Col. Jorge Echeverria, named by President Jose Maria Velasco Ibarra as the ringleader in a plot last week to overthrow the Government.

Emergency measures against overcrowding in the city's prisons have kept it from getting out of hand. But the problem is still far from solved. The first to concede this is the city's Commissioner of Correction, Mrs. Anna M. Kross.

ROME, Dec. 23 -- Winter pilgrims to Assisi, the birthplace of St. Francis, are startled to find bare walls in the Upper Church where they expected to see the famous Cimabue frescoes. But next summer the grandiose and severe angels will be back in their place, restored and protected from further deterioration.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Lieut. Col. John P. Stapp has slammed to a stop in a rocket sled in one and a half seconds after attaining a record land speed of 632 miles per hour.

An expanded program of educational television was predicted last night by Dr. David D. Henry, executive vice chancellor of New York University and chairman of the Joint Committee on Educational Television.

AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 27 -- Tension built up since last Friday, when the French Assembly rejected a resolution providing for the arming of West Germany, still was apparent around the "little White House" tonight.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- One of Governor-elect Averell Harriman's first economies is expected to be the elimination of Joe R. Hanley's post as special counsel to the Division of Veterans Affairs. The post pays a salary of $16,000 a year plus $7,000 for secretarial and office expenses.
Executive changes involving the promotion of three officials of James W. Elwell Co. and the retirement of a fourth were announced here yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 27 -- Germany has experienced a book boom in the last four months. Booksellers report sales far above anything experienced since the war.

MINEOLA, L. I., Dec. 27 -- The Nassau County Board of Supervisors unanimously adopted today a local law providing permanent personal registration for the county's 500,000 voters. The action followed a public hearing here.
PARIS, Dec. 7 -- "Paris must have a Museum of Costume," says Mme. Madeleine Vionnet, one of the great pre-war couturiers and an ever-active friend of the couture today.

New city legislation to punish giving of gratuities to city employes as a misdemeanor has been delayed. The delay was disclosed yesterday to stem at least in part from warnings by the Association of the Bar of the City of New York.

Negotiations between David O. Selznick and Metro-Goldwyn- Mayer, whereby Mr. Selznick would produce feature films independently for M-G-M release, were acknowledged yesterday by both Mr. Selznick and Nicholas M. Schenck, president of Loew's Inc., M-G-M's parent-company.

The Baldwin - Lima - Hamilton Corporation, a major manufacturer of locomotives, earth-moving machinery and heavy industrial equipment, confirmed reports yesterday that it was negotiating "regarding an affiliation" with Hydropress, Inc., and the latter's subsidiary, the Loewy Construction Company, Inc.
MOSCOW, Dec. 27 -- In the last few days the weather finally has provided some work for Moscow's snow-removal organization, one of the largest and most efficient in the world.

Cesar Brion, heavyweight performer from Cordoba in the Argentine, outpointed Dan Bucceroni of Philadelphia in the feature bout of ten rounds at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. The South American won a split decision.

NORFOLK, Va., Dec. 27 -- The big carrier Midway left her home port of Norfolk today for immediate duty with the Seventh Fleet in the Far East. The craft had been based here since commissioning in 1945.

The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday that it had a net income of $7,429,506 in the eleven months to Nov. 30, 1954. This was equal to $6.01 a share on the outstanding common stock, and compares with a net of $6,493,250, or $5.27 a share, in the comparable eleven months of 1953.
GREENVILLE, S. C., Dec. 27 (UP) -- Furman-downed New York University, 93 -- 85, tonight in a rough basketball game in which six N. Y. U. players were banished on personal fouls.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- Research institutions in New York State have been awarded $2,446,926 by the National Institutes of Health for research next year against disease.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 27 -- Hofstra gained the semi-finals in the fourth annual Christmas invitation basketball tournament tonight with a 66-62 victory over Lehigh.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 27 -- The Republican-run Post Office Department has ruled it is legal for admirers of Adlai E. Stevenson to paste his sayings on envelopes and packages in the mail.

United Arthur B. Bisguier, United States chess champion, and George Kramer of Philadelphia were the winners last night in the seventh round of the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Marshall Chess Club.

The men's clothing industry operated at 70 per cent of capacity during the first eleven months of this year, compared with 80 per cent in the 1953 period, the Clothing Manufacturers Association of the U. S. A. reported yesterday.
Clifford Odets' new play, "The Flowering Peach," starring Menasha Skulnik, will have its Broadway premiere at the Belasco Theatre this evening at 8 o'clock.

ALBANY, Dec. 27 -- A newly organized Republican Policy Committee had its first meeting here today. Its primary purpose is to develop and coordinate Republican policy for dealing with Governor-elect Averell Harriman and his Democratic-Liberal state administration.

The mysterious disappearance of diamond rings having a retail value of $65,000 from a Fifth Avenue jewelry store during business hours was reported yesterday to the police. They listed the loss as a theft.
Mrs. Anna M. Kross, City Commissioner of Correction, is aiming at long-range rehabilitation as a permanent solution of the critical overcrowding in the city's prisons.

DUNKIRK, N. Y., Dec. 28 (UP) -- A sixty-five-car eastbound Nickel Plate freight train was accidentally switched to the wrong track and plowed into a stationary six-car wrecking train here today. Seventeen crewmen were injured, none seriously.

Ron Howel, 19-year-old member of the Guelph hockey team of the Ontario Hockey League, will play for the New York Rangers against the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night. A younger brother of Defenseman Harry Howell of the Broadway Blues, Ron will play right wing on a line centered by Don Raleigh, with Pete Conacher at left wing.

The electronics industry should roll up an "outstanding" sales volume next year, Frank Folsom, president of the Radio Corporation of America, said yesterday. This will be accomplished, he said, by introduction of new and improved products, "coupled with continued vigor in merchandising that proved so successful during the past year."

Nearly all of the record companies yesterday were "studying" the price cuts announced on Monday by R. C. A. Victor. "No comment" was the invariable answer of the major companies when questioned about future plans and policy.

ANKARA, Turkey, Dec. 28 -- Five hundred fifty-six dock union members are standing trial at Izmir (Smyrna) on charges of having staged Turkey's largest labor walkout. Strikes and other organized work stoppages are illegal in this country.

Broadly speaking, the authorities -- public and private -- are in a far better position today to deal with excesses of one kind or another in the securities market than they were in the Twenties. Both the Exchanges themselves and the Securities Exchange Commission are policing the markets at all times for evidence of "pools" or "wash sales."

Convenience for the cook as well as tastiness for the eater distinguished many of the new products placed on grocers' shelves last year. Taking stock at year's end, we have compiled a list of some of the most noteworthy of these products.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Dec. 28 -- Merger of the Berkshire Fine Spinning Associates, Inc., and the Hathaway Manufacturing Company is being discussed.
BOSTON, Dec. 28 -- Homer's heroes were nearly as tall as the average American, evidence suggests from recent studies of opulently incarcerated Greeks of the second millennium B. C.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Humphrey Bogart and his business manager, Morgan Maree, were preoccupied today with contractual negotiations.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Federal Power Commission granted certificates to four interstate pipeline companies today authorizing construction of $80,000,000 worth of natural gas transmission and underground storage facilities to serve the New York-New Jersey area.

DENISON, Tex., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Taxes, the farm program and extension of reciprocal trade agreements will be early objectives of the new Congress, Mr. Rayburn said today as he prepared to leave for Washington.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Leaders of the National Union of Railway men refused today to call off a nation-wide strike they had ordered for Jan. 9.

With sales to establish profits or losses for 1954 tax purposes mostly out of the way, the stock market breathed more easily yesterday. Pressure removed, operators bought again and prices advanced to the best levels of the recovery movement.

ATLANTA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A 40-year-old former paratroop surgeon, whose wife found him dying beside the body of a woman patient in the latter's home, suffered a stroke and died of natural causes, an autopsy disclosed tonight.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- The fifty-seventh annual convention of the National Business Teachers Association opened here today with more than 800 educators registering for the three-day meeting.

MADRID, Dec. 28 -- Generalissimo Francisco Franco is expected to meet Don Juan of Bourbon in Spain tomorrow. The meeting with the pretender to the throne has been set at the estate of a wealthy Spaniard near Caceres, about eighty miles from the Spanish-Portuguese border.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The absence of Senator John F. Kennedy when the new Congress convenes on Jan. 5 is not expected to impede the organization of the Senate by the Democrats.
Down in South America live four relatives of the Old World's camel -- the alpaca, llama, guanaco and vicuna. All four, like the camel, have hair that makes fine fabrics.

OAK RIDGE, Tenn., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Atomic Energy Commission has let contracts totaling nearly $60,000,000 for construction and expansion of uranium refining and processing plants in Missouri and Ohio. S. R. Sapirie, A. E. C.'s Oak Ridge operations manager, said yesterday Fruin-Colnon Construction Company, St. Louis, and Utah Construction Company, San Francisco, had received a joint contract for $39,800,000.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The State Commerce Department said today that New York's economy showed some weak spots but was "essentially sound and dynamic."
MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- The skyscraper phase of construction in the Soviet Union is drawing to a close.

A $1,000-a-month consultant for the American Association for the United Nations -- paid by funds donated by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt -- made public his resignation yesterday. He added a sweeping attack on the unofficial, nonprofit group.

Strategic plans of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, including those of the United States, for the defense of Europe must inevitably be affected by the bitter French debate about German rearmament. This despite what appeared yesterday to be an affirmative vote on rearmament.
The junior fashion department on the second floor of Saks 34th displays a smart collection of spring styles for figures ranging from sizes 5 to 15.
Tidied-up comic books carrying the seal of approval of the recently formed Comics Code Authority are expected to appear on newsstands early next week.

NICOSIA, Cyprus, Dec. 28 -- (Reuters) -- A five-year plan to expand Cyprus port facilities and develop Nicosia as an international air traffic center was outlined today by Sir Robert Armitage, British governor of this Eastern Mediterranean island colony.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The 59-year-old curate of historic St. Peter's Episcopal Church was beaten to death early today in his bachelor quarters near the heart of the city.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec 28 (UP) -- Andrew J. Crevolin's Imbros equalled his track record at Santa Anita today as he raced to a length victory in the $23,900 Palos Verdes Handicap before an opening-day crowd of 31,000.

The Louisville and Nashville Railroad Company had a net income of $16,677,221, equal to $7.13 a share, for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30, it was announced yesterday. This represents a decline of 41.5 per cent from the $28,508,807, or $12.18 a share, reported for the corresponding period of 1953.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Peter Mueller, German middleweight, rallied after three knockdowns in the fourth tonight to score a seventh-round knockout over Ernie Durando of Bayonne, N. J. The ending drew a violent protest from the loser's manager, Al Weill.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Navy is gunning for more than a football victory over Mississippi in Saturday's Sugar Bowl game.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Marines said today they had eliminated the M-1 carbine as a weapon.
First Assistant Corporation Counsel Leo A. Larkin asserted yesterday that riders of the Long Island Rail Road faced the certain prospect of further fare increases.
ROME, Dec. 28 -- Ambassador Clare Boothe Luce left by plane for the United States today for three weeks of consultations in Washington. Her husband, Henry R. Luce, left with her.
The steady trend toward longer, lower and more powerful automobiles is complicating life for the nation's traffic and highway authorities.
The Presbytery of New York chose the Rev. Dr. Paul Silas Heath of Buffalo yesterday as its general presbyter to succeed The Rev. Dr. Theodore F. Savage, who has retired.
New York's and probably the world's most modern marine terminal was officially opened yesterday to the blare of band music, the whirring of helicopters, and the spouting of city fireboats.
BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 28 -- Vladimir Dedijer, former intimate of President Tito, today faced criminal prosecution on charges of engaging in hostile propaganda.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP) -- The State Department said today it would "very much like to see an agreement reached" on United States commercial air operations in India.
The roof fell in on the New York Knickerbockers last night. And it had to happen before Madison Square Garden's largest professional basketball crowd of the season -- 14,813 spectators.
The election of Arthur B: Foye as a member of the New York University Council, governing body of the institution, was announced yesterday by George E. Roosevelt, president of the council.
The police and the office of Chief Fire Marshal Martin Scott were investigating yesterday a possible link between a three-alarm fire in Brooklyn and a man found dead of burns seven blocks away.

Play followed form yesterday in the Eastern indoor junior tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory. George Mandel of Astoria, Queens, and Lawrence Nagler of Roslyn Heights, L. I., No. 1 in the junior singles and boys' singles, respectively, entered the quarter-finals with straight-set victories.

LONDON, Dec. 28 -- The stock market was quietly firm in nearly all divisions today. Most of the leading industrials rose modestly and several British Government securities finished one-sixteenth of 1 per cent better.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Debate in colleges and universities on whether the United States should recognize Red China was approved today at a conference sponsored by the Speech Association of America and other speech organizations.
The pattern of price cuts in the floor coverings industry was established yesterday.

STORRS, Conn., Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Brown basketball team, with a 2-4 record, contributed the second upset in three games in the opening round of the New England college tournament here tonight by beating previously undefeated Colby, 64 -- 57.

ATLANTIC CITY, Dec. 28 -- An assistant vice president of Atlantic City's largest bank was arrested by Federal Bureau of Investigation agents early tonight on a charge of misappropriating funds of the bank.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey approved today a program under which Federal surplus food will be distributed to private charitable agencies and some municipal institutions outside New York City.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Approximately 1,100 Deepfreeze plant workers today entered into a stock buying drive to block sale of their company.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 28 -- More consideration for foreign interprises and capital in Indonesia was advocated as part of an "urgency program" in the economic field adopted by the National Congress of the Masjumi (Moslem) party in Surabaya yesterday.
Heavy advertising in newspapers was credited yesterday with selling CinemaScope to the public and with helping to "revive the movie industry's confidence."

Tom and Jerry, a favorite New Year's drink, is usually made in individual portions. To serve a group easily and quickly make a batter allowing one egg and one tablespoon sugar for each serving. Beat egg white till stiff, adding sugar gradually and beat till stiff.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Rubber Producing Facilities Disposal Commission announced today that it would recommend closing the Government-owned plant operated by the General Tire and Rubber Company at Baytown, Tex.
BUFFALO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Fordham Rams overcame a stubborn five from Columbia, 67 -- 62, tonight in the semi-final round of the losers' bracket of the Queen City invitation basketball tournament.
The widespread "present-mindedness" of modern historians who are preoccupied with current affairs was deplored yesterday at the annual convention of the American Historical Association.

Cocoa futures soared the 1-cent-a-pound daily limit in all positions yesterday on the New York Cocoa Exchange. Volume was light, however, amounting to only 140 lots. Light dealer buying and short covering induced stop-loss purchasing.
Spyros P. Skouras, president of Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, predicted yesterday that the movie industry was in for one of its greatest years in 1955 both at home and abroad.
Robert Moses made public yesterday details of his plans to develop hydroelectric power from Niagara Falls.

New York's subway system may be in for some changes. Latest news from the underground front is of plans to issue timetables for the hours between 10 P. M. and 6 A. M. so that travelers need no longer stand around for uncertain periods in deserted, freezing stations.
HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Rita Hayworth and Columbia Pictures reached an agreement today in Reno, Nev., for a two-picture contract, the studio announced tonight.
LONDON, Dec. 28 -- Britain has decided to give new constitutions and partial self-government to five colonies in the Caribbean.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- All kinds of vital statistics records are being broken as the old year bows out.

The Libbey-Owens-Ford Glass Company announced yesterday in Toledo that directors had approved a $25,000,000 expansion of plate glass manufacturing facilities. Work is planned to go forward in 1955 as rapidly as engineering plans can be completed.

Having won three-quarters of his battle for ratification of the Paris pacts, Premier Mendes-France goes into the final test today with the demand that the National Assembly reverse its previous rejection of the Western European Union and approve the Paris agreements as a whole.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The National Association of Evangelicals urged the Government today to refuse to sign any agreement with Spain that would bar service men stationed there from being married by a chaplain of the United States armed forces.
The Republican leadership modified yesterday its position on a possible increase in state taxes.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Senator Mike Mansfield proposed today a 25 per cent pay increase for all enlisted men in the armed forces.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 28 -- Dr. Edward U. Condon was described tonight as the victim of "a present sickness in our country -- a sickness of rumor and anxiety.
January was proclaimed yesterday at City Hall as March of Dimes month in New York.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The United States Tariff Commission today announced it had decided against recommending any duty increase in imported wool gloves and mittens and mitten linings.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Government announced today that overseas military air mail would be shifted immediately to scheduled commercial airlines.
The City Council in special meeting yesterday elected former Representative James J. Murphy as the Councilman from Richmond to succeed Albert V. Maniscalco.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The civil division of the Department of Justice reported today that it recovered more than $30,000,000 for the Government this year.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The Clinton Machine Company of Clinton, Mich., has filed suit for $15,000,000 triple damages against the Briggs Stratton Corporation in Federal Court here alleging monopolistic practices in the mall machine business since 1946.

Chesapeake Industries, Inc., investment company, is going ahead with the acquisition of the Colonial Trust Company and four affiliated enterprises, William C MacMillen Jr., president of Chesapeake, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) Fourteen Negro school girls made their debuts last night at the Willard Hotel. The formal party was the first of its kind in memory at a downtown hotel.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- James P. Mitchell, Secretary of Labor, said today that the United States had to eliminate job discrimination based on age, handicaps, or racial and religious prejudice.
GUATEMALA, Dec. 28 -- A special National Constituent Assembly commission recommended tonight ratification of two agreements signed yesterday by the Government and the United Fruit Company.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Certain murals in the somewhat fusty old French National Assembly are painted in that outmoded style known as trompe-l'oeil for its deceptive appearance. In parliamentary argot the same expression is applied to bills that may be regarded as what we call eyewash.
This is to commend you for your editorial of Dec. 20 on Wolf Ladejinsky. I waited until I could read the statement of the Department of Agriculture before commenting.
VIENNA, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Three Americans previously reported held in forced labor camps are now at a Soviet discharge center, newly returned prisoners of war said today.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 28 -- The Syrian-Israeli Mixed Armistice Commission failed today to adopt a motion censuring Israel for the seizure of a Syrian Airways plane on Dec. 12. The Syrian motion failed when the neutral United Nations chairman abstained from voting.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 (AP) -- A sharp reduction in hog receipts, caused in part by wet weather in the Midwest, sent prices swirling upward today. Department of Agriculture reports of livestock trading here today:

THERE is an irresistible tendency on the part of sports analysts to forget that athletes are human beings. Instead, the athletes are regarded as machines that must follow the normal, prescribed method of operation as soon as the switch is thrown to start the motor. That's why we have upsets. That's why we find a he-can't-miss prospect who misses badly.
ONLY a few hundred New Yorkers have the right and the equipment to tune in on radio station KEA 627, which operates on 43.5 megacycles and sends nothing but code numbers.

" On the Waterfront," Columbia's presentation of Horizon Pictures' smashing dramatization of crime and labor racketeering on New York's docksides, was voted yesterday the best picture of the year by the New York Film Critics.

The bond market sems to have taken in stride the holiday-period borrowings for public works projects. Prices stiffened this week after a fortnight of retreat. New flotations appear to have been well digested.

On behalf of the United Parents Associations I should like to commend The New York Times for the public service it has performed by running two editorials on Dec. 20 and 22 urging appointments to the Board of Education on the basis of merit and qualifications.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The incoming Speaker of the House of Representatives said today he would not allow televising of House committee hearings.
Closing of the Oppenheim Collins department store in Greenwich, Conn., last Friday involved twenty-seven regular employes. All were offered other positions in the organization.

A $10,000 legacy, the $12,500 proceeds of a trust fund and $3 earned by Christmas carolers figured prominently in gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday. The day's contributions of $31,413.26 brought the total this year to $352,887.72, moving to within $9,185.94 of the amount recorded on the corresponding day of last year's appeal.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- French ratification of West Germany's inclusion in the North Atlantic Treaty did not evoke enthusiasm today among politicians and newspapers here.
MR. ODETS' new play is a beautiful one. His finest, in fact. "The Flowering Peach" he calls it. It opened at the Belasco last evening with a tender, lovely, humorous performance.
Thirty-six steps toward conquering cancer, taken at the Memorial Centers for Cancer and Allied Diseases in the last few years, were noted yesterday in its biennial report.
CAIRO, Dec. 28 -- An expedition of Egyptologists and engineers has been dispatched to Upper Egypt to survey a 200-mile stretch of the Nile valley.

SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Rex Hartwig, less than two weeks out of a sick bed, and Ken Rosewall, the slim little bomber from Down Under, saved Australia from utter humiliation today by winning the final two singles matches of the Davis Cup challenge round from the United States.

Premier Adnan Menderes of Turkey is giving the world proof that -- at least so far as he is concerned -- the democratic principles espoused after 1946 were nothing but a thin veneer. We see him now reverting to autocratic and dogmatic patterns. He is crushing freedom of the press and has actually arrested and put under trial 556 members of a trade union in Izmir who engaged in a four-day walkout.

THE versatility and good sense of George Gobel continues to be one of the season's major pleasures for the television viewer. Of the scores of programs that in one way or another observed the Christmas holiday his was unique in its felicitous fusion of simplicity, sincerity and humor (10 P. M. Saturday over the National Broadcasting Company network).
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The Eisenhower Administration has quietly dropped plans to ask Congress to modify the "Buy American" Act.

Reduced operating costs enabled the Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation and its subsidiaries to lift net earnings 92.5 per cent to a record $6,381,000 in the quarter ended Nov. 30. The net was $3,314,000 in the similar period last year.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- The West German Communist party opened its congress in Hamburg today. Thirty-two resolutions attacked the Paris agreements, called for the reunification of Germany in free elections next year and presented "an action program for the working class."
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Two former Democratic Governors of New York will attend the inauguration of Averell Harriman Saturday.
KENOSHA, Wis., Dec. 28 (AP) -- American Motors Corporation today began turning out 1955 model Nash and Hudson cars in sequence on a single final assembly line in Kenosha.
Charles Hamm of Exeter scored two victories as play began yesterday in the sixth annual Princeton Club Cup junior singles tournament sanctioned by the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

HOLYOKE, Mass., Dec. 28 -- Hugh J. Corcoran, president of the Board of Aldermen, today voiced opposition to a proposal that Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad, become a director of the Holyoke and Westfield Railroad.

Your editorial "France at the Crossroads" refers to the French National Assembly as "the most confused and irresponsible parliamentary body in the democratic world." No doubt the Assembly justly merits the criticism in this case. But it should be pointed out that the United States may have inadvertently contributed to some of this confusion, and that the irresponsibility may not be entirely confined to the French.
With the fortitude of their calling, publicity men -- only briefly deterred by an international crisis -- will send a "milk mission" to France this afternoon.
Waterfront union and employer representatives recessed early this morning until later today their efforts to iron out the last few obstacles to a new pier peace agreement.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Moral Re-armament opened a world assembly today to preach faith through strengthened moral standards.

Regardless of how other issues of foreign affairs are settled, the United States has won back the Davis Cup. We had been down under too long, since our last victory in 1949. The decisive ambassadors this year were Vic Seixas and Tony Trabert, who, by winning their singles in four-set matches on the first day and their doubles also by three sets to one, finally mastered the brilliant Australians Lew Hoad and Ken Rosewall.

Commissioner of Correction Kross is applying to the problem of over-crowded city prisons a philosophy born of wide experience and far-reaching vision. Since she took office last January this philosophy has taken concrete shape in a program that deserves public recognition and support.
HARTFORD, Dec. 28 -- Mistreatment of children at the New Haven County Home in West Haven was charged tonight.
Maritime labor in traditional seafaring countries still regards the merchant fleets of Costa Rica, Honduras, Liberia, and Panama as threats to labor standards.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 28 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will leave Thursday for Peiping to seek the release of Korean war captives held by Communist China. Among those imprisoned are eleven United States fliers accused of being spies.
Fresh as the breezes that blow over the Aegean Sea were the resort fashions presented at Best's yesterday.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 28 -- The Prime Ministers of the five Colombo powers held the first session of their two-day meeting this afternoon. The only decision announced was an agreement that the conference of Asian and African nations that the Premiers had convened here to arrange would take place the last week in April.

PORTLAND, Ore., Dec. 28 (AP) -- Oliver A. Wyman Jr., 33 years old, president and principal stock-holder of the bankrupt Yarmouth Rug Guild Corporation, was fined $1,000 in United States District Court today for using the mails to defraud a New York concern of $8,413 in March, 1953.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 28 -- President Eisenhower today chose Gov. John Davis Lodge of Connecticut as Ambassador to Spain.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 -- Expansion of the tractor and implement division of the Ford Motor Company to make it a major competitor in that field was announced today by Irving A. Duffy, vice president and general manager of the expanded division.

" Anastasia," starring Viveca Lindfors and Eugenie Leontovich, arrives at 8 o'clock this evening at the Lyceum. The Guy Bolton adaptation of Marcelle Maurette's melodrama, originally written in French but not yet seen in Paris, concerns the legendary survival from assassination of the last Czar's youngest daughter.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- The promised Democratic inquiry into the Eisenhower Administration's security program developed today.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- Important shifts among the Popular Republicans and conservatives helped in large measure to turn last Friday's unexpected defeat for Premier Pierre Mendes-France into this morning's victory.
HONG KONG, Dec. 28 -- Red China has signed agreements with the Vietminh to provide advisers, technicians and equipment for developing and re-orienting North Vietnam's communications systems.
RICHMOND, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Virginia Tech used its height advantage today to down Rutgers University, 88 -- 77, in the first round of the first Richmond invitation basketball tournament.
The Union of Orthodox Rabbis of the United States and Canada, at a special convocation yesterday, condemned the revision by Conservative Jews of the traditional Jewish marriage contract.
PINOLA, Miss., Dec. 28 (UP) -- Col. Cy Wilson, whose Air Force jet wing made a historic nonstop flight to England, crashed to his death during a rainstorm tonight, the Air Force reported.

We had one completely rewarding event at the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra, which Eugene Ormandy directed last night in Carnegie Hall. This was the glorious performance Nathan Milstein gave of Dvorak's violin concerto.
The Du Mont television network will reduce its national coaxial cable facilities and effect a cut-back in personnel because of "reduced activity" of the network.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 -- Navy's biggest problem in preparing for its New Year's Day football game with Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl here is an emotional one.

The Government's emergency ship repair program, originally intended for fifty-four vessels, is being expanded to take care of seventy ships, it was announced yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator.

PARIS, Dec. 28 -- The treaty authorizing a West German army of twelve divisions is expected to receive tomorrow even less enthusiastic approval than the entry of the Bonn Republic into the North Atlantic alliance received early today.

DETROIT, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Jesse Arnelle, 6-foot-5, counted 34 points to set a tournament record and lead Penn State to a 71-53 victory over Toledo tonight in the consolation game of the Motor City basketball classic.
Billy Loes, the Dodgers' right-hander who, on occasion, can be effective on the mound, yesterday became the Brooks' eighth player to come to terms for 1955.

ONE of the rewards of reading many books is the dramatic suddenness with which illuminating contrasts come to mind. Particularly striking are two current autobiographies by dark-skinned Africans who eagerly gulped down the white man's culture and wrote their books in the white man's language while living in exile in the white man's country.

State Housing Commissioner Herman T. Stichman ruled yesterday that Knickerbocker Village, Inc., a limited-dividend housing project, was entitled to a monthly rent increase of $1.14 a room starting Feb. 1. This will raise the average rental to $16.33 a room.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 28 -- The German Association for Physical Research is trying to discover if West Germany has enough uranium deposits to supply the 10,000-kilowatt atomic pile permitted under the Paris pacts.

LONDON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Britain has received a check for 367,000 ($1,027,600) from Communist China as compensation for the British airliner shot down by Chinese fighters July 23 near Hainan Island with the loss of ten lives, three of them Americans.
DESPITE the complaint of thousands of deer hunters that the woods are "full of does," New York stalkers harvested the largest number of deer in the history of the state during the past season.
The American people are making great progress toward achieving cultural maturity, Dr. Henry T. Heald, Chancellor of New York University declared last night.

The television show, "Strike It Rich," was found guilty yesterday of violation of the City Administrative Code for failure to have a license to solicit funds and other assistance from studio audiences.
Three sandhogs were rescued yesterday from a Queens sewer project after they had been trapped by an underground fire 880 feet from the nearest exit.
This letter is written on behalf of the Citizens Union Committee on Traffic in response to your editorial of Dec. 2, which protested the treatment of doctors.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec,. 28 (AP) -- Minnesota came from behind in the last four minutes of a nip-and-tuck game to defeat the defending champion, Duke, 79 -- 73, tonight. As a result the Gophers moved into the final of the Dixie Classic basketball tournament against unbeaten North Carolina State.

Admiral Husband E. Kimmel's own version of the bombing of Pearl Harbor will be published by Regnery on Jan. 14. Titled "Admiral's Kimmel's Story," it tells "what it was like to be left holding the bag in a most vulnerable position."

CAIRO, Dec. 28 (Reuters) -- Egypt sentenced five members of the armed forces to death today for taking part in a Moslem Brotherhood conspiracy to overthrow the Government. At the same time the regime arrested six Jews, including a woman, on charges of Communist and Zionist activity.

MOSCOW, Dec. 28 -- Usman Yusupov, Premier of the Uzbek Soviet Republic, who was recently criticized sharply by the Soviet Communist party leadership, has been relieved of his duties. He has been replaced by his deputy, Nuritdin A. Mukhitdinov

Today's new film is "Animal Farm," the first British-made cartoon feature in Technicolor, produced by Halas and Batchelor for Louis de Rochemont, at the Paris Theatre. The import, in production for three years, was adapted from George Orwell's fable lampooning the modern totalitarian state in terms of animal versus man.

GREENWICH, Conn., Dec, 28 -- A Connecticut Supreme Court decision against the Town of Greenwich today paved the way for the construction of a 200-family apartment house development on a ten-acre tract off Milbank Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (AP) -- The National Education Association said tonight that more than 900 Houston, Tex., school employes had reported that the city's teachers have been subjected to "unwarranted pressures'' in political, social and classroom activities.

Jay E. Crane, vice president of the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), has been designated chairman of the board of directors of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Federal Reserve agent, for 1955 -- posts he has held since January, 1953.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The State Commerce Department today reported the following winter sports conditions:
Menaced by the onset of sand blasters and stonecutters, Mayor Wagner yesterday abandoned City Hall. He retreated to previously prepared positions -- across the street.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey today, froze twenty-eight of his appointees into posts they could have lost with the advent of the Harriman Administration.

Parents planning dances for the junior high set during the holidays may be prompted to rearrange some of their plans if they consider the opinions of an instructor at Wayne University's Department of Psychiatry. According to this specialist -- who is also a child therapist -- the continually decreasing age at which "dating" begins is complicating rather than easing later boy-girl relationships.

CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- Rainfall in the arid Southwest crop areas proved to be light, with clearing conditions forecast. As a result there was much reinstatement of long lines of wheat and the market was strong today for both old and new crop futures.
CHICAGO, Dec. 28 -- New catalogues of two Chicago mail order companies now being delivered to customers throughout the United States contain attractive price reductions.
Philip J. Meagher, a reporter for The New York Times, received a civilian commendation from the Police Department yesterday for assisting in the capture of a hold-up suspect.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Tom Brown Jr. of San Francisco, the top-seeded player, bogged down on a soggy court today but rallied to beat Allen Morris of Atlanta, 7 -- 5, 5 -- 7, 6 -- 2, and advanced to the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament semi-finals.
ALBANY, Dec. 28 -- Governor Dewey today appointed a nine-member council for New Paltz State Teachers College. The council replaces the former Board of Visitors of the college.

A vacant business plot 183 by 35 feet at the northeast corner of Forty-third Avenue and Fifty-first Street in Woodside, Queens, has been purchased by Lawrence D. Maran, real estate operator, for improvement with a one-story taxpayer.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy today scheduled a marathon public session of his Senate Investigations subcommittee next Monday. Defense-plant subversives are the current targets of the inquiry.

The State Attorney General called yesterday for stricter regulation of the charges for funerals. He reported that "an unscrupulous segment" had found opportunities for fraud in funerals for persons on relief.
An independent aviation publishing and consulting service has been established by William D. Barrington, veteran aeronautical analyst and air tariff specialist.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 28 -- Mr. Kemper was appointed Ambassador to Brazil in June, 1953. The White House announced his resignation early this month. Secretary Dulles said then that Mr. Kemper had performed "outstanding service."
Arthur B. Bisguier, United States chess champion, administered the first defeat sustained by Samuel Reshevsky, America's international grand master, in the L. J. Rosenwald tournament last night.

SYRACUSE, Dec. 28 (UP) -- Eastern basketball officials today chose Madison Square Garden in New York as the site for a preliminary triple-header to select three teams for the National Collegiate tournament proper.
THOMPSON, Conn. Dec. 28 (AP) -- Sale of the Cluett, Peabody Co. plant here to the Republican Textile Equipment Company of New York City was announced today.
More persons will be protected against more contingencies as social legislation moves toward a goal of "completeness," an Administration official predicted yesterday.
HACKENSACK, N. J., Dec. 28 -- The Bergen County grand jury voted murder conspiracy indictments today against ten persons in the alleged plot to kill a leader of a seamen's union.
The cotton futures market on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, unchanged to 6 points off on active months.
CINCINNATI, Dec. 28 (UP) -- The Air Force today ordered the transfer of three officers accused of harassing civilian employes at the General Electric plant in near-by Evendale.

This hasn't turned out to be a Merry Christmas for the families and friends of the 391 persons who were killed in traffic accidents throughout the nation last week-end. It hasn't turned out to be a Merry Christmas for those now in hospitals as a result of holiday mishaps on the roads, for those who will be permanently disabled, for their families and friends.

Manhattan College captured the team title as a few surprises were recorded in the individual events of the annual Metropolitan Amateur Athletic Union junior track and field championship meet at the 102d Engineers Armory last night.
Americans may be physically comfortable but they are not physically fit, in the opinion of many physical training specialists.

PITTSBURGH, Dec. 28 (AP) -- Blaw-Knox Company said today it will start a multi-million-dollar long-range expansion program next year to integrate more fully the operations in several of its product lines. W. Cordes Snyder Jr., chairman and president of the company, said the modernization and enlargements will be paid for by long-term financing which is being arranged.
SYDNEY, Australia, Wednesday, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Tony Trabert of America's victorious Davis Cup tennis team said today he wanted to prove himself a "real champion" before turning professional.

The mercury, with heated disregard for winter, climbed to 60.4 degrees in this city at 3:05 P. M. yesterday. It was the warmest Dec. 28 ever recorded by the eighty-three-year-old Weather Bureau here. It topped by .8 of a degree the mark set for the date in 1949.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 28 -- Mark Davis scored 35 points for a tournament record as he paced Marietta College's basketball team to a 69-63 triumph over Wagner, 1953 winner, in the quarter-final round of the Hofstra invitation event tonight.
ATLANTA, Dec. 29 -- R. Clyde Williams, widely known retired Atlanta banker, was found dead of a gunshot wound at his home here today. He was 60 years old.

The final five-car shipment of a fifty-four unit order of railroad coaches placed in Germany by the Mexican Government was unloaded yesterday afternoon at Claremont Terminal, Jersey City, from the Liberian cargo ship Gertrud Therese.
Directors of the Delaware and Hudson Company have declared an extra dividend of $1.50 a share, it was announced yesterday. The disbursement will be made on Jan. 28 to holders of record on Jan. 13.

MIAMI, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Paul Andrews of Buffalo ended Boardwalk Billy Smith's eight-fight winning streak tonight with a smashing technical knockout victory over the No. 1 light heavyweight title contender. The bout was halted in 2:49 of the sixth round.

The long memories of two detectives resulted in the arrest last night of a burglary suspect, believed to be responsible for thefts of more than $100,000 in jewels and furs in midtown Manhattan hotels.
Fourth place in the National Hockey League will be at stake tonight when the New York Rangers meet the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden.
PITTSBURGH, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Koppers Company, Inc., said today it would spend $20,000,000 on new plants, equipment and improvements next year.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- A widespread winter storm spread snow, sleet, tornadoes and cold across the nation today. It trapped thousands of motorists in the Southwest and claimed a mounting toll of dead. At least twenty-eight deaths were attributed to the weather, nine of them in the crash of an Air Force C-119 Flying Boxcar during violent squalls in Alabama.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Pennsylvania Athletic Commission today postponed until next month a decision on whether Joey Giardello, middle-weight boxing contender, should be suspended for "actions detrimental to boxing."

Wolfgang Unzicker of West Germany and Istvan Bilek of Hungary, were the only winners yesterday in the opening round of the annual Christmas Chess Congress of the Hastings Chess Club, according to a report from London.
ALBANY, Dec. 29 -- Seven New York City undertakers faced loss or suspension of their licenses today. They have been accused of overcharging families on relief for burials.
LONDON, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Plumbing is one of the latest problems to concern Nikita S. Khrushchev, Soviet Communist party secretary.
Christmas gifts this year represented happy choices for the most part.

RALEIGH, N. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Guard John Maglio hooked in a goal with nine seconds remaining to give undefeated North Carolina State an 85-84 triumph over Minnesota and its fifth Dixie Classic basketball crown tonight before a wildly cheering crowd of 12,400.
Active cotton futures on the New York Cotton Exchange closed barely steady yesterday, 5 to 13 points net lower than on Tuesday.

CLEVELAND, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Defense attorneys for Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard, convicted wife-slayer, today subpoenaed five persons, including three members of the jury that convicted him, to appear at tomorrow's plea for a new trial.

ARCADIA, Calif., Dec. 29 (UP) -- Imported Poona II, under a sparkling ride by Willie Shoemaker, raced to a three-length victory today at Santa Anita in the $10,000 Arcadia Purse to set an American record for a mile and an eighth over the turf.

A borrowing of $6,000,000 in the German capital market has enabled the Hugo Stinnes interests to abandon plans for the sale here of an equal amount of notes and common stock registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission last month.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The military pay measure that President Eisenhower will send to Congress next month proposes a limited system of increases, to be distributed in such a way as to encourage good men to stay in service.
The National Broadcasting Company confirmed a report yesterday that "between thirty and forty" television engineers and technicians "will be let go at the end of the year."
Crime came up with something of an innovation yesterday.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- A three-man court appointed by the Government to inquire into a dispute that has led to the calling of a nationwide railway strike on Jan. 9 decided today to begin public hearings tomorrow.
Scarcely has the household devoured the Christmas bird and the flaming plum pudding than its members start considering the gastronomical aspects of the New Year.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Tom Brown Jr. of San Francisco and Eddie Moylan of Trenton today scored straight-set victories to enter the singles final of the Sugar Bowl tennis tournament.
In the most active session in more than four years, stock prices rose yesterday to the highest levels since 1929.

"Who is your Representative to Congress?" "Who is your State Senator?" "Who is your Assemblyman?" "Who is your City Councilman?" It is a standing but wry joke that many of us cannot give correct answers to these questions.
William J. O'Shea, chairman of the law committee of the Democratic State Committee, was appointed yesterday by Mayor Wagner as a member of the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board was asked today to order the Washington Pension Union of Seattle, Wash., to register as a Communist-front organization.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The Government announced plans today for a public offering Jan. 11 of $500,000,000 of notes issued by the Federal National Mortgage Association.

MADISON, Wis., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Little Dick Miller, University of Wisconsin guard, came through with 3 points in the last 35 seconds to give the Badgers a 66 -- 64 basketball victory over Princeton tonight.

The Raytheon Manufacturing Company, producer of radio television and electronics equipment, increased its net profit 46 per cent in the six months ended Nov. 30, to $2,396,000 from $1,639,000 in the similar period last year.

The first project in a slum- clearance plan for Chinatown that will preserve the area's character as a tourist attraction and as a center for New Yorkers of Chinese descent has been tentatively approved.
Your edition of Dec. 23 contains a story about certain murals being offered as a gift to the city of Norwalk by an artist alleged by the Veterans of Foreign Wars to be some shade of a "subversive."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Congress of Industrial Organizations and the National Association of Manufacturers split today on the business outlook for the new year, but also agreed on a few points.

GILBERT HIGHET'S "Juvenal the Satirist" is a work of formidable scholarship presented with notable wit and grace. It is brocaded in the stiff, bristling threads of scholiastic reference. Yet I think it would be prudent to say that this scrupulous study of a furious, brilliant Roman poet's life will outlast a thousand specious, clattering historical novels about the imperial decadence he lampooned unmercifully and, as it has turned out, immortally.

What was the common denominator of all Christmas trees -- the lights, the decorations the glowing star at the top? Yes, all of these things were found on any tree that was worth the name. Yet there was another, and one which will be around long after the baubles have been put away in the attic.
The wonders of science being what they are, it took exactly thirty-five minutes to reveal to a select audience yesterday what had taken four full days to prove some three months ago.
Most fields of industry and business will prosper in 1955, according to a canvass of leading executives reported yesterday by the Commerce and Industry Association of New York.
GUNTERSVILLE, Ala., Dec. 29 (UP) -- A C-119 Flying Boxcar with eleven Air Force men aboard crashed into a mountainside near here today. Nine men were killed.

The head of the Federal Power Commission, Jerome K. Kuykendall, declared yesterday that the agency had been as "considerate and reasonable" as possible in the regulation of independent natural gas producers.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Special "UN" license plates will disappear from New York streets early in 1955. The plates, now used only by few hundred delegates to the United Nations, are to be replaced with "DPL" licenses in New York's familiar black-and- yellow combination.
The situation in Indochina is extremely bad and it will certainly get worse -- or worse than it need get -- if the present official complacency and public optimism continue.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Army said tonight it had reinstated all but eleven of the thirty-five employes at Fort Monmouth, N. J., who were suspended under loyalty board proceedings.
HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 29 -- The Hofstra College Flying Dutchmen and the Lafayette Leopards gained the final round of the fourth Hofstra invitation basketball tournament in Calkins gymnasium tonight.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- A racial-equality group praised President Eisenhower today for "strong and constructive" civil rights leadership.
TETERBORO, N. J., Dec. 29 -- An experimental plane akin to a flying wing has been selected to land the main party of an Arctic expedition at the North Pole next March.

In its report to the President on Jan. 23, 1954, the Commission on Foreign Economic Policy (better known as the Randall commission) took an uncompromising stand against the Buy American Act. The act, it recalled, had been passed as an anti-depression measure in 1933.

A grant for establishing the Institute of Nuclear Medicine was announced yesterday by John Jay Hopkins, chairman and president of the General Dynamics Corporation. The grant will be made to the Lovelace Foundation for Medical Education and Research, Albuquerque, N. M., where the institute will be situated.
The voluntary hospitals suggested yesterday that the city increase its subsidy to them for care of the medically indigent by paying $1 for each nonpaying visitor to their out-patient departments.

Mr. and Mrs. Dana Converse Backus of 1158 Fifth Avenue and Hazeldean, Port Washington, L. I.; Mrs. William A. Eldridge of 1125 Park Avenue, and Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth Boyd Outerbridge of Princeton, N. J., gave a dinner dance jointly last night at the Colony Club for their respective debutante daughters, Miss Janet Graham Backus, Miss Janet A. Eldridge and Miss Judith Bayard Outerbridge.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Marine Corps announced today it was switching some 4,380 officers and men from supporting to combat roles. The aim is to offset a sharp cut ordered in manpower.
David Brechner of Brooklyn upset the fourth-seeded player, Lloyd Moglen of Mount Vernon, 6 -- 1, 3 -- 6, 7 -- 5, yesterday in the Eastern junior indoor tennis at the 102d Engineers Armory.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Two public power groups today denounced the proposed Dixon-Yates power contract as a threat to public power systems. They urged the Securities and Exchange Commission to reject it.
A Yale University law professor, who has acted in cases involving loyalty matters, is leaving the university because he has been denied a promotion.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Until a President committed to "progressive moderation" as a political philosophy is replaced by another disciple of the New-Fair Deal no Supreme Court majority seems likely to adopt the basic view of the minority in the case known as Adamson v. California.

A good year in food is foreseen for the nation's consumers by Ralph W. Burger, president of the Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company of America. Supplies will be plentiful and prices steady, he said, and there will be continued improvement in quality and service.
A new musical, "House of Flowers" and a melodrama, "The Troublemakers," have their New York premieres today.
DETROIT, Dec. 29 -- Prof. Seymour E. Harris of Harvard University said fears of the effects of a guaranteed annual wage were exaggerated.

SAN DIEGO, Calif., Dec. 29 -- Vice Admiral C. Turner Joy asserted today that a blockade of Communist China should be "seriously considered" if Korean war prisoners still held by the Communists were not returned.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 29 -- Jim Royer, Navy right tackle and the biggest man on the team, has been injured and may be lost for the Sugar Bowl football game with Mississippi on Saturday.
MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Joe Scarpinato and Art Tierney paced New York University to a 74-67 victory over the University of Miami basketball team tonight.

A series of organizational changes aimed at increased efficiency was announced yesterday by Louis S. Rothschild, Maritime Administrator. The changes involve the shipbuilding, ship operation, subsidy administration and training divisions of the Government agency.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- About 1,000,000 Federal employes will get pay raises ranging from 2.9 to 7.4 per cent under a "tentative'' program announced today by Philip Young, Chairman of the Civil Service Commission.
Help for two unhappy teen-agers was offered yesterday from a group of youngsters of the same age, but different circumstances, as the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund rose to $356,989.82.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold will leave at 3:40 P. M. tomorrow by air on his mission to Peiping to negotiate for the release of United Nations prisoners of the Korean war, including eleven United States fliers jailed by Communist China on "spy" charges.
A series of geometric units in resilient vinyl floor tiles has been designed by Marilyn Grayboff for the Robbins Floor Products Company.

BUFFALO, N. Y., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Stockholders of the Marine Midland Corporation, at a special meeting here today, approved proposals to issue a new series of preferred stock in the amount of $20,000,000, and to increase the authorized common stock from 8,000,000 to 10,000,000 shares.
In the next eighteen years the United States will need 250,000 more teachers, Dr. John J. Theobald, president of Queens College said yesterday.

Let me thank you on behalf of my fellow refugees for your touching editorial "Refugee Christmas" in the Dec. 25 issue of The Times. We thank you for the feeling of hope that you convey to us in your writing:

Five resolutions determining the function and structure of a new student Zionist organization were adopted here yesterday. The action was taken by 300 delegates from fifty-seven colleges in the United States and Canada attending the group's founding convention at Columbia University.

While the world waits for the final votes of the French Assembly on the Paris pacts it must be noted again that the proposed Western European Union is more than a military alliance. It is also an instrument for European integration through more effective economic, social and cultural cooperation -- the end goal of which must be political integration into a "more perfect union" if Europe is to survive in freedom.
CHARLOTTE, N. C., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Charlotte Observer was sold today to the Knight Newspapers for $7,000,000.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 29 -- The Federal Prosecutor said today that if Vladimir Dedijer were tried the trial would be held in accordance with Yugoslav law and in keeping with the United Nations Convention on Human Rights.

Two additional record companies yesterday announced a reduction in price. One of them, M-G-M, is meeting all of the new prices introduced by R. C. A. Victor last Monday. The other, Walden Records, will sell its twelve-inch LP disks at $4.95 instead of $5.95.

Net income of the Southern Pacific Transportation System for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 amounted to $44,713,738, it was announced yesterday. This represented a decline of 23.9 per cent from the $58,703,372 earned in the corresponding 1953 period.
WHATEVER the truth may be of the Anastasia mystery, the drama about it is superb. Logically enough, it is called "Anastasia," and it opened at the Lyceum last evening.

MONTREAL, Dec. 29 -- The International Air Transport Association, which represents seventy-one airlines throughout the world, announced today that scheduled carriers established records in every category of airline traffic during 1954.

It was quite appropriate for Alfred M. Lilienthal, as a leading exponent of the Arab League's position, to align himself in his letter of Dec. 23 with the views expressed earlier in your columns by the league's representative, Mr. Kamil Abdul Rahim. It was also not surprising that he placed himself in opposition to the type of constructive program for the Middle East which was presented in the letter of the American Christian Palestine Committee.

A series of volumes on European history from the French Revolution to the Second World War will be published by Oxford University Press under the general title "The Oxford History of Modern Europe." The first volume will be published Jan. 30 and will be called "The Struggle for Mastery in Europe, 1848-1918."

HARTFORD, Dec. 29 -- Fred Stickels, superintendent of the New Haven County Home for Children, said today he had "no intention" of resigning. A State Welfare Department report issued yesterday charged the home with mistreatment of children, and urged the dismissal of Mr. Stickels.

TEL AVIV, Israel, Dec. 29 -- Israeli Army and Navy units were called out this afternoon to evacuate low-lying areas flooded as a result of three days of continuous rainfall. Forecasts are for more rain through tomorrow.

BROOKLINE, Mass., Dec. 29 (AP) -- The defending champion, June Stack of Hamtramck, Mich., and Norma Harris of Brooklyn, N. Y., today reached the final round of the national girls' indoor tennis championships at the Longwood cricket club.

HONG KONG, Dec. 29 -- Delegations representing Communist China and Indonesia have completed "preliminary negotiations" on the status of Indonesia's overseas Chinese residents, it was announced tonight.
PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 30--The National Assembly's vote on German rearmament was put off early today until this afternoon.

New York has long had a reputation as a cosmopolitan city. Its subway passengers, made one people by their rush-hour sufferings, may soon be able to ride to another city of the world. It is appropriate, for many reasons, that Mayor Wagner should be thinking as he is of the desirability of joining the heart of New York City and the United Nations area by convenient subway transportation.
MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Political fur flew here today between Mayor Joseph P. Vaccarella and Public Safety Commissioner Oscar L. Spears. Both are Democrats.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- A split-level, brick-clapboard farmhouse, estimated to sell at $9,800, has been built experimentally at the Department of Agriculture's research center in Beltsville, Md.

The five-story apartment house at 340 East Eighty-third Street has been sold by Milton Greenebaum as trustee to Elizabeth Johnson for investment. The building contains fifty rooms and occupies a plot 25 by 100 feet. Schimmer, Kerner Feder and Samuel Sason-Arthur Lichtner were brokers in the transaction.

The television-radio division of Westinghouse Electric Corporation told last night of an elaborate promotion for its 1955 line of sets in which consumers, dealers and distributors will win as prizes travel tickets to far-off places, away from television.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -West Germany's coal and steel industries broke all post-war production records in 1954.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29--Senator-elect Richard L. Neuberger, Democrat of Oregon, and his wife, a member of the Oregon Legislature, arrived in Washington today.
MADRID, Dec. 29 -- Generalissimo Francisco France and Don Juan of Bourbon lunched together today. They had been hardly on speaking terms for nearly ten years.
Vernon A. Johnson has been appointed Washington, D. C., manager for Lockheed Aircraft Corporation.
BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- Recently deciphered writing is illuminating the days antedating Homer in Greece.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Reports linking cigarette smoking to bad health contributed to a decline in cigarette production this year, the Agriculture Department said today.
New Year's Eve is expected to be meteorologically dry and socially wet.
Representative Jacob K. Javits proposed yesterday the recruitment of 1,000,000 young Americans for overseas jobs in the next two decades as part of the country's effort to thwart Communist ambitions.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The State Department promised today to study a Swiss request for relief in connection with higher United States tariffs on Swiss watches.

MILWAUKEE, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Bobby Thomson, his broken right ankle fully mended and his spirits high, signed his 1955 contract with the Milwaukee Braves today. His pay was estimated at $30,000 to $35,000, the same as for 1954.

BONN, Germany, Dec. 6 -- Nine years ago the shipyards around the mouth of the Elbe River were a twisted mass of rusting steel. Allied bombs had turned the cradle of the once powerful German Navy and merchant marine into a silent junkyard, where a few shabbily dressed men and women were poking around for something they could exchange for food.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 29--Sunlight has been harnessed to create sugar and starch out of carbon dioxide and water for the first time outside the living cells of green plants.

MANILA, Thursday, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Danny Kid retained his Philippine flyweight championship last night by knocking out Australia's Vince Blake in 2 minutes 45 seconds of the seventh round of their scheduled twelve-round bout.
The American Federation of Labor urged Turkey yesterday to call off the trial of 556 dock union members on charges of having staged that country's largest labor walkout.
The electrical manufacturing industry will chalk up its second best year in 1954, according to the National Electrical Manufacturing Association.

TRENTON, Dec. 29 -- Joseph Weintraub, New Jersey member of the bi-state Waterfront Commission, vigorously denied here today that Gov. Robert B. Meyner had in any way meant to be critical of the agency when, on Monday, he commented upon its activities.
TOKYO, Dec. 29 -- Japan expects to take title soon to large stocks of United States military equipment, including some jet aircraft.

The practice of limiting employment opportunities to persons of specified ages is becoming more widespread through American business than ever. This practice is in conflict with the fundamental principles of the Constitution, which guarantees the right to life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness.

The appointment of Samuel H. Daroff of Philadelphia as head of a national campaign cabinet of fifty-three business, professional, religious and philanthropic leaders to help direct the 1955 drive of the United Jewish Appeal was announced yesterday.

An increase last week of 3,144,000 barrels in the nation's gasoline stocks was reported yesterday by the American Petroleum Institute. At the week-end, total supplies were 154,922,000 barrels, compared with 151,778,000 a week earlier and 153,953,000 a year ago.

Eight-year-old David W. Rudnick has proved that at a tender age he has learned that honesty is a pretty good policy. The youngster, who lives at 233 West Seventy-seventh Street, salvaged $2 in coins from two broken parking meters on Amsterdam Avenue between Seventy-third and Seventy-fourth Streets.
A train's tardiness sometimes shortens tempers -- especially those of schedule-minded commuters -- the New York, New Haven and Hartford Railroad agreed yesterday.
KARACHI, Pakistan, Dec. 29 -- The Government announced today that import restrictions imposed two years ago on a broad list of consumer and industrial items would be lifted Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The Food and Drug Administration initiated steps today to remove three widely used coal tar dyes from the list of artificial colorings considered harmless and suitable for use in foods.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 29 (Reuters) -- Following is the text of a communique issued here today by the Prime Ministers of the Colombo powers at the conclusion of their two-day meeting:
Rubber futures prices rose yesterday on the Commodity Exchange to the highest level in more than two years.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 29 -- The Government today told West German business to raise investment funds at home and to shun where possible borrowings abroad involving repayment in foreign exchange.
A thug who has made a habit of holding up Joseph Meyers, 70 years old, in his general merchandise store at 184 Stuyvesant Avenue, Brooklyn, took $45 from him yesterday.

Trans World Airlines, in a year-end statement yesterday, said that increases in air traffic over the 1953 levels were recorded in all departments. An estimated total of 3,182,000,000 passenger miles were flown over its United States and international routes, a gain of 10.5 per cent over 1953.
PARIS, Dec. 29 -- French naval shipping in service increased 5 per cent in 1954 from 362,000 tons to 380,000 tons, the Navy Ministry disclosed today.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- Aircraft manufacturers here are "reasonably confident" that the payloads of big airliners and atomic bombers can be increased as a result of new developments in the manufacture of titanium. This metal, combining lightness with great strength and corrosion resistance, is expected to allow gains of at least a ton.
