VIENNA, Dec. 29 -- Moscow and the Austrian Communist party have been telling Austria that ratification of the Paris agreements would end hope for resuming negotiations for a treaty recognizing Austria's statehood.

SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Tony Trabert and Vic Seixas, whose racquets won back the Davis Cup for the United States, said today their Australian tennis campaign probably would not have been successful without Capt. Bill Talbert.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- John McGovern, a member of the British Parliament, said today that coexistence with Russia was like trying to coexist with a lion in a jungle.

DETROIT, Dec. 29 (AP) -- A. L. Lott, chairman of Motor Products Corporation, advised stockholders this week that he had "no intention" of exchanging his Motor Products stock for preferred stock of General Tire and Rubber Company of Akron, Ohio.
PARIS, Dec. 29 (UP) -- French authorities moved today to sweeten the air of the Metro, the city's subway.

LONDON, Dec. 29 -- The stock market started strongly today on the news of the advance on Wall Street and the reduction in the United States Treasury bill rate. However, early gains were reduced or lost under profitaking.
Fresh contract concessions by waterfront employers appeared last night to have staved off the threat of an immediate pier strike.

Detroit is not worried over the slow but steady rise in stocks of new cars in dealers' hands. They stand at about 350,000 units now. By the first of the year some observers, according to an Associated Press dispatch from Detroit, believe they may go to 475,000.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- This has been one of the most tranquil years in post-World War II labor-management relations, the Labor Department said today.

PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Frank G. Binswanger, an official of the Greater Philadelphia-Delaware-South Jersey Council today urged President Eisenhower to reject any recommendation for local contributions toward deepening the Delaware River channel between Philadelphia and Trenton.
BERN, Switzerland, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Swiss announced today they had asked the United States to cancel the tariff increase on watches ordered last July.

THERE was a distinct note of pride in the voice of Elroy (Crazy-Legs) Hirsch when he admitted in a television interview the other day that he was co-holder with Don Hutson of the record for most touchdown passes caught in a season, seventeen. Although his statement was as a bit of a shock, it shouldn't have been.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 29 -- John Wayne, voted the box-office king of the year by movie theatre operators in the Motion Picture Herald's annual listing of money-making stars, is the first actor to reach the top a second time after having been displaced.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The net working capital of United States corporations rose to a record $95,300,000,000 at the end of September, the Securities and Exchange Commission reported today.

PARIS, Dec. 29 -- France and the associated states of Indo-china -- South Vietnam, Laos and Cambodia -- signed new agreements today. These accords were officially described as giving the three states full financial and economic independence.

The plant of the American Can Company at 449 Communipaw Avenue in Jersey City, N. J., has been purchased by N. Sumergrade Sons of the Bronx, manufacturer of pillows and comforters. J. I. Kislak, Inc., and Emanuel Kamm were co-brokers in the transaction.

The program that Lois Wann presented last night at Town Hall was listed as an oboe recital, but it turned out to be an event that would be more accurately described as an evening of chamber music for the oboe.

RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Colgate, with four of its players hitting in double figures, defeated Boston University today, 82 -- 73, in the consolation round of the Richmond invitation basketball tournament.
American legal education has suffered because of the "low salary scale which obtains in more than half the schools," a leader in the field asserted yesterday.
"Bootleg" instruction in foreign languages is being given in some elementary schools, the Modern Language Association of America heard yesterday.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., Dec. 29 -- Dutch elm disease has stricken the Roger Williams elm, a landmark on Prospect Terrace in this city, which has withstood the storms of three centuries. Charles R. Wood, administrative assistant to the Mayor of this city and coordinator of the city's Dutch elm disease control program, said the elm was one of 115 on city property that would be felled within a few weeks.

ROME, Dec, 29 (AP) -- The Vatican newspaper L'Osservatore Romano, continuing an attack on the Argentine Government, quoted today papal declarations that the Roman Catholic Church must deal with morals and education as well as religion.

Ben Moreell, chairman of the Jones Laughlin Steel Corporation, predicted yesterday that this country's steel industry "might well operate at 90 per cent" of its present rated annual capacity of 124,330,410 tons in 1955, barring major strikes or international hostilities.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (UP) -Mrs. Jane M. Spaulding Negro Republican leader, received her third job in the Eisenhower Administration this week -- consultant to the Foreign Operations Administration at $42.50 a day.

HAIPHONG, Vietnam, Dec. 29 (UP) -- The Vietnam Armistice Control Commission said today it was unable to check French charges that some Communists were violating the truce by sending arms to the Vietminh Reds.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 29 -- President Eisenhower will send a special message to Congress Jan. 11 urging pay rises for classified civil service and postal employes along with increased postage rates.
Tentative plans to start construction of the Harry S. Truman Library at Independence, Mo., in the spring, were made known yesterday at the annual convention of the American Historical Association.
KUMASI, The Gold Coast, Dec. 10 -- A controversy over cocoa prices has brought the Gold Coast its first major internal crisis under African government.
William F. Fay, who has spent almost forty-five years in private police work here, will retire Saturday as chief of the pier protective service of the Moore-McCormack Lines.
Commenting on monetary policy issues, the Guaranty Trust Company praised yesterday the record of the Federal Reserve System over the last four years.

In view of the unusual number of brilliant performances and new productions we had seen at the Metropolitan this season we went, with high hopes, to see its first "Carmen" of the winter last night. We were grievously disappointed.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- Raytheon announced today the appointment of Cliff Knoble to the newly created post of merchandising manager of its television and radio operations in Chicago. Curtis L. Peterson succeeded Mr. Knoble as advertising manager of the Chicago division.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Hog receipts greatly exceeded expectations today and prices declined around 25 cents on both butchers and sows. On some early sales butchers were down as much as 50 cents. Salable receipts at 18,000 head were 6,000 above the advance estimate. Most choice 190- to 220 pound butchers sold for $18 to $18.75 with a few lots setting a top at $18.85.

TORONTO, Dec. 29 (UP) -- Eric Nesterenko's second-period goal gained a 1-1 tie for the Toronto Maple Leafs against the Montreal Canadiens tonight. Maurice (Rocket) Richard scored his 401st goal for Montreal in the first period of the National Hockey League game.

The Bank of the Manhattan Company has leased banking space on the ground floor of the twenty-story office building to be built soon at 711 Third Avenue. This will be the bank's fifty-ninth office. The space comprises 5,000 square feet south of the main entrance, in addition to basement space for safe deposit vaults.
Bad visibility caused by rains resulted last night in fatal traffic accidents to a 26-year-old woman in White Plains, N. Y., and a 77-year-old man in Brooklyn.
The woman owner of a Harlem rooming house in which a fatal fire occurred two days before Christmas was arrested late yesterday on a homicide charge.

Governor-elect Averell Harriman is expected to announce today his decision on appointments to several high state offices. On a number of other top appointments, Mr. Harriman re portedly was still weighing his decision, with the possibility that some Republicans may hold over for short periods in the new State Administration, which begins Saturday.

MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- Prof. Borts Rybakov, who was Moscow University's delegate to Columbia University's bicentennial celebrations, approves of the bicentenary theme, "man's right to knowledge and the free use thereof." But he doubts that it can be implemented "in the conditions of the capitalist world."

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 29 -- Plans for a conference of thirty Asian and African nations were announced here tonight by the Prime Ministers of Indonesia, Pakistan, India, Burma and Ceylon. Communist China will be among the countries invited.

A two-year state investigation into welfare rackets resulted yesterday in recommendations for state regulation of labor welfare funds. This would be accomplished through laws designed to root out abuses by unions, employers and insurance companies.

SPRINGFIELD, Dec. 29 -- A merger of the New York, New Haven and Hartford and the Boston and Maine Railroads "might come in two or three years," Patrick B. McGinnis, president of the New Haven, said here today.
STORRS, Conn., Dec. 29. (AP) -- Dartmouth gained the final round tonight in the New England invitation college basketball tournament by downing Middlebury, 73-69.

An all-time record for safe travel in the air by the United States civil carriers is indicated for 1954. The Civil Aeronautics Board announces the amazing figure of a fatality rate of 0.08 per hundred million passenger miles flown for the scheduled domestic and American flag foreign carriers.

Pink balloons and silvered foliage provided a holiday decor for the sixth annual Post-Debutante Tiara Ball, which was held last night in the main ballroom of the Plaza for the benefit of the Spence - Chapin Adoption Service. Mrs. Frederic H. Rahr was chairman of the committee for the fete, which was attended by many young women who were introduced last season and in the two preceding years.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in ninety-four leading cities shows, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, the following principal changes for the week ended Dec. 22:

The annual report of American Business Shares, Inc., for its twenty-second fiscal year ended Nov. 30, show net assets of $33,821,000. This was equivalent to $4.49 a common share, and compared with assets of $35,507,940, or $3.97 on more shares outstanding on Nov. 30, 1953. During the year the mutual investment company repurchased 1,528,542 common shares.

The State Commission Against Discrimination has ruled that a Bronx swimming pool and recreation park is a "public" accommodation and cannot lawfully refuse to admit Negroes. The decision was two to one.

WHITE PLAINS, N. Y., Dec. 29 -- Painful illness suffered by 308 persons after a Christmas party in the new national headquarters of the General Foods Corporation is mystifying health officials. Four of the stricken persons were taken to hospitals and one was still confined tonight.
SEATTLE, Wash., Dec. 29 (AP) -- Charles H. Fisher, the Washington Pension Union president, denied the Attorney General's charge today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- Senator Joseph R. McCarthy fired another blast today at the Eisenhower Administration's policy in the Far East.

PARIS, Thursday, Dec. 30 -- A bill providing for provisional credits for defense in the first three months of 1955 was submitted to the National Assembly early today. The bill replaces the regular defense budget, which has been postponed because of the proposed reorganization of French defense.
"It is like butter and is of marvelous flavor, so good and pleasing to the palate that it is a marvelous thing."
ANOTHER waterfowl season is drawing to a close, and Saturday will provide the last opportunity to gather a duck-dinner in Long Island, Connecticut and New Jersey.

The three-story building at 19 Montieth Street in Brooklyn has been leased by the Lafayette Store Fixture Company, Inc., and will be used for the storing and assembly of store fixtures. The building is owned by Ashkenazy Bayer and was leased through the Kalmon Dolgin Company as broker.
Among the fifty probationaries sworn into the Fire Department yesterday was a city policeman.

Solomon Hoberman was appointed yesterday as director of training and career development and Ernest E. Johnson was named to the post of director of recruitment and public relations, both in the City Department of Personnel.

CHICAGO, Dec. 29 -- New high prices were registered for March and May wheat futures today. The market edged upward on quiet accumulation by commission houses, with some support from commercial interests.
LONDON, Dec. 29 -- British officials here are pessimistic over the mission to Peiping of Dag Hammarskjold, United Nations Secretary General.
MOSCOW, Dec. 29 -- About 100,000 Soviet youths are to be recruited at once to help erect plants for the manufacture of prefabricated, reinforced concrete construction parts.
PHILADELPHIA, Dec. 29 -The winner of a seat in the State Legislature was decided today in what was described as the first legal lottery ever held in City Hall.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 (AP) -- The World Bank and two private financial institutions today made a loan of $5,000,000 for imports of tractors and other farm equipment into Colombia.
Duquesne and La Salle will play tomorrow night for top honors in the Eastern College Athletic Conference's Holiday Festival basketball tournament.
With a victory over James T. Sherwin in a game adjourned from the sixth round, Samuel Reshevsky improved his lead in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Marshall Chess Club last night.

PARIS, Dec. 29 (AP) -- Renee Jeanmaire, ballerina and musical comedy star, and Roland Petit, leader of the ballet troupe in which she first gained fame as his partner, were married today at Saint-Cyr-la-Riviere; a suburb of Paris.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 29 -- The State Department is expected to announce tomorrow the appointment of Edward Corsi as special assistant to the Secretary of State on immigration and refugee questions.
The Wesson Oil and Snowdrift Company, processor of cottonseed oil and its by-products, reported yesterday a consolidated net profit of $942,371 for the quarter ended on Nov. 27.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (AP) Notre Dame combined deadly marksmanship with rugged play tonight to defeat Holy Cross, 74 -- 69, in the Sugar Bowl basketball final.

On the wall of a room in which a woman had been murdered a few years ago, a sentence was found written in lipstick saying "For heaven's sake catch me before I kill more -- I cannot control myself." William Heirens, 18 years old, was found guilty of that and other murders.
Gen, Carlos P. Romulo should be congratulated on his letter published in The New York Times on Dec. 21.
Sixteen young women, eight from New York and eight from other cities, were presented here last night at the first intercity Mistletoe Debutante Ball in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Fireman's Insurance Company of Newark, N. J., charged the Puerto Rican Government today with misrepresentation and falsehood in a $124,000 civil suit before a Federal Court.
Pennies and nickels spent by subway riders for candy, chewing gum, peanuts and ice cream will clink into the coffers of the New York City Transit Authority at the minimum yearly rate of $310,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Loadings of revenue freight totaled 33,862,883 cars in 1954, the Association of American Railroads estimated today. This would be 4,438,262 cars, or 11.6 per cent, fewer than in 1953.
The City Planning Commission adopted yesterday a new master plan of areas suitable for housing redevelopment.

The Revlon Products Corporation will spend Some $10,000,000, which it says is the largest advertising budget for a cosmetics concern for a single year, for its advertising in 1955. This word came yesterday from Charles Revson, president of the company, who said most of the money would go into newspapers, magazines and television.

Six persons were burned in a Fifth Avenue store last night when an irate wife went after her husband with a can of lye solution. The husband, toward whom she also wielded a steak knife, was unscathed.

LONDON, Dec. 30 (Reuters) -- Radio stations in Soviet bloc countries maintained tonight that the people of France would carry on a struggle against the armament of West Germany despite today's vote favoring it in the French National Assembly.
J. S. Parker has been appointed general manager of the aircraft gas turbine division of General Electric Company.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, Dec. 30 -- Criminal prosecution proceedings were initiated today against Milovan Djilas and Vladimir Dedijer. The case arose from interviews they granted foreign correspondents in which they criticized tactics of the Communist leadership here.
More public support for research into the causes of infant deaths was urged yesterday by Mrs. Mary W. Lasker, head of the Albert and Mary Lasker Foundation.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 (UP) -- T. I. Harkins' Ambroee and R. Nardini's Chall Wind, a pair of distaff sprinters, accounted for a $681.80 daily double today at the Fair Grounds.
SANTIAGO, Chile, Dec. 30 -- The Cabinet resigned today as a result of the lifting of the state of siege -- an issue on which the will of Congress prevailed.

Net income of the Union Pacific Railroad for the eleven months ended on Nov. 30 was only 1.8 per cent below results in the corresponding period of 1953, although gross operating revenues dropped 9.7 per cent.
With all hands anxious to get a flying start on the new year in the matter of lining up contracts, each of the three local major league clubs came up with a 1955 signer yesterday.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- The Government amplified today its statement of objectives for the new foreign investment policy that is about to supplant the capital market promotion law lapsing tomorrow.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., Dec. 30 (AP) -- Tuskegee Institute suggested today that persons of different races would get along better without laws to govern race relations in the United States.
New Year's Eve arrives tonight, with most adults ready to celebrate -- some mindful, others heedless of warnings against overdoing the celebration.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Winter's first big storm threatened floods at Pittsburgh and dumped freezing rain, sleet and snow on northern New England today.

The last day of the year finds this department repeating a pleasant tradition -- that of reprinting the recipes that, appearing in the column in the previous twelve months, have proved most popular with readers.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The appointment of Edward Corsi, New York State Industrial Commissioner, as special assistant to the Secretary of State for Refugee and Migration Problems was announced today.

Undoubtedly, Elaine Perry's Santa Claus this year must remind her of Shepard Traube. On two occasions, he came to her rescue. The first was when the booking situation was so clogged up that she didn't know which Broadway house would be available for her presentation of "Anastasia."

The C. I. T. Financial Corporation, installment credit concern, announced yesterday the election of Sterling Harrison as a vice president of three subsidiaries -- the Service Fire Insurance Company of New York, the Service Casualty Company of New York and the Patriot Life Insurance Company.
The Radio Corporation of America and the National Broadcasting Company have settled for "approximately $1,000,000" claims against them by the estate of the late Maj. Edwin H. Armstrong.
HANOI, Vietnam, Dec. 30 -- A long process of political re-education to turn the Hanoi populace into loyal partisans of the Vietminh regime has begun.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Charles S. Thomas, Secretary of the Navy, denied today a Congressional charge that Navy red tape was slowing construction of United States military bases in Spain.

In a few hours the time will come when more parties are being given, more toasts drunk, more traveling from one home to another than on any other night of the year. The high spirits, the gay good fellowship, the devil-may-care release after the long year is an old and honored tradition from which we would not dissuade you if we could.

ROCHESTER, N. Y., Dec. 30 (AP) -- A three-man commission appointed by a Federal court has recommended that $1,418,528 be paid to a Rochester shipbuilder whose property was taken by the Air Force under condemnation proceedings.

HEMPSTEAD, L. I., Dec. 30 -- Checking a determined bid by the host club in the fading moments, the Lafayette Leopards from Easton, Pa., won the fourth Hofstra invitation basketball tournament by defeating the Flying Dutchmen, 75 -- 72, in Calkins gymnasium tonight.
TROY, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- St. Francis Xavier, a co-favorite in Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute's invitation hockey tournament, won its opening game tonight from Yale, 3 -- 1.
CHICAGO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Department of Agriculture reports on livestock trading here today:
BUFFALO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Canisius gained the final of the Queen City invitation basketball tournament tonight by trimming Georgia Tech, 70 -- 56, before 3,619 persons in Memorial Auditorium.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- The French National Assembly's ratification of the Paris agreements was greeted with relief by the West German Government and with bitterness by Social Democratic leaders.
It took a month of training, but the Rangers finally won a hockey game. The Broadway Blues humbled the Boston Bruins at Madison Square Garden last night, 6 to 1.

HOLLYWOOD, Calif., Dec. 30 -- The National Broadcasting Company will televise and broadcast for the first time the announcement of the Academy Awards nominations on Feb. 12 as well as the "Oscar" presentation ceremony in March under terms of a six-year contract signed with the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences.

The donation of the 5,000th pint of blood at the City Penitentiary on Rikers Island to the regional Red Cross blood program was marked yesterday by presentation of a certificate of appreciation to the prison.

Fourteen charitable organizations share in the estate of Joseph Horwich, former Brooklyn court interpreter, who successfully contested the will of his brother, Conrad Hubert, flashlight manufacturer, and received a $1,000,000 settlement.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- Britons expressed relief tonight at the success in the French Assembly of the accord to arm West Germany.
NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 30 -- Misfortune befell the Navy football team again today, forty-eight hours, before its New Year's Day game with Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl here.
The Florida State Board of Education announced yesterday that it will sell $9,155,000 of school construction bonds on Feb. 8. The sale had been tentatively scheduled for Jan. 18.

Rumors that the president of the Brazilian Coffee Institute had resigned and that the cruzeiro might be devalued caused a drop in coffee prices yesterday on the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange. There was no substantiation for the rumors last evening.

Gian-Carlo Menotti's new opera, "The Saint of Bleecker Street," was presented at the Broadway Theatre last evening with two new singers in principal roles. They were Gabrielle Ruggiero, as Annina, and Davis Cunningham, as Michele.
RICHMOND, Va., Dec. 30 (AP) -- George Washington won the Richmond invitation tournament by beating Richmond, 89 -- 75, tonight.

A LITTLE more than two years ago, George Bellak's "The Troublemakers" traveled across the Atlantic to cause quite a stir in London. Yesterday it received its first public presentation in New York at the tiny President Theatre, Unhappily, it has not successfully weathered its two ocean crossings and the passing of time.

STORRS, Conn., Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Dartmouth basketball team registered a stunning upset tonight as it won the New England college tournament with a 66-65 victory over favored Connecticut. A one-handed shot by Dick Fairley with five seconds left gave the Big Green the victory.

The Swiss Government's request that the United States cancel its recent 50 per cent increase in tariffs on watches was supported yesterday by the American Watch Association, which represents more than 300 American-owned watch assembler and import companies.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The atomic-powered submarine Nautilus, the first of its kind, will be put through sea trials early in March, the Navy announced today.
State mediators abandoned last night their efforts to avert a strike that threatens to cut off two-thirds of the city's supply of fresh fruit and vegetables at midnight tonight.
HARTFORD, Dec. 30 -- Governor-elect Abraham A. Ribicoff disclosed today his intention to push reorganization of Connecticut's government.

Vassily Smyslov of Moscow, having postponed his first-round game with Paul Keres, another Soviet grandmaster, played his match in the second round in the international tournament at the annual chess congress in Hastings, according to a report received from London yesterday.
Prices of cotton futures moved 2 points higher to 10 points lower yesterday, with trading rather light on the New York Cotton Exchange.
Duquesne and La Salle will meet tonight at Madison Square Garden in the final of the Eastern College Athletic Conference's third annual holiday basketball festival.

SEOUL, Korea, Dec. 30 -- The Republic of Korea Army has made important and reassuring progress toward self-sufficiency in recent months, Maj. Gen. R. L. Howze, Chief of the United States Army's Korean Military Advisory Group, said today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Subversive Activities Control Board received a recommendation today that it order the Jefferson School of Social Science to register with the Attorney General as a Communist front.
PARIS, Dec. 30--France accepted West Germany as an armed and equal ally today but did so with marked reluctance.

Legislation granting the New York State Banking Department authority to require or prevent changes in the control of banking institutions was recommended yesterday. The authority would be exercised through the issuance of permits without which controlling interests would be unable to vote their stock.

It is to be hoped that the coming meeting in Washington next week between representatives of the American Federation of Labor and the Congress of Industrial Organizations will result in plans for a union of the two.

Donald Gordon is not only president of Canadian National Railways. He is of Scottish ancestry. So yesterday, not unexpectedly, in a year-end review and assessment of 1955 prospects for the vast government rail complex north of the border, he made the statement that despite the general prosperity, the relation of revenues to expenses still is a major problem in railroad economics.

Today's new film is "Black Tuesday," a United Artists melodrama with Edward G. Robinson, Peter Graves and Jean Parker, at the Palace. Robert Goldstein produced and Hugo Fregonese directed from an original story and screen play by Sidney Boehm.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Defense Department report said manpower improvements over the last three and a half years had been a big factor in allowing a planned Army strength of twenty combat divisions as of next June 30 despite a 25 per cent cut in uniformed personnel and a 120,000-man cutback in civilian employment.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- An $8,000,000,000 plan to create 4,000,000 new jobs within the next ten years is before the Italian Cabinet. Its author is Senator Ezio Vanoni, Minister for the Budget in the Government of Premier Mario Scelba.

In a historic decision that redeems the honor of France and lays the foundations for a new Europe the French National Assembly has approved all the pacts of Paris, which create a Western European Union and make that Union part of an Atlantic community strengthened for the defense of the free world.

Two former chess champions of the United States were still leading the field late last night in the Lessing J. Rosenwald Trophy tournament at the Marshall Chess Club. Samuel Reshevsky, international ace, held a one-point advantage after a draw in thirty-one moves with Donald Byrne of the University of Michigan.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary of Commerce Sinclair Weeks predicted today a happy and more prosperous new year for Americans.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Tennessee Valley Authority warned again today that power demand would far outstrip capacity in 1957 unless more facilities were provided soon.
WHILE there is always the possibility that our leg has been stretched from "thar to thar," we attempt to treat without suspicion some of the queries that cross this desk.
Charles S. Hamilton Jr., a lawyer who has been making an investigation for Governor Dewey into the cost of workmen's compensation in the state, submitted a report yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- A House subcommittee reported today that 212,800 useless jobs had been found and abolished in the armed forces in the last two years.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- Secretary General Dag Hammarskjold left today for Peiping after having promised to do his best to obtain the release of Korean war captives still held by Communist China. The prisoners include eleven United States fliers jailed on charges of spying.
Ten police departments in the New York area, and fifteen more in near-by states, will be serving free coffee to tired motorists tonight and tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Sergeants with more than eight years' service and with one dependant would draw approximately $278 a month in pay and basic allowances under the proposed new pay rise plan favored by the Pentagon.
AUGUSTA, Ga., Dec. 30 -- President Eisenhower today expressed "great gratification" that the French National Assembly had ratified the agreement calling for the armament of West Germany.

ROME, Dec. 30 -- The health of Pope Pius XII has improved so greatly in the last few days that he is now thinking of personally broadcasting his long delayed Christmas message instead of publishing it.
ROME, Dec. 29 -- Anti-Communist labor unions continue to register gains in many elections for shop stewards as compared to Communist-dominated unions.

A "BOOTLEG" recording of a Canadian radio program burlesquing Senator Joseph R. McCarthy appeared yesterday in retail record stores. The disk may stir up quite a fuss on the radio, political and diplomatic fronts; it is certainly something to be heard.
An immediate study looking toward legislation to relieve the "desperate" financial condition of most of the shipbuilding and ship repair yards in the Port of New York was urged on Congress yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- President Eisenhower will ask Congress to appropriate a little more than $3,000,000,000 for foreign aid in the coming fiscal year, Administration sources said today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- James V. Bennett, director of the Federal prison system, said today the number of inmates in Federal prisons rose in 1954 to a new high.

CHICAGO, Dec. 30 -- Irregular price movements marked the grain trade today. Wheat sold off from early advances but developed strength for the new-crop months later, while corn declined on hedge pressure and long liquidation.

George Mandel, seeded No. 1, advanced to the junior singles final, but Arthur Merovick upset first-seeded Lawrence Nagler in a boys' singles semi-final yesterday in the Eastern junior indoor tennis championships at the 102d Engineers Armory.
Many hosts and hostesses, in planning parties for this weekend, may wish that they had a general rule to gauge the amount of liquor required.
CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Dr. Samuel H. Sheppard's attorneys announced in court today that they had "newly discovered evidence" proving that he had not murdered his pregnant wife, Marilyn.
MIAMI BEACH, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Howard Abbey of Miami outraced fifty other contestants today to win the nine-hour endurance run, a feature of the Orange Bowl Regatta, and a $1,000 United States bond.

This year's Christmas cheer, if it can be measured in terms of gift wrappings and other holiday left-overs collected from the city's homes by the Sanitation Department, was one-third greater than that of last year.

Benjamin F. Fairless, chairman of the United States Steel Corporation, said yesterday there are "firm prospects" that the industry would produce about 95,000,000 tons of steel next year -- some 7,000,000 tons above the 1954 output.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Hundreds of Democrats were complaining bitterly tonight that they had not received inauguration tickets promised to them.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Two former Communists described the Moral Re-Armament movement today as a force for peace that could win the idealogical battle of the world.

There is a miserable thing going around which colloquial medical science refers to as a twenty-four-hour virus. It attacks suddenly and fiercely, lingers a time and then is gone. Its effect is something like that of any one of those hurricanes which were named for once-pretty girls.
Because of a strained ligament, Mia Slavenska was prevented last night from appearing in the leading role of Zachary Solov's ballet, "Vittorio," at the Metropolitan Opera.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Pennsylvania's new Attorney General is losing his driver's license for ninety days because of a speeding violation, the Highway Safety Bureau announced today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture said today the prices farmers received on crops and livestock fell 2 per cent during the month ended Dec. 15.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Department store sales in the United States during the week ended last Saturday were 16 per cent above sales in the corresponding period of last year, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

BUENOS AIRES, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Government today legalized prostitution in Argentina today -- a move certain to increase the tensions already existing between the Government and the Roman Catholic Church.

ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Governor Dewey announced tonight thirty-three "last minute" appointments to non-salaried state posts. Fifteen were from the New York area and were named to councils of state educational institutions.
BONN, Germany, Dec. 30 -- The Communist party's West German Congress closed today in Hamburg.
Attorney General-elect Jacob K. Javits, who will be the only Republican to hold major office in this state's new Democratic Administration, is going to set up an Investigations Bureau in his office.
Business loans of the New York City banks turned higher during the week ended on Wednesday, marking the first rise in such credits in four weeks.
At this time of year it is interesting to assess the happenings of the last twelve months. Here we note some of the highlights in the home furnishings and fashion fields.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 30 -- Observers here saw an opportunity for the Communist Chinese delegation to be a dominant one in the Asian-African conference called for April in Bandung, Indonesia.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Federal Trade Commission accused six more insurance companies today of false and misleading advertising in the sale of accident and health insurance policies.
A tribute to John H. Bruins, United States Foreign Service officer, who died on Christmas Day, was included among 196 gifts to the New York Times Neediest Cases Fund yesterday.

A tract of 130 acres at Lake Ronkonkoma, L. I., has been sold by Alvin Frevert to M. Kaufman who plans to construct 350 dwellings and a shopping center. Serge V. Traube was the broker in the transaction. The builder plans three-bedroom houses with attached garages in the $8,990 price class.

The three-story business building at 1359 Broadway in Brooklyn has been purchased by the Manhyle Realty Corporation from the 1351 Broadway Brooklyn Corporation, a wholly owned subsidiary of Finlay Straus. The building is in the block between Gates Avenue and Linden Street L. J. Phillips Co. were the brokers.

BOSTON, Dec. 29 -- A grant of $1,000,000 to reconstruct one of the most imposing buildings of the ancient Greek Agora, or market place of Athens, has just been matched by a like sum, thereby fulfilling a stipulation of the gift.
Mal Whitfield attained a long-cherished goal yesterday. The final tally of votes established the great half-miler as the 1954 winner of the James E. Sullivan Memorial Trophy.

The honors still are being heaped on the New York Giants. Baseball's world champions were named yesterday the outstanding team of 1954 by an overwhelming margin in the annual year-end Associated Press poll.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Dec. 30 (UP) -- Auburn's hopes for victory against Baylor in the Gator Bowl hinged today around a big blue kneecap.

TOKYO, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The chief of the Army's Psychological Warfare Section said today a corporal has been shifted to another job and a woman civilian script writer allowed to resign because they had "swallowed a portion" of the Communist line on China.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The state discovered today that $5 is too cheap a price for the vanity of motorists.
CAIRO, Dec. 30 -- The funerary bark of Cheops is being wrecked by neglect.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- Dr. Lewis A. Wilson disclosed today that he was contemplating retiring as State Commissioner of Education "within the next year."

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- An outbreak of rabies in Europe is described here as "more serious than any in Western Europe for at least a century." The disease is spreading westward across Germany and threatening neighboring countries.

Mrs. Gloria Vanderbilt Stokowski said last night that she had separated from her husband, Leopold Stokowski, internationally known symphony conductor. They were married in April, 1945, when she was 21 years old and he 58.

Dr. J. Robert Oppenheimer, the atomic scientist, will discuss his background, philosophy and interests in a filmed conversation to be presented over the Columbia Broadcasting System television network on Tuesday from 10:30 to 11 P. M.
Governor-elect Averell Harriman has not decided as yet whether to ask the Legislature to increase the state income tax to meet mandatory rises in government costs.

Columbia University's 200th anniversary celebration ends today after a year made stimulating and inspirational by its theme, the world-wide scope of participation, the range of special events and publications, the distinction of speakers and the enthusiasm that sustained and supported the year-long program.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- Secretary of State Dulles described as "good" today the news of the French Assembly vote for West Germany's admission to the Western European Union.

Mayor Wagner has adhered to his generally excellent standard of appointments by naming to one of the two vacancies on New York City's Board of Education William J. O'Shea, president of the New York County Lawyers Association and a first-rate citizen of capacity and distinction.

Substantial reductions, effective on Monday, in shipping rates for apparel and accessories was announced yesterday by the Railway Express Agency. The cuts, ranging from 25 to 35 per cent, will affect retailers' costs and should eventually bring some deduction in consumer prices.

THE Beethoven program conducted by George Szell with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall, with Erica Morini as soloist in the performance of the violin concerto, was inevitably of familiar music.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- National Airlines said today that Eastern Air Lines' employes and stockholders probably held 57,570 shares of Colonial Airlines stock instead of some 15,000 shares so identified by Eastern.

HANOI, Vietnam, Dec. 30 -- The Vietminh Government has just undertaken to widen its base by adding four Communist leaders from the south to the Cabinet. These leaders have just reached Hanoi under the population transfer that was approved in the Geneva accords.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The United States Court of Military Appeals upheld today the conviction of Mrs. Dorothy K. Smith for the premeditated murder of her husband, Col. Aubrey D. Smith.

TUGBOATS that churn past 10 Gracie Square almost always salute the slender gray-haired lady who spends a good part of her time from dawn to dusk, and sometimes even after sundown, painting on the third-floor terrace there.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- A judge of the Federal District Court ruled today that a company could discharge employes who invoked the Fifth Amendment in refusing to answer Congressional inquiries into their political affiliations.
The break between Capt. William V. Bradley, president of the International Longshoremen's Association, and the tugboat men he used to head became complete yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- The Department of Agriculture's security chief has suggested that Russian-born Wolf Ladejinsky's anti-Communist writings were a factor in labeling him a security risk.
The largest private shipping deal in the nation's maritime history has been arranged between the American President Lines and the Federal Maritime Board.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- George Meany, president of the American Federation of Labor, called on the Government today to undertake a big program of school, hospital and highway construction to provide jobs and give the economy a lift.
BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Dr. Vannevar Bush said tonight that the danger to our freedoms and institutions was greater from at home than from overseas.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- A United States District Court judge questioned today whether divided opinions of the Supreme Court were to be regarded as "controlling precedents" on lower courts.

Continued "persuasion" will be used in an effort to eliminate racial discrimination at sixteen Southern law schools. This method was decided on by the Association of American Law Schools at the session at the Biltmore Hotel yesterday that ended its fifty-fourth annual meeting.

For the second time in five weeks, the 120-member wage scale committee of the International Longshoremen's Association approved yesterday a contract designed to bring peace to the strike-groggy waterfront.

It begins to appear that operators of ski developments in Vermont's Green Mountains will be able to look back on one of the most successful Decembers in years. This point virtually was made certain yesterday when reports from Vermont indicated a fine week-end of sport.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Post Office Department today decided to stop the delivery of "junk mail."
John Wanamaker has decided to keep its branch store at Great Neck, L. I., and its projected unit in Cross County Center in Yonkers.

MOSCOW, Dec. 30 -- Almost any day at any time on any street in any part of Moscow at this season there is a man going home with a small fir tree over his shoulder. Quite often an excited boy trots beside him.

Miss Diane Carroll Jones was hohored at jarge dinner dance last night in the St, Regis Roof and Penthouse. The dance was given by her stepfather and mother, Mr. and Mrs. James Lowell Oakes Jr. of 1021 Park Avenue.

Five Asian states, three of them members of the British Commonwealth, have decided to call a meeting of Asian and African nations next spring. Indonesia, the host nation, will extend the invitations to about twenty-five countries for a meeting at the ministerial level to discuss problems of common interest.
Harassed librarians revealed yesterday that rabid puzzle contestants had inflicted thousands of dollars of damage upon New York reference collections in the last fortnight.

Some of the young students of the New York School for Nursery Years have been putting in considerable "overtime" recently. With their parents they have been coming back to school on week-ends. Their purpose: To help the energetic staff put final touches to rooms remodeled for small fry purposes from the stately salons of the Margaret Carnegie Miller mansion, 2 East Ninetieth Street.

MONTREAL, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Maurice (The Rocket) Richard scored three goals in one game for the twenty-second time in his National Hockey League career tonight to lead the Montreal Canadiens to a 7-4 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks.

WHEN I was a boy I always found something comforting in romantic adventure stories written in the first person singular. No matter how grave the odds against John Ridd, hero of "Lorna Doone," no matter how unlikely the possibility that Robinson Crusoe would escape from his island, I always knew that everything would turn out well.
AFTER concentrating on his work for some time Truman Capote has emerged from his library with a musical about a bordello, "House of Flowers," which opened at the Alvin last evening.
WEST POINT, N. Y., Dec. 30 -- The Corps of Cadets is pulling for a Navy victory against Mississippi in the Sugar Bowl.
PARIS, Dec. 30 -- Premier Pierre Mendes-France succeeded in maintaining his majority largely intact in this evening's final and crucial vote of 287 to 260 to arm the West Germans.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (UP) -- The Un-American Activities Committee of the House of Representatives voted today to drop contempt proceedings against Dr. Wilbur Lee Mahaney Jr., former Philadelphia high school teacher and admitted former Communist.
ALBANY, Dec. 30 -- The State Board of Law Examiners today announced the names of 479 applicants who passed the examination for admission to the bar, held last Nov. 4 and 5.

In another look at policies pursued by the Soviet Union in the Grand Alliance of World War II, historians agreed yesterday that the Russians knew what they wanted, but the goals of the United States and Great Britain were less clear.

Rising populations in the "Golden Empire" served by the Southern Pacific Company has made it necessary for the railroad to invest more than $400,000,000 in transportation property in the last five years to keep up with the growth of the territory it serves, D. J. Russell, president, said in a year-end review yesterday.

NAVY had upset Army, 27 to 20, but the margin of superiority was far from overwhelming. There even were some observers who believed that there was no manifestation of superiority at all. One chap who was afflicted by that nagging doubt decided to put the question bluntly to Eddie Erdelatz, the middie coach, who is in the habit of giving blunt answers himself.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The Federal Court of Appeals upheld today a lower court ruling that the Government had the right to evict tenants from Shanks Village, near Orangeburg, N. Y.

The large foundations are indignant over the majority report of the House Committee to Investigate Tax Exempt Foundations, which found that some "have actively supported attacks upon our social and governmental system and financed the promotion of socialism and collectivist ideas."

DETROIT, Dec. 30 (UP) -- Gordie Howe rapped in a pair of first-period goals tonight to lead Detroit to a 4-1 National Hockey League victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs and become the greatest goal-getter in Red Wings history.
DALLAS, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Four persons, headed by Mrs. Mildred (Babe) Didrikson Zaharias and Sammy Baugh, today were named to the Texas Sports Hall of Fame.

OTTAWA, Dec. 30 -- Approval by France of the West European Union, which will place 500,000 German troops in the ranks of the Western allies, was greeted, here today by the Canadian Government with considerable relief.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Secretary of Agriculture Ezra T. Benson today ordered a referendum among rice producers on Jan. 28 to determine whether marketing quotas shall be established for the 1955 crop.
LONDON, Dec. 30 -- A leader of the National Union of Railwaymen told a court of inquiry today that the only way members of the union could obtain elementary justice was by striking.

Fordham yesterday won the championship of the National Intercollegiate Chess League being held at John Jay Hall, Columbia, with a score of 21 -- 7. The Rams thus gained custody of the Harold M, Phillips Trophy for two years.
New groups went into the lead yesterday as the stock market milled about in indeterminate fashion and closed with virtually no change.
Thousands of New York churchgoers will shun for a few hours tonight the material frivolities of New Year's Eve.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- During the week ended yesterday, the Federal Reserve Board reported today, member bank reserves decreased $134,000,000.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- The open quarrel between the Departments of State and Agriculture in the case of Wolf Ladejinsky continued today with a repudiation by R. W. Scott McLeod, State's security officer, of a statement made by Milan D. Smith of Agriculture that McLeod concurred in the latter department's decision that Ladejinsky is a security risk.

BERKELEY, Calif., Dec. 30 -- Development of a new high vacuum technology has made possible the creation of a vacuum as low as one quadrillionth of an atmosphere. This is a hundred thousand times greater than the highest vacuums produced until now.
Ella Fitzgerald, Negro singer, and three associates filed a $270,000 damage suit yesterday in Federal Court against Pan American World Airways, Inc., charging racial discrimination.

Louis Schleiffer, real estate operator who specializes in the purchase of hotels, has contracted to buy the Lexington Hotel at the southeast corner of Lexington Avenue and Forty-eighth Street. The seller is the Hotel Lexington, Inc., of which Charles E. Rochester is president.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 30 -- There were two reactions in Washington today to the French ratification of the Paris agreements -- the official reaction and the true reaction.

NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 -- The Indian chairman of the International Armistice Commission for Vietnam said today that the Communist leader, Ho Chi Minhm, was "the symbol of nationalism" in both parts of divided Vietnam.
NEW DELHI, India, Dec. 30 -- The Government announced today what officials regard as a substantial liberalization of imports for the first six months of 1955.
ALBANY, Dec. 30--Governor Dewey moved out of the Executive Mansion and cleaned out his desk in the Capitol today preparatory to leaving office at midnight tomorrow.

LONDON, Dec. 30 -- The advance in the stock markets continued today with prices rising in nearly all sections except Government funds and South African gold minings. Buying was still selective but showed signs of broadening despite the railway strike threat.

The Hill School hockey team defeated the St. Mark's School sextet, 2 -- 0, at Madison Square Garden yesterday. The contest, played for the benefit of the scholarship funds of the two schools, attracted about 2,500 spectators.

A lingering echo of Columbia University's bicentennial celebration was heard yesterday at the closing session of the fifty-eighth annual convention of the College Physical Education Association. The year-long bicentennial observance ended last Sunday.
A two-car collision on a rain-swept thoroughfare in Ozone Park, Queens, shortly after midnight last night took the lives of three persons, including a 7-year-old boy.

No American industry looks forward with greater confidence to the coming year than the retail food industry, Louis Stein, president of Food Fair Stores, Inc., declared yesterday in a year-end statement.
DETROIT, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Harlow H. Curtice, president of General Motors Corporation, said today he believed 1955 "will be an excellent year for American business."

CLEVELAND, Dec. 30 (AP) -- Industrialist Cyrus Eaton predicted today 1955 would be "busy and prosperous" for America. But he added that any continuing prosperity would depend on "Governmental reform to restore true free enterprise.

The Metropolitan Rapid Transit Commission has urged the Interstate Commerce Commission to defer decision on the applications of railroads to discontinue commuter ferry services between New Jersey and Manhattan.

Jack Gilford and Sylvia Short were signed yesterday for the leading featured roles in "The Passion of Gross," a new play by Harold Levitt, which will have its New York premiere Jan. 18 at the Theatre de Lys.

A wild car chase of the cinematic variety startled midtown holiday crowds late yesterday, afternoon. It ended as two radio car patrolmen captured at gun-point three bandits who had just robbed a West Side ticket agency.
A former employe of a Fifth Avenue shoe store yesterday snatched a bag holding $5,011 in cash and checks from two present employes of the concern, the police said.

LONDON, Dec. 31 -- Diamonds, believed to be part of a consignment valued at 800,000 to 1,000,000 ($2,224,000 and $2,800,000) were recovered today in and around the remains of an airliner that crashed and burned at Prestwick Saturday. Most of them were discolored by the heat.

DETROIT, Dec. 31 (AP) -- Directors of the Briggs Manufacturing Company have recommended that the company's authorized capital be increased to 2,000,000 shares of $3.50 par value stock and that each of the 408,969 outstanding shares of non-par value be redeemed with three of the new shares.
